0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	0	Evidence That Endoplasmic Reticulum (ER)-associated Degradation of Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator Is Linked to Retrograde Translocation from the ER Membrane* Ximing Xiong, Elaine Chong, and William R.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Department of Molecular and Cellular Engineering and Department of Medicine, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania 19104.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	2	    ABSTRACT Top Abstract Introduction References.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	3	The ubiquitin-proteasome pathway has been implicated in the degradation of newly synthesized, misfolded and unassembled proteins in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Using a cell-free reticulocyte lysate system we have examined the relationship between biosynthesis and ER-associated degradation of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR), a polytopic protein with 12 predicted transmembrane segments.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Our results provide direct evidence that full-length, glycosylated and membrane-integrated CFTR is a substrate for degradation and that degradation involves polyubiquitination and cytosolic proteolytic activity.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	6	 CFTR ubiquitination was both temperature- and ATP-dependent.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Degradation was significantly inhibited by EDTA, apyrase, and the proteasome inhibitors hemin and MG132.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Degradation was inhibited to a lesser extent by clasto-lactacystin -lactone, ALLN, and N-tosyl-L-phenylalanine chloromethyl ketone and was relatively unaffected by lactacystin and N-tosyl lysyl chloromethyl ketone.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	9	 In the presence of hemin, polyubiquitinated CFTR remained tightly associated with ER microsomes.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	10	 However, membrane-bound ubiquitinated CFTR could be subsequently degraded into trichloroacetic acid-soluble fragments upon incubation in hemin-free, ATP-containing lysate.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Thus ER-associated degradation of CFTR occurs via a membrane-bound, rather than cytosolic, intermediate and likely involves recruitment of degradation machinery to the ER membrane.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Our data suggest a model in which the degradation of polytopic proteins such as CFTR is coupled to retrograde translocation and removal of the polypeptide from the lipid bilayer.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	13	     INTRODUCTION Top Abstract Introduction References.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	14	The rough endoplasmic reticulum (ER)1 facilitates translocation, membrane integration, folding, and oligomeric assembly of most proteins found in the secretory pathway of eukaryotic cells (1-4).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The ER also functions to recognize misfolded or unassembled proteins and prevent their exit to the Golgi complex (5-7) through a process termed ER-associated degradation (ERAD) (8).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Substrates for ERAD, like other secretory and transmembrane proteins, are initially targeted to and translocated across the ER membrane via the Sec61 translocon complex (1, 2).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	17	 However, aberrantly folded proteins are selectively translocated back into the cytosol where they undergo ubiquitination and degradation by cytosolic proteases (9-11).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Certain ERAD substrates such as major histocompatibility complex class I heavy chains (10, 12, 13) and unglycosylated prepro- factor undergo complete retrograde translocation into a soluble, cytosolic form prior to degradation (8).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	19	 In contrast, mutant forms of carboxypeptidase Y and unassembled T cell receptor  subunits translocate back to the cytosol but remain associated with cytoplasmic face of the ER membrane (14, 15).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	20	 In both cases the generation of cytosolic intermediates is thought to occur via retrograde transport through the Sec61 translocon complex (9-11).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	21	The ubiquitin-proteasome pathway is also involved in the ER-associated degradation of polytopic proteins.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Yeast mutants with defective ubiquitin-conjugating enzymes or proteasome subunits show decreased degradation of mutant forms of Sec61p (16, 17), a resident ER protein with 10 predicted transmembrane segments (18).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	23	 ERAD may also play a role in ensuring proper protein levels in the ER as suggested by mevalonate-mediated regulation of 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-coenzyme A reductase (19-21).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	24	 For the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR), a plasma membrane protein, approximately 80% of wild type protein and 100% of common mutant forms are degraded prior to reaching the Golgi complex (22, 23).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Recent studies have demonstrated that ER-associated degradation of CFTR also requires an intact ubiquitin conjugation pathway and likely involves the 26 S proteasome (24, 25).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	26	 While the underlying reasons for CFTR degradation remain unknown, it has been proposed that the majority of wild type CFTR, like mutant CFTR, is recognized by ER quality control machinery, because it fails to fold properly (26-29).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	27	Degradation of polytopic proteins by cytosolic proteases poses a particular problem in that multiple transmembrane (TM) segments must be removed from the membrane.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	28	 It is unclear whether polytopic proteins, like secretory and bitopic transmembrane proteins, proceed through cytosolic intermediates prior to degradation.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	29	 One possibility is that the proteasome might degrade only cytosolic peptide loops, leaving lumenal and/or transmembrane segments to be degraded by other proteases (7, 30).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Alternatively, degradation might be coupled to the process of retrograde translocation.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	31	 To distinguish among these possibilities, it will be necessary to define the temporal relationship between recognition, retrograde translocation, and degradation events involved in polytopic protein ER degradation.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	32	 In this regard, a cell-free system that reconstitutes ERAD is attractive, because it is readily amenable to physical and pharmacological manipulation.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Using such a system, Sato et al.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	34	 (31) recently demonstrated that CFTR could be ubiquitinated cotranslationally, indicating that initial recognition events in ER degradation might occur very early in the lifetime of a polytopic protein.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	35	 In the current study we use a similar cell free system to demonstrate that CFTR ubiquitination can also occur after protein synthesis, N-linked glycosylation, and membrane integration have been completed.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	36	 We have also been able to separate the process of ubiquitination from that of degradation and now show that ubiquitinated CFTR remains tightly associated with the ER membrane until it is degraded into trichloroacetic acid-soluble peptide fragments.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	37	 CFTR degradation is therefore physically localized to the ER.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Our results are consistent with a model in which cytosolic degradation machinery is recruited to the ER membrane by polyubiquitinated substrates and suggest that degradation occurs coincident with polypeptide removal from the lipid bilayer.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	39	Materials-- ALLN, TPCK, TLCK, hemin, bovine ubiquitin, anti-bovine ubiquitin antibody, and 14C-methylated lysozyme were purchased from Sigma.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The protease inhibitor mixture, (4-(2-aminoethyl)benzenesulfonyl fluoride, aprotinin, E-64, EDTA, and leupeptin), MG132, lactacystin, and clasto-lactacystin -lactone were purchased from Calbiochem.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Nucleotide triphosphates, creatine phosphate, creatine kinase, and dithiothreitol (DTT) were purchased from Boehringer Mannheim.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Anti-CFTR antisera was raised against synthetic peptides corresponding to residues 45-65 (N terminus), 680-700 (R domain), and 1458-1476 (C terminus) (BAbCo, Berkeley, CA).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Other regents were purchased from Sigma unless otherwise stated.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	44	Rabbit reticulocyte lysate for translation was prepared from fresh rabbit reticulocytes induced by acetylphenylhydrazine treatment as described previously (32) and stored at 80  degrees C.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Prior to freezing, hemin was added to a final concentration of 40  microM.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	46	 For degradation experiments, RRL was either purchased from Green Hectare Farm (Oregon, WI) or prepared as described previously (32) but without addition of hemin.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Although degradation efficiency varied between different preparations of RRL, no consistent differences were observed between different RRL sources.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	48	 To prepare ATP-depleted RRL, reticulocytes were washed three times with ice-cold phosphate-buffered saline, resuspended in Krebs-Ringer phosphate medium lacking glucose, and incubated in 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	49	2 mM 2,4-dinitrophenol and 20 mM 2-deoxyglucose at 37  degrees C for 90 min (33).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Reticulocytes were then washed twice with phosphate-buffered saline and lysed by adding 1.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Samples were centrifuged at 15,000 rpm for 30 min (Beckman JA17 rotor), and the supernatant (i.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	52	 RRL) was stored at 80  degrees C.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	53	Methylated ubiquitin was prepared by reductive methylation as described previously (34).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Bovine ubiquitin was incubated at room temperature for 20 h in 12 mM formaldehyde and 20 mM cyanoborohydride followed by an additional hour in fresh reagents.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The reaction was dialyzed for 48 h in 10 mM HEPES, 5 mM MgCl2, 3 mM DTT and concentrated to 10 mg/ml using a centricon (number 3) filter.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	56	Cell-free Transcription/Translation-- CFTR mRNA was transcribed in vitro at 40  degrees C for 1 h in reactions containing 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	57	4 mg/ml plasmid DNA (plasmid pSPCFTR(35)), 40 mM Tris (pH 7.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	58	5 mM GpppG (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech), 10 mM DTT, 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	59	75 unit/ml RNase inhibitor (Promega, Madison, WI), and 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	60	4 unit/ml SP6 RNA polymerase (New England Biolabs, Beverly, MA).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Transcript was stored frozen at 80  degrees C.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Translation was performed at 24-25  degrees C for 2 h in a reaction containing 20% transcription mixture, 40% nuclease-treated rabbit reticulocyte lysate, 20% Emix, and a final concentration of 400  microg/ml creatine kinase, 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	63	2  microl of RNAse inhibitor (Promega), 10 mM Tris (pH 7.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	64	5), 100 mM KOAc, 2 mM MgCl2, and 2 mM DTT.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Emix contains 5 mM ATP, 5 mM GTP, 60 mM creatine phosphate, 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	66	2 mM each of 19 essential amino acids, except methionine, and 5  microCi/ microl of Tran35S-label (ICN Pharmaceuticals, Irvine CA).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Canine pancreas microsomal membranes, prepared as described elsewhere (36), were added at the start of translation to a final concentration of A280 8.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	68	 For all experiments except those in Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	69	 1A, aurin tricarboxylic acid (0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	70	1 mM) was added to the translation mixture after 15 min to synchronize translation and reduce synthesis of partial length chains.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	71	 For membrane pelleting and floatation experiments puromycin HCl (final concentration 1 mM) was added at T = 110 min to ensure that nascent chains were released from ribosomes.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	72	Carbonate Extraction-- Translation products were incubated in 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	73	5) for 30 min on ice as described (37).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Samples were centrifuged at 180,000  x  g for 30 min, and membrane pellets were dissolved directly in SDS loading buffer.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Supernatants were precipitated in 20% trichloroacetic acid, pelleted at 16,000  x  g for 15 min, washed with acetone, and dissolved in SDS loading buffer.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	76	Immunoprecipitation-- RRL aliquots were diluted directly into 1 ml of ice-cold Buffer A (0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	77	1 M NaCl, 1% Triton X-100, 2 mM EDTA, 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	78	1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, and 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	79	0)) and preincubated with antisera for 10-30 min prior to addition of 5  microl of protein A Affi-Gel (Bio-Rad).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	80	 CFTR antisera and nonimmune antisera were used at 1:1000 dilution.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Ubiquitin antibody was used at 1:200 dilution (similar amounts of Ig were present in all reactions).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Samples were mixed at 4  degrees C for 6-10 h, washed three times with Buffer A, twice with 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	83	0), and taken up in SDS loading buffer.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	84	Degradation Assay-- The translation mixture was layered onto a 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	85	1 M KCl, 5 mM MgCl2, and 1 mM DTT) and centrifuged at 180,000  x  g for 10 min.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Membranes were resuspended in ice-cold 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	87	1 M KCl, 5 mM MgCl2, and 1 mM DTT) at one-half the original translation volume.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	88	 The degradation reaction, assembled on ice, included 20% resuspended membranes, 72% reticulocyte lysate, and a final concentration of 10 mM Tris (pH 7.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	89	5), 1 mM ATP, 5 mM MgCl2, 12 mM creatine phosphate, 3 mM DTT, and 80  microg/ml of creatine kinase.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Where indicated, RRL was replaced with water, and proteasome inhibitors were added.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	91	 For ATP-depleted RRL, ATP and creatine phosphate were omitted.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	92	 The degradation mixture was incubated at 37  degrees C, and aliquots were added directly to loading buffer for SDS-PAGE, EnHance (NEN Life Sceince Products) fluorography and autoradiography.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Autoradiograms were scanned on an AGFA studioscan II transmission scanner using Adobe Photoshop software.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Quantitation of autoradiograms was performed using an Amersham Pharmacia Biotech DTS scanning densitometer precalibrated with a Kodak photographic step tablet (Eastman Kodak Co.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Trichloroacetic acid-soluble counts were quantitated by precipitating degradation mixture in 20% trichloroacetic acid, incubating on ice for 30 min, pelleting at 16,000  x  g for 15 min, and counting supernatants in 10 volumes of Ready Safe scintillation fluid (Beckman, Fullerton, CA) in a Beckman LS6500 scintillation counter.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	96	Vesicle Pelleting and Floatation-- Microsomal membranes from translation mixture were pelleted, resuspended, and incubated in ATP- containing RRL in the presence of 40  microM hemin as described above.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	97	 For pelleting experiments, aliquots of this RRL/hemin mixture were taken at specified time points; KCl or Triton X-100 was added as indicated; the mixture was incubated on ice for 30 min and pelleted through 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Equivalent fractions of pellet and supernatant (resuspended directly in SDS loading buffer) were analyzed by SDS-PAGE.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	99	 For floatation experiments, aliquots of the RRL/hemin mixture were diluted into 10 volumes of 2.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	100	5), 5 mM MgCl2, 1 mM DTT, or into 2.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	101	 100- microl samples were incubated on ice for 30 min and overlaid with 300  microl of 1.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	102	1 M KCl, 4 mM MgCl2, 10 mM Tris (pH 7.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	103	5), and 1 mM DTT and then overlaid with 200  microl of 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Solutions were centrifuged at 350,000  x  g for 2 h in a TLA 100.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	105	 55- microl aliquots were taken from top to bottom, mixed with 180  microl of 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	106	1 M sucrose buffer, and samples were repelleted at 170,000  x  g for 10 min prior to addition of SDS loading buffer and autoradiography.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	107	In Vitro CFTR Biogenesis-- To examine the steps of CFTR degradation in native ER membranes, we first characterized expression of full-length CFTR protein in a cell-free RRL system.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Translation of plasmid pSPCFTR (35) in the absence of ER-derived microsomal membranes generated a polypeptide migrating at ~160 kDa (Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	109	 This translation product shifted 6 kDa in size when rough microsomes were added at the start of translation, consistent with the addition of two N-linked core carbohydrates at the predicted consensus sites in the fourth extracytoplasmic loop.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	110	 The presence of full-length CFTR was confirmed by immunoprecipitation with peptide-specific antisera raised against N terminus, R domain, and C terminus epitopes.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Carbonate extraction of translation products demonstrated that in vitro synthesized CFTR was fully integrated into the ER membrane.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Thus the RRL system is capable of efficiently reconstituting the early events of CFTR biosynthesis and processing, in agreement with results reported by Sato et al.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	113	 To test the stability of newly synthesized CFTR in the ER membrane, cyclohexamide was added after 2 h of translation, and samples were incubated for an additional 4 h (Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	114	 At 24  degrees C, CFTR was remarkably stable, whereas at 37  degrees C CFTR was rapidly converted into a high molecular weight (HMW) complex with an estimated size of  > 450 kDa (T1/2  < 30 min).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	115	 For convenience, this large complex will subsequently be referred to as the HMW complex, and the ~170 kDa band will be referred to as full-length CFTR.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	116	View larger version (93K):    Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	117	   Expression of CFTR in rabbit reticulocyte lysate.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	118	 A, CFTR cDNA (plasmid pSPCFTR(35)) was translated in a transcription-linked RRL translation system at 24  degrees C for 90 min as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	119	" Canine pancreas microsomal membranes were present during translation in all lanes except lane 1.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Lanes 1, 2, and 7 represent total translation products analyzed by SDS-PAGE.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Translation products were immunoprecipitated with nonimmune sera (lane 6) or with peptide-specific antisera raised against the N terminus (lane 3), R domain (lane 4) or C terminus (lane 5) of CFTR.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	122	 For carbonate extraction, translation products (lane 7) were incubated at pH 7.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	123	5 (Carb), and supernatant (S) and pellet (P) fractions were analyzed directly.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	124	 B, CFTR translation was carried out as in A except that aurin tricarboxylic acid (0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	125	1 mM) and cyclohexamide were added 15 min and 2 h after the start of translation, respectively.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Following addition of cyclohexamide, aliquots were removed at the specified time points and analyzed directly by SDS-PAGE.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	127	ATP-dependent Conversion of CFTR into a HMW Complex-- To determine the requirements for conversion of CFTR into the HMW complex, CFTR was translated in RRL, and microsomal membranes were collected by pelleting through a sucrose cushion (Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Microsomes were then resuspended and incubated at 37  degrees C in sucrose buffer containing ATP (lanes 1-5), RRL supplemented with an ATP regeneration system (lanes 6-10), ATP-depleted RRL (lanes 11-15), or ATP-depleted RRL supplemented with additional ATP (lanes 15-20).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	129	 At specified time points samples were analyzed directly by SDS-PAGE.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	130	 In the presence of buffer alone, or in ATP-depleted RRL,  > 70% of full-length CFTR remained intact after 4 h of incubation (Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	131	 However, when microsomal membranes were incubated in fresh RRL containing ATP, or in ATP-depleted RRL supplemented with additional ATP, full-length CFTR was rapidly converted into the HMW complex (T1/2  <  30 min) that subsequently disappeared over the next 4 h.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	132	 These results are consistent with a two-step process in which full-length CFTR is initially converted into a HMW complex via an ATP-dependent mechanism, and the HMW complex is then a substrate for degradation.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	133	View larger version (51K):    Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	134	   In vitro degradation of CFTR via a HMW intermediate.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	135	 A, CFTR was translated for 2 h in RRL (as in Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	136	 1B), after which microsomal membranes were pelleted through a 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	137	5 M sucrose cushion and resuspended in 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	138	1 M sucrose buffer as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	139	" Membranes were then incubated at 37  degrees C in buffer (lanes 1-5), RRL containing an ATP regeneration system (lanes 6-10), ATP-depleted RRL (lanes 11-15), or ATP-depleted RRL containing an ATP regeneration system (lanes 16-20).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	140	 At specified time points, aliquots were removed from each tube and analyzed directly by SDS-PAGE.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	141	 B, autoradiograms were digitized, and band intensities of full-length CFTR and the HMW complex were quantitated, normalized to the amount of full-length CFTR present at T = 0, and plotted for each time point.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Closed and open symbols represent CFTR and the HMW complex, respectively.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	143	The CFTR HMW Complex Is Polyubiquitinated-- We noted that degradation of the CFTR HMW complex in Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	144	 2 contrasted with results in Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	145	 1B where the complex accumulated over time.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	146	 One difference between these two experiments is that CFTR translation is performed in the presence of hemin, a required co-factor for protein expression in RRL (38), and aurin tricarboxylic acid, an inhibitor of protein synthesis initiation.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Both of these compounds inhibit ATP-dependent degradation of ubiquitinated substrates in RRL.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	148	 These results, together with the requirement for ATP and cytosol, suggested that the HMW complex might represent polyubiquitinated CFTR.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Microsomal membranes containing newly synthesized CFTR were therefore incubated in fresh RRL supplemented with bovine ubiquitin and 40  microM hemin.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Aliquots were then immunoprecipitated with anti-bovine ubiquitin antisera and analyzed by SDS-PAGE at specified time points.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	151	 3A, the HMW complex, but not full-length CFTR, was reactive against anti-ubiquitin antisera (lanes 11-15).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	152	 No reactivity was observed when immunoprecipitation was performed with nonimmune sera (NIS, lanes 6-10) or when bovine ubiquitin was omitted from the lysate (data not shown).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	153	 To further confirm CFTR ubiquitination, microsomes containing newly synthesized CFTR were incubated in RRL in the presence of methylated ubiquitin, which blocks the sequential addition of ubiquitin molecules by preventing isopeptide bond formation at ubiquitin residue Lys-48.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Under these conditions we observed a dose-dependent inhibition in the rate of HMW complex formation (Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Taken together, these data demonstrate that the sequential, covalent addition of multiple ubiquitin molecules contributes to the formation of the CFTR HMW complex.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	156	View larger version (91K):    Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	157	   In vitro ubiquitination of CFTR.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Microsomal membranes containing newly synthesized CFTR were resuspended in 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	159	1 M sucrose buffer and incubated at 37  degrees C in RRL containing 40  microM hemin and 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	160	4 mg/ml of bovine ubiquitin (A) or methylated ubiquitin (B).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	161	 At times indicated, samples were immunoprecipitated with nonimmune sera (NIS; A, lanes 6-10), anti-ubiquitin antisera (A, lanes 11-15), or analyzed directly (A, lanes 1-5 and B, all lanes).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	162	Inhibition of CFTR HMW Complex Degradation by Proteasome Inhibitors-- We next examined the ability of protease inhibitors to influence the disappearance of the CFTR HMW complex.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Inhibitors of serine, cysteine, and metalloproteases had essentially no effect on the rate of disappearance of either full-length CFTR or the HMW complex (Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	164	 In contrast, hemin and MG132, both known inhibitors of the proteasome, resulted in significant delay in the disappearance of the HMW complex particularly at early time points (Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Quantitation of autoradiograms revealed that hemin effectively blocked 60% of HMW complex degradation.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	166	 In contrast, MG132, ALLN, and TPCK slowed but did not prevent HMW complex disappearance.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Surprisingly, little inhibition was observed for lactacystin or TLCK.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	168	 These results suggested either that certain proteasome inhibitors might be relatively inactive in the RRL system, or alternatively, that degradation of ubiquitinated CFTR might involve additional protease activities.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	169	 To distinguish between these possibilities, we therefore examined the effect of proteasome inhibitors on the degradation of methylated lysozyme, a known substrate of the 26 S proteasome.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	170	 For these and subsequent experiments the rate and extent of protein degradation was quantitated by measuring the conversion of CFTR and/or lysozyme into trichloroacetic acid-soluble peptide fragments.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	171	View larger version (66K):    Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	172	   Effect of protease inhibitors on CFTR degradation.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Microsomal membranes containing newly synthesized CFTR were collected and incubated in RRL in the presence of a protease inhibitor mixture consisting of 500  microM 4-(2-aminoethyl)benzenesulfonyl fluoride, 150 nM aprotinin, 1  microM E-64, 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	174	5 mM EDTA and 1  microM leupeptin (A) or in individual proteasome inhibitors at the indicated concentrations (B).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	175	 At each time point, aliquots were mixed directly with SDS loading buffer and analyzed by PAGE.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	176	 C, CFTR and the HMW complex were quantitated at each time point by densitometry, normalized to the amount of CFTR present at T = 0, and plotted as a function of time.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Data shown are representative of results from multiple experiments.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	178	 5, 26% of [14C]lysozyme and 65% of newly synthesized CFTR were degraded into trichloroacetic acid-soluble peptide fragments within 3 h in RRL.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Lysozyme degradation was inhibited by approximately 90% in the presence of 40  microM hemin or 10 mM EDTA consistent with previous studies (39).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Hemin also resulted in formation of a HMW complex containing [14C]lysozyme (data not shown).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	181	 In contrast, the specific proteasome inhibitor lactacystin, as well as its active metabolite clasto-lactacystin -lactone, had little effect on lysozyme degradation ( < 10% inhibition).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Under these same conditions CFTR degradation was inhibited by approximately 80% in the presence of EDTA or the ATP hydrolyzing enzyme, apyrase.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Hemin inhibited CFTR degradation by 56%, while lactacystin and clasto-lactacystin -lactone inhibited CFTR degradation by only 20 and 35%, respectively.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	184	 In these latter experiments, lactacystin-based inhibitors were preincubated with RRL for 30-60 min prior to addition of CFTR-containing microsomal membranes.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	185	 These experiments demonstrate that specific lactacystin-based proteasome inhibitors are relatively inactive at blocking degradation of these ubiquitinated substrates in RRL.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	186	 It should also be noted that a significant amount of CFTR degradation in RRL (35-40%) appears to proceed through a hemin insensitive pathway distinct from that utilized by lysozyme.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	187	View larger version (22K):    Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	188	   Degradation of lysozyme and CFTR.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Degradation mixtures were assembled as described in the legend to Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	190	 2 and added to resuspended microsomal membranes containing CFTR or [14C]lysozyme (0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Hemin (40  microM), EDTA (10 mM), or apyrase (0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	192	1 unit/ microl) was added at T = 0 as indicated.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Lactacystin (100  microM) or clasto-lactacystin -lactone (100  microM) were preincubated with RRL for 30-60 min prior to assembling the reaction.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Aliquots were precipitated in 20% trichloroacetic acid, and soluble counts were calculated by the following formula: % counts released = (Cn  C0)/(T  C0), where Cn = soluble counts at each time point, C0 = soluble counts at T = 0, and T = total counts per aliquot.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Results represent the average ( plus or minus S.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	196	) of two to six separate experiments.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	197	Ubiquitinated CFTR Remains Tightly Associated with the ER Membrane-- Sixty-five percent of in vitro synthesized CFTR protein was degraded to trichloroacetic acid-soluble fragments within 3 h of incubation in RRL (Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Degradation could not be restricted solely to large cytosolic peptide loops (i.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	199	 N terminus, nucleotide binding domains, and the R-domain), as these loops contain only 47% of total methionine residues (40).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Rather, our data indicate that proteolytic machinery also gains access to small cytosolic loops and possibly lumenal and/or transmembrane regions of the protein.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Thus prior to or coincident with degradation, some or all of CFTR is likely to be extracted from the membrane.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	202	 We therefore tested whether the ubiquitinated HMW complex, which has already been targeted for degradation by ubiquitin-conjugating enzymes, might undergo retrograde translocation to a cytosolic intermediate.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Ubiquitinated CFTR complexes were generated by incubation in RRL (in the presence of hemin), and vesicles were collected by pelleting through a sucrose cushion.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	204	 6A, both CFTR and the CFTR HMW complex were nearly quantitatively recovered in the microsome pellet in the absence of detergent.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	205	 In addition, preincubation of CFTR-containing microsomes in high salt (up to 1.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	206	1 M KCl) failed to extract full-length CFTR or the HMW complex into the supernatant fraction (Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Thus ubiquitinated CFTR does not behave as a cytosolic or peripheral membrane protein.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	208	View larger version (74K):    Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	209	 CFTR-containing microsomes were incubated in RRL in the presence of hemin.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	210	 A, at times specified, aliquots were analyzed directly (lanes 1-4), pelleted through 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	211	5 M sucrose buffer (lanes 5-9), or incubated on ice in 1% Triton X-100 for 30 min prior to pelleting (lanes 10-14).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Pellets were dissolved directly into SDS loading buffer.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	213	 B, aliquots of RRL degradation mixture were taken at specified times and analyzed directly in SDS loading buffer (lanes 1-3) or incubated for 30 min on ice following addition of KCl to the final concentrations indicated (lanes 4-21).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Samples were then pelleted through 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	215	5 M sucrose buffer, and equal fractions of pellet and supernatant were analyzed by SDS-PAGE.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	216	 6 do not rule out the possibility that HMW ubiquitinated CFTR might also be pelleted as a large, detergent-sensitive protein complex.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	217	 We therefore tested whether the HMW complex was physically associated with the ER by membrane floatation.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Aliquots of RRL containing newly synthesized CFTR and/or polyubiquitinated CFTR were diluted into 2 M sucrose, layered beneath a discontinuous sucrose gradient, and centrifuged for 2 h as described under "Experimental Procedures" (Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	219	 For half of the samples, ribosomes were first stripped from membranes by incubation in KCl/EDTA (Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	220	 The secretory protein bovine prolactin (41) was used as a standard to determine the location of microsomal membranes in the gradient.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Both full-length CFTR and the polyubiquitinated complex exhibited the same floatation pattern as the secretory control.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Thus in the absence of degradation, CFTR remained membrane-associated long after ubiquitination had occurred.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Following ribosome stripping with EDTA/KCl microsomes more uniformly partitioned into the lighter fractions.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	224	 However ribosome removal had no detectable effect on dislocation of ubiquitinated CFTR from the ER membrane.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	225	View larger version (41K):    Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Microsomal membranes containing newly synthesized CFTR or bovine prolactin were incubated at 37  degrees C in RRL degradation mixture for 0, 20, or 120 min in the presence of hemin.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	227	 A, samples were mixed to a final concentration of 2 M sucrose, layered beneath a discontinuous sucrose gradient, and centrifuged at 350,000  x  g for 2 h as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	228	6 M) were added prior to centrifugation.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Aliquots were taken from top to bottom of the gradient (lanes 1-10, respectively).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	230	 The HMW complex, CFTR, and prolactin control are indicated.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	231	Degradation of Membrane-bound, Ubiquitinated CFTR-- To test whether membrane-bound CFTR remained a substrate for degradation and not simply a protease resistant aggregate, CFTR-containing microsomes were incubated in RRL in the presence of hemin to allow accumulation of the ubiquitinated intermediate.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Vesicles were isolated at sequential time points, reincubated in the presence or absence of fresh RRL, and degradation of CFTR was monitored by release of trichloroacetic acid-soluble counts.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	233	 8A, 70% of total CFTR was degraded into trichloroacetic acid soluble counts following 3 h incubation in ATP-containing RRL.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	234	 When vesicles were collected after 20 min of preincubation in hemin-containing RRL and resuspended in fresh RRL lacking hemin, 56% of the total CFTR was subsequently degraded.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	235	 This degradation remained sensitive to both hemin and EDTA.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Incubation of CFTR in hemin-containing RRL for longer periods of time (i.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	237	 1-2 h) resulted in the near complete conversion (~90%) of full-length protein into the HMW complex as in prior experiments (data not shown).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	238	 Even after 2 h of preincubation, 57% of total CFTR protein was still able to be degraded upon removal of hemin.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	239	 In each of these experiments, the degradation of polyubiquitinated CFTR was thus 80% as efficient as the degradation of newly synthesized protein.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Furthermore, with longer preincubation times the reversible component of CFTR degradation became progressively more sensitive to inhibition such that after 2 h of preincubation, hemin and EDTA each blocked degradation of polyubiquitinated CFTR by approximately 90%.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	241	 When microsomes containing pre-ubiquitinated CFTR were similarly resuspended and incubated in the presence of buffer alone (Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	242	 8B), no degradation of the HMW polyubiquitinated CFTR was observed.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	243	View larger version (16K):    Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	244	   Degradation of preubiquitinated CFTR.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	245	 CFTR-containing microsomal membranes were incubated in RRL in the presence of hemin as indicated.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	246	 A, at each time point, samples were pelleted through 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	247	5 M sucrose buffer and resuspended in fresh RRL in the presence or absence of hemin or EDTA.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Aliquots were precipitated in 20% trichloroacetic acid at the indicated times, and percent soluble counts released was determined by scintillation counting.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	249	 B, samples were pelleted through 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	250	5 M sucrose buffer in the presence or absence of 1 mM ATP and resuspended in 10 mM Tris, 5 mM MgCl2, 3 mM DTT, and 80  microg/ml creatine kinase, with or without 1 mM ATP/12 mM creatine phosphate.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Time scale for each graph is based on T = 0 for the starting RRL degradation mixture.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	252	 For T = 20, 60, and 120 min graphs, the base line soluble counts reflect the percent of counts released from RRL in the presence of hemin.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Total trichloroacetic acid-soluble counts plotted therefore represent the counts released during initial incubation plus the counts released following resuspension and reincubation of microsomes.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	254	Together these results demonstrate that: (i) the inhibitory effects of hemin on CFTR degradation are reversible, (ii) most, but not all, of the membrane-bound ubiquitinated CFTR remains a substrate for degradation, (iii) CFTR degradation, like ubiquitination, requires the presence of both ATP and cytosolic factors, and (iv) degradation is physically localized to the ER membrane and likely occurs coincident with removal of at least a portion of CFTR from the lipid bilayer.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	255	The ER is a primary site of cellular quality control involved in the recognition and disposal of misfolded and unassembled proteins (5).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	256	 While it was initially proposed that ER proteases were responsible for degrading ER substrates, recent evidence indicates that ERAD is mediated largely by cytosolic proteases including the 26 S proteasome (6, 7).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	257	 This topologic disparity between substrate and degradation machinery has resulted in a reevaluation of protein movement into and out of the ER compartment (6).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	258	 It now appears that translocation across the ER membrane is a bidirectional process that is regulated, in part, by the folded state of a given protein substrate.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Whereas, nascent secretory and transmembrane proteins are targeted to, translocated across, and/or integrated into the ER membrane by ER translocation machinery (2, 42), proteins that fail to fold properly may also be recognized by ER quality control machinery and transported out of the ER and back to the cytosol (6, 9, 10, 15).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	260	 These observations have raised important questions regarding the process of retrograde transport across the ER membrane.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	261	 At what stage of biogenesis are protein substrates identified? How do recognition events target proteins back to the translocon and/or facilitate movement into the cytosol? And how is this retrograde transport coupled to the process of degradation? In the current study, we address these issues by developing an in vitro system that reconstitutes de novo synthesis and ER-associated degradation of the polytopic protein CFTR.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Full-length, glycosylated and membrane-integrated CFTR was a substrate for ATP-dependent ubiquitination.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	263	 In addition, polyubiquitinated CFTR remained tightly associated with the ER membrane until it was degraded into trichloroacetic acid-soluble peptide fragments.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	264	 Thus ubiquitination precedes retrograde translocation, and degradation of polytopic proteins such as CFTR is physically localized to the ER membrane rather than the cytosol as proposed for some secretory and transmembrane substrates (8, 10, 13).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	265	Our results are consistent with a model in which CFTR degradation is tightly coupled to removal of the polypeptide from the lipid bilayer.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	266	 At least 65% of [35S]methionine-labeled CFTR was degraded into trichloroacetic acid-soluble fragments, consistent with proteasomal degradation in which the resulting polypeptides are 6-9 residues in length (43).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	267	 Because a small fraction of full-length CFTR (approximately 10-15%) remained intact in nearly all experiments, the extent of degradation for individual CFTR polypeptides actually approached 80%.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	268	 Thus CFTR degradation could not be limited to large cytosolic regions containing the N terminus, nucleotide binding domains, and R domain, which together comprise 61% of the total mass but only 47% of methionine residues (40).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	269	 If all cytosolic loops within 8-15 residues from the membrane were cleaved, then degradation of all full-length CFTR polypeptide chains would liberate only 60% total CFTR methionine into the trichloroacetic acid-soluble fraction (40).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	270	 It therefore seems likely that proteolytic machinery such as the proteasome might participate in removal of CFTR from the lipid bilayer to gain access to transmembrane segments and/or lumenal peptide regions.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	271	 This possibility is supported by the observation that: (i) proteasome-like particles are physically localized to the cytosolic surface of the ER membrane (44) and (ii) our results that CFTR degradation occurs via a membrane-bound, rather than cytosolic, intermediate.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	272	 If retrograde translocation of CFTR occurred through the Sec61 translocon, then extraction from the lipid bilayer could potentially involve the reverse process of membrane integration, namely lateral movement of TM segments from the membrane back into the translocation channel and into the cytosol (45, 46).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	273	While this study provides additional support that the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway is involved in ER-associated degradation of CFTR, it is unclear why different proteasome inhibitors exhibited different effects on CFTR degradation.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	274	 Lactacystin and clasto-lactacystin -lactone, which covalently inactivate the active site threonine residue on the 5 subunit of the 20 S proteasome (subunit X of the mammalian proteasome) (47, 48), had relatively minor effects on CFTR degradation as determined either by disappearance of the CFTR HMW complex (Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	275	 4) or generation of trichloroacetic acid-soluble fragments (Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	276	 It is interesting that clasto-lactacystin -lactone, the active form of lactacystin, is inactivated by glutathione in cells (49, 50).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Our observation that neither lactacystin nor its -lactone form inhibited the degradation of lysozyme, a known proteasome substrate, suggests that RRL is capable of rendering these agents inactive, even when preincubated in the absence of exogenous reducing agents.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	278	 We do not know why the results reported here differ from those of Qu et al.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	279	 (51) that demonstrated 20  microM lactacystin inhibited the degradation of both 1-antitrypsin and lysozyme in a similar RRL system.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	280	 However, our results were consistent for two different preparations of lactacystin and at multiple inhibitor concentrations up to 100  microM.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	281	 It is possible that these differences reflect varying amounts of proteasome in different RRL preparations.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	282	The most potent inhibitors of CFTR degradation were EDTA, apyrase, and hemin.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	283	 EDTA and hemin have been shown previously to inhibit the degradation of other proteasome substrates in RRL by stabilizing HMW ubiquitin conjugates (39, 52, 53).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	284	 Hemin, a heme precursor, exerts pleiotropic effects in RRL.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Its stimulatory effect on protein translation (38) is proposed to be mediated by inactivation of the translation factor eif-2, possibly by inhibiting an endogenous RRL kinase (54, 55).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	286	 In addition, hemin directly inhibits ATPase activities of the purified 19 S proteasome regulatory complex (PA700) as well as the 26 S proteasome itself (56).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	287	 Because the catalytic core of the 20 S proteasome cannot accommodate folded or ubiquitinated polypeptides, it has been proposed that ATPases contained within the 19 S regulatory subunit are required for substrate unfolding as well as deubiquitination (43, 48, 56-59).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	288	 It is therefore likely that hemin inhibits proteasome-mediated CFTR degradation by blocking ATPase activity and thereby preventing CFTR unfolding and/or deubiquitination.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	289	 If CFTR unfolding were required for removal from the bilayer, such a mechanism would explain the accumulation of membrane-bound, polyubiquitinated CFTR observed in the current study.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	290	Our results do not rule out the possibility that additional peptidase activities either in the ER lumen or within the membrane also participate in CFTR degradation as has been suggested previously (25, 60).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	291	 One such candidate is signal peptidase complex, an ER-localized protease that is capable of cleaving transmembrane proteins (61) and free signal peptides (30) at sites located within the plane of the lipid bilayer.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	292	 Interestingly, CFTR contains cryptic signal peptidase cleavage sites within or adjacent to TM segments of the N terminus hydrophobic domain (62, 63).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	293	 If similar proteases facilitated CFTR degradation, then TM segments and small peptide loops could potentially be released from the membrane.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	294	 Such a mechanism might explain why a significant amount of CFTR degradation was ATP-independent and hemin insensitive.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	295	 It is also possible that the membrane-bound HMW complex might actually consist of polyubiquitinated CFTR cleavage products that are then degraded by the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	296	Cell-free systems have significantly enhanced our understanding of protein folding (64) and translocation (2).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	297	 However we do not yet know whether the folded state of newly synthesized CFTR in the RRL system is the same as that found in the ER of cells or whether the mechanism of CFTR recognition by ER quality control machinery in vitro is the same as in vivo.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	298	 Processing in the RRL system is limited to early events that occur at the ER membrane, and it is possible that CFTR might require specialized cellular components that are limiting in RRL and/or canine pancreas microsomes.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	299	 Recently, RRL and yeast-derived cell-free systems have been used to examine the degradation of other secretory and transmembrane proteins (8, 51), including CFTR (31).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	300	 Our observation that 85-90% of newly synthesized wild type CFTR is degraded in the RRL system is consistent with studies that demonstrate most wild type CFTR is also degraded in the ER membrane of intact cells (22, 23).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	301	 In addition, preliminary experiments in our laboratory have demonstrated that other polytopic proteins expressed in the RRL system, such as human P-glycoprotein and aquaporin water channels, are much more stable than CFTR.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	302	2 These studies indicate that rapid CFTR degradation in vitro is not simply a cell free artifact, but rather reflects specific structural features recognized by ER quality control machinery.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	303	 In vitro systems such as RRL will thus likely provide a versatile tool for investigating the events and cellular machinery involved in ER-associated degradation.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	304	 In the case of CFTR, they may also provide screening assays to identify compounds that improve folding and trafficking efficiency.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	305	 Marks and members of the Skach laboratory for their helpful comments.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	306	* This work was supported by Grants GM53457 and DK51818 from the National Institutes of Health and by the North American Cystic Fibrosis Foundation.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	307	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	308	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	309	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.

0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	311	 Present address: Division of Molecular Medicine, 3181 SW Sam Jackson Park Rd.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	312	, NRC-3, Oregon Health Sciences University, Portland, OR 97201.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	313	: 503-494-7322; Fax: 503-494-7368; E-mail: skachw{at}ohsu.

0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	0	Role of the Cytoplasmic Segments of Sec61 in the Ribosome-binding and Translocation-promoting Activities of the Sec61 Complex David Radena, Weiqun Songa, and Reid Gilmorea a Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, University of Massachusetts Medical School, Worcester, Massachusetts 01655-0103.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	1	Correspondence to: Reid Gilmore, Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, University of Massachusetts Medical School, 55 Lake Avenue North, Worcester, MA 01655-0103.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	2	 Tel:(508) 856-5894 Fax:(508) 856-6231 E-mail:reid.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	3	  Abstract Top Abstract Introduction Materials and Methods Results Discussion Acknowledgements References.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	4	The Sec61 complex performs a dual function in protein translocation across the RER, serving as both the high affinity ribosome receptor and the translocation channel.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	5	 To define regions of the Sec61 complex that are involved in ribosome binding and translocation promotion, ribosome-stripped microsomes were subjected to limited digestions using proteases with different cleavage specificities.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Protein immunoblot analysis using antibodies specific for the NH2 and COOH terminus of Sec61 was used to map the location of proteolysis cleavage sites.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	7	 We observed a striking correlation between the loss of binding activity for nontranslating ribosomes and the digestion of the COOH- terminal tail or cytoplasmic loop 8 of Sec61.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	8	 The proteolyzed microsomes were assayed for SRP-independent translocation activity to determine whether high affinity binding of the ribosome to the Sec61 complex is a prerequisite for nascent chain transport.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Microsomes that do not bind nontranslating ribosomes at physiological ionic strength remain active in SRP-independent translocation, indicating that the ribosome binding and translocation promotion activities of the Sec61 complex do not strictly correlate.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Translocation-promoting activity was most severely inhibited by cleavage of cytosolic loop 6, indicating that this segment is a critical determinant for this function of the Sec61 complex.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	11	Key Words: endoplasmic reticulum, protein targeting, protein translocation, translocon structure, protein topology.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	12	  Introduction Top Abstract Introduction Materials and Methods Results Discussion Acknowledgements References.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	13	Proteins that are translocated across or integrated into the ER are cotranslationally recognized by the 54-kD subunit of the signal recognition particle (SRP)1 when the NH2-terminal signal sequence emerges from the exit site on the large ribosomal subunit (for review see Walter and Johnson 1994 ).
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Targeting of the SRP to ribosome nascent chain complex to the RER is mediated by the interaction between the SRP and the SRP receptor (SR), a heterodimeric GTPase localized to the RER.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	15	 A GTPase cycle involving SRP54 and SR initiates the release of the signal sequence from SRP, and results in the attachment of the ribosome to nascent chain complex (RNC) to the translocation channel (Connolly and Gilmore 1989 ; Rapiejko and Gilmore 1997 ).
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	16	The nascent polypeptide is subsequently transported across the ER membrane through a protein-lined aqueous pore in the membrane (Gilmore and Blobel 1985 ; Simon and Blobel 1991 ; Crowley et al.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	17	 The central core of this protein translocation channel is the Sec61 complex, a heterotrimeric integral membrane protein consisting of Sec61, Sec61ss, and Sec61 (Gorlich et al.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	18	 1992 ; Gorlich and Rapoport 1993 ).
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The Sec61 complex oligomerizes within the plane of the membrane to form a quasi-pentagonal 85 to 100-A ring surrounding a 20 to 40-A pore (Hanein et al.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Nascent polypeptides are thought to traverse the membrane via the central pore in the Sec61 oligomer, as proteins undergoing transport are in continuous contact with Sec61 once the ribosome to nascent chain complex engages the translocation channel (Mothes et al.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Of the 10 transmembrane (TM) segments of Saccharomyces cerevisiae Sec61, TM2 and TM7 are the targets for photoreactive cross-linking agents when a nascent prepro--factor chain is targeted to the yeast SEC complex (Plath et al.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	22	In addition to serving as the conduit for nascent polypeptide transport across the RER, the Sec61 complex functions as a high affinity ribosome receptor (Gorlich et al.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Ultrastructural studies of complexes between the S.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	24	 cerevisiae ribosome and the Sec61 complex have revealed that the exit site for the nascent polypeptide on the large ribosomal subunit is aligned with the translocation channel by a single point of contact between the Sec61 oligomer and the ribosome (Beckmann et al.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	25	 It is not known which segments of Sec61 are responsible for the high affinity binding of the ribosome to the translocation channel, nor is it certain that Sec61ss and Sec61 do not contribute to the affinity between the ribosome and the Sec61 complex.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	26	Ribosome to nascent chain complexes can bind to unoccupied Sec61 complexes in an SRP-independent reaction that is thought to be driven by the affinity between the ribosome and the Sec61 complex (Jungnickel and Rapoport 1995 ; Lauring et al.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	27	 1995a ; Raden and Gilmore 1998 ).
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	28	 This artificial targeting reaction is readily observed when elongation-arrested RNCs are incubated with ribosome-stripped microsomes that contain an excess of Sec61 complexes relative to added RNCs and 80S ribosomes.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Although SRP-independent binding of the RNCs to the Sec61 complex is not signal sequence to dependent (Lauring et al.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	30	 1995b ), the subsequent transport of polypeptides targeted by this mechanism is greatly facilitated by the recognition of the signal sequence by Sec61 (Jungnickel and Rapoport 1995 ).
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	31	 This signal sequence recognition activity of the Sec61 complex may provide a proofreading mechanism to enhance the fidelity of protein translocation across the RER.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	32	We have used limited proteolysis to sever cytoplasmically exposed segments of RER membrane proteins.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	33	 The protease-digested microsomes were assayed for SRP-independent translocation activity and for the ability to bind nontranslating ribosomes or ribosome to nascent chain complexes to determine which cytoplasmic segments of the Sec61 complex contribute to the various functions of the Sec61 complex.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	34	 We have obtained evidence that SRP-independent translocation is not obligatorily dependent upon high affinity binding of the ribosome to the Sec61 complex.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Cytoplasmic segments of the Sec61 complex that are important for high affinity ribosome binding map to COOH-terminal cytoplasmic segments of Sec61.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	36	  Materials and Methods Top Abstract Introduction Materials and Methods Results Discussion Acknowledgements References.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	37	Preparation of Rough Microsomes (RM), SRP, the SR Fragment, and Protease-digested PK-RM Rough microsomes (RM) and SRP were isolated from canine pancreas as described by Walter et al.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	38	 The 52-kD SR fragment was prepared as described previously (Nicchitta and Blobel 1989 ).
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Puromycin high salt to extracted rough microsomes (PK-RM) were prepared from RM as described previously (Raden and Gilmore 1998 ), except that PK-RM were washed once by centrifugation rather than twice with 50 mM triethanolamine acetate, pH 7.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	40	5 (TEA), 600 mM potassium acetate, 12 mM magnesium acetate, 1 mM DTT, and 1 mM EDTA.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	41	 The PK-RM were resuspended in membrane buffer (50 mM TEA, 250 mM sucrose, 1 mM DTT) at a concentration of 2 eq/ microl (eq as defined in Walter et al.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	42	Aliquots of the PK-RM (500  microl) were digested at a concentration of 2 eq/ microl for 1 h.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Trypsin (0 to 30  microg/ml) and chymotrypsin (0 to 200  microg/ml) digestions were done on ice and terminated with 1 mM PMSF, followed by a 15-min incubation on ice and adjustment to 10  microg/ml of aprotinin.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Digestion with endoproteinase Glu-C (200  microg/ml) was for 1 h at 37 degrees C, and was terminated with 1 mM 3,4-dichloroisocoumarin.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Thermolysin digestions (0 to 50  microg/ml), which were done in the presence of 1 mM CaCl2 at either 25 degrees C or on ice, were terminated by the addition of 2 mM EDTA.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The protease-digested PK-RM were adjusted to 550 mM potassium acetate and centrifuged for 30 min at 100,000 g in a Beckman type 50 rotor.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	47	 The membranes were resuspended at a concentration of 0.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	48	1 eq/ microl in membrane buffer, and centrifuged for 30 min at 100,000 g in a Beckman type 50 rotor.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	49	 After repeating the preceding resuspension and centrifugation steps, the protease-digested PK-RM were adjusted to a concentration of 1 eq/ microl in membrane buffer, and stored at -80 degrees C.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	50	Isolation of Ribosomes and 125I-Labeling of Ribosomes Ribosomes were isolated from wheat germ cytosol (Raden and Gilmore 1998 ) or from canine RM (Collins and Gilmore 1991 ) as described previously.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	51	 The canine ribosomes were resuspended in TKMD (50 mM TEA, 150 mM potassium acetate, 5 mM magnesium acetate, 1 mM DTT), applied to a 13-ml 10 to 30% sucrose gradient in TKMD, and centrifuged for 4 h at 200,000 gav in an SW40 rotor.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	52	 The ribosomes were collected using a density gradient fractionator (ISCO), and were quantified using an extinction coefficient at 260 nm of E = 6.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	53	The canine ribosomes were labeled with iodine-125 by incubating 26 pmol of ribosomes with 450  microCi of 125I-Bolton-Hunter reagent (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) for 2 h on ice.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Radiolabeling was terminated by adjusting the sample to 10 mM Tris-Cl, pH 7.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The 125I-labeled ribosomes were separated from unincorporated radiolabel by centrifugation on a 5 to 20% sucrose gradient in 50 mM Tris-Cl, pH 7.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	56	5 mM MgCl2 in an SW40 rotor for 3 h at 200,000 gav.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	57	Glycerol Gradient Centrifugation and Superose 12 Chromatography 20 eq of protease-digested PK-RM was mixed with 180  microl of a detergent high salt buffer to obtain the following final conditions: 20 mM Tris-Cl, pH 7.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	58	4, 500 mM NaCl, 1 mM MgCl2, 1 mM MnCl2, 1 mM DTT, 1x PIC (protease inhibitor cocktail as defined in Walter et al.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	59	 After a 20-min incubation on ice, the detergent extracts were clarified by centrifugation for 5 min at 30 psi in an airfuge.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	60	A 150- microl sample of the clarified detergent extract was applied to a 5-ml 8 to 30% glycerol gradient in 20 mM Tris-Cl, pH 7.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	61	4, 500 mM NaCl, 1 mM MgCl2, 1 mM MnCl2, 1 mM DTT, 1x PIC, 0.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	62	125% digitonin, and 25  microg/ml egg yolk phosphatidylcholine.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The gradients were centrifuged for 18 h at 85,000 gav in an SW50.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	64	1 rotor and separated into 13 to 15 fractions using a density gradient fractionator (ISCO).
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Clarified detergent extracts were applied to a 23.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	66	6-ml Superose 12 column equilibrated in 20 mM Tris-Cl, pH 7.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	67	4, 150 mM NaCl, 1 mM MgCl2, 1 mM MnCl2, 1 mM DTT, 1x PIC, 0.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	68	125% digitonin, and 25  microg/ml egg yolk phosphatidylcholine.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	69	5 ml were collected as the column was eluted with equilibration buffer.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	70	Ribosome Binding Assays of Protease-digested PK-RM Ribosome binding assays were performed by mixing a constant amount of 125I-labeled ribosomes (typically 0.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	71	7 pmol of unlabeled canine ribosomes.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	72	 The ribosomes were incubated with TX-PK-RM, CX-PK-RM, VX-PK-RM, or THX-PK-RM for 20 min on ice in TKMD.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	73	 The 30- microl sample was applied to a 1.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	74	3-ml Sepharose CL-2B column equilibrated in TKMD.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	75	 The column was eluted with 270  microl of TKMD, followed by 1.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	76	5 ml of 50 mM TEA, 500 mM potassium acetate, 5 mM magnesium acetate, and 1 mM DTT.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	77	 The ionic strength of the elution buffer was raised to reduce nonspecific absorption of unbound ribosomes to the Sepharose beads.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	78	 100- microl fractions of the eluate were collected, and the amount of 125I-labeled ribosomes in each fraction was determined using a Beckman -counter.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	79	 The elution positions of membrane-bound ribosomes (0.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	80	5 ml) were determined in control experiments wherein 125I-labeled ribosomes were fractionated after incubation in the presence or absence of PK-RM.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	81	 The binding data was fit to the following equation using a nonlinear least squares program: RB = (BM   RF)/(Kd + RF), where RB and RF are the concentrations of bound and free ribosomes, respectively; Bm is the number of binding sites; and Kd is the dissociation constant.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	82	SRP-dependent and SRP-independent Translocation Assays A full-length mRNA encoding preprolactin (pPL) and truncated mRNAs encoding the NH2-terminal 86 residues of preprolactin (pPL86) and the NH2-terminal 77 residues of firefly luciferase (ffLuc77) were isolated from preparative scale transcriptions as described previously (Rapiejko and Gilmore 1994 ).
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	83	 SRP-dependent translocation of preprolactin was assayed using 25- microl reticulocyte lysate translations that contained [35S]methionine, endogenous SRP, 1.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	84	2 eq of protease-digested PK-RM, and 200 fmol of the SR 52-kD fragment.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Translocated prolactin was resolved from preprolactin by PAGE in SDS.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	86	To assay SRP-independent translocation, the truncated pPL86 mRNA transcript was translated at 25 degrees C for 15 min in a wheat germ system that contained [35S]methionine as described previously (Gilmore et al.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Further protein synthesis was blocked by adding cycloheximide to a final concentration of 250  microM.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	88	 The translation products (10  microl, unless stated otherwise) were incubated with the protease-digested PK-RM (10 eq, unless specified otherwise) for 5 min at 25 degrees C.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Translocation of pPL86 was induced by releasing the peptidyl tRNA from the ribosome by incubation with 25 mM EDTA for 10 min at 25 degrees C (Connolly et al.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	90	 1989 ; Raden and Gilmore 1998 ).
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	91	 The assays were prepared for SDS-PAGE as previously described (Connolly et al.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	92	 1989 ), and were subjected to electrophoresis using Tris-tricine gels (Schagger and von Jagow 1987 ).
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	93	 The percent translocation of pPL86 was calculated after quantification of PL56 and pPL86 using the following formula: percent translocation = 100 x 1.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	94	33 corrects for the loss of the NH2-terminal methionine residue from pPL86 upon signal sequence cleavage.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	95	Binding of RNCs bearing 35S-labeled pPL86 to the protease-digested PK-RM was assayed by centrifugal flotation on discontinuous sucrose gradients as previously described (Lauring et al.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	96	 1995b ), or by gel filtration chromatography on Sepharose CL-2B columns, as described above, to separate membrane bound RNCs from unbound RNCs.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	97	 The percentage of RNCs that were membrane bound was quantified with a PhosphorImager after the pPL86 in each fraction was resolved by SDS-PAGE using Tris-tricine gels.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Insertion of pPL86 into the Sec61 translocation channel was assayed by resistance to a 1-h digestion on ice with 400  microg/ml of proteinase K as previously described (Connolly et al.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	99	Protein Immunoblots The procedure for protein immunoblots using enhanced chemiluminescence has been described (Raden and Gilmore 1998 ).
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Multiple film exposures were obtained to insure that the ECL signal was linear with respect to the quantity of antigen.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Western blots were quantified with a Fluor-s multi-imager (Bio-Rad Laboratories) and Multi-Analyst software.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Mouse mAbs specific for ribophorin I and SRss were provided by Dr.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Gert Kreibich (NYU School of Medicine, New York, NY) and Dr.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Peter Walter (University of California San Francisco, San Francisco, CA), respectively.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Rabbit antisera raised against the NH2 terminus of Sec61 and Sec61ss was provided by Dr.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Christopher Nicchitta (Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC) and Dr.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Tom Rapoport (Harvard University, Cambridge, MA), respectively.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	108	 An antibody was raised in rabbits against the COOH terminus of Sec61 (KEQSEVGSMGALLF) using standard procedures.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	109	  Results Top Abstract Introduction Materials and Methods Results Discussion Acknowledgements References.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	110	Sensitivity of Sec61 to Proteolysis Sec61 is integrated in the ER with a topology that places four loops (L2, L4, L6, and L8) plus the NH2- and COOH-terminal tails on the cytoplasmic face of the membrane (Fig 1 A).
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	111	 The ss and subunits of the Sec61 complex are integrated by single TM spans located near the COOH terminus.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Membrane-bound ribosomes effectively block access of proteases to Sec61 and, to a lesser extent, to Sec61ss (Kalies et al.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Ribosome-stripped microsomes (PK-RM) were digested with proteases to sever cytoplasmic segments of the Sec61 complex.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Trypsin, chymotrypsin, endoproteinase Glu-C, and thermolysin-digested PK-RM are designated, respectively, as TX-PK-RM, CX-PK-RM, VX-PK-RM, or ThX-PK-RM (where the subscript X denotes the concentration of protease, in  microg/ml, used for the digestion).
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Protein immunoblot analysis, using antibodies specific for the NH2- and COOH-terminal tails of Sec61, was used to determine which cytoplasmic segments of Sec61 are accessible to proteases.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Protease cleavage sites in Sec61 were mapped to cytoplasmic loops 6 and 8 by comparison to COOH-terminal Sec61 truncation products (Song et al.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	117	 The amino acid sequences of the cytoplasmic segments of the Sec61 complex are shown in Fig 1 B, together with potential cleavage sites for trypsin, chymotrypsin, and endoproteinase Glu-C.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Although each cytoplasmic segment of Sec61 contains predicted cleavage sites for at least two of the proteases tested, we observed a remarkable difference in the sensitivity of these regions to protease digestion (Fig 1 B).
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Loop 8 and the COOH terminus were the most protease-sensitive regions of Sec61, followed by loop 6.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	120	 The NH2-terminal tail, which is proposed to be an amphipathic -helix aligned with the membrane surface (Wilkinson et al.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	121	 1996 ), was far less sensitive to digestion.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Loops 2 and 4 were completely resistant to proteases under all conditions tested.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	123	View larger version (25K):    Figure 1.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	124	 The predicted membrane topology of the Sec61 complex.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	125	 (A) The topology diagrams for Sec61, Sec61ss, and Sec61 are adapted from those shown in previous publications (Gorlich et al.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	126	 The diagrams show the relative predicted sizes of the cytosolic and lumenal tails and loops.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Sec61 segments that were used as antigens for the production of anti to NH2- and anti to COOH-terminal antibodies are labeled.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	128	 (B) The amino acid sequences of the NH2- and COOH-terminal domains and the cytosolic loops of Sec61, Sec61ss, and Sec61 are shown.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Potential protease cleavage sites are indicated in bold (trypsin), italics (endoproteinase Glu-C), or by underlining (chymotrypsin).
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Digestion of Sec61, Sec61ss, and Sec61 in PK-RM by these proteases is summarized in the chart to the right.
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	131	 For trypsin and chymotrypsin, the subscript indicates the minimum concentration of protease tested that yielded 50% digestion of a given segment (see Materials and Methods for protease concentrations).
0.43387523.10893256.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Additional symbols designate the following: lack of detectable cleavage (-); less than 50% cleavage ( plus or minus ); 50% cleavage (+); and digestion to completion (++).
