0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	0	A Golgi-associated PDZ Domain Protein Modulates Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Regulator Plasma Membrane Expression* Jie Cheng, Bryan D.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Moyer  , Michal Milewski, Johannes Loffing**, Masahiro Ikeda, John E.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	2	From the  Department of Physiology and  Institute of Genetic Medicine, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, Baltimore, Maryland 21205, the   Department of Physiology, Dartmouth Medical School, Dartmouth College, Hanover, New Hampshire 03755, and the ** Institute of Anatomy, University of Zurich, CH-8057 Zurich, Switzerland.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	3	Received for publication, October 23, 2001, and in revised form, November 12, 2001.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	4	    ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	5	We identified a novel cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR)-associating, PDZ domain-containing protein, CAL (CFTR associated ligand) containing two predicted coiled-coiled domains and one PDZ domain.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	6	 The PDZ domain of CAL binds to the C terminus of CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Although CAL does not have any predicted transmembrane domains, CAL is associated with membranes mediated by a region containing the coiled-coil domains.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	8	 CAL is located primarily at the Golgi apparatus, co-localizing with trans-Golgi markers and is sensitive to Brefeldin A treatment.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Immunoprecipitation experiments suggest that CAL exists as a multimer.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Overexpression of CAL reduces CFTR chloride currents in mammalian cells and decreases expression, rate of insertion and half-life of CFTR in the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	11	 The Na+/H+ exchanger regulatory factor, NHE-RF, a subplasma membrane PDZ domain protein, restores cell surface expression of CFTR and chloride currents.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	12	 In addition, NHE-RF inhibits the binding of CAL to CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	13	 CAL modulates the surface expression of CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	14	 CAL favors retention of CFTR within the cell, whereas NHE-RF favors surface expression by competing with CAL for the binding of CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Thus, the regulation of CFTR in the plasma membrane involves the dynamic interaction between at least two PDZ domain proteins.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	16	     INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	17	Cystic fibrosis is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR)1 (1-3).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	18	 CFTR is a cAMP-regulated chloride channel and channel regulator (4) that mediates salt and water balance in a number of tissues, including the airways, intestines, pancreatic and sweat ducts, and kidney tubules (5).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	19	 In many polarized epithelial tissues, CFTR functions in the apical cell membrane but in the sweat duct CFTR is localized to both the apical and basolateral cell membranes.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Because a common mutation in CFTR, F508, is degraded through the endoplasmic reticulum (ER)-associated processes, many studies have focused on the trafficking of CFTR through this compartment (6).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Much less attention has been devoted to how CFTR is processed through the post-ER pathways.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	22	We reported previously that the polarization of CFTR in the apical membrane of human airway and kidney epithelial cells is altered in CFTR mutants lacking the C-terminal domain (7, 8).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	23	 These data suggested that the C-terminal domain plays a role either in the trafficking to and/or stability within the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	24	 The last three amino acids of CFTR (Thr-Arg-Leu) comprise a consensus sequence known to bind to PDZ domain proteins, a family of proteins containing a 80- to 90-amino acid motif that binds to the C terminus of a variety of ion channels and receptors (9-11).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	25	At least two PDZ domain-containing proteins, Na+/H+ exchanger regulatory factor, NHE-RF (also called EBP50), and the CFTR-associated protein CAP70 are known to bind to the terminal amino acids of CFTR (12, 13).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	26	 NHE-RF is a submembranous phosphoprotein that regulates the apical membrane Na+/H+ exchanger NHE3 (14).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Because NHE-RF associates with ezrin, which itself binds to the regulatory subunit of PKA (15), it was hypothesized that NHE-RF anchors CFTR to the cytoskeleton at a subapical compartment targeting protein kinase A near CFTR (12).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	28	 E3KARP, an NHE-RF-related protein, was also shown to interact with CFTR (16, 17).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	29	 CAP70, a subapical protein with four PDZ domains, binds to at least two CFTR molecules simultaneously via PDZ3 and PDZ4 (18).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	30	 CAP70 and NHE-RF enhance CFTR Cl channel activity in excised patches probably by cross-linking CFTR dimers (18, 19).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	31	 NHE-RF, E3KARP, and CAP70 are localized to subplasma membrane regions reflecting their proposed roles in anchoring and/or regulating CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	32	Although there is growing evidence of a functional interaction between CFTR and PDZ domain proteins at the plasma membrane, little is known about whether PDZ domain proteins play a role in intracellular trafficking of CFTR along the ER, the Golgi, and the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	33	 The post-ER secretory pathway involved in the trafficking of wild type and mutant CFTR to the plasma membrane is poorly characterized.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	34	 A recent study has demonstrated that CFTR has an unusually low distribution in cis-Golgi compartments compared with most membrane proteins (20), raising the possibility that CFTR may utilize novel modes of anterograde and retrograde trafficking mechanisms.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	35	To learn more about the role of the C terminus of CFTR in processing and trafficking, we used a yeast-two hybrid assay to identify proteins that bind to CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	36	 We identified a novel PDZ domain protein, CAL, that interacts with CFTR in the post-ER secretory pathway.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	37	 The PDZ domain of CAL binds directly to the C terminus of CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Native CFTR and CAL localize with Golgi markers in lung tissue in vivo.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Overexpression of CAL suppresses CFTR expression at the cell surface and reduces CFTR currents both in Xenopus oocytes and mammalian cells.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	40	 This suppression can be overcome by NHE-RF.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Our data demonstrate that CAL modulates the surface expression of CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Although NHE-RF alone does not enhance surface expression of CFTR, it competes with CAL for the binding of CFTR and indirectly enhances expression in the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Thus, the expression of CFTR in the plasma membrane involves the dynamic interaction between at least two PDZ domain proteins.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	44	     EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	45	Two-hybrid Screening and Cloning of CAL-- Yeast two-hybrid screening was used to identify proteins that interact with the C terminus of CFTR (21).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The bait consisted of the C-terminal 51 amino acids of rat CFTR (aa 1428-1478 of rCFTR), amplified by PCR from a rat lung MATCHMAKER cDNA library (CLONTECH, Palo Alto, CA).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	47	 The PCR products were subcloned into the BamHI/PstI sites of a pAS2-1 vector, in-frame with the Gal4 DNA-binding domain.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Approximately 1  x  107 recombinants of a rat lung MATCHMAKER cDNA library fused to the Gal4 activation domain (CLONTECH) were screened for interaction with the bait protein in Y190 yeast cells on triple-minus plates supplemented with 35 mM 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole (3-AT) (Leu, Trp, His, 3-AT).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	49	 A rat CAL (rCAL) fragment identified in yeast two-hybrid screening was used to screen a human lung cDNA library (CLONTECH) to obtain the full-length human CAL (hCAL).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Cloned inserts were sequenced in both directions by automated fluorescent sequencing (Johns Hopkins University Biosynthesis  and  Sequencing Facility).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	51	 A partial rat CAL truncated at the extreme N terminus was also obtained by hybridization screening of a rat hippocampus library (gift from Drs.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	52	Yeast Two-hybrid Assay-- rCFTRC4 (aa 1428-1474) and rCFTRC7 (aa 1428-1471) were subcloned into the BamHI/PstI sites of the pAS2-1 vector, in-frame with the Gal4 DNA-binding domain (CLONTECH).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	53	 rCFTRC4, rCFTRC7, or the empty pAS2-1 vector were co-transformed with rCAL (in pGAD10 vector) into Y190 cells.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Interactions were monitored by the LacZ expression on filter lifted from the transformed cells and by counting viable colonies on triple-minus plates (Leu, Trp, His, 35 mM 3-AT).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	55	Cell Culture and Transfection-- Human embryonic kidney cell line HEK 293 and colorectal carcinoma T84 cells (obtained from American Type Tissue Culture, Manassas, VA) were maintained in DMEM:F-12 (1:1), L-glutamine, penicillin, streptomycin, and 10% FCS.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	56	 African green monkey kidney cell (COS-7) and Madin-Darby Canine Kidney II cells (MDCK) (obtained from American Type Tissue Culture) were maintained in DMEM, L-glutamine, penicillin, streptomycin, 10% FCS.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Human bronchial epithelial cells (16HBE14o, gift of Dr.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Dieter Gruenert) were maintained in minimal essential medium, L-glutamine, penicillin, streptomycin, and 10% FCS.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Cystic fibrosis bronchial epithelial cells (IB3-1) (22) were maintained in LHC-8 basal medium, L-glutamine, penicillin, streptomycin, and 5% FCS.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	60	 LHC-8 basal medium was purchased from Biofluids.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	61	 All other media and components were purchased from Invitrogen (Carlsbad, CA).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	62	 L-Glutamine (2 mM), penicillin (100 units/ml), and streptomycin (100  microg/ml) were used.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	63	 COS-7, IB3-1, MDCK, and 16HBE14o cells were transfected using LipofectAMINE or LipofectAMINE 2000 (Invitrogen) according to the manufacturer's instructions.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	64	Antibody Production-- Glutathione S-transferase (GST) fusion protein of C-terminal polypeptide (aa 216-454) from human CAL was prepared using the GST gene fusion system (Amersham Biosciences, Inc.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	65	 The Precision protease-cleaved CAL C-terminal polypeptide was sent to a commercial producer (Covance, Princeton, NJ) to prepare rabbit polyclonal antibodies.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	66	Plasmid Construction-- The HA and myc-tagged constructs were made by PCR amplification and subcloning into SalI/NotI sites of the HA-tagged pRK5 vector (pRK5-HA) and myc-tagged pRK5 vector (pRK5-myc), respectively (gifts from Drs.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Huganir, Johns Hopkins University).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The resulting constructs contain HA or myc tag at the N terminus of the fusion proteins (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	69	 The GFP-tagged constructs were made by PCR amplification and subcloning into the SalI/NotI sites of the pEGFP-N1 vector (CLONTECH).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	70	 The resulting constructs contain EGFP tag at the C terminus of the fusion proteins (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	71	 All constructs were sequence-verified.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	72	Other plasmid constructs used were HA-NHE-RF (13), GFP-CFTR and GFP-CFTRTRL (7), and full-length vesicular stomatitis virus glycoprotein (VSVG) protein cloned into pcDNA3.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	73	Northern Blotting-- Multiple human tissue poly(A) RNA blots (MTB1 and MTB2, CLONTECH) containing 16 human tissue poly(A) RNAs were hybridized with full-length hCAL probes under stringent conditions according to the manufacturer's directions.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	74	Immunoprecipitation and Immunoblotting-- Cells were harvested and processed as described previously (23).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Briefly, cells were solubilized and lysates were spun at 14,000  x  g for 15 min to pellet insoluble material.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	76	 The supernatants were immunoprecipitated with 1  microg of monoclonal Myc antibody, HA antibody (Roche Molecular Biochemicals, Indianapolis, IL), R domain CFTR antibody (Genzyme, Cambridge, MA) or polyclonal GFP antibody (CLONTECH), and CAL antibody followed by Protein G-agarose beads for R domain CFTR antibody or Protein A-agarose beads for all other antibodies.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	77	 The eluted proteins were then subjected to SDS-PAGE and Western blot followed by enhanced chemiluminescence (ECL, Amersham Biosciences, Inc.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	78	 GFP-CFTR was detected with monoclonal GFP antibody (1:1000; Roche Molecular Biochemicals).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	79	 HA-CAL, HA-NHE-RF, and other HA-tagged molecules were detected with monoclonal HA antibody (1:2000; Roche Molecular Biochemicals).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Endogenous CAL was detected by CAL antibodies.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Endogenous CFTR was detected by immunoprecipitation with R domain CFTR antibody (Genzyme) followed by protein kinase A phosphorylation as described previously (24).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	82	Pull-down Assay-- Biotinylated peptides were first incubated with immobilized NeutrAvidin beads (Pierce, catalog number 53151) in Nonidet P-40 lysis buffer at 4  degrees C for 2 h.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The beads were washed three times in Nonidet P-40 lysis buffer.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	84	 500  microg of cell lysate in a total volume of 500  microl was added to 25  microg of immobilized NeutrAvidin beads and tumbled at 4  degrees C for 2 h.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Samples were washed three times in Nonidet P-40 lysis buffer.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	86	 The bound proteins were eluted with 2 x  Laemmli sample buffer supplemented with 100  microM DTT at 42  degrees C for 30 min.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Eluted proteins were subjected to SDS-PAGE and Western blot.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Biotinylated peptides used were CFTRCT, Biotin-SGSGSKPQIAALLEETEEEVQDTRL; CFTRCT2, Biotin-TEEEVQDTRL; and JN33, Biotin-MNRVIEEDGTSA (C terminus of human frizzled-3).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	89	Surface Biotinylation-- Biotinylated CFTR at the plasma membrane was precipitated as described in detail previously with some modifications (23).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Lysates were incubated with immobilized NeutrAvidin beads (Pierce, catalog number 53151), and bound proteins were eluted with 2 x  Laemmli sample buffer supplemented with 100  microM DTT at 42  degrees C for 30 min.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	91	 The eluted proteins were subjected to SDS-PAGE and Western blot.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	92	 GFP-CFTR was detected with monoclonal GFP antibody (1:1000; Roche Molecular Biochemicals).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	93	 For VSVG surface biotinylation, COS-7 cells were transfected with full-length VSVG.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	94	 VSVG was detected with rabbit anti-VSVG polyclonal antibody (25).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	95	Pulse-chase and Cell Surface Biotinylation-- Two days after transfection, COS-7 cells were washed twice in methionine/cysteine free DMEM and then incubated for 60 min in methionine/cysteine free DMEM.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Cells were incubated in methionine/cysteine free DMEM containing Tran35S-label (250  microCi/ml) for 30 min.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Subsequently, cells were washed extensively with DMEM containing 10 mM of non-labeled methionine and 10 mM of unlabeled cysteine and chased in this solution for 0, 30, 60, 90, or 120 min.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Biotinylated CFTR at the plasma membrane was immunoprecipitated as described previously (23).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Radiolabeled CFTR was analyzed using a PhosphorImager (Molecular Dynamics, Sunnyvale, CA).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	100	 To examine the effect of CAL overexpression on the half-life of CFTR in the plasma membrane, cells were incubated in methionine/cysteine free DMEM containing Tran35S-label (250  microCi/ml) for 3 h.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Cells were washed extensively with DMEM containing 10 mM non-labeled methionine and 10 mM unlabeled cysteine (containing penicillin/streptomycin and 10% FBS) and chased in this solution for 0, 12, 24, or 32 h.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Plasma membrane proteins were biotinylated at 0, 12, 24, or 32 h, and biotinylated CFTR was immunoprecipitated using a GFP monoclonal antibody.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Radiolabeled CFTR was analyzed using a PhosphorImager.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	104	Subcellular Fractionation-- For subcellular fractionation experiments, cells were trypsinized and collected by centrifugation.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	105	 The pellet were resuspended and incubated in ice-cold swelling buffer (1 mM DTT, 1 mM MgCl2, 1 mM EGTA, and Complete protease inhibitor mixture (Roche Molecular Biochemicals)) for 5 min.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Cells were collected by centrifugation and resuspended in buffer containing 0.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	107	25 M sucrose, 3 mM imidazole, pH 7.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	108	4, and Complete protease inhibitor mixture.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Lysate was obtained by homogenizing 10 strokes with a Dounce homogenizer.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	110	 After a pre-clarification centrifugation (100  x  g, 4  degrees C, 5 min), the lysate was spun in an Ultracentrifuge at 100,000  x  g for 45 min at 4  degrees C in a centrifuge (TL-100) using a TLA-100.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	111	2 rotor (both from Beckman Coulter).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	112	 -Tubulin monoclonal antibody was obtained from Amersham Biosciences, Inc.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	113	Confocal Microscopy-- Cultured cells were plated on glass coverslips 1-day post-transfection and examined 2-days post-transfection.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Cells were fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde and permeabilized in 0.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Nonspecific binding sites were blocked with 5% normal goat serum (NGS).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Cells were stained with anti-HA monoclonal antibody (1:2000, Roche Molecular Biochemicals) or -adaptin (1:10, Sigma Chemical Co.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Louis, MO) in 5% NGS, washed with 1% bovine serum albumin, and incubated with goat anti-mouse Cy3 secondary antibodies in 1% NGS.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	118	 In some cases, cells were counter-stained with 4',6-diamidino-2-phenyl-indole (200  microg/ml, Sigma) to visualize nuclei.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Specimens were mounted and viewed on an LSM 410 confocal microscope (Zeiss).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	120	The immunofluorescence of rat tracheae was performed exactly as described (26).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Sections of frozen tracheae 6  microM thick were incubated with the following antibodies: rabbit-anti-CAL (1:500), mouse-anti--COP (1:50, Sigma), mouse-anti-58K (1:50, Sigma), and mouse-anti-TGN38 (1:50, Oncogene, Cambridge, MA).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	122	Whole Cell Patch-clamp Recordings-- Whole-cell recordings were performed at room temperature on COS-7 cells grown on glass coverslips 1-2 days post-transfection.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	123	5 mg/ml sodium butyrate for 16 h the day before the experiments as described (23).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Transfected cells expressing GFP-CFTR were identified under a fluorescence microscope (TE200, Nikon).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Coverslips were perfused with an extracellular solution containing (in mM): 140 NaCl, 5 KCl, 2 MgCl2, 1 CaCl2, 10 glucose, 20 sucrose, 0.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Sucrose and DIDS were used to prevent the activation of endogenous chloride currents.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Pipette resistance, with a pipette solution (PS) containing (in mM) 150 CsCl, 1 MgCl2, 2 Na2ATP, 1 EGTA, 10 Hepes (pH 7.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	128	4 with Tris), ranged between 5 and 8 M.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	129	 The input capacitance ranged from 11 to 64 picofarads.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	130	 pClamp8 software (Axon Instruments) was used to sample and analyze data.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Current-voltage (I-V) relationships were obtained at 100 ms of each voltage step from a holding potential of 0 mV.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Junction potentials between extracellular solution and PS were measured using a 3 M KCl bridge and were  < 2 mV.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Therefore no correction for these potentials was made.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Extracellular membrane-permeant cAMP analogue 8-chlorophenyl-thio-cAMP (cpt-cAMP, 250  microM) was applied using a nearby pipette of 30- to 35- microm diameter.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	135	     RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	136	Identification and Tissue Distribution of CAL-- To identify PDZ domain proteins that interact with CFTR, we performed a yeast two-hybrid screen using the last 51 amino acids of the C terminus of rat CFTR (21).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Approximately 1  x  107 recombinants of a lung cDNA library fused to the Gal4 DNA activation domain were screened.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	138	 A novel protein designated as CAL (CFTR-Associated Ligand) was identified in this screening.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Fifty-six clones were isolated that encoded overlapping, partial sequences of CAL.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Each contained the consensus sequence for a complete PDZ domain.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	141	 The interaction between CFTR and CAL was confirmed by re-transforming the cloned cDNA into yeast.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	142	 The interaction was bait-dependent, because it did not occur with the vector alone.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	143	 The interaction was also dependent upon the terminal amino acids of CFTR, because it did not occur with CFTR C-terminal constructs missing the terminal 4 or 7 amino acids (data not shown).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	144	To obtain the full-length CAL, we screened a human lung cDNA library (CLONTECH) with rat CAL cDNA.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Seven independent and overlapping clones were identified.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	146	 The largest fragment contained a 1362-bp open reading frame, preceded 132 bp upstream by an in-frame stop codon.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	147	 A start codon consistent with a Kozak consensus sequence (27) was identified.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Translation in this reading frame predicts a 454-amino acid polypeptide with an estimated molecular mass of 50 kDa (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Hydropathy analysis did not detect any putative membrane-spanning regions (28).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	150	 No targeting signal sequence was detected.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	151	 The carboxyl half of CAL is identical to the amino half of an aberrant clone Homo sapiens RNA for ros1 oncogene (29).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	152	 This aberrant clone very likely results from the rearrangement of CAL to the human ros1 oncogene.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	153	 CAL mapped to chromosome 6q21A by aligning to a finished human genomic sequence (PAC 94G16) in GenBankTM (30).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	154	 A rat CAL cDNA that is highly homologous to the human CAL (91% identity, 94% conserved) was obtained in a hybridization screen (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Human CAL is also highly homologous (56% identity, 71% homology) to a protein identified in the Caenorhabditis elegans genome project (ZK849.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	156	2) suggesting an evolutionarily conserved function (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	157	 1A), as well as to a recently described protein (31).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	158	 In addition to a PDZ domain, CAL is predicted to have two coiled-coil domains.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Coiled-coil domains are also involved in protein-protein interactions (32).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	160	 The co-existence of coiled-coil domains and a PDZ domain suggests that CAL can potentially interact with multiple proteins.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	161	View larger version (90K):    Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	162	   Protein sequences, protein domains, and the tissue distribution of CAL.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	163	 A, conceptual translation of human CAL cDNA (hCAL: accession number AF450008), a partial rat CAL cDNA (rCAL), and a putative C.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	164	2: GenBankTM accession number T28036).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	165	 The box depicts the PDZ domain (aa 280-363).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Underlined are the coiled-coil domains (aa 77-132 and 143-198).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	167	 B, tissue distribution of CAL mRNA.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Multiple human tissue poly(A) RNA blots were probed with CAL under stringent conditions.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	169	 A major transcript (~5 kb) was detected in all tissues.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	170	5, and 2 kb) were detected in a number of tissues.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	171	 a, full-length CAL consists of the N-terminal domain (N), the coiled-coil domain (CC, in green), the PDZ domain (PDZ, in red), and the C-terminal domain (C).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	172	 b, HA-tagged PDZ domain of CAL (aa 216-404).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	173	 c, myc-tagged N-terminal half of CAL, including N-terminal and coiled-coil domains (aa 1-279).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	174	 d, myc-tagged C-terminal half of CAL, including the C-terminal and PDZ domains (aa 216-454).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	175	 e, GFP-tagged N-terminal domain of CAL (aa 1-76).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	176	 f, GFP-tagged the N-terminal and coiled-coil domains of CAL (aa 1-279).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	177	 g, GFP-tagged PDZ domain and C-terminal of CAL (aa 216-454).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Blue filled circles indicate the positions of epitope tags.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	179	Northern blot analysis detected CAL in all human tissues examined, including CFTR-expressing tissues such as lung and pancreas (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	180	 The major transcript is 5 kb; in addition, some tissues have less abundant transcripts of different sizes (e.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	181	 The ubiquitous expression pattern and evolutionarily conserved protein sequence of CAL suggest an essential housekeeping role for its interaction with CFTR and other membrane proteins with similar PDZ binding motifs.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	182	Native Properties of CAL-- To study CAL in vivo, we generated a rabbit polyclonal antibody raised against the C-terminal domain of human CAL (see "Experimental Procedures").
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Consistent with the wide pattern of expression of CAL mRNA, CAL protein is endogenously expressed in several cell lines, including human bronchial epithelial cells, 16HBE14o (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	184	 2A), the colonic carcinoma T84 cell line (see related data in Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	185	 3D) and in the cystic fibrosis bronchial epithelial cell line, IB3-1 (data not shown).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	186	 In Western blots, 16HBE14o cells display native CAL at two molecular masses, ~50-kDa and ~100-kDa bands (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	187	 2A, Lysate), when analyzed under non-reducing conditions, but only a single ~50-kDa band (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	188	 2A, +ME and +DTT) when analyzed under reducing conditions.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	189	 This raises the possibility that CAL can form a homo-multimer.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	190	 To test this further, we cotransfected HEK293 cells with HA-tagged full-length CAL (HA-CAL) and with each one of the following myc-tagged CAL constructs: full-length (myc-CAL), a construct containing only the C-terminal portion, including the PDZ domain (myc-CAL-PDZ-C), or a construct containing only the N-terminal amino acids, including the coiled-coil domains but minus the PDZ domain (myc-CAL-N-CC).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Only in cells containing the myc-tagged full-length CAL (first lane) and the N-terminal portion of CAL (third lane) was it possible to immunoprecipitate HA-tagged full-length CAL with anti-Myc antibodies (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	192	 The myc-labeled C-terminal portion is not capable of precipitating HA-tagged full-length CAL (second lane).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	193	 These data demonstrate that CAL forms a homo-multimer and the self-association domain lies in the N-terminal half of CAL.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	194	View larger version (31K):    Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	195	   The native properties of CAL.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	196	 A, expression of CAL in cultured cells.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Total lysate of 16HBE14ocells was boiled for 5 min in Laemmli sample buffer (see "Experimental Procedures") minus 5% -ME (lysate; non-reducing condition), and plus 5% -ME (+-ME; reducing condition).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	198	 The right lane contains the total lysate of cells incubated at 37  degrees C for 15 min in Laemmli buffer containing 50 mM DTT (+DTT; reducing condition).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	199	 CAL was detected by Western blot using rabbit polyclonal CAL antibody.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	200	 B, crude membrane (Pellet) and soluble fractions (Soluble) from 16HBE14o cells were separated by SDS-PAGE and detected by CAL polyclonal antibody (upper panel) and -tubulin monoclonal antibody (lower panel).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	201	 CAL was associated primarily with the membrane fraction.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	202	 C, co-immunoprecipitation of HA-CAL and three constructs of myc-tagged CAL.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	203	 HEK293 cells were co-transfected with HA-CAL with (left to right) myc-CAL containing full-length CAL, myc-CAL-PDZ-C containing the PDZ and the C-terminal domains, myc-CAL-N-CC containing the N-terminal and coiled-coil domains, and empty vector pRK5.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Cell lysates were immunoprecipitated with Myc monoclonal antibody followed by Western blot using HA monoclonal antibody.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	205	 D, GFP-tagged CAL constructs as indicated were transfected into HEK293 cells.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Crude membrane fraction (P) and soluble fraction (S) were isolated (see "Experimental Procedures"), separated by SDS-PAGE, and detected by GFP monoclonal antibody.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	207	 The predicted molecular masses are as follows: GFP-CAL-N, ~37 kDa; GFP-CAL-N-CC, ~57 kDa; GFP-CAL-PDZ-C, ~53 kDa; GFP-CAL-FL, ~ 80 kDa; GFP alone, 27 kDa.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	208	View larger version (39K):    Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	209	   Biochemical characterization of CAL and CFTR interaction.

0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	221	 C, interaction of the C terminus of CFTR with native CAL.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Total lysates of 16HBE14o cells were incubated with two biotinylated C-terminal CFTR peptides (SGSGSKPQIAALLEETEEEVQDTRL) (lane 1) and (TEEEVQDTRL) (lane 2) or a control biotinylated peptide JN33 (lane 3).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	223	 JN33 peptide comprises the biotinylated C terminus of human frizzled-3 (Biotin-MNRVIEEDGTSA).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	224	 JN33 was used as a control for nonspecific binding.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Bound fractions were precipitated with NeutrAvidin beads and analyzed by Western blot using CAL antibody.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	226	 D, co-immunoprecipitation of native CAL and CFTR in T84 cells.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Total lysates of T84 cells were immunoprecipitated with CFTR antisera (Genzyme R domain monoclonal antibodies, CFTR ~ 160 kDa) (lane 1), protein A beads (lane 2), or CAL antisera (lane 3).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Top panel, Western blot using CAL antibody.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Bottom panel, autoradiography of radiolabeled CFTR (see "Experimental Procedures").
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	230	To determine if CAL is a membrane-associated or cytosolic protein, 16HBE14o cells were fractionated by centrifugation into pellet and soluble fractions.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	231	 CAL was found both in the pellet and soluble fractions (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	232	 2B) suggesting that CAL could associate with a membrane fraction.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	233	 To isolate further the sequences responsible for membrane association, we transfected various truncation constructs of GFP-tagged CAL into HEK293 cells and assayed again after subcellular fractionation.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	234	 GFP did not change the CAL membrane association (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	235	 CAL containing only the N-terminal domain and lacking both the coiled-coil and PDZ domains (CAL-N) was mostly within the soluble fraction and with some in the pellet (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	236	 CAL containing both the N-terminal and the coiled-coil domains but lacking a PDZ domain (CAL-N-CC) was found in the pelleted fraction (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	237	 CAL containing the PDZ and the C-terminal domains (CAL-PDZ-C) was soluble (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	238	 Although CAL has no predicted transmembrane sequences, the coiled-coil domains conferred membrane association, presumably by binding to resident Golgi coiled-coil proteins.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	239	CAL Binds to CFTR-- To test whether full-length CAL and CFTR interact in animal cells, COS-7 cells were transiently transfected with an N-terminal-tagged, full-length HA-CAL and GFP-CFTR (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	240	 GFP-CFTR has single-channel and whole-cell current properties indistinguishable from wild type CFTR (23).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	241	 3, HA-CAL and GFP-CFTR were co-immunoprecipitated by a GFP polyclonal antibody (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Removal of the last 3 amino acid residues of the full-length CFTR (GFP-CFTRTRL) substantially reduced the ability of the truncated CFTR to interact with CAL (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	243	 3A, lane 3), suggesting the importance of the extreme C-terminal PDZ binding motif.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	244	 The faint band in lane 3 suggests that other weak binding sites for CAL may exist in CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	245	To test further whether the PDZ-interacting domain of CFTR is important for the CAL CFTR interaction, we conducted studies using the C terminus of CFTR and the PDZ domain of CAL (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	246	 COS-7 cells were transfected with the HA-tagged PDZ domain of CAL (HA-CAL-PDZ, aa 216-404) and the myc-tagged C terminus of CFTR (myc-CFTR-C, aa 1387-1480).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	247	 HA-CAL-PDZ was co-immunoprecipitated with myc-CFTR-C using an anti-Myc antibody (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	248	 As a control, HA-CAL-PDZ was not immunoprecipitated by the Myc antibody in the absence of myc-CFTR-C (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	249	 Because truncation of C-terminal CFTR residues (TRL) abolishes the binding (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	250	 3A), and binding can occur between portions containing only the PDZ domain of CAL and the C terminus of CFTR (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	251	 3B), the PDZ domain-mediated interaction is both necessary and sufficient for the CAL CFTR interaction.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	252	To confirm that the C terminus of CFTR was involved in the interaction, we immobilized biotinylated peptides corresponding to the C-terminal 8 and 24 residues of CFTR on NeutrAvidin beads and incubated the peptides with whole cell lysates prepared from 16HBE14o cells.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	253	 The bound fractions were examined by Western blot using CAL antisera.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Endogenous CAL bound to the immobilized CFTR peptides (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	255	 3C, lanes 1 and 2) but not to a control peptide (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Because the last 8 residues of CFTR bind to CAL, the interaction is likely to be direct and not mediated through other proteins.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	257	To test whether CAL is present in a complex with CFTR in vivo, CFTR was immunoprecipitated from T84 cell lysates using an R-domain antibody from Genzyme and the precipitated fraction was analyzed by Western blotting using CAL antibody.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	258	 CAL was found in the CFTR immunoprecipitated fraction (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	259	 3D, lane 1) but not in the control fraction (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	260	 In a reciprocal experiment, CAL antisera also precipitated CFTR (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	261	 Taken together, these data suggest that CFTR and CAL associate in vivo.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	262	Golgi Localization of CAL-- Next, we examined the expression of native CAL by indirect immunofluorescence staining with rabbit anti-CAL antibodies.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	263	 In rat trachea, CAL immunostaining was seen in surface epithelium and submucosal glands (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	264	 The staining was bright in both acini (A) and the ducts (D) of submucosal glands (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	265	 CAL is predominantly localized in intracellular compartments of acinar cells and is weakly expressed in cytoplasm (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	266	 Under the same conditions, the pre-immune serum shows no significant staining (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	267	 To examine the subcellular localization of CAL, acinar cells were double-labeled with CAL antibodies and Golgi markers.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	268	 4 (d-f), CAL colocalized with trans-Golgi network marker TGN38.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	269	 CAL partially colocalizes with COP, a medial and cis-Golgi marker (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	270	 4, g-i) and 58K, a marker for ER-Golgi Intermediate Compartment (ERGIC; Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	271	 A similar staining pattern was observed in rat kidney cells (data not shown).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	272	View larger version (33K):    Fig.

0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	280	 Co-localization was visualized by image overlay (yellow).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	281	 Bars: in a, 50  microm; in c, 20  microm; and in l, 3  microm.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	282	To investigate the subcellular localization of CAL further, we examined the transiently transfected HA-tagged CAL using monoclonal HA.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	283	 In IB3 and MDCK cells, CAL, detected by a monoclonal antibody to the HA epitope tag, appeared predominantly in the juxtanuclear region as a single spot and overlapped with the expression of the trans-Golgi network (TGN) marker, -adaptin (Figs.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	284	 Some weak expression was observed in the cytoplasm.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Treatment with BFA is known to redistribute Golgi coat proteins to the cytosol (33).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	286	 In IB3 cells, BFA treatments (15 min) caused a redistribution of -adaptin and CAL to the cytoplasm (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	287	 BFA also caused a redistribution of CAL to the cytoplasm in 16HBE14o (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	288	 Endogenous CAL was found in the same subcellular localization when detected by anti-CAL antibody (data not shown).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	289	View larger version (24K):    Fig.

0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	301	CAL Reduces CFTR Cl Current-- To elucidate the functional consequence of CAL CFTR interaction, we examined how co-expression of CAL affects CFTR-mediated Cl conductance in COS-7 cells.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	302	 6 shows whole cell recordings and summary data measured using the whole cell patch clamp technique.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	303	 CFTR expressing cells were identified using GFP fluorescence.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	304	 6, A and B) produced cAMP-activated Cl currents typical of those we have shown previously for CFTR (23).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	305	 CFTR Cl currents were not observed in non-transfected or mock-transfected cells (data not shown).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	306	 Co-transfection of CFTR and CAL resulted in greatly reduced currents despite the expression of CFTR (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	307	 In parallel experiments, the presence of both GFP-CFTR and HA-CAL was verified to prove that green-fluorescing cells were co-transfected with both CFTR and CAL.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	308	 To test this outcome further, CFTR and CAL mRNA were injected into Xenopus oocytes.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	309	 In the absence of CAL, expression of CFTR mRNA resulted in cAMP-activated currents typical of CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	310	 No such currents were present in non-injected oocytes.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	311	 Co-expression of CAL clearly inhibited CFTR-mediated cAMP-activated Cl currents (data not shown).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	312	 These data show that CAL inhibits CFTR currents in both mammalian and Xenopus oocyte expression systems.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	313	View larger version (22K):    Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	314	   CAL affects CFTR Cl currents.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	315	 COS-7 cells were transfected with 1  microg of GFP-CFTR (A and B); 1  microg of GFP-CFTR and 3  microg of HA-CAL (C and D); 1  microg of GFP-CFTR, 3  microg of HA-CAL, and 1  microg of HA-NHE-RF (E and F).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	316	 Currents were measured by the whole cell patch clamp.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	317	 Typical recordings in which application of cpt-cAMP (250  microM) evoked chloride currents (A, C, and E) and the relationships of the steady-state current to the membrane voltage are shown (B, D, and F).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	318	 The cell was held at 0 mV, and 100-ms voltage steps were applied (100 through 100 mV, increments of 20 mV).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	319	 Open and solid circles indicate the basal and cpt-cAMP-stimulated current, respectively.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	320	 No cpt-cAMP-induced current responses were observed in mock transfected cells (data not shown).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	321	 The bar graph (G) shows the maximum deviations of the current from each basal level during stimulation with 250  microM cpt-cAMP for 1 min.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	322	 Values are presented as mean  plus or minus  S.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	323	01 versus CFTR + CAL (Dunnett's method).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	324	 The numbers of experiments are given in parentheses.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	325	CAL Alters the Surface Expression of CFTR-- Because the inhibition of whole cell currents by CAL could be caused either by a direct inhibition of Cl channel activity or by a reduction in CFTR channel number at the cell surface, we investigated the effect of CAL on CFTR protein expression at the cell surface.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	326	 First, we co-expressed HA-CAL and GFP-CFTR in COS-7 cells and examined how CAL affects plasma membrane expression of CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	327	 HA-CAL alone was detected primarily at the Golgi apparatus with some expression in the cytosol and near the plasma membrane (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	328	 Wild type GFP-CFTR alone was found at both the plasma membrane and the ER (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	329	 In cells co-expressing HA-CAL and GFP-CFTR, CFTR disappeared from the cell membrane and clustered in an intracellular location (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	330	 Moreover, CAL colocalized with CFTR in the same intracellular location (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	331	View larger version (14K):    Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	332	   Immunochemical characterization of CFTR and CAL interaction.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	333	 COS-7 cells were transfected with HA-CAL alone (a), GFP-CFTR alone (b), or co-transfected with CAL and GFP-CFTR (c, d, e), CAL was detected by monoclonal antibody to HA epitope (red).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	334	 CFTR was detected by GFP fluorescence (green).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	335	 Co-localization was visualized by image overlay (yellow).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	336	 Co-expression of CAL and CFTR results in the redistribution and complete colocalization of each protein into clusters.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	337	Next, we tested whether cell surface expression of GFP-CFTR in COS-7, as assessed by surface biotinylation, was altered by co-expression with HA-CAL.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	338	 Approximately 10% of CFTR was expressed at the cell surface 40-48 h post-transfection.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	339	 Overexpression of HA-CAL reduced the expression of GFP-CFTR at the cell surface (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	340	 The reduction becomes more pronounced with increasing amounts of HA-CAL (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	341	 In contrast, overexpression of HA-CAL had no effect on plasma membrane expression of GFP-CFTRTRL (data not shown).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	342	 To test whether overexpression of CAL causes a generalized suppression of membrane protein trafficking, we co-transfected COS-7 cells with HA-CAL and the vesicular stomatitis virus glycoprotein (VSVG), known to traffic to the plasma membrane through the cis-, medial, and trans-Golgi (34).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	343	 8C) had no effect in VSVG surface expression.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	344	 Likewise, CAL has no effect on P-glycoprotein surface expression, which like CFTR is an apical membrane protein (data not shown).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	345	 Taken together, these data show that inhibition of surface expression of CFTR by CAL is not cause by a nonspecific effect of protein overexpression.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	346	 These data demonstrate that CAL selectively inhibits the cell surface expression of CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	347	View larger version (52K):    Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	348	   CAL affects cell surface CFTR expression.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	349	 A, COS-7 cells were co-transfected with 3  microg of GFP-CFTR and various amounts of HA-CAL, HA-NHE-RF, and empty vector pRK5.

0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	362	 The cell lysates were analyzed using HA monoclonal antibody (bottom panel).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	363	 IP, immunoprecipitation; WB, Western blot.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	364	CAL Alters the Insertion of CFTR and the Half-life of CFTR in the Plasma Membrane-- To characterize the mechanism by which CAL suppresses the surface expression of CFTR, we conducted two sets of experiments.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	365	 First, we measured the rate of appearance of CFTR in the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	366	 COS-7 cells were transfected with GFP-CFTR and HA-CAL.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	367	 Two days later cells were labeled with 35S-Cys/Met (30 min) and chased for 0-120 min, and plasma membrane CFTR was detected by cell surface biotinylation.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	368	 CAL inhibits the expression of CFTR at the plasma membrane at least in part by decreasing the rate of appearance of CFTR in the plasma membrane (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	369	 Second, we examined the effect of CAL on the half-life of CFTR in the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	370	 COS-7 cells were transfected with GFP-CFTR and HA-CAL.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	371	 Two days later, cells were labeled with 35S-Cys/Met (3 h) and chased for 0-32 h, and plasma membrane CFTR was then detected by cell surface biotinylation.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	372	 CAL also decreased the half-life of CFTR in the plasma membrane (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	373	 These data suggest that CAL may interact with components near the cell surface in determining the expression of CFTR at the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	374	View larger version (33K):    Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	375	   CAL affects insertion of CFTR to the plasma membrane as well as its half-life in the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	376	 A, rate of CFTR appearance in the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	377	 COS-7 cells were transfected with GFP-CFTR (3  microg) or GFP-CFTR (3  microg) and HA-CAL (3  microg).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	378	 Two days later cells were labeled with 35S-Cys/Met (30 min) and chased for 0-120 min.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	379	 The figure presents the rate of appearance of 35S-labeled CFTR in plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	380	 All data are relative to the amount of CFTR in the plasma membrane at t = 0 (CFTR cells) and are the averages of two independent experiments.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	381	 B, half-life of CFTR in the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	382	 COS-7 cells were transfected with GFP-CFTR (3  microg) or GFP-CFTR (3  microg) and HA-CAL (3  microg).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	383	 Two days later plasma membrane proteins were biotinylated at t = 0, and cells were placed back into the incubator for 12, 24, or 32 h.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	384	 Proteins were analyzed by Western blot using GFP monoclonal antibody.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	385	The Roles of CAL and Other PDZ Domain Proteins in Determining Cell Surface CFTR Expression-- NHE-RF is a subplasma membrane PDZ domain protein that may anchor CFTR to the cytoskeleton.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	386	 To understand how PDZ domain proteins may work together in regulating CFTR trafficking and membrane organization, we examined the effect of overexpressing NHE-RF alone and co-expressing NHE-RF and CAL on CFTR cell surface expression.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	387	 Overexpression of HA-NHE-RF did not change the plasma membrane expression of GFP-CFTR (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	388	 Co-expression of HA-NHE-RF with HA-CAL, however, restored cell surface GFP-CFTR expression (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	389	 Whereas CAL overexpression inhibited CFTR currents (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	390	 6, C, D, and G), these too were restored when NHE-RF was expressed along with CAL and CFTR (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	391	 Addition of NHE-RF alone with CFTR did not affect CFTR currents (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	392	 It has been shown that NHE-RF under certain conditions can enhance the open probability of CFTR in excised patches, but this stimulation was diminished when expression of NHE-RF was high (19).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	393	 6, GFP-tagged CFTR and HA-tagged NHE-RF were cotransfected at a ratio of 1:1 (by weight).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	394	 We also co-transfected GFP-CFTR and NHE-RF at a ratio of 1:3 (by weight) and observed the same results (data not shown).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	395	 Clearly, the effect of NHE-RF on restoring CFTR currents in cells overexpressing CAL parallels the restoration of CFTR in the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	396	Because both CAL and NHE-RF bind to the same PDZ binding motif at the C terminus of CFTR, we tested whether NHE-RF competes with CAL in binding to CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	397	 We co-transfected HA-tagged CAL and NHE-RF together with GFP-CFTR into COS7 cells and immunoprecipitated GFP-CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	398	 Indeed, the binding of CAL to CFTR was substantially reduced by the co-expression of NHE-RF (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	399	 Densitometry analysis indicated that co-expression of NHE-RF reduced the binding of CAL to CFTR by ~70%.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	400	 The ratio of CAL to NHE-RF was about 1:4.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	401	3 in the lysate of cells that co-express these two proteins (lane 3, bottom panel).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	402	 These data suggest that NHE-RF reverses the inhibitory effect of CAL by competing with CAL for the binding of CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	403	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	404	We identified a Golgi CFTR-interacting protein, CAL, that plays a role in regulating the plasma membrane expression of CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	405	 CAL is the first PDZ domain protein identified that regulates the trafficking of CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	406	 Biochemical evidence suggests that CAL can exist as a multimer that is mediated by domains in the N-terminal region.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	407	 CAL can form clusters of CFTR within the cell when overexpressed, suggesting that multimers of CAL may tether more than one CFTR within the cell as a mechanism to regulate export to the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	408	 This is consistent with data that overexpression of CAL suppresses CFTR expression at the cell surface.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	409	 In contrast to its effect on CFTR, CAL does not affect VSVG surface expression (see Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	410	 8C) or of P-glycoprotein expression, proteins that sort to the plasma membrane but do not have C-terminal PDZ interacting domains.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	411	 CAL also does not affect surface expression of CFTRTRL, eliminating the possibility that the inhibition of surface expression is due simply to the nonspecific effect of protein overexpression.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	412	 Thus, the role of CAL is restricted to proteins such as CFTR with C-terminal, PDZ domains capable of binding CAL.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	413	 Given the wide distribution of CAL in many tissues, it is likely that CAL can regulate the surface expression of molecules other than CFTR as long as they have a C-terminal domain capable of binding to CAL.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	414	 Although CAL is located primarily located within the Golgi, it is also found at the plasma membrane where it may also function (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	415	CAL contains two putative coiled-coil domains that play a role in membrane association.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	416	 Coiled-coil domains are found in SNARE proteins and a large number of Golgi resident proteins.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	417	 Recently, it has been shown that CAL can bind to the Q-SNARE protein syntaxin 6, a protein whose primary function is unknown (31).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	418	 It is likely that the coiled-coil domains of CAL may mediate interactions with multiple Golgi proteins.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	419	CAL overexpression also reduces the rate of appearance of CFTR in the plasma membrane suggesting that CAL may reduce the anterograde trafficking of CFTR to the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	420	 CAL also reduces the half-life of CFTR in the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	421	 There are at least two possible scenarios to explain how CAL may interact with CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	422	 First, CAL may be part of an anterograde trafficking complex that controls CFTR movement from ER to Golgi and to the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	423	 CAL with two coiled-coil domains may tether CFTR to the Golgi as a requisite step in moving CFTR to the cell surface.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	424	 The overexpression of CAL may disrupt the stoichiometry of such an anterograde trafficking complex and favor retention of the CAL CFTR complex in the Golgi.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	425	 Second, CAL may also regulate the retrograde trafficking of CFTR from the Golgi to ER and perhaps promote the recycling of CFTR to the ER for degradation.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	426	 Thus CAL, like the PDZ protein GRASP 55/65, may play a role in vesicle budding and cargo selection in ER to Golgi and Golgi to membrane transport (35, 36).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	427	 8a, overexpression of CAL enhances the ER-localized, immature, and core-glycosylated form of CFTR (band B), which is localized to the ER.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	428	If the role of CAL is to tether CFTR to the Golgi, then what promotes CFTR trafficking to the plasma membrane? Clearly, the majority of CAL is located within the Golgi, yet some is also found near the plasma membrane (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	429	 Also, membrane-biotinylated CFTR can be co-immunoprecipitated with CAL (data not shown) indicating that some CAL CFTR complexes do travel to the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	430	 Unlike CAL, other PDZ domain proteins such as NHE-RF and E3KARP are associated with the plasma membrane (12), suggesting that they play a key role in the function of CFTR at the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	431	 Our data show that, when CAL is overexpressed, CFTR trafficking to the plasma membrane is reduced but that suppression can be reversed by NHE-RF.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	432	 We hypothesize that, because CAL is more abundant in the Golgi, binding of CFTR to CAL may be favored.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	433	 As a CAL CFTR complex traffics to the plasma membrane where NHE-RF is abundant, CFTR may then bind to NHE-RF, which tethers CFTR to the actin-based cytoskeleton.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	434	 This tethering of CFTR to the plasma membrane increases the half-life of CFTR in the plasma membrane resulting in the apical polarization of CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	435	2 Overexpression of CAL increases its expression both in the Golgi and at the plasma membrane (data not shown), shifting the stoichiometry of the interaction of the CFTR with NHE-RF toward CAL and decreasing the half-life of CFTR in the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	436	 Our data answer a critical question as to why more than one PDZ domain protein interacts with CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	437	 At least for CAL and NHE-RF, we show that both are concentrated in different locations within the cell and only transiently interact, most likely within the plasma membrane, to regulate the surface expression of CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	438	 Thus, this regulation by two or more PDZ domain proteins may allow for the precise regulation of CFTR surface expression.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	439	Other membrane proteins are found to bind to multiple PDZ domain proteins.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	440	 For example, the C termini of the GluR2/3 subunits of AMPA receptors bind to both GRIP/ABP, which contains 7 PDZ domains (37), and to PICK1, which contains a single PDZ domain as well as a domain that interacts with protein kinase C (38).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	441	 Phosphorylation of the C terminus of GluR2 by protein kinase C prevents its binding to GRIP but not to PICK1, which may contribute to the protein kinase C-induced rapid internalization of surface GluR2 subunits (39).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	442	 Likewise, the C terminus of the 1-adrenergic receptor binds to a pair of PDZ proteins, PSD-95 and MAGI-2 (40, 41).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	443	 Although the agonist-induced internalization of the 1-adrenergic receptor is attenuated by PSD-95 co-expression, it is markedly increased by co-expression with MAGI-2 (41).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	444	 These reports, as well as our present findings, support the notion that multiple PDZ domain proteins interact with the same short C terminus of a membrane protein to regulate its function.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	445	The precise mechanism of how CAL may hand off CFTR to NHE-RF remains unknown.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	446	 It is not clear whether it is driven strictly by mass balance, by affinity, or by a combination of these two.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	447	 In our co-expression system, NHE-RF expression is ~4.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	448	 Under these conditions, NHE-RF may sufficiently compete with CAL for CFTR binding strictly by mass action.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	449	 Immunofluorescence localization studies suggested that CFTR is present in both the apical membrane and in the subapical vesicles (42).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	450	 These findings were confirmed by cryoimmunogold electron microscopy (43).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	451	 The translocation of CFTR from the intracellular pool to the plasma membrane may be regulated by protein kinase A as observed by some investigators (44, 45) but not by others (23, 46).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	452	 It is possible that CAL may pass CFTR off to NHE-RF in the subapical vesicles.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	453	 If so, it is important to determine the endogenous levels of CAL, NHE-RF and other CFTR binding proteins in these locations, as well as their relative affinity to CFTR in native tissues that express CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	454	 It is likely that these data, together with their regulation by protein kinase A and/or other physiological and pathophysiological stimuli, will provide a more comprehensive understanding of CFTR trafficking and its regulation in different native tissues.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	455	In summary, we have identified a novel CFTR-interacting protein, CAL, that plays a role in the surface expression of CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	456	 Recent evidence suggests that some F508 CFTR escapes from the ER and into the early secretory pathway.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	457	 Understanding the role of interacting proteins such as CAL in CFTR trafficking may prove useful in devising strategies to increase the plasma membrane expression of F508 CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	458	 The wide tissue distribution of CAL suggests that it may be important for trafficking of other ion channels and receptors with C-terminal sequences similar to that of CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	459	 Hubbard, and Peying Fong for critical reading of this manuscript.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	460	* This work was supported by Cystic Fibrosis Foundation Research Development Programs (to W.
