0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	164	 The human, cynomolgus, gibbon, squirrel monkey, rabbit, pig, sheep and cow sequences were aligned using the ClustalW global alignment tool (http://clustalw.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	165	 The gap open and extension penalties were set at 15 and 6.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	166	66, respectively, and sequence delay divergence of 30% with a DNA transition weight of 0.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	167	   RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   CFTR minimal promoter region encompassing the CFTR-CArG-like element is remarkably conserved To search the cis-acting elements involved in the CFTR gene expression regulation, we previously performed an in silico search for transcription factor binding sites (46), and reported that the human minimal CFTR promoter contains a CArG-like motif, which is localized  to 108 bp upstream of the major transcription initiation start site (38).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Because so far all described CArG-box elements were found in the regulatory regions of immediate early genes (47) and in muscle-specific genes (22), we confirmed our first binding site prediction by using two other algorithms, AliBaba (http://www.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	169	com/) and ConSite (http://clustalw.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	170	 As shown in Figure 1A, the CFTR-CArG-like element sequence (GC(A/T)6GG) diverges slightly at the 5' from the published SRF consensus sequence (CC(A/T)6GG) (22,37).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	171	 However, this divergence is similar to that observed in the smooth muscle-gamma-actin promoter which has been demonstrated to bind SRF (48).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	172	View larger version (29K):    Figure 1 Cross-species comparison of the CFTR-CArG-like element.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	173	 (A) Visualization of consensus CArG binding site: pop-up window containing information about SRF transcription factor obtained from in silico analysis performed with the ConSite tool.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	174	 (B) Detailed alignment view of the CArG-like element-including region of human CFTR minimal promoter with seven orthologous sequences: Cynomolgus, Gibbon, Squirrel Monkey, Rabbit, Pig, Sheep and Cow.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Dashes indicate gaps that were introduced to maximize alignment.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Each sequence is represented by a classical text representation with each nucleotide assigned its own color (A is colored in red, C in blue, G in green and T in black).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	177	 The numberings above the Cynomolgus sequence are indicated according to the major human transcription initiation site.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	178	 In the left panel, the phylogenetic relationships between the different species are illustrated in a rooted tree, directly derived from ClustalW program.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	179	 In the right panel, human/species homologies are indicated.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	180	 The accession number of each CFTR genomic sequence is indicated below each species name, in brackets and bold characters.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	181	 The human CFTR-CArG-like motif is noted above the Cynomolgus sequence.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	182	  To assess the putative functional importance of CFTR-CArG-like binding site, we used an orthogonal approach of deducing regulatory elements by considering orthologous CFTR minimal promoter regions from several mammalian species representing the Primates, Artiodactylia and Lagomorpha orders.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Comparison of human/species homologies was carried out using ClustalW multiple CFTR sequence alignments according to the numerous alignment parameters described previously (49).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Consistent with previous studies (50,51), we showed that the human minimal CFTR promoter is remarkably conserved across the orders studied (Figure 1B, right panel).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	185	 We found that the CFTR-CArG-like element is conserved within all the Primates species studied and also within the pig while, within the sheep, cow and rabbit species, some substitutions occur in the middle of the CArG-like motif (Figure 1B).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	186	 These data are consistent with previous CFTR promoter phylogenetic work that identified two types of regulatory elements: some are conserved between species, such as a non-consensus CRE at positions  to 0.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	187	1 kb relative to ATG and some are species-specific elements, such as a 300 bp purine.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	188	Py) stretch that is present only in rodents (50).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	189	Bronchial epithelial expression of SRF Because we could not previously identify SRF binding to the CFTR CArG-like element, even though an anti-SRF antibody had been used (12), we asked whether SRF, mainly described as highly expressed in muscle cells, was also present in epithelial cell lines.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	190	 To measure the expression levels of SRF mRNAs, we used a RT to PCR-based procedure previously described by Davis et al.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	191	 As reverse-transcribed control, the Hypoxanthine PhosphoRybosyl-Transferase (HPRT) housekeeping gene was amplified.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Amplification of SRF from bronchial epithelial cells and myoblasts yielded a fragment of the same size, 651 bp (Figure 2A), as that of the full-length SRF transcript produced by RT to PCR from human hearts (52).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	193	 The 453 bp band corresponding to SRF lacking exon 5 (SRF5) was only detected in the C2C12 myoblast line (Figure 2A).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	194	 To ensure that these bands were not the result of a PCR artifact or genomic contamination of samples, negative controls such as exclusion of RT or RNA during cDNA synthesis were included in each assay.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	195	 As expected, no PCR product appeared when either RT or the template was omitted (Figure 2A).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Densitometric analysis revealed that bronchial epithelial cells contained an appreciable amount of SRF mRNA.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Nuclear extracts from A549, Beas2B and C2C12 cells were electrophoresed and then assayed by western blotting with anti-SRF antibody reported to recognize all four isoforms of the protein (52).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	198	 As shown in Figure 2B, we found that robust expression of a 67 kDa band, that based on molecular mass, corresponds to full-length SRF (SRF-FL) in all of the cell lines examined.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Consistent wit RT to PCR analysis, a 57 kDa band corresponding to SRF5 was only detected in the C2C12 myoblast line.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	200	 As a control, we checked the ss-actin levels (Figure 2B).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Densitometric analysis of western blot revealed no apparent difference in the expression level of SRF proteins between the myoblasts and epithelial cells (Figure 2B).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	202	 In subsequent western blot analyses in which parallel blots were probed with only the secondary antibody, no band was detected (data not shown), thus confirming that these bands are indeed specific for SRF.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	203	 As further evidence, A549, Beas2B and C2C12 cells express relatively large amounts of SRF, the cell lines were assessed by indirect immunofluorescence labeling.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	204	 A similar staining pattern was noted in the bronchial epithelial cells and myoblasts (Figure 2C, rows A to C).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	205	 The nuclei have been stained blue with DAPI.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	206	 As negative control, no staining was detected when the primary antibody was omitted (Figure 2C, row D).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Consistent with other studies reporting that SRF is ubiquitously expressed in a variety of cell types (26,27,53), our SRF expression studies demonstrated that human SRF gene is expressed in bronchial epithelial cells.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	208	View larger version (25K):    Figure 2 Bronchial epithelial expression of SRF.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	209	 (A) Detection of SRF and HPRT transcripts from both bronchial epithelial and myoblast cell lines by RT to PCR analysis.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Total RNAs isolated from A549, Beas2B and C2C12 cells, as indicated, were reverse transcribed with random hexamers and PCR amplified with SRF or HPRT primers.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Amplified products were directly stained with bromide ethidium on non-denaturing polyacrylamide gel.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Expected size of PCR products is given at left of each transcript.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Negative controls are noted as follow: No RT for the absence of reverse transcriptase and No RNA for an H2O no-template reaction.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Densitometric analysis of SRF bands intensity was performed with relative HPRT mRNA expression in C2C12 myoblasts.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	215	 (B) Western blot analysis of nuclear extracts prepared from both epithelial and myoblast lines.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Each extract (25  microg) was separated by SDS/PAGE (10%) and western blotted using an anti-SRF Ab.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Relative mass, in kilodaltons, is indicated alongside.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	218	 As a control for proteins loading in SDS to PAGE, an anti ss-actin Ab was used in western blot.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Numbers below the ss-actin panel indicate densitometric values of the total SRF bands normalized over the corresponding ss-actin bands and expressed relative to the C2C12 controls bands, which are set to 1.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	220	 (C) The A549, Beas2B and C2C12 cells (rows A, B and C, respectively) were grown on coverslips, fixed and subjected to indirect immunofluorescence with anti-SRF Ab.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Left panel, cells were stained with FITC-conjugated secondary antibody (green).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Middle panel, cells were counterstained with DAPI (blue) for nuclear staining.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Right panel, shown is merge of SRF immunostaining and DAPI.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Row D, background immunofluorescence obtained in the absence of the primary antibody.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	225	  SRF binds the CFTR-CArG-like element Because the CArG box is not only found in the regulatory regions of many muscle-specific genes but also located at the center of other SREs (54) and forms the core binding site for SRF (55), we have attempted to determine whether or not SRF binds to the CFTR-CArG-like element sequence.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	226	 We performed two series of bandshift experiments.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	227	 First, we incubated the 32P-labelLed WT oligonucleotide corresponding to CFTR-CArG-like element sequence (as indicated in Table 2) with bacterially expressed SRF.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	228	 As shown in Figure 3A (lane 3), EMSA revealed a recombinant SRF to WT duplex.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	229	 As shown in Figure 3A (lane 5), bands defined as the CFTR-CArG-like-SRF complex disappeared when 100-fold molar excess of specific competitor containing the consensus SRE motif, derived from human c-fos promoter (56), was added.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	230	 In contrast, competition by an irrelevant oligonucleotide (noted UC) did not appear to significantly alter the complex suggesting specificity of binding (lane 6).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	231	 To confirm precisely the identity of protein binding in the minimal CFTR promoter (from  to 121 to  to 83 bp), bacterially expressed SRF was preincubated with anti-SRF antibody before incubation with 32P-labelled probe.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	232	 As shown in Figure 3A (lane 4), bands corresponding to CFTR-CArG-like-SRF complex disappeared, and more slowly migrating bands appeared when anti-SRF antibody was added.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	233	 To verify the antibody specificity, control experiments were performed either in the absence of the SRF protein (Figure 3A, lane 7) or in the presence of an irrelevant antibody (Figure 3A, lane 8).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	234	 These results demonstrate that the CFTR-CArG-like element is a bona fide SRF-binding site.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Second, we performed additional EMSA with the WT oligonucleotide, as main binding target, and nuclear extracts from both epithelial and muscle cells (Figure 3B).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	236	 While three nucleoprotein complexes were formed from nuclear extracts of Beas2B and C2C12 cells on the WT probe, five complexes were detected from A549 cells.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Each nuclear protein complex was designated by an upper case relative to nuclear lysate followed by a Roman numeral indicating its position into the gels.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	238	 The binding specificity of the different complexes was examined by competition analyses with both specific and non-specific unlabeled oligonucleotides (Figure 3B, lanes 2 to 4).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Although a few non-specific binding activities were observed, complexes BII, BIII, AIII, AV, CI, CII and CIII were efficiently competed with an excess of both WT and c-fos SRE unlabeled specific competitors indicating binding specificity (Figure 3B, lanes 2 and 3, respectively).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Control experiments including an irrelevant oligonucleotide did not reveal any change in electrophoretic profiles (Figure 3B, lanes 4).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	241	 To evaluate whether the SRF protein contributes to the formation of nucleoprotein complexes interacting with the CFTR-derived SRF site, we used a specific antibody against the SRF protein.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Although the incubation with the anti-SRF antibody apparently failed to give any discrete supershift from various sources of nuclear proteins, a significant decrease of specific complexes was observed (Figure 3B, lanes 6).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	243	 This effect seemed to be specific because none of these nuclear protein complexes was supershifted or abolished when a non-specific antibody was used (Figure 3B, lanes 7).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	244	 Control experiments containing only the anti-SRF antiserum and the radiolabeled WT oligonucleotide did not reveal any binding activities (Figure 3B, lanes 8).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	245	 In addition, supershift assays performed with the radiolabeled c-fos SRE oligonucleotide instead of the WT probe showed that bands corresponding to SRE to SRF complex disappeared and more slowly migrating bands appeared (Figure 3B, lane 10).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	246	 The absence of supershift for specific WT binding complexes (Figure 3D, lanes 6) may be explained if the epitope recognized by the anti-SRF antibody is part of (or located near) the CFTR-CArG-like DNA-binding site.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	247	 Antibody binding would compete DNA binding, resulting in a significant decrease or total disappearance of CArG-like complexes rather than in supershifted complexes.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Alternatively, if the interaction between the CFTR-CArG-like DNA-binding site and the SRF protein is insufficiently strong, it could be not as stable as the one observed with the SRE probe (Figure 3B, lane 10) to be detected as a supershift in gel retardation assays.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	249	 On the one hand, other DNA-binding proteins that are potentially part of this complex could interfere with the antibody's access to SRF protein.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Taken together, these EMSA studies establish SRF-binding CArG-like box within the minimal promoter of the human CFTR gene.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	251	View larger version (36K):    Figure 3 SRF is a component of CFTR-CArG-like binding complexes.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	252	 (A) EMSAs were performed with a radiolabeled oligonucleotide encompassing the studied CFTR-CArG-like motif (noted WT, see Table 2) and bacterially expressed SRF (lane 3).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Competition assays were carried out using a 100-fold molar excess of two specific competitors, noted WT and SRE (lanes 2 and 5, respectively).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	254	 UC (lane 6) indicates unspecific competitor that is used as negative control.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Supershift assays were carried out using either a specific antibody (lane 4) or an irrelevant antibody (lane 8).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	256	 The arrow SS indicates the Ab-supershifted complex.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	257	 Neither the retarded nor the supershifted complexes were found when the 32P-labeled WT double-stranded oligonucleotide was incubated either only with the binding buffer (lane 1) or with specific anti-SRF antibody in the absence of purified SRF protein (lane 7).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	258	 (B) EMSAs were performed with WT 32P-labeled probe in the absence of proteins (lanes 1) or with nuclear extracts (lanes 5) isolated from Beas2B (upper panel), A549 (middle panel) and C2C12 cells (lower panel).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Three or five nuclear protein complexes were detected and designated by a cell type-dependent upper-case to the left of autoradiograms.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Some binding reaction mixtures included a 100-fold molar excess of the indicated cold probes (lanes 2 to 4).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	261	 Immunologic assays were performed with either anti-SRF Ab (lanes 6), or anti-HA as irrelevant antiserum (lanes 7).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	262	 As a control, the 32P-labeled WT probe was incubated with anti-SRF Ab without nuclear extracts (lanes 8).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	263	 In additional control experiments, radiolabeled SRE double-stranded oligonucleotide corresponding to the SRE binding site of the c-fos promoter was subjected to EMSAs with nuclear extracts from Beas2B cells (upper panel) in the absence (lane 9) or presence of anti-SRF antiserum (lane 10).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	264	 Nuclear protein complexes that were significantly decreased or supershifted with anti-SRF Ab are indicated.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	265	  SRF binds the CArG-like motif of the CFTR minimal promoter within intact chromatin under physiological conditions Although there is extensive evidence that SRF can bind to CArG-like elements in in vitro assays and that it is involved in transcriptional regulation through CArG elements in reporter assays in cultured cells with a typical epithelioid morphology (53), there is a lack of direct evidence for involvement of SRF in transcription of the endogenous CFTR gene within the context of intact chromatin.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	266	 To directly address whether SRF also binds in vivo, ChIP was carried out in bronchial epithelial cells.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	267	 For this purpose, DNA-binding proteins of Beas2B epithelial cells were covalently linked to genomic DNA by treatment of the cells with formaldehyde.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	268	 Cross-linked chromatin was immunoprecipitated with either specific or irrelevant antibodies, anti-SRF and anti-HA, respectively.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	269	 The precipitated chromatin DNA was then purified and amplified by PCR with specific primers of the target sequences (Table 1).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	270	 The promoter of ss-globin gene, which lacks CArG elements, was used as negative control (Figure 4, row A).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	271	 The skeletal ss-actin promoter sequence, which contains at least a consensus SRF-binding site, was used as positive control (Figure 4, row B).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	272	 As expected, PCR signals were obtained when the DNA/protein adducts were immunoprecipitated with an anti-SRF antibody from both Beas2B (Figure 4, rows B and C, lane 1) and A549 (data not shown) epithelial cell lines.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	273	 In contrast, the negative controls, in which immunoprecipitation was performed with an irrelevant antibody (Figure 4, rows A to C, lane 3) or without antibody (Figure 4, rows A to C, lane 2), did not show any PCR signal.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	274	 These results were reproduced in several independently isolated ChIP populations.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	275	 These data show that the CFTR-CArG-like binding site identified within the CFTR minimal promoter binds SRF in vivo, in bronchial cell lines.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	276	View larger version (14K):    Figure 4 ChIP analysis of SRF binding to the endogenous CFTR minimal promoter.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Chromatin immunoprecipitation was carried out as described in Materials and Methods.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	278	 Sheared DNA/protein complexes were immunoprecipitated by using either an anti-SRF Ab or an irrelevant anti-HA Ab.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Then, PCR was carried out to detect the endogenous CArG regions in immunoprecipitated chromatin fragments.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	280	 Target promoter sequences are indicated as follow: row A, ss-globin; row B, ss-actin; row C, CFTR.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	281	 Lane 1 shows amplification of target sequences in immunoprecipitated chromatin fragments with anti-SRF Ab.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Lanes 2 and 3: PCR amplification of control samples, without Ab or with an irrelevant Ab.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	283	 Lane 4 shows amplification of 1:100 dilution samples of total input DNA for immunoprecipitation.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	284	  The human minimal CFTR promoter shows activity in both epithelial and muscular cells As the SRF transcription factor is thought to mainly mediate the tissue-specific transcription in muscular cells, we first assessed the activity of the minimal CFTR promoter in both epithelial and muscular cell types.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	285	 We therefore addressed the ability of the WT-pGL3 construct, previously described (12) to drive the expression in Beas2B, A549 and C2C12 cells.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	286	 As shown in Figure 5A, an efficient transcription of the CFTR promoter could be readily observed in all three cell lines compared with monkey kidney fibroblasts (COS-7), which are negative for CFTR expression (36,37).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	287	 Surprisingly, the activity of the minimal CFTR promoter in C2C12 cells was 4 to 5.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	288	5 times higher than that observed in Beas2B and A549 cells, respectively.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	289	 Although the expression of the CFTR protein was previously evidenced in some muscle cells (57 to 59), it has never been investigated in mouse C2C12 myoblasts.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	290	 Therefore, we investigated the CFTR expression at both mRNA and protein levels.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	291	 To examine CFTR mRNA expression in mouse myoblasts (C2C12), total RNA isolated from epithelial and non-epithelial cells was analyzed via RT to PCR with CFTR-specific primers (Table 1).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	292	 As shown in Figure 5B, while no PCR product for CFTR was seen with COS-7 cells, the expected CFTR amplified product was obtained for both epithelial (A549 and Beas2B) and muscular (C2C12) cell lines.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	293	 No product was detected in the absence of reverse transcriptase or RNA (noted No RT or No RNA, respectively).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	294	 Although the HPRT PCR control showed non-equivalent amounts of cDNA used in the different PCRs, densitometric analysis revealed that C2C12 cells contained an appreciable amount of CFTR mRNA.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	295	 Further determination of CFTR expression in C2C12 myoblasts was conducted by western blot analysis (Figure 5C).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	296	 Caco-2 cells were used as positive control and COS-7 as negative control.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	297	 As shown in Figure 5C, while mature fully glycosylated band C CFTR was observed in A549, Beas2B and C2C12 cells, the core glycosylated band B CFTR occurred at the same molecular mass only in a subset of cell lines, indicative of potential variations in glycosylation process.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	298	 To rule out the possibility of antibodies cross-reactivity or non-specific labeling, indirect immunofluorescence analysis was performed with another anti-CFTR antibody, L12B4 (Figure 5D).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	299	 As expected, the Caco-2 cell line used as a positive control showed strong immunoreactivity for CFTR protein (Figure 5D, row D).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	300	 In contrast, and as expected, COS-7 cells used as negative control did not stain with this anti-CFTR antibody (Figure 5D, row E).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	301	 No staining was detected when the primary antibody was omitted (Figure 5D, row F).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	302	 The comparison of immunofluorescence images between epithelial (Figure 5D, row A, B and D) and muscular (Figure 5D, row C) cells provides evidence that CFTR is significantly expressed in C2C12 myoblasts.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	303	 However, because the indirect immunofluorescence experiments were performed in permeabilized cells, they do not distinguish between CFTR that is located in the apical membrane and CFTR that is located in a vesicular pool just beneath the apical membrane.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	304	 These findings, together with the transcriptional activities presented above, suggest that the minimal CFTR promoter might contain tissue-specific enhancer(s) as well as repressive cis-regulatory elements that have the ability to mitigate the activity of the CFTR promoter between epithelial and non-epithelial lineages.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	305	 Because CF affects mainly epithelial tissues and Beas2B consistently yielded higher enhancer activity than A549, we restricted subsequent studies to this bronchial epithelial cell line.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	306	View larger version (25K):    Figure 5 Analysis of CFTR minimal promoter activity and CFTR expression.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	307	 (A) CFTR minimal promoter activities in Beas2B, A549, C2C12 and COS-7 cell lines.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	308	8  microg of WT-pGL3 construct was co-transfected together with 0.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	309	2  microg of internal control pRL-SV40 containing Renilla luciferase.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	310	 The empty pGL3-Basic vector was transfected as a negative control.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	311	 Normalized luciferase values are illustrated as relative light units.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	312	 The mean of two independent plasmids preps and each experiment with standard errors is shown.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	313	 The experimental value for luciferase activity represented the mean  plus or minus  SD of four separate experiments in triplicates.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	314	 (B) RT to PCR analysis of CFTR mRNA expression.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	315	 Total RNA was harvested from the indicated cell lines and subjected to PCR as described in  Materials and Methods .
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	316	 cDNA derived from COS-7 was used as a negative control.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	317	 Samples without reverse transcriptase (noted No RT) or with an H2O no-template reaction (noted No RNA) were used as additional negative controls.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	318	 Samples were also amplified for HPRT to control for RNA degradation during DNase treatment and reverse transcription.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	319	 Densitometric analysis of CFTR bands intensity was performed with relative HPRT mRNA expression in Beas2B bronchial epithelial cells.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	320	 Whole cell proteins extracts prepared from indicated cells were subjected to electrophoresis with 7% SDS to PAGE gel and transferred to supported PVDF membrane.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	321	 CFTR immunoreactivity was detected using 24.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	322	1 anti-CFTR Ab as the primary antibody.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	323	 Positions for the core glycosylated (band B) and mature fully glycosylated CFTR (band C) are indicated by the arrows at the right.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	324	 Numbers below the ss-actin panel indicate intensity values of integrated optical densities of the mature and immature CFTR bands normalized over the corresponding ss-actin bands and expressed relative to the Beas2B controls bands, which are set to 1.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	325	 (D) Indirect immunofluorescence analysis.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	326	 The A549, Beas2B, C2C12, Caco-2 and COS-7 cells (rows A to E, respectively) were fixed, permeabilized, and then stained with the L12B4 anti-CFTR Ab, followed by the appropriate secondary antibody as described in  Materials and Methods .
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	327	 Left panel, cells were stained with Cy3-conjugated secondary antibody (red).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	328	 Middle panel, cells were counterstained with DAPI (blue) for nuclear staining.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	329	 Right panel, shown is merge of CFTR immunostaining and DAPI.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	330	 Row F, Background immunofluorescence obtained in the absence of the primary antibody.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	331	  Effects of SRF on the proximal CFTR promoter To assess whether SRF protein might affect CFTR transcriptional regulation, we took two related approaches.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	332	 First, we co-transfected either exogenous full-length SRF or truncated SRF mutants with the wild-type CFTR minimal promoter.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	333	 Second, we utilized a siRNA approach to ask whether a reduction in endogenous SRF levels could affect basal CFTR activation.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	334	 Luciferase assays were carried out in Beas2B cells using the indicated SRF expression vectors and the WT-pGL3luciferase reporter construct (Figure 6B, left panel).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	335	 The 3XSRE-fos TATA-Luciferase reporter gene was used as positive control because its transcriptional activity is highly dependent on SRF binding (Figure 6B, right panel).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	336	 As expected, while this synthetic promoter containing several consensus SREs was markedly and significantly activated ( > 2-fold) by forced expression of full-length SRF protein (pHiv-SRF) (Figure 6B, right panel), truncated SRF mutants either containing only the amino acids 133 to 264 corresponding to DNA-binding domain of SRF (pHiv-DBD-SRF), or deleted of amino acids 153 to 165, an essential part for the DNA binding (pHiv-DN-SRF) induced modest but significant decrease of SRE activity (10% and 30%, respectively).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	337	 When these SRF expression vectors were transiently co-transfected with the WT-pGL3 luciferase reporter construct, the trans-activator effect of SRF was notably reduced.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	338	 Indeed, overexpression of full-length and dominant-negative (pHiv-DN-SRF) SRF proteins resulted in 50% increased and 30% decreased of luciferase activity, respectively (Figure 6B, left panel).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	339	 Unexpectedly and inconsistent with previous study (60), the pHiv-DBD-SRF construct induced 40% increase of the WT-pGL3 luciferase activity.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	340	 This results disparity may be explained by the fact that the c-fos promoter study (60) assessed the DBD to SRF domain activity via microinjection of corresponding truncated SRF polypeptide.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	341	 Perhaps, the best explanation for this increased activity is that the DNA-binding domain of SRF, also called MADS box, is sufficient for transcriptional activation of some SRF-dependent genes because it mediates interactions with accessory co-activators (61).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	342	 These results suggest that neither of the regions outside the MADS box, N- or C-terminal, appear essential for transactivation of the CFTR promoter by SRF.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	343	View larger version (24K):    Figure 6 Effect of SRF on the activity of CArG-containing CFTR minimal promoter.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	344	 (A) Schematic representation of different SRF constructs analyzed.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	345	 The SRF fragments shown were cloned into the pHiv expression vector as indicated in  Materials and Methods .
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	346	 The position of the MADS box containing the DNA-binding domain and dimerization domain of SRF is depicted by black rectangle.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	347	 WT SRF construct encodes a human full-length SRF open reading frame.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	348	 DBD SRF construct encodes only the DNA-binding domain of SRF.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	349	 DN SRF deletion construct encodes full-length SRF deleted of an essential part for the DNA binding.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	350	 (B) Expression of exogenous SRF in Beas2B cells.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	351	 Cells were co-transfected with the WT-pGL3 luciferase reporter plasmid (left panel) together with the empty pHiv vector, pHiv-SRF, pHiv-DBD-SRF or pHiv-DN-SRF constructs, as indicated below the bar diagram.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	352	 As a positive control, 3XSRE luciferase reporter plasmid was used.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	353	 In each experiment, a Renilla luciferase expression plasmid was included to normalize for transfection efficiency.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	354	 For each reporter plasmid, luciferase activity (mean  plus or minus  SE) is derived from 4 to 7 different transfection experiments performed in triplicate.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	355	 The errors bars indicate the standard deviations.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	356	 The luciferase activity value 100 was assigned to the samples co-transfected with the indicated reporter plasmid and the empty pHiv expression vector.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	357	 Statistical significance is referred to differences with the activity obtained with empty expression vector.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	358	 (C) Effects of SRF siRNA on CFTR promoter activity and expression in Beas2B epithelial cells.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	359	 Left panel: Beas2B cells were co-transfected with either human control siRNA vector or plasmid encoding SRF siRNA as indicated.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	360	 Forty-eight hours following transfection, total proteins were harvested and analyzed by western blotting.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	361	 Densitometric analysis showed a substantial decrease of endogenous SRF.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	362	 Right panel: the luciferase activity value 100 was assigned to the samples co-transfected with the control siRNA.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	363	  To further establish the role of SRF in mediating the increase in CFTR gene transcription, we performed siRNA experiments (Figure 6C).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	364	 To demonstrate the efficacy of specific SRF siRNA construct, Beas2B cells were co-transfected with either control or SRF siRNA plasmids and western blots were performed to analyze levels of SRF in these cells.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	365	 Densitometric analysis of western blot showed that endogenous SRF levels were strongly reduced in the presence of the SRF siRNA plasmid (Figure 6C, left panel).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	366	 Then, control and SRF siRNA plasmids were co-transfected into Beas2B cells with either the WT-pGL3 or the 3XSRE luciferase reporter construct.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	367	 As shown in Figure 6C (right panel), reduction of endogenous SRF protein level decreased the activity of both wild-type CFTR promoter and 3XSRE-fos TATA-Luciferase reporter constructs by 25%.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	368	Taken together, these findings indicate that endogenous SRF into bronchial epithelial cells normally function as transcriptional coactivator for the CArG-mediated transactivation.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	369	 However, we found that SRF activated the CFTR promoter less well than the SRE-containing synthetic promoter, suggesting that the CArG-like element mediated CFTR transcriptional activation probably required other bridging or co-activating factors.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	370	The CArG-like element contained in the human minimal CFTR promoter is important but not sufficient for basal transcriptional activity in Beas2B cells To assess the transcriptional relevance of the CArG-like binding sequence of CFTR minimal promoter, mutants were performed to create either more consensus CArG element or degenerated motif (Table 1).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	371	 We used the D upper-case and the C upper-case to designate the Degenerated CArG motifs and the Consensus CArG elements, respectively.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	372	 To ensure the efficacy of mutations in abrogating transcription factor binding, we first performed a series of EMSA experiments with each CArG mutant and the WT probe (Table 2).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	373	 As expected, based on the sequence analysis, the mutations resulting in more degenerated CArG motifs (D1, D2, D3 and D4 mutants) completely abolished SRF-binding activity (Figure 7A, lanes 1 to 4), when we compared with SRF-WT complexes (Figure 7A, lane 5).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	374	 In addition, the probes containing more consensus CArG boxes (C1, C2, C3, C4 and C5 mutants) bound SRF more strongly in nuclear extracts prepared from Beas2B (Figure 7A, lanes 6 to 10).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	375	 Inclusion of an anti-SRF antibody partially abolished SRF-binding activity and resulted in a slower mobility band, confirming the identity of the binding protein (Figure 7A, lane 11).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	376	 Then, minimal CFTR promoter constructs bearing the same consensus and disrupted CArG boxes were tested in a transient transfection assays in Beas2B cells (Figure 7B).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	377	 Compared with luciferase activity resulting from the WT-pGL3 construct, variable increases in reporter activity are observed when D1, D2, D3 and D4 mutant constructs, with disrupted CArG motif, were transiently transfected.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	378	 On the other hand, mutations that create more consensus CArG element result in either reducing or increasing in the transcriptional activity (Figure 7B).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	379	 Consistent with the preceding gel-shift results revealing an uncharacterized protein/DNA complex with slightly slower mobility and variable intensity compared with the SRF to DNA complex, these finer mutagenesis studies suggest that both co-activators and co-repressors might interact with the studied promoter sequences.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	380	 Taken together, these data demonstrated that the CFTR-CArG-like element alone is not sufficient to confer basal transcriptional activation of the CFTR gene.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	381	View larger version (51K):    Figure 7 The CFTR-CArG-like element is not sufficient for basal transcriptional activity in Beas2B cells.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	382	 (A) EMSA analysis with nuclear extracts from SRF protein-enriched Beas2B cells using mutated labeled oligonucleotide probes (sequences listed in Table 2).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	383	 Ab against SRF was included as indicated (lane 10).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	384	 The arrow SS indicates the supershifted complexes.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	385	 (B) Basal transcriptional activity of CArG variants of the CFTR promoter.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	386	 Luciferase activity obtained with the WT-pGL3 luciferase construct was defined as 100%, and relative luciferase activities from mutant constructs are expressed as a percentage of this value.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	387	 Firefly luciferase activity was normalized with respect to Renilla luciferase activity.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	388	 The errors bars indicate the standard deviations.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	389	  Functional antagonism between SRF and YY1 through competition for the CFTR-CArG-like binding As a further means of establishing the role for SRF-binding CArG boxes in mediating either the CFTR-enhancer or silencer activity observed with the different minimal CFTR promoter mutants, we performed additional computational analyses.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	390	 Sequence analysis of CArG boxes and their immediate flanking sequences showed that C1, C3 and C4 constructs contain consensus binding sites for a number of transcription factors, in addition to SRF, including the transcription factor YY1.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	391	 These findings with previous work (12) have particularly evoked our interest to examine the role of YY1 in SRF-mediated CFTR transcriptional activity.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	392	In a first set of experiments, we evaluated whether the YY1 factor contributes to the formation of nucleoprotein complexes interacting with the WT, C1, C3 and C4 radiolabeled probes.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	393	 As shown in Figure 8A, incubation with specific anti-YY1 antibody resulted in either a significant decrease or total disappearance of some complexes normally formed between the CArG boxes and a component of Beas2B nuclear extracts, establishing DNA binding between YY1 and the sequences tested.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	394	 As expected, control experiment performed with radiolabeled probe, D2, devoid of any YY1 binding site and the anti-YY1 antiserum did not reveal any change in electrophoretic profiles indicating specificity of the YY1 binding.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	395	 Thus, these EMSAs demonstrated that the CFTR-CArG-like (WT probe) and more consensus CArG elements (C1  <  C3  <  C4) served as binding site for at least two distinct nuclear factors, namely SRF and YY1 from bronchial epithelial cells.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	396	View larger version (43K):    Figure 8 Functional interplay between SRF and YY1.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	397	 (A) YY1 binding to CFTR-CArG elements.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	398	 Nuclear extracts from Beas2B cells were incubated with 32P-labelled oligonucleotide probe containing either CArG-like (noted WT), consensus CArG box (noted C1, C3 and C4) in the presence or absence of specific antibody raised against YY1 as indicated.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	399	 D2, which contain neither CArG element nor YY1 site, is included as negative control.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	400	 Arrows indicate the position of YY1.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	401	 (B) Mutually exclusive DNA-binding activity of YY1 versus SRF to the CFTR-CArG site.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	402	 The same labeled CArG oligonucleotides that those used in panel A were incubated with YY1-transfected Beas2B nuclear extracts (5  microg) in the presence of increasing amounts of bacterial purified SRF (100 to 1000 ng).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	403	 Arrows indicate the position of SRF and YY1.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	404	 (C) Functional antagonism between SRF and YY1.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	405	 Beas2B were transfected with constructs containing either the CFTR-CArG-like element (noted WT) or consensus CFTR-CArG-boxes (noted C1, C3 and C4), in the presence of SRF and/or YY1 expression vectors.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	406	 Luciferase activities were normalized for transfection efficiency to the Renilla luciferase used as internal control.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	407	 The luciferase activity value 100 was assigned to samples co-transfected with the indicated reporter plasmid and the empty expression vector.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	408	 The mean  plus or minus  SD from at least three independent experiments is represented.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	409	  Then, to determine whether the interaction of these two factors with their target DNA (CFTR-CArG-like or more consensus CArG sequence) was either mutually inclusive or exclusive, EMSAs were conducted using bacterially expressed SRF and nuclear extracts prepared from Beas2B cells transfected with a YY1 expression vector as a source of YY1 DNA-binding activity.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	410	 As shown in Figure 8B, the YY1-binding complex was significantly reduced by increasing SRF binding activity, suggesting their mutually exclusive binding to CArG sites.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	411	Consistent with other studies (32,62), these EMSAs results suggested as a working hypothesis that both SRF and YY1 likely act as functional competitors in the CFTR promoter activity.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	412	 Since the minimal CFTR promoter is activated by SRF and knowing from previous studies (30 to 33) that YY1 negatively regulates some promoter containing CArG elements, it seemed logical to first assess whether YY1 could also repress the CFTR promoter.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	413	 We asked whether CArG-like-binding site in the CFTR promoter acted as negative regulatory elements.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	414	 Several CFTR promoter reporter constructs containing either CArG-like (namely, WT) or consensus CArG element (C1, C3 and C4) were co-transfected with SRF and/or YY1 expression vectors into Beas2B cells.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	415	 As shown in Figure 8C, while co-transfections with SRF alone resulted in 1.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	416	5- to 2-fold luciferase activation, forced expression of YY1 protein caused a strong decrease in reporter activities (50 to 75% of the control luciferase value).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	417	 Therefore, we wanted to determine the functional relationship of both factors in the CFTR activity regulation.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	418	 Transient co-transfections analysis of combination of protein expression vectors showed that over-expression of SRF either did not restore (Figure 8C, panel with the WT and C4 reporter constructs) or only very slightly raised the YY1-repressed reporter activities (Figure 8C, panel with the C1 and C3 reporter constructs).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	419	 These findings are consistent with results obtained from co-transfections performed with the YY1 expression vector alone and previous alpha-actin promoter studies (30 to 33), in which YY1 acted as a strong repressor.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	420	 Taken together, these data suggested functional antagonism between SRF and YY1 through DNA-binding competition.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	421	Identification of multiple CArG binding sites in the non-coding regions of the human CFTR gene and assessment of their putative functional importance To assess the putative importance of CArG motifs in the human CFTR expression regulation, we performed an in silico inspection of additional sequences upstream of the minimal promoter and in the intronic regions.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	422	 Four CArG binding sites were found in the CFTR promoter regions, and seven in the intronic regions.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	423	 The distribution and the positions of these putative binding sites for SRF are shown in Figure 9A.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	424	 Then, to confirm the computational predictions, we used several approaches.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	425	 First, the nucleotide regions harboring these predicted cis-acting elements were analyzed for conservation in the cow, as physiologically relevant transcription factor binding sites are frequently conserved in the non-coding regions of orthologous genes (49,63).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	426	 Second, the SRF-binding sites were tested by EMSAs and also for one of them by ChIP.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	427	View larger version (61K):    Figure 9 The CFTR gene untranslated regions contain multiple SRF-binding sites (CArG-boxes).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	428	 (A) Schematic drawing of CFTR gene shows the exons (circles) and the location of the putative CArG boxes in the non-coding regions, including that identified in the minimal CFTR promoter.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	429	 (B) The CFTR gene non-coding regions encompassing the putative CArG elements were analyzed for conservation in the cow.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	430	 Species homology and positions of the conserved sequence within BAC clones are indicated, as reported in a recent work (49).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	431	 (C) Comparative binding of SRF to CFTR CArG boxes.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	432	 Each promoter and intronic CArG box-containing oligonucleotide (see Table 2) was radiolabeled and purified as described in  Materials and Methods .
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	433	 Upper panel, binding reaction was performed with bacterially expressed SRF.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	434	 Ab against SRF was included as indicated.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	435	 Arrow indicates specific DNA to SRF complexes and SS indicates the Ab-supershifted complexes.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	436	 Lower panel, EMSA analysis with nuclear extracts from Beas2B cells using mutated labeled oligonucleotide probes.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	437	 (D) ChIP analysis of SRF binding to the endogenous CArG regions.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	438	 Lane 1 shows amplification of target sequence in immunoprecipitated chromatin fragments with anti-SRF Ab.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	439	 The target sequence encompasses a CArG element, located to  to 2373 bp in the minimal CFTR promoter.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	440	 Lane 2 shows PCR amplification of a control sample, without Ab.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	441	 Lane 3 shows amplification of 1:100 dilution samples of total input DNA for immunoprecipitation.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	442	  We showed that all the predicted CArG elements occur in highly conserved CFTR non-coding regions (Figure 9B), which may contain tissue-specific transcription factors (5).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	443	 We provided evidence that the majority of in silico predicted CArG motifs form specific DNA to protein complexes with bacterially expressed SRF protein (Figure 9C, left panel).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	444	 We also demonstrated by using Beas2B nuclear extracts and supershift assays that some of these CArG elements bound in vitro SRF protein (Figure 9C, right panel, lanes 1, 3, 7 and 9).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	445	 Finally, additional ChIP experiments indicated that the only tested CArG element, located at  to 2373 bp in the CFTR promoter, bound SRF in chromatin from intact cultured Beas2B cells (Figure 9D, lane 1).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	446	 Collectively, these findings support the concept that SRF may play a key role in the CFTR expression regulation via binding to multiple CFTR CArG elements.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	447	   DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   While great strides have been made in CFTR research with emphasis on the structure and function of this protein, only incremental advances have been achieved in the field of transcriptional regulation.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	448	 In our previous works (12,20), we have identified a polymorphic CArG-like site and showed that a naturally occurring sequence variation in this motif may enhance the basal CFTR transcriptional activity.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	449	 The goal of the present study was to better characterize the human CFTR promoter region encompassing the CArG-like element.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	450	Comparisons of nucleotide sequences of this CFTR promoter region in eight mammalian species representing three different orders (Primates, Artiodactyla and Lagomorpha) revealed high levels of conservation of the minimal promoter region, as described previously (64).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	451	 However, the CArG-like element (GC(T/A)6GG), which does not conform to the authentic CArG box (CC(T/A)6GG), is absent from three species (sheep, cow and rabbit).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	452	 Even though this motif occurs in only a subset of the input sequences, it does not necessarily mean that it is of no functional importance.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	453	 Instances of cis-regulatory elements being species-specific have been already reported for the CFTR gene (50).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	454	 More generally, it is well known that some transcription factors can tolerate more than one type of nucleotide at a given position of the binding site.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	455	 Instances of substitutions in both the central core of the CArG element and the highly conserved contact points for SRF, at the terminal ends, not impairing SRF binding have been previously reported (48,65 to 68).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	456	 Taken together, these data support the notion that the CFTR-CArG-like element has possible important implication in the CFTR transcriptional regulation.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	457	Interestingly, analysis of SRF expression has revealed relatively high expression levels of SRF protein in the bronchial epithelial cells (Figure 2), as shown in other differentiated epithelial cells (27).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	458	 Accumulating evidence supports the concept that SRF could contribute to the CFTR expression regulation.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	459	 In addition to regulating growth-responsive genes and numerous muscle-specific genes (22,69), SRF is also described as a key trans-binding factor in various important physiological events.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	460	 For example, SRF has been shown to regulate pulmonary development in Drosophila (28), to promote both re-epithelialization and muscular structure restoration during gastric ulcer healing (70) and more recently to be involved in the regulation of endoplasmic reticulum-targeted gene (67).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	461	 Therefore, it was relevant to examine the potential role of SRF on the CFTR transcriptional activity.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	462	In the present study, we demonstrated that CFTR-CArG-like element forms specific DNA to protein complexes that include SRF protein as part of the complex, in vitro and in vivo (Figures 3 and 4).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	463	 We have investigated the expression driven by the proximal human CFTR promoter in a pGL3 construct in both epithelial and myoblasts lines.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	464	 Results of our transient transfections of 3XSRE-fos TATA and WT-pGL3 luciferase reporter genes showed that the human minimal CFTR promoter encompassing a CArG-like motif was sufficient to drive the expression in both cell types (Figure 5).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	465	 Consistent with other studies showing CFTR expression in smooth muscle tissue (71,72), our results demonstrated that the human CFTR minimal promoter had the ability to drive the expression in muscle lineages.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	466	 Our transient co-transfections analyses performed with full-length and dominant-negative SRF forms expression vectors, and also specific SRF siRNA constructs (Figure 6, panels B and C) provide the first evidence for a positive role of the SRF protein in the regulation of the human CFTR promoter.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	467	 However, the SRF-induced CFTR transactivation, though significant, is relatively modest.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	468	 These data with the results of finer mutagenesis studies presented in Figure 7 support the concept that SRF alone is not sufficient to drive the basal expression of the CFTR gene.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	469	 As suggested by other previous studies (73 to 75), it is likely that additional factors might be required to optimally drive the CFTR promoter, as well as to specify the cell-type-restricted expression.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	470	 Since YY1 was previously shown to bind the CFTR promoter (12) and a subset of SREs serve as binding sites for YY1 (30 to 33), we first evaluated this candidate in the SRF-mediated CFTR transcriptional activity.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	471	 The data analysis suggests a functional antagonism between SRF and YY1 through binding competition for the CFTR-CArG-like box.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	472	 However, the analysis of combinatorial co-transfection studies, presented in Figure 8C, suggests that the functional interplay between SRF and YY1, alone, is not sufficient to account for basal CFTR transcriptional activation.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	473	 Further studies will be necessary to determine whether another player might be involved in this functional interplay and accounted for the basal transcriptional CFTR activity observed in the Beas2B bronchial epithelial cells.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	474	Interestingly, we showed that, in addition to the CArG-like element defined in the minimal promoter of the CFTR gene, there are three CArG motifs located at the 5' end of the gene and seven are present in the intronic regions (Figure 9).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	475	 We also evidenced SRF binding to CArG elements of the endogenous CFTR gene in the context of intact chromatin (Figures 4 and 9D).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	476	 Although the role of these more distal CArG boxes has yet to be assessed, these findings are of major importance, since it has been shown that optimal activity of the SRF-dependent target genes may require a number of CArG boxes, including those that are defined in the intronic region (66,67,76).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	477	 Moreover, as already suggested for the -actin promoters (32,74), perhaps the presence multiple CArG elements in the CFTR gene with cooperative binding events might be essential for SRF to prevent YY1 from binding to the CFTR promoter.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	478	 Clearly, further studies are needed to directly investigate the role of these multiple CArG elements in transcriptional regulation of the CFTR gene.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	479	Taken together, our results demonstrated for the first time that the human CFTR promoter is a novel SRF target gene, subject to modest but significant SRF activation partially due to functional antagonism between YY1 and SRF through mutually exclusive DNA-binding activities of YY1 versus SRF to the CFTR-CArG-like site.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	480	A critical question is, thus, how might SRF contribute to orchestrating cell-restricted and context-dependent programs of CFTR gene expression? Our findings and investigations to date clearly indicate the presence of several different underlying mechanisms of SRF-dependent transcriptional activation, as represented in Figure 10.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	481	 These might include association of SRF with a variety of cell-restricted co-factors (noted in gray bubbles, Figure 10), such as MRTF-A highly expressed in epithelial cells of the lung, kidney, colon and testis, and MRTF-B also expressed in smooth muscle cells (77), ternary complex factors, such as p62 and SAP-1 (25,78) and remodeling chromatin co-factors in an HAT-dependent manner, such as the CREB-binding protein (79).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	482	 In addition, it is well known that binding of SRF to the CArG box induces an acute bend in the DNA and that this bending may vary with changing base compositions across the CArG box (80).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	483	 Such bending can probably facilitate interactions with other proteins already involved in the CFTR expression regulation, such as NF-B (13) and C/EBP (9) and described as interacting with SRF (81).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	484	 Finally, the Ras-related GTPases family (rac, RhoA and cdc42) might have a critical role in the activation of SRF (82).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	485	 Indeed, it is reported that RhoA-induced SRF activation occurs through a phenomenon of  actin treadmilling  restricted to CArG-dependent genes that do not have adjacent ETS-binding sites (e.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	486	 smooth muscle cell restricted CArG genes) (83,84).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	487	 Moreover, it has been shown that the activation of SRF may be mediated by the NF-B and C/EBP transcription factors (81).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	488	View larger version (33K):    Figure 10 Schematic model depicting potential mechanism that might contribute to epithelial-specific regulation of the CFTR gene.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	489	 In this model, arrows and bubbles marked in gray indicate multiple potential SRF-mediated regulation pathways, such as protein to protein interaction and potential induction by the Ras-related GTPases cascades.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	490	 Blue and pink bubbles indicate trans-factors identified in this study that contribute to the basal CFTR transcriptional activity.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	491	 Black and double arrow shows the functional antagonism between YY1 and SRF identified in this study through the CFTR-CArG-like element characterization.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	492	  These data provide the foundation for further studies on the regulation of CFTR and will unable the rational design of further functional studies, including various strategies aiming to further dissect the different regulation pathways.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	493	   ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS   This study was supported by grants from both French associations: Vaincre La Mucoviscidose (VLM) and Fondation pour la Recherche Medicale (FRM).

0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	613	, 209, 208 to 215[CrossRef][ISI][Medline] .
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	614	 (1994) Serum-regulated transcription by serum response factor (SRF): a novel role for the DNA binding domain EMBO J.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	615	 (2002) Increased actin polymerization reduces the inhibition of serum response factor activity by Yin Yang 1 Biochem.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	616	 J, 364, 547 to 554[CrossRef][ISI][Medline] .
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	617	 (2000) Human-mouse genome comparisons to locate regulatory sites Nature Genet.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	618	, 26, 225 to 228[CrossRef][ISI][Medline] .
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	619	 (1994) Analysis of the mouse and rat CFTR promoter regions Hum.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	620	 (1998) Evolutionarily conserved promoter region containing CArG*-like elements is crucial for smooth muscle myosin heavy chain gene expression Circ.

0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	637	 (1991) Activation of skeletal alpha-actin gene transcription: the cooperative formation of serum response factor-binding complexes over positive cis-acting promoter serum response elements displaces a negative-acting nuclear factor enriched in replicating myoblasts and nonmyogenic cells Mol.
