0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	659	 PubMed PubMed Citation Articles by Rene, C.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	660	 Online ISSN 1362-4962 - Print ISSN 0305-1048 Copyright   2006 Oxford University Press Oxford Journals Oxford University Press Site Map Terms  and  Conditions --> Privacy Policy Frequently Asked Questions Other Oxford University Press sites: Oxford University Press American National Biography Booksellers' Information Service Children's Fiction and Poetry Children's Reference Corporate  and  Special Sales Dictionaries Dictionary of National Biography Digital Reference English Language Teaching Higher Education Textbooks Humanities International Education Unit Law Medicine Music Online Products Oxford English Dictionary Reference Rights and Permissions Science School Books Social Sciences Very Short Introductions World's Classics.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	0	A domain mimic increases F508 CFTR trafficking and restores cAMP-stimulated anion secretion in cystic fibrosis epithelia Lane L.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Gawenis,1 Tzyh-Chang Hwang,2 Nancy M.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	2	Departments of 1Biomedical Sciences and 2Medical Physiology and Pharmacology and Dalton Cardiovascular Research Center, University of Missouri, Columbia, Missouri 65211.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	3	Submitted 5 August 2003 ; accepted in final form 10 March 2004.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	4	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION GRANTS REFERENCES   The major disease-causing mutation of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) is deletion of phenylalanine 508 (F508), which adversely affects processing and plasma membrane targeting of CFTR.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Under conditions predicted to stabilize protein folding, F508 CFTR is capable of trafficking to the plasma membrane and retains cAMP-regulated anion channel activity.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Overexpression is one factor that increases CFTR trafficking; therefore, we hypothesized that expression of a domain mimic of the first nucleotide-binding fold (NBF1) of CFTR, i.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	7	, the site of F508, may be sufficient to overwhelm the quality control process or otherwise stabilize F508 CFTR and thereby restore cAMP-stimulated anion secretion.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	8	 In epithelial cells expressing recombinant F508 human (h)CFTR, expression of wild-type NBF1 increased the amount of both core-glycosylated and mature protein to a greater extent than expression of F508 NBF1.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Expression of wild-type NBF1 in the F508 hCFTR cells increased whole cell Cl to  current density to 50% of that in cells expressing wild-type hCFTR.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Expression of NBF1 in polarized epithelial monolayers from a F508/F508 cystic fibrosis mouse (MGEF) restored cAMP-stimulated transepithelial anion secretion but not in monolayers from a CFTR-null mouse (MGEN).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Restoration of anion secretion was sustained in NBF1-expressing MGEF for  > 30 passages, whereas MGEN corrected with hCFTR progressively lost anion secretion capability.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	12	 We conclude that expression of a NBF1 domain mimic may be useful for correction of the F508 CFTR protein trafficking defect in cystic fibrosis epithelia.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	13	protein processing; mouse; retrovirus; gene therapy.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	14	THE MAJOR DISEASE-CAUSING mutation of the cystic fibrosis (CF) transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein is a deletion of phenylalanine at position 508 (F508) in the predicted cytoplasmic domain known as the first nucleotide binding fold (NBF1).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Approximately 70% of CF patients are homozygous for the F508 cftr, and  > 90% carry at least one F508 cftr allele (compound heterozygotes) (11).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Nascent wild-type human (h)CFTR is translated and core-glycosylated at the endoplasmic reticulum (ER).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	17	 A fraction of the core-glycosylated hCFTR protein (25 to 40%; Refs.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	18	 36 and 48) is transported to the Golgi apparatus, where glycosylation is further modified to form mature hCFTR that is targeted to the plasma membrane (5).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	19	 There, the wild-type hCFTR functions as a cyclic nucleotide-regulated anion channel and serves a number of transport functions, including regulation of other ion transport proteins and membrane recycling phenomena (2, 8).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	20	 In contrast to wild-type hCFTR, nearly all of F508 hCFTR is retained in the ER in its core-glycosylated form and sorted to the ubiquitin-proteasome protein degradation pathway instead of the Golgi apparatus (5, 25).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	21	 It is believed that improper folding of the mutant protein is recognized by proteins comprising a cellular "quality control" mechanism that retains misfolded proteins for degradation (44).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Chaperone proteins are also involved in the processing of hCFTR and at least two proteins, HSP70 and calnexin, bind F508 hCFTR with greater avidity than wild-type hCFTR (39).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	23	 The process of recognition by the quality control machinery and the conformation of the misfolded F508 hCFTR have not been elucidated.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	24	 In epithelia homozygous for the F508 mutation, retention and degradation of the mutant hCFTR essentially eliminates the capacity for cyclic nucleotide-regulated anion secretion, and it is believed that this deficit is fundamental to the pathogenesis of the disease (38).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	25	Defective processing of F508 hCFTR is at least partially reversible.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Studies in cells expressing recombinant F508 hCFTR and tissues cultured from transgenic F508 murine (m)CFTR mice have shown that a fraction of the mutant protein undergoes biosynthetic maturation when cells are grown at subphysiological temperatures (26 degrees C) (13).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Studies in which F508 hCFTR-expressing cells were treated with "chemical chaperones" such as glycerol and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) or organic cellular osmolytes such as myo-inositol and betaine have also found increased maturation of F508 hCFTR, a result that was attributed to stabilization of the mutant protein (1, 3, 22, 52).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Overexpression of the mutant protein either by transfection or by treatment with butyrate results in trafficking of F508 hCFTR to the plasma membrane (4, 40).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	29	 The above observations have important therapeutic implications because F508 hCFTR in the plasma membrane retains its capacity as a cyclic nucleotide-regulated anion channel (13).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Studies in cell-free systems indicate that stimulated F508 hCFTR may have channel kinetics similar to wild-type hCFTR (23, 31, 42), whereas on-cell patch studies measure reduced channel kinetic activity compared with wild-type hCFTR (12, 20, 24).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Even if F508 CFTR has reduced function and shorter membrane residence (32), previous studies suggest that only a small amount (10 to 15%) of F508 CFTR activity in the membrane is required to restore epithelial function and moderate disease (15, 26).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Combined with recent pharmacological studies showing that F508 hCFTR channel activity can be significantly enhanced by treatment with compounds such as 8-cyclopentyl-1,3-dipropylxanthine (CPX), genistein, or class III phosphodiesterase inhibitors (28), it is clear that correcting F508 hCFTR trafficking is a viable strategy for treating CF.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	33	Recent studies have shown that expression of polypeptides representing the structural domain of a protein (i.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	34	, "domain mimics") can predictably alter posttranslational processing of the protein.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Expression of a minigene encoding the carboxy terminus of human ether-a-go-go-related gene was shown to rescue a carboxy-terminal truncation mutant from misprocessing (29).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	36	 In another study, a 6-mer peptide mimic of the reactive center loop of 1-antitrypsin was used to block pathological polymerization of the Z variant mutation of the protein (35).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	37	 With regard to CFTR, expression of a polypeptide representing the NBF1 plus the regulatory "R" domain of hCFTR was shown to inhibit activity of ENaC, the epithelial Na+ channel reputedly regulated by CFTR (45).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Because the NBF1 domain of hCFTR is the location of F508 as well as several other processing mutants (46), the NBF1 domain itself may serve as a "checkpoint" for recognition by the cellular quality control machinery or, alternatively, may function in a critical intramolecular interaction that stabilizes hCFTR structure within the ER.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Therefore, we hypothesized that expression of the NBF1 domain may be sufficient to increase F508 CFTR activity in epithelial cells.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The NBF1 domain of CFTR is well conserved among mammalian species (17), and in the mouse, deletion of F508 results in a mCFTR processing defect that recapitulates the fundamental cellular defect of F508 homozygous CF patients (16, 50).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	41	 In the present study, both heterologous cell systems expressing recombinant F508 hCFTR and epithelial monolayers from a F508 CFTR homozygous mouse were used to test the hypothesis that expression of a NBF1 domain mimic increases trafficking F508 CFTR and restores cAMP-stimulated anion secretion.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	42	   MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION GRANTS REFERENCES   Cell culture.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Mouse mammary epithelial cell lines (C127) expressing wild-type hCFTR, F508 hCFTR, or empty plasmid were obtained courtesy of Genzyme (Cambridge, MA) and maintained in plastic culture flasks by using Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (DMEM) with high glucose supplemented with 10% (vol/vol) fetal bovine serum (FBS) and 200  microg/ml geneticin.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	44	 SV40-LT antigen-immortalized mouse gallbladder epithelial cells were derived from a mCFTR knockout (cftr to / to ) mouse (i.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	45	, the MGEN cell line) and a F508 mCFTR (F508cftr/F508cftr) mouse (i.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Both mouse strains for these purposes were maintained on a C57BL/6J background.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Both cell lines were grown on Transwell-COL permeable supports (Corning Costar, Cambridge, MA) in Ham's F-12 medium containing 1  microg/ml insulin, 7.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	48	5  microg/ml transferrin, 1  microM hydrocortisone, 30 nM triiodothyronine, 2.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	49	5 ng/ml epidermal growth factor, and 10 ng/ml endothelial cell growth substance and supplemented (1:1) with 3T3 fibroblast-conditioned DMEM containing 2% (vol/vol) FBS, as previously described (9).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	50	Stable expression of NBF domain mimics.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	51	 NotI restriction endonuclease site-flanked cDNA constructs of wild-type NBF1 and F508 NBF1 (coding for amino acids 429 to 591 of full-length hCFTR) with a flag epitope (DYKDDDDK) inserted at the carboxy terminus were prepared as previously described (6).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	52	 The constructs were subcloned into the Zeocin-selectable vectors pZEOSV or pCDNA3.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	53	 C127 cell lines were transfected with the NBF1 construct plasmids by electroporation and selected in medium containing 200  microg/ml Zeocin.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Clones were isolated 2 wk after electroporation.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	55	 For stable expression of the NBF1 construct in the polarized MGEF and MGEN epithelial cell lines (passages 3 to 16), the NotI-flanked construct was subcloned into the retroviral vector pLXSNz [i.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	56	 John Olsen, University of North Carolina) that was engineered with Zeocin resistance] to form the proviral component NBF1-LXSNz.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	57	 As a positive control, hCFTR cDNA was introduced into the plasmid to produce the proviral component hCFTR-LXSNz.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Transfection by Ca/PO4 precipitation of NBF1-LXSNz, hCFTR-LXSNz, and pLXSNz (empty vector control) into the virus-packaging cell line PA317 led to the production of replication-defective virus.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Virus stock supernatant was used to infect the MGEF and MGEN cells, which were subsequently selected in medium containing 200  microg/ml Zeocin.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Transfected cell lines were screened for expression of the NBF1 constructs by RT-PCR essentially as described previously (19) utilizing a gene-specific primer (5'-GGATCCACTGGAGCAGGCAAG-3') in combination with a primer specific for the flag epitope of the NBF1 domain mimic (5'-ATCATCGTCGTCTTTGTAGTC-3').
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	61	 C127 cells were grown on glass coverslips for whole cell patch-clamp recordings as described previously (47).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Briefly, a Cl to  gradient was established with the following solutions: pipette (in mM): 85 aspartic acid, 5 pyruvic acid, 10 EGTA, 10 HEPES, 20 tetraethylammonium-Cl, 5 Tris, 10 MgATP, 2 MgCl2, and 5.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	63	4 with CsOH); bath (in mM): 145 NaCl, 5 glucose, 5 HEPES, 2 MgCl2, 1 CaCl2, 5 KCl, and 20 sucrose (pH 7.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	64	 An outward current generated by Cl to  influx was observed at a holding potential of 0 mV on activation of CFTR.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	65	 The holding current at 0 mV was normalized with the membrane capacitance to yield current density.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Current traces in response to voltage pulses ( plus or minus 100 mV at 20-mV increments) were filtered at 1 kHz with a built-in four-pole Bessel filter and digitized (at 2 kHz) through an ITC-16 interface (Instrutech, Great Neck, NY).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	67	 MGEN and MGEF cells were cultured on a rat tail collagen membrane covering a 4.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	68	5-mm-diameter aperture in polycarbonate cups as previously described (10).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Bioelectric measurements were made under voltage-clamp conditions with intermittent voltage spikes to calculate transepithelial resistance (with Ohm's law).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	70	 The preparations were bathed on the luminal and basolateral surfaces with warmed (37 degrees C), oxygenated Krebs bicarbonate Ringer (KBR) solution containing (in mM) 115 NaCl, 4 K2HPO4, 0.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	71	2 CaCl2, and 10 glucose at pH 7.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	72	 In ion substitution studies, gluconate and sulfate replaced Cl to , N-tris(hydroxymethyl)methyl-2-aminoethanesulfonic acid (TES) replaced HCO3 to , and tetramethylammonium (TMA+) replaced Na+ on an equimolar basis.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	73	Detection of hCFTR and F508 hCFTR glycosylation status by immunoprecipitation-32P labeling.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Detection of hCFTR and its glycosylation status was performed as described by Gregory et al.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Cultured cells (1 confluent T-25 flask) were homogenized in 1 ml of lysis buffer [50 mM Tris pH 7.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	76	4, 150 mM NaCl, 10 mM MgCl2, 1% (vol/vol) Triton X-100, 1% (wt/vol) 3-[(3-cholamidopropyl)dimethylammonio]-1-propanesulfonate (CHAPS), 1 mM Pefabloc, 10  microg/ml aprotinin].
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	77	 After low-speed centrifugation to remove insoluble material (14,000 g), CFTR was immunoprecipitated with 1.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	78	5  microg of the monoclonal antibody M3A7 (27), which recognizes an epitope within the NBF2 domain (Genzyme), and the addition of protein A agarose beads.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	79	 After tumbling (2 h, 4 degrees C), the beads were washed three times in lysis buffer and incubated for in vitro phosphorylation in buffer containing 25 mU protein kinase A, 0.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	80	2 mM rATP, and 50  microCi of [-32P]ATP for 10 min at 30 degrees C.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	81	 After washing to remove unincorporated [-32P]ATP, bound phosphorylated protein was eluted from the beads into SDS-PAGE sample buffer at room temperature for 1 h.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Total protein was separated by SDS-PAGE on 4 to 20% gels, dried, and autoradiographed (1 to 7 days).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Densitometric measurements were performed on a Kodak Image Station 2000R (Rochester, NY) with 1D Image Analysis software.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Forskolin, genistein, and 5-nitro-2-(3-phenylpropylamino)benzoate (NPPB) were diluted in DMSO to stock concentrations of 10, 10, and 100 mM, respectively.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Amiloride was diluted to a stock concentration of 10 mM in distilled water.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	86	 All reagents were obtained from either Sigma (St.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Louis, MO) or Fisher Scientific (Springfield, NJ).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Data are expressed as means  plus or minus  SE.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Data between two treatment groups were compared with a two-tailed Student's t-test assuming equal variances.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Data from more than two treatment groups were compared with a one-way ANOVA with a post-hoc Student-Newman-Keuls test.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	91	 A probability value of P  <  0.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	92	05 was considered statistically significant.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	93	   RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION GRANTS REFERENCES   Expression of NBF1 domain mimics increases F508 hCFTR protein trafficking and reconstitutes cAMP-stimulated whole cell Cl to  currents.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	94	 On the basis of the observation that overexpression increases CFTR trafficking (4), we hypothesized that expression of NBF1 domain mimics in F508 hCFTR-expressing cells may produce excess NBF1 polypeptides that would either competitively inhibit quality control proteins that retain and degrade F508 hCFTR during processing or reconstitute domain interactions that may permit a fraction of F508 hCFTR to be fully processed.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	95	 C127 cells expressing F508 hCFTR were transfected with either F508 NBF1 or wild-type NBF1 domains and assayed for hCFTR expression by immunoprecipitation-32P labeling.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	96	 With this method, the mature, fully processed CFTR (band C) electrophoreses at 180 kDa whereas the immature, unprocessed CFTR (band B) runs at 160 kDa.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	97	 1A, most wild-type hCFTR expressed in the C127 cells (lane 1) is processed to the high-molecular-mass band C form, indicative of glycosylation chain modifications occurring at the trans-Golgi network.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	98	 The apparent dominance of band C hCFTR is typical for these cells with the immunoprecipitation-32P labeling technique.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	99	 1A, lanes 2 to 5) coexpressing F508 hCFTR and the F508 NBF1 domain mimic uniformly expressed the nascent or core-glycosylated forms of unprocessed hCFTR, i.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	100	, band B, but expressed very small amounts of the fully glycosylated hCFTR, i.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	101	 The density of band B shown in Fig.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	102	 1A, lanes 2 to 5, is typical of the F508 C127 cells that have not been transfected (n  >  20; data not shown).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Surprisingly, clonal cell lines coexpressing F508 hCFTR and the wild-type NBF1 domain mimic (Fig.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	104	 1A, lanes 6 to 8) expressed greater amounts of both fully processed and core-glycosylated F508 hCFTR, suggesting that the wild-type NBF1 domain mimic stabilizes F508 CFTR protein throughout processing and membrane trafficking.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	105	View larger version (29K):    Fig.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Immunoblot analysis and whole cell Cl to  current densities of phenylalanine 508-deleted (F508) human (h) cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR)-transfected C127 cells coexpressing first nucleotide-binding fold (NBF1) domain mimics.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	107	 A: lane 1, cells expressing wild-type (WT) hCFTR; lanes 2 to 5, F508 hCFTR cell lines coexpressing F508 (F) NBF1; lanes 6 to 8, F508 hCFTR cell lines coexpressing wild-type NBF1.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	108	 B: relative contribution of band C to pixel intensity profile/lane for WT hCFTR, F508 hCFTR cell lines coexpressing F508 NBF1 (n = 4) and F508 hCFTR cell lines coexpressing wild-type NBF1 (n = 3) from data in A.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Relative intensity was calculated as the pixel intensity of band C/combined pixel intensity for bands B + C (after correction for background in each lane).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	110	 *Significantly different from F NBF1.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	111	 C: whole cell patch-clamp measurements of Cl to  current density (in pA/pF to normalize for differences in cell size) of C127 epithelial cell transfectants.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Data were collected after cell treatment with a cocktail containing 2  microM forskolin and 100  microM genistein.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	113	 WT and F508 C127 cell lines expressing full-length WT and F508 hCFTR, respectively; F508/27 degrees C, C127 cells expressing F508 hCFTR that were maintained at 27 degrees C for 48 h before experimentation; NBF1, wild-type NBF1 domain mimic.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Bars labeled with different letters are significantly different.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	115	  Whole cell patch-clamp analysis was used to investigate Cl to  current density in the cell clones showing a maximal increase in F508 hCFTR maturation after coexpression of the wild-type NBF1 domain mimic.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Because the open probabilities of wild-type hCFTR and F508 hCFTR are greatly enhanced in the presence of forskolin plus genistein (23), the whole cell Cl to  current density was used to estimate the activity of functional channels in the plasma membrane.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	117	 As positive controls, cells expressing wild-type hCFTR and cells expressing F508 hCFTR but exposed to processing-permissive temperature conditions (27 degrees C) for 48 h were also assayed for comparison.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Earlier studies using cells expressing recombinant F508 hCFTR showed that temperature-induced band C expression correlates positively with whole cell Cl to  current and I to  efflux (13, 21).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	119	 1C, C127 cells expressing wild-type hCFTR demonstrate a whole cell Cl to  current density that is severalfold greater than that in cells expressing F508 hCFTR.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Cells expressing F508 hCFTR grown at a temperature permissive for F508 hCFTR trafficking to the plasma membrane had a Cl to  current density that was 50% of wild-type hCFTR-expressing cells.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Most importantly, clonal F508 hCFTR cell lines expressing wild-type NBF1 showed an increased Cl to  current density that was similar in magnitude to that in the temperature-corrected F508 hCFTR cells.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	122	Expression of a NBF1 domain mimic in F508/F508 CFTR murine epithelial monolayers reconstitutes cAMP-stimulated anion secretion.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	123	 The studies described above demonstrate that coexpression of the NBF1 domain mimic can increase plasma membrane activity of F508 hCFTR in an epithelial cell line expressing recombinant protein driven by a nonnative promoter.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Because the level of F508 hCFTR expression can affect trafficking in the cell (4), we asked whether expression of the NBF1 domain mimic would also improve plasma membrane trafficking of endogenously expressed F508 CFTR in a polarized epithelium.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	125	 After an extensive search, we were unable to identify a human F508/F508 CFTR epithelial cell line that retained the ability to both form polarized epithelial monolayers and express significant levels of the endogenous F508 hCFTR protein for the retroviral transfection studies.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Because previous studies demonstrated that defects in processing and plasma membrane expression of the F508 mCFTR homolog in murine epithelia recapitulate the defects of F508 hCFTR (16), an epithelial cell line (MGEF) developed by transformation of gallbladder epithelia from a F508/F508 CFTR mutant mouse model was transfected with the NBF1 domain mimic (50).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	127	As shown by the short-circuit current (Isc) trace from an Ussing chamber experiment (Fig.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	128	 2A), expression of the NBF1 domain mimic in the MGEF epithelial monolayer not only increased the basal Isc [means for n = 9 monolayers: NBF1 =  to 18.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	129	 zeomycin-resistance gene (Zeo) =  to 6.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	130	05] but, more importantly, yielded a distinct Isc response to forskolin stimulation compared with MGEF cells transduced with only the empty vector control (pLXSNz).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Subsequent treatment of the monolayer with the CFTR channel blocker NPPB inhibited both the cAMP-stimulated Isc and a large fraction of the basal Isc.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Although the ionic basis of the residual Isc was not investigated, previous studies indicate the presence of a Ca2+-activated anion channel in the apical membrane of the MGE epithelial cells (9).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	133	 As a negative control, the mCFTR-null cell line MGEN, developed by transformation of gallbladder epithelium from a CFTR knockout mouse, was also transfected with the NBF1 construct for comparison with the NBF1-expressing MGEF cells.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Expression of the NBF1 domain mimic in the MGEN cells slightly increased the basal Isc (means for n = 5 monolayers: NBF1 =  to 4.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	135	 However, in contrast to cAMP-induced Isc responses in the NBF1-expressing MGEF cells, expression of the NBF1 domain mimic in the MGEN cells did not restore the Isc response to cAMP stimulation (see cumulative data in Fig.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	136	 As a positive control for the transfection and selection procedure, hCFTR was expressed in the CFTR( to / to ) MGEN cell line by the same transduction process used for the NBF1-expressing cell lines.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Expression of hCFTR in the MGEN cell monolayers resulted in a significantly greater basal Isc (mean for n = 7 monolayers: hCFTR =  to 6.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	138	 1C, a greater stimulation of Isc after forskolin treatment than MGEN cells transduced with only pLXSNz.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	139	View larger version (26K):    Fig.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Short-circuit current (Isc) measurements of F508/F508 MGEF or murine (m)CFTR-null MGEN epithelial monolayers.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	141	 A: Isc recording of MGEF cells expressing either the selectable zeomycin-resistance gene (Zeo) or NBF1 + Zeo (NBF1).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Repetitive upward current deflections result from applied voltage (2 mV) used to measure transepithelial resistance.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Treatments (arrows) were sequential additions to the luminal bath of 10  microM forskolin (Forsk) and 100  microM 5-nitro-2-(3-phenylpropylamino)benzoate (NPPB).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	144	 B: comparison of the maximal Isc change (Isc) after 10  microM forskolin treatment for MGEF or MGEN cell lines transfected with Zeo, NBF1 + Zeo (NBF1), or wild-type hCFTR.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	145	 *Significantly different from MGEN + Zeo and MGEF + Zeo (n = 5 to 9).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	146	 C: ion substitution studies of the Isc induced by treatment with 10  microM forskolin of MGEF cells expressing NBF1 + Zeo (NBF1).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	147	 KBR, Krebs bicarbonate Ringer solution.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	148	 *Significantly different from KBR (n = 4 to 9).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	149	  Because the cAMP-stimulated Isc in the NBF1-expressing F508 homozygous MGEF monolayers could result from either electrogenic cation (Na+) absorption or electrogenic anion (Cl to  + HCO3 to ) secretion, ion substitution studies were used to investigate the ionic basis of the cAMP-stimulated Isc in the NBF1-expressing MGEF cell line.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	150	 2C, substitution of Na+ with the impermeant cation TMA+ in the mucosal bath did not significantly affect the cAMP-stimulated Isc response compared with the response in standard KBR solution.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Subsequent addition of 10  microM amiloride to the mucosal solution of NBF1-expressing MGEF cells bathed in the standard KBR solution also did not affect the magnitude of the cAMP-stimulated Isc [change in ()Isc =  to 0.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	152	 These findings indicated that the cAMP-induced Isc response in the transduced cell line was not due to electrogenic Na+ absorption.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	153	 In contrast, when both Cl to  and HCO3 to  were substituted with impermeant anions in the mucosal and serosal bathing solutions, the cAMP-stimulated Isc of the NBF1-expressing MGEF cell monolayers was nearly eliminated.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Together with the evidence that the cAMP-stimulated Isc response in the NBF1-expressing MGEF cells is sensitive to NPPB (see Fig.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	155	 2A), the findings are consistent with the conclusion that the stimulated Isc represents F508 CFTR-mediated anion secretion.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	156	cAMP-stimulated Isc is maintained in successive passages of the NBF1-expressing MGEF epithelial cell line.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Previous studies showed that expression of recombinant CFTR can induce downregulation of the cftr gene and adversely affect cell proliferation (41).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Therefore, we compared the stability of the Isc response in the NBF1-expressing MGEF cell line with that in the hCFTR-expressing MGEN cell line by measuring the cAMP-stimulated Isc response of monolayers from successive passages of the two cell lines.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	159	 3, the NBF1-expressing MGEF cell monolayers maintained an almost identical magnitude of cAMP-stimulated Isc response for over 30 passages (passaged every 4 to 7 days).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	160	 In contrast, the magnitude of the cAMP-stimulated Isc progressively decreased in hCFTR-transfected MGEN cells with successive passages and was essentially absent after passage 9.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	161	View larger version (13K):    Fig.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Comparison of the maximal Isc resulting from treatment with 10  microM forskolin for the MGEN cell line expressing hCFTR and the MGEF cell line expressing NBF1 for successive passages.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Cell lines were passaged approximately once per week.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Each data point represents an average of experiments from 2 to 5 monolayers.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	165	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION GRANTS REFERENCES   Misfolded CFTR protein is discriminated by a stringent quality control process, which retains the protein within the ER and directs most to a cytosolic ubiquitination/proteosomal pathway (44).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Only 20% of wild-type CFTR and very little of F508 CFTR completes the process to yield functional channels at the plasma membrane (48).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Neither the action by which the F508 mutation disrupts the yield of correctly folded CFTR nor the molecular features of misfolded protein that are recognized as abnormal are known.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	168	 The present study was based on the premise that the NBF1 domain, i.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	169	, the location of F508 and several other mutations that affect CFTR processing (46), may be the key molecular component involved in successful processing of CFTR.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	170	 By expressing a wild-type NBF1 domain mimic, increased amounts of fully glycosylated F508 CFTR were observed and cAMP-stimulated anion secretion was restored in epithelial cells expressing recombinant F508 hCFTR.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Furthermore, expression of the wild-type NBF1 also increased cAMP-stimulated anion secretion in polarized epithelial monolayers expressing endogenous F508 mCFTR.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Together these results indicate that one function of the NBF1 domain mimic is to increase F508 hCFTR trafficking to the plasma membrane.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	173	Restoration of cAMP-stimulated anion secretion in the F508 CFTR-expressing epithelial cells yielded bioelectrical responses with characteristics consistent with activation of a F508 CFTR conductance.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	174	 In studies of F508 hCFTR cells expressing NBF1, genistein-forskolin treatment increased whole cell Cl to  currents to 50% of those exhibited by C127 cells stably expressing wild-type CFTR.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	175	 This difference, whether due to reduced open probability or to numbers of membrane channels, is similar to that observed when F508 hCFTR cells are exposed to reduced ambient temperature or after increased expression of the mutant CFTR (4, 13, 16, 40).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	176	 In studies of the polarized MGEF monolayers expressing NBF1, the macroscopic Isc response to forskolin treatment activated at a slower rate compared with MGEN cells expressing wild-type hCFTR (data not shown), which might reflect a characteristic of the F508 CFTR protein that attenuates its protein kinase A phosphorylation-dependent activation (47).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	177	 However, in contrast to the C127 cells, the absolute magnitude of the cAMP-induced Isc in the NBF1-expressing MGEF monolayers was approximately the same as in the MGEN monolayers expressing recombinant hCFTR.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	178	 This variance may reflect differences in the activities of the recombinant vs.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	179	 the endogenous CFTR channel or result from inherent differences in F508 CFTR properties between the two species (30).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Interestingly, the basal Isc of the NBF1-expressing MGEF and MGEN cells was elevated compared with the Zeocin-expressing control monolayers.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	181	 This change is consistent with previous demonstrations that expression of NBF1 yields a transmembrane configuration of the peptide and an increase in the basal halide permeability in mammalian cell lines (7, 19).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	182	 However, similar to our findings with the NBF1-expressing MGEN cells, expression of only the NBF1 domain did not result in cAMP-regulated anion permeability.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	183	 In the present study, restoration of cAMP-regulated anion secretion required NBF1 coexpression in F508 CFTR-expressing epithelial cells.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	184	Expression of cytosolic domain mimics has previously been used to alter specific intra- and intermolecular interactions within cells.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Pioneering work by Lefkowitz and coworkers (33) used domain mimics to disrupt interactions between plasma membrane receptors and G proteins coupled to phospholipase C activation.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	186	 More recently, a domain mimic expressed via a minigene was used to rescue misprocessing of a carboxy-terminal truncation mutant of human ether-a-go-go-related protein (29) and a domain peptide was used to selectively mask portions of mutant 1-antitrypsin to prevent posttranslational polymerization within hepatocytes (35).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	187	 With regard to CFTR, exogenous copies of the R domain have been shown to interact with full-length CFTR and modify gating behavior of its channel activity (34).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Domain mimics of CFTR and the integral membrane protein syntaxin 1A were used to modify channel activity and demonstrate a direct protein-protein interaction (37).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Furthermore, peptide mimics have been used to demonstrate binding interactions between NBF1 and the R domain of CFTR, which could be partially disrupted by introduction of the F508 mutation (6).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	190	Given the findings of the present study and previous observations with expression of recombinant F508 CFTR (4, 40), at least two mechanisms can be postulated that would result in increased processing of F508 CFTR beyond the ER.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	191	 First, expression of recombinant NBF1 may overwhelm the quality control system that is involved in retention and degradation of the mutant protein.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	192	 A similar process could be postulated for the plasma membrane appearance of F508 hCFTR when the mutant protein is overexpressed in heterologous cell systems (4, 40).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	193	 This mechanism would predict competitive binding for, perhaps specific, chaperone proteins or proteases, thereby allowing escape of mutant protein from the ER.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	194	 However, some evidence weakens the case for this proposed mechanism.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Our measures of protein expression in the C127 cells indicated that clones expressing wild-type NBF1 were more likely to have greater expression of the fully processed F508 CFTR compared with clones expressing the F508 NBF1 peptide (Fig.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	196	 This seems contrary to the prediction that F508 NBF1 would be more efficacious in competing for quality control proteins.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Furthermore, although it is possible that the concentration of the recombinant NBF1 at the quality control binding site(s) far exceeds that needed to discern differences between the two domain mimics, our estimates of NBF1 peptide concentration ( < 5 ng/ microl in cell pellets, as based on detection of the flag epitope with M2 monoclonal antibody) are well below the millimolar concentrations that are typically necessary to inhibit proteases with chemical inhibitors (25, 49).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	198	 The second potential mechanism by which NBF1 expression may lead to increased processing of F508 CFTR is that coexpression of additional NBF1 peptides may bind immature F508 CFTR and stabilize its structure in the ER.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	199	 For example, peptide interaction with the R domain of F508 CFTR may mask a site on the misfolded protein that is recognized by the quality control machinery, or additional copies of NBF1 may temporarily interact with F508 CFTR to catalyze a folding reaction that results in properly folded protein.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Given recent evidence that mature CFTR protein may dimerize in the plasma membrane (51), it seems plausible that cooperation between different CFTR monomers may be necessary for correct folding and that this interaction may be mimicked by the NBF1 domain peptides.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	201	Although the precise mechanism resulting in increased expression of F508 CFTR at the plasma membrane using coexpression of NBF1 peptides remains speculative, the significant aspect of the present study is that it suggests a refinement for therapeutic approaches to correcting F508 CFTR processing.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	202	 One major drawback to the use of viral vectors such as adeno-associated virus 2 for gene therapy is that the packaging capacity of the virus is limited, which, with a large gene like CFTR, leaves little capacity for promoter sequences (14).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Thus modification of the strategy to instead transfect only the NBF1 domain is attractive because the small size of the construct (0.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	204	5 kb) would improve packaging efficiency.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Furthermore, two biological advantages of using NBF1 domain transduction as therapy can be envisioned.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	206	 First, the expression of F508 CFTR is driven by its endogenous promoter, which may avoid the consequences of CFTR overexpression on the epithelium, e.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	207	, reduced cell proliferation potential (41).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	208	 A second advantage is that the NBF1 peptide is less likely to be toxic than the full-length channel protein when inadvertently expressed in nontarget tissues.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	209	 The NBF1 construct fused to a protein transduction domain (43) may also be useful for peptide therapy, especially if the smallest effective subunit of NBF1 can be defined.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Thus, on the basis of the observations in the present study, the therapeutic approach to correcting the basic protein-processing defect of F508 CFTR should be refined to focus on NBF1 domain mimics that alter trafficking of the mutant protein.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	211	   GRANTS TOP ABSTRACT MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION GRANTS REFERENCES   The study was supported by Cystic Fibrosis Foundation Grants CLARKE99P0 and CLARKE99G0 and National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases Grant DK-48816 (to L.

0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	0	EDITORIAL FOCUS Focus on "Exocytosis is not involved in activation of Cl secretion via CFTR in Calu-3 airway epithelial cells" William B.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	1	Department of Physiology and Pediatrics, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, Baltimore, Maryland 21205.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	2	    ARTICLE Top Article References.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	3	RAPID CHANGES IN salt and water movement occur in many epithelial tissues that respond quickly to alterations in overall salt and water balance.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	4	 For example, the amount of Cl secreted by the shark rectal gland can vary greatly in response to changes in the external environment (4).
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	5	 To rapidly change the rate of transport, epithelial cells regulate the transport rates of specific ion channels, pumps, and carriers.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	6	 This regulation commonly occurs by either affecting the activity of an individual transport process and/or the number of transport entities in the plasma membrane.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	7	 The activity of many ion channels is regulated by voltage, by extracellular ligands, or by intracellular signal transduction mechanisms (6).
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Thus many ion channels can be easily switched on and off to match the needs of a rapidly changing physiological process.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	9	 CFTR is an excellent example of a highly regulated Cl channel (2).
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	10	 The activity of CFTR is controlled by the coordination of two processes, phosphorylation of several sites primarily within the regulatory domain followed by ATP binding and hydrolysis by the nucleotide binding domains.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	11	 These two processes act together to both switch on and regulate channel opening (3).
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	12	In contrast, in some clear-cut cases, once inserted into the plasma membrane the activity of a variety of transporters is difficult to regulate.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	13	 In those cases, the most effective way to modulate transepithelial transport is to alter the number of transporters in the plasma membrane.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	14	 For example, it is well known that mature aquaporin water channels move water in an unregulated fashion (1).
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	15	 To modulate overall transepithelial water transport such as in the renal collecting duct, vesicles containing aquaporin 2 water channels are rapidly inserted into the plasma membrane following activation by antidiuretic hormone (8).
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The specific question addressed by this article in focus is whether exocytosis is involved in the activation of Cl secretion via CFTR in the human airway serous cell line, Calu-3.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Serous cells are located primarily in the submucosal glands of human airway and are known to express CFTR.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	18	The overall question of how much of the function of CFTR is dependent on its insertion into the plasma membrane can be answered by the phrase "it depends.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	19	" CFTR is expressed in a variety of tissues, including airway, pancreas, gastrointestinal tract, heart, and kidney, where it participates in ion transport (5).
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Thus how much of CFTR-mediated transport is controlled by exocytosis may depend critically on which organ is being considered.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Moreover, when cultured cells are being studied, it may also depend on the degree of differentiation of the cells.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	22	For example, in the current article in focus (Ref.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	23	 C913 in this issue), Loffing and colleagues demonstrate that exocytosis of CFTR-containing vesicles is not involved in the activation of Cl secretion in Calu-3 cells.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Similarly, exocytic delivery of CFTR does not occur in gallbladder epithelium (14).
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Presumably in these tissues, activation of resident CFTR is sufficient to regulate transport.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	26	 In other tissues such as the shark rectal gland, bronchial epithelial cells, and in transporting cell lines such as Madin-Darby canine kidney (MDCK) II and A6, cAMP increases the amount of CFTR in the apical cell membrane (7, 9, 11, 13).
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	27	 In T84 cells (a colonic epithelial cell line), the results are conflicting, suggesting either that culture conditions may affect the machinery for cAMP-dependent exocytosis of CFTR (12, 15) or that methodological difficulties in localizing CFTR in the plasma membrane make it difficult to detect exocytosis of CFTR.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Thus the question of how much of a role exocytosis plays in regulating the transport of CFTR in T84 cells is still unresolved.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	29	Loffing and colleagues (10) speculate that serous cells in the airway have high basal rates of Cl and antibiotic secretion.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	30	 This may require that high levels of CFTR be present at all times to support such a high level of transport.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Given that CFTR is highly regulated both by phosphorylation and ATP binding and hydrolysis, then why do some tissues need to control its function further by rapidly moving CFTR to the plasma membrane via exocytosis? One may speculate that stimulation of transport via CFTR, by increasing the number of channels though exocytosis, may occur only in tissues such as the shark rectal gland, where very large and rapid changes in transport occur.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	32	This report was funded by grants from the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute, the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases, and the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	33	    REFERENCES Top Article References.

0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	43	 cAMP-regulated trafficking of epitope-tagged CFTR.

0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Acute regulation of CFTR trafficking in an intact epithelium.

0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	48	 44): C913-C920, 1998[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Vesicle targeting and ion secretion in epithelial cells: implications for cystic fibrosis.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Cell surface labeling of CFTR in T84 cells.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	51	 33): C491-C498, 1993[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Rapid endocytosis of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator chloride channel.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	53	 USA 91: 5192-5196, 1994[Abstract].
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Polarized expression of cAMP-activated chloride channels in isolated epithelial cells.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	55	 40): C1574-C1582, 1996[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Apical recruitment of CFTR in T-84 cells is dependent on cAMP and microtubules but not Ca2+ or microfilaments.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	57	 109: 1325-1334, 1996[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	58	Am J Physiol Cell Physiol 275(4):C911-C912 0002-9513/98 $5.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	59	00 Copyright   1998 the American Physiological Society.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	0	EDITORIAL FOCUS Chaperoning the maturation of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator Jeffrey L.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	1	Department of Biological Sciences, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15260.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	2	    ARTICLE TOP ARTICLE REFERENCES.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	3	THE ENDOPLASMIC RETICULUM (ER) serves as a way station during the biogenesis of nearly every integral membrane and secreted protein synthesized in eukaryotic cells.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	4	 As such, its primary role is to facilitate the folding of nascent polypeptides.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Thus plentiful among the ER resident proteins are 1) enzymes that catalyze conformational rearrangements, such as protein disulfide isomerase and peptidylprolyl isomerase; 2) enzymes that chemically modify the nascent polypeptide, such as signal sequence peptidase and oligosaccharyl transferase; and 3) molecules that retain the polypeptide in a soluble, aggregation-free state.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	6	 The factors constituting this last group are molecular chaperones, many of which were first identified as heat shock proteins (HSPs) because their synthesis is induced when cells are exposed to high temperatures or other stresses.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	7	 However, most HSPs have cellular homologs that are constitutively produced, and these are named heat shock cognate proteins (HSCs).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	8	 HSC and HSP molecular chaperones are defined by their molecular masses (in kDa), and a plentiful class found in every cell type are those with a molecular mass of ~70 kDa (i.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	9	HSP70 and HSC70 hydrolyze ATP concomitant with their binding to and release from polypeptide substrates, and their ATPase activities may be activated by another group of chaperones (21, 33) known as HSP40 or DnaJ homologs.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	10	 In some cases, the HSP40 cochaperone delivers a polypeptide substrate to the HSP70 or HSC70 (17, 37).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	11	 With the use of a variety of in vitro techniques, the HSC70 and HSP70 chaperones have been shown to bind preferentially to short stretches of amino acids with overall hydrophobic character (3, 13, 31).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Such motifs are normally buried within the core of a native protein but may become solvent accessible during protein folding and upon protein denaturation.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Thus HSC70 and HSP70 chaperones are ideally suited to aid unfolded proteins en route to their native conformations by limiting protein aggregation.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	14	Deletion of the phenylalanine at position 508 in the cystic fibrosis (CF) transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) is the most common mutation associated with CF (27).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	15	 CFTR most likely functions as a chloride channel in the plasma membrane of airway and other epithelial cells, but cells containing only the F508 variant either lack or harbor variable amounts of the protein at the plasma membrane (7, 16).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Both wild-type and the F508 mutant form of CFTR are translocated into the ER membrane, at which time protein folding should commence.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	17	 However, in vitro studies by Qu and colleagues (25, 26) suggest that the efficiency of F508 CFTR folding is severely impaired compared with that of the wild-type protein.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	18	 It has also been shown that the F508 mutant protein is unable to undergo an ATP-dependent conformational change in the ER (20, 40).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Consistent with an inability of F508 CFTR to fold efficiently, incubation of cells expressing the mutant at lower temperatures, a condition that may favor protein folding and/or stability, permits some of this variant to traffic to the plasma membrane where it is active (10), albeit with a reduced open probability and half-life (9, 11, 19).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	20	 In contrast, if CFTR folding is retarded in the ER, the protein becomes a substrate for ER-associated degradation, a quality control mechanism that degrades aberrant proteins in the secretory pathway (4).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Degradation of CFTR, like most other ER-associated degradation substrates, requires ubiquitinylation and delivery to the multicatalytic cytoplasmic proteasome (14, 36, 38).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Although a significant proportion of even wild-type CFTR is degraded, nearly all of the F508 mutant is destroyed; therefore, cells expressing only the mutant form of the protein are phenotypically null.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	23	Because F508 CFTR is unable to attain a native conformation in the ER, it should not come as a surprise that it interacts with molecular chaperones.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Specifically, cytoplasmic HSC70 and HSP90, the luminal Ca2+-binding chaperone calnexin, and a cytoplasmic HSP40 homolog Hdj2 can be coprecipitated with CFTR (18, 22, 24, 39).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	25	 HSC70 and Hdj2 also prevent the in vitro aggregation of the first nucleotide-binding domain of CFTR (22, 34), the domain in which the phenylalanine at position 508 resides.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Although wild-type, folded CFTR is released from the chaperones on its transit from the ER to the Golgi apparatus, HSC70 and calnexin remain bound to the mutant until degradation ensues (24, 39).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	27	 A HSC70-interacting factor, CHIP, has recently been shown to facilitate the degradation of immature forms of CFTR (23).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	28	 One interpretation of these combined data is that the chaperone-CFTR complexes represent folding intermediates.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	29	Because several human diseases arise from defects in protein folding (4, 35), because of the devastating effects and widespread occurrence of CF, and because a profound amount of information is available on the mechanisms of molecular chaperones, the modulation of protein folding and chaperone activity has been attempted with small molecules and genetic manipulations.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	30	 For example, it was demonstrated by the Welch (5) and Kopito (32) laboratories that F508 CFTR-expressing cells incubated in glycerol, a polyol known to stabilize proteins in vitro, contain ER-matured forms of CFTR and display cAMP (forskolin)-activated plasma membrane chloride transport, a hallmark of functional CFTR.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Glycerol also facilitates the in vitro folding of the first nucleotide-binding domain lacking the phenylalanine at position 508 by preventing off-pathway intermediates from forming (25).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	32	 F508 CFTR-expressing cells incubated in trimethylamine oxide (TMAO), an osmotic stabilizer found in sharks to protect proteins from urea denaturation, exhibit similar properties (5).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Compounds such as TMAO and glycerol are now commonly known as chemical chaperones.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	34	Another means to alter protein folding in vivo is through the modulation of intracellular chaperone concentration.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	35	 (28) showed that sodium 4-phenylbutyrate (4PBA), an ammonia scavenger approved for the treatment of urea cycle disorders and a known transcriptional regulator, permits a fraction of F508 CFTR to mature in bronchial epithelial cell lines and primary nasal epithelial cells from patients with CF.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Maturation of the mutant coincides with cAMP-stimulated plasma membrane Cl conductance in the treated cells.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	37	 To determine the molecular basis of 4PBA-mediated rescue of the F508 CFTR phenotype, immunoprecipitations were performed to examine the amount of CFTR associated with HSC70, and a 4PBA dose-dependent decrease in the amount of CFTR-HSC70 complex was observed (30).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Because HSC70 was shown to facilitate ubiquitination of several test proteins in vitro (2), the authors suggested that HSC70 targets CFTR for degradation and that 4PBA, through an unknown mechanism, reduces the amount of the complex by which CFTR is delivered to the proteasome.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	39	The studies described above support the concept of using chaperone modulation as a means to rectify the pathophysiology associated with F508 CFTR.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Now, three papers in this issue of the American Journal of Physiology-Lung Cellular and Molecular Physiology (8, 12, 29) represent a significant leap in our understanding of the molecular basis of chaperone modulation, with the ultimate hope that such interventions may become clinically relevant for CF.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	41	Building on previous studies, Rubenstein and Lyons (29) show that the mechanism by which 4PBA downregulates HSC70 levels is through a decrease in the stability of HSC70 mRNA.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Although HSC70 mRNA is known to be relatively unstable, 4PBA appears to further accelerate its degradation.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Coincident with an acceleration of mRNA degradation, an ~40% reduction in the amount of HSC70 is evident.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The mechanism by which this occurs is unknown, but it has been shown that inhibiting the initiation of yeast HSC70 translation leads to a rapid destruction of its message (1).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Because a large number of translation poisons are known, many of which were first isolated as antibiotics, this hypothesis can be tested.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	46	Does 4PBA only modulate HSC70 levels? Although previous data (30) suggested that this was so, new work from Choo-Kang and Zeitlin (8) indicates that 4PBA raises HSP70 levels, leading to increased HSP70-F508 CFTR complex formation and F508 CFTR maturation.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	47	 One concern is that this phenomenon may arise from a secondary effect of decreasing HSC70 levels (see above), which, in turn, could induce a general heat shock or stress response.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	48	 However, the authors show that CFTR maturation is also facilitated by selectively increasing the intracellular levels of HSP70 by transient transfection with an HSP70 expression vector.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	49	These combined studies suggest that modulating the levels and thus the activities of HSC70 and HSP70 enhances CFTR maturation.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	50	 They also point to the complexity of HSP70 or HSC70 function in the cell.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	51	, HSP70) facilitates protein folding, its homolog (i.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	52	, HSC70) targets a misfolded protein for degradation.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Previous data suggest that multiple chaperones bind coordinately to nascent polypeptides.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Although the functions of many of these chaperones are likely to be redundant, it seems logical that a subset is required for folding and another subset is necessary for protein degradation.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	55	 If one group fails to fold the polypeptide, another is readily available to target the substrate for destruction.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The activities of the unique sets of chaperones may be further defined by the action of the HSP40/DnaJ cochaperones that regulate HSP70 and HSC70 function.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	57	 In other cases, the folding and degradation targeting activities may reside in one chaperone complex.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	58	 For example, HSP90 has been proposed to facilitate both CFTR maturation and degradation (18).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	59	Another means to catalyze CFTR folding is through the use of chemical chaperones, an attack that has shown promise in in vitro model systems as described above.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	60	 To determine whether this approach is feasible in an animal system, Fischer et al.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	61	 (12) examined whether TMAO corrects the F508 CFTR trafficking defect in mice.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Because the severity of the defect associated with the F508 form of CFTR is most prevalent in the rodent intestine, measurements of rectal potential difference (RPD) were undertaken in control mice, those lacking CFTR, and F508 CFTR mice.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Administration of TMAO over 24 h by subcutaneous injection reveals significant increases in forskolin-activated RPD hyperpolarization in the control and F508 CFTR mice, consistent with a partial rescue of the folding defects associated with the wild-type and mutant proteins.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Most promising from a clinical perspective is the observation that administering the flavinoid apigenin, a CFTR activator, further increases the forskolin-activated RPD in the F508 CFTR-expressing mouse.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	65	 This result supports the promise that combined therapeutic attacks may present the best option to lessen the pathophysiology of CF.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Combining small-molecule activators of CFTR function is warranted, particularly in this case, because the concentrations of TMAO used for these studies are quite high and the physiological effects of prolonged administration of TMAO are unknown.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	67	Might chaperone-based therapies become clinically relevant and generalized to the spectrum of diseases that arise from protein misfolding? The corrective effects of glycerol and 4-PBA on the maturation and secretion of another "conformational disease"-causing protein, the Z variant of antitrypsin, have been recently reported by Burrows et al.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	68	 In addition, other chaperone modulators are currently being examined for their ability to correct misfolded proteins.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	69	 15-Deoxyspergualin, a known HSC70 effector and immunosuppressant, increases the cAMP-stimulated plasma membrane Cl channel activity of F508 CFTR-expressing cells (15).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	70	 However, because an increase in ER-matured forms of F508 CFTR could not be observed with 15-deoxyspergualin treatment, only a small amount of the mutant had likely trafficked to the plasma membrane and yielded the desired activity.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Nevertheless, with the advent of combinatorial chemistry and more defined methods to examine protein folding and chaperone action at the molecular level, I suspect that we will see a new convergence of chemical, cell biological, and biophysical tools geared to combat a variety of human diseases.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	72	Address for reprint requests and other correspondence: J.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	73	 of Biological Sciences, 267 Crawford Hall, Univ.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	74	 of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA 15260 (E-mail: jbrodsky{at}pitt.

0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	167	 EMBO J 16: 1501-1507, 2000[Abstract/Free Full Text].

0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Glycerol reverses the misfolding phenotype of the most common cystic fibrosis mutation.

0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	192	   Zhang, F, Kartner N, and Lukacs GL.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Limited proteolysis as a probe for arrested conformational maturation of F508 CFTR.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Nat Struct Biol 5: 180-183, 1998[ISI][Medline].
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	195	Am J Physiol Lung Cell Mol Physiol 281(1):L39-L42 1040-0605/01 $5.
