0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	371	HOME HELP FEEDBACK SUBSCRIPTIONS ARCHIVE SEARCH TABLE OF CONTENTS  All ASBMB Journals   Molecular and Cellular Proteomics   Journal of Lipid Research   Biochemistry and Molecular Biology Education  Copyright   2005 by the American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	0	Chemokine expression in CF epithelia: implications for the role of CFTR in RANTES expression Lisa M.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Schwiebert1,2, Kim Estell1, and Stacie M.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	2	1 Department of Physiology and Biophysics and 2 Gregory Fleming James Cystic Fibrosis Research Center, University of Alabama, Birmingham, Alabama 35294.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	3	    ABSTRACT Top Abstract Introduction METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION References.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	4	To delineate the mechanisms that facilitate leukocyte migration into the cystic fibrosis (CF) lung, expression of chemokines, including interleukin-8 (IL-8), monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 (MCP-1), and RANTES, was compared between CF and non-CF airway epithelia.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	5	 The findings presented herein demonstrate that, under either basal conditions or tumor necrosis factor- (TNF-)- and/or interferon- (IFN-)-stimulated conditions, a consistent pattern of differences in the secretion of IL-8 and MCP-1 between CF and non-CF epithelial cells was not observed.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	6	 In contrast, CF epithelial cells expressed no detectable RANTES protein or mRNA under basal conditions or when stimulated with TNF- and/or IFN- (P  0.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	7	05), unlike their non-CF counterparts.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Correction of the CF transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) defect in CF airway epithelial cells restored the induction of RANTES protein and mRNA by TNF- in combination with IFN- (P  0.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	9	05) but had little effect on IL-8 or MCP-1 production compared with mock controls.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Transfection studies utilizing RANTES promoter constructs suggested that CFTR activates the RANTES promoter via a nuclear factor-B-mediated pathway.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Together, these results suggest that 1) RANTES expression is altered in CF epithelia and 2) epithelial expression of RANTES, but not IL-8 or MCP-1, is dependent on CFTR.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	12	epithelial cells; cystic fibrosis; cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator; inflammation.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	13	    INTRODUCTION Top Abstract Introduction METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION References.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	14	CYSTIC FIBROSIS (CF) is a lethal inherited disorder caused by mutations in the CF transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene (23).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The CFTR gene encodes a 180-kDa glycosylated protein that functions as a low-conductance, cAMP-regulated chloride channel (23).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Progressive pulmonary tissue damage is a hallmark of CF; however, pancreatic, liver, and intestinal dysfunction are also characteristic of CF.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	17	 The CF lung disease phenotype includes thick mucus secretion and bacterial colonization of the airway with Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Recent reports suggest that the CF lung may exhibit an exaggerated immune response (19) even in the absence of bacterial infection (1, 12).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	19	CF-associated airway inflammation is characterized by a profound influx of neutrophils into the lung; however, other types of leukocytes, including eosinophils and monocytes, have been implicated in CF airway inflammation.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	20	 (2) detected the presence of highly activated eosinophils in the lungs of transplanted and deceased CF patients.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Moreover, Koller and co-workers (13) observed increased levels of eosinophilic cationic protein in the serum and sputum of CF patients compared with healthy nonatopic donors.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	22	 These authors also demonstrated that CF eosinophils have an increased propensity to degranulate in vitro compared with eosinophils isolated from control subjects or patients with bronchial asthma (15).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	23	 In addition, previous studies have reported that monocytes derived from CF patients have an increased metabolic level (34, 36) and generate increased levels of inflammatory mediators, including elastase and superoxide, compared with non-CF monocytes (9, 22, 36).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	24	Airway epithelial cells have been described classically as barrier cells that are involved in ion and fluid homeostasis.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	25	 These cells respond to a variety of environmental stimuli, resulting in the alteration of their cellular functions, such as ion transport and movement of airway secretions.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	26	 In addition, airway epithelial cells may act as immune effector cells in response to endogenous or exogenous stimuli.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Several studies have shown that airway epithelial cells express and secrete a variety of inflammatory mediators, including the chemokines interleukin-8 (IL-8), monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 (MCP-1), and RANTES (regulated on activation, normal T cell expressed, and, presumably, secreted; reviewed in Ref.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	28	 IL-8 belongs to the C-X-C subfamily of chemokines, which displays four highly conserved cysteine amino acid residues, with the first two separated by one nonconserved residue.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	29	 In contrast, MCP-1 and RANTES belong to the C-C subfamily, which exhibits two adjacent cysteine amino acid residues.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	30	 The chemokine subfamilies exhibit cell selectivity with respect to chemoattraction.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Members of the C-X-C subfamily primarily target neutrophils, whereas various members of the C-C subfamily target monocytes, lymphocytes, eosinophils, and basophils.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Specifically, IL-8 mediates neutrophil chemotaxis; however, MCP-1 mediates monocyte and basophil chemotaxis and activation.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	33	 RANTES induces chemotaxis of eosinophils, monocytes, and CD45 RO+ memory T lymphocytes.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	34	 The expression of chemokines by airway epithelial cells implicates these cells in facilitating the leukocyte migration associated with airway inflammatory diseases such as CF.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	35	Despite recent advances in understanding the cellular and molecular basis of CF, the mechanisms that initiate and maintain CF-associated airway inflammation remain ill defined.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	36	 In an attempt to understand the mechanisms that trigger the recruitment of leukocytes into the CF lung, the present study examines the expression of IL-8, MCP-1, and RANTES in CF airway epithelial cells.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Results presented herein demonstrate that, in the presence and/or absence of proinflammatory cytokines, CF airway epithelial cells express the chemokines IL-8 and MCP-1 yet little or no RANTES.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Moreover, these results suggest that complementation of CF epithelial cells with wild-type CFTR (WT-CFTR) to correct the CFTR defect restored cytokine induction of RANTES expression via a nuclear factor-B (NF-B)-mediated pathway but had no effect on IL-8 or MCP-1 expression from these cells.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	39	    METHODS Top Abstract Introduction METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION References.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Experiments employed the following non-CF epithelial cells: the airway epithelial cell lines BEAS2B [bronchial; American Type Culture Collection (ATCC), Manassas, VA], 16HBE14o (bronchial; a gift from Dr.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Dieter Gruenert, University of California, San Francisco, CA; Ref.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	42	 5), and A549 (alveolar type II; ATCC) and the pancreatic carcinoma cell line PANC-1 (ATCC).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	43	 The following CF epithelial cells were utilized: the airway epithelial cell lines IB3-1 (bronchial; F508/W1282X compound heterozygote; a gift from Dr.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Pam Zeitlin, Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, MD; Ref.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	45	 37), CFBE41o (bronchial; F508 homozygote; a gift from Dr.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	46	 5), and CFTE29o (tracheal; F508 homozygote; a gift from Dr.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	47	 5) and the pancreatic adenocarcinoma cell line CFPAC-1 (F508 homozygote; ATCC).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Primary CF (F508 homozygous) and non-CF airway epithelial cells (derived from human bronchi or nasal polyps) were provided by Dr.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Sorscher (Gregory Fleming James Cystic Fibrosis Research Center, University of Alabama, Birmingham, AL; Ref.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	50	 John Engelhardt (University of Iowa, Iowa City, IA; Ref.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Nael McCarty (Emory University, Atlanta, GA; Ref.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	52	 All cells were grown on Vitrogen 100 (Collagen, Palo Alto, CA)-coated flasks; Vitrogen 100 contains a mixture of collagen types I and IV.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	53	 All airway epithelial cells were cultured in LHC-8 medium (Biofluids, Rockville, MD) containing 5% FCS, 1% penicillin-streptomycin, and 0.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	54	 The pancreatic cells were maintained in MEM-D-valine medium (GIBCO BRL Life Technologies, Grand Island, NY) containing 5% FCS, 1% penicillin-streptomycin, and 0.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	55	Correction of CFTR defect in CF epithelial cells.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	56	 CFPAC-1 cells that had been transduced previously with a virus containing WT-CFTR or a control virus (mock) were included in these studies (Ref.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	57	 7; Gregory Fleming James Cystic Fibrosis Research Center).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	58	 IB3-1 cells were transiently transfected as follows.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Cells were grown on Vitrogen 100-coated wells of a 12-well plate in medium (CFPAC-1 in MEM-D-valine; IB3-1 in LHC-8) containing 5% FCS, 1% penicillin-streptomycin, and 0.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	60	 At ~50% confluence, cells were incubated with low-serum Opti-MEM I medium (GIBCO BRL) containing Lipofectamine Plus (6  microg/well; GIBCO BRL) with pRSV-WT-CFTR (Ref.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Erik Schwiebert, University of Alabama, Birmingham, AL) and pSV--galactosidase reporter plasmid (each at 0.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	62	5  microg/well; Promega) or pGreen Lantern-1 [green fluorescence protein (GFP); GIBCO BRL] and pSV--galactosidase reporter plasmid (each at 0.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	63	5  microg/ml) as a mock control for 6 h at 37 degrees C.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	64	 After incubation, 2 ml of MEM-D-valine or LHC-8 medium containing 5% FCS were added to each well, and cells were cultured for an additional 48 h before analysis.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	65	 To determine the percentage of cells transfected transiently, GFP-positive and GFP-negative mock-transfected cells were counted using a fluorescence microscope; transfection percentages normally ranged between 40 and 50%.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Mock and WT-CFTR transfected cells were analyzed for relative transfection efficiency using the -galactosidase reporter assay system (Promega) according to manufacturer's protocols.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	67	 WT-CFTR function in complemented IB3-1 and CFPAC-1 cells was monitored via chloride efflux as described previously (27).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	68	Analysis of IL-8, MCP-1, and RANTES protein expression.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	69	 To analyze IL-8, MCP-1, and RANTES protein expression, cells were cultured in the presence and absence of tumor necrosis factor- (TNF-; 100 ng/ml; R and D Systems, Minneapolis, MN) and/or interferon- (IFN-; 100 ng/ml; R and D Systems) for 18 h at 37 degrees C.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	70	 After culture, supernatants were harvested and prepared for ELISA of IL-8, MCP-1, or RANTES protein content (R and D Systems); cells were harvested and counted to account for differences in cell number.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	71	 ELISAs were performed according to the manufacturer's protocol (limits of detection  < 3 pg/ml).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	72	Analysis of IL-8, MCP-1, and RANTES mRNA expression.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	73	 To analyze IL-8, MCP-1, and RANTES mRNA expression, cells were cultured in the presence and absence of TNF- (100 ng/ml) and/or IFN- (100 ng/ml) for 2 (IL-8, MCP-1) or 18 (RANTES) h at 37 degrees C.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	74	 After culture, total RNA was isolated from these cells with TRIzol (GIBCO BRL) and prepared for Northern blot analysis.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	75	 For Northern blot analysis, ~10  microg of total RNA were electrophoresed through a formaldehyde-containing gel and then transferred to nitrocellulose (GeneScreen Plus, Amersham, Arlington Heights, IL).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Blots were prehybridized in a buffer containing 50% formamide, 2 x  PIPES buffer (0.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	77	5% SDS, and denatured salmon sperm DNA (100  microg/ml; Sigma Chemical, St.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Louis, MO) for 18 h at 37 degrees C.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Blots were hybridized with a DNA fragment specific for IL-8, MCP-1, or RANTES that was randomly labeled (Random Prime labeling kit, Promega) with [-32P]dATP (5  x  105 counts   min1   ml1; New England Nuclear, Boston, MA) for 18 h at 37 degrees C.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	80	 After hybridization, blots were washed once with 2 x  SSC (0.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	81	03 M trisodium citrate   2H2O, pH 7.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	82	0) for 15 min at room temperature, once with 2 x  SSC-1% SDS for 15 min at 65 degrees C, and once with 0.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	83	1 x  SSC for 15 min at room temperature.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Blots were then prepared for autoradiography.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	85	 To control for differences in loading, blots were stripped (0.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	86	0% SDS, heated to 100 degrees C, 15 min) and then hybridized with glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase probe as described above.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Results from these analyses were quantitated through densitometry.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	88	Analysis of RANTES promoter activity.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	89	 To analyze RANTES promoter activity, constructs containing portions of the RANTES promoter ligated to a luciferase reporter gene were generated and provided by Dr.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Hiro Moriuchi (National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD) (17).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	91	4-kb 5' noncoding sequence of the RANTES gene (1.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	92	4RANTES) was cloned into pGL2-basic (Promega).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	93	2RANTES, and a site-directed mutation of an NF-B binding site within this noncoding sequence, designated B, were confirmed via ddDNA sequencing (17).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	94	 IB3-1 cells were cotransfected with pSV--galactosidase, pRSV-WT-CFTR, and pGL2-basic, 1.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	95	5  microg/ml) in the presence of Lipofectamine Plus as described above (Correction of CFTR defect in CF epithelial cells).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	96	 In parallel experiments, IB3-1 cells were cotransfected with pSV--galactosidase, pGreen Lantern (GFP), and the respective RANTES promoter construct as mock controls (each at 0.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	97	 After transfection, cells were cultured in the presence and absence of TNF- in combination with IFN- (each at 100 ng/ml) for 18 h at 37 degrees C.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Cells were then harvested, and luciferase activity was monitored via the dual-luciferase reporter assay system (Promega) according to the manufacturer's protocol.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	99	 The percentage of cells transfected transiently, determined via GFP expression as described above, ranged between 40 and 50%; relative transfection efficiency was assessed via measurement of -galactosidase activity.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	100	    RESULTS Top Abstract Introduction METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION References.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	101	IL-8 expression in CF and non-CF airway epithelial cells.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	102	 CF-associated inflammation is characterized by a profound influx of neutrophils into the lung.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	103	 To determine whether epithelial cells contribute to CF airway inflammation through increased expression of the neutrophil chemoattractant IL-8, expression of IL-8 was compared between CF and non-CF airway epithelial cells in vitro.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Specifically, IL-8 expression was analyzed in the non-CF airway epithelial cell lines BEAS2B, 16HBE14o, and A549 and the CF airway epithelial cell lines IB3-1, CFBE41o, and CFTE29o.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	105	 IB3-1 is heterozygous for the F508 CFTR mutation (F508/W1282X), whereas CFBE41o and CFTE29o are homozygous for the F508 CFTR mutation.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	106	 IL-8 expression was also compared between primary CF and non-CF airway epithelial cells; the CF primary cells were homozygous for the F508 CFTR mutation.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	107	 For these analyses, epithelial cells were cultured in the presence and absence of the proinflammatory cytokines TNF- and IFN-, as these cytokines have been shown previously to upregulate chemokine expression in airway epithelial cells (33).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Moreover, increased levels of TNF- have been detected in bronchioalveolar lavage fluid (BALF) collected from CF patients (26).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	109	 1, BEAS2B cells expressed IL-8 protein under basal conditions ( > 20 ng/106 cells); TNF- in combination with IFN- stimulated a twofold increase in IL-8 protein expression in these cells (Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	110	 16HBE14o and A549 cells also expressed IL-8 protein under basal conditions (~0.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	111	 TNF- stimulation of 16HBE14o and A549 cells induced a 10- to 100-fold increase in IL-8 protein expression in these cells (between 2 and 20 ng/106 cells); IFN- either had no effect (A549) or inhibited IL-8 expression (16HBE14o) (Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	112	 The CF airway epithelial cell lines IB3-1, CFBE41o, and CFTE29o each expressed low levels of IL-8 protein (between 0 and 0.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	113	5 ng/106 cells) under basal conditions; IL-8 expression in these cells was enhanced between 3- and 80-fold in the presence of TNF- alone or TNF- in combination with IFN- (between 1.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	114	 In comparison, CF and non-CF primary airway epithelial cells expressed greater amounts of IL-8 protein (~80 ng/106 cells) under basal conditions than their respective cell lines (Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Interestingly, TNF- together with IFN- did not significantly affect IL-8 protein expression in these cells (Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Northern blot analysis of the CF and non-CF airway epithelial cell lines and primary cells described above, cultured in the presence and absence of TNF- and/or IFN-, revealed that IL-8 mRNA expression (data not shown) paralleled the pattern of IL-8 protein expression observed in these cells (Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Overall, these data suggest that CF and non-CF airway epithelial cells express IL-8 in the presence and absence of TNF- and IFN- at levels that are not consistent.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	118	View larger version (30K):    Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	119	   Cystic fibrosis (CF) and non-CF epithelial cells express varied levels of interleukin-8 (IL-8) protein.

0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	123	05 compared with carrier control.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	124	MCP-1 expression in CF and non-CF airway epithelial cells.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Monocytes derived from CF patients have been reported to exhibit an increased metabolic level (34, 36) and to generate increased levels of inflammatory mediators, such as elastase and superoxide, compared with non-CF monocytes (9, 22, 36).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	126	 To determine whether CF airway epithelial cells express the monocyte-chemoattracting and -activating agent MCP-1, MCP-1 expression was compared between CF and non-CF airway epithelial cell lines and primary cells in vitro.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	127	 2, BEAS2B cells expressed MCP-1 protein under basal conditions (~16 ng/106 cells); TNF- in combination with IFN- enhanced this expression approximately twofold (26 ng/106 cells).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	128	 In comparison, 16HBE14o and A549 cells expressed little or no MCP-1 protein in the absence of stimuli (Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Interestingly, TNF- and/or IFN- induced a 60- to 140-fold increase in MCP-1 protein expression in A549 cells yet had no effect on MCP-1 expression in 16HBE14o cells (Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	130	 The CF cell lines CFBE41o and IB3-1 expressed no detectable MCP-1 protein under basal conditions; however, CFTE29o cells expressed ~5 ng/106 cells under basal conditions (Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	131	 TNF- or IFN- alone had no effect on MCP-1 protein expression in CFBE41o or CFTE29o cells yet induced expression in IB3-1 cells to ~20 ng/106 cells; TNF- in combination with IFN- enhanced MCP-1 protein expression (~2.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	132	5 ng/106 cells) in CFBE41o cells only.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	133	 In contrast, neither CF nor non-CF primary airway epithelial cells expressed MCP-1 protein under basal conditions (Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	134	 However, TNF- together with IFN- induced a significant increase in MCP-1 expression in CF cells (18 ng/106 cells) and non-CF cells (42 ng/106 cells).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Northern blot analysis of the CF and non-CF airway epithelial cell lines and primary cells described above, cultured in the presence and absence of TNF- and/or IFN-, revealed that MCP-1 mRNA expression (data not shown) paralleled the pattern of MCP-1 protein expression observed in these cells (Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Taken together, these findings indicate that, although CF and non-CF primary airway epithelial cells expressed significantly different levels of MCP-1 in the presence and absence of TNF- and IFN-, the respective cell lines do not express consistent levels of MCP-1.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	137	View larger version (33K):    Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	138	   CF and non-CF epithelial cells express varied levels of monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 (MCP-1).

0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	142	05 compared with carrier control.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	143	RANTES expression in CF and non-CF airway epithelial cells.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Recent studies suggest that eosinophils may play a role in the progressive tissue damage observed in the CF lung (2).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	145	 To determine whether CF epithelial cells express the eosinophil chemoattractant RANTES, RANTES expression was compared between CF and non-CF airway epithelial cells in vitro.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Specifically, the levels of RANTES were compared, under basal and TNF-- and/or IFN--stimulated conditions, between the non-CF airway epithelial cell lines BEAS2B, 16HBE14o, and A549 and the CF airway epithelial cell lines CFBE41o, IB3-1, and CFTE29o as well as between non-CF and CF primary airway epithelial cells.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	147	 3A, BEAS2B and A549 expressed low levels of RANTES protein ( < 1 ng/106 cells) under basal conditions or when stimulated with IFN-; TNF- induced RANTES protein expression (12 ng/106 cells) in A549 cells only.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	148	 However, TNF- in combination with IFN- induced a significant increase in RANTES protein expression in both BEAS2B cells (14 ng/106 cells) (31, 35) and A549 cells (28 ng/106 cells) (Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	149	 3A), as has been reported previously (16).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Interestingly, 16HBE14o cells expressed RANTES constitutively (~6 ng/106 cells); TNF- and/or IFN- had no effect on RANTES expression in these cells (Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	151	 In contrast, CFBE41o, IB3-1, and CFTE29o cells expressed no detectable RANTES protein under basal conditions or in the presence of TNF- and/or IFN- (Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	152	 In comparison, non-CF and CF primary airway epithelial cells expressed no detectable RANTES protein in the absence of stimuli (Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	153	 TNF- in combination with IFN- stimulated RANTES protein expression in non-CF cells (33 ng/106 cells), yet these proinflammatory cytokines had no significant effect on CF cells (Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	154	 These results suggest that CF airway epithelial cells express no detectable RANTES protein compared with non-CF controls under basal or cytokine-stimulated conditions.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	155	View larger version (25K):    Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	156	   CF airway epithelial cells do not express RANTES protein.

0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	158	 After culture, supernatants were collected and analyzed via a RANTES-specific ELISA; cells were harvested and counted to account for differences in cell number.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Results are reported as ng RANTES protein/106 cells (n = 6-9).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	160	To compare RANTES mRNA expression between non-CF and CF airway epithelia, the non-CF airway epithelial cell lines BEAS2B, A549, and 16HBE14o and the CF airway epithelial cell lines IB3-1, CFBE41o, and CFTE29o as well as non-CF and CF primary airway epithelial cells were cultured in the presence and absence of TNF- and/or IFN- and then analyzed for mRNA expression via Northern blot analysis.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	161	 4, TNF- in combination with IFN- stimulated significant levels of RANTES mRNA expression (6-fold over basal levels) in BEAS2B cells; TNF- or IFN- alone had no effect on RANTES expression in these cells.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	162	 However, TNF- alone or together with IFN- induced a significant increase (~2-fold and 7-fold over basal levels, respectively) in RANTES mRNA expression in the non-CF airway epithelial cell line A549 (Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Interestingly, 16HBE14o cells exhibited significant levels of RANTES mRNA expression in both the absence and presence of TNF- and/or IFN- (Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	164	 In contrast, IB3-1, CFBE41o, and CFTE29o cells expressed no detectable RANTES mRNA in the presence or absence of TNF- and/or IFN- (Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Importantly, non-CF and CF primary airway epithelial cells yielded patterns of RANTES mRNA expression similar to those observed in their respective cell lines.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	166	 TNF- together with IFN- stimulated a significant increase in RANTES mRNA expression (~5-fold over basal levels) in non-CF cells yet failed to stimulate RANTES mRNA expression in CF cells (Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Together, these findings indicate that CF airway epithelial cells express no detectable RANTES mRNA compared with their non-CF counterparts.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	168	View larger version (49K):    Fig.

0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	177	IL-8, MCP-1, and RANTES expression in non-CF and CF pancreatic epithelial cells.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	178	 To determine whether the pattern of IL-8, MCP-1, and RANTES expression observed in CF airway epithelial cells was exhibited by epithelial cells derived from CF-affected organ systems other than the lung, IL-8, MCP-1, and RANTES expression was compared between non-CF and CF pancreatic epithelial cell lines in the presence and absence of TNF- and IFN-.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	179	 The non-CF pancreatic epithelial cell line PANC-1 and the CF pancreatic cell line CFPAC-1 (F508 homozygote) were utilized in these studies.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	180	 5, PANC-1 cells cultured with TNF- alone or together with IFN- expressed increased levels of IL-8 protein (11 and 6 ng/106 cells, respectively).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Interestingly, CFPAC-1 cells expressed approximately eightfold more IL-8 protein (9 ng/106 cells) under basal conditions than their non-CF counterpart; TNF- alone or TNF- together with IFN- further enhanced IL-8 protein expression in CFPAC-1 cells (23 ng/106 cells; Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	182	 A similar pattern of IL-8 mRNA expression was observed in PANC-1 and CFPAC-1 cells (data not shown).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	183	 In contrast, PANC-1 cells expressed MCP-1 protein constitutively (between 20 and 24 ng/106 cells); TNF- and/or IFN- had no effect on MCP-1 protein expression in these cells (Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Interestingly, CFPAC-1 cells expressed significantly less MCP-1 protein (between 3 and 5 ng/106 cells) than their non-CF counterpart; TNF- and/or IFN- had no effect (Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	185	 A similar pattern of MCP-1 mRNA expression was observed in PANC-1 and CFPAC-1 cells (data not shown).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Together, these results demonstrate that CF and non-CF pancreatic epithelial cells display a different pattern of IL-8 and MCP-1 expression than that observed for the CF and non-CF airway epithelial cells described above.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	187	View larger version (21K):    Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	188	   CF and non-CF pancreatic cells express IL-8, MCP-1, and RANTES differentially.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	189	 CF and non-CF pancreatic epithelial cells were cultured in presence and absence of TNF- and/or IFN- (each at 100 ng/ml) for 18 h at 37 degrees C.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Supernatants were collected, and cells were harvested and counted to control for differences in cell number; supernatants were analyzed via ELISA for IL-8 (A), MCP-1 (B), and RANTES (C) protein content.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Results are reported as ng protein/106 cells (n = 3).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	192	Interestingly, CF and non-CF pancreatic epithelial cells exhibited a pattern of RANTES expression similar to that observed in CF and non-CF airway epithelial cells.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Specifically, PANC-1 cells expressed increased levels (between 20 and 25 ng/106 cells) of RANTES protein (Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	194	 6) when stimulated with TNF- alone or in combination with IFN-; low levels of RANTES protein (1 ng/106 cells) and mRNA were observed under basal conditions or in the presence of IFN- alone.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	195	 CFPAC-1 cells, however, expressed little or no detectable RANTES protein (Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	196	 6) in the presence and absence of TNF- and/or IFN-.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Because these findings parallel the pattern of RANTES expression observed in non-CF and CF airway epithelial cells, these findings demonstrate that epithelial cells derived from multiple CF-affected organs express significantly lower amounts of RANTES than their non-CF counterparts.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	198	View larger version (47K):    Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	199	   CF pancreatic cells do not express RANTES mRNA.

0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Lane 1, carrier control; lane 2, TNF-; lane 3, IFN-; lane 4, TNF- + IFN-.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	205	Role of CFTR in the regulation of IL-8, MCP-1, and RANTES expression.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	206	 To determine whether CFTR directly modulates chemokine expression in epithelial cells, the CF epithelial cell lines CFPAC-1 and IB3-1 were complemented with either WT-CFTR, to correct the mutant CFTR phenotype, or a mock control and then analyzed for IL-8, MCP-1, and RANTES expression in the presence and absence of TNF- and/or IFN-.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Specifically, CFPAC-1 cells that had been transduced previously with an engineered PLJ virus containing either WT-CFTR or a mock control (7) and IB3-1 cells that were transiently transfected with a plasmid carrying either WT-CFTR or a mock control were utilized in these studies (8).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	208	 WT-CFTR function in complemented CFPAC-1 and IB3-1 cells was monitored via chloride efflux as described previously (27).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Each cell type complemented with WT-CFTR displayed at least a twofold increase in chloride efflux activity in the presence of cAMP nucleotide analogs compared with mock controls (data not shown); these results suggest that WT-CFTR was expressed and functional in the complemented CFPAC-1 and IB3-1 cells.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Transient transfection of IB3-1 cells with WT-CFTR did not alter the protein or mRNA expression of IL-8 or MCP-1, either under basal or cytokine-stimulated conditions, compared with mock controls (data not shown).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Similarly, CFPAC-1 cells transduced with a virus containing WT-CFTR expressed equivalent levels of IL-8 and MCP-1 protein and mRNA; TNF- and/or IFN- did not further enhance IL-8 or MCP-1 expression above mock control levels (data not shown).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	212	 In contrast, CFPAC-1 and IB3-1 cells that were complemented with WT-CFTR displayed a significant increase in RANTES protein expression (CFPAC-1, 3.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	213	4 ng/106 cells or 7-fold; IB3-1, 1.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	214	3 ng/106 cells or 2-fold) when cultured in the presence of TNF- in combination with IFN- compared with respective mock controls (Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	215	 CFPAC-1 containing WT-CFTR also displayed a significant increase in RANTES mRNA when stimulated simultaneously with TNF- and IFN- (9-fold greater than mock control, Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	216	 No significant difference in RANTES expression was observed between WT-CFTR-complemented CFPAC-1 and IB3-1 cells and their respective mock controls under basal conditions or when stimulated with TNF- or IFN- separately (Figs.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	217	 These findings, taken together with the results presented above, demonstrate that CFTR modulates the expression of RANTES, but not IL-8 or MCP-1, at the protein and mRNA levels.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	218	View larger version (17K):    Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	219	   CF epithelial cells complemented with wild-type CF transmembrane conductance regulator (WT-CFTR) express RANTES protein in presence of TNF- and IFN-.

0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Lane 1, carrier control; lane 2, TNF-; lane 3, IFN-; lane 4, TNF- + IFN-.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	230	Effect of WT-CFTR on RANTES promoter activity.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	231	 RANTES gene expression has been reported to be regulated at the level of transcription and not mRNA stability (25).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Therefore, to delineate the role of CFTR in RANTES mRNA expression, transfection assays utilizing RANTES promoter constructs fused to a luciferase reporter gene were performed in IB3-1 CF airway epithelial cells complemented with WT-CFTR and their respective mock controls; RANTES promoter constructs were generated and provided by Dr.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	233	4-kb 5' noncoding sequence of the RANTES gene was cloned into pGL2-basic (Promega); this 1.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	234	4-kb region, 5' deletion mutations of this region, and a site-directed mutation in an NF-B binding site of this region (Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	235	 9, IB3-1 cells transfected with the complete 1.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	236	4-kb RANTES promoter construct in the absence of WT-CFTR displayed low reporter activity in the presence or absence of TNF-/IFN-.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	237	 In contrast, IB3-1 cells transfected with the 1.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	238	4-kb RANTES promoter construct together with WT-CFTR displayed an approximately fourfold increase in reporter activity in the presence of TNF- and IFN- compared with unstimulated controls (Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	239	 To determine the regions of the RANTES promoter that were essential for CFTR-mediated activation, 5' deletions of the RANTES promoter construct were analyzed.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Interestingly, IB3-1 cells transfected with only 0.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	241	4-kb RANTES promoter construct, either in the absence or presence of WT-CFTR, exhibited increased reporter activity under basal conditions, suggesting that a negative regulatory element exists upstream of this deletion; this activity was not responsive to the effects of TNF- and IFN- (Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	242	 However, IB3-1 cells transfected with only 0.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	243	4-kb RANTES promoter construct displayed a pattern of activity similar to that observed for the complete 1.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	244	 Specifically, IB3-1 cells transfected with the 0.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	245	2-kb RANTES promoter construct together with WT-CFTR exhibited a fourfold increase in reporter activity when stimulated with TNF- in combination with IFN- compared with unstimulated and mock controls (Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	246	 These findings indicate that transcription factor binding sites located within 300 bp upstream of the 0.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	247	2-kb construct, such as activator protein-1, signal transducer and activator of transcription (STAT), and nuclear factor of activated T cells (NF-AT) (Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	248	 9A), mediate constitutive activation of the RANTES promoter; however, binding sites within the 0.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	249	2-kb construct itself, including nuclear factor IL-6 and NF-B (Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	250	 9A), confer WT-CFTR modulation of RANTES promoter activation.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	251	 NF-B has been implicated as an essential factor in the TNF-- and/or IFN--mediated induction of RANTES gene expression (17, 21).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	252	 To determine whether WT-CFTR modulates RANTES promoter activation via NF-B, IB3-1 cells were transfected with the complete 1.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	253	4-kb RANTES promoter construct containing a mutant NF-B site (B) and WT-CFTR or mock control.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	254	 9C, IB3-1 cells transfected with both WT-CFTR and the B RANTES promoter construct were not responsive to the effects of TNF- and/or IFN-, as had been observed with the intact 1.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Taken together, these results suggest that, in the presence of TNF- and IFN-, WT-CFTR modulates activation of the RANTES promoter in airway epithelial cells via an NF-B-mediated pathway.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	256	View larger version (21K):    Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	257	   WT-CFTR modulates RANTES promoter activation in presence of TNF- and IFN-.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	258	4-kb 5' noncoding sequence of RANTES gene (modified from Ref.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	259	 17), showing mutant nuclear factor-B (NF-B) binding site (B).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	260	 RANTES promoter constructs containing 1.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	261	2R) of 5' noncoding sequence or B were utilized.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	262	 B: IB3-1 cells were transfected transiently with 1.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	263	2R and WT-CFTR or a mock control.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	264	 C: IB3-1 cells were transfected transiently with 1.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	265	4R or B construct and WT-CFTR or a mock control.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	266	 Cells were then cultured in presence and absence of TNF- and IFN- as described in Fig.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	267	 3, harvested, counted, and processed for reporter activity.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	268	 Results are reported as relative reporter activity compared with unstimulated mock controls (n = 3-5).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	269	    DISCUSSION Top Abstract Introduction METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION References.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	270	The present study was performed to delineate the role of the airway epithelium in the leukocyte recruitment associated with CF airway inflammation.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	271	 The data presented herein demonstrate that CF and non-CF airway epithelial cells, in the presence or absence of the proinflammatory cytokines TNF- and IFN-, expressed levels of IL-8 and MCP-1 that were not consistent; therefore, these data suggest that no differences exist in the expression of these molecules between CF and non-CF cells.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	272	 In sharp contrast, however, CF epithelial cells expressed little or no RANTES protein or mRNA compared with non-CF controls.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	273	 Although CF and non-CF epithelial cells derived from the pancreas, another CF-affected organ, exhibited a pattern of IL-8 and MCP-1 expression that differed from their respective airway epithelial counterparts, the pattern of RANTES expression was the same: CF pancreatic epithelial cells expressed no detectable RANTES protein or mRNA compared with non-CF controls.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	274	 Importantly, insertion of WT-CFTR into CF airway and pancreatic epithelial cells to correct the CFTR defect restored RANTES protein and mRNA expression in the presence of TNF- and IFN- via an NF-B-mediated pathway; however, correction of the CFTR defect had no effect on IL-8 or MCP-1 expression in these cells.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	275	 Together, these results demonstrate that 1) cytokine-induced RANTES expression is altered in CF epithelia and 2) epithelial gene expression of RANTES, but not IL-8 or MCP-1, is dependent on CFTR.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	276	The studies presented herein were performed in the presence and absence of TNF- and/or IFN-, but not P.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	277	 (26) detected elevated levels of TNF- in the sputum of CF patients who were not infected with P.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	278	 Their study concluded that high concentrations of proinflammatory cytokines, including TNF-, may contribute to the localized neutrophil-dominated inflammatory state observed in the CF airway (26).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Second, increasing evidence suggests that an exaggerated inflammatory response may exist in the CF lung in the presence or absence of bacterial infection.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	280	 (12) demonstrated that airway inflammation may occur before the appearance of bacterial pathogens in CF patients.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	281	 These investigators examined BALF from control and CF infants; their results demonstrated a significant increase in the number of neutrophils and in IL-8 levels in the BALF of CF infants who had negative cultures for common bacterial CF-related pathogens, including P.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	282	 aeruginosa and Staphylococcus aureus, compared with normal controls.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	283	 In contrast, Armstrong and co-workers (1) reported that the early onset of airway inflammation in CF infants is due to the presence of respiratory pathogens not previously diagnosed.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	284	 Their studies demonstrated that increased neutrophil numbers and IL-8 levels in the BALF of CF infants correlate with bacteria and/or viral infection.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	285	 However, these authors also showed that uninfected CF infants have a greater number of BALF neutrophils than normal controls, suggesting that an enhanced airway inflammatory response occurs in CF patients (1).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	286	 (19) reported that IL-8 levels were markedly elevated in the BALF of infected CF patients compared with levels in infected and uninfected controls, even after standardization of IL-8 concentrations to bacterial counts.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	287	Although the studies presented herein indicate that CF and non-CF airway epithelial cell lines express inconsistent differences in the levels of IL-8 and MCP-1 in the presence and absence of TNF- and IFN-, the mere expression of these chemokines implicates CF epithelia in the leukocyte migration observed in CF-associated airway inflammation.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	288	 Moreover, the observation that CF and non-CF airway epithelial cells expressed comparable levels of IL-8, in the presence or absence of proinflammatory cytokines, together with the observation that complementation of CF epithelial cells did not alter IL-8 expression by these cells, suggests 1) that enhanced IL-8 expression by CF airway epithelial cells is not the source of the increased IL-8 levels detected in uninfected CF patient BALF and 2) that cytokine-induced epithelial IL-8 expression is regulated independently of CFTR.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	289	 These findings contradict previous studies that reported increased IL-8 expression by CF airway epithelial cells in the presence and absence of proinflammatory stimuli (24, 30).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	290	 Ruef and co-workers (24) demonstrated that the CF airway epithelial cell line JME/CF15 secreted IL-8 in the absence of stimuli; this expression was enhanced further in the presence of IL-1.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	291	 From these analyses of a single CF epithelial cell line, the authors concluded that local production of IL-8 by CF epithelial cells may trigger significant upregulation of airway inflammation in CF (24).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	292	 (30) reported recently that the CF airway epithelial cell lines IB3-1 and 2CF expressed significantly more IL-8 protein than the non-CF epithelial cell lines BEAS2B or normal human primary bronchial epithelial cells in the presence of TNF- or IL-1; the WT-CFTR-complemented IB3-1 cell line C38 expressed IL-8 levels that were similar to that expressed by non-CF cells.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	293	 However, these authors examined only two CF epithelial cell lines, did not compare IL-8 expression between CF and non-CF primary airway epithelial cells, and, importantly, did not demonstrate that the complemented cell line C38 exhibited WT-CFTR activity (30).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	294	The inability of CF epithelial cells to express RANTES protein or mRNA suggests that these cells do not recruit eosinophils into the CF lung via this particular C-C chemokine.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	295	 Airway epithelial cells have been shown to express C-C chemokines other than RANTES, including eotaxin (20) and MCP-4 (32), that may facilitate eosinophil migration.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	296	 To this end, we have been unable to detect eotaxin expression in CF and non-CF primary airway epithelial cells; however, we have observed that the non-CF pancreatic epithelial cell line PANC-1 expresses eotaxin in response to TNF- alone or together with IFN-, whereas its CF counterpart CFPAC-1 does not (L.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	297	 Schwiebert, unpublished observations).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	298	 In a recent report by Stellato et al.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	299	 (32), the authors demonstrated that the CF airway epithelial cell line IB3-1 expressed MCP-1 mRNA in the presence of TNF- in combination with IFN-.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	300	 However, the level of MCP-4 mRNA expression in IB3-1 cells was significantly lower than that observed in the non-CF airway epithelial cell lines BEAS2B and A549 stimulated in the same manner (32).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	301	 (14) observed that RANTES levels in the BALF of CF patients were significantly lower than RANTES levels in the BALF of asthmatics.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	302	 This report suggests that expression of RANTES by other cell types that express this chemokine, including T lymphocytes and macrophages, may be depressed in the CF lung.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	303	 At present, it is unclear what role RANTES may play in improving CF-associated airway inflammation and/or bacterial clearance of the CF lung.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	304	RANTES gene expression appears to be regulated at the level of transcription; the 3' untranslated region of RANTES mRNA does not contain an AU-repeat element, suggesting that RANTES mRNA expression is not regulated at the level of mRNA stability (25).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	305	 Results reported herein demonstrate that TNF- and IFN- synergize in the induction of RANTES expression in CF epithelial cells complemented with WT-CFTR and that WT-CFTR modulates RANTES promoter activation via NF-B.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	306	 The NF-B transcription factor family is composed of c-Rel, NF-B1 (p50), NF-B2 (p52), RelA (p65) and RelB (reviewed in Ref.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	307	 Most members of this family can form homo- or heterodimers that are retained in the cytoplasm of unactivated cells through interaction with members of the IB inhibitor family; members of the IB family include IB, IB, and IBR (3).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	308	 TNF- has been reported to induce rapid phosphorylation and subsequent degradation of IB, allowing NF-B to translocate to the nucleus and activate transcription (3).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	309	 Interestingly, a recent paper by Ray and co-workers (21) suggests that RANTES and IL-8 are differentially regulated by NF-B.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	310	 These authors reported that overexpression of IBR in the alveolar epithelial cell line A549 sequesters p50 homodimers, thereby facilitating the binding of a unique NF-B-Rel complex to the RANTES B region; this binding, in turn, triggered a rapid 50- to 100-fold induction of RANTES upon cytokine stimulation compared with control cells (21).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	311	 However, IBR overexpression in A549 cells did not enhance gene expression of the chemokine IL-8 (21).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	312	It is possible that a loss of CFTR activity, i.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	313	, loss of chloride transport, in CF epithelial cells may alter the activity of transcription factors such as NF-B and the subsequent induction of RANTES gene expression.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	314	 Several studies have linked the activity of ion channels to immune responses in vivo (10, 11, 29).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	315	 Cahalan and Lewis (4) hypothesize that activating kinase-regulated chloride channels, such as CFTR, may result in the depolarization of the membrane potential and, thereby, may suppress mitogen-stimulated calcium influx.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	316	 (18) demonstrated that adding a permeable cAMP analog to T lymphocytes suppressed both calcium influx and NF-AT-mediated gene expression of IL-2 in response to T cell receptor activation.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	317	 The activity of transcription factors other than NF-AT, including c-Fos, has also been linked to membrane depolarization and calcium influx (29).
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	318	Defining the cellular and molecular mechanisms that trigger the migration of leukocytes into the CF lung will be critical in understanding the pathophysiology of this disease.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	319	 Moreover, determining how CFTR regulates the expression of chemokines, such as RANTES, will further the understanding of airway inflammation in general.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	320	 Schleimer for encouragement and Drs.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	321	 Etty Benveniste, John Engelhardt, Nael McCarty, Hiro Moriuchi, Erik M.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	322	 Schwiebert, and Theresa Strong for assistance.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	323	 Sorscher, the Department of Physiology and Biophysics, and the Gregory Fleming James Cystic Fibrosis Research Center for continued support.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	324	This work was funded by grants from the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation and the American Lung Association.
0.41277942.10069998.html.plaintext.txt	325	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
