0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	0	Erythrocytes of humans with cystic fibrosis fail to stimulate nitric oxide synthesis in isolated rabbit lungs Griffith Liang,2 Alan H.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	1	Departments of 1Pharmacological and Physiological Science and 2Internal Medicine, Saint Louis University School of Medicine, St.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	2	Submitted 9 August 2004 ; accepted in final form 2 December 2004.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	3	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION GRANTS REFERENCES   Erythrocytes (red blood cells) of either rabbits or healthy humans are required to demonstrate the participation of nitric oxide (NO) in the regulation of pulmonary vascular resistance in the isolated rabbit lung.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	4	 The property of the erythrocyte that is responsible for the stimulation of NO synthesis was reported to be the ability to release ATP in response to physiological stimuli, including deformation.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Moreover, a signal transduction pathway that relates mechanical deformation of erythrocytes to ATP release has been described, and the cystic fibrosis (CF) transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) is a component, i.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	6	, erythrocytes of individuals with CF do not release ATP in response to deformation.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Here, we investigated the hypothesis that, in contrast to those of healthy humans, erythrocytes of humans with CF fail to stimulate endogenous NO synthesis in the isolated rabbit lung.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	8	 We report that CFTR is a component of the membranes of both rabbit and human erythrocytes.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	9	 The addition of the NO synthase inhibitor N-nitro-L-arginine methyl ester (L-NAME, 100  microM) produced increases in vascular resistance in isolated rabbit lungs perfused with physiological salt solution (PSS) containing erythrocytes of healthy humans, but L-NAME was without effect when the lungs were perfused with PSS alone or PSS containing erythrocytes of CF patients.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	10	 These results provide support for the hypothesis that, in CF, a defect in ATP release from erythrocytes could lead to decreased endogenous pulmonary NO synthesis and contribute to pulmonary hypertension.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	11	adenosine triphosphate; red blood cells; pulmonary circulation.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	12	IT IS WELL ESTABLISHED that the endothelium-derived relaxing factor nitric oxide (NO) is produced by endothelial cells and, when released, relaxes vascular smooth muscle (10, 14, 19).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Physiologically, an alteration in shear applied to the endothelium of blood vessels has been suggested to be a major stimulus for NO release (3, 22).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	14	 However, in the pulmonary circulation, a reappraisal of this viewpoint was required when it was reported that, in isolated rabbit (31) and rat (36, 38) lungs perfused with a physiological salt solution (PSS), alterations in shear stress alone did not evoke release of NO.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	15	 In contrast, when lungs of these species were perfused with either blood (36) or PSS containing washed erythrocytes (30, 38), inhibition of endogenous NO synthesis produced a shift in the slope of the pressure-flow relationship consistent with a decrease in vascular caliber, i.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	16	, NO was a determinant of vascular resistance.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	17	 The ability of the erythrocyte to stimulate NO synthesis in the pulmonary circulation of the rabbit and rat was reported to be independent of effects on viscosity or pressure (31, 36).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The property of the erythrocyte that was associated with the stimulation of endogenous NO synthesis was shown to be the release of ATP (26, 28, 30).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	19	 In support of the hypothesis that erythrocyte-derived ATP is a stimulus for endogenous NO synthesis in the lung, the addition of ATP to the perfusate of isolated rabbit lungs produces vasodilation that is, in large part, dependent on the stimulation of endogenous NO synthesis (30).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Importantly, in addition to rabbit erythrocytes, human erythrocytes were reported both to release ATP in response to physiological stimuli, such as mechanical deformation, and to stimulate endogenous NO synthesis in the isolated perfused rabbit lung (26).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	21	Recently, a signal transduction pathway that relates mechanical deformation to ATP release from human and rabbit erythrocytes has been described (17, 18, 27, 29).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	22	 This pathway includes the heterotrimeric G proteins Gs (17) and Gi (18), adenylyl cyclase (29), PKA (29), and the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) (27).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	23	 The activity of CFTR was shown to be required for deformation-induced ATP release from erythrocytes of both rabbits and humans (27).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Thus erythrocytes of humans with cystic fibrosis, a condition in which CFTR activity is absent or markedly reduced, and rabbit erythrocytes incubated with inhibitors of CFTR activity failed to release ATP in response to mechanical deformation (27).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Here, we demonstrate that CFTR is expressed in the membrane of both rabbit and human erythrocytes and that, in contrast to those of healthy humans, erythrocytes from humans with cystic fibrosis fail to stimulate endogenous NO synthesis in the isolated rabbit pulmonary circulation.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	26	   MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION GRANTS REFERENCES   Isolation of rabbit and human erythrocytes.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Rabbit erythrocytes were obtained from New Zealand White rabbits (male, 2 to 3 kg body wt).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	28	 The animals were anesthetized with ketamine (12.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	29	5 ml/kg im) and xylazine (1 mg/kg im) followed by pentobarbital sodium (10 mg/kg iv).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	30	 After tracheal intubation, the animals were mechanically ventilated with room air (tidal volume 10 ml/kg, rate 20 to 25 breaths/min).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	31	 A catheter was placed into the carotid artery for the administration of heparin (500 units) and for a phlebotomy.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Ten minutes after heparin, the animals were exsanguinated.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Human erythrocytes were obtained by venipuncture performed in an antecubital vein without the use of a tourniquet.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Sixty milliliters of blood were collected into a syringe containing 50 units of heparin.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Protocols for removal of blood from rabbits and humans were approved by the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee and the Institutional Review Board of Saint Louis University, respectively.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	36	Rabbit and human blood was centrifuged at 500 g for 10 min at 4 degrees C.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	37	 The plasma, buffy coat, and uppermost erythrocytes were removed by aspiration and discarded.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	38	 The remaining erythrocytes were washed three times in buffer solution containing 140.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	39	5% BSA fraction V (ICN Biomedicals; Aurora, OH), with a final pH of 7.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The hematocrit of the washed erythrocytes was determined using an Autocrit Ultra 3 centrifuge (Becton Dickinson; Bedford, MA).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	41	Preparation of erythrocyte membranes.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Washed rabbit or human erythrocytes were diluted 1:100 with ice-cold lysis buffer (5 mM Tris HCl and 2 mM EDTA, pH 7.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	43	4) and stirred at 4 degrees C for 20 min.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The resulting mixture was centrifuged at 23,000 g for 15 min at 4 degrees C.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	45	 The supernatant was removed and discarded.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The membranes were resuspended in cold lysis buffer and centrifuged a second time.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	47	 The pellets were pooled, resuspended in ice-cold lysis buffer, and centrifuged at 23,000 g for 15 min at 4 degrees C a final time.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	48	 The supernatant was discarded, and the protein concentration was determined (BCA Protein Assay, Pierce; Rockford, IL).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Aliquots were frozen at  to 80 degrees C.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Immediately before electrophoresis, membranes were thawed on ice, sonicated briefly (W-220F sonicator, Heat Systems-Ultrasonics; Farmingdale, NY), vortexed with 5  microl of 10% SDS per 200 ml of sample, and heated to 95 degrees C for 90 s.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	51	Preparation of T84 human colon carcinoma cells.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	52	 T84 cells (American Type Culture Collection), which express large amounts of CFTR (4, 33), were grown to confluence in a 1:1 mixture of DMEM and Ham s F12 medium on a 70-mm culture dish.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	53	 The dishes were then washed for 5 min with PBS (pH 7.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	54	4) containing a cocktail of protease inhibitors (Complete, Roche Diagnostics; Mannheim, Germany).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Cells were removed by mechanical scraping and centrifuged at 8,000 g for 90 s.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The resulting cell pellet was resolubilized in ice-cold 250 mM sucrose, 1 mM EDTA, and 20 mM imidazole (pH 7.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	57	2) with the protease inhibitor cocktail.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	58	 After a 10-min incubation on ice, the suspension was briefly sonicated and centrifuged at 16,000 g for 30 s at 4 degrees C.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	59	 The supernatant (200 ml) was vortexed with 10% SDS (5 ml) and heated at 95 degrees C for 90 s.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Samples were stored at  to 80 degrees C for Western blot analysis.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Membrane proteins were mixed in sample buffer [1.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	62	5% SDS, 6% (vol/vol) glycerol, 0.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	63	6% dithiothreitol, 10 mM Tris (pH 6.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	64	01% bromophenol blue], heated to 95 degrees C for 2 min, and resolved by electrophoresis in 5% SDS-polyacrylamide precast gels (Bio-Rad; Hercules, CA).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	65	 After electrophoresis, the proteins were transferred to a polyvinylidene difluoride (PVDF) membrane (Millipore; Bedford, MA) in transfer buffer (25 mM Tris base, 192 mM glycine, and 10% methanol).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	66	 The PVDF membranes were blocked for 1 h in a buffer solution containing 5% nonfat dry milk, 10 mM sodium phosphate, 150 mM NaCl, and 0.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	67	 The PVDF membranes were then immunoblotted overnight with a mouse monoclonal anti-CFTR antibody (R and D Systems) in wash buffer solution containing 1% nonfat dry milk, 10 mM sodium phosphate, 150 mM NaCl, and 0.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The PVDF membranes were washed three times with 10 mM sodium phosphate, 150 mM NaCl, and 0.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	69	4 and immunoblotted with anti-mouse IgG secondary antibody conjugated to horseradish peroxidase (Amersham; Piscataway, NJ).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	70	 After the membranes were washed, protein was visualized using enhanced chemiluminescence (Amersham).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Rabbits were anesthetized, ventilated, and exsanguinated as described above.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	72	 The heart and lungs were removed en block during continuous ventilation.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	73	 A catheter was placed in the main pulmonary artery through the right ventricle, and a second catheter was placed in the left atrium.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	74	 The heart and lungs were suspended in a humidified chamber maintained at 37 degrees C and ventilated with gas containing 15% O2-6% CO2-balance N2.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Residual blood present in the lungs was removed by perfusion with 200 ml PSS [118.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	76	1 mM glucose, and 5% hetastarch (Baxter Healthcare; Deerfield, IL)] without recirculation.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	77	 The lungs were then perfused with PSS at 80 ml/min with a recirculating volume of 100 ml.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Pulmonary arterial pressure (PPA), left atrial pressure (PLA), and airway pressure (PAW) were recorded continuously.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	79	 PLA was set to a pressure of 2 to 3 mmHg with a screw clamp, and lungs were perfused under zone III conditions (PPA  >  PLA  >  PAW).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Pulmonary microvascular pressure (PMV) was determined by the double occlusion method (15).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	81	 The arterial and venous cannulae were simultaneously occluded with electronically controlled solenoid pinch valves that cause minimal fluid displacement.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Occlusions were maintained for 3 to 5 s, and the resulting equilibration pressures in the pulmonary arterial and venous catheters were recorded as an estimate of PMV.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Samples of perfusate were analyzed for pH, PO2, and PCO2 under control and experimental conditions (pHOx blood gas analyzer, Nova Biomedical; Waltham, MA).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	84	 After a minimum of 15 min of perfusion at 80 ml/min, the pressure-flow relationship was determined by measuring vascular pressures (PPA and PMV) at flow rates of 50, 100, 200, and 300 ml/min.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Within 20 s of a change in flow rate, PLA was adjusted to 2 to 3 mmHg and PMV was determined.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Finally, the flow rate was returned to 80 ml/min (recovery).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	87	 N-nitro-L-arginine methyl ester (L-NAME; Calbiochem) was then added to the perfusate to achieve a final concentration of either 30, 100, or 300  microM.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	88	 After 30 min, a second pressure-flow relationship was determined.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	89	 In separate studies, the isolated lungs were perfused with either PSS alone or PSS to which washed erythrocytes obtained from healthy humans or humans with cystic fibrosis were added.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Erythrocytes were obtained on the day of use and were added to the perfusate within 15 min of being washed.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Statistical significance between experimental periods was determined with ANOVA.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	92	 In the event that the F-ratio indicated that changes had occurred, a least-significant difference test was used to identify individual differences.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	93	 The slope of the pressure-flow relationships was determined by least-squares linear regression analysis.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	94	05 or less were considered statistically significant.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Results are reported as means  plus or minus  SE.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	96	   RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION GRANTS REFERENCES   Identification of CFTR in erythrocyte membranes.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	97	 If CFTR is a component of the signal transduction pathway for ATP release from rabbit and human erythrocytes, then it must be present in these cell membranes.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Membranes prepared from a human colon carcinoma cell line that has been shown to express CFTR (T84 cells) were used as a positive control (4, 33).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Membranes of both human and rabbit erythrocytes were found to contain CFTR protein when examined by Western blot analysis (Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	100	View larger version (80K):    Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Identification of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein in the membranes of humans and rabbit erythrocytes and T-84 colon carcinoma cells.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Cell membranes were prepared as described, and protein was resolved using a 5% SDS-PAGE gel.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Protein was transferred to a polyvinylidene difluoride membrane and incubated with mouse monoclonal anti-CFTR antibody.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Lane 1, rabbit erythrocyte membranes (15  microg protein, representative of 3 studies); lane 2, T-84 cell membranes (15  microg protein, representative of 3 studies); lane 3, human erythrocyte membranes (50  microg protein, representative of 5 studies).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	105	  Effect of L-NAME on pressure-flow relationships in isolated rabbit lungs perfused with PSS in the absence of erythrocytes.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	106	 The pressure-flow relationship was determined in isolated rabbit lungs perfused with PSS in the absence and presence of L-NAME at concentrations of either 30, 100, or 300  microM.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	107	 In the absence of erythrocytes, L-NAME had no effect on the pressure-flow relationship (Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	108	View larger version (24K):    Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	109	 A: effect of N-nitro-L-arginine methyl ester (L-NAME) at perfusate concentrations of either 30, 100, or 300  microM on the relationship between flow rate and the pressure gradient across the pulmonary circulation [pulmonary artial pressure (PPA)  to  left arterial pressure (PLA)] in lungs perfused with physiological salt solution (PSS) in the absence of erythrocytes (n = 3 in all groups).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	110	 B: effect of L-NAME on the pressure gradient across the pulmonary circulation (PPA  to  PLA) in lungs perfused with PSS containing erythrocytes of healthy humans (n = 5) or humans with cystic fibrosis (n = 4).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	111	05 compared with all other groups.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Values are means  plus or minus  SE.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	113	  Perfusion of isolated rabbit lungs with PSS containing washed human erythrocytes.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Initial pH, gas tensions, and hematocrit in studies in which lungs were perfused with PSS containing erythrocytes from healthy human erythrocytes or from humans with cystic fibrosis are depicted in Table 1.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Humans with cystic fibrosis, identified as homozygous for the F508 genotype, were treated with medications including inhaled -agonists, ipratropium bromide, corticosteroids, antibiotics, DNAse, and inhibitors of mast cell degranulation as well as oral pancreatic enzyme replacement, antibiotics, proton pump inhibitors, and vitamins.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	116	 The addition of washed human erythrocytes to the perfusate of isolated rabbit lungs did not result in increased airway pressure or weight gain over the course of the experiment.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Perfusate pH and gas tensions in isolated perfused rabbit lungs perfused with PSS containing RBCs of healthy humans or humans with cystic fibrosis.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	118	  Effect of L-NAME on pressure-flow relationships in isolated rabbit lungs perfused with PSS containing erythrocytes from healthy humans.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Under control conditions (perfusion at 80 ml/min), the addition of L-NAME to the perfusate resulted in an increase in perfusion pressure (Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Moreover, the addition of L-NAME resulted in a shift in the pressure-flow relationship such that the pressure difference across the pulmonary circulation (PPA  to  PLA) was increased at each flow rate studied (Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Importantly, the slope of this relationship was increased after L-NAME (P  <  0.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	122	01) consistent with the interpretation that, under these conditions, inhibition of endogenous NO synthesis was associated with an increase in Ohmic resistance (15).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Finally, the site of increased resistance was examined by determination of the effect of L-NAME on changes in both upstream (PPA  to  PMV) and downstream (PMV  to  PLA) vascular resistance.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	124	 The increases in vascular resistance were confined to the upstream vascular segment (Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	125	View larger version (15K):    Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Effect of L-NAME (100  microM) on the relationship between flow rate and the pressure gradient across the pulmonary circulation (PPA  to  PLA) in lungs perfused with PSS containing washed erythrocytes of healthy humans (n = 5).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	127	05 compared with control (pre-L-NAME) values.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Values are means  plus or minus  SE.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	129	  View larger version (15K):    Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Effect of L-NAME (100  microM) on the relationship between flow rate and the pressure gradient across the upstream (arterial) segment of the pulmonary circulation (A) [PPA  to  pulmonary microvascular pressure (PMV)] and the pressure gradient across the downstream (venous) segment of the pulmonary circulation (B; PMV  to  PLA) in lungs perfused with PSS containing washed erythrocytes of healthy humans (n = 5).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	131	05 compared with control (pre-L-NAME) values.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Values are means  plus or minus  SE.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	133	  Effect of L-NAME on pressure-flow relationships in isolated rabbit lungs perfused with PSS containing erythrocytes from humans with cystic fibrosis.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	134	 In isolated rabbit lungs perfused with PSS containing erythrocytes from humans with cystic fibrosis, L-NAME administration did not result in any change in perfusion pressure under control conditions (Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Moreover, in the presence of these erythrocytes, L-NAME had no effect on pressure-flow relationships (Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	136	View larger version (13K):    Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Effect of L-NAME (100  microM) on the relationship between flow rate and the pressure gradient across the pulmonary circulation (PPA  to  PLA) in lungs perfused with PSS containing washed erythrocytes of humans with cystic fibrosis (n = 4).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Values are means  plus or minus  SE.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	139	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION GRANTS REFERENCES   It was reported previously that erythrocytes from either rabbits (31), rats (36, 38), or healthy humans (26) are required for the demonstration of flow-induced NO synthesis in isolated perfused lungs.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	140	 These observations, coupled with the findings that physiological stimuli, such as mechanical deformation (18, 26, 27, 29), stimulate ATP release from erythrocytes and that ATP is a stimulus for endogenous NO synthesis in the isolated rabbit lung (30), suggest a novel mechanism for the control of pulmonary vascular caliber.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	141	 In this construct, as the erythrocyte is deformed by increments in the velocity of blood flow through a vessel and/or by reductions in vascular caliber, it releases ATP, which stimulates endothelial synthesis of NO resulting in relaxation of vascular smooth muscle and, thereby, an increase in vascular caliber.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	142	 This vasodilation would then result in a decrease in pulmonary vascular resistance as well as a decrease in the stimulus for additional erythrocyte deformation and ATP release.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	143	 On the basis of this scheme, erythrocyte-derived ATP would contribute to the low vascular pressure in the healthy lung via stimulation of endogenous NO synthesis.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	144	Recently, a signal transduction pathway that relates mechanical deformation to ATP release from erythrocytes of rabbits and humans has been described.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Components of this pathway include the heterotrimeric G proteins Gs (17) and Gi (18), adenylyl cyclase (29), PKA (29) and CFTR (27).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	146	 A role for CFTR in this pathway was suggested by reports that this member of the ATP binding cassette could facilitate the movement of ATP out of cells either by acting as an ATP conduit (21, 22) or by regulating another channel for ATP release (20, 23).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	147	 The finding that CFTR activity is lost or markedly diminished in humans with cystic fibrosis (5, 6) provided a unique opportunity for investigation of the role of CFTR in the release of ATP from erythrocytes in response to the physiological stimulus of mechanical deformation.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	148	 It was reported previously that erythrocytes of patients with cystic fibrosis as well as rabbit erythrocytes incubated with two chemically dissimilar inhibitors of CFTR, namely, glibenclamide (24, 25) and niflumic acid (7), failed to release ATP in response to mechanical deformation (27).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	149	A necessary step in establishing that CFTR is a component of a signal transduction pathway for ATP release from erythrocytes is the demonstration of its presence in erythrocyte membranes.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Recently, it was shown that CFTR protein is present in erythrocyte membranes of both healthy humans and humans with cystic fibrosis (1, 32).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	151	 In addition, it was reported that human erythroblasts contain CFTR mRNA (37).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	152	 However, it must be noted that neither CFTR protein in human erythrocytes nor mRNA in human erythroid progenitor cells were detected in another study (13).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	153	 In the present work, we confirm the finding that CFTR protein is a component of human erythrocyte membranes (Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	154	 In addition, we show that the membranes of rabbit erythrocytes also possess CFTR (Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Thus CFTR, a necessary component of a proposed signal transduction pathway for ATP release from erythrocytes, is present in the membranes of both rabbit and human erythrocytes, cells that release ATP in response to mechanical deformation (26, 27, 29).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	156	Although CFTR activity is required for deformation-induced ATP release from erythrocytes of humans (27), the loss of CFTR activity may have a different effect on basal ATP release from these cells.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	157	 It was reported that the concentration of ATP was increased in the blood of CFTR knockout mice as well as humans with cystic fibrosis compared with either wild-type controls or healthy humans, respectively (1).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	158	 It is important to note that, in these studies, ATP release was studied under quiescent conditions, i.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	159	, erythrocytes were not subjected to mechanical deformation.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Thus it is possible that, although CFTR is required for deformation-induced ATP release from erythrocytes, another member of the ATP binding cassette, such as the multidrug resistance-associated protein 1, is involved in basal ATP release from these cells (1).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	161	The hypothesis that ATP, released from erythrocytes of healthy humans in response to deformation, stimulates endogenous NO synthesis in the isolated rabbit lung is supported by previous studies.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Erythrocytes of healthy humans release ATP in response to mechanical deformation as would be encountered as they pass through the pulmonary circulation.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	163	 The amount of ATP released in response to deformation was shown to be stimulus dependent (26, 27, 29).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	164	 In addition, the inclusion of human erythrocytes in the perfusate of isolated rabbit lungs resulted in the stimulation of endogenous NO synthesis (26).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Finally, the addition of ATP to the perfusate of isolated rabbit lungs resulted in concentration-dependent decreases in total pulmonary vascular resistance that were inhibited by pretreatment with the NO synthase inhibitor L-NAME (30).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	166	In view of the findings that CFTR is expressed in human erythrocyte membranes, that it is a component of a signal transduction pathway that relates erythrocyte deformation to ATP release (27), and that ATP release from erythrocytes is a stimulus for endogenous NO synthesis in the rabbit pulmonary circulation (30), we hypothesized that erythrocytes of humans with cystic fibrosis, a condition in which the activity of CFTR is defective, would fail to stimulate NO synthesis in the isolated perfused rabbit lung.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	167	 In the presence of washed erythrocytes from healthy humans, the administration of the NO synthase inhibitor L-NAME to the perfusate of isolated lungs resulted in a shift in the pressure-flow relationship in a manner consistent with an increase in Ohmic resistance (Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	168	 This increase in vascular resistance was confined to the upstream vascular segment (PPA  to  PMV as a function of flow rate; Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	169	 In contrast, in the presence of erythrocytes of patients with cystic fibrosis, L-NAME was without effect on the pressure-flow relationship, i.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	170	, NO was not a determinant of pulmonary vascular resistance (Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	171	Several studies suggest that endogenous NO synthesis in the lung may be decreased in humans with cystic fibrosis.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	172	 It was reported that amounts of NO detected in exhaled gas are decreased in humans with cystic fibrosis compared with healthy humans (2, 15, 35).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	173	 It must be recognized that the source of NO that is measured in exhaled gas is unknown and could derive from the endothelium of blood vessels, the airways, or other resident cells.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	174	 However, it was reported that exhaled NO is reduced in neonates with cystic fibrosis before the development of detectable respiratory symptoms, suggesting that the decrease in exhaled NO is not the result of increased mucus accumulation and/or inflammation (9).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Thus the decrease in measurable NO in exhaled gas in cystic fibrosis patients compared with healthy controls could reflect, in part, the failure of erythrocyte-derived ATP to stimulate endogenous NO synthesis.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	176	Importantly, it was reported that isolated blood vessels obtained from lungs of humans with cystic fibrosis, when precontracted with phenylephrine, relaxed in response to the application of ADP, the first degradation product of ATP (8).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	177	 This response was shown to be endothelium dependent, although the nature of the endothelium-derived relaxing factor was not determined.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Thus it is reasonable to hypothesize that if erythrocyte-derived ATP were released into the pulmonary circulation of humans with cystic fibrosis, endogenous NO synthesis could be stimulated.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	179	Failure of deformation-induced ATP release from erythrocytes and, thereby, the loss of a physiological stimulus for endogenous NO synthesis could be expected to lead, ultimately, to the development of pulmonary hypertension.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Pulmonary hypertension is seen in humans with cystic fibrosis; however, this condition has most often been attributed to the destructive lung disease and the subsequent loss of pulmonary capillaries and/or hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction (11, 34).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	181	 The results presented here suggest that a defect in ATP release from erythrocytes of cystic fibrosis patients as they traverse the pulmonary circulation could be an additional factor leading to the development of pulmonary hypertension in these individuals.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	182	In summary, we demonstrate that CFTR is a component of the erythrocyte membrane of rabbits and humans.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Erythrocytes from humans in whom this protein is functional stimulate endogenous NO synthesis in the isolated rabbit lung.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	184	 In contrast, erythrocytes of humans with cystic fibrosis, a condition in which CFTR activity is impaired, do not stimulate NO synthesis in this model.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	185	 These findings provide support for the hypothesis that erythrocyte-derived ATP, released in response to a physiological stimulus, such as mechanical deformation, could serve to aid in the maintenance of normal pulmonary vascular resistance via the stimulation of endogenous NO synthesis.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	186	   GRANTS TOP ABSTRACT MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION GRANTS REFERENCES   This study was supported by National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute Grants HL-51298, HL-52675, and HL-39226.

0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	0	EDITORIAL FOCUS Focus on "Sodium 4-phenylbutyrate downregulates Hsc70: implications for intracellular trafficking of F508-CFTR" Neil A.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	1	Cystic Fibrosis Research Center, Department of Cell Biology and Physiology, University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15261.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	2	    ARTICLE TOP ARTICLE REFERENCES.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	3	THE ABILITY OF NEWLY SYNTHESIZED PROTEINS, particularly oligomeric or multidomain proteins, to fold into unique, three-dimensional structures in vivo is dependent on their amino acid sequence and the activities of enzymes and molecular chaperone proteins that catalyze folding (9).
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Evidence is accumulating that many human diseases are caused by improper folding of nascent polypeptides as they achieve a final three-dimensional structure.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Such proteins are either inactive or have altered activity as a result of inappropriate folding, as is the case in Marfan syndrome and familiar hypercholesterolemia, or are mislocalized due to trafficking defects arising from abnormal folding, as is the case for Tay-Sachs disease and 1-antitrypsin deficiency.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	6	Mutations in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) give rise to cystic fibrosis (CF), the most common lethal autosomal genetic disease of Caucasians.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Deletion of the codon for phenylalanine-508 (F508) accounts for ~70% of all disease causing CF alleles (11) and yields a protein that is unable to exit from the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and traffic to the plasma membrane where it functions normally as an ion channel.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Available evidence suggests that nascent F508-CFTR is a temperature-sensitive protein (4), which adopts a slightly altered protein conformation.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	9	 As such, it is recognized by ER quality control mechanisms as abnormal, leading to ER retention (3) (but see also Ref.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	10	 6) and ultimately to degradation by the ubiquitin-proteosome pathway (7).
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Such retention appears, at least in part, to be due to the cellular chaperones, heat-shock protein Hsc70 and calnexin (10, 17).
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	12	 The question of how to shield or dissociate mutant CFTR molecules from the ER quality control machinery and allow its exit to the plasma membrane has been the focus of research in several CF laboratories.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Because F508-CFTR retains some regulated chloride channel activity (16), correcting the folding and/or preventing the ER retention of mutant CFTR by chaperones may have therapeutic benefit for the treatment of CF.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	14	Attempts to pharmacologically manipulate the folding of F508-CFTR have included the use of protein stabilizing reagents, or chemical chaperones, such as glycerol and trimethylamine N-oxide, as well as deuterated water (2, 14).
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Indeed, evidence suggests that such approaches can facilitate exit of F508-CFTR from the ER and insertion into the apical plasma membrane in vivo.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	16	 A previous publication by Rubenstein and colleagues (12) has shown that sodium 4-phenylbutyrate (4PBA) similarly facilitates exit of F508-CFTR from the ER, though the mechanism of action has remained elusive.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Previous work has shown that F508-CFTR remains associated with the cellular chaperone Hsc70 to a much greater extent than wild-type CFTR (17), an association that may direct mutant CFTR to the ubiquitin-dependent degradation pathway (1).
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	18	 In the current article in focus (Ref.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	19	 13, see page C259 in this issue), Rubenstein and Zeitlin demonstrate that association of mutant CFTR with the heat-shock protein Hsc70 can be reduced by exposing cells to 4PBA.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Mechanistically, it appears that 4PBA inhibits the interaction of F508-CFTR with Hsc70, allowing mutant CFTR to escape targeting for degradation and facilitating its exit from the ER.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	21	 4PBA appears to do so by downregulating the expression of Hsc70 at the protein and mRNA level, thereby limiting the amount of Hsc70 that is available to bind to CFTR.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Such a hypothesis is consistent with the observations of Cheng and colleagues (5), who utilized deoxyspergualin, a compound that does not affect Hsc70 protein levels but competitively inhibits peptide binding to Hsc70, to partially restore CFTR function in heterologous cells expressing F508-CFTR.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	23	 It would appear, however, that the efficacious effects of inhibiting CFTR chaperone interactions are limited to Hsc70, since perturbation of CFTR-Hsc90 interactions have been shown to accelerate CFTR degradation (8).
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	24	Manipulating CFTR folding by "chemical chaperones" does not appear to be readily feasible in the context of a CF patient.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	25	 However, preventing the recognition of misfolded CFTR as abnormal may be amenable to pharmacological strategies.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Thus the current article by Rubenstein and Zeitlin offers exciting insight into how one might be able to disrupt cellular chaperone-dependent retention of mutant CFTR molecules in the ER, allowing their insertion into the plasma membrane.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Moreover, both 4PBA and deoxyspergualin are approved drugs for urea cycle disorders and antitumor/immunosuppression, respectively.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Indeed, clinical trials using 4PBA have suggested a small but significant improvement in nasal epithelial chloride transport in F508-homozygous CF patients.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	29	 However, before such observations can be fully realized as therapies, several questions must be addressed.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	30	 For example, just how much mutant CFTR must escape from the ER quality control machinery to effect clinical benefit? The studies of Cheng and colleagues (5) would argue that the amount of mutant CFTR required to reach the plasma membrane to provide a measurable cAMP-sensitive chloride conductive pathway is less than which can be detected as mature CFTR protein by biochemical methods.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	31	 However, since F508-CFTR does not retain full wild-type function, even after reaching the plasma membrane, further pharmacological activation of plasmalemmal resident mutant CFTR may be still required (15, 16).
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	32	 It remains to be determined what impact perturbation of the ER quality control machinery will have on protein folding and processing pathways for other proteins expressed in the cell.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	33	 In addition, Hsc70 has other cellular functions, including the ATP-dependent uncoating of clathrin-coated vesicles in the endocytic pathway and targeting of proteins for lysosomal degradation.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	34	 It is unclear what effects alterations in Hsc70 activity would have on these intracellular processes.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Nevertheless, the ability to screen large libraries of compounds for drugs that disrupt CFTR-Hsc70 interactions may be fruitful in providing a pharmacological therapy for CF.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	36	This report was funded by grants from the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases and the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	37	Address for reprint requests and other correspondence: N.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Bradbury, S306 BST South, Dept.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	39	 of Cell Biology and Physiology, 3500 Terrace St.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	40	 of Pittsburgh School of Medicine, Pittsburgh, PA 15261 (E-mail: nabrad{at}pitt.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	41	    REFERENCES TOP ARTICLE REFERENCES.

0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	61	 In vitro pharmacologic restoration of CFTR-mediated chloride transport with sodium 4-phenylbutyrate in cystic fibrosis epithelial cells containing F508-CFTR.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	62	 100: 2457-2465, 1997[Abstract/Free Full Text].

0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	69	 170: 51-66, 1999[ISI][Medline].
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	70	 The common variant of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator is recognized by hsp70 and degraded in a pre-Golgi nonlysosomal compartment.
0.5620728.10666019.html.plaintext.txt	71	 USA 90: 9480-9484, 1993[Abstract].
