0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	0	Increased functional cell surface expression of CFTR and F508-CFTR by the anthracycline doxorubicin Rangan Maitra1, Collin M.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	1	1 Departments of Pharmacology and Toxicology and 2 Physiology, Dartmouth Medical School, Hanover, New Hampshire 03755-3835.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	2	    ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	3	Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a disease that is caused by mutations within the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	4	 The most common mutation, F508, accounts for 70% of all CF alleles and results in a protein that is defective in folding and trafficking to the cell surface.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	5	 However, F508-CFTR is functional when properly localized.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	6	 We report that a single, noncytotoxic dose of the anthracycline doxorubicin (Dox, 0.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	7	25  microM) significantly increased total cellular CFTR protein expression, cell surface CFTR protein expression, and CFTR-associated chloride secretion in cultured T84 epithelial cells.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Dox treatment also increased F508-CFTR cell surface expression and F508-CFTR-associated chloride secretion in stably transfected Madin-Darby canine kidney cells.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	9	 These results suggest that anthracycline analogs may be useful for the clinical treatment of CF.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	10	trafficking; chloride secretion.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	11	    INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	12	THE CYSTIC FIBROSIS TRANSMEMBRANE conductance regulator (CFTR) is a cAMP- and protein kinase-regulated chloride channel found on the apical membranes of polarized epithelial cells (10).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Mutations within this gene lead to the CF phenotype that ultimately results in premature death primarily from a combination of chronic lung infections, loss of pulmonary function, and pancreatic insufficiency (5).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	14	 This genetic disease is among the most prevalent in the human population, occurring in ~1 of 2,500 Caucasian live births.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	15	 CFTR is a member of the structurally related ATP-binding cassette family of transmembrane transport proteins whose other members include P-glycoprotein (Pgp, the MDR1 gene product), multidrug resistance-associated protein and other related multidrug resistance proteins, and the sulfonylurea receptor (21).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	16	Of the more than 850 individual CFTR mutations leading to the CF phenotype that have been described, the most important is F508 (phenylalanine deletion at amino acid position 508), which is seen in ~70% of all CF patients.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	17	 The F508-CFTR mutation results in improper folding and trafficking of the CFTR protein, leading to its degradation in the endoplasmic reticulum by the 26S proteosome machinery of the cell (23).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	18	 However, importantly, if this mutant protein is folded and expressed in the membrane by experimental cell culture techniques such as glycerol (20) or low temperature treatments (3), it functions normally as a chloride channel.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Moreover, it is estimated that restoration of functional CFTR expression to ~10% of normal levels would be sufficient to ameliorate the symptoms of the disease in vivo (19).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Thus there is great interest in development of strategies that can enhance F508-CFTR cell surface expression, which may be clinically useful in treatment of CF patients.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	21	There is evidence of coregulation of Pgp and CFTR in epithelial cells, although the mechanism and level of this overlapping regulation is currently unknown (2).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Previous work in our laboratory demonstrated both transcriptional and posttranscriptional effects of low-dose, noncytotoxic treatments with the cancer chemotherapy drugs mitomycin C (MMC) and doxorubicin (Dox) on expression of Pgp in various cell lines and in a mouse in vivo model (6, 7).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	23	 We therefore hypothesized that CFTR expression might also be modified by these or related drugs under similar treatment conditions.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	24	 We recently demonstrated that MMC increased total protein and cell surface functional expression of wild-type CFTR in HT-29 and T84 human colon cells (15a).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	25	 In this study, we investigated the effects of Dox on CFTR and F508-CFTR expression.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	26	 We report here that low-dose Dox (0.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	27	25  microM) significantly increased functional cell surface expression of CFTR and F508-CFTR in T84 and Madin-Darby canine kidney (MDCK) cells, respectively, and that this was primarily a result of posttranscriptional effects.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	28	    METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Human colon adenocarcinoma T84 cells (American Type Culture Collection, Manassas, VA) were maintained in DMEM/F-12 media (Life Technology, Rockville, MD) containing L-glutamine supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS) and antibiotics (Life Technology).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	30	 An isogenic line of MDCK/C-7 cells stably expressing green fluorescent protein (GFP) tagged to the NH2 terminus of F508-CFTR (MDCK/F508) were created in a fashion similar to a cell line expressing GFP tagged to the NH2 terminus of CFTR (MDCK/CFTR) described elsewhere (17, 18).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	31	 This cell line and parental MDCK-C7 cells were maintained in minimum essential media (MEM, Life Technology) supplemented as above.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	32	3 mg/ml of G418 Sulfate (Sigma, St.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Louis, MO) was added to the MDCK/F508 media for maintaining the selection pressure.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	34	 For immunoblot analysis and RT-PCR following drug treatment, cells were grown in six-well plates (Costar, Cambridge, MA) to confluence, washed with PBS, and treated with or without 0.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	35	 After this, completed media were replenished and cells were harvested at various time points.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	36	 For short-circuit current measurements and cell-surface biotinylations, cells were cultured on Transwell-type filters (Corning, Ithaca, NY).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	37	 The medium was completely changed every 24 h, and experiments were performed 14 days postseeding.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Total RNA from T84 cells was isolated using TRIAZOL reagent (Life Technology).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	39	 One microgram of total RNA from T84 cells was reverse-transcribed using the RNA PCR Core Kit (Perkin Elmer, Foster City, CA) in 20  microl total volume.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The cDNAs were divided into two equal aliquots and amplified using 0.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	41	5  microl of AmpliTaq DNA polymerase (5 U/ microl), 20 pM upper and lower primers specific for human CFTR (upper: 5'-CCT GAA CCT GAT GAC ACA CT-3', lower: 5'-TAA AAC TGC GAC AAC TGC TA-3') or 1.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	42	25  microl of 5  microM 18S RNA specific primers and Competimers (Ambion, Austin, TX) in a ratio 3.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Prior titration experiments ensured that amplification of both CFTR and 18S RNA products were within linear range.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The cDNA products were separated by electrophoresis on 1% agarose gels (Life Technology) and stained with ethidium bromide to confirm proper product sizes.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Cells were treated with solvent or Dox, washed once with cold PBS, and scraped in a small volume of lysis buffer (50 mM Tris   HCl, pH 6.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	46	8, 150 mM NaCl, 1% Nonidet P-40) containing a protease inhibitor cocktail (Roche Biochemicals, Indianapolis, IN).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Protein was extracted from the samples by a 30-min incubation on ice with intermediate vortexing and frozen at 70 degrees C.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Protein in each sample was quantified by the bichinchoninic acid assay (Pierce, Rockford, IL).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	49	 SDS-PAGE was performed on 4-15% minigels using 50  microg of protein lysate per lane.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Proteins were separated and transferred to polyvinylidene difluoride membrane (Millipore, Bedford, MA) at 120 mA for 1 h in Towbin's transfer buffer (25 mM Tris, 192 mM glycine, 12% methanol).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	51	 After transfer, the blots were blocked and probed sequentially, first with polyclonal A2 rabbit anti-CFTR antisera (25) (generously provided by Dr.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Skach, Oregon Health Sciences Institute) overnight at 4 degrees C and then with a horseradish peroxidase (HRP)-labeled anti-rabbit secondary polyclonal antibody (Amersham, Piscataway, NJ).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Membranes were washed six times in PBS + 0.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	54	3% Tween 20 (PBST) at room temperature for 10 min each in between.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The blots were developed by enhanced chemiluminescence (ECL) Blaze substrate (Pierce) and exposed to film.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	56	Cell-surface biotinylation and immunoprecipitation.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	57	 T84 cells were biotinylated on the apical plasma membrane with a commercially available biotinylation kit (Roche Biochemicals).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	58	 After treatment at 4 degrees C with LC-(+)-biotin-hydrazide, cells were washed with cold PBS and harvested in lysis buffer on ice, and total protein in each sample was quantified as described above.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Two hundred micrograms of protein from each sample was immunoprecipitated using polyclonal A2 rabbit anti-CFTR antisera (1:1,000) and Protein A-agarose (Roche Biochemicals).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	60	 The beads were washed in PBST, and immunoreactive proteins were separated by SDS-PAGE and detected by streptavidin-HRP and ECL as described above.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	61	 The F508-CFTR-expressing MDCK cells were immunoprecipitated similarly but immunoblotted using a monoclonal anti-GFP antibody (Clontech Laboratories, Palo Alto, CA).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	62	 In other experiments, CFTR was immunoprecipitated with A2 as described above and detected with the M3A7 monoclonal anti-CFTR antibody (12), a generous gift of Dr.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Riordan (Mayo Institute, Scottsdale, AZ).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	64	Measurement of short circuit current.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Short-circuit current (Isc) was measured across monolayers of T84 cells grown on filters.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Cells were treated with Dox (0.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	67	25  microM, 24 h) beginning at 14 days after seeding, and the media were changed to remove residual drug before Isc measurement.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Isc was measured in cells in the presence of amiloride (105 M) in the apical solution to block the potential contribution of sodium transport to Isc.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	69	 In the presence of amiloride, 8-(4-chlorophenylthio)-cAMP (CPT-cAMP)-stimulated Isc in T84 cells is equivalent to electrogenic Cl secretion (1).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	70	 The CFTR antagonist diphenylamino carboxylic acid (DPC) and the Cl/HCO exchange inhibitor 4,4'-diisothiocyanostilbene-2,2'-disulfonic acid (DIDS) were added as previously described (1, 17).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Bath solutions were maintained at 37 degrees C and were stirred by bubbling with 5% CO2-95% air.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Current output from the voltage clamp was digitized by a TL-1 DMA interface analog-to-digital converter (Axon Instruments, Foster City, CA).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Data collection and analysis were done with Axotape 2.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	74	 During experiments, cells were bathed in a FBS-free MEM solution containing (in mM) 116 NaCl, 116 NaHCO3, 3 KCl, 2 MgCl2, 0.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	75	Fluorescent chloride efflux assay.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Cells were grown to confluence in six-well plates and loaded with 10 mM N-(ethoxycarbonylmethyl)-6-methoxyquinolinium bromide (MQAE, Molecular Probes, Eugene, OR) overnight as described in detail previously (24).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Briefly, cells were incubated in a chloride-containing, nitrate-free buffer for chloride concentration equilibration inside and outside of the cells, and background fluorescence was recorded over 3 min.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	78	 After this, the buffer was changed to a chloride-free, nitrate-containing buffer.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Both buffers contained 100  microM CPT-cAMP (Roche Biochemicals) to stimulate CFTR.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	80	 In the presence of chloride, MQAE is caged and the probe's fluorescence is quenched.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Upon changing over to a chloride-free, nitrate-containing buffer, a chloride gradient is established, which results in the rapid exchange of chloride for nitrate in the cells.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Over the first few minutes, the rate of increase in free MQAE fluorescence is then proportional to the number of chloride channels at the membrane.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Increase in MQAE fluorescence was monitored over 20 min after buffer exchange.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The rates of chloride efflux were calculated from the slopes of the fluorescence curves over the first 3 min.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	85	 A Cytofluor II plate reader (PerSeptive Biosystems, Framingham, MA) equipped with a 360 nm excitation/460 nm emission filter set was used to measure MQAE fluorescence in the cells.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Densitometric quantification and image processing were carried out using Adobe Photoshop (Adobe Software, San Jose, CA) and NIH Image (National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD) software packages.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	87	 All statistical analyses were performed using Instat and Prism software (Graphpad Software, San Diego, CA).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	88	    RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	89	Effects of Dox on CFTR expression in T84 cells.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	90	 In all experiments described below (except Fig.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	91	 2C), cells were treated with 0.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	92	25  microM Dox for up to 24 h, which caused no overt cytotoxicity or change in cell viability as measured by trypan blue exclusion assay.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	93	 This dose is 20-fold lower than the half-maximal lethal concentration (LC50) for Dox in these cells (J.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	94	 The effects of Dox on CFTR mRNA expression were examined in T84 cells by a semiquantitative RT-PCR assay.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Treatment of cells for up to 24 h with 0.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	96	25  microM Dox had little or no effect on steady-state CFTR mRNA expression (Fig.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	97	 In contrast, Dox treatment significantly altered CFTR protein levels.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	98	 A 24-h Dox treatment increased CFTR protein by approximately twofold (Fig.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	99	 2, A-C), particularly the "C" band, which represents the mature, fully glycosylated form of CFTR (Fig.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Dose-response and time course studies indicated that the optimal treatment was 0.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	101	 An increase in CFTR protein was also observed after immunoprecipitation with the A2 antibody and subsequent immunoblotting with a second CFTR-specific monoclonal antibody, M3A7 (Fig.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	102	View larger version (20K):    Fig.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	103	   Effects of doxorubicin (Dox) on cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) mRNA expression in T84 cells.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	104	25  microM Dox for 6-24 h as shown or vehicle [24 h, control (con)].
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Total RNA from the cells was isolated and analyzed for CFTR mRNA steady-state expression by RT-PCR as described in METHODS.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	106	 A: representative gel image from RT-PCR analysis.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	107	 18S rRNA expression is shown for each sample for comparison.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	108	 B: densitometry analysis of RT-PCR experiments.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Quantitiation was performed as described in METHODS, and each CFTR value was normalized to the values for 18S rRNA.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Each bar represents the mean + SE of values from 3-6 independent samples.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	111	 There were no statistically significant differences among these treatment groups (ANOVA with ad hoc pairwise comparison).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	112	View larger version (22K):    Fig.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	113	   Effects of Dox on CFTR protein expression in T84 cells.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Cells were treated with Dox (0.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	115	25  microM) or vehicle (con), and total protein was isolated as described in METHODS.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	116	 A: representative immunoblotting of total cellular protein from control and Dox-treated cells (24 h) with the polyclonal A2 antibody.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Arrows indicate the positions of the B and C forms of CFTR based on relative mobilities.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	118	 B: time course for effects of Dox on CFTR expression.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Western blotting was performed as in A at various time points after Dox treatment as indicated, and CFTR bands were quantified by densitometry.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Each bar represents the mean + SE of densitometry values (total CFTR) from 3 separate samples at each time point.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	121	 *Significant difference from control at P  <  0.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	122	01 (ANOVA with ad hoc pairwise comparison).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	123	 C: dose response for effects of Dox on CFTR expression.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Western blotting was performed as in A at 24 h after Dox treatment as indicated, and CFTR bands were quantified by densitometry.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Each bar represents the mean + SE of densitometry values (total CFTR) from 3 separate samples at each time point.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	126	 ***Significant difference from control at P  <  0.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	127	01 (ANOVA with ad hoc pairwise comparison).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	128	 D: immunoprecipitation of CFTR from total cellular protein samples with the A2 antibody followed by Western blotting detection using the monoclonal M3A7 antibody against CFTR in control and Dox-treated (24 h) samples (immunoprecipitation with PrA, sepharose-protein A control; YB1, immunoprecipitation with the nonspecific anti-YB1 antibody).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	129	 E: densitometry of blot in C, as in B, above.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	130	 ***Significant difference from control at P  <  0.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	131	 F: representative blot following cell-surface biotinylation of the apical membrane of control and Dox-treated cells (24 h) followed by immunoprecipitation of CFTR and detection using horseradish peroxidase-conjugated streptavidin as described in METHODS.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	132	 G: densitometric analysis of biotinylation experiments as shown in E, above.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Each bar represents the mean + SE of values from 3 separate samples.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	134	 ***Significant difference from control at P  <  0.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	135	To assess whether Dox specifically increased membrane CFTR expression, we performed selective cell-surface biotinylation of apical membrane proteins followed by immunoprecipitation with a CFTR-specific polyclonal antibody and detection using HRP-conjugated streptavidin.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	136	 2, F and G, Dox-treated cells, compared with control cells, had an approximately twofold increase in levels of plasma membrane-associated CFTR that was detected as a single 170-kDa band (mature "C" band) on the immunoblots (Fig.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Taken together, these experiments indicate that Dox treatment of T84 cells leads to enhanced CFTR protein expression at the cell surface.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	138	Experiments were then conducted to assess whether the increased plasma membrane expression of CFTR resulted in enhanced chloride secretion in T84 cells.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	139	 When we used an MQAE fluorescence-based assay, a 24-h Dox treatment increased chloride permeability approximately twofold relative to control, as shown in Fig.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Electrogenic chloride secretion was also measured across monolayers of T84 cells (Fig.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Dox treatment increased CFTR-associated chloride secretion approximately twofold compared with control.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Thus, when we used two different assays for CFTR function, Dox significantly increased CFTR-mediated chloride permeability in association with increased levels of membrane-associated CFTR in these cells.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	143	View larger version (20K):    Fig.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	144	   Effects of Dox on CFTR-associated chloride secretion in T84 cells.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Two different assays were used to demonstrate the effects of Dox (0.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	146	25  microM, 24 h) on functional cell surface expression of endogenous human CFTR in T84 cells as described in METHODS.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	147	 A: representative data from the N-(ethoxycarbonylmethyl)-6-methoxyquinolinium bromide (MQAE) fluorescence assay, demonstrating the change in fluorescence recorded over time.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	148	 The slope of the tracing for the linear portion of the curve was used to generate the data shown in B (solid line, Dox; dotted line, control).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	149	 B: effects of Dox on cAMP-stimulated chloride permeability as measured by the chloride-sensitive fluorescent probe MQAE.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Values are expressed as the rate of change in MQAE fluorescence from the linear portion of the curve shown in A.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	151	 *Values that were significantly different from control at P  <  0.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	152	 C: representative data from the Ussing chamber assay demonstrating the change in short circuit current used to generate the data shown in D (see METHODS).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	153	 DPC, diphenylamino carboxylic acid; DIDS, 4,4'-diisothiocyanostilbene-2,2'-difulsonic acid.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	154	 D: effects of Dox on short-circuit current (Isc) as measured in an Ussing chamber assay.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Values represent the change in Isc as measured in  microAmp/cm2 and as shown in C.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Each bar represents the mean + SE of values obtained from 6 independent monolayers.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	157	 *Values that were significantly different from control at P  <  0.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	158	Effects of Dox on F508-CFTR expression in MDCK cells.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	159	 The effects of Dox treatment on functional cell surface expression of the CFTR folding mutant F508-CFTR were then assessed with these same techniques.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	160	 CFTR-associated chloride secretion was measured in an Ussing chamber across monolayers of parental MDCK-C7 cells and two isogenic MDCK cell lines stably expressing either GFP-tagged human CFTR or human GFP-F508-CFTR.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Dox treatment had no effect on chloride secretion in MDCK-C7 parental cells (Fig.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	162	 However, in MDCK cells expressing the mutant GFP-F508-CFTR, Dox treatment caused an ~2.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	163	3-fold increase in CFTR-mediated chloride secretion compared with untreated control cells (Fig.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	164	 The increase in GFP-F508-CFTR expression was confirmed by Western blotting of these cells (Fig.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	165	 It is important to note that the control level of chloride secretion in these cells was similar to that of the parental MDCK cells expressing the canine CFTR (Fig.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	166	 4A), suggesting that there was essentially very little or no functional F508-CFTR expression in the plasma membrane of these cells before Dox treatment.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	167	View larger version (24K):    Fig.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	168	   Effects of Dox on CFTR and F508-CFTR-associated chloride secretion and F508-CFTR protein expression in parental Madin-Darby canine kidney (MDCK)-C7 cells and independently derived cell lines stably expressing a green fluorescent protein (GFP)-tagged human CFTR or F508-CFTR.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Cells were treated with Dox (0.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	170	25  microM, 24 h), and Isc and protein expression were assayed as described in METHODS and in Figs.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	171	 A: Dox effects on Isc in parental MDCK cells (wt) and stably transfected MDCK cells expressing CFTR (CFTR) or F508-CFTR (DF508).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Each bar represents the mean + SE of values obtained from 6 independent samples.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	173	 *Values that are significantly different than control at P  <  0.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	174	 B and C: Dox effects on CFTR expression as detected by Western blots of cells treated as in A above and analyzed for expression of human wild-type GFP-CFTR (B) or GFP-F508-CFTR (C) as described in METHODS and Fig.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	175	 D: Dox effects on GFP-F508-CFTR protein expression as determined by immunoprecipitation.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Cells were treated as described in A and analyzed by immunoprecipitation with the anti-CFTR polyclonal antibody A2 and by detection using an anti-GFP antibody as described in METHODS and Fig.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Arrows indicate positions of the GFP-F508-CFTR fusion proteins.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	178	Interestingly, Dox had no effect on chloride secretion in the MDCK cell line expressing the wild-type human GFP-CFTR (Fig.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	179	 There was also no effect on expression as determined by Western blotting (Fig.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	180	 The reason for the lack of effect on either canine or human wild-type CFTR in these experiments is not clear, since wild-type CFTR expression had been affected in the T84 cells (Figs.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	181	 This may be due to the already high level of expression of CFTR in the MDCK cells as demonstrated by the fivefold increase in their chloride secretion compared with the parental MDCK cells expressing only the canine form (Fig.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Conversely, it may be that in these MDCK cells, there are two distinct pathways for normal and mutant CFTR protein trafficking, the latter of which is more Dox sensitive.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Several previous experimental cell culture procedures, such as high concentrations of glycerol, low-temperature incubation, or treatment with the xanthine drug, CPX, have been shown to be able to increase functional cell surface F508-CFTR expression (3, 4, 14).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Interestingly, these same treatments did not appear to affect wild-type CFTR expression in these cells, suggesting that these agents are targeting an alternative pathway specific for the mutant, misfolded protein rather than general trafficking of CFTR or other proteins (3, 4, 14).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Thus there may be differences in the efficiency of wild-type CFTR expression in these cells, e.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	186	, more CFTR may follow the alternative pathway in T84 cells, and therefore be available for "rescue" by Dox treatment compared with the MDCK cells.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	187	 In any event, Dox's lack of effect on functional expression of endogenous canine CFTR in the parental MDCK cells or on expression of the stably expressed normal human GFP-CFTR suggests that the change in chloride current in the GFP-F508-CFTR MDCK cells was principally a result of substantially increased cell surface expression of GFP-F508-CFTR from an essentially undetectable functional level.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	188	To further confirm the Isc and Western results, we then examined changes in GFP-F508-CFTR expression in the MDCK cells by immunoprecipitation.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	189	 4D, Dox increased the expression of F508-CFTR protein in these cells.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Large glycoproteins typically migrate at a reduced rate on denaturing gels and, as a result, the mature "C" band of GFP-F508-CFTR is detected at ~240 kDa rather than at 210 kDa as predicted.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Our laboratory had previously demonstrated a similar migration pattern for wild-type GFP-CFTR (17).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Taken together, these results demonstrate that a noncytotoxic dose of Dox can substantially increase the functional cell surface expression of F508-CFTR in epithelial cells.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	193	    DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	194	We report that a single, noncytotoxic dose of Dox increased the amount of functional CFTR in the plasma membrane of T84 cells and the amount of functional F508-CFTR in the plasma membrane of MDCK cells.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	195	 In the T84 cells, this appeared to be principally a posttranscriptional effect because there was little effect on CFTR mRNA expression.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	196	 In both cell models, Dox caused a significant increase in total cellular CFTR protein levels and a proportionate increase in CFTR-associated chloride secretion.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	197	 These results suggest that analogs may be identified that will be clinically useful in ameliorating the CF disease phenotype in human CF patients.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	198	The purpose of these studies was to obtain proof of principle for this class of drugs.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Although the exact mechanistic basis behind this effect is currently being investigated, one possibility is that Dox increases the stability of the F508-CFTR nascent forms, allowing them to fold properly.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Dox may alter the kinetics of F508-CFTR biogenesis influencing the interaction of the nascent protein with cellular chaperones.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Previous reports indicate that heat shock cognate protein (HSC70) facilitates the early steps of F508-CFTR biogenesis that appear to be important for maturation of the protein (22), and compounds that are capable of altering this association facilitate F508-CFTR (9) expression and chloride secretion.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Another possibility is that Dox directly interacts with and alters the folding, stability, or trafficking of F508-CFTR during its biogenesis.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	203	 For example, mutations in Pgp that alter its folding and plasma membrane trafficking, including a mutation that is comparable to F508-CFTR, can be corrected by treatment of cells with Pgp substrate drugs (15).
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	204	 The authors proposed that such drugs acted as "chemical chaperones" that interact with Pgp and allow proper folding of the nascent molecule to the functional, mature form.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	205	 A similar phenomenon could occur for F508-CFTR, although this same study indicated no effect of these treatments on F508-CFTR expression indicating that the effect was Pgp specific.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	206	 However, anthracycline analogs were not tested in that study.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Other drugs have also been described that are capable of altering both CFTR and Pgp protein levels.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	208	 For example, butyrate compounds have been shown to be capable of stimulating both Pgp (16) and CFTR (18) protein expression.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	209	 We found that another cancer chemotherapy drug, mitomycin C, also increased functional cell surface expression of CFTR in T84 and HT-29 cells, although the effects were more modest than those of Dox (R.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	210	Alternatively, Dox may inhibit degradation of misfolded F508-CFTR, which might favor proper folding and maturation.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	211	 However, previous studies by Kopito and colleagues (11, 23) demonstrated that inhibition of the 26S proteosomal degradation pathway per se does not enhance F508-CFTR folding, but rather leads to aggregation.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Because other proteolytic pathways are involved in CFTR degradation (8), this possibility cannot be completely ruled out.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	213	 These and other possibilities remain to be explored in future studies.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	214	Perhaps most interestingly, a recent clinical observation was made (13) in a CF patient with F508-CFTR mutation in one allele and G673X stop mutation in the other allele who had fibrosarcoma.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	215	 This patient demonstrated significantly improved lung function and inhibition of his Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection after combination chemotherapy with cyclophosphamide and the anthracycline epirubicin.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	216	 This is an intriguing clinical observation that should be further investigated systematically in CF cancer patients receiving chemotherapy.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	217	In this study, the Dox treatment regimen at which significant F508-CFTR effects were observed (0.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	218	25  microM) is more promising from a clinical pharmacology perspective.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	219	 This Dox concentration is ~20-fold lower that its LC50 in these cell systems, suggesting that one might also be able to achieve these effects in vivo at a comparably low dose that is well below those used in cancer chemotherapy and that can elicit significant "nontarget" toxicity.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Dox itself is unlikely to be useful in a CF clinical setting due to its cumulative systemic toxicity.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	221	 However, it is likely, given that there are thousands of anthracyclines and their derivatives that have been developed and characterized over the past 50 years, that analogs can be discovered or developed that share the beneficial properties of Dox in increasing F508-CFTR expression while avoiding its cumulative toxicities.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	222	 The long-term goal of this research is to develop clinically useful drugs for the systemic treatment of CF patients with the aim of ameliorating their disease phenotype.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Givan for help with flow cytometry.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	224	This work was supported by grants from the National Institutes of Health to B.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Stanton, and from the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation to B.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Hamilton was also partially supported by the Norris Cotton Cancer Center, and R.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Maitra was partially supported by a research grant to J.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Hamilton from Bristol-Myers Squibb.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	229	Address for reprint requests and other correspondence: J.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	230	 of Pharmacology  and  Toxicology, Dartmouth Medical School, 7650 Remsen, Hanover, NH 03755-3835 (E-mail josh.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	231	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	232	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.42004547.11287314.html.plaintext.txt	234	Received 1 February 2000; accepted in final form 17 November 2000.

0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	0	Severed Molecules Functionally Define the Boundaries of the Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator's NH2-terminal Nucleotide Binding Domain Kim W.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Chana, Laszlo Csanadya, Donna Seto-Younga, Angus C.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	2	 Gadsbya a Laboratory of Cardiac/Membrane Physiology, The Rockefeller University, New York, New York 10021 b Laboratory of Molecular and Cellular Neuroscience, The Rockefeller University, New York, New York 10021.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Gadsby, Laboratory of Cardiac/Membrane Physiology, The Rockefeller University, 1230 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021-6399.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Fax:212-327-7589 E-mail:gadsby{at}rockvax.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	5	  Abstract Top Abstract INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION Acknowledgements References.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	6	The cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator is a Cl- channel that belongs to the family of ATP-binding cassette proteins.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	7	 The CFTR polypeptide comprises two transmembrane domains, two nucleotide binding domains (NBD1 and NBD2), and a regulatory (R) domain.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Gating of the channel is controlled by kinase-mediated phosphorylation of the R domain and by ATP binding, and, likely, hydrolysis at the NBDs.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Exon 13 of the CFTR gene encodes amino acids (aa's) 590 to 830, which were originally ascribed to the R domain.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	10	 In this study, CFTR channels were severed near likely NH2- or COOH-terminal boundaries of NBD1.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	11	 CFTR channel activity, assayed using two-microelectrode voltage clamp and excised patch recordings, provided a sensitive measure of successful assembly of each pair of channel segments as the sever point was systematically shifted along the primary sequence.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Substantial channel activity was taken as an indication that NBD1 was functionally intact.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	13	 This approach revealed that the COOH terminus of NBD1 extends beyond aa 590 and lies between aa's 622 and 634, while the NH2 terminus of NBD1 lies between aa's 432 and 449.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	14	 To facilitate biochemical studies of the expressed proteins, a Flag epitope was added to the NH2 termini of full length CFTR, and of CFTR segments truncated before the normal COOH terminus (aa 1480).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The functionally identified NBD1 boundaries are supported by Western blotting, coimmunoprecipitation, and deglycosylation studies, which showed that an NH2-terminal segment representing aa's 3 to 622 (Flag3-622) or 3 to 633 (Flag3-633) could physically associate with a COOH-terminal fragment representing aa's 634 to 1480 (634-1480); however, the latter fragment was glycosylated to the mature form only in the presence of Flag3-633.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Similarly, 433-1480 could physically associate with Flag3-432 and was glycosylated to the mature form; however, 449-1480 protein seemed unstable and could hardly be detected even when expressed with Flag3-432.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	17	 In excised-patch recordings, all functional severed CFTR channels displayed the hallmark characteristics of CFTR, including the requirement of phosphorylation and exposure to MgATP for gating, ability to be locked open by pyrophosphate or AMP-PNP, small single channel conductances, and high apparent affinity of channel opening by MgATP.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Our definitions of the boundaries of the NBD1 domain in CFTR are supported by comparison with the solved NBD structures of HisP and RbsA.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	19	Key Words: adenosine triphosphate-binding cassette transporter, domain structure, chloride channel, gating kinetics, coimmunoprecipitation.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	20	  INTRODUCTION Top Abstract INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION Acknowledgements References.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	21	The cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator is the ~170-kD protein product of the gene mutated in cystic fibrosis patients (Riordan et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	22	 The topological organization of CFTR that was predicted from the nucleotide sequence when the gene was cloned (Riordan et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	23	 1989 ) has largely stood the test of time.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	24	 CFTR comprises two approximately homologous halves, each incorporating a putative hexa-helical transmembrane domain followed, in the linear sequence, by a cytoplasmic nucleotide binding domain (NBD).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	25	1 The two halves are linked by a charged, cytoplasmic, ~200-residue regulatory (R) domain that contains multiple sites for phosphorylation by protein kinase A and protein kinase C (Riordan et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Apart from this large linker domain, CFTR's overall predicted domain structure identifies it as a member of the very large family of ATP-binding cassette (ABC) membrane transporters (e.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	27	 There are several other well-known eukaryotic ABC proteins such as P-glycoprotein (Pgp) and multi-drug resistance-related protein (MRP), both associated with multi-drug resistance in tumor cells, and STE6, the a-mating factor transporter of yeast.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	28	 In all these examples, both membrane-spanning domains and the two NBDs are encoded by a single large gene.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	29	 But, in the much larger number of prokaryotic ABC transporters, the NBDs are frequently expressed from individual genes (as for HisP, the NBD of histidine permease; e.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	30	 1998 ), or two NBDs may be fused in a single gene product (as for RbsA, the NBDs of the ribose transporter; e.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	31	 1998 ), while the transmembrane domains may be expressed from yet other genes.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	32	 One implication of such post-translational assembly of functional transporters in bacteria is that these separate gene products (which, in many cases, are single domains) must each possess all the information needed to fold correctly and to interact with the complementary domains that make up a fully functioning transporter.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	33	Unlike any other ABC protein, CFTR functions as a chloride channel (reviewed in Sheppard and Welsh 1999 ).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	34	 The R domain, with its multiple phosphorylation sites, is also unique to CFTR, and in its dephosphorylated state it prevents the opening of CFTR Cl- channels.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Even once it has been phosphorylated by PKA, however, a CFTR channel cannot open until it is exposed to ATP or another hydrolyzable nucleoside triphosphate.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	36	 The regulation of opening and closing of CFTR channels by phosphorylation of the R domain and nucleotide binding and hydrolysis at the NBDs is extremely complex and is not yet fully understood.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	37	 One suggestion is that ATP hydrolysis at NBD1 results in both channel opening and binding of ATP at NBD2, which then stabilizes the open-channel conformation (e.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	38	, Csanady and Gadsby 1999 ; Gadsby and Nairn 1999 ).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Recently, however, on the basis of direct comparisons of ATP hydrolysis and gating measurements of wild type and mutant CFTR, it has been suggested that ATP hydrolysis might not be strictly coupled to channel opening (Ramjeesingh et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Still, it remains clear that interactions between the two NBDs, and between the NBDs and the R domain, play important roles in the gating of CFTR channels (reviewed in Csanady and Gadsby 1999 ; Gadsby and Nairn 1999 ; Sheppard and Welsh 1999 ).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	41	Further dissection of these roles would greatly benefit from structural information on each of these domains, which is presently lacking.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Nevertheless, peptide models of the R domain (Picciotto et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	43	 1992 ; Dulhanty and Riordan 1994 ), of the NH2-terminal NBD (NBD1; Hartman et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	44	 1992 ; Ko and Pedersen 1995 ; Yike et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	45	 1998 ), and of the COOH-terminal NBD (NBD2; Randak et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	46	 1997 ) have been expressed and partly characterized.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	47	 A valid concern with several of these constructs is the sparse knowledge of the location of the domain boundaries.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	48	 As a first step towards addressing this concern, we attempted to define the boundaries of NBD1 of CFTR by exploiting a functional approach.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	49	 It has already been shown that the CFTR channel protein can be severed near the COOH-terminal end of the R domain, and the two halves coexpressed to form a functional complex (Ostedgaard et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Therefore, given the modular design of ABC transporters in general, we reasoned that judicious cuts in the links flanking NBD1 ought to be tolerated.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Indeed, cuts between three of the four domains of STE6 did not abrogate its function (Berkower et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	52	 We describe here our search for the boundaries of NBD1 by coexpressing contiguous, or near contiguous, segments of CFTR in Xenopus oocytes and assessing function with two-microelectrode voltage clamp and excised-patch recordings.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Expression and physical association of the CFTR protein segments were assayed using immunoblots and coimmunoprecipitation.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Using this approach, we find that the NH2 terminus of NBD1 lies between amino acids (aa) 432 and 449 and the COOH terminus lies between aa's 622 and 634.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Moreover, regions spanning aa's 415 to 432 and 634 to 667 can be omitted without severely impairing CFTR channel function.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	56	  MATERIALS AND METHODS Top Abstract INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION Acknowledgements References.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	57	Molecular Biology pGEMHE-WT was constructed by subcloning a CFTR cDNA fragment, excised from pBQ4.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Johanna Rommens, The Hospital for Sick Children, Toronto, Ontario, Canada), into the SmaI and XhoI (BioLabs, Inc.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	59	 A Flag epitope (M-DYKDDDDK) followed by a leucine was added to the NH2 terminus of a CFTR fragment containing amino acids 3 to 835 by running two consecutive PCR reactions using a GeneAmp PCR system 2400 (PerkinElmer).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	60	 In the first PCR reaction, FlagFW1 (5'-TACAAAGACGACGACGACAAGCTTAGGTCGCCTCTGGAAAAGGC) and 835RV (5'-CCGCTCGAGCTA-ATCAAAAAAGCACTCCTTTAAGTC) were used with pGEMHE-WT as template.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	61	 In the second PCR reaction, FlagFW2 (5'-TCC-CCCGGGCCGCCATGGATTACAAAGACGACGACGACAAG) and 835RV were used with the purified PCR product, obtained from the first reaction, as template.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	62	 The PCR product from the second reaction was subcloned into the SmaI and XhoI sites of pGEMHE to make pGEMHE-Flag3-835.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	63	 pGEMHE-Flag3-589 was made by PCR using T7 FW primer (5'-TAATACGACTCACTATAGGGCGAATT) and a specific reverse oligonucleotide primer 589RV (5'-CCGCTCGAGCTAGCTTTCAAATATTTCTTTTTC) with pGEMHE-Flag3-835 as template, followed by subcloning into pGEMHE.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	64	 pGEMHE-Flag3-611, pGEMHE-Flag3-622, pGEMHE-Flag3-633, pGEMHE-Flag3-432, and pGEMHE-Flag3-414 were similarly constructed using T7 FW and the corresponding specific reverse primers.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	65	 pGEMHE-590-1480 was made by PCR using 590FW (5'-TCCCCCGGGCCGCCATGTGTGTCTGTAAACTGA-TGGCTAACAAAA) and SP6 RV (5'-CGCCAAGCTATTTAGGTGACACTATAG) with pGEMHE-WT as template followed by subcloning.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	66	 pGEMHE-449-1480, pGEMHE-433-1480, pGEMHE-634-1480, and pGEMHE-668-1480 were similarly constructed using specific forward primers.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	67	 pGEMHE-FlagWT was constructed by subcloning a BspEI/XhoI fragment from pGEMHE-WT, which encodes part of TM6 and all the domains that follow, into BspEI and XhoI sites of pGEMHE-Flag3-835.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	68	 pGEMHE-1-432 and pGEMHE-1-633 were constructed by PCR reactions using pGEMHE-WT as template.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	69	 All PCR reactions used Pfu polymerase (Stratagene) and a low number (15 to 20) of PCR cycles, and all constructs were confirmed by automated sequencing.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	70	 The coding sequence for every engineered CFTR segment began with a Kozak consensus sequence (CCGCCATG) that includes the methionine start codon.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Plasmid DNAs were linearized with NheI, and cRNAs were produced by in vitro transcription using a T7 mMessage mMachine kit (Ambion), and then run on denaturing gels to check size and quality.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	72	 RNA concentration was estimated by comparison with a known amount of 0.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	73	Isolation and Injection of Xenopus Oocytes Stage V to VI oocytes were isolated from adult female Xenopus laevis (Nasco) by partial ovariectomy under Tricaine (1% solution) anaesthesia and were defolliculated by treatment at room temperature (21 to 23 degrees C) for up to 2 h, with ~2 mg/ml collagenase (Type II; Worthington Biochemicals or Type I; GIBCO BRL) in nominally Ca2+-free oocyte Ringer's solution containing (mM): 82.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	74	5 NaCl, 2 KCl, 1 MgCl2, 5 HEPES, pH 7.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Defolliculated oocytes were rinsed extensively with Ca2+-free Ringer's (three to five washes, 50-ml each), and then incubated at 18 degrees C for several hours in Ringer's with 1.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	76	8 mM Ca2+ and 50  microg/ml gentamycin (GIBCO BRL) before they were pressure-injected (nanojet; Drummond Scientific) with cRNAs.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Injection pipettes were pulled (PP83; Narishige) from glass capillaries (3-000-203-G/X; Drummond Scientific) and their tips were broken to an internal diameter of 10 to 20  microm.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Usually, and unless otherwise specified, 2.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	79	5 ng of each cRNA, premixed if for coexpression, in a constant total volume of 50 nl, were injected per oocyte.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Injected oocytes were further incubated at 18 degrees C for 2 to 3 d before they were used for recording or for preparation of membranes.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	81	Electrophysiology For two-microelectrode voltage-clamp measurements, oocytes in a plexiglass recording chamber (volume ~150  microl) were continuously superfused (~2 ml/min) at ~22 degrees C with gravity-fed solutions selected by manual valves (Hamilton).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	82	 The dead volume was ~100  microl, and solutions were completely exchanged in  < 8 s.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The standard bath solution was Ca2+-free Ringer's solution.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The chamber was connected to virtual ground circuitry through Ag/AgCl electrodes in 2.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Currents were measured by a voltage-clamp amplifier (OC-725A oocyte clamp; Warner Instrument Corp.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	86	), filtered at 50 Hz by an eight-pole Bessel filter (Frequency Devices, Inc.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	87	), digitized online at 100 Hz using a Digidata 1200 board (Axon Instruments, Inc.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	88	2 software (Axon Instruments, Inc.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Microelectrodes, pulled from glass capillaries (3-000-210-G; Drummond Scientific), were filled with 3 M KCl and had resistances of 0.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Voltage steps were applied via the amplifier's toggle switch (duration 0.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	91	5 to 1 s) or using pCLAMP software.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Steady state currents were averaged over 200 ms near the ends of 1-s voltage steps, and plotted against voltage.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Conductance was calculated from linear fits to the steady currents between -60 and -20 mV.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Average values were from at least five oocytes.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	95	For patch-clamp recording, oocytes were shrunk for ~2 min in standard bath solution containing (mM): 138 NMG, 2 Mg-sulfamate, 5 HEPES, 0.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	96	5 EGTA, 134 sulfamic acid, pH 7.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	97	1 with sulfamic acid, supplemented with 100 mM NaCl.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	98	 The vitelline membranes were removed manually and the oocytes were transferred to a recording chamber containing standard bath solution.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Patch pipettes were pulled from borosilicate glass (N-51A; Drummond Scientific) using a vertical pipette puller, and fire-polished to a tip diameter of 1 to 2  microm (4 to 7 M).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	100	 The pipette solution contained (mM): 138 NMG, 2 MgCl2, 5 HEPES, 136 HCl, pH 7.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	101	 200 to 300-G seals were obtained by gentle suction.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Patches were excised and transferred to a flow chamber, where the cytoplasmic surface was continuously superfused at 21 to 23 degrees C with standard bath solution containing various test substances.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Switching between solutions was implemented by computer-driven electric valves (General Valve Corp.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	104	 With the dead volume of ~20  microl and flow rate of ~0.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	105	5 ml/min, complete solution exchange took 2 to 4 s.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Solution-exchange rate was verified at the end of each recording by applying a brief pulse of 2 mM Ca-sulfamate, and observing the rate of decay of endogenous Ca2+-activated Cl--channel current upon Ca2+ removal.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	107	 The bath electrode (Ag/AgCl pellet in 100 mM KCl) was connected to the flow chamber by an agar bridge (4% agar in 100 mM KCl).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Outward unitary currents in CFTR channels were recorded at a pipette potential of -40 mV (Vm = +40 mV) via an Axopatch 200A amplifier (Axon Instruments, Inc.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	109	), filtered at 100 Hz with an eight-pole Bessel filter (Frequency Devices, Inc.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	110	), digitized online at 1 kHz using an ITC-16 board (Instrutech) and recorded on disk by PULSE software (Heka Elektronik).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	111	 CFTR channels were activated by 300 nM catalytic subunit of protein kinase A purified from bovine heart (Kaczmarek et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	112	 1980 ); measurements of steady state macroscopic CFTR current at various [PKA] (Csanady et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	113	 1998 ) showed that even 300 nM was less than saturating due to highly active membrane-associated phosphatases.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	114	 MgATP (Sigma-Aldrich) was added from a 400-mM stock solution (pH 7.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	115	 At the end of each experiment, channels were counted by locking them in the open state with 2 mM NMG-pyrophosphate (PPi; Fluka) in the presence of 100  microM MgATP and 300 nM PKA, supplemented by 2 mM Mg-sulfamate (for example, see Fig 8, below).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Li4-AMPPNP (Sigma-Aldrich) was added from a 400-mM stock solution.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	117	View larger version (14K):    Figure 1.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	118	 (A to C) Representative current recordings from oocytes held at their initial resting membrane potential in Ca2+-free oocyte Ringer's solution.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Oocytes were injected with (A) water, (B) 6 ng of WT CFTR RNA, or (C) 2.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Horizontal bars mark periods of exposure to 50  microM forskolin plus 1 mM IBMX.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Basal and activated conductances were monitored by applying  plus or minus 60-mV voltage steps 1-s long.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Magnitudes of basal and activated conductances and rates of activation were similar in oocytes injected with 2.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	123	 (D) I-V relationships obtained at times a-f in A to C; empty symbols, resting (basal); filled symbols, activated.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Steady current levels averaged over ~200 ms near the end of 1-s voltage steps from -100 to +80 mV, in 20-mV increments, are plotted against voltage.

0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	130	 The COOH terminus lies between residues 622 and 634.

0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	141	 (A and B) Immunoblots of membrane proteins from oocytes expressing individual CFTR segments or pairs of segments, as indicated, resolved by SDS-PAGE, transferred, and blotted with anti to R-domain antibody (A) or with anti to Flag M2 antibody (B).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	142	 (C) Coexpressed constructs Flag3-633 plus 634-1480 were digested with N-glycosidase-F (left) or endoglycosidase-H (right), and the products were identified with anti to R-domain antibody.
