0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	154	 (A) Constructs severed near the COOH terminus of NBD1: uninjected (lane 1), Flag3-622+634-1480 (lane 2), Flag3-633+634-1480 (lane 3); arrows are as in Fig 5 A.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	155	 (B) Constructs severed near the NH2-terminus of NBD1: Flag3-432+449-1480 (lane 1), Flag3-432+433-1480 (lane 2); arrows are as in Fig 6 A.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	156	View larger version (45K):    Figure 8.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Representative excised-patch current recordings showing WT, 1-432+433-1480, 1-633+634-1480, Flag-WT, Flag3-432+433-1480, and Flag3-633+634-1480 CFTR channels.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	158	 All constructs displayed hallmark characteristics of WT CFTR including requirement for phosphorylation by PKA (here 300 nM) and exposure to MgATP (here 1 mM for WT, 2 mM for others) for channel activity, slow burst kinetics, and locking in the open state by a mixture of ATP (0.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	159	For kinetic analysis, digitized (100 Hz bandwidth, 1 kHz sampling rate), baseline-corrected currents from records containing one to seven channels were idealized using conventional half-amplitude threshold crossing.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	160	 The desired parameters were mean burst and interburst durations for the intact and severed CFTR constructs, and these were determined as follows.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	161	 First, gating transitions were modeled as a simple closed to open scheme, while brief ("flickery") closures were attributed to pore blockage events (e.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	162	, Ishihara and Welsh 1997 ), resulting in the three-state closed to open-blocked scheme in Scheme 1:.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	163	Then, for each record, the best set of rate constants, rCO, rOC, rOB, and rBO, was extracted from a simultaneous maximum likelihood fit to the dwell-time histograms obtained from all of the conductance levels, as described (Csanady 2000 ).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Finally, mean interburst durations were calculated using the relationship ib = 1/rCO, while mean burst durations were given by b = (1/rOC)(1 + rOB/rBO).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	165	 As a control, because a similar burst-type gating to that of the C-O-B scheme arises from the alternative linear three-state model, closed to closed to open (C-C-O), the events list was sometimes also fitted assuming this C-C-O scheme; this yielded a new set of rate constants, but identical mean burst and interburst durations for the same record in every case.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Open probabilities (Po) were calculated directly from the events lists as the time average of the idealized current divided by channel number (estimated for each patch as described above) and the measured single-channel current amplitude.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	167	Macroscopic currents from patches containing 20 to 1,000 CFTR channels were digitally refiltered at 10 Hz using a Gaussian filter, and then sampled at 50 Hz.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	168	 The average steady state current towards the end of 10 to 30-s test applications of 50  microM MgATP was normalized to the mean of the steady currents at 2 mM MgATP before and after the test, and the ratios were used to estimate apparent affinities for ATP.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	169	Single-channel conductances were estimated from amplitude histograms of excised-patch currents recorded at holding potentials of -80, -40, 0, +40, and +80 mV, in symmetrical 140 mM [Cl-].
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	170	 The distances between adjacent peaks, from fits to sums of Gaussians, were plotted against voltage, and straight lines fitted to yield conductances.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Results are presented as mean  plus or minus  SEM of five or more experiments for kinetic data, and three or more experiments for apparent affinities and single-channel conductances.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Statistical significances were evaluated by Student's t test.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	173	Preparation of Oocyte Membranes Oocytes injected with cRNA were incubated for 48 h, and then frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at -80 degrees C.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Aliquots of ~150 frozen oocytes were homogenized at 4 degrees C with 1 ml lysis buffer, containing (mM): 10 HEPES, pH 7.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	175	5 with NaOH, 6 EDTA, 50 NaCl, 1 mg/ml BSA, 1 PMSF, and protease inhibitor cocktail (Calbiochem; final concentrations were 1 mM AEBSF HCl, 300 nM aprotinin, 2  microM E-64, 2  microM leupeptin hemisulfate), and the suspensions were centrifuged at 3,000 g for 10 min.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Supernatants were kept and centrifuged again at 3,000 g for 10 min.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	177	 2 ml of lysis buffer was added to the resulting supernatants before centrifugation at 173,600 g for 1 h.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	178	 The pellets were washed with 3 ml modified lysis buffer (with 10% glycerol instead of BSA, and only 0.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	179	5 mM PMSF), the centrifugation was repeated and the pelleted membranes resuspended in 0.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	180	2 ml modified lysis buffer and stored at -80 degrees C.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	181	Western Blotting and Coimmunoprecipitation Membrane proteins (75  microg total membrane protein per lane) were resolved by 7.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	182	5% SDS-PAGE and blotted onto nitrocellulose membranes using a semi-dry transfer cell (Bio-Rad Laboratories).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Protein bands containing the R domain were detected with anti to R-domain Ab (Picciotto et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	184	 1992 ) and horseradish perozidase to conjugated goat anti to rabbit IgG as the secondary Ab.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	185	 NH2-terminal fragments were detected either using anti to Flag M2 monoclonal Ab (Sigma-Aldrich) with HP-conjugated goat anti to mouse IgG as the secondary Ab or, in coimmunoprecipitation experiments, using an anti to NH2-terminal Ab (A2; kindly provided by Dr.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Skach, Oregon Health Sciences University, Portland, OR) with HP-conjugated goat anti to rabbit IgG as secondary Ab.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Protein bands were visualized with the ECL Western blotting kit (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	188	Coimmunoprecipitation was by a procedure modified from that of Ostedgaard et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	189	 450  microg of each total membrane protein sample were solubilized for 1 h in 1 ml solubilization buffer (1.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	190	25% digitonin, 150 mM NaCl, 50 mM Tris/HCl, pH 7.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	191	5) and the suspensions centrifuged at 173,600 g for 1 h.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Each supernatant of soluble proteins was mixed with 200  microl of anti to Flag M2 affinity gel (Sigma-Aldrich) prewashed with solubilization buffer, and the mixtures were rocked overnight, and then centrifuged at 26,000 g for 5 min.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	193	 The pellets, containing anti to Flag M2 affinity gel with bound proteins, were washed three times with solubilization buffer, three times with high-salt buffer (500 mM NaCl, 50 mM Tris/HCl, pH 7.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	194	5), and then twice with 50 mM Tris, pH 7.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	195	 The coimmunoprecipitated proteins were eluted with 150  microl Laemmli buffer.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	196	Deglycosylation and Protein Determination Oocyte membrane protein samples (75  microg) were treated with N-glycosidase-F and endoglycosidase-H for 1 h at 37 degrees C following the supplier's protocol (Boehringer).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Protein concentrations were measured with bicinchonic acid (Pierce Chemical Co.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	198	  RESULTS Top Abstract INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION Acknowledgements References.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	199	Wild-Type CFTR Channels Display Basal Activity in Resting Xenopus Oocytes Xenopus oocytes have proven to be a convenient expression system for functional and biochemical analysis of a variety of ion channels, including CFTR (e.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	200	 1999 ), and were adopted for this study.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Fig 1A to C, shows typical recordings of membrane current in oocytes, held near their resting potentials, 2 d after injecting them with (A) water, (B) WT CFTR cRNA, or (C) a mixture of two cRNAs encoding contiguous CFTR segments Flag3-633 and 634-1480.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Membrane conductance was monitored every minute or so with  plus or minus 60-mV steps away from the holding potential, which yielded negligibly small currents ( plus or minus 0.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	203	1  microA or less) at all times in control, H2O-injected oocytes (also in uninjected oocytes).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	204	 By contrast, these voltage steps elicited clearly discernible currents of approximately  plus or minus 1  microA in unstimulated oocytes expressing WT CFTR (reflecting their mean basal conductance, 10  plus or minus  1  microS) and of approximately  plus or minus 10  microA (mean activated conductance, 173  plus or minus  4  microS) within ~2 min of stimulating the cAMP/PKA pathway in those oocytes by exposing them to 50  microM forskolin plus 1 mM IBMX (Fig 1 and Table 1).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	205	 The steady current levels near the ends of 1-s voltage pulses to potentials between -100 and +80 mV are shown in the steady state current to voltage plots in Fig 1 D.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	206	 For oocytes expressing WT CFTR, these I-V relationships were approximately linear, and showed roughly the same reversal potential, both before and during stimulation of PKA (Fig 1 D, c and d).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	207	 In oocytes expressing WT CFTR, but not in uninjected oocytes, subsequent injection of the PKA inhibitor RpcAMPS (estimated final concentration, ~1 mM) diminished the basal conductance until it matched that of H2O-injected, or of uninjected, oocytes (Csanady, L.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Gadsby, manuscript submitted for publication).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	209	 This indicates that the basal conductance reflected activity of WT-CFTR channels phosphorylated by basally active PKA, and that phosphatases must also have been constitutively active in the oocytes to dephosphorylate CFTR channels and abolish their basal activity after introduction of RpcAMPS.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Accordingly, the forskolin- and IBMX-induced increase in membrane conductance of oocytes expressing CFTR presumably reflected activation of CFTR by PKA-mediated phosphorylation (e.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	211	 1993 ) and possibly also a direct stimulation of CFTR by IBMX (Al-Nakkash and Hwang 1999 ).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Conductances of Oocytes Expressing Various CFTR Constructs.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	213	Defining the COOH-terminal Boundary of NBD1 by Assessing Function of Coexpressed Severed CFTR Segments The location of the boundary between NBD1 and the R domain in CFTR is presently unclear.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	214	 The initial suggestion was that exon 13 of CFTR, comprising aa's 590 to 830, encoded the R domain, and hence that the exon 12/13 junction marked the boundary between NBD1 and the R domain (Riordan et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	215	 If that were so, it might reasonably be expected that functional CFTR channels could be reconstituted by coexpression of the two contiguous segments of CFTR severed between residues 589 and 590; i.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	216	 The NH2-terminal Flag epitope was incorporated to facilitate immunoprecipitation and detection of the expressed proteins (see below).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Injection of oocytes with a mixture of the two cRNAs encoding these two segments resulted in conductances that were negligible under both basal (2  plus or minus  1  microS) and activated (2  plus or minus  1  microS) conditions, just as in control, uninjected oocytes (Fig 2 and Table 1).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	218	 On the assumption that NBD1 likely stretches beyond aa 589 (compare Annereau et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	219	 1997 ), a series of constructs was made in which the COOH terminus of Flag3-589 was incrementally extended.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Each of these constructs in turn was coexpressed with the 590-1480 segment, and basal and activated conductances were measured to assess channel function (Fig 2).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	221	 These conductances mimicked those of uninjected oocytes until the Flag-tagged CFTR segment was extended to aa 633.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Thus, basal and activated conductances were 2  plus or minus  1 and 3  plus or minus  1  microS for oocytes injected with Flag3-622 plus 590-1480, but jumped to 8  plus or minus  1 and 91  plus or minus  7  microS in oocytes coexpressing Flag3-633 plus 590-1480.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	223	 However, the basal and activated conductances produced by Flag3-633 plus 590-1480 constructs were both smaller than those attained by WT CFTR (Fig 2).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Speculating that this shortfall might be attributable to the repetition of residues 590 to 633 upon coexpression of Flag3-633 plus 590-1480, we removed the overlapping residues by coexpressing Flag3-633 with segment 634-1480, and found basal and activated conductances of 17  plus or minus  1 and 182  plus or minus  4  microS, respectively, comparable with those of oocytes expressing WT CFTR (Fig 1, B to D, and 2; Table 1).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	225	These results show that robust CFTR channel function is obtained when the COOH terminus of the segment Flag3-589 is extended to aa 633 (but not to aa 622) and when that construct is coexpressed with the appropriate complementary segment, suggesting that the COOH terminus of NBD1 lies between aa's 622 and 634.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	226	 (In other words, it could lie at aa 623, or 624, or 625, etc.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	227	, but could extend as far as aa 633.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	228	) An alternative possibility, that a crucial part of NBD1 extends beyond aa 633 but can nevertheless associate with the Flag3-633 segment to form a complete NBD1 domain, is rendered unlikely by our finding that strong CFTR channel activity was reconstituted by coexpression of Flag3-633 with 668-1480: despite this omission of the 34-residue segment aa's 634 to 667, basal and activated conductances (16  plus or minus  1 and 175  plus or minus  7  microS, respectively; Fig 2 and Table 1) were similar to those of WT CFTR.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	229	 On the other hand, oocytes coexpressing Flag3-622 plus 634-1480, in which any CFTR channels must lack aa's 623 to 633, displayed negligible basal and activated conductances like those of uninjected oocytes.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	230	Defining the NH2-terminal Boundary of NBD1 We used a similar strategy to incrementally extend the NH2 terminus of segment 590-1480 in an attempt to build a complete NBD1 there.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Upon coexpression with Flag3-589, the extended segment 449-1480 yielded conductances indistinguishable from those of uninjected oocytes, but extended segment 433-1480 gave substantial activated (129  plus or minus  12  microS) conductance, though still smaller than that of WT CFTR-injected oocytes (Fig 3).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	232	 However, omission of the overlapping section (residues 433 to 589) by coexpression of Flag3-432 plus 433-1480 resulted in somewhat larger basal (6  plus or minus  1  microS) and activated (157  plus or minus  5  microS) conductances that approached those of oocytes expressing WT CFTR channels.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	233	 The fact that coexpression of Flag3-432 plus 449-1480 yielded no functional channels confirms that segment 433-448 is an essential part of NBD1.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	234	 In contrast, coexpression of Flag3-414 plus 433-1480, which effectively deleted the 18-residue segment aa's 415 to 432, nevertheless resulted in oocytes that displayed basal and activated conductances (7  plus or minus  1 and 195  plus or minus  5  microS, respectively) comparable with those of oocytes expressing intact CFTR (Fig 2 and Table 1).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	235	 These data suggest that the NH2-terminal boundary of NBD1 lies between aa's 432 and 449.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	236	As a control test, each individual segment of CFTR used to investigate the functional boundaries of NBD1 was expressed by itself in oocytes, and basal and activated conductances were measured in the usual manner.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	237	 In all cases, the resulting conductances were similar to those of uninjected oocytes (Fig 4), confirming that none of these truncated CFTR fragments readily forms viable channels when expressed alone in Xenopus oocytes.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	238	Expression and Maturation of Severed CFTR Segments Western blots of proteins resolved from whole oocyte membrane preparations were used to evaluate expression of intact or truncated CFTR proteins.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	239	 As expected, the R-domain antibody did not recognize the Flag3-622 or Flag3-633 segments (Fig 5 A, lanes 1 and 2), but did detect a single sharp band of ~95 kD (Fig 5 A, lane 3, thin arrow) when segment 634-1480 was expressed alone.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	240	 However, an additional broad band of ~150 kD appeared when 634-1480 was coexpressed with Flag3-633 (Fig 5 A, lane 5, fat arrow), implying that segment 634-1480 was then glycosylated.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	241	 Accordingly, the ~95-kD band could be digested to a perceptibly smaller band of ~90 kD (Fig 5 C, thin arrows) by either endoglycosidase-H or N-glycosidase-F, whereas the broad ~150-kD (Fig 5 C, fat arrow) band was insensitive to endoglycosidase-H, but was largely digested to a ~90-kD band after treatment with N-glycosidase-F (Fig 5 C).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Because endoglycosidase-H may be expected to remove glycosyl moieties only from proteins not yet modified by the early Golgi enzyme mannosidase II, whereas N-glycosidase-F removes all asparagine-linked glycosyl groups, these results argue that the ~90-kD band corresponds to the deglycosylated form of segment 634-1480, while the ~95- and ~150-kD bands correspond to its core glycosylated and fully glycosylated forms, respectively.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	243	 This, in turn, suggests that segment 634-1480 was merely core glycosylated when expressed alone (Fig 5 A, lane 3), but could be fully glycosylated when it was coexpressed with the contiguous segment Flag3-633 (Fig 5 A, lane 5).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	244	 Together with the several-fold increase in density of the 634-1480 signal in the presence of Flag3-633 (compare lanes 3 and 5), these findings indicate that maturation and stabilization of segment 634-1480 are promoted by its coexpression with an appropriate complementary segment such as Flag3-633.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	245	 Interestingly, however, the ~150-kD band was not detected when segment 634-1480 was coexpressed with Flag3-622 (Fig 5 A, lane 4).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	246	 This, despite the fact that the Flag3-633 and Flag3-622 segments, detected by the anti to Flag M2 antibody as single narrow bands (Fig 5 B), were both expressed at similar levels, and at almost the same level whether expressed alone or coexpressed with 634-1480.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	247	 Thus, although removal of the eleven residues (aa's 623 to 633) from Flag3-633 did not affect the stability of the resulting segment, Flag3-622 (Fig 5 B, lanes 2 and 5 vs.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	248	 1 and 4), this deletion abrogated the ability of that segment to promote glycosylation of the coexpressed fragment, 634-1480 (Fig 5 A, lane 5 vs.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	249	 These data indicate that completion of the COOH terminus of segment Flag3-622 by some or all of aa's 623 to 633 is required for productive interaction with segment 634-1480, which, in turn, seems essential for maturation of the resulting complex.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	250	 This is consistent with the conclusion from the functional measurements, using two-electrode voltage clamp, that the COOH terminus of NBD1 lies between residues 622 and 634.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	251	Similarly, the R-domain antibody did not detect the Flag3-432 segment (which lacks an R domain; Fig 6 A, lane 1), but recognized segment 433-1480, which, when expressed alone, gave a sharp band at ~125 kD (Fig 6 A, lane 2, thin arrow).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Coexpression of 433-1480 with Flag3-432 (Fig 6 A, lane 5) yielded that same band (thin arrow), together with an additional, broader band (fat arrow) of ~160 kD (together with weak degradation bands ~70 to 75 kD), consistent with glycosylation of segment 433-1480.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Indeed, after treatment with either endoglycosidase-H or N-glycosidase-F the lower (~125-kD) Mr band migrated as a slightly smaller fragment of ~120 kD (Fig 6 B, thin arrows).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	254	 On the other hand, the higher (~160-kD; Fig 6 B, fat arrow) Mr band was insensitive to endoglycosidase-H, but was converted to a ~120-kD band by N-glycosidase-F.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	255	 It seems, then, that the ~120-kD band represents the unglycosylated form of segment 433-1480, while the ~125- and the ~160-kD bands represent its core glycosylated and fully glycosylated forms.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	256	 However, hardly any protein was detected (over the range ~45 to ~180 kD) by the R-domain antibody when segment 449-1480 was expressed alone (Fig 6 A, lane 3).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	257	 Even when it was coexpressed with the Flag3-432 segment, only a relatively weak band of ~70 kD could be detected, presumably representing a degraded form of 449-1480 protein (Fig 6 A, lane 4, *).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	258	 So, it appears that the stability of 449-1480 protein was slightly increased in the presence of Flag3-432, although no glycosylated form of 449-1480 was observed.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Thus, deletion of aa's 433 to 448 from 433-1480 yielded a segment that seemed highly unstable, even when coexpressed with a complementary segment of CFTR.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	260	 These biochemical findings support our conclusion from the electrophysiological assays of function that the NH2 terminus of NBD1 lies between residues 432 and 449.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	261	Physical Association between Complementary Fragments Starts in the Endoplasmic Reticulum Coimmunoprecipitation tests were made using anti to Flag M2 affinity beads to evaluate physical association between Flag-tagged NH2-terminal segments of CFTR and complementary COOH-terminal segments in membrane extracts from oocytes coinjected with cRNAs encoding severed CFTR molecules.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Both segments Flag3-622 and Flag3-633 (detected with an antibody against an epitope near CFTR's NH2 terminus; Fig 7 A, bottom, lanes 2 and 3) were able to coimmunoprecipitate the core glycosylated (~95-kD; thin arrow) form of segment 634-1480 (top, lanes 2 and 3).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	263	 However, the fully glycosylated (~150-kD; fat arrow) form of 634-1480 was coimmunoprecipitated only with Flag3-633 (Fig 7 A, top, lane 3) and not with Flag3-622 (lane 2).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	264	 Because the immunoprecipitation was via the Flag tag, it appears that both Flag3-622 and Flag3-633 segments associate with the core glycosylated segment 634-1480 (Fig 7 A, top, lanes 2 and 3, thin arrow), presumably in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), but only the Flag3-633 plus 634-1480 complex proceeds to the Golgi compartment, and eventually to the cell surface membrane as a mature, fully glycosylated channel.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	265	 The Flag3-622 plus 634-1480 complex (Fig 7 A, lane 2), on the other hand, does not appear to leave the ER.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	266	Correspondingly, immunoprecipitation of segment Flag3-432 (detected with the anti to NH2-terminal antibody; Fig 7 B, bottom, lanes 1 and 2) resulted in coimmunoprecipitation of both core-glycosylated (thin arrow) and fully glycosylated (fat arrow) forms of segment 433-1480 (top, lane 2), but of little or no protein corresponding to segment 449-1480 (top, lane 1).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	267	 The latter result corroborates the conclusion from the Western blot of Fig 6 A that segment 449-1480 appears to be rapidly degraded in the oocyte.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	268	 Coimmunoprecipitation (using the anti to Flag beads) of both immature and mature forms of 433-1480 (Fig 7 B, top, lane 2, thin and fat arrows), however, demonstrates that segments Flag3-432 and 433-1480 physically associate with each other, and that this association takes place in the ER (or, at the latest, in the early Golgi compartment).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	269	 These data indicate that the complementary pairs of CFTR segments that constitute functional channels, whether severed just before or just after the intact NBD1, begin their association in the ER before proceeding through the Golgi to the cell membrane, whereas segment pairs that do not comprise an intact NBD1 fail to exit the ER.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	270	The NH2-terminal Flag Epitope Lowers the Po of CFTR Channels by Slowing Opening Forskolin activates CFTR channels indirectly via a pathway that involves adenylyl cyclase and PKA holoenzyme, and, in the oocyte, such activation appears to be subject to saturation (Csanady, L.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	271	 Gadsby, manuscript submitted for publication).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	272	 Moreover, IBMX at millimolar concentrations likely directly stimulates CFTR channel activity (Al-Nakkash and Hwang 1999 ).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	273	 Both of these facts make our two-microelectrode recordings only coarse assays of the function of CFTR channels, whether intact or severed, expressed in oocytes.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	274	 We therefore directly activated the channels by applying catalytic subunit of PKA to the cytoplasmic surface of inside-out patches excised from the oocytes, and evaluated their behavior in detail.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	275	 Also, because the NH2-terminal CFTR segments described so far had all been tagged with the Flag M2 epitope, we characterized the unitary currents of the three representative channel types, WT CFTR, CFTR severed just before NBD1, and CFTR severed just after NBD1, in each case with and without the Flag tag (e.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	276	 The representative recordings in Fig 8 show that WT and Flag-WT CFTR channels share several of the accepted hallmark characteristics, such as single-channel conductance, the requirement for ATP and prior phosphorylation by PKA for channel activity, relatively slow channel gating (interburst and burst durations on the order of seconds), and locking of the channels in the open state by PPi or by AMPPNP (data not shown).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	277	 However, kinetic analysis revealed that the Po of Flag-WT was ~1/3 that of WT (Fig 9 and Table 2).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	278	 This reduction in Po was not due to any change in mean burst duration (i.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	279	, in closing rate), but rather reflected an approximately threefold prolongation of the mean interburst duration (i.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	280	, approximately threefold lower opening rate) of Flag-WT compared with WT channels (Fig 9).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	281	 Comparable results were obtained when the severed CFTR channels Flag3-432 plus 433-1480 and Flag3-633 plus 634-1480 were compared with their Flag-less counterparts (Fig 9).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	282	 As evident from the recordings in Fig 8, all of these constructs displayed the same general channel characteristics as listed above for WT CFTR channels.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	283	 Despite this broad similarity, both of the severed CFTR channels containing the NH2-terminal Flag showed interburst durations two- to threefold longer than those of the corresponding Flag-less severed CFTR channels (Fig 9 and Table 2).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	284	 Therefore, the Flag epitope added to the NH2 terminus of CFTR significantly reduces channel Po by selectively slowing channel opening.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	285	View larger version (25K):    Figure 9.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Kinetic analysis of WT, 1-432+433-1480, 1-633+634-1480, Flag-WT, Flag3-432+433-1480, and Flag3-633+634-1480 channels.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	287	 Kinetic parameters were extracted from records (filtered at 100 Hz, sampled at 1 kHz) of patches containing one to seven channels, exposed to 2 mM MgATP and 300 nM PKA.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	288	 Mean burst durations of constructs severed between NBD1 and the R domain (1-633+634-1480 and Flag3-633+634-1480) were significantly shorter than those of WT or Flag-WT.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	289	 All constructs containing the Flag epitope (Flag-WT, Flag3-432+ 433-1480, and Flag3-633+634-1480) showed significantly prolonged interburst durations and, hence, significantly reduced Po compared with WT.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	290	 Gating Kinetics of Intact and Severed CFTR Channels.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	291	Severing CFTR between NBD1 and the R Domain Lowers Po by Speeding Channel Closing The more interesting question is whether severing CFTR, either just before or just after NBD1, affects channel gating.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	292	 The results of the kinetic analysis (Fig 9 and Table 2) demonstrate that severed channels formed from segments 1-432 plus 433-1480 had a Po, a mean burst duration, and a mean interburst duration that were not significantly different from those of WT CFTR channels.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	293	 Furthermore, this similarity was not influenced by addition of the Flag epitope, since severed channels formed from Flag3-432 plus 433-1480 segments showed Po, and burst and interburst durations, closely similar to those of Flag-WT channels (Fig 9 and Table 2).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	294	 However, severed channels formed from CFTR segments 1-633 plus 634-1480 had a smaller Po than WT or 1-432 plus 433-1480 channels, attributable to a reduced burst duration (i.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	295	, to an increased closing rate).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	296	 This effect of severing CFTR channels just after NBD1 was independent of the presence or absence of the Flag epitope, because the mean burst duration of channels comprising segments Flag3-633 plus 634-1480 was significantly shorter than that of either Flag-WT or Flag3-432 plus 433-1480 channels (Fig 9 and Table 2).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	297	 These findings indicate that severing CFTR just before NBD1 has no measurable effect on channel Po or gating kinetics, whereas severing CFTR between NBD1 and the R domain leads to a reduction in Po due to an increase in channel closing rate.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	298	Neither Adding the Flag Epitope, nor Severing CFTR before or after NBD1, Affects Single-Channel Conductance or the Apparent Affinity for ATP To verify that neither incorporating the Flag epitope nor severing CFTR before or after NBD1 causes a major structural alteration in the channel pore, we measured single-channel conductances of WT and Flag-WT CFTR channels, and of severed channels formed from segments 1-432 plus 433-1480, or Flag3-432 plus 433-1480, or 1-633 plus 634-1480, or Flag3-633 plus 634-1480, in excised patches exposed to symmetrical 140 mM Cl- solutions.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	299	 Under these conditions, as illustrated for WT and for 1-432 plus 433-1480 channels, each channel type was characterized by an ohmic single-channel conductance: its average magnitude was ~7 pS and there was no significant difference between the conductance of WT CFTR channels and that of any of the other constructs (P = 0.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	300	 This argues that severing CFTR, or adding the NH2-terminal Flag, did not grossly alter the pore architecture.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	301	View larger version (26K):    Figure 10.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	302	 Single-channel conductances of WT, 1-432+433-1480, 1-633+634-1480, FlagWT, Flag3-432+433-1480, and Flag3-633+634-1480 channels in symmetrical 140 mM Cl-.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	303	 (A and B) Segments of representative CFTR channel current records, illustrated for WT and 1-432+433-1480, at holding potentials of -80, -40, 0, +40, and +80 mV, were used to create amplitude histograms, fitted by sums of Gaussians (right).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	304	 The distances between adjacent peaks, plotted against potential gave linear I-V plots.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	305	 (C) Fitted slopes gave conductances of 6.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	306	1 (Flag3-633+634-1480), none of which differed significantly from WT at P  <  0.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	307	Assuming that a step after binding of ATP at one of the NBDs rate limits channel opening (see Csanady and Gadsby 1999 ; Gadsby and Nairn 1999 ; Zeltwanger et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	308	 1999 ), there are two possible explanations for the observation that opening rate, and hence Po, are decreased in Flag-tagged CFTR channels.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	309	 This decrease could result from a reduction either in the binding affinity for ATP at that site, or in the rate of a step after binding (such as a step related to hydrolysis, or transmission of the gating conformational change to the pore).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	310	 To distinguish between these two possibilities, for each CFTR construct we measured macroscopic currents in large patches containing many channels, and compared the current magnitude during a test exposure to 50  microM MgATP with that obtained at 2 mM MgATP, just before and after the test (Fig 11).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	311	 The ratio of these currents (I50 microM/I2mM) provides a rough measure of apparent affinity for ATP because, for all constructs, 2 mM MgATP proved to be a saturating concentration; thus, I1mM/I2mM ratios were 1.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	312	03 for Flag3-432+433-1480, and 1.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	313	 Both the representative macroscopic current records for each of these constructs and the bar graph summary (Fig 11) show that the I50 microM/I2mM ratios were all very similar and close to 0.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	314	5, indicating that K1/2(ATP) for activation of Po (since the time-averaged number of active channels may be assumed constant during these bracketed measurements) was ~50  microM for all these constructs.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	315	 Hence, the observed reduction in Po after addition of the Flag epitope to the NH2 terminus of CFTR (Fig 9) is likely to reflect slowing of a rate-limiting step after ATP binding.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	316	View larger version (26K):    Figure 11.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	317	 Apparent affinities for activation of channel Po by MgATP.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	318	 Representative macropatch currents are shown for WT and Flag-WT (A), 1-633+634-1480 and Flag3-633+634-1480 (B), 1-432+433-1480 and Flag3-432+433-1480 (C), and Flag3-414+433-1480 (D) channels.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	319	 After prephosphorylation by PKA, and removal of both PKA and ATP, once all channels had closed, 50  microM ATP was applied for 10 to 30 s, bracketed between exposures to 2 mM ATP.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	320	 (E) The ratios of the mean steady currents, I50 microM/I2mM, were 0.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	321	 None of the constructs differed significantly from WT at P  <  0.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	322	Deletion of aa's 415 to 432 in CFTR Does Not Alter the Apparent Affinity for ATP The demonstration that effective deletion of aa's 415 to 432, by coexpression of segments Flag3-414 and 433-1480, impairs CFTR channel activity very little, if at all (Fig 3), has ramifications for our understanding of the relationship between the structure of these channels and their function.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	323	 This is because residues 415-432 in CFTR align (Fig 12, below) with those comprising the first ss strand in the recently solved high-resolution structures of HisP, the NBD of histidine permease (from Salmonella typhimurium; Hung et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	324	 1998 ), and of the NH2-terminal NBD in RbsA, which incorporates the two NBDs of the ribose transporter (from Escherichia coli; Armstrong et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	325	 Although the sequences of these three NBDs (NBD1 of CFTR, NH2-terminal NBD of RbsA, and HisP) share only on the order of 20% identity, largely restricted to the highly conserved ABC signature sequence and to the Walker A and B sequences (Walker et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	326	 1982 ), because the latter both contribute to the active site, and yet are separated by ~140 residues in HisP, this large distance strongly constrains alignments of different NBD sequences (Hung et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	327	 Moreover, despite the small degree of identity, the catalytic site architectures of HisP and RbsA are closely similar: both resemble an open cup, formed by a broken ss-barrel, within which the nucleotide binds (Hung et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	328	 In both crystal structures, a conserved aromatic residue, Tyr16 in HisP and Phe14 in RbsA, located at the end of the first ss strand (Fig 12, below), makes extensive hydrophobic contact with the adenine base of the bound nucleotide and, at least in HisP, seems crucial for nucleotide binding (Shyamala et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	329	 Depending on the alignment, the corresponding residue in NBD1 of CFTR is likely to be Leu435 (Fig 12, below; compare Hung et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	330	 Insofar as the structure of NBD1 in CFTR resembles those of HisP and RbsA, the deletion of aa's 415 to 432 may be expected to remove the entire first ss strand, which, in turn, through its proximity to Phe433 and Leu435, would be anticipated to influence nucleotide binding.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	331	 To see whether this deletion affects the apparent affinity for ATP activation of channel Po, we measured the ratio I50 microM/I2mM for Flag3-414+433-1480 CFTR channels in macropatches (Fig 11).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	332	 This ratio was found to be close to 0.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	333	5 for Flag3-414+433-1480 channels, the same value as observed for WT (as well as all the other CFTR constructs tested in Fig 11).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	334	 Since, in one experiment, I1mM/I2mM was 1.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	335	02 in a macropatch of Flag3-414+433-1480 channels, we may conclude that K1/2 (ATP) was ~50  microM for these channels also.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	336	View larger version (22K):    Figure 12.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	337	 Alignment of CFTR's NBD1 with HisP.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	338	 PSI-Blast aligned CFTR residues 422 to 637 with corresponding residues in HisP.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	339	 Secondary structure elements shown below (ss-strands, magenta arrows; -helices, orange boxes) correspond to those of the solved crystal structure of HisP (Hung et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	340	 CFTR residue numbers are centered above the corresponding letters.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	341	 Teal boxes identify the three consensus sequences conserved in most ABC proteins.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	342	 Red boxes in the CFTR sequence identify nontolerated, green boxes tolerated, cut sites.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	343	 (Cuts occurred between the two highlighted residues in each case.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	344	) Gray boxes identify sections flanking the NBD1 sequence that could be omitted without destroying channel function.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	345	  DISCUSSION Top Abstract INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION Acknowledgements References.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	346	In this work, we have demonstrated that physical and functional association of complementary segments of CFTR, severed just before or after NBD1, results in split channels with microscopic properties closely similar to those of intact WT CFTR.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	347	 Further, by systematically shifting the sever point, we have been able to define the domain boundaries of NBD1 to within 10 to 15 amino acids.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	348	 The newly defined boundaries have important ramifications for structural and functional studies of CFTR's NBDs, whether as isolated polypeptides or in their native state, incorporated into full-length CFTR.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	349	That a severed membrane transport protein may nevertheless function has been demonstrated previously.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	350	 coli cells expressing both putative hexahelical halves of lac permease, severed within its central cytoplasmic loop, transport lactose at about one third the rate of cells expressing intact permease, but no transport is seen in cells expressing either half alone (Bibi and Kaback 1990 ).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	351	 Similarly, coexpression in Xenopus oocytes of up to three complementary segments (severed within cytoplasmic or extracellular loops) comprising the full-length human erythrocyte anion exchanger (band 3, or AE1) resulted in Cl- influx levels comparable with those observed after expression of intact WT band 3 (Groves et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	352	 Although the domain organization of band 3 is not yet known, it is remarkable that the protein backbone can be cut at at least four sever points (and at at least two of them simultaneously) with little detectable loss of Cl- transport function.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	353	 It is perhaps less surprising that a known multidomain protein like the voltage-gated Na channel, which has four repeats, each with six putative membrane-spanning helices, can still function with a single cut between two repeats (at least, in two of the three linking loops; Stuhmer et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	354	 Eukaryotic ABC transporters are also multidomain proteins with homologous internal repeats, a consequence of their evolution from prokaryotic ancestors in which the individual domains are often expressed from separate genes (e.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	355	 So it is not surprising that ABC molecules such as the yeast a-factor transporter, STE6, can also function when coexpressed as two separate halves (Berkower and Michaelis 1991 ), nor that coimmunoprecipitation experiments demonstrate that those two halves physically interact (Berkower et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	356	 Representatives of the two families of multidrug-resistance ABC proteins, Pgp (Loo and Clarke 1994 ) and MRP (Gao et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	357	 1996 ) have also been shown to survive being cut in half, between NBD1 and the second transmembrane domain, and to retain at least partial function: severed MRP transported substrate at least a third as well as intact MRP (a fraction possibly simply reflecting the efficiency of simultaneous transfection of the insect cells used; Gao et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	358	 1996 ), whereas severed Pgp supported substrate-induced ATPase activity about half that of intact Pgp, but showed no sign of drug transport in NIH-3T3 cells, possibly due to defective trafficking to the cell membrane (Loo and Clarke 1994 ).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	359	 Physical and functional association between NH2- and COOH-terminal halves of CFTR (residues 1-835 and 837-1480; cut after the R domain) was demonstrated by Ostedgaard et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	360	 1997 , who found that the severed construct supported intracellular cAMP-activated anion fluxes, assayed by measurements of SPQ fluorescence, that were comparable with those of WT CFTR.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	361	Assaying the function of severed molecules to define domain boundaries is an approach well suited to multidomain, single-gene eukaryotic ABC transporters, because individual domains may each correspond to the product of a single ancestral gene and may therefore reasonably be expected to be capable of folding separately.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	362	 Indeed, there are already several examples of putative links between domains of such eukaryotic ABC proteins being severed without destroying the molecule's overall function (as described above).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	363	 In general, if severing the backbone of a protein does not detectably impair its function, it is reasonable to conclude that covalent linkage at that point is not required for the assayed function.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	364	 It may further be concluded either that the cut occurs between functional domains, or that the sever point lies within such a domain but the native fold and function are nevertheless retained (Shiba and Schimmel 1992 ; Betton and Hofnung 1994 ).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	365	 However, the latter possibility becomes far less likely if function remains intact when a substantial deletion is introduced on one side or the other of the sever point.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	366	 That was precisely our finding when we effectively deleted the 18-residue segment 415-432 (by coexpressing Flag3-414 plus 433-1480; Fig 3) from the NH2-proximal side of NBD1, or the 34-residue segment 634-667 (by coexpressing Flag3-633 plus 668-1480; Fig 2) from the COOH-proximal side of NBD1 (Fig 12, gray).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	367	 In contrast, we could detect neither function nor mature protein when we simply introduced a single cut (Fig 12, red) only 16 or 11 residues away from those deletions, respectively, but in the direction of the conserved core of the domain.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	368	 Therefore, the domain boundaries of NBD1 of CFTR, as defined by the assays of microscopic function used here, can be confidently assigned to lie within residues 433 to 448 and 623 to 633 at the NH2 and COOH termini of NBD1, respectively.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	369	In the present work, we have made detailed single-channel measurements that show that individual severed CFTR channels, cut just before (1-432 plus 433-1480) or after (1-633 plus 634-1480) NBD1, have the same unitary conductance as WT CFTR channels (Fig 10) and almost identical microscopic gating characteristics in the presence of PKA catalytic subunit (Fig 9).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	370	 Both severed constructs had the same opening rate as WT channels, and the same apparent affinity for activation of channel Po by MgATP, and both were locked open by PPi (Fig 8) or AMPPNP.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	371	 Only the closing rate of channels cut after NBD1 differed from that of WT, and was ~40% faster, indicating that the bursting state is somewhat destabilized by that cut, due to a slight acceleration of the rate-limiting step for channel closing (likely reflecting speeding of the slowest step in the ATP hydrolysis cycle at NBD2; Csanady et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	372	 Thus, we can conclude that the normal gating function of NBD1 (which we and others infer to be control of channel opening; for reviews, see, e.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	373	, Csanady and Gadsby 1999 ; Gadsby and Nairn 1999 ) does not depend on its covalent linkage either to the first transmembrane domain or to the R domain, since the maximal opening rates are the same for intact channels as for channels cut before or after NBD1 (Fig 9).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	374	 Nor does channel opening require segments 415-432 (Fig 3 and Fig 11) or 634-667 (Fig 2).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	375	 On the other hand, we found a consistent and significant effect of incorporating the eight-residue Flag tag at the NH2 terminus of CFTR, which reproducibly slowed channel opening approximately two- to threefold, resulting in an approximately two- to threefold reduction in Po for both severed and intact constructs, without affecting the mean burst duration, conductance, or locking of any of the channels.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	376	 It is notable that attaching the 238-residue green fluorescent protein (GFP) to the NH2 terminus of CFTR was found to affect neither single-channel conductance (assayed in bilayers) nor macroscopic whole-cell conductance in transfected NIH-3T3 cells (Moyer et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	377	 But it remains unclear whether channel Po was affected by the large GFP tag, because the bilayer experiments did not address channel number or gating kinetics, and no comparison was made between the levels of CFTR protein expressed in cells transfected with WT CFTR and those transfected with GFP-CFTR.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	378	 Interestingly, an interaction between an acidic region of CFTR's NH2-terminal cytoplasmic tail and the R domain was recently demonstrated, which stabilized the open state of the channel (Naren et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	379	 1999 ); disrupting the interaction by mutating the acidic residues resulted in shorter bursts.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	380	 It is not yet clear whether, or how, that finding relates to our observation here that incorporation of the largely acidic Flag at the NH2 terminus of CFTR stabilized the channel closed state (both for intact and severed channels).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	381	 We have found, however, that this effect is also mediated via the R domain, since addition of an NH2-terminal Flag does not alter the opening rate of severed CFTR channels from which the entire R domain (aa's 634 to 836) is missing (Csanady, L.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	382	 Gadsby, manuscript submitted for publication).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	383	None of the half-molecule constructs gave measurable basal or activated Cl- conductance in two-microelectrode recordings of macroscopic currents, regardless of whether the oocytes were expressing the NH2-terminal half with (construct Flag3-835; not illustrated) or without (Flag3-633; Fig 4) the R domain, or the COOH-terminal half with (CFTR construct 634-1480; Fig 4) or without (construct 837-1480; not illustrated) the R domain.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	384	 However, because we did not record from patches excised from those oocytes, we cannot rule out the possibility that an extremely low density of channels might be formed from certain half molecules.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	385	 Our macroscopic current results contrast with a recent report that expression of only the COOH-terminal half of CFTR, either with or without the R domain, gave macroscopic, intracellular cAMP-activated, whole-cell currents in injected oocytes and in transfected IB3 cells, as well as unitary currents activated by PKA and ATP in patches excised from the IB3 cells (Devidas et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	386	 Although a major procedural difference was the injection of 50 ng cRNA per construct in those experiments (vs.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	387	5 ng in ours), it seems unlikely that protein expression was correspondingly high because the activated conductance of WT CFTR was only 10  microS (Devidas et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	388	 1998 ), more than 20-fold smaller than the average in the present experiments (Fig 1 Fig 2 Fig 3, Table 1).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	389	 1994 did observe channel currents in patches excised from HeLa cells expressing just the NH2-terminal half of CFTR truncated after the R domain (segment 1-835), though channel formation was far less efficient than for WT CFTR, which presumably accounts for the fact that no change in SPQ fluorescence could be detected when the same cells were challenged with cAMP-elevating cocktail (Ostedgaard et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	390	How do the boundaries of CFTR's NBD1 that we have functionally defined here compare with the crystal structures of the HisP and RbsA NBDs, whose close similarity to each other supports their being considered reasonable models for the structure of all ABC NBDs, including those of CFTR? Although the safe boundaries of CFTR's NBD1 (433-633) circumscribe only 200 residues, whereas the crystallized NBDs of HisP and RbsA included 259 and 241 residues, respectively, they still compare reasonably well because alignments (e.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	391	 1998 ) indicate that NBD1 of CFTR lacks a stretch of 20 to 30 amino acids present in the other NBDs.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	392	 Moreover, the safe sever points can be rationalized on the basis of such alignments.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	393	 Thus, Phe433 would be predicted to occur near the end of the first ss strand (Fig 12), some distance from the -phosphate of bound ATP (although nearby Leu435, if not Phe433 itself, is implicated in binding of the nucleotide base; see Hung et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	394	 1998 ), and Leu633 would be expected to occur after the final ss strand in the NBD structure, between it and a pair of final helices (arranged slightly differently in HisP and RbsA).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	395	 In contrast, the nontolerated sever point Glu449 occurs just before a highly conserved glycine that in HisP and RbsA begins a ss strand at the center of the ss sheet that forms the major wall of the active site, where severing might be anticipated to disrupt its structure.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	396	 At the COOH terminus, Gly622 is predicted to lie in the loop connecting the last two (antiparallel) ss strands of that large ss sheet, where severing might perturb stabilizing interactions between those two strands.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	397	 Overall, that the structures of HisP and RbsA afford reasonable interpretations of our results with NBD1 of CFTR supports the notion that the NBDs of all ABC transporters are likely to share the same general fold.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	398	 If so, our findings have importance for the design of peptide models of CFTR's NBDs and imply, for instance, that CFTR NBD1 constructs truncated at or near residue 589 would be structurally incomplete and hence functionally disadvantaged (see Hartman et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	399	 1992 ; Ko and Pedersen 1995 ; Ko et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	400	 1998 ), as might CFTR NBD2 constructs truncated at Leu1399 (corresponding to NBD1 Leu602; Randak et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	401	The finding that severed CFTR channels lacking residues 415-432 (i.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	402	, coexpressed Flag3-414 plus 433-1480) are opened by MgATP with the same apparent affinity as seen for WT CFTR channels (K1/2 ~ 50  microM; Fig 11) is intriguing.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	403	 This is because a number of observations have suggested that it is binding of ATP at NBD1 (and possibly hydrolysis of that ATP) that is responsible for CFTR channel opening (reviewed in Csanady and Gadsby 1999 ; Gadsby and Nairn 1999 ).
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	404	 For example, CFTR 1-835 channels, truncated after the R domain and hence lacking NBD2, are opened by MgATP with micromolar apparent affinity (Sheppard et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	405	 1994 ), and CFTR 1-1218 channels, also lacking NBD2, yield large currents in whole oocytes and robust channel gating in excised patches (Chan et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	406	 Moreover, mutant K1250A CFTR channels, in which ATP hydrolysis at NBD2 is severely impaired (Ramjeesingh et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	407	 1999 ), show brief WT-like openings at low micromolar [ATP], but extremely long openings at higher [ATP] that reflect binding at NBD2 of ATP that cannot be hydrolyzed (Zeltwanger et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	408	 1999 ); those results imply that the brief openings at low [ATP] involve only NBD1.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	409	 It is, nevertheless, possible that the binding site responsible for channel opening is not formed entirely by NBD1.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	410	 If the relatively high affinity action of MgATP to open CFTR channels does indeed occur at NBD1 even in Flag3-414 plus 433-1480 channels, then our findings prompt a new series of questions.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	411	 Thus, despite an overall similarity in the organization of the NBDs of all ABC transporters, perhaps the detailed structure of the nucleotide binding pocket of NBD1 in CFTR differs from that of HisP or RbsA? Or, perhaps the detailed structures are similar, but our expectations of the consequences of deleting the ss strand formed by residues 415-432 are unwarranted? Alternatively, perhaps substantial contributions to the binding energy for MgATP at NBD1 are made by other regions of the CFTR polypeptide, such as NBD2 (e.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	412	, Jones and George 1999 ) or cytoplasmic loops from the transmembrane domains (e.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	413	 1997 )? Point mutations at residues believed to lie in or near the catalytic sites of CFTR's NBDs, chosen on the basis of the HisP and RbsA structures, should soon help resolve some of these questions (compare Vergani et al.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	414	1 Abbreviations used in this paper: aa, amino acid; ABC, ATP-binding cassette; ER, endoplasmic reticulum; MRP, multi-drug resistance-related protein; NBD, nucleotide binding domain; Pgp, P-glycoprotein; PPi, pyrophosphate; R domain, regulatory domain.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	415	  Acknowledgements Top Abstract INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION Acknowledgements References.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	416	We thank Roberto Sanchez and Andrej Sali for help with alignments and for structural modeling, David Kopsco and Atsuko Horiuchi for technical assistance, and Kate Hall, Peter Hoff, and Paola Vergani for help with the manuscript and figures.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	417	 Csanady is a William O'Baker Graduate Fellow of The Rockefeller University.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	418	 This work was supported by National Institutes of Health grant DK-51767.
0.43467933.10919864.html.plaintext.txt	419	Luis Reuss served as guest editor.
