0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	0	Efficient Intracellular Processing of the Endogenous Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator in Epithelial Cell Lines* Karoly Varga, Asta Jurkuvenaite, John Wakefield , Jeong S.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Venglarik, Ashutosh Niraj, Marina Mazur, Eric J.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	2	From the Departments of Cell Biology, **Medicine, ||Genetics and Gregory Fleming James Cystic Fibrosis Research Center, University of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, Alabama 35294 and the  Tranzyme Corporation, Birmingham, Alabama 35209.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	3	Received for publication, February 11, 2004 , and in revised form, March 22, 2004.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	4	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   The cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) is a cAMP-dependent protein kinase A-activated chloride channel that resides on the apical surface of epithelial cells.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	5	 One unusual feature of this protein is that during biogenesis, 75% of wild type CFTR is degraded by the endoplasmic reticulum (ER)-associated degradative (ERAD) pathway.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Examining the biogenesis and structural instability of the molecule has been technically challenging due to the limited amount of CFTR expressed in epithelia.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Consequently, investigators have employed heterologous overexpression systems.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Based on recent results that epithelial specific factors regulate both CFTR biogenesis and function, we hypothesized that CFTR biogenesis in endogenous CFTR expressing epithelial cells may be more efficient.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	9	 To test this, we compared CFTR biogenesis in two epithelial cell lines endogenously expressing CFTR (Calu-3 and T84) with two heterologous expression systems (COS-7 and HeLa).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Consistent with previous reports, 20 and 35% of the newly synthesized CFTR were converted to maturely glycosylated CFTR in COS-7 and HeLa cells, respectively.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	11	 In contrast, CFTR maturation was virtually 100% efficient in Calu-3 and T84 cells.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Furthermore, inhibition of the proteasome had no effect on CFTR biogenesis in Calu-3 cells, whereas it stabilized the immature form of CFTR in HeLa cells.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Quantitative reverse transcriptase-PCR indicated that CFTR message levels are 4-fold lower in Calu-3 than HeLa cells, yet steady-state protein levels are comparable.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Our results question the structural instability model of wild type CFTR and indicate that epithelial cells endogenously expressing CFTR efficiently process this protein to post-Golgi compartments.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	15	   INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Newly synthesized proteins entering the secretory pathway are carefully monitored by the ER1 quality control machinery to ensure that only correctly folded molecules exit and continue their journey to the cell surface.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Misfolded membrane and secretory proteins are promptly recognized as such and degraded by the ER-associated degradation pathway (ERAD; reviewed in (1, 2).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Understanding this process is critical, since a number of diseases, including cystic fibrosis, congenital hypothyrosis, and familial hypercholesterolemia are caused by protein folding defects that often arise from missense or deletion mutations (3, 4).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Despite the fact that many of these mutations result in the production of proteins that retain some biological activity, they are rapidly degraded by ERAD, preventing proper targeting of the proteins to their biologically relevant destinations (reviewed in Ref.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	19	Interestingly, inefficient protein biogenesis appears to occur even for "wild type" proteins, with a number of examples that include the epithelial sodium channels (6), Shaker-type potassium channels (7), major histocompatibility complex class II molecules (8), the opioid receptor (9, 10), the erythropoietin receptor (11), the erythrocyte anion exchanger 1 (Band 3) (12), and CFTR (13).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Many of these proteins, including CFTR, are assembled in the cell membrane as part of a multiprotein complex (14, 15), suggesting that the molecular rationing of the components in these complexes might be regulated during biogenesis.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	21	CFTR is a large transmembrane glycoprotein consisting of two homologous halves, each containing six transmembrane segments (TMD1 and TMD2) and a nucleotide-binding domain (NBD1 and NBD2), that are connected by a regulatory domain (16).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	22	 The 1480-amino acid protein is a member of the traffic ATPase or ATP binding cassette (ABC) transporter family (17) and functions as a cAMP-regulated Cl- channel (18, 19) that regulates other ion conductive pathways including epithelial Cl-, Na+, and ATP transport (20-22).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	23	 The most common mutation in CFTR, F508, results in the production of a protein that fails to exit the ER (13) and is rapidly degraded by ERAD (23-25).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Interestingly, even the wild type protein is substrate for ERAD, with as much as 75% being degraded by the proteasome during biogenesis (13, 24, 25).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Since only a small fraction of newly synthesized wild type CFTR reaches the cell surface where it performs its biological function, the question has often arisen as to why CFTR biogenesis so inefficient.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	26	 A study by Tector and Hartl (26) suggested the possibility that transmembrane segment 6 in TMD1 is unstable due to 3 charged residues within this domain.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Substitution of these residues with non-charged amino acids resulted in an increase in protein stability but a loss of chloride transport (26), suggesting that protein stability had been compromised for biological function.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	28	 This hypothesis has not been evaluated in cells endogenously expressing CFTR.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	29	It has been suggested that an appropriate cellular context may be necessary to support proper membrane protein trafficking (reviewed in Refs.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	30	 In addition, it is possible that altered protein trafficking may result from the use of overexpression systems or non-physiological experimental conditions (reviewed in Bertrand et al.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Given that the initial studies of CFTR biogenesis were performed primarily in transfected, heterologous overexpression systems, a careful analysis of endogenous CFTR biogenesis both in the early (ER) and post-Golgi pathways is warranted.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Heterologous systems may lack CFTR binding partners such as EBP50, syntaxin 1A, and CAL (15, 29-33), and association of these and other proteins with CFTR may be required for proper maturation and/or trafficking.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	33	In the present studies, we monitored the maturation efficiency of CFTR in two human epithelial cell lines that endogenously expresses CFTR, Calu-3 (34), and T84 cells (35).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Metabolic pulse-chase analysis of CFTR in these cells grown under both nonpolarizing and polarizing conditions indicated that core glycosylated (Band B) CFTR is very efficiently (100%) processed to a maturely glycosylated (Band C) protein that is extremely stable.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Moreover, quantitative cell surface biotinylation assays revealed that the CFTR surface pool is substantially elevated in Calu-3 cells compared with heterologous expression systems.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Thus, endogenous CFTR maturation differs fundamentally from the patterns reported in recombinant overexpression systems, and these differences extend across multiple cellular compartments.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Our findings cast doubt upon the viewpoint that wild type CFTR protein maturation is inefficient.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	38	   MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Cell Lines and Culture Conditions COS-7, Calu-3, and T84 cells were obtained from the ATCC (www.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	39	org) and maintained in the Cystic Fibrosis Research Center at University of Alabama at Birmingham.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	40	 HeLa cells overexpressing wild type CFTR were transduced and selected as previously described (36, 37), cultured in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (Invitrogen) with 10% FBS at 37  degrees C in a humidified incubator in 5% CO2.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	41	 For cell monolayers, Calu-3 cells were seeded on 6.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	42	5- or 12-mm diameter Transwell filters (Corning-Costar, Corning, NY).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	43	 After 2-3 days, the medium containing 10% FBS was exchanged to 2% FBS containing media, and cells were cultured for an additional 7-9 days with liquid both at the apical and the basolateral compartments.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Under these conditions, the cells formed monolayers with trans-epithelial resistances of  > 800  cm2.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	45	Transient Transfection of COS-7 Cells COS-7 cells were transiently transfected using LipofectAMINE PLUS reagent (Invitrogen) according to the manufacturer's protocol.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Transfected cells were cultured for 24-48 h before analysis as described previously (38).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	47	Immunoprecipitation of CFTR CFTR was immunoprecipitated using the 24-1 anti-C-terminal antibody (ATCC number HB-11947) (38) and phosphorylated with [-32P]ATP (PerkinElmer Life Sciences) and cAMP-dependent protein kinase (Promega).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Labeled CFTR was analyzed by SDS-PAGE and autoradiography as described previously (39).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	49	Metabolic Pulse-Chase One hour before addition of radiolabeled amino acids, the tissue culture medium was replaced with methionine/cysteine-free minimal essential medium.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	50	 After 1 h of methionine starvation at 37  degrees C, 300  microCi/ml EasyTag Protein Labeling Mixture ([35S]methionine/cysteine, PerkinElmer Life Sciences) was added, and cells were pulse-labeled for 30 min (for the maturation studies) or 60 min (for protein half-life analysis).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	51	 The radioactive medium was then exchanged with cold, complete medium and cultured for various chase periods.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Cells were lysed at the time points indicated and CFTR was immunoprecipitated using the 24-1 monoclonal antibody and protein A+G-agarose (Roche Diagnostics).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Immunoprecipitated samples were analyzed by SDS-PAGE (6% gels) and detected using autoradiography (PhosphorImager, Amersham Biosciences).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Calculation of protein half-lives was performed as described by Straley et al.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Maturation efficiency was measured by comparing the density of the labeled Band B to the density of the fully glycosylated band C using IPLab software (Scanalytics, Inc.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	56	Cell Surface Biotinylation Cell surface glycoproteins were biotinylated as described previously (38).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Total CFTR and biotinylated CFTR was immunoprecipitated and in vitro phosphorylated using [-32P]ATP (PerkinElmer Life Sciences) and PKA catalytic subunit (Promega), separated by SDS-PAGE, and detected using autoradiography and PhorphorImager analysis as described previously (38).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Biotinylation efficiency was tested by comparing transferrin receptor 125I binding assay with the biotinylated fraction of the transferrin receptor.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	59	 The efficiency of the cell surface biotinylation in the experiments presented was 75  plus or minus  4%.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	60	Semiquantitative RT-PCR Total RNA was isolated from each filter using RNeasy mini kit (Qiagen).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	61	 RNA concentration was calculated based on the absorbance of samples at 260 nm.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	62	 One tube from the RT-PCR kit (Qiagen) was used to amplify the CFTR mRNA using 1 ng of total RNA as templates.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The primers were designed to anneal to two different exons (exon 10 and exon 11) to prevent possible amplification from genomic DNA and pre-mRNA.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	64	 The sequences of the primers were 5' ACTTCACTTCTAATGATGAT 3'(exon-10F1) and 5' AAAACATCTAGGTATCCAA 3'(exon-11R).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Two primers specific for GAPDH were used as controls for each sample (42).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	66	 RT-PCR was performed as instructed by manufacturer.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	67	 The number of PCR cycles for this experiment was experimentally determined (28 cycles) to allow semiquantification of PCR products during the log-linear phase of amplification.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	68	 RNA samples isolated from CFTR-negative HeLa cells were used as control to assure the specificity of the PCR product.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	69	 The specificity of the GAPDH primers were previously tested (42).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Controls with no template or reverse transcriptase were also included.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Experiments were repeated two times.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	72	Fluorescence-based Kinetic Real-time PCR Isolated RNA samples were also analyzed by fluorescence-based kinetic real-time PCR using the ABI PRISM 7900 Sequence Detection System as described previously for other genes (43).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	73	 One-step RT-PCR was performed on serial dilutions of RNA isolates using Master Mix Reagent kit and Assay-on-Demand Gene Expression Probes (Applied Biosystems, CFTR Assay ID: HS00357011_m1).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	74	 6-Carboxylfluorescein was chosen as reporter dye at the 5'-end of the probe and minor groove binder as the quencher at the 3'-end.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	75	 The 5' nuclease activity of Taq DNA polymerase cleaves the probe and generates a fluorescent signal proportional to the amount of starting target template.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Each reporter signal is then divided by the fluorescence of an internal reference dye 5-carboxy-X-rhodamine, to normalize for non-PCR-related fluorescence.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	77	 The TaqMan RT-PCR reaction was performed in a final volume of 20  microl containing 0.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	78	5  microl of RNA, 10  microl of TaqMan One-step RT-PCR master mix (Applied Biosystems), 0.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	79	5  microl of Multiscribe/RNase inhibitor, and 1  microl of 20x primer/probe set for CFTR and/or 18 S rRNA as endogenous control.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Six 10-fold serial dilutions (100-10-6) of RNA samples isolated from the models cell lines were amplified in duplicates using CFTR and/or 18 S endogenous control.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Data were exported from the ABI Prism 7900SDS software into Microsoft Excel where relative standard curves were plotted.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Using the Excel Trendline option, a line of best fit was plotted.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Data from each cell line were analyzed based on these standard curves and relative quantities were extrapolated.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	84	 CFTR values were normalized to 18 S by dividing the CFTR values by the corresponding 18 S values from the same sample according to the Applied Biosystems relative quantification method.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	85	 The specificity and quality of the primers is assured by ABI.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Appropriate controls with no RNA, primers, or reverse transcriptase were included in each set of experiments.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	87	Microscopy Indirect immunofluorescence was performed as described previously (41).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	88	Statistical Analysis Results were expressed as means  plus or minus  S.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Statistical significance among means was determined using the Student's t test (two samples).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	90	   RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Calu-3 Cells Express High Levels of CFTR Compared with Heterologous Expression Systems To compare CFTR biogenesis in heterologous versus endogenous expression systems, we first determined the relative amounts of CFTR in transiently transfected COS-7 cells, in HeLa cells stably expressing CFTR, and in cells that endogenously express CFTR, Calu-3 cells.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	91	 COS-7 cells represent a common cell type that has been used extensively to study CFTR biogenesis (13, 38, 44), while HeLa (45) and Calu-3 cells (15, 41, 46, 47) were selected based on their stable, high expression levels of wild type CFTR.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	92	To compare CFTR expression levels in the model cell lines, CFTR was immunoprecipitated from 250  microg of total cellular protein under standardized conditions.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Relative amounts of CFTR expressed in each cell type were calculated based on densitometry and are shown in Fig.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	94	 In COS-7 cells, CFTR expression levels are dependent upon transfection efficiency, while in HeLa and Calu-3 cells, the expression levels were consistently high.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Since the relative expression level in Calu-3 cells was similar to HeLa cells stably expressing wild type CFTR, we selected Calu-3 cells for the initial analysis.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	96	View larger version (14K):    FIG.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	97	 A, steady-state wild type CFTR protein level is high in Calu-3 cells.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	98	 In transfected COS-7 cells, wild type CFTR expression levels were analyzed 48 h after transfection.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	99	 HeLa cells stably expressing CFTR, and Calu-3 cells endogenously expressing the protein, were grown under standard conditions and tested at 80% confluence.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	100	 CFTR was immunoprecipitated from 250  microg of total protein from each cell type using an anti-CFTR C-terminal monoclonal antibody, 24-1.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Immunoprecipitated CFTR was in vitro phosphorylated with protein kinase A and [-32P]ATP and analyzed by SDS-PAGE and autoradiography.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	102	 A representative gel of four is shown (upper panel).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	103	 The relative amounts of wild type CFTR expressed in each of the cell lines were calculated based on densitometry (lower panel).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	104	 The averages  plus or minus  S.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	105	 were calculated from four independent experiments.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	106	 B, CFTR mRNA levels are significantly lower in Calu-3 cells than in HeLa cells.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	107	 CFTR message levels in HeLa and Calu-3 cells were tested using semiquantitative RT-PCR using GAPDH as control (upper panel, representative gel is shown) and TaqMan quantitative PCR using 18 S rRNA as control (lower panel).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Results are plotted as CFTR mRNA levels relative to 18 S rRNA, mean and S.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	109	 of four separate samples amplified under the same condition.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	110	 In contrast to slightly lower CFTR protein levels, CFTR message levels are 4-fold higher in HeLa cells.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	111	  The simplest explanation for high CFTR levels both in HeLa and Calu-3 cells is that they have similar CFTR mRNA levels, protein synthetic rates, and stability.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	112	 To compare CFTR mRNA levels in HeLa and Calu-3 cells, we developed a semiquantitative RT-PCR using GAPDH as an internal control.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	113	 1B, while GAPDH message levels are similar, CFTR message levels are significantly higher in HeLa cells than in Calu-3 (in contrast to rather similar protein levels (Fig.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	114	 To further assess these differences, we also performed TaqMan Quantitative PCR (Fig.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	115	 The results of the real-time experiments establish that CFTR message levels in HeLa cells are 3.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	116	5-fold higher than in Calu-3 cells.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	117	 These findings imply that the high steady-state levels of CFTR in Calu-3 cells must be due to increased translational rate, increased maturation efficiency, extended protein half-life, or some combination of these effects.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	118	CFTR Maturation and Protein Stability Are Enhanced in Calu-3 Cells To monitor CFTR maturation efficiency and protein half-life in Calu-3 cells and compare these values to previously reported results, we performed metabolic pulse-chase experiments and followed CFTR maturation in COS-7, HeLa, and Calu-3 cells.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	119	 In these experiments, we compared the amount of the newly synthesized Band B CFTR and its conversion to the fully glycosylated Band C CFTR in each cell type.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	120	 The results indicate that significantly more CFTR was synthesized in COS-7 and HeLa cells than in Calu-3 cells, as was first described by Cheng et al.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	121	 The conversion of the immaturely glycosylated CFTR to the maturely glycosylated form was extremely inefficient, with 27  plus or minus  7.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	122	; n = 7) maturation efficiency in COS-7 cells and 39  plus or minus  5.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	123	 In contrast, while the amount of the newly synthesized Band B form of CFTR was the lowest in Calu-3 cells, the maturation efficiency was 92.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	124	4  plus or minus  8% (n = 11) after 4 h (Fig.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	125	 These results indicate that although less CFTR was being produced in Calu-3 cells, the protein was processed much more efficiently to the mature form.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Furthermore, comparing the total densities of Band B and Band C CFTR over the 4-h chase indicated that the total densities remain constant.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	127	 This suggests that there is no early degradation, and all newly synthesized Band B is converted into Band C, and that the maturation only reaches maximum after 4 h of the pulse.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	128	View larger version (25K):    FIG.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	129	 CFTR maturation is efficient in Calu-3 cells.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	130	 COS-7, HeLa, and Calu-3 cells were pulse-labeled with 300 mCi/ml 35S-labeled amino acids (EasyTag Protein Labeling Mixture, PerkinElmer Life Sciences).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	131	 After the pulse, the [35S]methionine/cysteine-containing medium was replaced with complete medium.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Cells were lysed at the time points specified, and CFTR was immunoprecipitated with anti-CFTR 24-1 antibody.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Samples were separated by SDS-PAGE on 6% gels and analyzed using a Phosphorimager (Amersham Biosciences).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	134	 CFTR maturation efficiency was measured by comparing the density of labeled band B (100%) after a 30-min pulse to the density of Band C after 4 h of chase using IPLab software.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	135	 A, average maturation efficiencies at the end of a 4-h chase in each cell line tested.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Results are plotted as percent of newly synthesized Band B converted to Band C by the end of a 4-h chase (average + S.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	137	 B, representative pulse-chase experiments are shown for each cell line (left panels).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Arrows indicate the core (Band B) and fully glycosylated (Band C) CFTR.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Average disappearance of Band B (maturation and/or degradation) and formation of Band C at each time point (right panels).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Disappearance of Band B (diamonds) and formation of Band C (squares) were calculated based on densitometry at each chase time point.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Results are plotted as percent of band B density at the 0 time point (average + S.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	142	  To test whether increased CFTR maturation efficiency alone is responsible for high CFTR levels in Calu-3 cells, we determined the half-life of the fully glycosylated CFTR in each cell line.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Using a more extended chase period in the metabolic labeling experiments, we found that CFTR half-lives were 10.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	144	 The results indicate that CFTR is more stable in Calu-3 cells compared with heterologous cells.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Therefore, more efficient CFTR maturation and elongated protein half-lives contribute to the high steady state CFTR levels in these cells.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	146	View larger version (31K):    FIG.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	147	 CFTR half-life is longer in Calu-3 cells compared with heterologous expression systems.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	148	 In COS-7 cells, CFTR half-lives were tested 24 h after transfection and in HeLa and Calu-3 cells 24 h after seeding.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	149	 After a 1-h pulse with [35S]methionine (EasyTag Protein Labeling Mixture) and the indicated chase periods in complete medium, the cells were lysed in radioimmune precipitation assay buffer and CFTR was immunoprecipitated and analyzed as described above.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	150	 A, average CFTR half-lives were monitored by densitometry (n = number of experiments).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Calculation of the protein half-lives was performed as described by Straley et al.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	152	 B, representative gels for CFTR half-life measurements are shown below for each of the cell types.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	153	  ERAD of CFTR Is Insignificant in Calu-3 Cells Early degradation of wild type CFTR by the proteasome has been described as a common feature of CFTR biogenesis (23, 25, 48).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Because CFTR maturation approaches 100% efficiency in Calu-3 cells, we hypothesized that the disappearance of Band B CFTR in these cells is clearly the result of maturation and not degradation by the proteasome.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	155	 To test this possibility, we compared the effects of two proteasome inhibitors (ALLN (50  microM) (48) and clasto-lactacystin--lactone (10  microM) (49)) on the half-lives of Band B CFTR in HeLa and Calu-3 cells.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	156	 4, while 50  microM ALLN caused a significant increase in the half-life of Band B CFTR in HeLa cells, it had no effect on the stability of the immature CFTR in Calu-3 cells, suggesting that the core-glycosylated protein is not a substrate for ERAD in Calu-3 cells.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Similar results were seen when the proteasome was blocked using 10  microM clasto-lactacystin--lactone (data not shown).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	158	 These results support our hypothesis that in Calu-3 cells all newly synthesized, core-glycosylated CFTR is processed to the fully glycosylated form, and therefore, there is no role for the proteasome in the early events of CFTR processing in Calu-3 cells.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	159	View larger version (46K):    FIG.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Proteasome inhibition has no effect on CFTR processing in Calu-3 cells.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Metabolic pulse-chase experiments were performed as described in the legend to Fig.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	162	 2 on Calu-3 and HeLa in the presence (+) or absence (-) of 50  microM ALLN.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	163	 In the + samples, ALLN was present in the medium during the entire experiment.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Representative gels are shown on the left, and the densities of Band B (triangle and diamond) and Band C (x and square) CFTR at each chase time point is plotted as percent of Band B at the 0 time point.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	165	 ALLN treatment resulted in an increase of the half-life of Band B in HeLa cells only (top, right panel).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	166	 A representative of two experiments is shown.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	167	  Cell Surface CFTR Expression Is Elevated in Calu-3 Cells To test whether increased CFTR stability translates to a higher percentage of CFTR at the cell surface, we performed quantitative cell surface biotinylation experiments and compared the biotinylated and total pools of CFTR in each of the cell lines.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	168	 5A indicate that the biotinylated CFTR pool in COS-7 cells was 11  plus or minus  2.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	169	5%, and in Calu-3 was 20  plus or minus  4.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Since Calu-3 cells were grown on plastic dishes under standard tissue culture conditions; we tested whether growing the cells on semipermeable supports as polarized monolayers affects CFTR surface expression.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	171	 After growing the cells for 9-12 days on 12-mm filters, the cells formed tight monolayers as monitored by measuring transepithelial resistance ( > 800  cm2).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Under these conditions, the biotinylated CFTR fraction was 17  plus or minus  5%, similar to non-polarized cells.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	173	 These results demonstrate that the surface CFTR pool in Calu-3 cells is higher, but cell polarity does not affect the relative surface pool.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	174	View larger version (27K):    FIG.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	175	 CFTR distribution in COS-7, HeLa, and Calu-3 cells.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	176	 A, the relative surface pools of CFTR expressed in COS-7, HeLa, and Calu-3 cells were determined using a surface biotinylation assay (38).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	177	 In these assays, the total CFTR from 50% of the lysates (T) was compared with the biotinylated fraction (B).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Cells were lysed in radioimmune precipitation assay buffer, and CFTR was immunoprecipitated using anti-CFTR C-terminal (24-1) monoclonal antibody.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	179	 From the other 50% of the lysates, CFTR was immunoprecipitated as described above, eluted, and re-captured using avidin-Sepharose beads (biotinylated CFTR (B)).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Total CFTR (T) and biotinylated CFTR (B) were in vitro phosphorylated with protein kinase A and [-32P]ATP, separated by SDS-PAGE, and analyzed by Phosphorimaging and densitometry.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Representative gels of seven or more experiments are shown.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	182	 The average percentage of biotinylated CFTR for each cell type was calculated based on densitometry.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	183	 B, CFTR distribution in Calu-3 monolayers.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Calu-3 cells were grown on permeable supports and analyzed after 10-12 days of culture using indirect immunofluorescence.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	185	 CFTR was labeled with 24-1 monoclonal antibody and anti-mouse IgG, Alexa-Fluor488 (green).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Tight junctions were stained using a polyclonal (rabbit) anti-ZO1 antibody (Zymed Laboratories Inc.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	187	) and anti-rabbit IgG Alexa-Fluor596 (red).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	188	 A side view and a top view at the apical membrane domain are shown.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	189	 CFTR (green) is present at the apical membrane and also intracellularly.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Tight junctions are well developed as represented by the organized red staining of ZO1.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	191	 C, CFTR maturation efficiency in Calu-3 cells grown on filters.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Calu-3 cells were grown on 12-mm filters and metabolically labeled, and CFTR maturation efficiency was monitored as described in the legend to Fig.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Conversion of the Band B to Band C was compared at each time points of the chase.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Results are plotted as percent of Band B at the 30 min (highest density) chase time.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	195	  The fact that CFTR surface expression is not elevated in polarized cells was somewhat surprising, given that in HT29 cells, a colonic epithelial cell line, CFTR surface expression requires polarization of the colonocytes (50).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	196	 To confirm that Calu-3 cells had formed polarized monolayers, we monitored the expression a ZO-1, a marker for tight junctions (red) (51), and CFTR (green) localization in the Calu-3 cells using immunocytochemistry (Fig.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	197	 5B indicate that the Calu-3 cells have formed tight monolayers as evidenced by ZO-1 staining (red) close to the apical surface and that CFTR (green) is found both at the cell surface and in intracellular sites.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Next, we tested whether the rate and efficiency of CFTR maturation was affected by cell polarity.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	199	 5C confirm that similar to conventional tissue culture conditions (Fig.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	200	 2, A and B), CFTR maturation is also efficient under polarizing conditions ( > 90%).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Interestingly, these experiments in Calu-3 monolayers suggested that the amount of radiolabeled CFTR dramatically decreased compared with non-polarized conditions and that rates of conversion of newly synthesized (Band B) CFTR to fully glycosylated (Band C) CFTR was slower than under standard conditions.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Only 30% of the newly synthesized (Band B) CFTR was converted into fully glycosylated (Band C) at 2 h, and maturation was completed only after 6 h of chase.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	203	CFTR Maturation Is Efficient in T84 Cells Grown under Standard Tissue Culture Conditions To determine whether efficient CFTR maturation is a special feature of Calu-3 cells or present in other endogenous CFTR expressing cell lines, we also tested T84 and HT29 colonic epithelial cell lines endogenously expressing wild type CFTR.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	204	 6A indicates that steady state CFTR protein levels are highest in Calu-3 cells.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	205	 In T84 and HT29 cells, CFTR levels are 3- and  > 10-fold lower than in Calu-3, respectively (Fig.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	206	 TaqMan RT-PCR measurements demonstrated that CFTR message levels in T84 cells are 4-fold and in HT29 are 10-fold lower than in Calu-3 cells grown under the same conditions (Fig.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Because of low transcription and consequent low translation of CFTR in HT29 cells, only T84 cells synthesized sufficient amounts of the protein to effectively follow maturation efficiency.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	208	 6C, although CFTR synthetic levels were quite low and maturation efficiency in the early chase periods was variable, by the end of the 4th h into the chase, the maturation of the newly synthesized protein was virtually 100% in T84 cells.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	209	 These results indicate that efficient processing of endogenous wild type CFTR is not a unique feature of Calu-3 cells but also exists in a colonic epithelial cell line.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	210	View larger version (28K):    FIG.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	211	 CFTR expression and maturation in T84 cells.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	212	 CFTR protein (A) and mRNA levels (B) were compared in Calu-3, T84, and HT29 cells as described under "Materials and Methods.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	213	" CFTR maturation efficiency was monitored in T84 cells as described in the legend to Fig.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	214	 A representative gel (n = 3) is shown (C, left panel).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	215	 The relative amount of fully glycosylated CFTR (Band C, squares) and core glycosylated CFTR (Band B, diamonds) is plotted as percent of the immature Band B after the pulse (right panel).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	216	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   To our knowledge, the experiments shown here represent the first complete analysis of wild type CFTR biogenesis in human epithelial cell lines endogenously expressing the protein and highlight the following important points.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	217	 First, in contrast to heterologous CFTR-expressing cell lines, CFTR maturation is efficient in Calu-3 and T84 cells.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Second, the mature CFTR is very stable and a large portion of it is intracellular.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Third, since CFTR biogenesis is efficient, ERAD plays no role in the degradation of the wild type protein.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	220	 And finally, although CFTR message levels are low in Calu-3 cells compared with transduced cells, the steady-state protein levels are comparable with heterologous expression systems, suggesting that CFTR biogenesis and protein stability are not faithfully reproduced in the heterologous systems.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	221	 These studies indicate that detailed analysis of endogenous CFTR expressing cell lines is warranted.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	222	Initial studies of CFTR biogenesis described complete and early degradation of the F508 CFTR and inefficient maturation of the wild type protein (13, 24, 52).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Most of these studies employed heterologous overexpression systems, with one exception (24).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Kopito and colleagues (24) compared wild type CFTR maturation efficiency in stable HEK cells to HT29 and T84 cells endogenously expressing wild type CFTR.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	225	 In these cells, CFTR expression levels were 10-50-fold lower than in HEK, but the maturation efficiency of CFTR was only 25% after 2 h of chase.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	226	 In our studies, CFTR maturation in Calu-3 and T84 cells reached the maximum (100%) only after 4 h.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Analysis of CFTR maturation efficiency in COS-7 and HeLa cells suggested that there was no significant increase in Band C levels between the 2- and 4-h chase periods, whereas in Calu-3 cells and T84 cells CFTR maturation was only completed by the end of the 4th h.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	228	 This slower CFTR processing noted in endogenously expressing cells was even more pronounced in Calu-3 cells grown as polarized monolayers.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	229	 As a comparison with other cell lines, we found that CFTR mRNA and protein levels were 4- and 10-fold higher in Calu-3 cells than in T84 and HT29 cells.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	230	 While we were not able to follow the maturation of the protein in HT29 cells, analysis in T84 revealed that CFTR maturation was very efficient and only complete by the end of a 4-h chase.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	231	A more rapid disappearance of Band B CFTR in T84 and HT29 than in HEK cells was also described and attributed only to degradation (24).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	232	 However, those experiments were completed before the role of the proteasome in early CFTR degradation was described or before protein overexpression was shown to overload the proteasome.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Subsequently, it has been demonstrated that either the inhibition of the proteasome (25, 48) or protein overproduction (53) could result in delayed degradation.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Therefore, it is now clear that disappearance of Band B could be due to both degradation and maturation.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	235	 In our studies, proteasome blockade revealed that in Calu-3 cells disappearance of band B was not due to proteasomal degradation, whereas in HeLa cells it partially was.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	236	The increased half-life of the mature CFTR in Calu-3 cells suggests that epithelial factors stabilize CFTR.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	237	 This finding is supported by studies showing that CFTR half-life in heterologous systems is 8-12 h (38, 52), whereas in LLC-PK1 (54) and in MDCK cells (55), two kidney epithelial cells stably expressing the wild type CFTR, the half-life is significantly longer when the cells are grown under polarized conditions.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	238	 Increased stability of the mature wild type CFTR in epithelial cells is also consistent with our previous findings that growing MDCK cells as polarized monolayers results in increased steady-state CFTR levels and function.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Furthermore, possible cell type-specific differences in wild type CFTR biogenesis and stability are suggested by our findings that cellular polarization in Calu-3 cells did not have a significant effect on total and cell surface CFTR levels in contrast to our previous findings in MDCK cells (56).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	240	Both morphological and cell surface biotinylation studies indicate the existence of a large intracellular CFTR pool in Calu-3 cells.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	241	 The dynamics and precise cellular localization of this pool remain unclear, but several studies (44, 57-61) have indicated that CFTR is found in endosomal and recycling endosomal compartments.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	242	 How regulation of surface localized CFTR is accomplished in polarized epithelia and whether there is a physiological role for the intracellular pool remain open questions.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	243	The factors that allow efficient CFTR maturation as well as those that are responsible for stabilizing the mature protein in Calu-3 and T84 cells have not been identified.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	244	 However, dramatic progress has been made recently in identifying tissue-specific factors that organize the delivery and function of transport proteins to their appropriate membrane domains (27, 62-64).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	245	 These results suggest that both the cellular context and molecular rationing of transport components are important not only for proper function but also for intracellular trafficking (27, 64).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Nevertheless, normal epithelial cell function depends on the accurate delivery of a large number of membrane components to a particular cell surface domain, and defects in this process often lead to disease (3, 4).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	247	 Therefore, it is crucial to understand how different cell types organize the biogenesis and intracellular processing of key molecules (27, 28).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Since CFTR plays a central role in the regulation of epithelial ion transport in multiple organ systems, understanding its biogenesis, cellular distribution, and stability in epithelia may be the first step toward identifying the molecular defects leading to early degradation of otherwise functional mutants, such as F508 CFTR.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	249	The importance of elucidating the biogenesis and intracellular journey of wild type CFTR is also underscored by two publications indicating that some F508 CFTR can be found at the cell surface in native epithelia (65, 66).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	250	 These earlier reports raise the possibility that in the correct physiological milieu, even the mutant protein might traffic differently than reported in heterologous expression systems.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Furthermore, a number of CFTR-associating proteins have been identified and shown to regulate either the function (32) or the intracellular journey of CFTR (33).
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Whether these or other yet to be identified proteins have any effect on the biogenesis and stability of the wild type protein in native epithelia remains to be determined.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Although endogenous, wild type CFTR synthesis is quite low in many native tissues, our results suggest the usefulness of cell lines endogenously expressing CFTR as powerful tools for investigating cell type-specific differences in CFTR biogenesis and function.
0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	254	   FOOTNOTES   * This work was supported in part by a fellowship from the Research Development Program of the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation (CFF) (to K.

0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	257	), and a grant from the Research Development Program of the CFF and the National Institutes of Health (to E.
