0.4319393.15066992.html.plaintext.txt	328	 80, 857-868[Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve].
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	0	Newly Synthesized Human  Opioid Receptors Retained in the Endoplasmic Reticulum Are Retrotranslocated to the Cytosol, Deglycosylated, Ubiquitinated, and Degraded by the Proteasome* Ulla E.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Petaja-Repo  , Mireille Hogue, Andre Laperriere, Suparna Bhalla, Philippe Walker , and Michel Bouvier**.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	2	From the  Departement de Biochimie, Universite de Montreal, Montreal, Quebec H3C 3J7, Canada,   AstraZeneca Research and Development Montreal, St.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Laurent, Quebec H4S 1Z9, Canada, and the   Department of Anatomy and Cell Biology, University of Oulu, FIN-90014 Oulu, Finland.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	4	Received for publication, August 7, 2000, and in revised form, October 25, 2000.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	5	    ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	6	We have previously shown that only a fraction of the newly synthesized human  opioid receptors is able to leave the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and reach the cell surface (Petaja-Repo, U.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	7	 In the present study, we investigated the fate of those receptors that are retained intracellularly.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Pulse-chase experiments revealed that the disappearance of the receptor precursor form (Mr 45,000) and of two smaller species (Mr 42,000 and 39,000) is inhibited by the proteasome blocker, lactacystin.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	9	 The treatment also promoted accumulation of the mature receptor form (Mr 55,000), indicating that the ER quality control actively routes a significant proportion of rescuable receptors for proteasome degradation.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	10	 In addition, degradation intermediates that included full-length deglycosylated (Mr 39,000) and ubiquitinated forms of the receptor were found to accumulate in the cytosol upon inhibition of proteasome function.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Finally, coimmunoprecipitation experiments with the -subunit of the Sec61 translocon complex revealed that the receptor precursor and its deglycosylated degradation intermediates interact with the translocon.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Taken together, these results support a model in which misfolded or incompletely folded receptors are transported to the cytoplasmic side of the ER membrane via the Sec61 translocon, deglycosylated and conjugated with ubiquitin prior to degradation by the cytoplasmic 26 S proteasomes.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	13	     INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	14	The endoplasmic reticulum (ER)1 quality control scrutinizes newly synthesized proteins entering the secretory pathway and ensures that only correctly folded and, in the case of multimeric proteins, fully assembled complexes are deployed to distal cellular compartments (1).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Those that fail to fulfill these criteria are retained in the ER and subsequently degraded.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Even minor changes in the protein primary structure can cause retention in the ER.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	17	 This is exemplified in many diseases, including cystic fibrosis and cases of 1-antitrypsin deficiency and familial hypercholesterolemia, which are characterized by an "ER storage phenotype" (2).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Although less thoroughly characterized, numerous naturally occurring mutations leading to ER retention of G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) have also been evoked as the cause of inherited diseases.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	19	 For example, ER-retained mutants of rhodopsin, the luteinizing hormone receptor, and the V2-vasopressin receptor have been implicated in some forms of retinitis pigmentosa, male pseudohermaphroditism, and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, respectively (3-6).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	20	Emerging evidence indicates that degradation of aberrant ER proteins is mediated by the cytosolic multiprotease complex, the 26 S proteasome.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Indeed, an increasing number of misfolded or unassembled yeast and eukaryotic integral membrane and secreted proteins have been shown to be substrates for this disposal mechanism (7-26).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	22	 However, proteasome-mediated degradation is not restricted to misfolded or unassembled proteins, as evidenced by the observation that some resident ER proteins are substrates for this degradation pathway in response to cellular signals (27-29).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	23	 It can thus be hypothesized that this degradation pathway might have a role in regulating steady state levels of normal wild type proteins traversing the secretory pathway, as has been described for many cytosolic and nuclear regulatory molecules (for review, see Refs.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Reported examples pointing to this phenomenon are, however, scarce, exceptions being apolipoprotein B100 (32, 33), apolipoprotein(a) (34), and tyrosinase (35).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	25	 In a recent report, Schubert and co-workers (36) showed that at least 30% of newly synthesized proteins might be degraded by the proteasomes.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Whether these degraded proteins represent defective ribosomal products resulting from errors in translation, as suggested, or might also include correctly translated but incompletely folded proteins remains to be determined.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	27	Proteasome-mediated ubiquitin-dependent degradation of cytosolic and nuclear proteins is a well described phenomenon (for review, see Refs.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	28	 30 and 31), but the detailed mechanisms involved in the ER-associated proteasomal degradation remain unclear.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Recent findings have led to the emergence of models suggesting that misfolded or incompletely folded ER proteins are retrotranslocated to the cytosolic side of the ER membrane through the Sec61 translocon complex and conjugated with ubiquitin before hydrolysis by the 26 S proteasomes (for review, see Refs.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	30	We have previously shown that the human  opioid receptor (hOR) is an example of integral membrane proteins that are partially retained in the ER, possibly due to difficulties in the folding process (40).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Another example is the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) (for review, see Ref.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Only about 40% and 25% of the newly synthesized wild type hOR and CFTR molecules, respectively, are able to leave the ER and reach the cell surface.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	33	 We thus set out to determine whether the ER-retained hORs are targeted for degradation by the 26 S proteasomes and, if so, to delineate the mechanisms involved in this process.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	34	 The results presented here indicate that these receptors are transported back to the cytosol, in a process that involves the Sec61 translocon, and deglycosylated before being degraded by the proteasomes.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Furthermore, inhibition of the proteasomal pathway led to the accumulation of ubiquitinated receptor forms, pointing to the fact that polyubiquitination may be a targeting signal for disposal of misfolded or incompletely folded hOR molecules.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	36	     EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	37	Materials-- EXPRE35S35S protein labeling mix (1175 Ci/mmol) and [9-3H]bremazocine (26.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	38	6 Ci/mmol) were purchased from PerkinElmer Life Sciences.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Recombinant peptide-N-glycosidase F (PNGase F) of Flavobacterium meningosepticum, purified from Escherichia coli (EC 3.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	40	52) was from Roche Molecular Biochemicals.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	41	 The proteasome inhibitors lactacystin, Z-Leu-Leu-Leu-CHO (MG-132) and Z-Ile-Glu(OtBu)-Ala-Leu-CHO (PSI) were obtained from Calbiochem.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Cell culture reagents were either from Life Technologies Inc.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	43	 The anti-FLAG M2 monoclonal antibody, the anti-FLAG M2 affinity resin, and the FLAG peptide were products of Sigma.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The anti-calnexin (SPA-860), the anti-heat shock protein 70 (Hsp70) (SPA-820), and the anti-ubiquitin (SPA-200) antibodies were from Stressgen Biotechnologies Corp.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	45	 and Protein G-Sepharose from Amersham Pharmacia Biotech.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The anti-Sec61 antibody was a generous gift from Dr.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Rapoport (Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	48	 All the other reagents were of analytical grade and obtained from various commercial suppliers.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	49	Cell Culture-- Cells were cultured in either 25-cm2 or 75-cm2 culture flasks and grown to 80-90% confluence at 37  degrees C in a humidified atmosphere of 5% CO2.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Human embryonic kidney 293S (HEK-293S) cells stably expressing the hOR tagged at the C terminus with the FLAG epitope (DYKDDDDK) (40) were maintained in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (DMEM) containing 10% (v/v) fetal calf serum, 1000 units/ml penicillin, 1 mg/ml streptomycin, 1.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	51	5  microg/ml fungizone (complete DMEM) and 400  microg/ml Geneticin.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	52	 A clone expressing 10 pmol of receptor/mg of membrane protein was chosen for this study.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	53	Metabolic Labeling with [35S]Methionine/Cysteine-- For [35S]methionine/cysteine labeling, cells were first preincubated in methionine and cysteine-free DMEM for 60 min at 37  degrees C, and the labeling was performed in fresh medium containing 150  microCi/ml [35S]methionine/cysteine.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	54	 After an incubation of 60 min at 37  degrees C, the pulse was terminated by washing the cells twice with the chase medium (complete DMEM supplemented with 5 mM methionine) and chased for different periods of time as specified in the figures.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	55	 When labeling was performed in the presence of the proteasome inhibitors, the reagents were added 3 h before the pulse labeling at a final concentration of 10  microM (lactacystin) or 25  microM (MG-132 and PSI).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	56	 After the labeling, cells were washed with and harvested in phosphate-buffered saline and, unless otherwise indicated, quick-frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at 80  degrees C.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	57	Immunoprecipitations-- Total cellular lysates were prepared in buffer A (0.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	58	5% n-dodecyl--D-maltoside (DDM) (w/v), 25 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	59	4, 140 mM NaCl, 2 mM EDTA, 5  microg/ml leupeptin, 5  microg/ml soybean trypsin inhibitor (STI), 10  microg/ml benzamidine, 2  microg/ml aprotinin, 0.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	60	5 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride (PMSF), 2 mM 1,10-phenanthroline).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Insoluble material was removed by centrifugation at 5000  x  g for 30 min, and bovine serum albumin was added to a final concentration of 0.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	62	 The receptor was immunoprecipitated using the anti-FLAG M2 affinity resin as described (40).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	63	 For the Sec61 immunoprecipitation, DDM was replaced by digitonin while NaCl, EDTA, and 1,10-phenanthroline were omitted from the buffer.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	64	 For the ubiquitin immunoprecipitation, N-ethylmaleimide (NEM) was included in all buffers to distinguish the high molecular weight ubiquitinated receptor forms from putative aggregated receptors.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Before immunoprecipitation of calnexin, Hsp70, Sec61, and ubiquitin, samples were precleared for 60 min with 15  microl of Protein G-Sepharose.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	66	 The appropriate antibody (dilutions: 1:200, 10  microg/ml, 1:100, and 1:100, respectively) and 15  microl of Protein G-Sepharose were then added and incubated overnight at 4  degrees C with gentle agitation.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Following washing of the resin as described (40), the bound antigens were eluted in SDS-sample buffer (62.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	68	8, 2% (w/v) SDS, 10% (v/v) glycerol, 0.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	69	001% (w/v) bromphenol blue) at 95  degrees C for 5 min.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	70	 If two or more consecutive immunoprecipitation steps were performed, the antigens were eluted with 1% (w/v) SDS, 25 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	71	4, at 95  degrees C for 5 min and the eluates diluted 10-fold with buffer A prior to the next immunoprecipitation.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	72	Cell Fractionation-- Cells were harvested and homogenized in buffer B (25 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	73	4, 140 mM NaCl, 2 mM EDTA, 5  microg/ml leupeptin, 5  microg/ml STI, 10  microg/ml benzamidine, 2  microg/ml aprotinin, 0.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	74	5 mM PMSF, 2 mM 1,10-phenanthroline) with a Dounce homogenizer (Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	75	 3 (D and E) and 4B), cells were homogenized by freezing and thawing the cell suspension and passing it 10 times through a 26-gauge needle.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Fractionation was performed as described (42).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Briefly, homogenates were first centrifuged at 1000  x  g for 10 min to pellet unbroken cells and nuclei.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	78	 The supernatant was then centrifuged at 10,000  x  g for 30 min to pellet the crude membranes, and the supernatant was further centrifuged at 100,000  x  g for 60 min to clarify the cytosolic fraction.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	79	 DDM was added to the soluble fraction to a final concentration of 0.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	80	5% (w/v) to decrease nonspecific binding of proteins to either the anti-FLAG M2 affinity resin or Protein G-Sepharose.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Pellets were washed with buffer B, solubilized in buffer A, and insoluble material removed by centrifugation at 100,000  x  g for 60 min.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Immunoprecipitations from the soluble fraction and the solubilized membranes were carried out as described above.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	83	Deglycosylation of the Immunoprecipitated HORs-- The immunoprecipitated receptors were deglycosylated following elution from the anti-FLAG M2 affinity resin with 1% (w/v) SDS, 50 mM sodium phosphate, pH 7.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Before the enzyme reaction, the eluates were diluted 10-fold with 0.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	85	5% (w/v) DDM, 50 mM sodium phosphate, pH 7.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	86	5 mM PMSF, 2 mM 1,10-phenanthroline, 5  microg/ml leupeptin, 5  microg/ml STI, 10  microg/ml benzamidine, and 1% 2-mercaptoethanol.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	87	 PNGase F was added at a final concentration of 0.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	88	01-10 units/ml, samples incubated at 37  degrees C for 16 h, and the reaction terminated by the addition of SDS-sample buffer.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	89	SDS-Polyacrylamide Gel Electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE)-- SDS-PAGE was performed as described (43), using 4% stacking gels and 10% separating gels.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Samples were heated at 95  degrees C for 2 min in the presence of 50 mM dithiothreitol and run on a Bio-Rad Mini-Protein II apparatus.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Molecular weight markers (Bio-Rad) detected by staining with Coomassie Brilliant Blue (Bio-Rad) were used to calibrate the gels.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	92	 For the detection of radioactivity, the gels were treated with EN3HANCE  (PerkinElmer Life Sciences) according to the manufacturer's instructions, dried, and exposed at 80  degrees C for 1-15 days using Biomax MR film and intensifying screens (Eastman Kodak Co.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	93	 The relative intensities of the labeled bands on the fluorographs were analyzed by densitometric scanning with an Agfa Arcus II laser scanner, and the data were quantified using the NIH image program, version 1.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	94	61, subtracting the local background from each lane.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	95	Miscellaneous Procedures-- Total protein was measured using the Bio-Rad DC assay kit and bovine serum albumin as a standard.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Binding assays were carried out using [3H]bremazocine, essentially as described (40).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	97	     RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	98	Degradation of ER-retained Newly Synthesized hORs Is Mediated by the Proteasomal Pathway-- We have previously shown that a large fraction of newly synthesized hORs in HEK-293S cells remains in a pre-Golgi compartment as core-glycosylated Mr 45,000 precursors that are not transported to the cell surface (40).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Now we set out to investigate the fate of these intracellularly retained receptors.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	100	 To determine whether proteasomes are involved in the degradation of these receptor forms, cells were incubated with lactacystin, a specific inhibitor of the 26 S proteasome (44, 45).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	101	 HEK-293S cells stably expressing the receptor carrying a C-terminal FLAG epitope (HEK-293S-hOR-FLAG cells) were metabolically labeled with [35S]methionine/cysteine and after a chase in a medium containing an excess of unlabeled methionine, cell lysates were prepared and the receptors isolated by immunoprecipitation (Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	102	 A major band of Mr 45,000 and two minor ones of Mr 42,000 and 39,000 were apparent in untreated cells at the end of the pulse (Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	103	 During the subsequent chase, label incorporated into these bands decreased and a slower, more diffusely migrating band of Mr 55,000 appeared, representing the fully mature receptor (40).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	104	 When the cells were treated with lactacystin, an increase in labeling of all receptor species was detected (Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Furthermore, proteasome inhibition significantly retarded the disappearance of the Mr 45,000, 42,000, and 39,000 receptor species, the half-life of the last one being the most dramatically affected (Table I).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Similar findings were obtained using two other proteasome inhibitors, the peptide aldehydes MG-132 and PSI (45) (data not shown).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Taken together, these results suggest an active role of proteasomes in the elimination of newly synthesized hORs.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	108	 The fact that lactacystin promoted increase in receptor labeling, even within a shorter pulse period of 15 min, suggests that targeting to degradation begins very early, either cotranslationally or immediately after the receptor synthesis is complete.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Inhibition of this rapid degradation is most likely responsible for the increase in the amount of mature receptors observed in pulse-chase labeling experiments (compare lanes 4 and 5 in Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	110	 This increase was accompanied by a 38% increase in the number of [3H]bremazocine-binding sites detected.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Our findings are not due to the presence of a FLAG-epitope tag at the C terminus of the receptor since the same results were also obtained using a receptor harboring the tag at its N terminus (data not shown).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Unfortunately, the lack of a high affinity and selective antibody for the hOR makes it impossible to carry out these experiments on the native untagged receptor.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	113	View larger version (39K):    Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	114	   HOR synthesis and maturation in untreated and lactacystin-treated HEK-293S cells.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	115	 HEK-293S-hOR-FLAG cells were untreated (A) or treated with 10  microM lactacystin (B) for 3 h, pulse-labeled for 60 min with [35S]methionine/cysteine, and then chased for the indicated times in the absence (A) or continued presence of the proteasome inhibitor (B).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Cellular lysates were prepared and the solubilized receptors isolated by a two-step immunoprecipitation using the anti-FLAG M2 antibody as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	117	" The samples were analyzed by SDS-PAGE and fluorography and the dried gels exposed to x-ray films.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	118	 The fluorographs shown are representative of four independent experiments.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Arrows indicate the molecular weights of the different receptor forms.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Markers used to calibrate the gels are indicated (from the top: myosin, -galactosidase, phosphorylase b, bovine serum albumin, ovalbumin, and carbonic anhydrase).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	121	                              View this table:    Table I Half-lives of the hOR species in the absence and presence of lactacystin Relative intensities of the labeled receptor species were quantified from fluorographs of pulse-chase experiments, an example of which is presented in Fig 1, by densitometric scanning.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	122	 The half-lives of the different receptor species were determined using the GraphPad Prism program, version 2.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	123	01, and the data represent the mean  plus or minus  S.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	124	 of four independent experiments.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Statistical significance of the differences was assessed using the two-tailed Student's t test.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	126	The Mr 42,000 and 39,000 hOR Species Represent Receptors Carrying One or No N-Linked Oligosaccharides, Respectively-- It has been reported previously that N-linked oligosaccharides of newly synthesized glycoproteins are removed before proteasomal degradation (13-17, 26, 35, 42, 46).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	127	 We therefore assessed whether the smaller molecular weight receptor species of Mr 42,000 and 39,000 represent deglycosylated receptors rather than proteolytic fragments.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	128	 For this purpose, immunoprecipitated [35S]methionine/cysteine pulse-labeled samples were subjected to enzymatic deglycosylation using PNGase F to remove the two N-linked glycans from the receptor (40).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	129	 2 (lane 5), complete deglycosylation of the Mr 45,000 receptor precursor led to the appearance of a single species migrating at Mr 39,000.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	130	 The fact that the Mr 42,000 species was found to be an intermediate in the stepwise deglycosylation of the receptor precursor suggests that this species represents a receptor carrying one N-linked glycan.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	131	 The mobility of the Mr 39,000 species that was stabilized in lactacystin-treated cells was indistinguishable from that of the PNGase F-digested core-glycosylated Mr 45,000 receptor form (Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	132	 2, compare lanes 5-7), confirming the fact that this species represents an intact receptor polypeptide with no N-linked glycans.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Protein translocation into the ER membrane and core glycosylation are believed to occur cotranslationally in mammalian cells (47).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Thus, it is very likely that the Mr 39,000 receptor species represents a previously core-glycosylated receptor that has been deglycosylated and is an intermediate in the degradation pathway.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	135	View larger version (34K):    Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	136	   Deglycosylation of the metabolically labeled hOR with PNGase F.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	137	 HEK-293S-hOR-FLAG cells were pulse-labeled for 60 min with [35S]methionine/cysteine in the absence or presence of lactacystin as indicated.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Receptors were then isolated from cellular lysates by immunoprecipitation as described in Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	139	 The immunoprecipitates were incubated for 16 h at 37  degrees C with increasing concentrations (0.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	140	01-1 unit/ml) of PNGase F as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	141	" The enzyme-free controls (lanes 1 and 6) contained buffer only.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Reactions were stopped by adding SDS-sample buffer followed by SDS-PAGE and fluorography.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	143	The Mr 39,000 hOR Species Dislocates from the ER Membrane and Accumulates in the Cytosol-- To further verify the nature and the subcellular localization of the Mr 39,000 hOR species, fractionation of cellular homogenates was performed after metabolic labeling (Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Receptors were immunoprecipitated from four fractions: 1000  x  g pellet containing cellular debris, nuclei and trapped soluble proteins, 10,000  x  g pellet containing crude membranes, 100,000  x  g pellet containing residual microsomal membranes, and 100,000  x  g supernatant containing cytosolic proteins.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	145	 As a control, the ER membrane protein, calnexin, and the cytosolic protein Hsp70 were immunoprecipitated from aliquots of the same four fractions.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Calnexin was detected in the membrane fraction (Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	147	 3B, lanes 3 and 4) but not in the cytosolic one (lanes 7 and 8), whereas the opposite was true for Hsp70 (Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	148	 As expected, both proteins were also detected in the 1000  x  g pellet (Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	149	 3A, in addition to be found in the membrane fraction, the Mr 39,000 receptor species was recovered from the cytosolic fraction of lactacystin-treated (lane 8) but not of untreated cells (lane 7).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	150	 This is in agreement with the notion that it represents an intermediate in the degradation pathway that would normally be broken down by the cytosolic proteasomes.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Higher molecular weight bands forming a regularly spaced ladder, of which the smallest had an apparent molecular weight of 45,000, were also found in the cytosolic fraction of lactacystin-treated cells (Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	152	 This Mr 45,000 species does not represent the core-glycosylated receptor precursor seen in Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	153	 3A (lanes 1-4), because PNGase F was not able to decrease its molecular weight (Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	154	 It is more likely that the ladder and the accompanying high molecular weight smear comprise polyubiquitinated forms of the Mr 39,000 receptor (see below).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	155	View larger version (40K):    Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	156	   Subcellular fractionation of metabolically labeled HEK-293S-hOR-FLAG cells.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	157	 HEK-293S-hOR-FLAG cells were pulse-labeled for 60 min with [35S]methionine/cysteine in the presence or absence of lactacystin as indicated and either harvested immediately (A-D) or chased for the indicated times in the continued presence of the proteasome inhibitor (E).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	158	 The total cellular homogenates were fractionated by differential centrifugation as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	159	" HOR (A, D, and E), calnexin (B), and Hsp70 (C) were immunoprecipitated from the fractions obtained using the appropriate antibodies.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	160	 The immunoprecipitates were then either analyzed directly by SDS-PAGE and fluorography (A-C and E) or deglycosylated with PNGase F prior to SDS-PAGE (D).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Arrows indicate migration of the different receptor species, calnexin and Hsp70.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Results shown are representative of four (A-C) or two (D and E) independent experiments.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	163	The fact that inhibition of proteasomal degradation significantly increased the amount of the Mr 39,000 hOR species in the cytosolic fraction (Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	164	 3A, lanes 7 and 8), suggests that this species may dislocate from the ER membrane and accumulate in the cytosol prior to proteasomal degradation.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	165	 To test this hypothesis, receptors were immunoprecipitated from the soluble fraction after pulse-chase labeling of lactacystin-treated cells.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	166	 3E, a small amount of the Mr 39,000 receptor species was present in the cytosol at the end of the pulse.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	167	 However, the amount detected clearly increased during the chase, indicating that the Mr 39,000 species originates from a pool of newly synthesized receptors that are retained in the ER and not from a failure or inefficiency of the translocation machinery.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Thus, this species most likely results from deglycosylation of the Mr 45,000 receptor precursor that is destined for degradation and eventually dislocates from the ER membrane.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Removal of the N-linked glycans most likely occurs prior to retrotranslocation to the cytosol since the deglycosylated hOR species was found both in the cytosolic and the membrane fractions (Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	170	 3A, lanes 8 and 4, respectively).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	171	Inhibition of Proteasomal Degradation Leads to Accumulation of Polyubiquitinated hORs-- To directly test the hypothesis that the hOR is modified by ubiquitination, cellular lysates from [35S]methionine/cysteine pulse-labeled cells were subjected to sequential immunoprecipitation.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	172	 First, the hORs were immunoprecipitated with the anti-FLAG M2 antibody and the purified material was denatured by SDS.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Proteins were then reimmunoprecipitated using an anti-ubiquitin antibody.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	174	 All these immunoprecipitation steps (Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	175	 4, A and B) were carried out in the presence of NEM to prevent inappropriate aggregation of proteins.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	176	 In lactacystin-treated cells, the immunoprecipitated material migrated as a high molecular weight smear that extended upwards toward the top of the gel (Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	177	 4A, lane 4), a feature that is characteristic of ubiquitinated proteins (8, 10, 17, 20, 22, 33, 35, 48, 49).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	178	 This smear is probably due to the variable number of ubiquitin molecules that are added to individual receptor molecules during the process of polyubiquitination.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Ubiquitinated proteins were barely detectable in the absence of lactacystin (Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	180	 4A, lane 3), indicating that they normally are efficiently disposed by the proteasomes.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	181	View larger version (41K):    Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	182	   Immunoprecipitation of the ubiquitinated hOR species from metabolically labeled HEK-293S-hOR-FLAG cells.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	183	 HEK-293S-hOR-FLAG cells were pulse-labeled for 60 min with [35S]methionine/cysteine in the absence or presence of lactacystin as indicated, and cellular lysates were prepared (A) or membrane (B, lanes 1-3, 7, and 8) and soluble fractions (B, lanes 4-6) were isolated.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	184	 The total pool of receptors (A (lanes 1 and 2) and B (lanes 1 and 4)) and the ubiquitinated receptor forms (A (lanes 3 and 4) and B (lanes 2, 3, and 5-8)) were isolated by sequential immunoprecipitation using the anti-FLAG M2 and the anti-ubiquitin antibodies as indicated.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	185	 The immunoprecipitates were then subjected to SDS-PAGE and fluorography.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Lanes 7 and 8 in B represent longer exposures of lanes 2 and 3, respectively.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Results shown are representative of three independent experiments.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	188	To assess whether the ubiquitinated hOR species are associated with the ER membranes or represent dislocated cytosolic receptors, [35S]methionine/cysteine-labeled receptors were subjected to sequential immunoprecipitation following fractionation of lactacystin-treated cells.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	189	 4B, the presence of ubiquitinated receptors in the cytosolic fraction could be easily detected following re-immunoprecipitation of the purified hORs with the anti-ubiquitin antibody (lane 5).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Although hardly any ubiquitinated material could be seen in the membrane fraction (lane 2), longer exposure revealed that some ubiquitinated receptors were also associated with this fraction (lane 7).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	191	 These results suggest that ubiquitinated receptors accumulate in the cytosol after the receptor dislocates from the ER membrane but that addition of ubiquitin molecules to the receptor begins prior to dislocation.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	192	 To further verify that the receptor itself was being ubiquitinated and did not coimmunoprecipitate with other ubiquitinated proteins, the anti-ubiquitin antibody immunoprecipitates were purified a second time with the anti-FLAG M2 antibody following SDS denaturation.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	193	 As expected for an ubiquitinated receptor, the diffusely migrating material was recovered again (Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	194	 The distinct higher molecular weight species detected in Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	195	 4 (panels A (lane 2) and B (lane 4) but not in panels A (lane 4) and B (lane 5)) most likely represent labeled proteins that interact with the newly synthesized receptor in a SDS-resistant manner or receptor oligomers that are resistant to NEM.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Polyubiquitination of the receptor did not result from the presence of a FLAG-epitope tag at its C terminus since a N-terminally tagged receptor form was also found to be ubiquitinated (data not shown).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	197	The observation that a significant proportion of the soluble receptors migrates as a nonubiquitinated Mr 39,000 species (Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	198	 4B, lane 4) is consistent with previous observations (8, 17, 35, 48).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Such nonubiquitinated species probably results from constant deubiquitination by ubiquitin isopeptidases (50).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	200	 It is very unlikely that this form could result from a lactacystin-mediated interference in cotranslational protein translocation into the ER membrane since this species accumulates in the cytosol during the chase period of the metabolic labeling experiment shown in Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	201	The ER-retained Newly Synthesized hORs Are Retrotranslocated to the Cytosol via the Sec61 Complex-- The cellular fractionation experiments clearly showed that the ER-retained newly synthesized hORs dislocate from the ER membrane into the cytosol (Figs.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	202	 To assess whether this dislocation involves retrotranslocation through the Sec61 translocon, as has been reported for other membrane proteins that are degraded by the proteasomes (13, 17, 21), coimmunoprecipitation experiments with the -subunit of the Sec61 complex were performed.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Cells treated or not with lactacystin were pulse-labeled with [35S]methionine/cysteine and chased for 60 min.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	204	 5A (lanes 5 and 6), re-immunoprecipitation of the Sec61 immunoprecipitates with the anti-FLAG M2 antibody recovered the Mr 45,000, 42,000, and 39,000 receptor species, suggesting that they interact with the translocon.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	205	 This interaction was shown to be specific because these species were absent when the anti-Sec61 antibody was replaced with a preimmune serum in the first immunoprecipitation step (Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	206	 5A, lanes 3 and 4) or when the anti-FLAG M2 affinity resin was replaced with the anti-mouse IgG agarose in the second step (data not shown).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Although the three receptor species were found to coimmunoprecipitate with the -subunit of the Sec61 complex in both untreated and lactacystin-treated cells, treatment with the proteasome inhibitor increased their amount and the Mr 39,000 species became prevalent (Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	208	 The sensitivity of the Mr 45,000 and the Mr 42,000 receptors to PNGase F (Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	209	 5B, lanes 3 and 4) confirmed their identity as the precursor and the deglycosylation intermediate, respectively.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Because the cells were chased for 60 min before the lysates were prepared, the receptor species that interact with the translocon are more likely to be in transit to exit the ER rather than being translocated into the membrane.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	211	 The fact that the fully deglycosylated Mr 39,000 receptor as well as the glycosylated Mr 42,000 and 45,000 species all associate with the Sec61 complex confirms that deglycosylation occurs before complete retrotranslocation of the receptor to the cytosol.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	212	View larger version (34K):    Fig.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	213	   Immunoprecipitation of the Sec61 complex-associated hOR species from metabolically labeled HEK-293S-hOR-FLAG cells.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	214	 HEK-293S-hOR-FLAG cells were pulse-labeled for 60 min with [35S]methionine/cysteine and chased for 60 min in the presence or absence of lactacystin as indicated.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	215	 The total pool of receptors (A (lanes 1 and 2) and B (lanes 1 and 3)) and those interacting with the Sec61 complex (A (lanes 5 and 6) and B (lanes 2 and 4)) were isolated from total lysates by sequential coimmunoprecipitation using the anti-FLAG M2 and the anti-Sec61 antibodies as indicated, and the immunoprecipitates were subjected to SDS-PAGE and fluorography either directly (A) or after PNGase F digestion (B).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	216	 The results shown are representative of three independent experiments.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	217	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	218	The results of the present study indicate that core-glycosylated hOR precursors that are not competent to enter the maturation pathway are transported to the cytosol in a process that involves the Sec61 translocon, removal of N-linked oligosaccharides, and addition of ubiquitin molecules.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	219	 This process leads to targeting of a significant proportion of newly synthesized receptors for degradation by the 26 S proteasomes.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	220	 The hOR thus appears to be a protein that, due to inherent difficulties in acquiring its native conformation, is very efficiently disposed of by the ER quality control.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	221	 This elimination could result either from a high level of irreversible misfolding or from limitations in the folding kinetics.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Because proteasomal blockade was found to enhance ER export and maturation of the receptor, kinetic limitations leading to the premature degradation of folding intermediates most likely contribute to the observed phenomenon.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Irrespective of the nature of the receptor forms that are targeted for degradation (irreversibly misfolded or folding intermediates), the present results show that the ER quality control can eliminate a high proportion of wild type proteins.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	224	 This does not seem to be unique to the hOR since Schubert and colleagues (36) recently suggested that at least 30% of newly synthesized proteins are degraded by the proteasomes (36).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	225	 It was hypothesized that degradation of what was referred to as defective ribosomal products could serve as an important adaptation for early antigen presentation during viral infection (36, 51).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Whether the high rate of degradation of the newly synthesized hORs also serves a biological purpose remains to be determined.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Alternatively, this process could merely reflect the exceedingly stringent control system monitoring the rapid but error-prone protein synthesis machinery.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Because expression to a relatively high level (~10 pmol/mg of protein for the clone used) is needed to perform the type of studies presented here, one cannot entirely exclude that overexpression is in part responsible for the proteasomal-mediated degradation observed.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	229	 However, we feel that this is unlikely since identical data were obtained using a clone expressing a smaller number of receptors (4 pmol/mg of protein; data not shown).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Additionally, the fact that several endogenously expressed ER proteins have been shown to be targeted for proteasomal degradation in a regulated manner (27-29) reinforces the idea that this proteolytic pathway is a general mechanism used to regulate protein biosynthesis.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	231	Several lines of evidence demonstrate the role of cytoplasmic proteasomes in the high degradation rate of newly synthesized hORs.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	232	 First, the turnover rate of the core-glycosylated Mr 45,000 precursor as well as that of the two smaller receptor species of Mr 42,000 and 39,000 was reduced considerably in cells treated with proteasomal inhibitors, lactacystin, MG-132, and PSI.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Second, the amount of the fully mature receptor was increased upon proteasomal inhibition.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Finally, the Mr 39,000 receptor and its polyubiquitinated forms accumulated in the cytoplasm following proteasomal blockade.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Given that the Mr 39,000 receptor species contains the full-length receptor polypeptide, these data support the hypothesis that integral membrane proteins are released completely from the ER membrane prior to proteasomal degradation rather than cleaved partially within the membrane (13-15, 17, 42).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	236	Association of the hOR precursor and that of the two full-length deglycosylated intermediates with the Sec61 translocon supports the recently proposed model, suggesting that retrotranslocation of misfolded or incompletely folded ER proteins to the cytoplasm is mediated by the Sec61 complex (13, 17, 21, 46, 52, 53), the multimeric protein complex that is also responsible for the cotranslational translocation of proteins into the ER (54).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Like the hOR, the major histocompatibility class I molecule and the F508 mutant of the CFTR were found to interact with the Sec61 translocon during their transit out of the ER, which leads to their degradation by the proteasomes (13, 17).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	238	 It can be hypothesized that dislocation of these integral membrane proteins may involve a reverse process of membrane integration involving lateral opening of the translocon toward the lipid bilayer (39, 54).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	239	 However, how these misfolded or incompletely folded proteins are recognized and delivered to the dislocation machinery is unknown.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Similarly, the precise mechanism by which these proteasomal substrates are extracted from the lipid bilayer as well as the origin of the driving force for their retrotranslocation are still unresolved issues.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	241	The finding that the Mr 39,000 hOR degradation intermediate accumulates in the cytosol following lactacystin treatment suggests that proteasomal function is not obligatory for dislocation of membrane proteins from the ER membrane.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	242	 However, this does not rule out the possibility that, in normal conditions (i.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	243	 when proteasomes are not impaired), dislocation and degradation of misfolded or incompletely folded proteins may be tightly coupled events.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	244	 In fact, three observations in the present study suggest coupling between proteasome function and dislocation of proteins from the ER membrane.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	245	 Inhibition of the proteasome was found to: 1) increase the amount and reduce the turnover-rate of the membrane bound Mr 42,000 and 45,000 forms of the receptor, 2) increase the total amount of receptor coimmunoprecipitated with the -subunit of the Sec61 complex, and 3) increase the relative proportion of the translocon-associated Mr 39,000 degradation intermediate that ultimately dislocates from the ER membrane into the cytosol.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Thus, although proteasomal function is not obligatory for dislocation, its impairment appears to lead to attenuation of the process and prolongation of association with the translocon.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	247	 These results are consistent with findings showing that mutant (21) and chimeric (55) transmembrane proteins were stabilized within the ER membrane of yeast mutants expressing functionally impaired proteasomes.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Coupling of dislocation and degradation could be achieved by direct transfer of protein substrates to the proteasomes.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	249	 Indeed, although proteasomes are mainly detected in the cytosol and the nucleus, some have been found to be associated with ER membranes (56).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Coupling of membrane dissociation and proteolysis would clearly increase the efficiency of proteolysis, because direct transfer of the unfolded retrotranslocated proteins to the proteasome would eliminate the need for additional unfolding of the substrate that is a prerequisite for proteasomal degradation (31).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	251	 At the same time, the proteasome itself, via its regulatory subcomplex, PA700, could provide the driving force for the retrotranslocation (31).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Such coupling would also be a very effective way to prevent cytoplasmic aggregation of dislocated membrane proteins.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	253	 In this context, it is noteworthy that proteasomal blockade has been shown to promote the formation of high molecular weight insoluble aggregates (8, 16).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	254	 For example, both wild type and F508 mutant forms of the CFTR were shown to accumulate, together with cytosolic chaperones, in a specific pericentriolar structure, called the aggresome (57, 58).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	255	Inhibition of proteasomal degradation resulted in accumulation of polyubiquitinated forms of the hOR in the cytosol, suggesting that this modification may target the misfolded or incompletely folded receptors to the proteasome.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Based on the finding that a small amount of ubiquitinated receptor forms was detected in the membrane fraction, it can also be envisioned that polyubiquitination could provide a direct signal for proteasome recruitment to the ER membrane.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	257	 However, it is unclear whether ubiquitination is a prerequisite for the rapid breakdown of the receptor, as has been shown for many other integral membrane and secretory proteins that are degraded by the proteasomes.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	258	 For example, many misfolded or unassembled ER proteins were shown to be stabilized by mutant ubiquitin-activating (8, 46, 48) or ubiquitin-conjugating enzymes (9, 10, 18, 20, 21, 59) or by dominant-negative ubiquitin mutants that prevent polyubiquitination of substrate proteins (8-10, 18, 21, 48, 60).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	259	 When considering the enzymes that could be responsible for the ubiquitination of the hOR while it is still membrane-bound, it is noteworthy that two yeast ubiquitin-conjugating enzymes, the Ubc6p and the Ubc7p, have been implicated in the ubiquitination and degradation of ER proteins (9, 10, 18, 20, 21, 28, 59).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Both of these enzymes are localized to the ER, thus possibly enabling ubiquitination of misfolded or incompletely folded proteins prior to their dislocation from the membrane.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	261	 The Ubc6p is an integral membrane protein, which is anchored to the membrane via a C-terminal hydrophobic sequence (61), whereas the Ubc7p is docked onto the membrane protein Cue1p (59).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	262	 In a recent report, several mammalian homologs of the Ubc6p were identified (62).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Whether these enzymes are actually involved in ubiquitination and degradation of ER proteins remains to be determined.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	264	Proteasomal degradation of the hOR is preceded by removal of the two N-linked oligosaccharides from the Mr 45,000 receptor precursor.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	265	 This is in agreement with previous reports on glycoproteins for which proteasomal degradation has been described (13-17, 26, 35, 42, 46).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	266	 Although PNGase-type activity has been detected in both cytosolic and microsomal membrane fractions of mammalian tissues (63, 64), the enzymes mediating the deglycosylation of misfolded or incompletely folded proteins as well as their precise location have remained elusive.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	267	 However, recent cloning of a cytosolic yeast PNGase (65) may be pointing to the first candidate involved in deglycosylation of proteasomal substrates.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	268	 In any case, our data suggest that deglycosylation of the hOR occurs prior to dislocation from the ER membrane and the translocon.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	269	 Indeed, neither the Mr 45,000 receptor precursor nor the partially deglycosylated Mr 42,000 form were found in the cytosolic fraction.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Furthermore, the fully deglycosylated Mr 39,000 degradation intermediate was found to coimmunoprecipitate with the -subunit of the Sec61 complex.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	271	Whether the degradation pathway uncovered for the hOR in the present study is a unique characteristic of this receptor or represents a general mechanism regulating the maturation and cell surface expression of most GPCRs remains an open question.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	272	 Indeed, very little is known about the processes involved in the folding/maturation/degradation of other GPCRs.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	273	 Inhibition of proteasome function was found to lead to an increase in the 2-adrenergic receptor expression in HEK-293 cells (66) and only three GPCRs, rhodopsin (67) and the yeast - and a-mating factor receptors (68, 69), have previously been shown to be ubiquitinated.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	274	 For rhodopsin, no specific role has yet been attributed to the modification whereas ubiquitination has been proposed to be an internalization signal for the activated -mating factor receptor, leading to its lysosomal/vacuolar degradation (68, 70-72).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	275	 Interestingly, monoubiquitination rather than polyubiquitination normally associated with the proteasome degradation pathway appears to be sufficient to promote such internalization (70, 72).
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	276	 It will be interesting to determine whether ubiquitination of the hOR and other mammalian GPCRs can, in addition to its role in the proteasome-mediated degradation of ER-retained receptors, also be implicated in their internalization and lysosomal degradation.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Such a dual role for ubiquitination has been proposed for a number of yeast and mammalian membrane proteins (38) but has not been documented yet for mammalian GPCRs.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	278	Results of the present study support the notion that the cytosolic proteasomal disposal mechanism is involved in the elimination of newly synthesized hORs, resulting ultimately in degradation of even salvageable folding intermediates.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	279	 This raises several important questions.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	280	 For example, it becomes important to determine the mechanisms by which the stringent ER monitoring system discriminates conformational variants of the receptor and sorts them either for degradation or allows their transport downstream within the secretory pathway.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	281	 Future studies are also needed to identify the pathways and components that facilitate folding of the receptor and to determine whether these are under the control of dynamic regulatory processes.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Although inhibiting proteasomal function favored ER export and maturation of the receptor, a large proportion of the newly synthesized receptors still remained entrapped within the ER.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	283	 Whether approaches acting at earlier off-pathway steps could be more effective in enhancing receptor folding still remains to be investigated.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	284	 Rapoport (Harvard Medical School, Boston) for providing us the anti-Sec61 antibody.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Thierry Groblewski for critical reading of the manuscript.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	286	* This work was supported in part by grants from the Medical Research Council of Canada (to M.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	287	) and from the Ella and Georg Ehrnrooth Foundation, the Helsinki University Pharmacy, and the Oulu University Scholarship Foundation (to U.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	288	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	289	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	290	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.

0.44344512.11054417.html.plaintext.txt	299	The abbreviations used are: ER, endoplasmic reticulum; CFTR, cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator; DDM, n-dodecyl--D-maltoside; DMEM, Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium; GPCR, G protein-coupled receptor; hOR, human  opioid receptor; HEK-293S, human embryonic kidney 293S; Hsp70, heat shock protein 70; MG-132, Z-Leu-Leu-Leu-CHO; NEM, N-ethylmaleimide; PAGE, polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis; PMSF, phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride; PNGase F, peptide-N-glycosidase F; PSI, Z-Ile-Glu(OtBu)-Ala-Leu-CHO; STI, soybean trypsin inhibitor.
