0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	358	 99, 11211 to 11216[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	0	Improved oxygenation promotes CFTR maturation and trafficking in MDCK monolayers Zsuzsanna Bebok1,2, Albert Tousson3, Lisa M.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	1	Departments of 1 Medicine, 4 Physiology and Biophysics, and 3 Cell Biology and 2 Gregory Fleming James Cystic Fibrosis Research Center, University of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, Alabama 35294-0005.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	2	    ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	3	Culturing airway epithelial cells with most of the apical media removed (air-liquid interface) has been shown to enhance cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR)-mediated Cl secretory current.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Thus we hypothesized that cellular oxygenation may modulate CFTR expression.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	5	 We tested this notion using type I Madin-Darby canine kidney cells that endogenously express low levels of CFTR.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Growing monolayers of these cells for 4 to 5 days with an air-liquid interface caused a 50-fold increase in forskolin-stimulated Cl current, compared with conventional (submerged) controls.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Assaying for possible changes in CFTR by immunoprecipitation and immunocytochemical localization revealed that CFTR appeared as an immature 140-kDa form intracellularly in conventional cultures.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	8	 In contrast, monolayers grown with an air-liquid interface possessed more CFTR protein, accompanied by increases toward the mature 170-kDa form and apical membrane staining.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Culturing submerged monolayers with 95% O2 produced similar improvements in Cl current and CFTR protein as air-liquid interface culture, while increasing PO2 from 2.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	10	5% to 20% in air-liquid interface cultures yielded graded enhancements.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Together, our data indicate that improved cellular oxygenation can increase endogenous CFTR maturation and/or trafficking.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	12	cystic fibrosis; cellular polarization; hypoxia; cell culture methods.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	13	    INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	14	CYSTIC FIBROSIS TRANSMEMBRANE CONDUCTANCE REGULATOR (CFTR) is an epithelial anion channel that requires cAMP-dependent phosphorylation plus intracellular ATP to open (19, 46, 50).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	15	 These channels are normally expressed in the apical membranes of epithelial cells lining the airways, intestines, pancreatic ducts, and kidney tubules (19, 46, 33, 56).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Mutations in the gene coding for CFTR impair epithelial Cl and HCO3 transport and cause cystic fibrosis (CF).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Most CF patients ( > 90%) have an allele coding for a mutant CFTR that lacks phenylalanine at the 508 position (19, 46).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	18	 F508 CFTR retains function as a protein kinase A- and ATP-regulated anion channel (9) but is absent from the plasma membranes of most cells used for heterologous expression (6, 14).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Hence, many CF patients are expected to benefit from increased F508-CFTR expression.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	20	 (34, 35) identified an important caveat regarding heterologous expression of CFTR.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Specifically, they showed that wild-type CFTR was not present in the plasma membranes of HT-29 intestinal epithelial cells unless the cells were confluent and polarized.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Furthermore, the change in CFTR localization to the cell surface was not mediated by a change in transcription or translation, since polarized and nonpolarized HT-29 cells contained similar amounts of CFTR mRNA and protein (34, 35).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	23	 These data suggest that the trafficking of CFTR to the apical cell surface is highly regulated.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	24	 There are also a number of reports showing that detectable amounts of endogenous CFTR protein is present at the apical membranes of epithelial cells from F508-homozygous CF patients (14, 15, 28, 44, 49, 62).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Thus it is likely that additional factors regulate endogenous CFTR maturation and cell surface localization in epithelial cells.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	26	 The aims of this study were to test this hypothesis and to gain some insight regarding how endogenous CFTR expression may be increased.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	27	Growing primary or immortalized airway epithelial cells on filters with nearly all of the apical fluid removed has been shown to cause a six- to eightfold increase in CFTR-mediated anion secretion compared with conventional (submerged) controls (30, 52).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	28	 This maneuver has been referred to as air-liquid interface culture (27, 31, 36, 41, 43) or air interface culture (30, 52).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	29	 The mediator responsible for the increased Cl or HCO3 secretory response following air-liquid interface culture and its possible effects on CFTR remains unknown.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Since most conventional cell cultures are hypoxic (8, 12, 40, 59), we hypothesized that improved cellular oxygenation may enhance CFTR expression.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	31	We used a subclone of the Madin-Darby canine kidney (MDCK) cell line as a model to test this hypothesis.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	32	 MDCK cells from American Type Culture Collection (23) consist of at least two strains or types (38, 45).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Type I MDCK cells form high-resistance monolayers that demonstrate small Cl secretory currents following addition of cAMP-mediated agonists, whereas type II MDCK cells form low-resistance monolayers and do not respond to cAMP (5, 32, 45, 51).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Recent studies indicate that type I clones endogenously express small amounts of CFTR under conventional culture conditions (32).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Thus subclones of type I MDCK cells may provide a good model to test for possible enhancement of CFTR expression.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	36	In the present study, we show that culturing type I MDCK cells with an air-liquid interface caused a 50-fold increase in forskolin-stimulated Cl secretion over a period of 4-5 days in culture.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	37	 On the basis of this observation, we then tested the notion that the increased Cl secretory response was mediated by enhanced CFTR expression.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Finally, we exposed submerged or air-liquid interface cultures to varying amounts of O2 to determine whether the effects of air-liquid interface culture were mediated by improved oxygenation.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	39	 The data presented here show that increasing oxygen from hypoxic to atmospheric levels markedly enhanced CFTR maturation and apical membrane localization.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Our observations have important implications since cultured cells (39, 47, 53, 59) and CF patients (18, 24, 57) are often hypoxic.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	41	    MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	42	MDCK-AA7 cells and culture methods.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	43	 We obtained the type I MDCK subclone, MDCK-AA7 (16, 38), from the University of Alabama at Birmingham Cystic Fibrosis Research Center.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	44	 of Physiology, East Tennessee State Univ.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	45	) also kindly provided MDCK-AA7 cells for study (16).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	46	 We grew these cells in MEM containing Earle's salts, L-glutamine, and nonessential amino acids (GIBCO BRL, Grand Island, NY), supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (Atlanta Biologicals, Norcross, GA or HyClone, Logan, UT) (23).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Medium was aspirated and replaced at 2-day intervals.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	48	Cells were passaged by pretreatment with a Ca2+- and Mg2+-free phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) that contained 1 mM EDTA for 20-30 min, followed by a 10-min incubation in the same PBS plus 0.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Dispersed cells were seeded at a density of 2-7  x  104 cells/cm2 on 0.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	50	45- microm Millicell-HA filters (Millipore, Bedford, MA) or 0.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	51	40- microm Falcon PET filters (Becton Dickinson, Franklin Lakes, NJ) for use in experiments.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	52	 MDCK-AA7 cells were maintained with fluid on both sides for 1 wk after seeding to permit monolayer formation.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Thereafter, most of the apical media were gently aspirated and not replaced.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Previous studies have shown that airway cells grown under these conditions remained hydrated by a thin (~15  microm) fluid layer (27).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Some filters were maintained in conventional (submerged) culture to serve as controls.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	56	 In initial studies, cells were grown in a humidified incubator that contained 5% CO2-95% room air at 37 degrees C.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	57	 In some later experiments, filters were cultured in sealed plastic chambers that were gassed daily with mixtures of 5% CO2 and 2.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	58	2%, 12%, 20%, or 95% O2 plus balance N2 to test for possible effects of cellular oxygenation.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Reductions in PO2 were verified by testing the media with an Instrumentation Laboratory 1640 blood gas analyzer.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	60	Transepithelial short-circuit current measurements.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Filters were mounted in modified Ussing chambers (Jim's Instruments, Iowa City, IA) and bathed on both sides with identical HEPES-buffered saline solutions that contained (in mM) 130 NaCl, 5 sodium pyruvate, 4 KCl, 1 CaCl2, 1 MgCl2, 5 D-glucose, and 5 HEPES-NaOH (pH 7.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Bath solutions were stirred vigorously and gassed with room air.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Solution temperature was maintained at 37 degrees C.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Short-circuit current (Isc) measurements were obtained by using an epithelial voltage clamp (VCC-600; Physiologic Instruments, San Diego, CA).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	65	 A 10-mV pulse of 1-s duration was imposed every 100 s to monitor the transepithelial resistance (Rt), which was calculated using Ohm's law.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Amiloride (100  microM) was routinely added to the apical solutions to abolish Na+ absorption (3).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Forskolin (10  microM) was then added to both bathing solutions to stimulate cAMP-mediated Cl secretion (51).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Cl secretory currents were identified on the basis of activation by forskolin and by sensitivity to basolateral BaCl2 (5 mM), bumetanide (10  microM), or ouabain (100  microM) (1, 5, 10, 51).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	69	 All drugs were added as a small volume of a concentrated stock solution.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	70	5 M), and ouabain (10 mM) stocks were made up in water.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Forskolin (10 mM) was dissolved in ethanol while bumetanide (3 mM) was dissolved in 0.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	72	 The methods used to immunoprecipitate CFTR have been previously described in detail (2, 42).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Briefly, cells were washed with ice-cold PBS that contained 1 mM CaCl2 and MgCl2 and lysed in a buffer that contained 150 mM NaCl, 20 mM HEPES, 1 mM EDTA, and 1% Nonidet P-40, supplemented with a protease inhibitor cocktail (Complete mini; Boehringer Mannheim, Indianapolis, IN).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Protein concentration was determined using Protein Assay Reagent (Bio-Rad).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Lysates that contained 300  microg of total protein were then immunoprecipitated at 4 degrees C for 2 h using an anti-CFTR COOH-terminal monoclonal antibody (Genzyme, Framington, MA) and protein G-agarose beads (Boehringer Mannheim).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Immunoprecipitated proteins were phosphorylated using [32P]ATP (DuPont-NEN) plus the catalytic subunit of cAMP-dependent protein kinase (Promega) and separated on 6% polyacrylamide gels (Novex).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Gels were placed on a PhosphoScreen and analyzed with a PhosphorImager (Molecular Dynamics).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Images were further processed using IPLab Spectrum software (Signal Analytics).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	79	CFTR localization by confocal immunofluorescence microscopy.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	80	 MDCK-AA7 cells were grown on transparent cyclopore filters (Falcon).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Two primary anti-CFTR antibodies were used: a rabbit polyclonal antibody against the first nucleotide binding domain (NBD) that was kindly provided by Dr.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	82	 of Alabama at Birmingham) (2, 42) and a monoclonal antibody specific to the regulatory domain (R-domain) from Genzyme.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Monolayers probed with anti-NBD antibody were fixed initially in methanol at 20 degrees C.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Monolayers probed with anti-R-domain antibody underwent preliminary fixation in methanol:acetic acid (3:1) at 20 degrees C.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Formaldehyde (3%) in PBS was used to complete fixation for all specimens.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Nonspecific protein binding was blocked with 1% (wt/vol) bovine serum albumin.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Oregon green-labeled anti-rabbit IgG or Texas red X-labeled anti-mouse IgG (Molecular Probes) were used as secondary antibodies.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Samples were counterstained with the nuclear dye bisbenzimide.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Filters were cut and folded cell-side out during mounting to enable cross-sectional views (35).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	90	 CFTR immunolocalization was examined using an Olympus IX70 inverted epifluorescence microscope equipped with a step motor, filter wheel assembly (Ludl Electronics Products, Hawthorn, NY), and 83,000 filter set (Chroma Technology, Brattleboro, VT).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Images were captured with a SenSys-cooled charge-coupled device high-resolution digital camera (Photometrics, Tucson, AZ).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Partial deconvolution of images was performed using IPLab Spectrum software (Scanalytics, Fairfax, VA).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	93	Analysis of CFTR mRNA by RT-PCR.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Total RNA was isolated from filter-grown MDCK-AA7 monolayers using TRIzol (GIBCO BRL).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Contamination of genomic DNA was eliminated using 1 U DNase (GIBCO BRL) per microgram of total RNA.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	96	 One microgram of the DNase-treated RNA was then reverse transcribed in a reaction that contained 200 U Moloney murine leukemia virus RT (GIBCO BRL), 0.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	97	5 mM dNTP, and 25 U RNase inhibitor (RNAsin; Promega, Madison, WI).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	98	 cDNA samples were amplified for CFTR in a reaction that contained 0.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	99	2  microg cDNA, 1 U Taq polymerase (Perkin Elmer, Norwalk, CT), 200  microM dNTP, and 20 pmol each of the following PCR primers: 5'-GAG GAC ACT GCT CCT ACA C-3' and 5'-CAG ATT AGC CCC ATG AGG AG-3' (GIBCO BRL).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	100	 These primers span the region between CFTR nt 531 and 778.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Reactions for CFTR were cycled as follows: initial melt at 95 degrees C for 5 min, 40 cycles of 95 degrees C for 1 min, 58 degrees C for 1 min, 72 degrees C for 2 min, and a final extension at 72 degrees C for 10 min.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	102	 The expected size for the CFTR product is 248 bp.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	103	We amplified the cDNA products for the housekeeping gene -actin as a control.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Amplification of -actin consisted of mixing 0.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	105	2  microg of each cDNA sample with 1 U Taq polymerase (Perkin Elmer), 200 mM dNTP, and 20 pmol each of the PCR primers: 5'-TGA CGG GGT CAC CCA CAC TGT GCC CAT CTA-3' and 5'-CTA GAA GCA TTG CGG TGG ACG ATG GAG GG-3' (GIBCO BRL).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	106	 These primers span nucleotides from 2133 to 2822 of the -actin cDNA.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	107	 PCR reactions for -actin were cycled with an initial melt at 95 degrees C for 5 min; 30 cycles of 95 degrees C for 30 s; 46 degrees C for 1 min; 72 degrees C for 1 min; and a final extension at 72 degrees C for 10 min.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	108	 The expected fragment size for the -actin product is 690 bp.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Salts, buffers, and all other reagents were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich unless otherwise noted.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Aqueous solutions were made with MILLI-Q water (Millipore).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	111	    RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	112	Air-liquid interface culture induces a large Cl secretory response in MDCK-AA7 monolayers.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Figure 1 compares representative Isc records from MDCK-AA7 monolayers grown either with the apical side submerged by culture medium (solid line) or with an apical air-liquid interface for 4 days (dashed line).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Forskolin (10  microM) was added to both sides to increase cellular cAMP (43).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	115	 The forskolin-stimulated currents were inhibited by basolateral addition of either barium (5 mM, see Fig.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	116	 1), bumetanide (10  microM, not shown), or ouabain (100  microM, not shown).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	117	 The effects of forskolin, barium, bumetanide, and ouabain indicate that the forskolin-stimulated Isc provides a direct measure of electrogenic Cl secretion (1, 5, 10, 45, 51, 52, 60).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	118	 These results also agree with those of previous studies of type I MDCK cells (5, 45, 51).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Electrogenic Na+ absorption did not contribute to Isc, since apical amiloride (100  microM) had no effect on Isc when added before (Fig.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	120	 1) or after forskolin (not shown).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Both filters that produced the records shown in Fig.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	122	 1 were seeded with ~5  x  104 cells/cm2, and both were cultured under standard conditions for 1 wk.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	123	 One monolayer was then exposed to an air-liquid interface for 4 days by having most of the apical fluid removed and not replaced, while the other monolayer remained submerged under  > 2.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Thus the imposition of an apical air-liquid interface for 4 days markedly enhanced forskolin-stimulated Cl secretion.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	125	View larger version (9K):    Fig.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	126	   Comparison of the forskolin-stimulated short-circuit current (Isc) across a Madin-Darby canine kidney (MDCK)-AA7 monolayer cultured for 4 days with an apical air-liquid interface (dashed line) or with a paired medium-submerged control (solid line).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	127	 The Millicell-HA filters with attached monolayers were bathed on both sides with identical HEPES-buffered saline solutions and voltage clamped to 0 mV as described in MATERIALS AND METHODS.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Amiloride (100  microM) was used to abolish possible Isc due to active Na+ absorption (3).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Forskolin (10  microM) was then added to both sides to increase cellular cAMP and stimulate electrogenic Cl secretion (52).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	130	 We added basolateral BaCl2 (5 mM) to inhibit Cl secretory currents (1).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Amiloride, forskolin, and BaCl2 were present continuously in the bathing solutions following addition.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	132	 The maximum Isc response was 1  microA/cm2 for the monolayer culture fluid submerged, compared with 47.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	133	2  microA/cm2 for the monolayer cultured with an air-liquid interface.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	134	 This experiment has been repeated  > 60 times with similar results (also see Fig.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	135	Figure 2 summarizes the relationships between the forskolin-stimulated Isc or basal Rt and number of days that monolayers were grown with an air-liquid interface.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	136	 All of the time-paired submerged controls (n = 24) behaved similarly and are plotted at day 0.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Figure 2 (left) shows that growing MDCK-AA7 cells with an apical air-liquid interface caused a 50-fold increase in forskolin-stimulated Cl secretion that plateaued between days 4 and 5.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	138	 In contrast, the control monolayers grown by conventional technique possessed relatively small forskolin-stimulated currents (0.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	139	 The enhanced response observed in air-liquid interface-grown monolayers compared with cells grown by conventional culture suggests that CFTR Cl channel activity increased.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	140	View larger version (13K):    Fig.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	141	   The forskolin-stimulated short-circuit current (Isc-forskolin) and basal transepithelial resistance (Rt) plotted as a function of the number of days the monolayers were cultured with most of the apical media removed (air-liquid interface).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Isc-forskolin was calculated as the difference between the basal or resting Isc and the maximum Isc that was evoked by forskolin (10  microM).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	143	 1 and MATERIALS AND METHODS for further details regarding the experimental design and conditions.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Rt was calculated from the magnitude of the current pulse arising from a 10-mV change in holding potential using Ohm's law.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	145	 The basal Rt before forskolin addition provides an estimate of the junctional resistance.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	146	 All of the time-paired controls (n = 24) behaved similarly, having low forskolin-stimulated Isc (0.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	147	4  microA/cm2) and high Rt (2,250  plus or minus  650 cm2).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	148	 These data were combined and are plotted as the initial (day 0) points; n = 7 for all other points, and error bars depict SD.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	149	Comparison of the amount, biochemical form, and subcellular localization of CFTR.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	150	 One possible explanation for the results shown in the previous section is that growth with an air-liquid interface increased the number of CFTR Cl channels in the apical membranes.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	151	 As an initial test of this hypothesis, immunoprecipitation was used to determine whether air-liquid interface culture had any effect on the amount and/or biochemical properties of CFTR.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Figure 3 compares the immunoprecipitated CFTR derived from conventional, fluid-immersed monolayers (fluid) with the CFTR obtained from air-interface monolayers (air).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	153	 CFTR immunoprecipitated from filter-grown T84 cells served as a control (1, 10).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Submerged MDCK-AA7 monolayers expressed only a small amount of CFTR.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Furthermore, much of the protein from submerged monolayers had an electrophoretic mobility corresponding to a 140-kDa molecular weight protein.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	156	 In contrast, the MDCK-AA7 monolayers grown with an air-liquid interface for 5 days showed an increase in total CFTR protein level as well as a shift toward a higher molecular weight (~170 kDa).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Previous studies indicate that a 140-kDa band B form of CFTR represents an immature, core-glycosylated protein, whereas a 170-kDa band C form is fully glycosylated (6, 14).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Thus the increase in the total amount of CFTR protein and the increase in molecular weight following air-liquid interface culture suggest that the 50-fold increase in forskolin-stimulated Isc is mediated, at least in part, by enhanced maturation.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	159	View larger version (41K):    Fig.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	160	   Immunoprecipitation of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) from lysates of MDCK-AA7 cells grown either fluid submerged (fluid) or with an air-liquid interface (air) for 5 days.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	161	 32P-phosphorylated CFTR immunoprecipitates were derived from equivalent amounts of lysates from either MDCK-AA7 monolayers cultured under these 2 conditions or control T84 cells using an anti-CFTR COOH-terminal antibody.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	162	 We treated the MDCK-AA7 air-liquid interface lysate with preimmune serum as a negative control.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Samples were analyzed on a 6% polyacrylamide SDS gel.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	164	 These data are representative of 4 experiments.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	165	Next, we performed immunocytochemistry and digital confocal microscopy to gain insight regarding possible changes in CFTR staining patterns following air-liquid interface culture.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Figure 4 compares monolayers cultured either conventionally (submerged) or exposed to an air-liquid interface for 6 days.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	167	 On the basis of the immunoprecipitation data shown in Fig.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	168	 3 and previous studies (2, 6, 14, 46), we expected CFTR to be located intracellularly in MDCK-AA7 monolayers grown using conventional methodology.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Indeed, punctate CFTR immunofluorescence was localized within a perinuclear compartment of the submerged cells.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Together, the results shown in Figs.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	171	 3 and 4 suggest that CFTR protein is translated but not fully processed and/or trafficked to the cell surface in submerged monolayers.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	172	 4 (right; air-liquid interface) shows that considerable amounts of CFTR were present at the apical membranes of MDCK-AA7 monolayers grown without apical media for 6 days.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	173	View larger version (110K):    Fig.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	174	   CFTR immunolocalization in monolayers either grown under conventional conditions (submerged) for 13 days or submerged for 1 wk followed by an apical air-liquid interface for 6 days.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	175	 We used 2 different primary antibodies raised against CFTR that are labeled R-Domain or Nucleotide Binding Domain (NBD).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	176	 The anti-CFTR antibodies were then labeled with either Texas red X (R-Domain) or Oregon green 488, and the nuclei counterstained blue with bisbenzimide.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Fixed and immunologically stained monolayers were folded to permit the cross-sectional views shown above the en face views.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	178	 All images were obtained at the same magnification, and the bar = 40  microm.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	179	Analysis of CFTR mRNA between submerged and air-liquid interface monolayers by RT-PCR.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	180	 We then performed semiquantitative RT-PCR analysis to determine whether air-interface culture augmented CFTR transcription.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Figure 5 shows representative results.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Triplicate monolayers were assayed for CFTR mRNA after either 2 or 4 days of growth with an apical air-liquid interface (air).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	183	 These were compared with time-matched triplicate fluid-submerged monolayers (fluid).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	184	 All MDCK-AA7 monolayers contained low levels of CFTR mRNA compared with control 16HBE14o airway cells (60).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	185	 These results are consistent with other studies showing that only low levels of CFTR mRNA can be detected in native epithelial cells (55, 61).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Furthermore, the data presented in Fig.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	187	 5 show that the 50-fold increase in forskolin-stimulated Isc (Figs.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	188	 1 and 2) and the change in CFTR protein (Figs.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	189	 3 and 4) observed after air-liquid interface culture were not accompanied by a 50-fold enhancement of CFTR mRNA.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	190	 These data are consistent with the changes in CFTR mobility and cellular localization shown in the previous section that strongly implicate a posttranscriptional mechanism.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	191	View larger version (57K):    Fig.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	192	   Expression of CFTR mRNA in submerged (fluid) vs.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	193	 air-liquid interface (air) MDCK-AA7 cultures as determined by RT-PCR.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	194	 cDNA derived from triplicate MDCK-AA7 monolayers was amplified for CFTR with specific primers spanning the region between nt 531 and 778 (248 bp fragment).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	195	 cDNA derived from the 16HBE14o airway cell line was amplified for CFTR as a positive control (lane +); a reaction containing no template was included as a negative control (lane ).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Samples were also amplified for -actin (690-bp fragment) to control for RNA degradation during DNase treatment and reverse transcription.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	197	 M, lanes containing 100-bp markers.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	198	Improvements in forskolin-stimulated Isc and CFTR expression are oxygen mediated.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Removing the fluid from the apical surface of epithelial cells will give rise to a transepithelial hydrostatic pressure gradient, decrease the luminal volume, possibly dry and irritate the monolayer, increase apical cytokines, and permit more oxygen to reach the cells.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	200	 To test the hypothesis that improved cellular oxygenation mediates the increase in CFTR maturation and cell surface expression, we cultured submerged MDCK-AA7 monolayers in a humidified atmosphere containing 95% O2 plus 5% CO2 for 5-6 days.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Figure 6 compares representative records from monolayers grown under identical conditions except for the culture atmosphere, which contained either 95% O2 (dashed line) or room O2 (solid line).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	202	 The forskolin-activated current observed following 5-6 days of incubation with 95% oxygen (48  plus or minus  4  microA/cm2, n = 6) was markedly elevated compared with the control.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	203	 The results with 95% O2 are comparable to the paired control 5- to 6-day responses for air-liquid interface cultures (40.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Since both monolayers were grown under identical conditions except for a fivefold increase in PO2, we conclude that increased oxygen mediates the 50-fold increase in Cl secretion.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Immunoprecipitation and immunolocalization of CFTR further revealed that culturing submerged monolayers with 95% oxygen produced similar changes in the mobility and cellular localization of CFTR as air-liquid interface culture (data not shown, also refer to Fig.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	206	View larger version (9K):    Fig.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	207	   A fivefold increase in atmospheric O2 enhances CFTR-mediated Isc across submerged MDCK-AA7 monolayers.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	208	 These records show 2 representative experiments comparing the effect of forskolin (10  microM) on Isc across submerged filters cultured with either 95% oxygen and 5% CO2 for 5 days (dashed line) or with room air plus 5% CO2 (solid line).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Both monolayers were submerged by ~200  microl of media on the apical side corresponding to a depth of ~2.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	210	 This experiment was repeated 6 times with similar results (see text).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Additional details regarding the experimental design and methods are provided in the legend for Fig.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	212	These data demonstrate that CFTR cell surface expression is increased by improved oxygenation in MDCK-AA7 cells.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	213	 However, it is not certain from the data shown in Fig.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	214	 if this enhancement occurs at hypoxic, normoxic, or hyperoxic levels.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Thus we grew air-liquid interface cultures in atmospheres containing 2.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	216	2%, 12%, or 20% O2 plus 5% CO2 and balance N2 for 4-5 days.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Figure 7 summarizes data from functional studies.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	218	 This plot shows that forskolin-stimulated Isc increased in a graded manner over the range of PO2 tested.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Results obtained from submerged monolayers (L) are plotted for comparison.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Parallel studies were performed to assay for possible dose-dependent effects on CFTR protein using immunoprecipitation, and a representative gel is presented in Fig.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	221	 These data show that increasing PO2 enhanced the ~170-kDa form of CFTR.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	222	 The oxygen dependence of the increase in CFTR glycosylation was quantified by densitometry as shown in Fig.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Using the change in CFTR function (Fig.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	224	 8) as a bioassay further suggests that conventional cultures of MDCK-AA7 cells are hypoxic.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Finally, these data demonstrate that CFTR maturation and function at the cell surface can be increased over pathophysiological to physiological levels of cellular oxygenation.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	226	View larger version (14K):    Fig.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	227	   Isc-forskolin demonstrates a graded response to increased oxygenation.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Air-liquid interface cultures of MDCK-AA7 were exposed to atmospheres that contained 2.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Each point represents the mean from 5 experiments, and error bars show SD.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	230	 The response from conventional (submerged) monolayers (L) is plotted for comparison.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Refer to MATERIALS AND METHODS and the legend for Fig.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	232	 1 for additional information regarding experimental conditions and design.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	233	View larger version (52K):    Fig.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	234	   CFTR protein maturation shows a graded response to increased O2 in air-liquid interface cultures.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	235	 The top panel shows the CFTR immunoprecipitated from equivalent amounts of lysates from MDCK-AA7 cells cultured with an air-liquid interface in atmospheres that contained 2.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	236	2%, 12%, or 20% O2 (refer to Fig.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	237	 The immunoprecipitated protein from submerged monolayers (L) is plotted for comparison.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	238	 The control experiment with atmospheric (20%) O2 was performed  > 7 times, and the increase in the higher mobility form of CFTR in this figure is not typical (refer to the lane with 12% O2 and Fig.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Densitometry was used to quantify the increase in CFTR protein maturation to the ~170-kDa form as shown (bottom).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	240	Reducing the apical media volume in culture increases forskolin-stimulated Isc.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	241	 Since CFTR maturation and cell surface expression are augmented by oxygen in MDCK-AA7 cells, we further predict that the forskolin-stimulated Isc should increase as the volume of apical media is decreased.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	242	 This prediction is based on the notion that the apical media acts as a barrier to oxygen diffusion (refer to DISCUSSION).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	243	 We tested this hypothesis by growing MDCK-AA7 cells for 6 days with 40, 80, 160, or 300  microl of apical MEM and then assaying for forskolin-stimulated Isc.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	244	 These data are summarized in Fig.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	245	 Indeed, the CFTR-mediated Isc (Isc-forskolin) increased with decreasing volumes of media (left), and the plot of Isc-forskolin as a function of volume1 is suggestive of a linear relationship (right).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	246	 The minimum depth tested that permitted maximum current was ~0.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	247	 Moreover, these data show that even modest changes in media volume (i.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	248	,  < 20  microl) markedly altered this measure of CFTR activity.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	249	 Thus we have identified an important caveat regarding the study of endogenous CFTR expression using conventional cell culture technique.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	250	View larger version (10K):    Fig.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	251	   Relationship between apical fluid volume and CFTR-mediated Cl secretory response.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	252	 We grew monolayers with 40, 80, 160, or 300  microl of medium on the apical side for 6 days (surface area = 0.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	253	 The left panel plots the forskolin-stimulated Isc as a function of apical media volume ().
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Results from air-liquid interface cultures are shown for comparison ().
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	255	 To further define this relationship, we plotted the forskolin-stimulated Isc as a function of apical fluid volume1 as shown (right).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	256	 The line illustrates the fit of the data by simple linear regression (r = 0.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	257	 Each point represents the mean, and error bars represent SD of 4 experiments.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	258	    DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	259	Hypoxia conditions in culture can have important consequences regarding CFTR trafficking and function.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	260	 The large unstirred layer of medium overlaying cells in culture limits the amount of oxygen available for cellular respiration.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	261	 Figure 10 illustrates how the partial pressure of O2 will vary as a linear relation of the media depth (d), given a steady state.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	262	 This relationship is derived from a simple force-flow relation (i.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	263	, Fick's law) (1) where the flow of oxygen (JO2, in units of milliliters per minute per cm2 of cells) is directly proportional to the difference between PO2 at the air-media interface [(PO2)air] and the cells [(PO2)cell] and the O2 diffusion constant of Krough for water at 37 degrees C (k = 3.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	264	4  x  105) (53), and is inversely related the media depth (d).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	265	 Since oxygen flow (JO2) and consumption (r) are equivalent at steady state, rearrangement of Eq.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	266	 1 yields (2) Stevens (53) derived this equation, estimated the rate of oxygen consumption for freshly isolated, confluent hepatocytes (r = 1.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	267	6  x  104 ml O2/min), and calculated that the fluid depth should not exceed 0.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	268	34 mm to maintain cellular PO2 within the low to normal range (i.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	269	 Indeed, monolayers of L cells cultured in excess of this depth were shown to be hypoxic by polarographic analysis (59).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	270	 More recently, Ostrowski and Nettesheim (41) varied the media overlaying airway cells and found that the maximum depth permitting airway ciliogenesis to be 0.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	271	5 mm, which is consistent with the value calculated by Stevens (0.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	272	34) as well as our results shown in Fig.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	273	View larger version (13K):    Fig.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	274	   Model illustrating the expected relationship between the partial pressure of oxygen (PO2) in cell culture and the fluid (media) depth (d).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	275	 This model is based on a linear force-flow relation (e.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	276	, Fick's law) and assumes that oxygen diffusion and utilization have reached steady state.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	277	Maneuvers that improve oxygenation in cultures either by stirring the overlaying fluid layer using a rocking shaker (12, 47) or rolling bottle (20) or by reducing the medium depth with an air-liquid interface (27, 30, 36, 41, 43, 52, 54) enhance cellular growth, proliferation, and differentiation in a variety of cells.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	278	 Hypoxia can also have important functional consequences.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	279	 For example, monolayers of kidney proximal tubule epithelial cells are only gluconeogenic (39) and ammoniagenic (8) as observed in vivo when cells are cultured in the presence of increased oxygen levels.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	280	 Similarly, pancreatic -cells have been shown to release insulin only in normoxic cultures (13).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	281	 The data contained in the present study demonstrate that improved cellular oxygenation markedly augments CFTR function, maturation, and localization in a model cell line.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	282	Assuming that MDCK-AA7 cells consume oxygen at a similar rate as hepatic (53), LLC-PK1 (8), 3T3 (53), or L cells (59), Eq.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	283	 2 predicts that confluent MDCK-AA7 monolayers submerged under our conventional conditions (i.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	284	 We further expect that either removing the apical media or culturing these monolayers with an approximate fivefold increase in oxygen should restore cellular PO2 to approximately normoxic levels (53).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Indeed, both maneuvers caused similar increases in CFTR-mediated Isc and cell surface expression.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	286	 However, these data do not exclude the alternative hypothesis that conventional cultures are normoxic and that the effects of 95% O2 were mediated by hyperoxia (58).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	287	 Thus we exposed air-liquid interface cultures to varying PO2 (Figs.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	288	 The use of CFTR as a bioassay indicates that conventional MDCK-AA7 cultures are hypoxic, as predicted by Eq.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	289	 Furthermore, these data show that CFTR maturation and function varies with physiological oxygenation.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	290	 Interestingly, the increase in PO2 between arterial and venous blood may cause a two- to threefold enhancement of CFTR expression.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	291	Comparing CFTR expression between cell lines.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	292	 One question that arises from this study is, Why do conventional culture conditions nearly abolish CFTR expression in MDCK-AA7 cells, whereas T84 cells grown under identical conditions express high levels of mature CFTR protein (refer to Fig.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	293	 3)? One possible explanation comes from previous studies by Dickman and Mandel (12) and others showing that the poor oxygenation in culture favors the proliferation and growth of cells with enhanced glycolysis (4, 12, 37, 40).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	294	 The selection and evolution in vitro is expected to be driven further by media formulated with high glucose (25 mM) and containing few substrates for oxidative phosphorylation.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	295	 Indeed, T84 cells express few mitochondria (T.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	296	 Hence differences in metabolism should be considered in future studies of wild-type and mutant CFTR.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	297	Moreover, the ability of air-liquid interface culture to increase cAMP-dependent Cl secretion is not limited to MDCK-AA7 cells.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	298	 An augmented Cl secretory response following air-liquid interface culture has been observed in three cell lines; Calu-3 (52), MDCK-AA7 (this article), and several T84 clones (Venglarik, unpublished data) as well as in primary cultures of airway epithelial cells (Ref.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	299	 30 and Venglarik, unpublished data).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	300	 The observation that CFTR-expressing epithelial cells derived from airways, kidney, and colon respond similarly to air-liquid interface culture is suggestive of a relationship between oxygen tension and Cl secretion in vivo.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	301	 It is also likely that the mediator and cellular mechanisms underlying the enhanced Cl secretory Isc are the same.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	302	 Hence, this study provides important new insight regarding a relationship between cellular oxygenation and CFTR maturation and trafficking and identifies a model cell line to further investigate the underlying mechanisms.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	303	Possible role of metabolism in CFTR expression.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	304	 Previous studies show that vectorial transport is reduced by conditions that decrease oxidative phosphorylation, presumably to preserve cellular integrity (7,17).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	305	 Therefore, we favor the hypothesis that oxygen-induced increase in CFTR expression in MDCK-AA7 cells may also be related to improved metabolism.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	306	 We and others have shown that decreasing the cellular ATP/ADP ratio can acutely limit Cl secretion by reducing the open probability of the CFTR Cl channels (19, 50).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	307	 The results presented in this article are suggestive of a more long-term mechanism whereby a decrease in oxygen can reduce the number of CFTR channels present in the apical membrane.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	308	 Such an adaption may help conserve energy either during prolonged periods of moderate hypoxia or under conditions where ATP is being consumed by either vectorial transport or other metabolic pathways (17).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	309	 There is already evidence that air-liquid interface culture markedly increases oxidative phosphorylation in primary cultures of bovine airway cells (31).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	310	 MDCK-AA7 cells should provide a convenient model for future studies investigating the precise relationship between cellular metabolism and CFTR expression.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	311	 We have identified an important source of variability in CFTR cell surface localization that may explain why some cells have F508 CFTR at the plasma membranes while others have none.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	312	 Indeed, many freshly isolated epithelial cells and cultured epithelial cells grown with an air-liquid interface have functionally or biochemically detectable levels of F508 CFTR at the cell surface (14, 28, 44, 49, 60, 62), whereas most conventional cultures do not (6, 11, 21, 25).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	313	 (49) were the first to demonstrate that the 180-kDa form of F508 CFTR was expressed in the apical membranes of primary and immortalized CF cell lines (49).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	314	 On the basis of the oxygen dependence of wild-type CFTR expression in MDCK-AA7 cells, we consider it likely that some of the variation in F508 CFTR cell surface expression is due to hypoxic culture conditions.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	315	Furthermore, although there is evidence that the maturation and trafficking of F508 CFTR may be defective in heterologous systems (6), little is known regarding the processes that normally regulate CFTR biogenesis.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	316	 Our data show that oxygen can modulate endogenous CFTR expression posttranscriptionally.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	317	 Oxygen is known to regulate the expression of several other proteins at this level (22, 26, 29, 48).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	318	 For example, normoxia promotes the translation and/or folding of cytochrome c oxidase (22), while hypoxia abolishes the ubiquitin-mediated proteolysis of hypoxia-inducible factor 1 (26, 48) and stabilizes the plasma membrane form of the glucose transporter GLUT-3 (29).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	319	 Increased synthesis, decreased degradation, or an extended half-life are three possible mechanisms for the O2-enhanced CFTR expression.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	320	 We have been unable to detect augmented synthesis of CFTR in air-liquid interface cultures of MDCK-AA7 cells using 35S-met pulse chase analysis (data not shown).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	321	 Hence, we speculate that the increased levels of fully glycosylated (170-kDa) CFTR may be due to increased maturation and/or stability at the apical plasma membrane.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	322	 There is already some evidence to suggest that normoxia causes apical membranes to differentiate both functionally (47) and morphologically (30, 41).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	323	 Thus it is possible that the improvement in CFTR biogenesis is mediated by a more global mechanism designed to regulate the composition and/or architecture of the apical membranes during differentiation.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	324	Finally, many CF patients are hypoxic due to mucus plugs in the small airways and progressive loss of lung function (18, 24, 57).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	325	 If F508 CFTR cell surface expression depends on oxygenation, then there may be some correlation between nasal potential difference and pulmonary function among this subset of CF patients.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	326	 Indeed, two recent reports show that the basal nasal potential difference was similar to nonaffected controls in a subpopulation of CF patients that have normal pulmonary function (18, 24).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	327	 Although these results are somewhat controversial, they are consistent with studies localizing mutant CFTR at or near the apical membranes of F508 homozygous patients (14, 44, 49, 60, 62).
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	328	 Thus CF patients with at least one F508 allele (i.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	329	, 92% of the total CF population) may benefit from maneuvers that improve tissue oxygenation or drugs that mimic oxygen signaling pathways in CFTR-expressing epithelial cells.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	330	 Eric Sorscher for access to his labs and for support and encouragement.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	331	 Tom Ecay, Kim Barrett, and Eric Schwiebert for generously providing the MDCK-AA7, T84, and 16HBE14o cell lines, respectively, and Drs.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	332	 Eric Sorscher, Kevin Kirk, and Cathy Fuller for critique of earlier versions of this article.
0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	333	 Gerhard Giebisch and an anonymous reviewer for suggesting that we vary PO2 in air-liquid interface cultures.

0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	391	 Organotypic monolayer cultures of nervous tissue.

0.4332927.11121385.html.plaintext.txt	512	00 Copyright   2001 the American Physiological Society.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	0	COOH-terminal Truncations Promote Proteasome-dependent Degradation of Mature Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator from Post-Golgi Compartments Mohamed Benharougaa,b, Martin Haardta,b, Norbert Kartnerc, and Gergely L.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Lukacsa,b a Program in Lung and Cell Biology, The Hospital for Sick Children, Toronto M5G 1X8, Ontario, Canada b Department of Laboratory Medicine and Pathobiology, University of Toronto, Toronto M5G 1X8, Ontario, Canada c Department of Pharmacology, University of Toronto, Toronto M5G 1X8, Ontario, Canada.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	2	 Lukacs, Program in Lung and Cell Biology, The Hospital for Sick Children, 555 University Ave.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	3	, Toronto M5G 1X8, Ontario, Canada.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Tel:(416) 813-5125 Fax:(416) 813-5771 E-mail:glukacs{at}sickkids.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	5	  Abstract Top Abstract Introduction Materials and Methods Results Discussion Acknowledgements References.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	6	Impaired biosynthetic processing of the cystic fibrosis (CF) transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR), a cAMP-regulated chloride channel, constitutes the most common cause of CF.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Recently, we have identified a distinct category of mutation, caused by premature stop codons and frameshift mutations, which manifests in diminished expression of COOH-terminally truncated CFTR at the cell surface.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Although the biosynthetic processing and plasma membrane targeting of truncated CFTRs are preserved, the turnover of the complex-glycosylated mutant is sixfold faster than its wild-type (wt) counterpart.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Destabilization of the truncated CFTR coincides with its enhanced susceptibility to proteasome-dependent degradation from post-Golgi compartments globally, and the plasma membrane specifically, determined by pulse to chase analysis in conjunction with cell surface biotinylation.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Proteolytic cleavage of the full-length complex-glycosylated wt and degradation intermediates derived from both T70 and wt CFTR requires endolysosomal proteases.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	11	 The enhanced protease sensitivity in vitro and the decreased thermostability of the complex-glycosylated T70 CFTR in vivo suggest that structural destabilization may account for the increased proteasome susceptibility and the short residence time at the cell surface.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	12	 These in turn are responsible, at least in part, for the phenotypic manifestation of CF.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	13	 We propose that the proteasome-ubiquitin pathway may be involved in the peripheral quality control of other, partially unfolded membrane proteins as well.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	14	Key Words: cystic fibrosis, lysosomal proteolysis, structural destabilization, functional complementation, ubiquitination.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	15	  Introduction Top Abstract Introduction Materials and Methods Results Discussion Acknowledgements References.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	16	Newly synthesized secretory and membrane proteins must attain their native conformation spontaneously or with the assistance of ER-resident and cytosolic chaperones before their export from the ER.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	17	 The ER quality control mechanism assures that functionally incompetent, misfolded, or unassembled oligomeric proteins are retained and targeted for proteolysis via the ER-associated degradation (ERAD)1 pathway (Hurtley and Helnius 1989 ; Brodsky and McCracken 1997 ; Bonifacino and Weismann 1998 ; Ellgaard et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The ERAD involves the recognition, dislocation, and proteolysis of misfolded polypeptides by the 26S proteasome, a multicatalytic enzyme complex localized to the cytoplasm and nucleus (Baumeister et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	19	 1998 ; Bonifacino and Weismann 1998 ; Brodsky and McCracken 1999 ; Plemper and Wolf 1999 ).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	20	 The ATP-dependent cleavage process is facilitated by multiple ubiquitin attachments to the -amino groups of lysine residues of the substrate and catalyzed by a cascade of enzymatic reactions involving ubiquitin-activating (E1) and -conjugating (E2) enzymes in addition to ubiquitin-protein ligases (E3) (Hershko and Ciechanover 1998 ).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	21	Trafficking defects have been recognized as the underlying mechanism in a growing number of genetic diseases, including cystic fibrosis (CF), diabetes insipidus, and 1 antitrypsin deficiency (Thomas et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	22	 1995 ; Bonifacino and Weismann 1998 ; Hershko and Ciechanover 1998 ; Aridor and Balch 1999 ; Kopito 1999 ; Schwartz and Ciechanover 1999 ).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	23	 CF, the most prevalent recessive genetic disorder in the caucasian population, is caused by the dysfunction of the CF transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR), a member of the ATP-binding cassette transport protein family (Riordan et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	24	 CFTR is a cAMP-stimulated Cl- channel, residing predominantly at the cell surface and, less abundantly, in the endosomal compartment (Bradbury 1999 ).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	25	 The channel consists of two homologous halves, each comprised of six transmembrane helices and a nucleotide binding domain (NBD1 and NBD2), which are connected by the regulatory domain (Riordan et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	26	 This complex, multidomain structure conceivably renders the posttranslational folding of wild-type (wt) CFTR inefficient.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Approximately 70% of the newly synthesized wt CFTR is trapped in the ER as core-glycosylated folding intermediate (apparent molecular weight 150, 000) and degraded with a t1/2 of 30 min by the ERAD.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Proteasome activity is responsible, at least in part, for the degradation of the co- and posttranslationally ubiquitinated and incompletely folded CFTR at the ER (Jensen et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	29	 However, inhibition of proteasomes has failed to promote the processing of core-glycosylated wt as well as the F508 CFTR (Jensen et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	30	Only 20 to 30% of the newly synthesized CFTR enters the secretory pathway after its ATP-dependent conformational maturation (Lukacs et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	31	 1998 ) assisted by cytosolic and ER-resident chaperones (Yang et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Processing of the high mannose type N-linked glycan to complex type oligosaccharides in the cis/medial Golgi region is reflected by a decreased electrophoretic mobility (180 kD), providing a convenient method to monitor the trafficking of the CFTR (Cheng et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	33	 1994 ; Ward and Kopito 1994 ; Riordan 1999 ).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Not only does the folded complex-glycosylated CFTR have a slow turnover in vivo (t1/2 > 12 h), but it also displays a conformation which is more resistant to proteolysis in vitro (Zhang et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	35	 The posttranslational folding or conformational maturation of CFTR is independent of ER to Golgi vesicular transport, implying that complex glycosylation is not a prerequisite to attain the native conformation (Lukacs et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	36	 1994 ; Ward and Kopito 1994 ; Zhang et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	37	The majority of CF-associated point mutations, including the most common, F508 CFTR, impair biosynthetic processing by disrupting posttranslational folding at the ER (Welsh and Smith 1993 ; Zielenski and Tsui 1995 ; Riordan 1999 ).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Recently, we have identified a mechanistically distinct category of mutation, caused by premature terminations and frameshift mutations in the CF gene (Haardt et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Although the ER processing of these COOH-terminally truncated CFTR variants missing their last 70 to 82 amino acid residues (T70 and T82 CFTR) is similar to that of the wt form, the biological half-life of the complex-glycosylated mutants is sixfold shorter than their wt counterpart (Haardt et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Although the proteolytic elimination mechanism of the processing mutants entrapped in the ER has been extensively studied (Welsh and Smith 1993 ; Kopito 1999 ; Riordan 1999 ), the cellular processes responsible for the short residence time of the truncated CFTR in post-Golgi compartments remained obscure.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	41	Here we show that deletion of the COOH terminus renders the complex-glycosylated truncated CFTR highly susceptible to proteasome-dependent proteolysis at post-Golgi compartments, including the plasma membrane.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Structural destabilization, demonstrated by increased protease susceptibility in vitro and diminished thermostability of the complex-glycosylated mutants in vivo, may serve as signal for premature proteolysis.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	43	 In contrast, lysosomal proteolysis appears to represent the rate-limiting step in the degradation of the complex-glycosylated wt CFTR.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	44	 These results reveal a novel aspect of the proteasome-dependent degradation pathway in the elimination of nonnative CFTR after its escape from the ER quality control.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	45	  Materials and Methods Top Abstract Introduction Materials and Methods Results Discussion Acknowledgements References.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	46	Plasmids The influenza hemagglutinin (HA) epitope was attached to the NH2 terminus ubiquitin using PCR mutagenesis and the cDNA of the yeast ubiquitin as template (provided by Dr.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Haguenauer-Tsapis, Jacques Monod, University of Paris VII, Paris, France).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	48	 To generate the Tac-Lamp1 chimera, the extracellular and transmembrane segment of the interleukin 2 receptor (Tac) was fused to the cytoplasmic tail of Lamp-1.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	49	 The constructs were sequenced to verify that no errors had been introduced.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	50	 The cDNA, encoding for the Tac and Tac-TCR, were provided by Dr.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Bonifacino (National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Tac, Tac-TCR, and Tac-Lamp1 were stably transfected in BHK-21 cells using the pNUT expression cassette (Haardt et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	53	Cell Lines and Transfections Mixtures of stably transfected BHK-21 cells expressing wt, truncated CFTR (missing the last 26, 70, 82, and 98 amino acid residues: T26, T70, T82, and T98 CFTR, respectively) or Tac, Tac-TCR, and Tac-Lamp1, were generated and maintained as described (Haardt et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Intestinal epithelia (T84 and CaCo-2) expressing endogenous CFTR were cultured as described (Lukacs et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	55	 COS-1 cells were transiently transfected with Lipofectamine (Haardt et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	56	Electrophoresis and Immunoblotting Cells were washed with ice-cold PBS and lysed in RIPA buffer (150 mM NaCl, 20 mM Tris-HCl, 1% Triton X-100, 0.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	57	0), containing 5  microg/ml of leupeptin and pepstatin A, 10 mM iodoacetamide, and 1 mM PMSF at 4 degrees C.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Nuclei and unbroken cells were removed by centrifugation (15,000 g, 15 min at 4 degrees C).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Proteins were denatured in Laemmli sample buffer, separated by SDS-PAGE, and transferred to nitrocellulose membrane.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Immunoblotting was performed as described previously, using mouse monoclonal L12B4 and M3A7 anti-CFTR antibodies (Abs; Kartner et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	61	 1992 ), mouse monoclonal anti-HA (Covance), and antiubiquitin Abs (Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Inc.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Primary Abs were visualized by horseradish peroxidase to conjugated sheep anti to mouse IgG and enhanced chemiluminescence (ECL Western blot kit; Amersham Pharmacia Biotech).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	63	Metabolic Pulse to Chase Labeling and Immunoprecipitation BHK or COS-1 cells were pulse labeled in the presence of [35S]methionine and [35S]cysteine (0.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	64	25 mCi/ml; Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) and chased in complete medium for the specified time at 37 degrees C.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	65	 CFTR was immunoprecipitated with a mixture of M3A7 and L12B4 anti-CFTR Abs, as described (Lukacs et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	66	 The duration of pulse and chase periods and withdrawals of samples are indicated on schematic figures.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Radioactivity associated with CFTR was visualized by fluorography and quantified by PhosphorImager (PDI) using the ImageQuant software (Haardt et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	68	Cell Surface Biotinylation To determine the expression levels of wt and truncated CFTR at the cell surface and early endosome, BHK cells were metabolically labeled to steady state overnight and rinsed with H buffer (154 mM NaCl, 10 mM Hepes, 3 mM KCl, 1 mM MgCl2, 0.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	69	1 mM CaCl2, 10 mM glucose, pH 7.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Cells were biotinylated in the presence of 1 mg/ml sulphosuccinimidyl-2-(biotinamido)ethyl-1,3-dithiopropionate (EZ-Link sulfo-NHS-SS-biotin; Pierce Chemical Co.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	71	) in H buffer at 37 degrees C (Lukacs et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Cells were washed with ice-cold PBS, supplemented with 0.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	73	1 mM CaCl2, and solubilized in RIPA buffer.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Biotinylated CFTR was isolated by immunoprecipitation with M3A7 and L12B4 anti-CFTR Abs and then on Streptavidin-Sepharose (Sigma-Aldrich).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Biotinylated CFTR was visualized with fluorography and its radioactivity was measured by PhosphorImage analysis.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	76	Subcellular Fractionation Cells were washed with ice-cold PBS three times, resuspended in homogenization medium (0.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	77	25 M sucrose, 10 mM Hepes, 1 mM EDTA, 1 mM DTT, pH 7.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	78	2, supplemented with 5  microg/ml leupeptin, 5  microg/ml pepstatin A, and 2 mM PMSF).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	79	 CHO-BQ1, CHO-K1, CaCo-2, and T84 cells were homogenized by nitrogen cavitation as described (Zhang et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	80	 1998 ), whereas BHK cells were homogenized in a Dounce homogenizer.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	81	 After the sedimentation of unbroken cells and nuclei (2,500 g, 5 min at 4 degrees C), mitochondria were pelleted by centrifugation (10,000 g, 10 min at 4 degrees C) from the postnuclear supernatant.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Microsomes were fractionated on self-forming Percoll density gradient (25% Percoll in 0.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	83	25 M sucrose, 10 mM Hepes and 1 mM EDTA, 5  microg/ml leupeptin, 5  microg/ml pepstatin A, pH 7.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The density profile of the gradient was verified with density-marker beads (Sigma-Aldrich) and fractions were downloaded as described (Lukacs et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	85	 In some experiments lysosomes were labeled with the fluid-phase marker, fluorescein-dextran (0.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	86	5 mg/ml, 70 kD; Molecular Probes), overnight and chased in full medium for 3 h.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Alkaline phosphatase, ss-glucoronidase, and mannosidase II activity, specific markers of plasma membrane, lysosomes, and Golgi regions, respectively, were measured as described (Lukacs et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	88	 The fluorescence associated with the fractions was determined with fluorescence spectrophotometry in the presence of 0.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	89	Limited Proteolysis BHK cells expressing wt or T70 CFTR were incubated in the presence of cycloheximide (100  microg/ml) to ensure the degradation of the core-glycosylated wt and T70 CFTR (Lukacs et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Isolation of ER-, Golgi complex to , and plasma membrane to enriched microsomes was performed as described (Zhang et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	91	5 mg/ml) were digested in HSE medium (10 mM Hepes, 0.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	92	6) in the presence, at the indicated concentration, of trypsin or proteinase K for 15 min at 4 degrees C (Zhang et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Proteolysis was terminated by the addition of 1 mM PMSF.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Samples were immediately denatured in 2x Laemmli sample buffer at 37 degrees C for 20 min and probed by immunoblot analysis.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	95	Measurement of the cAMP-stimulated Iodide Conductance of the Plasma Membrane The plasma membrane cAMP-dependent halide conductance of BHK cells expressing T70 CFTR was determined with iodide efflux as described (Mohamed et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Iodide efflux was initiated by replacing the loading buffer with efflux medium (composed of 136 mM nitrate in place of iodide).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	97	 The extracellular medium was replaced every minute with efflux buffer (1 ml).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	98	 After a steady state was reached, the intracellular cAMP level was raised by agonists (10  microM forskolin, 0.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	99	2 mM isobutyl-methyl xanthane) to achieve maximal phosphorylation of the T70 CFTR.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	100	 The collection of the efflux medium resumed for an additional 6 to 9 min.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	101	 The amount of iodide in each sample was determined with an iodide-selective electrode (Orion).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	102	  Results Top Abstract Introduction Materials and Methods Results Discussion Acknowledgements References.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	103	Cell Surface Delivery of the Truncated CFTR Is Preserved We have demonstrated previously that the steady state expression level of the complex-glycosylated CFTR missing its last 70, 82, or 98 amino acids (designated as T70, T82, and T98 CFTR) was decreased by 90% compared with wt CFTR in heterologous expression systems (Haardt et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	104	 In contrast, deletion of the last 26 amino acid residues (T26 CFTR) was without effect (Mickle et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	105	 It was also shown that neither the translational rate nor the biosynthetic maturation of the T70 and T82 CFTR was significantly impaired at the ER in transient COS-1 (Haardt et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	106	 1999 ) or in stable BHK expression systems (Benharouga, M.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	107	 We proposed that, in contrast to the most prevalent CF-associated processing mutations (e.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	108	, F508 CFTR), which compromise the biogenesis of CFTR, destabilization of the mature form at distal stages of the biosynthetic or endocytic pathway accounts for the phenotypic manifestation of truncated CFTR (Haardt et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	109	To examine whether impaired plasma membrane targeting of the complex-glycosylated truncated CFTR can attribute to accelerated degradation, the efficacy of cell surface delivery of the mutant was determined first.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	110	 BHK cells constitutively expressing wt or truncated CFTR were metabolically labeled with [35S]methionine and [35S]cysteine overnight and cell surface to exposed CFTR was covalently tagged with sulfo-NHS-SS-biotin.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	111	 After the solubilization and immunoprecipitation of CFTR, biotinylated polypeptides were isolated on Streptavidin-Sepharose and visualized by fluorography after separation by SDS-PAGE (Fig 1 A).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	112	 PhosphorImage analysis revealed that the abundance of biotinylated T70, T82, and T98 CFTR was only 5 to 8% relative to wt or T26 CFTR in the mixture of clones (Fig 1 B).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	113	 The steady state level of the complex-glycosylated T70, T82, and T98 CFTR pool was also diminished to 5 to 10% relative to that of wt or T26 CFTR, as determined by quantitative Western blotting using L12B4 or M3A7 anti-CFTR Abs (Fig 1B and Fig C).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	114	 The complex and core-glycosylated forms of wt and truncated CFTR could be distinguished by their distinct electrophoretic mobility as well as their endoglycosidase H sensitivity as described previously and shown on Fig 1C and Fig D (Cheng et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	115	 The parallel decrease in the size of the complex-glycosylated and biotinylated pools of the truncated CFTR suggests that the plasma membrane targeting is largely preserved.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	116	 To confirm this notion, the cell surface delivery of newly synthesized T70 CFTR was measured.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	117	View larger version (46K):    Figure 1.

0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	145	 The cell surface targeting efficiency of T70 CFTR was 74  plus or minus  4% (mean  plus or minus  SEM, n = 4) of wt CFTR.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Since this measurement is compounded by the rapid degradation of the complex-glycosylated T70 CFTR (t1/2 1.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	147	5 to 2 h, see also Fig 6 B; Haardt et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	148	 1999 ), the calculated targeting efficiency of the T70 CFTR represents an underestimate and suggests that the plasma membrane delivery of the complex-glycosylated T70 CFTR is largely preserved.

0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	183	 (C and D) To rule out that lactacystin (10  microM) delays the degradation of the complex-glycosylated form by promoting the biosynthesis or the conversion of the core-glycosylated form, cells were treated with lactacystin after the pulse labeling (C) or after the conversion of the core- to complex-glycosylated T70 (D).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	184	 This protocol provided similar inhibition of the complex-glycosylated turnover as reported for A.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	185	 When indicated, BFA (5  microg/ml) was included to prevent the conversion of the residual core-glycosylated form (D and E).

0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	192	 (A) Protease inhibitors have no effect on the disposal and maturation efficiency of the core-glycosylated T70 CFTR.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Pulse-labeled (20 min) BHK transfectants were chased in the presence of lactacystin (10  microM), MG 132 (10  microM), or leupeptin and pepstatin A (50  microg/ml) as indicated.
