0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	195	 PhosphorImage analysis showed that none of the drug had significantly delayed the degradation of the core-glycosylated form (not shown).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	196	 (B) Lactacystin (10  microM), but not leupeptin and pepstatin A (50  microg/ml), impedes the degradation of the core-glycosylated Tac-TCR.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Stable transfectants were pulse labeled for 15 min and chased in the presence of the indicated drugs.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Fluorography was performed as described in the legend to Fig 2 D.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	199	 (C) The degradation of the Tac-Lamp1 chimera is sensitive to the inhibition of the vacuolar H+-ATPase with bafilomycin B (Baf B).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	200	 BHK cells stably expressing Tac-Lamp1 were labeled (30 min) and chased for 2 h.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	201	 After the addition of NH4Cl (10 mM), bafilomycin B (2  microM), or MG132 (10  microM) the cells were chased for an additional 3 h and Tac-Lamp1 was isolated by immunoprecipitation.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	202	 (D) The effect of lactacystin and MG132 on the steady state expression of mutant CFTR.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Equal amounts of whole cell lysate, obtained from cells exposed to lactacystin (Lac; 10  microM) and MG132 (10  microM) for 3 h, were separated by SDS-PAGE and immunoblotted with the L12B4 anti-CFTR Ab.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Complex- and core-glycosylated CFTR are indicated by black and white arrowheads, respectively.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	205	 (E) Functional rescue of T70 CFTR by lactacystin.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	206	 The cAMP-activated halide conductance of T70 CFTR to expressing BHK cells was measured by the iodide efflux assay in the absence (control) or presence of lactacystin treatment (+Lac; 10  microM for 3 h).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Data points are averages of triplicate determinations and show the difference of iodide release in the presence and absence of the protein kinase A agonist cocktail (10  microM forskolin, 0.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	208	View larger version (41K):    Figure 6.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Residence time of cell surface biotinylated wt and T70 CFTR.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	210	 (A) After metabolic labeling of the complex-glycosylated wt or T70 CFTR, cell surface resident proteins were biotinylated for 45 min and chased for the indicated time in complete medium.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Biotinylated CFTR was immunoprecipitated by L12B4 and M3A7 anti-CFTR Abs and then isolated on Streptavidin-Sepharose (top).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	212	 For comparison, 10% of the immunoprecipitate was loaded for fluorography (bottom).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	213	 (B) Turnover rates of biotinylated wt and T70 CFTR.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Radioactivity incorporated into the biotinylated CFTR was measured with PhosphorImage analysis and expressed as the percentage of the initial label.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Data represent means  plus or minus  SEM, n = 3.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	216	 (C and D) Proteasome inhibitors delay the degradation of the biotinylated T70 CFTR.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Radioactivity remaining in the biotinylated T70 CFTR was measured in pulse to chase experiments after 4 h of chase in the absence or presence of lactacystin (Lac; 10  microM) or MG132 (MG; 10  microM) by PhosphorImage analysis.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Data are expressed as a percentage of the amount remaining for the control T70 CFTR and represent means  plus or minus  SEM, n = 3.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	219	Contribution of Endolysosomal Proteases to the Turnover of Complex-glycosylated Wt and Truncated CFTR In light of efficient clathrin-dependent internalization of CFTR (Prince et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	220	 1997 ; Bradbury 1999 ) and proteolysis of other plasma membrane-resident ATP-binding cassette transporters in the vacuolar/lysosomal compartments (Loayza and Michaelis 1998 ; Hicke 1999 ; Katzmann et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	221	 1999 ), we hypothesized that COOH-terminal truncations may interfere with the recycling of CFTR and lead to premature endolysosomal proteolysis.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	222	To test this hypothesis, the disposal rate of the metabolically labeled, complex-glycosylated T70 and T82 CFTR was measured in the presence of lysosomal protease inhibitors after allowing the conversion of the core- into complex-glycosylated form (Fig 2 A).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	223	 The degradation rate was unaltered upon exposing the cells to NH4Cl, chloroquin, or bafilomycin B, agents that inhibit endolysosomal proteolysis by dissipating the acidic luminal pH and interfering with cargo delivery (Fig 2 B).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Similarly, leupeptin and pepstatin A, inhibitors of cathepsins B, H, L, N, S, and T (Seglen 1983 ), have a negligible effect on the degradation rate (Fig 2A and Fig B) and the steady state expression of truncated CFTRs (Fig 2 C).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	225	 In contrast, these drugs stabilized the interleukin 2 receptor chain (Tac), which is targeted for lysosomal degradation (Fig 2 D; Hemar et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	226	 1995 ), validating their efficacy and suggesting that the initial proteolysis of the truncated CFTR is largely independent of endolysosomal proteases.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	227	Pulse to chase analysis has revealed that the disposal of the complex-glycosylated wt CFTR was mitigated by NH4Cl and chloroquin (Fig 2E and Fig F).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	228	 To further examine the discordant role of lysosomal proteases in the wt and T70 CFTR degradation, subcellular fractionation was performed, after the enrichment of short-lived proteolytic intermediates that may have been difficult to detect by treating the cells with the cathepsin inhibitors.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Heavy and light microsomes, containing predominantly lysosomes and Golgi complex plasma membrane, and endosomes, respectively, were isolated on Percoll density gradient (Fig 3 A).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	230	Although cathepsin inhibitors stabilized the complex-glycosylated wt CFTR by 7 to 10-fold in lysosomes as well as in the light-density fraction, only a modest accumulation of T70 CFTR could be documented by immunoblot analysis (Fig 3 B).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Similar results were obtained in lysosomes isolated by the calcium-precipitation method (data not shown; Kawashima et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Surprisingly, leupeptin and pepstatin A provoked the accumulation of degradation intermediates of both wt and T70 CFTR predominantly in lysosomes (Fig 3 B).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	233	 These inhibitors also provoked the appearance of breakdown products in isolated lysosomes of intestinal epithelia (CaCo-2 and T84) expressing CFTR endogenously, implying that lysosomal proteolysis cannot be attributed to heterologous overexpession (data not shown).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Considering that cathepsin inhibitors are unable to promote the ER processing of the core-glycosylated form (Lukacs et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	235	 1994 ; Ward and Kopito 1994 ), our results suggest that endolysosomal proteases are essential for the elimination of the complex-glycosylated full-length wt CFTR.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	236	 In addition, endolysosomal proteases appear to be involved in the processing of the proteolytic intermediates derived from both T70 and wt CFTR.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	237	Proteasome-dependent Degradation of the Complex-glycosylated Truncated CFTR The 26S proteasome is responsible for the degradation of misfolded polypeptides recognized by the ER quality control, short-lived cytosolic, and some plasma membrane proteins after their ligand-induced internalization (Hochstrasser 1996 ; Bonifacino and Weismann 1998 ; Hershko and Ciechanover 1998 ; Brodsky and McCracken 1999 ; Plemper and Wolf 1999 ; Schwartz and Ciechanover 1999 ).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	238	 To reveal the involvement of the 26S proteasome in the metabolism of the truncated CFTR, the impact of the peptide aldehyde, MG 132 (CBZ-leu-leu-leucinal), and lactacystin, a specific, irreversible inhibitor of the 20S subunit, was assessed (Fenteany et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	239	The disappearance of the complex-glycosylated, but not the core-glycosylated, T70, T82, and T98 CFTR was inhibited 2.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	240	1-fold, respectively, by lactacystin when the drug was present during the pulse labeling and chase (Fig 4A and Fig B, and Fig 5 A).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	241	 MG132 exerted a less pronounced effect (Fig 4 B).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Comparable inhibition was observed when lactacystin was added after the pulse labeling (Fig 4 C) or after a 2-h chase (Fig 4 D).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	243	 This latter protocol has ensured that augmented conversion of the core- to the complex-glycosylated form was not attributable to the lactacystin effect.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	244	 Similarly, preventing ER to Golgi complex transport of the residual core-glycosylated T70 CFTR with brefeldin A (BFA) failed to influence the inhibitory effect of lactacystin (Fig 4 D), substantiating the notion that disposal of the complex-glycosylated mutants is delayed, rather than that the escape of core-glycosylated form is facilitated, by lactacystin.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	245	 In fact, neither lactacystin nor MG 132 promoted the processing of the core-glycosylated T70 CFTR (Fig 5 A), similarly to other CFTR mutations identified in NBD1 (Jensen et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	246	 The maturation efficiency of T70 CFTR (20  plus or minus  2%, n = 9) was negligibly increased in the presence of lactacystin (23  plus or minus  4%, n = 4).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	247	If deletion of the COOH terminus destabilizes CFTR exclusively in post-Golgi compartments, retention of folded T70 CFTR in the ER would protect against degradation.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Taking advantage of the fact that BFA can provoke the accumulation of folded CFTR in the ER without interfering with ERAD, the stability of folded T70 CFTR was measured after the elimination of the immature core-glycosylated form (Fig 4 E).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	249	 The turnover of the folded core-glycosylated T70 CFTR was fourfold slower (t1/2 7 h) than that of the complex-glycosylated T70 CFTR (t1/2 1.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	250	 In contrast, ER retention only marginally increased the half-life of the wt CFTR (t1/2 14 h vs.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	251	 11 h; Fig 4 G), underlining our previous observations that destabilization of T70 CFTR primarily manifests at the distal stage of the secretory pathway.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Similar stabilization was observed upon retaining the complex-glycosylated T70 CFTR in the distal Golgi region by aluminum fluoride (Benharouga, M.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Lukacs, unpublished observation).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	254	To rule out that cross talks between lysosomal and proteasomal degradation pathway account for the stabilization of the complex-glycosylated T70 CFTR, the specificity of the drugs was examined on BHK cells expressing Tac-TCR or Tac-Lamp1 chimeras.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Although the former polypeptide is a substrate of the ERAD (Bonifacino et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	256	 1990 ), the latter is targeted for lysosomal proteolysis (Marks et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	257	 As we anticipated, proteasome inhibitors mitigated the disappearance of Tac-TCR, but not Tac-Lamp1, whereas bafilomycin B, but not the proteasome inhibitors, stabilized Tac-Lamp1 (Fig 5B and Fig C).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	258	 Consistent with the notion that proteasome activity accounts, at least in part, for the proteolysis of the complex-glycosylated truncated CFTR, proteasome inhibitors increased the steady state level of the complex-glycosylated T70, T82, and T98 CFTR by two- to fourfold according to densitometric analysis of immunoblots (Fig 5 D).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	259	 This was also reflected by the elevated cAMP-activated anion conductance of the plasma membrane (Fig 5 E).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Lactacystin treatment significantly increased the protein kinase A to stimulated iodide release from BHK cells constitutively expressing T70 CFTR as compared with nontreated cells (Fig 5 E).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	261	Proteasome-dependent Turnover of Cell Surface Resident T70 CFTR To investigate the influence of proteasome inhibitors on the residence time of truncated CFTR at the cell surface, the turnover of biotinylated T70 CFTR was measured by the pulse to chase technique.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	262	 The half-life of biotinylated T70 CFTR is sevenfold shorter (t1/2 1.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Lactacystin and MG132 inhibited the turnover of biotinylated T70 CFTR by 2.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	264	 This observation provides direct support for our hypothesis that proteasomes, directly or indirectly, are involved in the proteolysis of complex-glycosylated T70 CFTR from the cell surface and endosomal compartments (Fig 6C and Fig D).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	265	Ubiquitination of the Complex-glycosylated T70 CFTR Since recognition of most of the substrates destined for destruction by the proteasome requires polyubiquitin modification (Hershko and Ciechanover 1998 ; Laney and Hochstrasser 1999 ; Plemper and Wolf 1999 ; Hirsh and Ploegh 2000 ), we examined whether T70 CFTR is subjected to ubiquitin attachments.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	266	 COS-1 cells were transiently cotransfected with plasmids encoding for the wt or T70 CFTR and HA-tagged ubiquitin (HA-Ub).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	267	 HA-Ub was detected with the monoclonal anti-HA Ab in immunoprecipitated T70 CFTR.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	268	 The abundance of high molecular weight immunoreactive polypeptides was augmented by lactacystin and MG132, suggesting that proteasome activity is involved in the degradation of polyubiquitinated T70 CFTR (Fig 7 A, top, lanes 8 to 10).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	269	 Similar results were obtained by monitoring the conjugation of endogenous Ub with a monoclonal anti-Ub Ab (Fig 7 A, middle, lanes 6 to 10).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Ubiquitinated T70 CFTR could not be detected in cells expressing T70 CFTR or HA-Ub individually (Fig 7 A, top, lanes 3 to 7) or after mock transfection (Fig 7 A, lanes 1 to 3), validating the specificity of the assay.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	271	 To discriminate whether polyubiquitinated T70 CFTR was derived from the core- and/or the complex-glycosylated T70 CFTR (Jensen et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	272	 1999 ), double immunoprecipitation of metabolically labeled T70 CFTR was performed.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	273	View larger version (100K):    Figure 7.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	274	 Proteasome inhibitors induce the accumulation of the polyubiquitinated T70 CFTR.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	275	 (A) COS-1 cells transiently expressing HA-Ub, T70 CFTR, or a combination of these, were treated with MG132 (MG; 10  microM) or lactacystin (Lac; 10  microM) for 3 h at 37 degrees C.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	276	 Equal amounts of cellular proteins were immunoprecipitated with L12B4 and M3A7 anti-CFTR Abs and immunoblotted with mouse monoclonal anti-HA (top) or antiubiquitin (middle) Ab.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Expression of T70 CFTR was verified by probing 10% of the cell lysate with L12B4 anti-CFTR Ab (bottom).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	278	 (B) Detection of polyubiquitinated complex-glycosylated T70 CFTR.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	279	 After the pulse labeling (20 min) of T70 CFTR to expressing (T70) or nontransfected (mock) BHK cells, the degradation of the core-glycosylated T70 CFTR was ensured during a 2-h chase.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	280	 An additional 2-h chase was performed in the presence of MG132 (MG; 10  microM) or leupeptin and pepstatin A (leu+pep; 50  microg/ml) (lanes 4 and 5).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	281	 CFTR to ubiquitin conjugates were isolated with sequential immunoprecipitation (IP) using L12B4 and M3A7 Abs first and then antiubiquitin Ab (top and middle) and visualized by fluorography.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	282	 The processing of the pulse-labeled T70 CFTR pool was monitored by visualizing 10% of the CFTR-immunoprecipitate (bottom).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	283	 (C) Detection of polyubiquitinated complex-glycosylated T70 CFTR in COS-1 cells.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	284	 The experimental protocols, described for B, were performed on transiently transfected COS-1 cells expressing T70 CFTR and HA-Ub.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Incubation with protease inhibitors was extended to 4 h as indicated and lactacystin (Lac) was used at 20  microM.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	286	 The second immunoprecipitation was done with anti-HA Abs.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	287	Stably transfected BHK cells were pulse labeled for 20 min and chased for 2 h to ensure the elimination of core-glycosylated T70 CFTR, verified by fluorography (Fig 7 B, bottom, lanes 1 and 2; see also Fig 4 D).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	288	 In a second set of samples, separation of ubiquitinated adducts was achieved by sequential immunoprecipitation with anti-CFTR and then with anti-Ub Ab.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	289	 The results show that a negligible amount of polyubiquitinated and core-glycosylated T70 CFTR persisted after the initial 2-h chase (Fig 7 B, top and bottom, lanes 1 and 2).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	290	 In contrast, radioactivity appeared in the high molecular weight, polyubiquitinated T70 CFTR when MG132 was present during the last 2 h of chase (Fig 7 B, top, lane 4).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	291	 Accumulation of polyubiquitinated T70 CFTR was more pronounced in COS-1 cells transiently coexpressing T70 CFTR and HA-Ub (Fig 7 C).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	292	 This is most likely due to the higher immunoprecipitation efficiency of the anti-HA Ab.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	293	 Ubiquitinated conjugates were not detectable upon inhibition of lysosomal proteolysis, or in mock transfected cells (Fig 7 B, top and middle, and C).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	294	 Considering that the turnover of the complex-glycosylated, but not the core-glycosylated T70 CFTR, is sensitive to proteasome inhibitors and the core-glycosylated form has been largely eliminated before proteasome inhibition, we conclude that at least a fraction of polyubiquitinated T70 CFTR originates from the complex-glycosylated T70 CFTR.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	295	 Although we cannot rule out that a small amount of polyubiquitinated T70 CFTR is derived from the core-glycosylated form, the following observations substantiate the notion that the complex-glycosylated T70 CFTR can form ubiquitinated adducts.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	296	 Ubiquitinated complex-glycosylated form was visualized by anti-Ub Abs after the separation of the core- and complex-glycosylated forms by immunoprecipitation with anti-CFTR Abs and wheat germ agglutinin affinity chromatography (data not shown).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	297	 Furthermore, coexpression of the dominant negative K48RUb with T70 CFTR delayed the disposal of the complex-glycosylated mutant CFTR (data not shown).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	298	Deletion of the COOH-terminal Tail Structurally Destabilizes CFTR Nonnative or partially denatured soluble proteins are subjected to ubiquitination and/or proteasome-mediated degradation (Pacifici et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	299	 1998 ; Laney and Hochstrasser 1999 ).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	300	 A similar scenario may prevail for T70 CFTR if the COOH-terminal tail is engaged in the structural stabilization of CFTR in the post-ER compartment.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	301	 A large body of evidence demonstrates the existence of intra- and intermolecular interactions in CFTR (Seibert et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	302	To compare the conformational stability of the complex-glycosylated wt and T70 CFTR, in situ protease susceptibility and in vivo thermostability assays were performed.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	303	 The conformation of the cytosolic domains was probed with limited proteolytic digestion in conjunction with immunoblotting, a method we have implemented to reveal conformational difference between the wt and the F508 CFTR (Zhang et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	304	 Intact microsomes were isolated by differential centrifugation from BHK cells, enriched in the complex-glycosylated wt or T70 CFTR by cyclohexamide chase, and subjected to limited proteolysis in the presence of an increasing concentration of trypsin.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	305	 Immunoblot analysis of the proteolytic fragments with the L12B4 anti-CFTR Ab recognizing the NBD1 demonstrates a distinct proteolytic digestion pattern and a moderate, but reproducibly increased protease sensitivity of the complex-glycosylated T70 CFTR compared with wt CFTR (Fig 8).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	306	 Similar results were obtained with proteinase K and using the NBD2-specific, M3A7 anti-CFTR Ab (data not shown), indicating that not only the NBD2, but also the NBD1 conformation was altered upon truncating the COOH terminus.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	307	View larger version (47K):    Figure 8.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	308	 Protease susceptibility of native wt and T70 CFTR.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	309	 After treating the cells with cyclohexamide (100  microg/ml) for 2.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	310	5 h at 37 degrees C to deplete the core-glycosylated forms, microsomes were isolated with differential centrifugation from BHK-21 cells stably expressing wt or T70 CFTR.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	311	 Microsomes were subjected to limited proteolysis at the indicated concentrations of trypsin for 15 min at 4 degrees C.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	312	 The proteolytic digestion pattern was probed by L12B4 anti-CFTR Ab and ECL.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	313	If the complex-glycosylated T70 CFTR was conformationally unstable, it was anticipated that the polypeptide in vivo thermostability would be compromised.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	314	 The temperature dependence of the turnover of the complex-glycosylated wt and T70 CFTR was compared by metabolic pulse to chase studies.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	315	 The turnover of the complex-glycosylated T70 CFTR was more than fivefold faster at 40 degrees C (t1/2 0.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	316	5 h) than at 37 degrees C (t1/2 2.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	317	 In sharp contrast, the turnover of the wt CFTR was only marginally affected at 40 degrees C (t1/2 10.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	318	 15 h at 37 degrees C) (Fig 9B and Fig D).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	319	 The simplest interpretation of these data is that the intrinsic structural instability of the T70 CFTR becomes more apparent at elevated temperature, leading to thermodenaturation and proteolysis, whereas the compact tertiary structures of wt CFTR are resistant to unfolding.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	320	View larger version (30K):    Figure 9.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	321	 Thermostability of the complex-glycosylated wt and T70 CFTR in vivo.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	322	 (A and B) Temperature-dependent turnover of the complex-glycosylated T70 and wt CFTR.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	323	 Metabolic stability of the pulse-labeled complex-glycosylated T70 and wt CFTR was monitored as described in the legend to Fig 4.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	324	 Chase was conducted at 26 degrees C, 37 degrees C, or 40 degrees C.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	325	 (C and D) The disappearance kinetics of complex-glycosylated T70 and wt CFTR were determined by PhosphorImage analysis in experiments shown in A and B.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	326	 Data are means  plus or minus  SEM, n = 3.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	327	  Discussion Top Abstract Introduction Materials and Methods Results Discussion Acknowledgements References.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	328	A combination of transcriptional, cotranslational, and posttranslational mechanisms contributes to the ER quality control, preventing misfolded secretory and membrane proteins from traversing the secretory pathway (Ellgaard et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	329	 Nevertheless, several examples demonstrate that the fidelity of the ER quality control is far from perfect.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	330	 Nonfunctional polypeptides can escape ER retention, whereas mutants with partially or fully preserved biological function are being trapped, causing severe human diseases such as CF and alpha 1 to protease inhibitor deficiency (Thomas et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	331	 1995 ; Zielenski and Tsui 1995 ; Aridor and Balch 1999 ; Schwartz and Ciechanover 1999 ).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	332	 Nonnative polypeptides could also be generated in post-ER compartments as a result of unfolding upon environmental stresses or mutations that compromise the native form stability (Goldenberg 1992 ; Pacifici et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	333	 1993 ; Parsell and Lindquist 1993 ; Sitte et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	334	 Little is known about the mechanism responsible for the degradation of abnormal membrane proteins from post-ER compartments.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	335	In mammalian cells, aggregated furin, incompletely assembled Golgi coronavirus E1, and mutant connexin32 are destined for lysosomal degradation from the Golgi region without reaching the cell surface (Armstrong et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	336	 A post-ER quality control mechanism appears to be responsible for targeting and vacuolar degradation of mutant plasma membrane ATPase, the late Golgi protease Kex2, and a model protein, comprising the secretory invertase and the NH2 terminus of the lambda repressor in Saccharomyces cerevisiae (Wilcox et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	337	 1992 ; Chang and Fink 1995 ; Hong et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	338	 Aggregation of unoccupied class II major histocompatibility complex molecules and cross-linking of cell surface membrane proteins, such as the transferrin receptor, can evoke preferential lysosomal targeting and degradation (Weissman et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	339	 Although most of these examples illustrate that nonnative membrane protein is targeted for lysosomal proteolysis either before their arrival to the cell surface or after their internalization, the complex-glycosylated truncated CFTR has a distinct intracellular fate.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	340	We presented compelling evidence indicating that the dramatically decreased expression level and residence time of the complex-glycosylated truncated CFTR cannot be attributed to missorting for lysosomal degradation at the trans-Golgi or endosomal compartment.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	341	 Instead, the truncated CFTR is targeted to the plasma membrane with comparable efficiency to its wt counterpart (Fig 1).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	342	 The turnover of the total and cell surface biotinylated T70 CFTR pools was insensitive to inhibitors of endolysosomal proteases.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	343	 In contrast, weak bases and cathepsin inhibitors stabilized the full-length form and degradation intermediates of wt CFTR in transfected cells as well as in epithelia, highlighting the multiple role of endolysosomal proteolysis in the turnover of wt CFTR (Fig 2 and Fig 3).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	344	Several criteria were used to establish that proteasomes are involved in the accelerated metabolism of the truncated CFTR from post-Golgi compartments, including the cell surface.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	345	 First, the degradation rates of the complex-glycosylated T70, 82, and 98 CFTR were delayed in the presence of lactacystin, the most specific inhibitor of proteasome (Fenteany et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	346	 Second, a dramatic extension of the plasma membrane residence time of biotinylated T70 CFTR was evoked by lactacystin (Fig 6), implying that proteasomes are indispensable in the proteolysis of the truncated CFTR from the cell surface and/or endosomal compartment.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	347	 Since proteasome inhibitors had no impact on the degradation of Tac-Lamp1, an indirect effect of lactacystin on lysosomal proteolysis could be precluded (Fig 5).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	348	 Third, MG132 and lactacystin evoked the accumulation of polyubiqutinated adducts of the complex-glycosylated T70 CFTR, consistent with the notion that a fraction of the T70 CFTR is tagged by polyubiquitin chain(s) before degradation (Fig 7).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	349	 Finally, both MG132 and lactacystin partially restored the expression level of complex-glycosylated T70, T82, and T98 CFTR, as well as the plasma membrane cAMP-activated chloride conductance of T70 CFTR transfectants without facilitating the biogenesis of the mutants (Fig 5D and Fig E).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	350	 Although these observations indicate that proteasome activity is one of the rate-limiting steps for the turnover of the full-length complex-glycosylated T70 CFTR, proteasome inhibitors failed to restore the mutant stability to that of the wt CFTR.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	351	 This could be explained by incomplete inhibition of proteasome activity and/or the involvement of other, presently unidentified proteolytic mechanisms.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	352	The COOH-terminal tail of CFTR might confer stability to the mature CFTR by several mechanisms or a combination thereof.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	353	 Deletion of the COOH terminus, comprising a postsynaptic density-95, disc-large, and zonula occludens-1 to binding motif (1476DTRL) that ensures the association of CFTR with EBP-50 (for ezrin-radixin-moesin to binding phosphoprotein 50) both in vitro and in vivo may facilitate lysosomal degradation by compromising endosomal sorting for recycling (Hall et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	354	 A similar paradigm was proposed for the accelerated degradation of the ss2-adrenergic receptor upon preventing its binding to EBP-50 (Cao et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	355	 However, this possibility appears to be unlikely, since the steady state expression level and turnover rate of a CFTR variant lacking the COOH-terminal 26 amino acid residues are normal (Mickle et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	356	 Neither can aggregation of T70 CFTR at the trans-Golgi or at early endosomes target the mutant for lysosomal degradation.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	357	 Finally, the absence of the COOH-terminal tail may structurally destabilize the folded CFTR, increasing the portion of nonnative molecules that are susceptible to proteolysis.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	358	Evidence suggests that nonnative states of soluble polypeptides induced by mutations or thermal or chemical denaturation can lead to accelerated degradation (Parsell and Lindquist 1993 ; Hershko and Ciechanover 1998 ; Brodsky and McCracken 1999 ; Plemper and Wolf 1999 ), a paradigm that may apply to the degradation of nonnative plasma membrane proteins, including the truncated CFTR, as well.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	359	 Based on the enhanced protease susceptibility and the decreased in vivo thermostability of T70 CFTR (Fig 8 and Fig 9), we speculate that structural destabilization of the native form is induced by disrupting interaction(s) of the COOH terminus.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	360	 Using various yeast screening assays and site-directed mutagenesis of the Deg-1 proteolytic motif in the MAT2 transcription factor, it has been established that ubiquitin-conjugating enzymes (Ubc6 and Ubc7) can recognize hydrophobic stretches and exposed hydrophobic surfaces on amphipathic helices (Sadis et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	361	 These or similar motifs, normally buried inside the globular domains of CFTR or inserted into the membrane plane, may serve as recognition signal(s).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	362	 In support of this notion, the decreased plasma membrane residence time and impaired expression level of the ss2- and the 2A-adrenergic receptors were also attributed to structural destabilization (Gether et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	363	 1997 ; Wilson and Limbird 2000 ).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	364	 However, the mechanism responsible for the downregulation of these G protein to coupled receptors, which could be partially rescued with ligand stabilization, has remained obscure.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	365	A key question that remains to be resolved is whether ubiquitination is a prerequisite for proteasome-dependent degradation of the mutant CFTR from the cell surface or endosomal compartment.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	366	 Several tyrosine kinase and G protein to coupled receptors have been observed to undergo ligand-induced ubiquitination and downregulation via lysosomal and/or proteasomal degradation (Bonifacino and Weismann 1998 ; Hershko and Ciechanover 1998 ; Hicke 1999 ; Strous and Govers 1999 ).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	367	 Ubiquitination also appears to be necessary and sufficient to induce the internalization and downregulation of plasma membrane receptors and transporters (e.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	368	, FUR4, GAP1, STE2, STE3, and STE6) via vacuolar proteolysis in yeast (Hicke 1999 ).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	369	 The constitutive downregulation of the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC), in association with the Nedd4 ubiquitin-ligase, was proposed to follow a similar degradation route, in contrast to the unassembled subunits of the channel, which were degraded by a proteasome-dependent mechanism at the ER (Staub et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	370	Since both covalent and noncovalent attachment of ubiquitins can serve as a degradation signal of plasma membrane proteins via internalization (Govers et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	371	 2000 ), one possible scenario is that augmented ubiquitination of CFTR, or an associated protein, facilitates the internalization of the mutant.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	372	 On the other hand, in light of multiple tyrosine- and dileucine-based endocytic signals in CFTR, ubiquitin attachment may not be a prerequisite for endocytosis (Lukacs et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	373	 Consistent with the dispensable nature of ubiquitination, downregulation of the ss2-adrenergic and mutant m2-muscarinic receptors can proceed without endocytosis, presumably by direct association with proteasome and/or other, presently unidentified proteases (Jockers et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	374	 1999 ; Wilson and Limbird 2000 ).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	375	 The recognition that both 26S proteasome and P700 subunit are able to degrade nonnative polypeptides lacking polyubiquitin conjugates supports the notion that a ubiquitin-independent degradation mechanism cannot be ruled out (Murakami 1992 ; Braun et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	376	 Importantly, these degradation pathways are not mutually exclusive and may function in parallel.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	377	Since the retrograde translocation of the T70 CFTR via the translocon is unlikely to occur in post-Golgi compartments (Xiong et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	378	 1999 ), the coordinated action of multiple proteolytic systems is invoked to resolve the topological problem of disposing transmembrane segments and exofacial loops of the T70 CFTR.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	379	 Degradation appears to be initiated by the unfolding of cytosolic domains in a proteasome-dependent manner.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	380	 The biochemical as well as functional rescue of cell surface resident T70, but not wt CFTR (data not shown), by proteasome inhibitors substantiate this hypothesis.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	381	 Whereas the initial cleavage of the mature wt CFTR, as opposed to mutant, relies on the activity of lysosmal proteases, subsequent degradation of wt and T70 CFTR converges in endolysosomes, demonstrated by their overlapping proteolytic fragmentation pattern in the presence of cathepsin inhibitors (Fig 3 B).
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	382	Although the truncated CFTR is one of the first mutant plasma membrane proteins subjected to sequential proteasomal and lysosomal breakdown, the coordinated action of these proteolytic systems is not without precedent.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	383	 Although both lysosomes and proteasomes are involved in the constitutive and ligand-induced disposal of connexin43, the renal Na/Pi cotransporter, and the PDGF ss receptor, respectively (Mori et al.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	384	 1998 ), the recognition mechanism of these substrates by the proteasome remains unknown.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	385	 Considering that deletion of the COOH-terminal tail appears to destabilize CFTR structurally, we propose that the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway may play a role in the recognition and elimination of not only the T70 CFTR, but also other nonnative or partially unfolded plasma membrane proteins.
0.45175216.11381082.html.plaintext.txt	386	1 Abbreviations used in this paper: Ab, antibody; BFA, brefeldin A; CF, cystic fibrosis; CFTR, CF transmembrane conductance regulator; ERAD, ER-associated degradation; HA, hemagglutinin; HA-Ub, HA-tagged ubiquitin; NBD, nuclear binding domain; wild-type, wt.
