0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	137	, n = 5-10 sets of experiments, *, p  <  0.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	138	To determine absolute diffusion coefficients, comparative photobleaching measurements were done for the GFP-labeled CFTR chimeras (Fig.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	139	 3A) and for soluble GFP in the ER lumen.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	140	 From a series of experiments shown in Fig.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	141	 3A, t1/2 measured using a  x 60 objective were 3.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	142	6 s (F508-CFTR, BFA) (n = 5-10 sets of experiments).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	143	 3D (top) shows the substantially faster fluorescence recovery of soluble GFP in the ER lumen of COS7 cells (t1/2, 60  plus or minus  4 ms; n = 12).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	144	 This value was similar to that measured in CHO-K1 cells under identical conditions (t1/2, 65  plus or minus  4 ms; n = 6, not shown).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	145	 The absolute diffusion coefficient for luminal GFP in COS7 cells was computed using a simple model to correct for ER geometric effects (28) as (6.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	146	5)  x  108 cm2/s, similar to that previously measured in CHO cells (25) and LLC-PK1 cells (27).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	147	 3D (middle) summarizes diffusion coefficients for the GFP-chimeras.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	148	 There was no significant effect of the F508 mutation on CFTR diffusion and/or of BFA treatment on F508-CFTR mobility.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	149	 3D (bottom) summarizes the percentage of mobile GFP, determined from the completeness of the fluorescence recovery at long times.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	150	 GFP-wt-CFTR fluorescence recovered almost completely (92  plus or minus  2%, n = 10), whereas GFP-F508-CFTR recovery in BFA-treated and untreated cells was slightly though significantly smaller (85  plus or minus  2% and 82  plus or minus  1%).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	151	To investigate interactions of wt-CFTR and F508-CFTR with elements of the ER quality control machinery, we used a series of maneuvers to modulate molecular chaperone interactions.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	152	 4A shows wt-CFTR mobility after ATP depletion (a maneuver that increases interactions between CFTR and chaperones in the ER), which was produced by 30 min of incubation with 6 mM 2-deoxyglucose and 0.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	153	 The diffusion coefficient of GFP-wt-CFTR was similar to control conditions, (10.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	154	9)  x  1010 cm2/s (n = 7), and the percentage recovery was reduced significantly to 80  plus or minus  2%.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	155	 The diffusion coefficient of GFP-F508-CFTR was reduced significantly after a 30-min ATP depletion to (6.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	156	 4A, bottom curve), and substantially more GFP-F508-CFTR became immobilized (mobile percentage, 55  plus or minus  5%).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	157	 ATP depletion for 60 min had no further effect.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Table I summarizes averaged diffusion coefficients and percentages of mobile GFP.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	159	 To investigate whether the reduced F508-CFTR mobility in ATP-depleted cells was related to restructuring or fragmentation of the ER, the mobility of the fluorescent ER membrane marker diOC4(3) was measured.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	160	 4B shows that diffusion of diOC4(3) was essentially complete with a diffusion coefficient of (2.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	161	 diOC4(3) diffusion was unaffected by BFA treatment ((2.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	162	1)  x  108 cm2/s, n = 5, middle curve) or ATP depletion ((2.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	163	3)  x  108 cm2/s, n = 4, bottom curve).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Further, photobleaching of transfected cells expressing GFP-labeled wild type CFTR or F508-CFTR and subsequently labeled with diOC4(3) in situ showed that the expression of GFP-CFTR chimeras did not affect ER structure or fluidity (not shown).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Image photobleaching experiments similar to those shown in Fig.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	166	 2 were also performed on diOC4(3)-labeled cells (not shown), and it was demonstrated that ATP depletion did not alter ER continuity or gross structure.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	167	View larger version (70K):    Fig.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	168	   Slowed GFP-F508-CFTR diffusion after ATP depletion.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	169	 A, photobleaching after cellular ATP depletion produced by a 30-min incubation with 6 mM 2-deoxyglucose and 0.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	170	02% sodium azide ( x 60 objective).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	171	 B, photobleaching of the ER lipid probe diOC4(3) in control, BFA-treated, and ATP-depleted cells ( x 100 objective).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	172	 C, fluorescence depletion experiments of GFP-wt-CFTR under control conditions (top) and of GFP-F508-CFTR after ATP depletion (bottom).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Images shown before bleaching, with the bleach spot indicated by white cross-hairs, and after the indicated number of bleach pulses.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	174	                              View this table:    Table I Diffusion coefficients (D) and mobilities of wt- and F508-CFTR Data as mean  plus or minus  S.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	175	 (n = 4-10 sets of measurements, each measurement the average of 5-12 recovery curves from different cells) for indicated maneuvers (see "Experimental Procedures").
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	176	To identify the cellular location of the immobilized GFP-F508-CFTR in ATP-depleted cells, fluorescence loss in photobleaching (FLIP) experiments were performed (Fig.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	177	 A fixed spot in the cell was repetitively bleached with delays between each bleach pulse to permit diffusion of unbleached GFP-labeled CFTR into the location of the bleach spot.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Under these conditions GFP-wt-CFTR freely diffused throughout the ER with ~10% of cell fluorescence remaining after 35 bleach pulses (top).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	179	 In contrast, a substantial amount of fluorescence remained after bleaching of GFP-F508-CFTR in ATP-depleted cells (bottom) with the remaining fluorescence having an ER pattern.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	180	 These findings suggest that ATP depletion does not alter ER continuity or gross structure and that the immobilization of F508-CFTR in ATP-depleted cells results from interactions with ER proteins.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	181	Additional maneuvers were carried out to modulate putative CFTR interactions with molecular chaperones and elements of protein processing and degradation (Fig.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Heat shock, which nonspecifically up-regulates the expression of molecular chaperones, produced small reductions in the diffusion coefficients and percentage mobilities of wt-CFTR and F508-CFTR (Fig.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Proteasome inhibition by lactacystin resulted in mild slowing and immobilization of wt-CFTR and F508-CFTR after 6 h of incubation (second curves), with complete immobilization after 14 h (third curves).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	184	 GFP was seen in an ER pattern at 6 h but was concentrated in aggresomes at 14 h (not shown).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	185	 The ansamysin compound geldanamycin, which disrupts associations with Hsp90, caused comparable slowing of wt-CFTR and F508-CFTR with somewhat greater immobilization of F508-CFTR (fourth curves).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Last, the role of glycosylation was investigated by incubation with tunicamycin (to inhibit addition of oligosaccharide chains), using a glycosylation-null mutant of wt-CFTR (asparagines 894 and 900 replaced by glutamines).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Somewhat more immobilization of F508-CFTR than wt-CFTR was found with tunicamycin (fifth curves).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Although the glycosylation-null mutant of wt-CFTR expressed poorly and a substantial proportion of fluorescence was associated with aggresomes, the mobility of ER-associated CFTR could be measured in some cells and was found to be similar to that produced by tunicamycin (sixth curve).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	189	View larger version (22K):    Fig.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	190	   Effect of putative modulators of molecular chaperone interactions on the ER mobility of GFP-wt-CFTR and GFP-F508-CFTR.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Photobleaching experiments were done on cells expressing wt-CFTR (A) and F508-CFTR (B) using a  x 60 objective as in Fig.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Recovery curves are the average of 5-12 individual measurements, each from a single cell.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Maneuvers are described under "Experimental Procedures" and include: heat shock, 1 h of incubation at 42  degrees C followed by 16-20 h of recovery at 37  degrees C; lactacystin, 6  microM for 6 and 14 h; geldanamycin, 0.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	194	1  microg/ml for 90 min; tunicamycin, 5  microg/ml for 20 h; and glycosylation-null mutant of GFP-wt-CFTR.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	195	 For curves shown, the fitted absolute diffusion coefficient (in cm2/s  x  1010) and percentage recoveries were the following: 9.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	196	2, 83% (heat shock, F508-CFTR); 6.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	197	2, 81% (lactacystin 6 h, wt); 5.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	198	7% (lactacystin 6 h, F508-CFTR); 7.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	199	0, 63% (geldanamycin, F508-CFTR); 6.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	200	2, 61% (tunicamycin, F508-CFTR); 6.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	201	 See Table I for summary of fitted mobilities and diffusion coefficients.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	202	As was done for the ATP depletion experiments, the diffusion of the ER marker diOC4(3) was measured in transfected cells to establish that ER restructuring or fragmentation was not responsible for reduced CFTR mobility.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	203	 The diffusion of diOC4(3) in cells that were heat-shocked or treated with lactacystin, geldanamycin, or tunicamycin was essentially complete ( > 96% mobile) and similar to that measured in control cells, with diffusion coefficients of 2.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	204	7  x  108 cm2/s (n = 4 for each treatment, data not shown).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	205	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	206	This study has shown that although F508-CFTR is retained in the ER, it diffuses at a comparable rate to wt-CFTR in BFA-treated cells.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Similar observations were made for the T126M mutant of AQP2 (a water channel that is partially misfolded and similarly retained in the ER, Ref.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	208	 27) and for a temperature-sensitive folding mutant of the vesicular stomatitis virus G protein (29).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Therefore, slowed or restricted F508-CFTR mobility in the ER cannot account for its failure to be exported.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Efficient recycling from the Golgi or failure to be recognized by the ER export machinery remain possible explanations for the ER localization of F508-CFTR.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	211	 The observation of small amounts of F508-CFTR in post-ER membranes suggests that efficient recycling may be responsible for the retention of F508-CFTR in the ER (30).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	212	The small immobile pool of F508-CFTR and the substantial immobilization after ATP depletion suggest that a greater fraction of F508-CFTR interacts with molecular chaperones than does wt-CFTR.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Approximately 50% of F508-CFTR was immobile after ATP depletion, with only minor effects on the mobility of wt-CFTR.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	214	 The simplest interpretation of this finding is that ATP depletion, which stabilizes protein interactions with molecular chaperones, is able to reveal F508-CFTR interactions that are not observable under normal conditions.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	215	 As discussed in the Introduction, F508-CFTR structure is thought to be similar to that of an early intermediate of wt-CFTR, and biochemical evidence supports F508-CFTR associations with molecular chaperones.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	216	Additional maneuvers were performed to investigate specific interactions between wt-CFTR and F508-CFTR and the cellular protein processing machinery.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Inhibition of N-linked glycosylation by tunicamycin resulted in significant slowing and immobilization of both wt-CFTR and F508-CFTR, similar to findings for the VSVG glycoprotein (29).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Similar results were found with a glycosylation-null wt-CFTR mutant, which was poorly expressed in the plasma membrane as determined by biotinylation studies (not shown).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Protein glycosylation can facilitate folding, sorting, and quality control (31).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Our data are thus consistent with a role for glycosylation in CFTR folding.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Proteasome inhibition causes the accumulation of deglycosylated wt-CFTR and F508-CFTR in detergent-insoluble, high molecular weight aggregates (9, 32).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Consistent with the observations here, Bebok et al.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	223	 (32) demonstrated an association between the Sec61 translocation system and CFTR that was enhanced by proteasome inhibition.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	224	 After prolonged (14 h) incubation with lactacystin, wt-CFTR and F508-CFTR were found in aggresomes (9, 10).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Aggresomes are vimentin-enclosed, pericentriolar, electron-dense structures that contain aggregates of misfolded, often ubiquinated proteins associated with molecular chaperones and proteasomes.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	226	 As expected, the GFP-CFTR chimeras were completely immobile in aggresomes.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	227	Inhibition of interaction between Hsp90 and CFTR by geldanamycin also slowed the diffusion of wt-CFTR and F508-CFTR, with greater immobilization of F508-CFTR.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Geldanamycin has been shown to disrupt interactions of Hsp90 and CFTR, increasing the degradation rates of wt-CFTR and F508-CFTR (14).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Hsp90 has thus been proposed to have a potential role in protecting CFTR from rapid degradation.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	230	 The relative immobilization of wt-CFTR and F508-CFTR after geldanamycin treatment supports a role of Hsp90 for CFTR processing.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	231	 As suggested for VSVG by Nehls et al.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	232	 (29), we believe that the physical state of wt-CFTR and F508-CFTR after perturbation of CFTR processing by tunicamycin or geldanamycin may be different from that produced by ATP depletion.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	233	 The slowing and immobilization of CFTR by ATP depletion may represent CFTR interactions with molecular chaperones existing in large complexes (33), whereas the immobilization after tunicamycin and geldanamycin, or molecular deglycosylation, may represent CFTR self-aggregation.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Because of the logarithmic relationship between molecular radius and diffusion rate for a protein in a bilayer, substantial aggregates (10-100 units) must be formed to significantly slow diffusion.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	235	 The similar responses of wt-CFTR and F508-CFTR to some of the pharmacological maneuvers are consistent with the intrinsically inefficient folding of wt-CFTR, which when compared with P-glycoprotein (another member of the ABC cassette family) is poorly folded.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	236	The diffusion coefficient for CFTR diffusional mobility in the ER, ~10  x  1010 cm2/s, is within the range of other ER membrane proteins that have been studied.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	237	 The membrane water channel AQP2 (retained in the ER with BFA) and the ER-retained mutant AQP2-T126M have diffusion coefficients of 2.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	238	 Cytochrome P450 2C2, an intrinsic ER protein, has a diffusion coefficient of 5.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	239	 VSVG in its native and misfolded states and two ER resident transmembrane proteins (lamin B receptor and the -subunit of the signal recognition particle receptor) have diffusion coefficients of 26-50  x  1010 cm2/s, depending upon temperature (29).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Two Golgi resident transmembrane proteins (galactosyltransferase and the KDEL receptor) retained in the ER with BFA have diffusion coefficients of 21-48  x  1010 cm2/s, depending upon cell type and temperature (29, 35).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	241	 The diffusion coefficient of the ER-retained MHC class 1 molecule H2Ld is 20-46  x  1010 cm2/s and that of TAP1 (transporter associated with antigen presentation 1) is 12  x  1010 cm2/s (36).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	242	 The variation in these diffusion coefficients probably reflects different protein sizes, interactions with ER and cytoplasmic proteins, and ER composition in different cells.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	243	In summary, the photobleaching data provide the following evidence: (a) the ER retention of F508-CFTR is not due to restricted ER mobility, (b) the majority of F508-CFTR is not aggregated or bound to slowly moving membrane proteins, and (c) F508-CFTR may interact to a greater extent with molecular chaperones than does wt-CFTR.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	244	 Measurements of ER membrane protein diffusion provide a unique in vivo approach to study protein-protein associations that complements classical biochemical and 2-hybrid methods.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	245	We thank Katherin Karlson for assistance with the generation of the glycosylation-null mutant of EGFP-CFTR.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	246	* This study was supported by National Institutes of Health Grants EB00415, DK43840, HL59198, DK35124, EY13574, and HL60288, Research Development Program Grant R613 from the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation (to A.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	247	 V), and National Institutes of Health Grants DK45881 and DK34533 and a Research Development Program grant from the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation (to B.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	248	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	249	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	251	  To whom correspondence should be addressed: 1246 Health Sciences East Tower, Cardiovascular Research Inst.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	252	, University of California, San Francisco, San Francisco, CA 94143-0521.

0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	256	, numerical aperture; VSVG, vesicular stomatitis virus G protein; AQP, aquaporin; diOC4(3), 3,3'-dibutyloxacarbocyanine iodide; FLIP, fluorescence loss in photobleaching.

0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	290	Copyright   2002 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	0	The F508 mutation shortens the biochemical half-life of plasma membrane CFTR in polarized epithelial cells Ghanshyam D.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Heda1,2, Mridul Tanwani2, and Christopher R.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	2	1 Research and 3 Medical Services, Veterans Affairs Medical Center and Departments of 2 Medicine and 4 Physiology and Biophysics, The University of Tennessee Health Sciences Center, Memphis, Tennessee 38163.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	3	    ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	4	Although the biosynthetic arrest of the F508 mutant of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) can be partially reversed by physical and chemical means, recent evidence suggests that the functional stability of the mutant protein after reaching the cell surface is compromised.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	5	 To understand the molecular basis for this observation, the current study directly measured the half-life of F508 and wild-type CFTR at the cell surface of transfected LLC-PK1 cells.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Plasma membrane CFTR expression over time was characterized biochemically and functionally in these polarized epithelial cells.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Surface biotinylation, streptavidin extraction, and quantitative immunoblot analysis determined the biochemical half-life of plasma membrane F508 CFTR to be ~4 h, whereas the plasma membrane half-life of wild-type CFTR exceeded 48 h.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	8	 This difference in biochemical stability correlated with CFTR-mediated transport function.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	9	 These findings indicate that the F508 mutation decreases the biochemical stability of CFTR at the cell surface.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	10	 We conclude that the F508 mutation triggers more rapid internalization of CFTR and/or its preferential sorting to a pathway of rapid degradation.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	11	cystic fibrosis; regulation; membrane protein; endocytosis; chloride channel; cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	12	    INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	13	MOST CYSTIC FIBROSIS (CF) is caused by a gene mutation that results in the deletion of the phenylalanine at position 508 of CFTR, the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein (13).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	14	 The F508 deletion results in a misfolding of the nascent CFTR molecule in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), leading to its retention in the ER by chaparone proteins and its subsequent ubiquitination and premature degradation by the cytoplasmic proteosome complex (reviewed in Ref.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	15	 As a consequence, little if any F508 CFTR is processed to its mature, fully glycosylated form or trafficked to the plasma membrane where CFTR normally functions as a cAMP-activated chloride channel.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Because the F508 mutant retains some intrinsic chloride transport function (8, 18), interest in approaches that drive F508 CFTR past the ER quality control system and to the cell surface has grown.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	17	Several in vitro studies have shown that surface expression of F508 CFTR can be upregulated by chemical or physical means.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Butyrate compounds have been shown to create cAMP-activated chloride currents in cultured F508 cells, presumably by overwhelming the ER quality control system through an increase in gene transcription (4, 28).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Glycerol (30) and low temperature (8) stabilize the conformation of newly synthesized F508, allowing some of it to bypass the ER quality control system and reach biochemical maturity.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	20	 After each of these treatments, an increase in cAMP-activated chloride transport can be detected in the mutant cells.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	21	 These findings suggest that pharmacological agents that downregulate the ER quality control system might be useful in correcting the chloride transport defect in F508 cells.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	22	For this approach to be clinically effective, the F508 protein must maintain some degree of biochemical stability after reaching the cell surface.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Little is known, however, of the fate of the CFTR protein after it reaches the cell surface.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Initial work suggested that F508 and wild-type CFTR had similar plasma membrane half-lives (8), but a subsequent in vitro study has shown that cAMP-activated chloride currents in nonpolarized F508 cells are less stable than those in wild-type cells (23).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Because plasma membrane expression of the CFTR proteins was not directly examined in that study, the molecular basis for this observation is not known.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	26	 The functional instability in F508 cells could have been due to more rapid inactivation of F508 channels at the cell surface or to more rapid internalization and/or degradation of the mutant protein.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Functional inactivation is supported by data from several studies that show the conduction properties of F508 CFTR differ from those of wild-type CFTR (6, 9, 11).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	28	 In fact, a recent electrophysiological study has since confirmed that F508 CFTR is more rapidly inactivated than wild-type CFTR in excised membrane patches (31).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	29	Documented differences in vesicle trafficking of F508 and wild-type CFTR (2, 32) suggest a potential role for membrane trafficking in the regulation of plasma membrane CFTR function.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	30	 However, technical difficulties in getting measurable quantities of the F508 protein to the cell surface have hindered efforts to compare plasma membrane F508 and wild-type CFTR protein expression.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	31	 The current study overcame that obstacle by the simultaneous treatment of cells with low temperature and sodium butyrate, which act synergistically to markedly upregulate surface CFTR expression (12).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	32	 With readily detectable levels of F508 CFTR at the cell surface, it became possible to test the hypothesis that the F508 protein is more biochemically unstable than wild-type CFTR.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Performed in a polarized epithelial cell line, the experiments presented confirm that the biochemical half-life of plasma membrane F508 CFTR is much shorter than that of wild-type CFTR.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	34	 These differences in biochemical half-life correlate with transport function, suggesting that rapid internalization and/or degradation of F508 CFTR alone can account for the rapid loss of chloride transport function characteristic of F508 cells.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	35	    MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Pig kidney epithelial cells (LLC-PK1), stably transfected with human wild-type or F508-CFTR cDNA were kindly provided by Dr.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Seng Cheng (Genzyme, Boston, MA).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Cells were grown in low-glucose DMEM supplemented with 10% FBS and 400  microg/ml Genticin (Life Technologies, Grand Island, NY) at 37 degrees C on plastic dishes coated with human placental type IV collagen (Sigma Chemical, St.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	39	 For 125I efflux experiments, cells were grown on clear transwell membrane inserts coated with type IV collagen (Corning Costar, Cambridge, MA).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	40	 For immunocytochemical experiments, cells were grown on collagen-coated glass coverslips.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	41	Upregulation of surface CFTR expression.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Transfected LLC-PK1 cells grown to ~70% confluence as described above were treated for 60 h at 27 degrees C in the presence of 5 mM sodium butyrate to upregulate surface CFTR expression (12).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Because low temperature partially inhibits cell proliferation, cell overgrowth did not occur during this 60-h treatment, and confluency was rarely achieved.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	44	Biochemical determination of surface CFTR expression over time.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	45	 After upregulation of surface CFTR expression, cells were washed with butyrate-free media and were incubated at 37 degrees C in media containing 20  microg/ml of cycloheximide, an inhibitor of protein synthesis, for designated time intervals up to 48 h.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Cells were then washed with ice-cold PBS, pH 7.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	47	1 mM CaCl2 and 1 mM MgCl2 to inhibit vesicle trafficking, and surface biotinylation was performed as described previously (19).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Briefly, the glycosidic moieties of surface membrane proteins were derivatized with sodium periodate and biotinylated using biotin-LC-hydrazide according to company protocol (Pierce, Rockford, IL).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	49	 The efficiency of surface biotinylation was tested by examining the effect of increasing biotin-LC-hydrazide exposure times on surface CFTR expression.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	50	 No time-dependent increase in surface CFTR expression occurred with prolonged reagent exposure (data not shown).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	51	After surface biotinylation, cells were lysed with 1% SDS containing 0.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	52	2 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride and 1 mM benzamidine, sonicated to shear DNA molecules, and centrifuged at 10,000 g for 10 min at 4 degrees C to remove cellular debris.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	53	 The clear supernatants, normalized to 50  microg of total protein, were nutated for 30 min with an excess of streptavidin-coated agarose (SA) beads or uncoated control agarose (CN) beads (Sigma).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	54	 After incubation, the beads were pelleted, and the supernatants were subjected to 6.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	55	5% SDS-PAGE followed by transfer to Hybond-P polyvinylidene difluoride membrane (Amersham, Sunnyvale, CA).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The transfer was blocked with 5% nonfat dry milk in 137 mM NaCl, 0.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	57	1% Tween 20, and 20 mM Tris   HCl, pH 7.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	58	6, and immunoblotted with 1:100 dilution of R3194, an affinity-purified polyclonal anti-CFTR antibody.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	59	 The specificity of R3194 for CFTR has been characterized previously in transgenic mice (37), in CFTR- and mock-transfected HEK-293 cells (17), and by COOH-terminal CFTR peptide competition experiments (37).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	60	 CFTR bands were visualized by enhanced chemifluorescence (Amersham) and were quantified using a STORM 860 imaging system with ImageQuant software (Molecular Dynamics, Sunnyvale, CA).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	61	With the use of the above approach, biotinylated surface proteins were irreversibly extracted by the SA bead processing.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	62	 The efficiency of this extraction step was examined by stripping the immunoblots and reblotting with streptavidin-conjugated horseradish peroxidase followed by Sigma Fast diaminobenzidine color development to confirm the absence of biotinylated proteins in SA bead processed samples (see Fig.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Thus the post-SA bead supernatants contain only intracellular (unbiotinylated) proteins, whereas CN bead supernatants contain all cellular proteins (biotinylated and unbiotinylated).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Surface CFTR expression was then determined by subtracting the intensity of the CFTR signal after SA bead extraction from the intensity of the total CFTR signal from CN bead processed samples.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	65	Functional determination of surface CFTR expression over time.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Chloride secretion was determined by isotopic efflux of 125I from preloaded cells as previously described (33).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Briefly, membrane inserts containing LLC-PK1 cells treated with 20  microg/ml of cycloheximide at 37 degrees C were excised, and cells were washed with efflux buffer (140 mM NaCl, 4.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	68	2 mM CaCl2, 10 mM glucose, and 10 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	69	 The cells were then loaded with 125I by incubation with 3  microCi of 125I-labeled Na (New England Nuclear, Boston, MA) for 1 h at 37 degrees C.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Cell monolayers were washed free of excess 125I, and the time-dependent efflux of the isotope into the media was measured after stimulation with the cAMP agonists forskolin (10  microM) and isobutyl methylxanthine (IBMX, 1.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Cells were then solubilized with 0.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	72	1 N NaOH, and 125I radioactivity in the media samples and the final cell lysate was determined by counting gamma emissions (Packard Minaxi gamma counter, series 5000).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	73	 The rate coefficient of iodide efflux (r) was calculated using the following formula where R1 and R2 are the percent of counts remaining in the cell layer at times t1 and t2.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Data are presented as means  plus or minus  SE of replicate experiments.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Differential inhibition of 125I efflux by DIDS and diphenylamine-2-carboxylic acid was used to confirm that the cAMP-stimulated efflux from these cells was CFTR mediated.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	76	Immunocytochemical determination of surface CFTR expression.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Butyrate/low-temperature-treated cells, grown on collagen-coated coverslips, were fixed for 1 h with 4% paraformaldehyde and then permeabilized with 0.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Free aldehyde residues were quenched for 30 min with 50 mM NH4Cl, and cells were blocked with 1% BSA, both prepared in PBS.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Cells were then incubated overnight at 4 degrees C with R3194 (polyclonal anti-CFTR) and/or monoclonal antibody 6H (monoclonal against the -subunit of rat Na+-K+-ATPase, generously provided by Michael J.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Caplan, Yale School of Medicine, New Haven, CT).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Anti-CFTR labeling was detected with FITC-conjugated goat anti-rabbit F(ab')2 fragments, and anti-Na+-K+-ATPase labeling was detected with tetramethylrhodamine isothiocyanate-conjugated goat anti-mouse F(ab')2 fragments (Jackson ImmunoResearch Labs, West Grove, PA).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	82	 For double-label experiments, primary antibodies were applied simultaneously as were the fluorescent-conjugated secondary antibodies.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Fluorescent signals were visualized on an Axiophot fluorescent microscope (Zeiss) and digitally stored using Photoshop 4.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	84	01 software (Adobe Systems, Mountain View, CA).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Photoshop was not used to modify images other than to adjust contrast for improved signal definition.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	86	 No signal was detected in the absence of primary antibody, indicating that background labeling was low under the experimental conditions employed (data not shown).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	87	    RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	88	Because there is no natural cell type that expresses both F508 and wild-type CFTR, transfected cell lines have served as the standard model system for studying differences in the processing and trafficking of CFTR.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	89	 The most widely used cell lines (CHO, 3T3, C127, and HEK), however, are either unpolarized or of undetermined polarity.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Because vesicle trafficking in polarized and unpolarized cells may differ, we sought to examine CFTR surface expression in a transfected mammalian cell line with evidence of cellular polarity.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	91	 LLC-PK1 cells are transformed epithelial cells from the proximal tubule of pig kidney.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Morphological evidence for polarity was obtained by electron microscopy, which demonstrated the appearance of apical tight junctions in monolayers of transfected cells (Fig.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Functional polarity was demonstrated by double-label immunofluorescent microscopy experiments using apical and basolateral membrane markers.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	94	 1B, Na+-K+-ATPase expression in LLC-PK1 cells is primarily surface and basal in location, consistent with its known distribution along the basolateral membrane of polarized epithelial cells.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Although CFTR has both a surface and an intracellular signal in these high-expressing cells, the surface signal is more apically distributed and does not colocalize with that of Na+-K+-ATPase.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	96	 The prominent intracellular CFTR signal seen in these cells is discussed in greater detail below.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	97	 These experiments indicate that CFTR-transfected LLC-PK1 cells have both morphological and functional features characteristic of polarized epithelial cells.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	98	View larger version (95K):    Fig.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	99	   Analysis of LLC-PK1 cell polarity.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Wild-type LLC-PK1 cells were grown on permeable supports, and their polarity was determined both morphologically and functionally.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	101	 A: low (left)- and high (right)-magnification electron micrographs showing tight junctions at the apical domain of adjacent cells (arrowheads).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Original magnifications were  x 12,500 and  x 24,000, respectively.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	103	 B: double-label immunofluorescence micrographs of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR; green) and Na+-K+-ATPase (red) distribution in the same LLC-PK1 cells.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	104	 The distribution of both membrane proteins was captured through the apical, subapical, and basal regions of cells by epifluorescence microscopy.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	105	 CFTR labeling is seen throughout the cell, but membrane labeling is most prominent in the apical and subapical regions.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Na+-K+-ATPase is localized to the plasma membrane at the basal part of the cell.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	107	 The plasma membrane labeling pattern differs for each.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	108	For direct biochemical study of F508 expression at the plasma membrane, sufficient quantities of the protein had to be driven to the cell surface.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	109	 To accomplish this, cells were treated at 27 degrees C in the presence of 5 mM sodium butyrate to markedly upregulate surface CFTR expression (12).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Previous time course experiments identified 60 h of treatment as optimal for the upregulation of CFTR expression (12).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Although wild-type cells did not require butyrate or low temperature treatment for the detection of plasma membrane CFTR, we chose to control our experiments by treating all cells identically.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	112	 2, mature (band C) F508 CFTR was not detected in LLC-PK1 cells grown at 37 degrees C in the presence or absence of sodium butyrate, nor was it detected by immunoblot analysis in cells grown at 27 degrees C alone.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	113	 When sodium butyrate and low-temperature treatments were combined, however, there was a marked increase in total F508 CFTR expression that was accompanied by the appearance of the mature, fully glycosylated form (band C).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	114	 The upregulation of CFTR expression under these experimental conditions was even more pronounced in wild-type LLC-PK1 cells.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	115	View larger version (39K):    Fig.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	116	   Effect of sodium butyrate (SB) and temperature on CFTR protein expression.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	117	 F508 and wild-type LLC-PK1 cells were grown to ~70% confluence and then were treated for 60 h in the absence () or presence (+) of 5 mM sodium butyrate at 37 or at 27 degrees C.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	118	 After treatment, cells were harvested, lysed, and normalized to 50  microg total protein before SDS-PAGE and immunoblotting with the anti-CFTR antibody R3194.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Arrows identify CFTR bands B and C.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	120	Although mature (band C) CFTR has routinely been used as a marker of plasma membrane CFTR expression (5, 8, 30), studies in both native (26, 36) and transfected (21) cells have shown that not all mature CFTR resides at the cell surface.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	121	 To confirm that F508 CFTR was driven to the surface of LLC-PK1 cells by butyrate and low-temperature treatment, plasma membrane CFTR expression was measured biochemically, functionally, and cytochemically.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Surface biotinylation and streptavidin extraction were used to determine how much F508 protein actually reached the cell surface and what molecular form(s) of CFTR were targeted there.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	123	 3, most of the CFTR in treated F508 and wild-type LLC-PK1 cells did not reach the cell surface.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Based on replicate experiments (n = 5), ~35% of CFTR was found to reside at the cell surface (33.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	125	 These biotinylation experiments also demonstrated that only the mature band C form of CFTR was expressed at the plasma membrane.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	126	 The immature band B form was unaffected by streptavidin extraction, indicating that it was not biotinylated and therefore not present at the cell surface.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Surface expression of F508 CFTR after butyrate and low-temperature treatment was subsequently confirmed cytochemically and functionally (Fig.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	128	 The relative distribution of CFTR between surface and intracellular compartments, including the prominent intracellular signal, correlated with the above biotinylation data.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Functional evidence for surface CFTR expression in both cell lines was obtained by forskolin/IBMX-stimulated 125I efflux assay (Fig.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	130	View larger version (70K):    Fig.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	131	   Plasma membrane expression of CFTR.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	132	 F508 and wild-type LLC-PK1 cells were grown to ~70% confluence and then were treated with 5 mM sodium butyrate at 27 degrees C for 60 h to upregulate plasma membrane CFTR expression.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Cells were then surface biotinylated as described in MATERIALS AND METHODS.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Detergent lysates of the biotinylated cells were normalized to total protein (50  microg) and then reacted with streptavidin-conjugated agarose beads (SA) to remove all surface-biotinylated proteins or with plain agarose (control, CN) beads, which remove no protein.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Lysate proteins after bead treatment were separated by SDS-PAGE and were transferred to polyvinylidene difluoride membranes.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Top: transfer membrane was immunoblotted with R3194 to detect CFTR protein expression.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	137	 CN lanes depict total CFTR expression, whereas SA lanes show only the unbiotinylated (intracellular) proteins in those samples.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Arrows identify CFTR bands B and C.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Bottom: the same transfer membrane was stripped of antibodies and reblotted with streptavidin-conjugated alkaline phosphatase followed by diaminobenzidine reaction to detect the presence of biotinylated proteins in each lane.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	140	 The absence of biotinylated proteins in the SA lanes shows the efficiency of the streptavidin bead extraction step.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	141	View larger version (67K):    Fig.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	142	   Cytochemical and functional detection of plasma membrane CFTR.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Expression of F508 (left) and wild-type (right) CFTR at the plasma membrane after butyrate and low-temperature treatment was determined by immunofluorescence microscopy (top) and 125I efflux assay (bottom).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Arrows in the immunofluorescence micrographs denote plasma membrane CFTR labeling.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Arrows in the 125I efflux graphs note the time when cells were stimulated with forskolin/isobutyl methylxanthine (IBMX).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	146	 , Control condition (cells grown at 37 degrees C without any butyrate treatment); , 27 degrees C + SB.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	147	 125I efflux values represent means  plus or minus  SE from replicate experiments.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	148	With the use of the surface biotinylation procedure, the half-life of plasma membrane CFTR in F508 and wild-type cells was examined next (Fig.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	149	 In these experiments, surface CFTR expression was upregulated by pretreatment with sodium butyrate and low temperature.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Cells were then transferred to physiological temperature (37 degrees C) and treated for up to 48 h in the presence of cycloheximide.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Cells were then surface biotinylated, solubilized, and streptavidin-extracted, with immunoblot analysis being used to quantify CFTR protein expression.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	152	 The rapid fall in immature (band B) CFTR expression in the F508 cells was due to the inhibition of new protein synthesis by cycloheximide, combined with ER degradation and some conversion to the mature band C form.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	153	 5, band B CFTR was also rapidly degraded in wild-type cells (the signal was undetectable by 4 h, the earliest time point we examined).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	154	 These findings are consistent with the observations of Ward and Kopito (34), who demonstrated that the immature forms of F508 and wild-type CFTR have similar rates of degradation.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	155	View larger version (44K):    Fig.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	156	   Biochemical half-life of plasma membrane CFTR.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	157	 F508 and wild-type LLC-PK1 cells were pulsed with butyrate and low temperature and then were chased at 37 degrees C in the presence of 20  microg/ml cycloheximide for the times indicated.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	158	 At the completion of the chase, cells were transferred to 4 degrees C, and surface proteins were biotinylated, solubilized, and processed through either streptavidin (SA) or control (CN) agarose beads.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Postbead lysates, normalized to 50  microg total protein, were immunoblotted with R3194 anti-CFTR antibody.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Arrows identify CFTR bands B and C.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	161	In F508 cells, total band C CFTR expression was nearly eliminated by 6 h.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	162	 In contrast, total band C CFTR expression in the wild-type cells persisted for 48 h.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Although most of the band C CFTR was intracellular, the persistence of a streptavidin-extractable pool for as long as 48 h provides biochemical evidence for the presence of plasma membrane CFTR expression in wild-type cells for at least this length of time.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Because the relative distribution of CFTR between intracellular and plasma membrane compartments did not change appreciably over time (data not shown), the plasma membrane half-life of each protein was estimated by quantifying the rate of degradation of total band C CFTR.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	165	 From replicate experiments (n = 7), we calculated the biochemical half-life of plasma membrane CFTR in F508 cells to be ~4 h, whereas the biochemical half-life of plasma membrane CFTR in wild-type cells exceeded 48 h.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	166	To rule out the possibility that the relatively long plasma membrane half-life of wild-type CFTR was an artifact of overexpression, these biochemical and functional studies were repeated under conditions of comparable total CFTR expression in the two cells lines.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	167	 2, wild-type cells treated with sodium butyrate at 37 degrees C had CFTR expression levels that were comparable to those found in F508 cells treated with sodium butyrate at 27 degrees C.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Thus cells were pretreated in this manner and then processed and analyzed as described previously.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Under these conditions of comparable total CFTR expression, the biochemical half-life of band C CFTR in wild-type cells continued to exceed 24 h.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Surface biotinylation experiments also confirmed the presence of plasma membrane CFTR for at least this length of time (Fig.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	171	 This contrasts with the near absence of any detectable F508 protein after 6 h of chase.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Although we were able to detect some functional F508 CFTR at these early time points by the qualitative 125I efflux assay, no functional CFTR expression was detected in F508 cells after 24 h of chase, which contrasts sharply with the persistence of functional CFTR in the wild-type cells at this time.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Similar kinetic studies were performed in transfected (unpolarized) C127 cells, where F508 expression exceeds that of wild-type CFTR after butyrate and low-temperature treatment, and similar half-life values for F508 and wild-type CFTR were obtained (data not shown).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Thus several lines of evidence indicate that the difference in plasma membrane expression of F508 and wild-type CFTR reflects the biology of these two protein species and not simply overexpression.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	175	View larger version (41K):    Fig.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	176	   Half-life of plasma membrane CFTR under conditions of comparable levels of CFTR expression.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	177	 To confirm that the long plasma membrane half-life of wild-type CFTR was not an artifact of overexpression, an experiment was performed under conditions of comparable total CFTR expression in both cell types.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	178	 2, F508 cells treated with 5 mM sodium butyrate at 27 degrees C were compared with wild-type cells treated with 5 mM sodium butyrate at 37 degrees C.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	179	 After treatment, all cells were transferred to 37 degrees C and were incubated in the presence of 20  microg/ml cycloheximide for the times shown.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Top: biochemical half-life of F508 and wild-type CFTR after surface biotinylation, SA or CN bead extraction, and immunoblotting with R3194.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Bottom: 125I efflux from forskolin/IBMX-stimulated cells at baseline () and after 24 h of chase at 37 degrees C ().
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	182	 , Control condition (cells grown at 37 degrees C without any butyrate treatment or chase period).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	183	 The biochemical and functional stability of wild-type CFTR continues to exceed 24 h, even when relative overexpression is corrected.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	184	    DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	185	Until the long-term goals of gene therapy are realized, strategies designed to upregulate plasma membrane expression of F508 CFTR remain an important potential therapeutic option in CF (16, 29).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Much emphasis has been placed on the biogenesis of F508 CFTR, with the goal being to overcome its biosynthetic arrest and thereby increase the delivery of functional F508 CFTR channels to the cell surface.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Effective correction of the CF defect, however, will require stable expression of F508 after reaching the plasma membrane, and one study has shown that the functional half-life of plasma membrane F508 in intact cells is less than that of wild-type CFTR (23).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	188	 The current study sought to test the hypothesis that the short functional half-life in F508 cells results from more rapid removal of CFTR channels from the cell surface.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	189	To study the biochemical stability of plasma membrane F508 CFTR, sufficient quantities of the mutant protein needed to be driven to the cell surface.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	190	 The current study took advantage of combination therapy with sodium butyrate and low temperature to increase surface F508 protein expression to levels sufficient for the direct measurement of CFTR protein half-life by a quantitative immunoblot technique (12).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Thus, in all experiments, cells were pretreated with sodium butyrate and low temperature to upregulate CFTR protein expression and then were followed at 37 degrees C to examine the plasma membrane half-life of each CFTR species.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Because cell polarity can affect membrane trafficking, all experiments were performed in a polarized epithelial cell line (LLC-PK1).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	193	After butyrate and low-temperature treatment, most of the CFTR in these cells was intracellular.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Surface biotinylation experiments demonstrated that only the mature, fully glycosylated (band C) form of CFTR reached the cell surface.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	195	 No evidence for the direct targeting of immature (electrophoretic bands A and B) CFTR to the plasma membrane was found.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Quantitative analysis of CFTR distribution in butyrate/low-temperature-treated LLC-PK1 cells demonstrated that ~65% of band C CFTR remained intracellular.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	197	 This was true for both F508 and wild-type CFTR and is similar to observations made in other cell systems (26, 36).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Although changes in band C CFTR expression correlated with changes in plasma membrane CFTR expression in transfected LLC-PK1 cells, this may not be true in all cell types.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Thus surface protein labeling techniques remain the most accurate means of measuring plasma membrane CFTR expression.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	200	The biochemical finding of a prominent intracellular compartment of CFTR was confirmed immunocytochemically.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	201	 After butyrate/low-temperature treatment, both F508 and wild-type cells labeled similarly, with modest surface but prominent intracellular signals.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	202	 The identity of the intracellular signal in each cell type remains unknown.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	203	 In the wild-type cells, surface biotinylation demonstrated that most of the unbiotinylated CFTR is of the band C form and therefore is presumably in a post-ER compartment (Golgi, endosomes, transport vesicles, etc.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	204	 In F508 cells, where most of the unbiotinylated CFTR is of the band B form, a large ER component to the intracellular signal would be expected.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Identification of the sources of intracellular CFTR labeling in these cells will, however, require much additional study.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	206	The kinetics of F508 and wild-type CFTR degradation over time was examined at physiological temperature and under conditions of protein synthesis inhibition.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	207	 The rate of CFTR degradation was quantified biochemically and confirmed by functional assay.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Replicate experiments indicate that the biochemical half-life of plasma membrane F508 CFTR is ~4 h, whereas the biochemical half-life of plasma membrane wild-type CFTR exceeds 48 h.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	209	 These values correlate with changes in 125I efflux and are remarkably similar to the functional data generated by Lukacs et al.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	210	 (23) in nonpolarized C127 cells.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	211	 This time-dependent correlation between the rate of plasma membrane CFTR degradation and the loss of cAMP-stimulated 125I efflux indicates that the functional instability in F508 cells can be theoretically attributed to more rapid degradation of plasma membrane F508 CFTR.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	212	 The data, however, do not exclude a contributory role for channel inactivation in this process.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	213	These findings establish that the F508 mutation has a negative effect on the biochemical stability of CFTR at the cell surface.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	214	 This biochemical instability must be due to more rapid internalization of mutant protein and/or its selective targeting for rapid degradation.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	215	 CFTR is endocytosed in clathrin-coated vesicles (1, 22), and the molecular signal for CFTR internalization may reside in its cytoplasmic tail (10, 24, 25).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	216	 The F508 mutation, however, is in the first nucleotide-binding domain and is some distance from the cytoplasmic end of the molecule.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Thus CFTR must have another internalization signal, or the F508 mutation must have an indirect effect on the COOH-terminal signal(s).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Based on our understanding of CFTR folding during biogenesis, it is attractive to hypothesize that the F508 mutation affects CFTR folding in such a manner that the COOH-terminal internalization signal is altered.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	219	 The fundamental question is what is the signal? COOH-terminal tyrosine-based sequences have been implicated in the positioning of membrane proteins in coated pits (7, 20), and one recent study has implicated phosphorylation of tyrosine-1424 in the regulation of CFTR endocytosis (25).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	220	 On the other hand, the rate of internalization of Ste6, a yeast homolog of CFTR, and Ste3p, another yeast membrane protein, are regulated by ubiquitination (14, 27).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Because ubiquitination is the major signal for the degradation of both wild-type and F508 CFTR during biogenesis (35), it is provocative to speculate that it is also involved in plasma membrane CFTR degradation.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	222	 During CFTR biosynthesis, ubiquitination targets the immature forms of both F508 and wild-type CFTR to rapid proteosome degradation with similar kinetics (34).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	223	 A pool of wild-type CFTR, however, escapes this fate, becomes fully glycosylated, and reaches the plasma membrane.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	224	 If ubiquitination was also the signal for plasma membrane CFTR degradation, one would have to postulate that the wild-type and mutant proteins were differentially ubiquitinated at the cell surface to account for their different rates of degradation.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Because the yeast data suggest that the proteasome complex is not the final target of ubiquitinated plasma membrane Ste6 (15), one must also consider the possibility that ubiquitination of plasma membrane CFTR serves a different role (e.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	226	, signaling for internalization and/or sorting rather than proteosome degradation).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Although provocative, a role for ubiquitination in the downregulation of surface CFTR expression remains highly speculative at this time.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	228	Alternatively, mutant and wild-type CFTR may have similar rates of internalization but are differentially sorted in the endocytic compartment, with F508 being targeted for rapid lysosomal degradation while wild-type CFTR is recycled back to the plasma membrane.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	229	 In this case, the F508 mutation might be affecting the interaction of CFTR with specific GTP-binding (Rab) proteins that regulate vesicle trafficking (reviewed in Ref.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Rab4 has been most closely associated with sorting endosomes, so an understanding of its interactions with F508 and wild-type CFTR would be of particular interest.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Last, one must consider the effect of phosphorylation on CFTR trafficking, particularly in light of data showing that the rate of endocytosis differs in F508 and wild-type cells after cAMP activation (2).
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Although the current study did not examine the biochemical stability of plasma membrane CFTR under stimulatory conditions, the basal phosphorylation state of these two CFTR species may differ, and this, in turn, could expose different internalization signals.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	233	In conclusion, the F508 mutation dramatically reduces the residence time of CFTR at the cell surface.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	234	 This must be due to an effect of the mutation on the rate of CFTR internalization and/or its intracellular targeting.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Although little is known about this aspect of CFTR biology, it has clear implications for any therapeutic strategies that rely on delivering more F508 protein to the cell surface.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Frizzell for helpful discussions and acknowledge the technical assistance of Virginia Jeanes.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	237	This work was supported by the Office of Research and Development, Medical Research Service, Department of Veterans Affairs (C.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	238	 Marino) and by the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation (C.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	239	Address for reprint requests and other correspondence: C.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Marino, Medical Service (111), VA Medical Center, 1030 Jefferson Ave.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	241	, Memphis, TN 38104 (E-mail: cmarino{at}utmem.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	242	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	243	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	244	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
