0.48690367.11121388.html.plaintext.txt	352	Am J Physiol Cell Physiol 280(1):C166-C174.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	0	Transcriptional Adaptation to Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator Deficiency* Yan Xu , Jean C.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Divisions of  Pulmonary Biology,   Developmental Biology,   Pediatric Informatics, and  Pulmonary Medicine, Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center, Cincinnati, Ohio 45229-3039.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received for publication, October 8, 2002, and in revised form, November 13, 2002.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	3	    ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	4	Cystic fibrosis, the most commonly inherited lethal pulmonary disorder in Caucasians, is caused by mutations in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene (CFTR).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	5	 To identify genomic responses to the presence or absence of CFTR in pulmonary tissues in vivo, microarray analyses of lung mRNAs were performed on whole lung tissue from mice lacking (CFTR()) or expressing mouse CFTR (CFTR(+)).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Whereas the histology of lungs from CFTR() and CFTR(+) mice was indistinguishable, statistically significant increases in the relative abundance of 29 and decreases in 25 RNAs were identified by RNA microarray analysis.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Of RNAs whose expression was consistently altered by the absence of CFTR, functional classes of genes influencing gene transcription, inflammation, intracellular trafficking, signal transduction, and ion transport were identified.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	8	 RNAs encoding the transcription factor CCAAT enhancer-binding protein (CEBP)  and interleukin (IL) 1, both known to regulate CFTR expression, were induced, perhaps indicating adaptation to the lack of CFTR.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	9	 RNAs mediating lung inflammation including calgranulin-S100 family members, IL-1 and IL-4, were increased.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Likewise, expression of several membrane transport proteins that interact directly with CFTR were increased, suggesting that CFTR-protein complexes initiate genomic responses.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Absence of CFTR influenced the expression of genes modulating diverse pulmonary cell functions that may ameliorate or contribute to the pathogenesis of CF.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	12	     INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	13	Cystic fibrosis (CF)1 is the most common lethal, inherited pulmonary disorder and is caused by mutations in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) (1).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	14	 More than 800 distinct mutations in the CFTR gene have been associated with clinical diseases characteristic of cystic fibrosis (2).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Whereas many organs are affected in CF, morbidity and mortality in the disease is primarily related to mucus accumulation, recurrent infections, and excessive inflammation in the lung.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Whereas the pathogenesis of CF is not fully understood, abnormalities in cyclic AMP-dependent chloride secretion and excessive sodium reuptake by epithelial cells related to CFTR deficiency are thought to alter fluid homeostasis at the airway surface liquid leading to its dehydration, impaired mucociliary clearance, and infection (see Ref.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Because the elucidation of the primary structure of CFTR, a myriad of functions and numerous interactions with other cellular proteins have been ascribed to CFTR.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Thus, in addition to the role of CFTR in the regulation of cAMP-dependent chloride transport, this protein may play pleotropic roles in many cellular processes by interacting with the cytoskeleton, membrane transport proteins, as well as receptors, protein routing and degradation machinery (2).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	19	 A number of studies support the concept that the excessive inflammatory responses occur in the CF lung, but the mechanisms underlying these abnormalities have not been clarified.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Changes in levels of IL-8 and other proteins mediating inflammatory signaling including NFB and iNOS have been associated with CF, in the presence or absence of infection, raising the possibility that abnormalities in CFTR may constitutively alter pathways mediating inflammation (4-6).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	21	In the lung, CFTR is distributed primarily in apical regions of airway and submucosal gland epithelial cells (7).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Abundance and cellular sites of expression of CFTR are strongly influenced by developmental, spatial, and humoral factors, supporting the concept that the expression and function of CFTR are regulated at both transcriptional and post-transcriptional levels.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Despite extensive study, the precise role of CFTR in the pathogenesis of CF disease remains poorly understood.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	24	 At the clinical level, severity of CF disease is highly variable even among individuals bearing identical mutations, supporting the concept that environmental and hereditary factors may influence the severity of the disorder (2).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	25	 These clinical observations, and observations demonstrating strain differences in the severity of CF phenotype after CFTR gene targeting or mutation in mice (8), support the concept that the expression of CFTR and its function in cellular processes may be influenced by many genes or pathways intensifying or mollifying CF disease in various organs.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Morbidity and mortality in patients with CF is strongly associated with pulmonary disease caused by mucous accumulation, inflammation, and infection; however, deletion of CFTR mice does not cause significant pulmonary disease suggesting that expression of alternative channels or other complementary genes maintains pulmonary homeostasis in the mouse.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Whereas numerous in vitro and in vivo models have been developed for study of CFTR, analysis of genomic responses to the presence or absence of CFTR are complicated by heterogeneity of cell models, and culture conditions that may influence cell function and gene expression independently of CFTR.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Direct RNA analysis of pulmonary tissue from humans with CF is complicated by the nearly ubiquitous, severe pulmonary infections that may secondarily modify cellular responses and gene expression, complicating identification of responses to CFTR in vivo.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	29	In the present study, we undertook experiments to identify RNAs influenced by the presence and absence of CFTR in vivo, seeking to identify genes and pathways that interact with or compensate for the CFTR to maintain pulmonary function.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	30	 In this study, stereotypic genomic responses to the lack of CFTR were observed in pulmonary tissues in the absence of infection or disease.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	31	     MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	32	Transgenic mice bearing a null mutation in CFTR (CFTR()), generally succumb to intestinal disease in the weanling period (9).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	33	 To generate healthy mice deficient in CFTR, the human CFTR cDNA was expressed in the intestinal epithelium under control of the intestinal fatty acid-binding protein gene promoter (iFABP), fully correcting small intestinal pathology and supporting normal postnatal survival of CFTR() mice (10).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	34	 The iFABP-hCFTR, mCFTR() mice have been maintained in a mixed FVB/N, C57BL/6 background without evidence of gastrointestinal or pulmonary disease for nearly a decade in our laboratory.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Histological andbiochemical studies identified no overt pathology in lung tissue from these mice compared with CFTR expressing littermate controls (10, 11).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Mice were maintained in filtered microisolator cages.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Sentinal mice were free of mouse pathogens.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Lungs of adult iFABP-hCFTR, mCFTR(), and control mice were free of bacterial pathogens or colonization as assessed by quantitative culture of lung homogenates on blood agar plates.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	39	RNA Preparation-- Matings of FABP-hCFTR(+/+)/mCFTR(/) mice to wild type FVB/N-mCFTR(+/+) mice were used to produce F1 FABP-hCFTR(+/)/mCFTR(/+) mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	40	 These mice were crossed to generate F2 offspring littermates that were then genotyped, choosing FABP-hCFTR(+)/mCFTR() and hCFTR(+)/mCFTR(+) mice for use in RNA comparisons.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	41	 To minimize the potential influence of strain differences in this colony, lung RNA was isolated from sex-matched littermates at 3, 6, and 11 weeks of age.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	42	 RNA was also isolated from lungs of surviving CFTR()/hCFTR() and CFTR(+) littermates at 3 weeks of age for comparison with those bearing the iFABP-hCFTR transgene.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	43	 All CFTR(+) mice were heterozygous for the targeted mCFTR gene.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Lungs from sex-matched littermates were carefully dissected and the conducting airways and mediastinal structures removed.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	45	 RNA, cDNA synthesis, and microarray analysis were performed in pairs to minimize technical variability related to RNA and isolation and hybridization conditions.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Lungs were homogenized in TRIzol reagent (Invitrogen) using methods recommended by the manufacturer.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Genotyping was performed using the following primers: primers for mCFTR PCR: forward primer (intron 9), 5'-AGGGGCTCGCTCTTCTTTGTGAAC-3', and reverse primer (intron 10), 5'-TGGCTGTCTGCTTCCTGACTATGG-3'; neomycin resistance gene PCR: forward primer, 5'-CACAACAGACAATCGGCTGCT-3', and reverse primer, 5'-ACAGTTCGGCTGGCGCGAG-3'; and hCFTR PCR: forward primer (exon 9), 5'-AAACTTCTAATGGTGATGACAG-3', and reverse primer (exon 11), 5'-AGAAATTCTTGCTCGTTGAC-3'.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	48	Validation of RNAs by RT-PCR-- Changes in selected RNA levels identified in the microarray analysis were validated by RT-PCR using a Light CyclerTM or a regular thermocycler followed by gel electrophoresis.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	49	 For these studies, lung RNAs were isolated as described above.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	50	 cDNAs were generated by reverse transcription and PCR analysis was performed using the following primers for: Kir 4.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	51	2 forward, 5'-CTTTGAGTTTGTGCCTGTGGTTTC-3', and reverse, 5'-GCTGTGTGATTTGGTAGTGCGG-3'; human CFTR, same as above; and mouse CFTR forward, 5'-TGCTTCCCTACAGAGTCATCAACGG-3', and reverse, 5'-CACAGGATTTCCCACAACGCAGAG-3'; -actin for normalization, forward, 5'-TGGAATCCTGCGGCATCCATGAAC; reverse, 5'-TAAAACGCAGCTCAGTAACAGTCCG-3'; glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, forward, 5'-CTTCACCACCATGGAGAAGGC-3', and reverse, 5'-GGCATGGACTGTGGTCATGAG-3'; CCAAT enhancer-binding protein (CEBP) , forward, 5'-CGCAACAACATCGCTGTG-3', and reverse, 5'-GGGCTGGGCAGTTTTTTG-3'; TNF-AIP-3, forward, 5'-GCACGAATACAAGAAATGGCAGG-3', and reverse, 5'-GGCATAAAGGCTGAGTGTTCACG-3'; and Grin 2d, forward, 5'-CCTTCTTTGCCGTCATCTTTCTTGC-3', and reverse, 5'-AAACTTCAGGGGTGGGTATTGCTCC-3'.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	52	RNA Microarray and Data Analysis-- Total RNA was subjected to reverse transcription using oligo(dT) with T7 promoter sequences attached, followed by second strand cDNA synthesis.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Antisera cRNA was then amplified and biotinylated using T7 RNA polymerase, prior to hybridization to the Affymetrix genechip mouse U74aV2 using the Affymetrix recommended protocol (12, 13).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Affymetrix MicroArray Suite version 5.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	55	0 was used to scan and quantitate the genechips using default scan settings.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Intensity data were collected from each chip, scaled to a target intensity of 1500, and the results were analyzed using both MicroArray Suite and GeneSpring 5.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	57	cDNAs were hybridized to U74aV2 chips (Affymetrix Inc.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Hybridization data were normalized in a CCAAT enhancer-binding protein two-step process to remove or minimize systemic sources of variation at both chip and gene level.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Specifically, each chip was normalized to the distribution of all genes on the chip to control for variation between samples.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Each RNA from mCFTR() mice was normalized to its specific control (i.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	61	 sex and age-matched mCFTR(+) littermates).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Data were further transformed into log ratio for analysis and symmetry of distribution.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Changes in mRNAs were identified by the combination of a distribution analysis (JMP4, SAS Institute, Inc.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	64	), and the Welch analysis of variance.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Outlier box and quartile box plots were used to identify outliers with the definition of up-outlier  >  upper quartile + 1.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	66	5 (interquartile range), and the down-outlier  <  lower quartile  1.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Significant changes were calculated by the Welch t test at p  <  0.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Adjusted p values were calculated by Westfall and Young permutation for correction of false positives (GeneSpring 4.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Comparisons between genotype and age groups were performed using one-way analysis of variance.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	70	 To identify genes that were differentially expressed because of CFTR genotype regardless of age, hierarchical, and k-means clustering were used to identify consistent changes in gene expression in response to the lack of CFTR at all three time points.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Candidate RNAs were further filtered on the basis of reproducibility and absolute intensity.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Mean, standard deviation, and coefficient variation were calculated for each replicate.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Replicates with coefficient variations  >  50% were deleted from analysis.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Genes whose expression was below the level of detection were eliminated as experimental noise.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	75	Pathway and Literature Analysis-- Selected genes were subjected to intensive search to identify biological function and associated regulatory pathways.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	76	 A U74Av2 annotation data base with system identifiers was constructed for all the array elements and their associated GenBankTM accession numbers.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Gene description, functional categories, biological processes, molecular functions, cellular components, protein domain, and literature information were identified.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Information resources included NetAffy (www.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	79	com), Source Search genome-www5.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	80	edu/cgi-bin/SMD/source/), BLAST NCBI, Locus Link, mouse-human homolog search (www.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	81	gov), and Gene Ontology data base (www.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Differentially expressed genes were classified into functional categories based on the gene ontology definition.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	83	 To determine which functional category is overrepresented in the selected gene list, the binomial probability was calculated for each category using the entire U74Av2 (contains 12488 mice genes) as a reference data set.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The binomial probability is defined by the following.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	85	 1) It returns the probability of getting k successes of n trials if the probability is p in the given population (U74Av2).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Potential protein/protein or protein/DNA interactions were identified using the published literature information.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	87	Lung Histology and Immunohistochemistry-- Lungs from postnatal animals were inflation fixed with 4% paraformaldehyde at 25 cm H2O pressure via a tracheal cannula.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Lung tissue was processed according to standard methods and embedded in paraffin.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Procedures for immunostaining were previously described (14).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Rabbit monoclonal antibody against the 110-kDa Mac-3 antigen was used at 1:40,000 to identify alveolar macrophages (BD Pharmingen, San Diego, CA).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	91	     RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	92	Histology and Immunohistochemistry-- Lung histology in adult iFABP-hCFTR, CFTR(); iFABP-hCFTR, CFTR(+), and CFTR(+) control mice was not different (Fig.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	93	 There was no evidence of pulmonary inflammation, infection, or remodeling.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Mac-3 staining was used to identify alveolar macrophages.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Numbers and histology of alveolar macrophages were not altered by mCFTR.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	96	View larger version (133K):    Fig.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	97	   Normal lung histology in CFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Lung tissue was obtained after inflation fixation from iFABP-hCFTR, mCFTR() mice (B and D) and iFABP-hCFTR, mCFTR(+) littermates (A and C) at 3 months of age.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Lung histology after staining with hematoxylin-eosin (A and B) or Mac-3 antibody (C and D), a marker of alveolar macrophages, were not altered in the CFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	100	Identification of Gene Responses to the Lung CFTR Deletion-- To identify genes responsive to CFTR, lung RNAs from iFABP-hCFTR, mCFTR(), iFABP-hCFTR, mCFTR(+), mCFTR() and mCFTR(+) littermates at the age of 3, 6, or 11 weeks of age were compared.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Microarray analyses were performed in duplicate from RNA isolated at 3 and 6 weeks of age.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Data from 10 Affymetrix Murine Genome U74Av2 chips were normalized and statistical differences between CFTR-deficient (CFTR()) and control (CFTR(+)) mice were identified.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Differences related to age were identified by outlier analysis and/or unpaired t test.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	104	 After normalization, normal distributions were observed in the intensity data from lung tissue obtained at all ages.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Lung RNA data from 3-week-old mCFTR(+) and mCFTR() mice (lacking the iFABP-hCFTR transgene) were similarly distributed to those bearing the FABP-hCFTR gene and were, therefore, included in the analysis.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	106	To identify RNAs that were differentially expressed in response to CFTR regardless of age, mCFTR() and mCFTR(+) data were separated into two groups.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	107	 The log-ratio distribution and outlier plot of the combined data set are represented by Fig.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	108	 A total of 1977 outliers were identified from 12442 genes/expressed sequence tags analyzed.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	109	 The abundance of 848 RNAs was increased; 1129 were decreased.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Welch t test together with the Westfall and Young step-down permutation further narrowed the number of differentially expressed RNAs to 315.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Hierarchical clustering was used to visualize and classify the data set (Fig.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Data are shown in a two-dimensional matrix to identify groups of genes with similar expression patterns and show remarkably ordered gene expression profiles of 315 selected genes.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	113	 On the chip level (top dendrogram) RNAs influenced by CFTR formed two distinct groups.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Within each group, the samples collected from age-matched pairs were more closely related than those from different ages, suggesting that age also influenced gene expression.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	115	 At the RNA level (the dendrogram at the left side), genes were clearly separated into two major groups: those mRNAs increased or decreased in mCFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Genes were further filtered for the consistency of differences in expression levels across all time points (coefficient variation  <  50%) and for their absolute intensity above 243 (90% of genes called absent by Affymetrix software,  < 243 for this data set).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Additional filters reduced the number of RNAs to 54, of which 29 were consistently increased and 25 were decreased in mCFTR() compared with their mCFTR(+) littermates (Tables I and II).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	118	 The expression profiles of these 54 genes are shown in Fig.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	119	 4, demonstrating consistent patterns of expression of the CFTR-responsive RNAs regardless of age.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	120	View larger version (28K):    Fig.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	121	   Distribution of lung RNAs from mCFTR() and mCFTR(+) mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	122	 The left panel is a histogram of log ratio and gene frequency.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	123	 The right panel is the outlier box plot.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	124	 The ends of the dashed lines, denoted by an x and y markers, are the outliers identified from their respective quartiles.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	125	View larger version (47K):    Fig.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	126	   Two-dimensional hierarchial clustering of 315 genes/expressed sequence tag that were significantly altered in response to the presence or absence of mCFTR.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Intensity in the red and green color range indicates up-regulated and down-regulated RNAs, respectively.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Each row represents a single gene.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Each column represents a particular experimental condition.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Each box represents the normalized RNA intensity value.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Clustering was performed by UPGMA.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Similarity measures were assessed utilizing Euclidean distance.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	133	                              View this table:    Table I Genes up regulated in mCFTR() versus mCFTR(+) mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	134	                              View this table:    Table II Genes down-regulated in mCFTR () mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	135	View larger version (31K):    Fig.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	136	   Expression profile chart (A) and hierarchical clustering (B) of 54 selected RNAs that were consistently altered in response to the lack of CFTR regardless of age.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Hierarchical clustering was performed by UPGMA.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Data were normalized using Trimmed Mean and Z-score calculations.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	139	 In the profile chart, data were normalized by pairwise control.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	140	 The y axis is normalized intensity (log scale) and the x axis represents experimental ages.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Red lines represent the profiles of lung RNAs increased in CFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Green lines represent the profiles of down-regulated RNAs.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	143	Differentially expressed genes were further classified according to their known or predicted functions.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Each gene was annotated and assigned to a functional category.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	145	 To simplify the calculation, we assumed that genes in each category could be fit to a binomial distribution.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	146	 The binomial probability was calculated for each category using the entire U74Av2 as reference data set.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	147	 "Inflammatory Response" was the most represented category of those RNAs increased in mCFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Among RNAs whose abundance was increased by the lack of CFTR, those influencing inflammation, transcription, and transport were most highly represented and consisted of a group of functional categories quite distinct from those whose expression was decreased in mCFTR() mice (Tables I-III).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	149	                              View this table:    Table III Functional Categories of the gene list.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	150	The potential influence of the FABP-hCFTR transgene on RNA expression was also assessed using the Welch t test at the three ages.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Differentially regulated RNAs identified in analysis of gastrointestinal-corrected mice were similarly affected in mCFTR() mice, demonstrating a lack of effect of iFABP-hCFTR on this subset of genes.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Genes whose expression was independently altered by the iFABP-hCFTR transgene included 7 RNAs decreased and 11 increased.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Differences in their levels of expression were modest (less than 1.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	154	                              View this table:    Table IV The effect of fabp-hCFTR(+) on lung gene expression Lung RNA samples from iFABP-hCFTR,CFTR() (i.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	155	 gut corrected, GC) were compared with those from CFTR(+) (lacking the iFARP-hCFTR transgene, i.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Ratio is defined as: R = GC/NGC, if (GC  >  NGC); R = NGC/GC if (GC  <  NGC).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	157	Validation of Selected mRNAs-- To validate the responsive RNAs identified by microarray analyses, real time RT-PCR was performed.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	158	 mRNA levels were normalized using -actin or glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	159	2 (Kcnj15), CEBP, TNF-AIP-3, and Grin 2d mRNA were significantly increased in CFTR() mice compared with control littermates (Fig.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	160	 As expected, murine CFTR was not detectable by RT-PCR in mCFTR() mice, nor was hCFTR mRNA detected in lung from the iFABP-hCFTR bearing mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	161	View larger version (19K):    Fig.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	162	   Real time PCR analysis of Grin 2d (A), Kir4.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	163	2 (B), CEBP (C), and TNF-AIP-3 (D).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Lung mRNA abundance was determined by RT-PCR using a Light CyclerTM in tissue from mCFTR() (open) and mCFTR(+) mice (black).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Values were normalized to -actin or glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase RNAs and represent mean  plus or minus  S.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	166	, n = 56 determinations and differences were assessed by paired t test.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	167	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	168	The absence of CFTR caused stereotypic changes in gene expression in the lungs of CFTR() mice in the absence of detectable infection or inflammation.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Cellular responses to CFTR included enhanced expression of transcription factors and signaling pathways known to influence CFTR gene expression (IL-1 and CEBP).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Likewise, expression of RNAs modulating inflammation, ion transport, protein trafficking, and degradation were altered, indicating that a number of cellular pathways may compensate for or mediate CFTR-dependent functions that, in turn, may maintain normal pulmonary homeostasis in the CFTR() mice or alternatively, influence CF phenotype following response to pathogens.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	171	 The absence of CFTR initiates reproducible changes in lung gene expression that may modify inflammation, host defense, and other cellular functions, that likely contribute to or mollify the pathogenesis of pulmonary disease in CF.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	172	Because strain is known to influence pulmonary findings in CF mice (8), and the transgenic mice presently studied were generated in a mixed FVB/N, C57 Bl/6 background, lung RNA was compared from sex-matched littermates at various ages.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	173	 An extensive data set was utilized to identify CFTR-dependent changes in gene expression that were present throughout development and in the absence of inflammation, seeking to identify pathways influenced primarily by CFTR, rather than sex, strain, age, or other secondary phenomena.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	174	 As expected, expression of mCFTR was not detected in the gastrointestinal-corrected mCFTR() mice, consistent with previous findings (10).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Histologic analyses, performed presently and previously, demonstrated no structural abnormalities, infection or inflammation in the lungs of these mice as maintained in our vivarium (10, 11), supporting the concept that changes in gene expression were related to CFTR and not to age or lung disease.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Analysis of arrays prepared from pairs of mCFTR() mice and mCFTR(+) littermates (those lacking the iFABP-hCFTR transgene), confirmed the microarray findings, demonstrating both the lack of mCFTR mRNA in lungs of the mCFTR() and that RNA changes were independent of the iFABP-hCFTR transgene.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	177	Expression of Genes Modulating CFTR-- Expression of a number of genes known to influence CFTR expression was enhanced in the lungs of CFTR() mice, including CEBP and IL-1 suggesting that CFTR cells responded by enhancing levels of RNAs encoding transcription factors or pathways that may compensate for the lack of CFTR.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	178	 IL-1 increased CFTR gene transcription in epithelial cells in vitro (15) and cis-acting elements binding CEBP (to CCAAT enhancer sites) and c-Fos (to AP-1 elements) are present in the promoter-enhancer regions of the mouse CFTR gene (16, 17).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Previous studies demonstrated that CEBP directly enhanced CFTR gene transcription in vitro (18), thus, the increased CEBP expression may represent a potential compensatory response to CFTR deficiency that, in turn, may influence expression of genes unrelated to CFTR.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Expression of c-fos was also increased in the mCFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Whereas AP-1 sites have been identified in the hCFTR promoter, the precise role of c-fos in regulation of CFTR has not been clarified; although treatment of various cell types with phorbol esters decreased CFTR gene transcription in vitro (18).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Because CEBP and c-fos activate or inhibit the expression of numerous genes that share cis-active elements with the CFTR gene, changes in their activity may broadly influence gene expression, perhaps inadvertently linking CFTR deficiency to the expression of genes whose activities are not directly related to CFTR protein function.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	183	 RNA encoding TNF-AIP-3, a zinc finger transcription factor, was also increased in the CFTR() mice, further linking transcription responses to the lack of CFTR.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Of considerable interest, TNF-AIP-3 RNA was induced by either IL-1 or TNF.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	185	 TNF-AIP-3 inhibited NFB translocation in vitro, and may represent a compensatory response to the increased expression of IL-1 seen in the CFTR() mice (19).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	186	 JAK-3, nuclear receptor subfamily 2, and interferon regulatory factor-1 RNAs were decreased in CFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	187	 These RNAs encode transcription factors that regulate various pathways involved in inflammation and may, therefore, represent responses to the proinflammatory proteins induced in the CFTR() mice, in essence, being secondarily responsive to initial compensatory changes.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	188	Enhanced Expression of Genes Modulating Inflammation-- Genes involved in inflammation were overly represented among the RNAs induced and were distinct from those that were decreased in the lungs from CFTR() mice (Table III).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Most prominent among genes whose expression was increased were a family of calcium-binding proteins termed the calgranulins (S100A8, S100A9, and calbindin D9K).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	190	 S100A8 is expressed primarily by macrophages and monocytes and its expression is enhanced by various cytokines including TNF-, IL-1, and interferon  (20, 21).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	191	 This family of peptides is expressed by various cell types and share potent chemoattractant activities, stimulating inflammatory cell trafficking.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Increased expression of S100A8 (calgranulin A) was previously demonstrated in alveolar macrophages from CFTR mutant mice, the authors suggesting that increased S100A8 may contribute to the enhanced inflammatory responses seen in the absence of CFTR (22).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Expression of S100A8 by alveolar macrophages was induced by TNF-, interferon  and IL-1, mediated at least in part by AP-1-dependent pathways (20).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Chitinase A mRNA was also consistently increased in the lungs of CFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	195	 The acidic chitinase A is a small peptide containing a mammalian lectin domain that binds complex carbohydrates on surfaces of microbial pathogens including fungi.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Like the S100 family of proteins, chitinase family members are also expressed by alveolar macrophages in the lung (23).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Thus, decreased mCFTR initiated changes in expression of gene expressed primarily in alveolar macrophages.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	198	 It remains unclear whether these responses are mediated by direct effects of CFTR in alveolar macrophages or by altered cellular signaling initiated by the lack of CFTR in epithelial or other pulmonary cells that secondarily alters macrophage activity.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	199	Intense neutrophilic infiltration and an increased IL-8 production are strongly associated with CF lung disease in humans (2).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Increased IL-8 and neutrophilic infiltrates were observed in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid from CF patients in the absence of documented pulmonary infection (4).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Although it remains possible that antecedent, but resolved, infections may have contributed to the increased inflammation observed in the CF, these observations support the concept that CF is associated with increased susceptibility to pulmonary inflammation.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	202	 In the present study, IL-1, IL-4, and CSF-1 receptor RNAs were increased and each may contribute to the proinflammatory milieu.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	203	 IL-1 enhances CFTR gene transcription, induces inflammation, and is known to stimulate production of the S100-calgranulins, perhaps indicating a network of genes influenced by CFTR through IL-1.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	204	 IL-4 is a potent inflammatory mediator that enhances inflammation and mucous production in airway epithelia.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Transgenic animals expressing IL-4 or animal models in which IL-4 is induced developed severe goblet cell hyperplasia, increased mucous production, and inflammatory cell infiltrates (24), findings typically found in patients with cystic fibrosis.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	206	 CSF-3r RNA encoding a receptor that mediates monocytic cell migration, proliferation, and activity in response to CSF-3 (G-CSF) was increased 3-4-fold in the CFTR() mice (25).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Thus, taken together, expression of a number of genes; many influenced by IL-1 and mediating inflammation, were induced in the lungs of CFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	208	Despite the increased expression of proinflammatory molecules, there is no evidence of inflammation in the lung of the CFTR() mice perhaps indicating that normal homeostasis is maintained by the complex responses of the lung to the lack of CFTR.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	209	 The presence of stereotypic changes in expression of many genes suggests that the presence of a single ameliorating gene, for example, an alternative chloride channel, does not fully explain the physiologic adjustment of the lung the CFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	210	 At present, it is unclear whether these proinflammatory responses are secondary to changes in the expression and function of CFTR in the epithelial cells that, in turn, modulate cell signaling and cytokine production in the lung.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Alternatively, the absence of CFTR in the alveolar macrophages may alter expression of genes mediating inflammation in those cells.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	212	 It is of considerable interest that changes in RNAs modifying inflammation were altered in the lungs of mCFTR() mice in the absence of detectable bacterial infection or inflammation, supporting the concept that the transcriptional adjustment to CFTR deficiency suffices to maintain normal pulmonary homeostasis in the mouse in vivo.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Alternatively, the levels of expression of the proinflammatory molecules may not be adequate to cause histologically detectable inflammation.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	214	 It remains unclear whether these adjustments in gene expression may, in turn, render the CFTR() mice susceptible to inflammation following infection or injury.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	215	Changes in NFB- and TNF--dependent Pathways-- RNAs encoding a number of proteins involved in TNF signaling and NFB activation were also induced in the CFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	216	 The abundance of TNF-AIP-3 mRNA, a zinc finger transcription protein, a protein whose expression is induced by both TNF- and IL-1, was increased in the CFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	217	 TNF-AIP-3 inhibits NFB activity at target genes (19) and may represent a response to the proinflammatory milieu established in the CFTR() lung.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	218	 PEG-3, a protein that regulates the induction of NFB following TNF stimulation, was also increased, providing for the support for transcriptional relationships between CFTR deficiency and activity of NFB (26).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Recent studies of Schroeder et al.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	220	 (27) support the concept that the CFTR is required for regulation of NFB, serving as a pattern-associated molecular recognition molecule, following pulmonary exposure to Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	221	 In that study, NFB activation and its nuclear trafficking were deficient in CF cells.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Taken together with the observation that IL-1-mediated transcription of CFTR gene transcription is dependent upon NFB, this important pathway mediating inflammation appears to be influenced by CFTR.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	223	In the present microarray analysis, CFTR deficiency was associated with increased claudin 8 and decreased gap junction connexin 37.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Decreased expression of gap junction proteins (Cx43, 40, -37, and -32) and decreased gap junction communication were observed in various in vitro cell systems after exposure to proinflammatory cytokines (28).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	225	 The observed changes in RNAs mediating cell adhesion and increased expression of IL-1 seen in the CFTR() mice are consistent with findings that in the absence of CFTR, IL-1 and TNF- failed to inhibit cell communication via gap junctions.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Previous studies demonstrated that CFTR is required for the uncoupling of gap functions between epithelial cells during inflammation, a process that may restrict the spread of pathogens or signaling among adjacent cells.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	227	 It will be of interest to test whether cell adhesion mediated by the claudins is also linked to the pathogenesis of CF.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	228	Changes in Protein Degradation Pathways-- Several genes involved in protein degradation were altered in the absence of CFTR compared with normal.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Proteosome 26 S subunit (PSMC3) is the major proteolytic component of the ubiquitin-dependent proteosome.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Proteosome 26 S regulates degradation of proteins influencing cell cycle, oncogenesis, transcription, and immunity, including CFTR itself (29, 30).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	231	 The proteosome is composed of two subcomplexes, the 20 S proteosome and PA700.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	232	 PSMC3 expression was modestly, but significantly increased (1.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	233	 In contrast, PA28 (PSME3), an activator of the 20 S proteosome, was decreased 1.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	234	 These observations are consistent with previous findings that proinflammatory cytokines, including TNF- or interferon- increased expression of the 26 S proteosome and its activators PA28  and  (31), whereas expression of PA28  was decreased by interferon- (32).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	235	 RNA encoding adaptor protein complex AP-2, 1 subunit (Ap2a1), a protein involved in the formation of intracellular transport vesicles was also decreased in the absence of CFTR.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	236	 CFTR co-precipitates with -adaptin (33).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Recent studies demonstrated that a C-terminal domain of CFTR binds to the AP-2 adaptor complex to form clathrin-coated vesicles that mediates CFTR internalization (34).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	238	 ADP-ribosylation factor 5 belongs to a family of GTP-binding proteins that play important roles in the control of membrane trafficking, including formation of secretory vesicles at the trans-Golgi network, endosomal and vesicle-plasma membrane fusion (35).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Recent studies support the concept that CFTR regulates endosomal fusion and vesicular trafficking (36, 37) indicating potential relationships between CFTR and the actions of ADP-ribosylation factor 5.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Another gene in this functional category is represented by kinesin3, an mRNA that was decreased in the lungs of CFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	241	Transport Proteins Influenced by CFTR-- RNAs encoding several transmembrane transport proteins and receptors were also altered in the lungs of CFTR() mice, including solute carrier 38 (member 4), the potassium inwardly rectifying channel (Kir 4.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	242	2 or Kcnj 15), the glutamate receptor (Grin 2d), the naturietic peptide receptor 3 (Npr-3), and the 3-adrenergic receptor (ADRB-3).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	243	 Thus, expression of a number of membrane transport proteins was influenced by CFTR, perhaps representing compensatory responses to defects in CFTR-mediated transport activity.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	244	2 and Grin 2d RNAs were increased 2-3-fold in CFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	245	2 is expressed in respiratory epithelial cells at sites similar to that of CFTR (38).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	246	2 regulates cation transport upon which chloride transport via CFTR or other chloride channels may be influenced.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	247	 Surprisingly, there is evidence for interactions between CFTR and Kir family members because they are both known to bind via PDZ binding domains through interactions with channel interacting PDZ domain protein (39).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Likewise, there is precedence for PDZ-dependent interactions among glutamate receptors, CFTR, and Kir family members (40).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	249	 Thus, the lack of CFTR enhanced the expression of a number of membrane proteins that may interact with CFTR via PDZ domains, perhaps indicating that CFTR-protein complexes may initiate changes in gene expression.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	250	 These findings support the concept that CFTR interacts with numerous membrane transport proteins and do not support a model in which activity of an alternative Cl transporter alone suffices to compensate for the lack of CFTR in pulmonary cells in the CFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	251	Regulation of Cell Receptors by CFTR-- Natriuretic peptide receptor C (Npr-3 or NprC) was increased more than 2-fold in CFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Natriuretic peptides comprise a family of 3 structurally related molecules: atrial (ANP), brain (BNP), and C-type (CNP) whose functions are cGMP-dependent (41, 42).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Among them, CNP increased ciliary beat, mucociliary clearance in airway epithelial cells, and activated CFTR-dependent chloride transport (42).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Natriuretic peptides regulate cytokine-stimulated NO production via the binding of Npr-3 (43).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Because deficient NO production was observed in respiratory epithelial cells of the iFABP-hCFTR, CFTR() mice, the increased expression of Npr-3 in CFTR() mice may represent a compensatory response influencing airway clearance and nitric oxide production via cGMP (44).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	256	 In contrast to the transport/receptors that were induced, ADRB3, a G protein-coupled transmembrane protein mediating cAMP production was decreased in CFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	257	 ADRB3 is co-expressed with CFTR in airway epithelium (45) and may be functionally coupled to CFTR via cAMP-independent pathways (46).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	258	 2-Adrenergic receptors directly interact with CFTR via the Na(+)/H(+) exchanger regulatory factor to form a signal transduction complex (47).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Co-regulation of ADRB3 and CFTR may indicate that these proteins interact closely at both structural and functional levels, a finding that may be linked to the important role of -adrenergic stimulation and cAMP in the activation of chloride transport mediated by CFTR.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	260	Altered Expression of RNAs Encoding CFTR Interacting Proteins-- Surprisingly, analysis of the RNA influenced by CFTR identified a number of proteins that directly or indirectly interact with CFTR via protein-protein interactions.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	261	 This list included proteins involved in protein trafficking and degradation (proteosome 26 S and PA28 subunits and -adaptin), ion transport (Kcnj15 and Grin 2d), and receptors (Npr-3 and ADRB3).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Interaction of CFTR with many proteins occurs via PDZ binding domains that mediate protein-protein complex formation.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	263	 The finding that expression of CFTR interacting proteins is altered in the lungs of CFTR() mice, suggests that CFTR influences networks of signaling and transport activities in the cell and that cells respond to CFTR deficiency via transcriptional responses to CFTR-protein complexes, rather than to CFTR per se.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	264	Are Changes in Gene Expression Bystander Effects?-- Whereas genomic responses may compensate for the lack of CFTR mRNA and represent compensation for CFTR function, some responses may be secondary and mediated by pathways not directly related to the action of CFTR per se.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	265	 Alterations in cytokine production or changes in transcription factor activity caused by the absence of CFTR may secondarily change the behavior of numerous cell types, that may, in turn, contribute to the pathogenesis of CF lung disease by processes that are not direct functions of CFTR.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	266	 Because CFTR is known to form a membrane-associated cyclic nucleotide-activated Cl channel and interacts with numerous other cellular proteins, changes in gene expression may indicate that cells sense the CFTR protein, CFTR-dependent activity, or CFTR-protein complexes that initiate transcriptional responses related to or unrelated to CFTR function.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	267	 At present, it is unclear whether the "sensor" is chloride ion, the presence of CFTR, or CFTR-protein complexes in intracellular and membrane compartments or to other functions of CFTR.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	268	 Likewise, the hierarchy and interrelatedness of the networks of RNA responses to CFTR deficiency remain to be unraveled.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	269	Maintenance of pulmonary homeostasis in the mCFTR() mouse was associated with complex adaptive responses in gene expression.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	270	 CFTR influenced RNAs encoding transcription factors, ion channels, membrane receptors, cytokines, and intracellular trafficking proteins.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	271	 Finally, CFTR altered the expression of a number of proteins that interact with CFTR via protein-protein interactions perhaps representing transcriptional responses to functions mediated by CFTR() protein complexes (Fig.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	272	 The diversity of genes whose expression was altered by CFTR support the concept that, in addition to regulation of Cl transport, CFTR plays diverse roles in multiple cellular functions.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	273	 The present findings support the hypothesis that pulmonary homeostasis in the CFTR() mouse is maintained by complex genomic responses to the lack of CFTR rather than by the action of a single alternative Cl channel.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	274	 Finally, the genes and pathways identified in this study provide new links between CFTR and cellular processes that may influence the pathogenesis of CF lung disease.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	275	View larger version (40K):    Fig.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	276	   Molecular pathways and networks influenced by CFTR.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	277	 A model is proposed by which the lack of CFTR initiates expression of genes that are known to enhance CFTR expression IL-1 and CEBP, secondarily modulating inflammation (1, 2).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	278	 Increased expression of cytokines, IL-4 and IL-1, and the cytokine receptor, CSF-3R, may influence inflammation (2) as well as expression of genes modulating protein trafficking, degradation, and cell-cell communication (3-5).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Abundance of RNA of chemoattractant peptides of the calgranulin family were enhanced, perhaps contributing to a proinflammatory environment within the lung (2).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	280	 CFTR altered the expression of RNAs encoding transport proteins and membrane receptors that likely interact with CFTR via PDZ domains (6, 7) supporting the concept that pulmonary cells respond to the lack of CFTR or CFTR complexes by regulating the expression of CFTR partners.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	281	 Alterations in pathways regulating second messengers, including cAMP, via the 3-adrenergic receptor (Adrb3), were observed (7).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Absence of CFTR also influenced expression of genes mediating endocytosis, membrane recycling, and regulated secretion (4, 8, 9).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	283	We thank Theresa Richardson for technical support.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	284	* This work was supported by the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation and National Institutes of Health Grant HL56387.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	285	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	286	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	287	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.

0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	291	The abbreviations used are: CF, cystic fibrosis; CFTR, cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator; IL, interleukin; iFABP, intestinal fatty acid-binding protein gene promoter; RT, reverse transcriptase; CEBP, CCAAT enhancer-binding protein; TNF, tumor necrosis factor; CSF, colony stimulating factor; Npr-3, naturietic peptide receptor 3; ADRB, 3-adrenergic receptor.

0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	330	 7, 49-58[CrossRef][Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] 40.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	331	 11, 161-172[CrossRef][Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] 41.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	332	 137, 347-359[Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] 42.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	333	 265, L598-L605[Abstract/Free Full Text] 43.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	334	 7, 438-448[CrossRef][Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] 44.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	335	 94, 2604-2608[Abstract/Free Full Text] 45.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	336	 274, 6107-6113[Abstract/Free Full Text] 47.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	337	 308, 963-973[CrossRef][Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve].
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	338	Copyright   2003 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	0	Voltage-dependent Gating of the Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator Cl- Channel Zhiwei Cai, Toby S.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	1	Department of Physiology, University of Bristol, School of Medical Sciences, University Walk, Bristol BS8 1TD, UK.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	2	 Sheppard, Department of Physiology, School of Medical Sciences, University Walk, University of Bristol, Bristol BS8 1TD, UK.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Fax: (44) 117 928 8923; email: D.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	4	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   When excised inside-out membrane patches are bathed in symmetrical Cl--rich solutions, the current-voltage (I-V) relationship of macroscopic cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) Cl- currents inwardly rectifies at large positive voltages.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	5	 To investigate the mechanism of inward rectification, we studied CFTR Cl- channels in excised inside-out membrane patches from cells expressing wild-type human and murine CFTR using voltage-ramp and -step protocols.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Using a voltage-ramp protocol, the magnitude of human CFTR Cl- current at +100 mV was 74  plus or minus  2% (n = 10) of that at -100 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	7	 This rectification of macroscopic CFTR Cl- current was reproduced in full by ensemble currents generated by averaging single-channel currents elicited by an identical voltage-ramp protocol.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	8	 However, using a voltage-step protocol the single-channel current amplitude (i) of human CFTR at +100 mV was 88  plus or minus  2% (n = 10) of that at -100 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Based on these data, we hypothesized that voltage might alter the gating behavior of human CFTR.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Using linear three-state kinetic schemes, we demonstrated that voltage has marked effects on channel gating.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Membrane depolarization decreased both the duration of bursts and the interburst interval, but increased the duration of gaps within bursts.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	12	 However, because the voltage dependencies of the different rate constants were in opposite directions, voltage was without large effect on the open probability (Po) of human CFTR.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	13	 In contrast, the Po of murine CFTR was decreased markedly at positive voltages, suggesting that the rectification of murine CFTR is stronger than that of human CFTR.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	14	 We conclude that inward rectification of CFTR is caused by a reduction in i and changes in gating kinetics.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	15	 We suggest that inward rectification is an intrinsic property of the CFTR Cl- channel and not the result of pore block.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	16	Key Words: ATP-binding cassette transporter   cystic fibrosis   chloride ion channel   channel gating   voltage dependence.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	17	   INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   The cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR; Riordan et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	18	, 1989) is a phosphorylation-regulated Cl- channel that plays a central role in transepithelial fluid and electrolyte transport (Gadsby and Nairn, 1999; Sheppard and Welsh, 1999).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The characteristic behavior of CFTR is determined by the function of the different domains from which CFTR is assembled.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	20	 These include the two membrane-spanning domains (MSDs) that are each composed of six transmembrane segments, the two nucleotide-binding domains (NBDs) that each contain motifs which interact with ATP, and the unique R (regulatory) domain that contains multiple consensus phosphorylation sites and many charged amino acids.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	21	 The MSDs assemble to form the Cl--selective pore while the NBDs and R domain control CFTR channel gating (Gadsby and Nairn, 1999; Sheppard and Welsh, 1999).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	22	In cell-attached membrane patch recordings, the single-channel current-voltage (I-V) relationship of CFTR outwardly rectifies (Berger et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	23	 (1991) attributed this outward rectification to Goldman-type rectification caused by the Cl- concentration gradient.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	24	 However, subsequent studies have offered alternative explanations.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	25	 (1993) proposed that rectification is a function of the concentration and permeability of anions within the cell.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Second, Fischer and Machen (1994) attributed rectification to high frequency gating of the CFTR Cl- channel at negative voltages.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Third, studies by a number of investigators have demonstrated that large anions cause a voltage-dependent block of the CFTR Cl- channel when they are present in the intracellular solution (McDonough et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	28	, 1994; Linsdell and Hanrahan, 1996; Sheppard and Robinson, 1997; Zhou et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	29	 These anions bind within a deep wide vestibule at the intracellular end of the CFTR pore to prevent Cl- permeation (Linsdell and Hanrahan, 1996; Sheppard and Robinson, 1997; Hwang and Sheppard, 1999; Zhou et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	30	 This block of the CFTR Cl- channel by large intracellular anions is reminiscent of the effect of intracellular cations on inward-rectifier K+ channels (Kir channels; Hille, 2001).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Inward rectification of these K+ channels is caused by voltage-dependent block by Mg2+ and polyamines found in the cytoplasm of the cell (Vandenberg, 1987; Lopatin et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Thus, as first proposed by Tabcharani et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	33	 (1991), the outward rectification of CFTR Cl- channels observed in cell-attached membrane patches is likely caused by voltage-dependent block by large anions found in the cytoplasm of the cell (Linsdell and Hanrahan, 1998a, 1999).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	34	When inside-out membrane patches excised from cells expressing wild-type human CFTR are bathed in symmetrical Cl--rich solutions, the single-channel I-V relationship of CFTR is linear (e.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	35	 However, we previously observed inward rectification of wild-type CFTR Cl- currents in excised membrane patches from C127 cells expressing wild-type human CFTR (Lansdell et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	36	, 2000; Cai and Sheppard, 2002).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	37	 At negative voltages, the I-V relationship was linear, whereas at positive voltages, the I-V relationship exhibited inward rectification that was most marked at voltages above +50 mV (Lansdell et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	38	, 2000; Cai and Sheppard, 2002).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Using excised membrane patches from baby hamster kidney (BHK) cells expressing wild-type human CFTR, Linsdell and colleagues observed similar results in some studies (Linsdell and Hanrahan, 1999; Linsdell and Gong, 2002), but not in others (e.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	40	, 1998; Linsdell and Hanrahan, 1998b).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	41	 (1996) reported inward rectification of CFTR Cl- channels reconstituted into planar lipid bilayers.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	42	 In this study, we investigate the mechanism of inward rectification of the CFTR Cl- channel.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	43	 We employ voltage-ramp and -step protocols to study macroscopic and single-channel currents in excised inside-out membrane patches from cells expressing wild-type human and murine CFTR and kinetic modeling to analyze channel gating.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	44	   MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Cells and Cell Culture For this study, we used mouse mammary epithelial (C127) cells stably expressing wild-type human CFTR and Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells stably expressing wild-type murine CFTR.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	45	 C127 and CHO cells were gifts of Dr.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	46	 O'Riordan (Genzyme, Framingham, MA) and Dr.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Wainwright (University of Queensland, Brisbane, Australia), respectively.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Cells were cultured as described previously (Sheppard and Robinson, 1997; Lansdell et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	49	 For experiments using excised inside-out membrane patches, cells were seeded onto glass coverslips and used within 48 h.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	50	Electrophysiology CFTR Cl- channels were recorded in excised inside-out membrane patches using an Axopatch 200A patch-clamp amplifier (Axon Instruments, Inc.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	51	) and pCLAMP data acquisition and analysis software (version 6.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	52	) as described previously (Hamill et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	53	, 1981; Sheppard and Robinson, 1997).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	54	 The established sign convention was used throughout; currents produced by positive charge moving from intra- to extracellular solutions (anions moving in the opposite direction) are shown as positive currents.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	55	Both the pipette (extracellular) and bath (intracellular) solutions contained (mM): 140 NMDG, 3 MgCl2, 1 CsEGTA, and 10 TES, adjusted to pH 7.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	56	3 with HCl, ([Cl-], 147 mM; free [Ca2+],  < 10-8 M).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Patch pipettes had resistances of 10 to 30 M when filled with this solution.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	58	 The intracellular solution was maintained at 37 degrees C using a temperature-controlled microscope stage (Brook Industries).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	59	After excision of inside-out membrane patches, we added the catalytic subunit of PKA (75 nM) and ATP (1 mM) to the intracellular solution within 5 min of patch excision to activate CFTR Cl- channels.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	60	 To prevent the rundown of CFTR Cl- channels in excised membrane patches, we added PKA to all intracellular solutions.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Unless otherwise indicated, membrane patches were voltage-clamped at -50 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	62	To investigate the voltage dependence of CFTR, we used either membrane patches containing large numbers of active channels or membrane patches containing five or less active channels.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The number of channels in a membrane patch was determined from the maximum number of simultaneous channel openings observed during the course of an experiment, as previously described (Lansdell et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Using multichannel patches, we generated macroscopic I-V relationships by averaging currents generated by 15 to 30 ramps of voltage each of 2-s duration; holding voltage was -50 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Basal currents with no active CFTR Cl- channels recorded in the absence of PKA (75 nM) and ATP (1 mM) were subtracted from those recorded in the presence of PKA and ATP to generate the I-V relationship of CFTR Cl- currents.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	66	 To generate ensemble currents, we applied the same voltage protocol used with multichannel patches to membrane patches containing five or less active channels 50 to 100 times.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	67	 We subtracted basal currents recorded in the absence of PKA (75 nM) and ATP (1 mM) from currents recorded in the presence of PKA and ATP before averaging subtracted currents to generate the ensemble current.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	68	 For single-channel studies of the voltage dependence of CFTR, voltage was stepped from -100 to +100 mV in 20-mV increments of 30 to 60 s duration.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Alternatively, voltage was clamped at a single voltage for 2 to 4-min periods to acquire sufficient data for analyses of gating kinetics.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	70	CFTR Cl- currents were initially recorded on digital audiotape using a digital tape recorder (model DTR-1204, Biologic Scientific Instruments; Intracel Ltd.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	71	 On playback, records were filtered with an eight-pole Bessel filter (model 902LPF2, Frequency DevicesTM; SCENSYS Ltd.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	72	) at a corner frequency of 500 Hz and acquired using a Digidata 1200 interface (Axon Instruments, Inc.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	73	) and pCLAMP software at sampling rates of either 1.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	74	0 kHz (voltage-ramp protocols) or 5 kHz (single-channel studies).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	75	 To determine whether a sampling rate of 1 kHz was suitable for the construction of I-V relationships, we compared the effects of acquiring voltage-ramp protocols at sampling rates of 1 and 5 kHz.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	76	 1 B demonstrates that identical I-V relationships were obtained using the two different sampling rates.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	77	To measure single-channel current amplitude (i), Gaussian distributions were fit to current amplitude histograms.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Chord conductance was calculated by dividing unitary current by the difference between the applied voltage and the reversal potential.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	79	 For open probability (Po) and kinetic analyses, lists of open open and closed times were created using a half-amplitude crossing criterion for event detection.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Transitions  < 1 ms in duration were excluded from the analyses.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Single-channel open and closed time histograms were created using logarithmic x-axes with 10 bins decade-1.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Histograms were fit with one or more component exponential functions using the maximum likelihood method.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	83	 To determine which component function fitted best, the log-likelihood ratio test was used and considered statistically significant at a value of 2.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Burst analysis was performed as described by Carson et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	85	 (1995a), using a burst delimiter (tc; the time that separates interburst closures from intraburst closures) determined by analyses of closed time histograms (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Closures longer than tc were considered to define interburst closures, whereas closures shorter than this time were considered gaps within bursts.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	87	 The mean interburst interval (TIBI) was calculated using the equation:.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	88	(1)where Tb = (mean burst duration) x (open probability within a burst).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Mean burst duration (TMBD) and open probability within a burst (Po(burst)) were determined directly from experimental data using pCLAMP software.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	90	 TMBD was determined from histograms of burst duration data plotted with logarithmic x-axes with 10 bins decade-1, Po(burst) was calculated using burst duration and closed times within bursts data, and Po was calculated as described previously (Lansdell et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Only membrane patches that contained a single active channel were used for single-channel kinetic analyses.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	92	Modeling of Single-channel Kinetics To perform maximum likelihood analysis and develop kinetic models of CFTR channel gating, we used the QuB software suite (www.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	93	, 1997) to analyze data from membrane patches that contained only a single active channel as described previously (Cai and Sheppard, 2002).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	94	 In brief, digitized current records generated by pCLAMP software were imported with no further filtering and baseline corrected (program PRE).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Using a recursive Viterbi algorithm (program SKM), idealized currents were produced.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Finally, rate constants for kinetic models were calculated from the idealized current dwell time sequence using a maximum likelihood approach (program MIL).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	97	 For consistency with analyses using pCLAMP software, transitions  < 1 ms were excluded.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	98	To investigate the voltage dependence of rate constants, we first calculated rate constants at equivalent positive and negative voltages from individual membrane patches.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	99	 If rate constants are voltage dependent, the relationship between rate constant and voltage is described by the single exponential function:.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	100	(2)where k is the unknown rate constant, k0 is the rate constant at unitary ligand concentration and zero voltage, P is the ligand concentration, and V is voltage.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	101	(3)where zg is the equivalent gating charge (defined as the product of the unit charge moved (z) times the fraction of the electric field ()), qe is the elementary charge, kB is the Boltzmann's constant, and T is the absolute temperature.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	102	 The parameters k1 and k0 are intrinsic properties of the channel that do not vary with experimental conditions (Qin et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	103	 To determine k0 and k1, we simultaneously fitted combined sets of data obtained at equivalent positive and negative voltages (e.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	104	,  plus or minus 75 mV) from the same membrane patch.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Because the ligand concentration (P) is constant under the experimental conditions employed ([ATP]i = 1 mM), the value of P is assumed to be 1.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Finally, using values of k0 and k1, we simulated the effects of voltage on rate constants over a wide range of voltages (program SIM; Qin et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	107	Reagents The catalytic subunit of PKA was purchased from Promega UK.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	108	 ADP (disodium salt), ATP (disodium salt), pyrophosphate (tetrasodium salt), and TES were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	109	 All other chemicals were of reagent grade.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	110	Statistics Results are expressed as means  plus or minus  SEM of n observations.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	111	 To compare sets of data, we used either a one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) or Student's paired t test.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Differences were considered statistically significant when P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	113	 All tests were performed using SigmaStatTM (version 2.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	114	Online Supplemental Material To investigate the possibility that inward rectification of CFTR Cl- currents is caused by a component of the recording solutions, we examined the effect on CFTR of a number of factors in the bath and pipette solutions.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	115	 These included the nature of the biological buffer (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	116	 S1) and the monovalent cation used in our recording solutions (Figs.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Supplemental figures and text is available at http://www.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	118	   RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Voltage Dependence of the CFTR Cl- Channel To learn how voltage regulates the activity of CFTR, we studied CFTR Cl- currents in excised inside-out membrane patches from C127 cells expressing wild-type human CFTR.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	119	 We bathed membrane patches in symmetrical 147 mM Cl- solutions and recorded membrane currents over the voltage range  plus or minus 100 mV using a voltage-ramp protocol.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	120	 1 A demonstrates that under basal conditions, the voltage ramp protocol evoked only tiny membrane currents.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	121	 However, after the activation of CFTR Cl- currents by cAMP-dependent phosphorylation, the voltage-ramp protocol elicited large membrane currents (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	122	 To identify the membrane currents generated by CFTR, we subtracted the membrane currents recorded under basal conditions from those recorded following the addition of PKA (75 nM) and ATP (1 mM) to the intracellular solution.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	123	 1 B shows the I-V relationship of these CFTR Cl- currents.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	124	 At negative voltages, the I-V relationship is linear, whereas at positive voltages, the I-V relationship exhibits weak inward rectification (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	125	 This inward rectification of CFTR Cl- currents is more clearly demonstrated in Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	126	 1 C, where data are expressed as a percentage of the current value at -100 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	127	 At voltages above +50 mV, current values diverge noticeably from the I-V relationship of an ion channel that obeys Ohm's law (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	128	 These data indicate that CFTR Cl- currents exhibit weak inward rectification when bathed in symmetrical Cl--rich solutions.
