0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	129	View larger version (17K):    FIGURE 1.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	130	 I-V relationship of CFTR Cl- currents.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	131	 (A) Current traces from an excised inside-out membrane patch from a C127 cell expressing wild-type human CFTR.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	132	 The recordings were made in the absence (middle) and presence (bottom) of PKA (75 nM) and ATP (1 mM) in the intracellular solution.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	133	 The basal recording is the current in response to a single ramp of voltage with no active CFTR Cl- channels, whereas the recording in the presence of PKA + ATP is the average current of 30 ramps of voltage.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Holding voltage was -50 mV and the membrane patch was bathed in symmetrical 147 mM NMDGCl solutions.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	135	 The voltage ramp protocol used is shown and currents were acquired at a sampling rate of 1 kHz as described in the MATERIALS AND METHODS.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	136	 (B) I-V relationship constructed by subtracting the basal trace from the PKA + ATP trace shown in A.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	137	 The inset shows the I-V relationship of the same data acquired at a sampling rate of 5 kHz (abscissa: -100 to +100 mV; ordinate: -30 to +30 pA).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	138	 (C) I-V relationship of CFTR Cl- currents.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Data are means  plus or minus  SEM (n = 10) at each voltage calculated by expressing individual current values measured from -100 to +100 mV in 10-mV increments as a percentage of the current value at -100 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Error bars are smaller than symbol size.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	141	 The continuous line is the fit of a second order regression to the data.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	142	 The dotted line shows the predicted ohmic I-V relationship.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	143	  To further investigate the inward rectification of CFTR, we studied single Cl- channels.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	144	 We reasoned that if the I-V relationship of individual CFTR Cl- channels exhibits inward rectification, summation of single-channel currents should reproduce the rectification of macroscopic CFTR Cl- currents.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	145	 To test this hypothesis, we applied the same voltage protocol used to study macroscopic CFTR Cl- currents to membrane patches containing five or less active channels.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	146	 2 A shows the activity of a single CFTR Cl- channel evoked by five ramps of voltage from -100 to +100 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Visual inspection of these single-channel records suggests that current amplitude at negative voltages is larger than that at positive voltages.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Consistent with this idea, the ensemble current generated by averaging the single-channel currents elicited by 70 voltage ramps inwardly rectifies (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Importantly, the extent of the inward rectification observed for the ensemble current agrees closely with that of macroscopic CFTR Cl- currents (Figs.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	150	 For example, at +100 mV the magnitude of the macroscopic CFTR Cl- current was 74  plus or minus  2% (n = 10) of that at -100 mV while that of the ensemble current was 79  plus or minus  3% (n = 5) of that at -100 mV (P > 0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	151	 These data indicate that voltage-dependent changes in the single-channel activity of CFTR account for the inward rectification of macroscopic CFTR Cl- currents.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	152	View larger version (27K):    FIGURE 2.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Summation of single-channel currents reproduces the rectification of macroscopic CFTR Cl- currents.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	154	 (A) Representative recordings of a single CFTR Cl- channel in an excised inside-out membrane patch elicited by a depolarizing voltage ramp from -100 to +100 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	155	 ATP (1 mM) and PKA (75 nM) were continuously present in the intracellular solution.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	156	 The dotted line indicates the zero current level.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	157	 For the purpose of illustration, single-channel records were digitally refiltered at 100 Hz.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	158	 (B) Ensemble current obtained by averaging 70 ramps of voltage from the same experiment as that shown in A.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	159	 The continuous line is the fit of a second-order regression to the data.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	160	 (C) I-V relationship expressed as a percentage of the current value at -100 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Data are means  plus or minus  SEM (n = 5) at each voltage.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	162	  Effect of Voltage on the Single-channel Activity of CFTR In principal, the inward rectification of CFTR Cl- currents might be caused by a voltage-dependent change in first, the number of active channels; second, current flow through open channels; third, channel gating and hence, Po.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	163	 To discriminate between these different possibilities, we investigated the effect of voltage on the single-channel activity of CFTR.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	164	 3 compares the activity of a single CFTR Cl- channel phosphorylated by PKA and ATP at -75 and +75 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	165	 These single-channel records suggest that inward rectification was not caused by a decrease in the number of active channels present at positive voltages (n = 6; Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	166	 On the contrary, the single-channel data suggest that inward rectification is caused by both a reduction in i and changes in gating behavior at positive voltages (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	167	View larger version (55K):    FIGURE 3.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Effect of voltage on the single-channel activity of CFTR.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Representative recordings of a single CFTR Cl- channel at -75 mV (top) and +75 mV (bottom).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	170	 ATP (1 mM) and PKA (75 nM) were continuously present in the intracellular solution.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Dotted lines indicate the closed channel state.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Downward and upward deflections correspond to channel openings at -75 mV and +75 mV, respectively.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	173	 For the purpose of illustration, single-channel records were filtered at 500 Hz and digitized at 1 kHz.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	174	  The decrease in i at positive voltages is not readily apparent by visual inspection of single-channel records (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	175	 However, it is evident from single-channel current amplitude histograms and the I-V relationship of CFTR (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	176	 4 A shows histograms of the distribution of current values at  plus or minus 50 and  plus or minus 75 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	177	 When compared with i values at negative voltages, the reduction in i at +50 mV was very slight and that at +75 mV was small (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Nevertheless, like that of macroscopic CFTR Cl- currents, the single-channel I-V relationship of CFTR weakly inwardly rectified at positive voltages (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Consistent with these data, the chord conductance of CFTR decreased from 11.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	180	3 pS at +100 mV (n = 10; P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	181	View larger version (31K):    FIGURE 4.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Single-channel conductance of CFTR.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	183	 (A) Single-channel current amplitude histograms of a single CFTR Cl- channel at the indicated voltages recorded using the conditions described in Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	184	 At negative voltages (top), the closed-channel amplitude is shown on the right, whereas at positive voltages (bottom), the closed channel amplitude is shown on the left.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Linear x-axes with 20 bins decade-1 were used for the histograms and the continuous lines represent the fit of Gaussian distributions to the data.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	186	 The vertical dashed lines indicate the position of the open and closed channel levels at negative voltages.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	187	 (B) Single-channel I-V relationship of CFTR.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	188	 (C) Relationship between chord conductance and voltage for the data shown in B.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Chord conductance was calculated as described in MATERIALS AND METHODS.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	190	  Comparison of the macroscopic and single-channel I-V relationships of CFTR (Figs.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	191	 1 C and 4 B) suggests that the decrease in i at positive voltages is insufficient to account for the rectification of macroscopic CFTR Cl- currents.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	192	 For example, at +100 mV single-channel current amplitude (i) = 88  plus or minus  2% of that at -100 mV (n = 10), whereas at +100 mV macroscopic current (I) = 74  plus or minus  2% of that at -100 mV (n = 10; P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	193	 In agreement with these data, Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	194	 3 demonstrates that the pattern of channel gating at +75 mV differs strikingly from that observed at -75 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	195	 At negative voltages the gating behavior of CFTR was characterized by bursts of channel activity, interrupted by brief flickery closures, separated by longer closures between bursts (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	196	 In contrast, at positive voltages both the duration of bursts as well as the long closed periods separating bursts were decreased in length (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	197	To quantify the changes in gating behavior at positive voltages, we used membrane patches that contained only a single active channel.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	198	 We analyzed histograms of open and closed times at  plus or minus 75 mV to determine how voltage alters the distribution of open and closed times.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	199	 At both -75 and +75 mV, open and closed time histograms of CFTR were best fitted with one- and two-component functions, respectively (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	200	 However, at positive voltages the distribution of open and closed times was altered in several ways.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	201	 First, the open time constant (O1) was decreased by 52% (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Second, the fast closed time constant (C1) that describes the flickery closures which interrupt channel openings was increased by 79%, while its share of the closed time distribution expanded slightly from 61 to 66% (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Third, the slow closed time constant (C2) that describes the long closures which separate channel openings was decreased by 27%, while its share of the closed time distribution contracted slightly from 39% to 34% (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	204	 As a consequence of these changes in channel gating, the number of events per minute at +75 mV was double that at -75 mV (Table I).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	205	View larger version (34K):    FIGURE 5.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Analysis of the dwell time histograms of a single CFTR Cl- channel.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	207	 (A and B) Representative open and closed time histograms for a single CFTR Cl- channel recorded at -75 and +75 mV, respectively, using the conditions described in Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	208	 For open time histograms, the continuous line is the fit of a one-component exponential function.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	209	 For closed time histograms, the continuous line is the fit of a two-component exponential function.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	210	 The dotted lines show the individual components of the exponential functions.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Logarithmic x-axes with 10 bins decade-1 were used for both open and closed time histograms.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	212	 (C) Burst duration (top), interburst interval (middle), and Po (bottom) of CFTR at the indicated voltages.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Columns and error bars indicate means  plus or minus  SEM (n = 10) at each voltage.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	214	 For the Po data, filled circles connected by lines represent individual experiments and the open circles are means  plus or minus  SEM (n = 10).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	215	 The asterisks indicate values that are significantly different from the -75 mV data (P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Burst duration and interburst interval were calculated as described in MATERIALS AND METHODS.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	217	  View this table:    TABLE I Effect of Voltage on the Open and Closed Time Constants of Wild-type CFTR Cl- Channels.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	218	  To further investigate the changes in gating behavior at positive voltages, we performed an analysis of bursts using a burst delimiter (tc) determined as the nadir between the two populations of channel closures (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	219	 5, A and B, and Table I; Carson et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	220	32 ms (n = 10), whereas at +75 mV, tc = 18.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	221	 The large difference between the fast and slow time constants at both negative and positive voltages, suggests that errors caused by misclassification of bursts should be rare.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	222	 5 C demonstrates that both burst duration and interburst interval were significantly decreased at +75 mV (P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	223	 As a result, the Po of CFTR at +75 mV was only slightly decreased compared with the value at -75 mV, although the difference was statistically significant (P = 0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	224	 These data suggest that voltage alters the gating behavior of the CFTR Cl- channel without noticeably changing Po.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	225	Thus, our data suggest that the single-channel behavior of CFTR accounts for the rectification of CFTR Cl- currents.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	226	 CFTR Cl- current is determined by the product of the number of CFTR Cl- channels in the membrane patch (N), the single-channel current amplitude (i), and the probability (Po) that a single channel is open: ICFTR = N x i x Po.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	227	 If we set each of these variables to 100% for the -100 mV data, we can compare the CFTR Cl- current generated at -100 and +100 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Table II presents values of each variable, the predicted CFTR Cl- current determined by calculating N x i x Po and the observed value of CFTR Cl- current.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Differences between the observed and predicted values are likely accounted for by using data at  plus or minus 75 mV and not  plus or minus 100 mV to calculate Po and the subtraction of basal currents.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	230	1 Nevertheless, the predicted and observed values agree closely.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	231	View this table:    TABLE II Comparison of Predicted CFTR Cl- Current, N x i x Po, and Measured CFTR Cl- Current at -100 and +100 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	232	  Voltage Changes the Gating Kinetics of CFTR To understand better how voltage changes the pattern of channel gating, we used maximum likelihood analysis and kinetic modeling.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Using this approach, Winter et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	234	 (1994) demonstrated that the gating kinetics of single phosphorylated wild-type CFTR Cl- channels are described equally well by the linear three-state schemes shown in Figs.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	235	 In these schemes, C1 represents the long duration closed state separating channel openings, C2 the brief flickery closures that interrupt channel openings, and O the open state.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Transitions between the three states are described by the rate constants ss1, ss2, 1 and 2.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Using the C1C2O kinetic scheme, intracellular ATP regulates CFTR at the transition between C1 and C2: as the ATP concentration is raised, ss1 increases (Winter et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	238	 In contrast, none of the other transition rates were altered significantly by ATP (Winter et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Similar analyses of our own data support this model of ATP-dependent regulation of CFTR channel gating (Cai and Sheppard, 2002).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	240	 They also suggest that using the C1OC2 kinetic scheme, intracellular ATP regulates CFTR at the transition between C1 and O with ss1 increasing at elevated ATP concentrations while the other rate constants remain unchanged (unpublished data).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	241	 As the gating behavior of CFTR is equally well described by the kinetic schemes C1C2O and C1OC2, we used both schemes to determine how voltage regulates CFTR channel gating.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	242	View larger version (24K):    FIGURE 6.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	243	 Effect of voltage on the rate constants of the C1C2O kinetic scheme.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	244	 (A) The C1C2O kinetic scheme that describes CFTR channel gating (Winter et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	245	 States C1, C2, and O represent two closed states and one open state, respectively, while ss1, ss2, 1, and 2 represent the rate constants describing transitions between these states.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	246	 States enclosed within the dashed box represent the bursting state.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	247	 (B) Rate constants at the indicated voltages determined by the maximum likelihood fit to the model shown in A.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Data are means  plus or minus  SEM (n = 6) at each voltage.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	249	 The asterisks indicate values that are significantly different from the -75 mV data (P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	250	 (C) The relationship between the rate constants ss1 (filled circles), ss2 (filled diamonds), 1 (open circles) and 2 (open diamonds) and voltage for the C1C2O model.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Values are means  plus or minus  SEM (n = 5 to 6) at each voltage.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	252	 The continuous lines represent fits of the single exponential function k=k0Pexp (Eq.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	253	 2) as described in the MATERIALS AND METHODS.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	254	 6 B shows the rate constants for the C1C2O kinetic scheme (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	255	, 1994) at -75 and +75 mV calculated using the QuB software suite (www.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	256	 When compared with the -75 mV data, 1 was decreased by 53% at +75 mV, 2 was increased by 88%, ss2 was decreased by 24%, but ss1 was unchanged.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	257	 The duration of bursts is influenced first by 1, the rate constant that determines the velocity with which the channel leaves the bursting state, and second by 2 and ss2, the rate constants that control opening and closing transitions within the bursting state (see Eq.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	258	 The decrease in 1 delays the exit from the bursting state and hence, increases the duration of bursts at +75 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	259	 In contrast, the decrease in ss2 and particularly the increase in 2 both act to decrease the duration of bursts at +75 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Thus, the data suggest that depolarized voltages produce reciprocal changes in 1 and the rate constants within the bursting state (i.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	261	, 2 and ss2) that tend to offset each other.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	262	 7 B shows the rate constants for the C1OC2 kinetic scheme (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	263	 When compared with the -75 mV data, 1 was increased by 27% at +75 mV, ss1 was increased by 29%, ss2 was increased by 118% and 2 was decreased by 34%.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	264	 As with the C1C2O kinetic scheme, the duration of bursts in the C1OC2 model is influenced by 1, 2, and ss2 (see Eq.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	265	 However, unlike the C1C2O kinetic scheme, the changes in 2 and ss2 have little effect on burst duration at +75 mV while the increase in 1 accelerates the rate of exit from the bursting state and hence, decreases the duration of bursts at +75 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	266	 Similarly, the increase in ss1, the rate constant that determines the velocity with which the channel enters the bursting state, causes a reduction in the interburst interval at +75 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	267	View larger version (24K):    FIGURE 7.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	268	 Effect of voltage on the rate constants of the C1OC2 kinetic scheme.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	269	 (A) The C1OC2 kinetic scheme that describes CFTR channel gating (Winter et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	270	 (B) Rate constants at the indicated voltages determined by the maximum likelihood fit to the model shown in A.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	271	 (C) The relationship between the rate constants ss1 (filled circles), ss2 (filled diamonds), and 1 (open circles) and voltage for the C1OC2 scheme.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	272	 The inset shows the relationship between the rate constant 2 and voltage for the same scheme.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	273	  To investigate whether the changes in rate constants counteract each other, we used the rate constants for the C1C2O and C1OC2 kinetic schemes to calculate values of (i) burst duration, (ii) mean duration of gaps within bursts, (iii) interburst interval, and (iv) Po and compared these values with those derived using pClamp software.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	274	 First, using the kinetic scheme C1C2O, mean burst duration is given by the equation (Sakmann and Trube, 1984):.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	275	 4, mean burst duration decreased from 158  plus or minus  17 ms (n = 6) at -75 mV to 130  plus or minus  18 ms (n = 6) at +75 mV, a decrease of 18% (P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	276	 Using the kinetic scheme C1OC2, mean burst duration is given by the equation (Sakmann and Trube, 1984):.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	277	 5, mean burst duration decreased from 145  plus or minus  18 ms (n = 6) at -75 mV to 120  plus or minus  16 ms (n = 6) at +75 mV, a reduction of 17% (P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	278	 These data are in close agreement with the mean burst duration values determined using rate constant data for the C1C2O kinetic scheme and pClamp software (19% decrease; Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	279	 They indicate that burst duration decreases at positive voltages.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	280	Second, using the kinetic scheme C1C2O, mean duration of gaps within bursts is given by the equation (Sakmann and Trube, 1984):.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	281	 6, mean duration of gaps within bursts increased from 1.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	282	17 ms (n = 6) at +75 mV, an increase of 57% (P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	283	 Using the kinetic scheme C1OC2, mean duration of gaps within bursts is given by the equation (Sakmann and Trube, 1984):.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	284	 7, mean duration of gaps within bursts increased from 1.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	285	15 ms (n = 6) at +75 mV, an increase of 52% (P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	286	 These data are in reasonable agreement with the values of mean duration of gaps within bursts calculated using rate constant data for the C1C2O kinetic scheme and excellent agreement with values determined using pClamp software (-75 mV, 2.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	287	25 ms (n = 10); 52% increase; P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	288	 They indicate that bursts become interrupted by longer brief closures at positive voltages.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	289	Third, using the kinetic scheme C1C2O, an approximate value of interburst interval can be determined using the equation (Sakmann and Trube, 1984):.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	290	 8, interburst interval decreased from 113  plus or minus  18 ms (n = 6) at -75 mV to 84  plus or minus  11 ms (n = 6) at +75 mV, a decrease of 26% (P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	291	 Using the kinetic scheme C1OC2, interburst interval is given by the equation (Sakmann and Trube, 1984):.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	292	 9, interburst interval decreased from 106  plus or minus  18 ms (n = 6) at -75 mV to 80  plus or minus  11 ms (n = 6) at +75 mV, a reduction of 25% (P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	293	 These data are in very good agreement with the values of interburst interval calculated using rate constant data for the C1C2O kinetic scheme, but only reasonable agreement with those values determined using pClamp software (16% decrease; Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	294	 They indicate that interburst interval decreases at positive voltages.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	295	Fourth, using the kinetic scheme C1C2O, Po is given by the equation (Sakmann and Trube, 1984):.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	296	 10, Po decreased slightly from 0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	297	04 (n = 6) at +75 mV, a decrease of 2% (P > 0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	298	 Using the kinetic scheme C1OC2, Po is given by the equation (Sakmann and Trube, 1984):.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	299	 11, Po decreased marginally from 0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	300	04 (n = 6) at +75 mV, a reduction of 2% (P > 0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	301	 These data are in very good agreement with the values of Po calculated using rate constant data for the C1C2O kinetic scheme and good agreement with values determined using pClamp software (5% decrease; Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	302	 However, the decrease in Po calculated using rate constant data was not statistically significant, unlike that calculated using pClamp software.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	303	 We attribute this subtle effect of voltage on Po to the changes in mean burst duration and interburst interval counterbalancing each other.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	304	To understand better the voltage dependence of CFTR channel gating, we calculated rate constants for both kinetic schemes at -50, -20, +20, and +50 mV and fitted the data using the single exponential function k=k0Pexp (Eq.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	305	 To determine whether rate constants changed with voltage, we performed one-way ANOVAs.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	306	 Considering first the C1C2O kinetic scheme, this test indicated that ss1 and ss2 did not change significantly with voltage (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	307	2 In contrast, a significant difference was found between voltage and 2 and 1 (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	308	2 Considering next the C1OC2 kinetic scheme, one-way ANOVAs indicated that 1 and ss2 did not change significantly with voltage (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	309	 In contrast, a significant difference was found between voltage and ss1 and 2 (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	310	 Thus, in both kinetic schemes voltage has profound effects on the gating behavior of the CFTR Cl- channel.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	311	 However, because in both kinetic schemes the effects of voltage on the rate constants tend to oppose one another, CFTR Cl- currents exhibit only weak voltage-dependence.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	312	Finally, using the data in Figs.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	313	 6 C and 7 C, we derived values of equivalent gating charge for each of the rate constants in the two kinetic schemes (Tables III and IV).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	314	 For the C1C2O kinetic scheme, the total equivalent gating charge for CFTR is 0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	315	32e (Table III) while for the C1OC2 kinetic scheme it is 0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	316	 These values of gating charge are threefold lower than that of ClC-0, the voltage-dependent Cl- channel of Torpedo electric organ (Hanke and Miller, 1983; Pusch et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	317	, 1995; Chen and Miller, 1996) and about fortyfold lower than those of voltage-gated Na+, K+ and Ca2+ channels (Hille, 2001).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	318	View this table:    TABLE III Summary of the Fits to the Rate Constants for the C1C2O Kinetic Scheme.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	319	  View this table:    TABLE IV Summary of the Fits to the Rate Constants for the C1OC2 Kinetic Scheme.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	320	  Effect of Voltage on the Regulation of Channel Gating by the NBDs Following cAMP-dependent phosphorylation, the gating behavior of CFTR is controlled by cycles of ATP binding and hydrolysis at the NBDs (Gadsby and Nairn, 1999; Sheppard and Welsh, 1999).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	321	 Previous work indicates that ADP inhibits the activity of CFTR by antagonizing ATP-dependent channel opening to prolong greatly the duration of long closures separating channel openings (Winter et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	322	 Conversely, the inorganic phosphate analogue, pyrophosphate (PPi) stimulates the activity of CFTR by increasing the frequency and prolonging dramatically the duration of channel openings (Carson et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	323	 We were especially interested in the effects of PPi on the voltage dependence of CFTR channel gating, because PPi abolished the asymmetric permeability of CFTR to large organic anions (Linsdell and Hanrahan, 1998b).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	324	 We speculated that PPi might convert CFTR from an inwardly rectifying channel to a linear channel.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	325	 To test this hypothesis, we examined the effect of PPi on the inward rectification of CFTR Cl- currents using voltage ramp protocols.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	326	 As a control, we tested the effect of ADP, which is without effect on the asymmetric permeability of CFTR to large organic anions (Linsdell and Hanrahan, 1998b).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	327	 8 A shows I-V relationships of CFTR Cl- currents recorded in the absence and presence of PPi (5 mM).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	328	 PPi (5 mM) increased CFTR Cl- currents by similar amounts at both negative and positive voltages (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	329	 8 B), indicating that PPi-stimulation of CFTR is voltage-independent.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	330	 9, A and B, demonstrates that CFTR inhibition by ADP (1 mM) was voltage independent.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	331	 Consistent with these data, neither PPi (5 mM) nor ADP (1 mM) altered the inward rectification of CFTR Cl- currents (Figs.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	332	View larger version (14K):    FIGURE 8.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	333	 Pyrophosphate stimulation of CFTR Cl- currents is voltage independent.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	334	 (A) I-V relationships of CFTR Cl- currents recorded in the absence and presence of pyrophosphate (PPi; 5 mM) in the intracellular solution.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	335	 (B) Effect of voltage on the fraction of CFTR Cl- current stimulated by PPi (5 mM).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	336	 Values are means  plus or minus  SEM (n = 4) at each voltage.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	337	 The continuous line is the fit of a first order regression to the data.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	338	 (C) I-V relationships of CFTR Cl- currents recorded in the absence (open circles) and presence (filled circles) of PPi (5 mM) expressed as a percentage of the current value at -100 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	339	 Data are means  plus or minus  SEM (n = 4) at each voltage.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	340	  View larger version (13K):    FIGURE 9.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	341	 ADP inhibition of CFTR Cl- currents is voltage independent.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	342	 (A) I-V relationships of CFTR Cl- currents recorded in the absence and presence of ADP (1 mM) in the intracellular solution.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	343	 (B) Effect of voltage on the fraction of CFTR Cl- current inhibited by ADP (1 mM).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	344	 (C) I-V relationships of CFTR Cl- currents recorded in the absence (open circles) and presence (filled circles) of ADP (1 mM) expressed as a percentage of the current value at -100 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	345	  Voltage Dependence of the Murine CFTR Cl- Channel In previous work, we demonstrated that wild-type murine CFTR Cl- channels have a reduced single-channel conductance, a dramatically decreased Po and an altered pattern of channel gating compared with those of wild-type human CFTR (Lansdell et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	346	 To explore further the voltage dependence of CFTR, we investigated the effect of voltage on the activity of wild-type murine CFTR Cl- channels in excised inside-out membrane patches.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	347	 10 A demonstrates that at -80 mV the pattern of gating of murine CFTR is characterized by transitions between a closed state and two open states: sustained openings to a subconductance state and brief openings to a full open state (Lansdell et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	348	 At +80 mV, the gating behavior of CFTR was also characterized by prolonged openings to a subconductance state and brief openings to a full open state (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	349	 However, the frequency and duration of openings to the full open state appeared to be reduced compared with those at -80 mV (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	350	View larger version (36K):    FIGURE 10.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	351	 Effect of voltage on the murine CFTR Cl- channel.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	352	 (A) Recordings of a single murine CFTR Cl- channel at -80 mV (top) and +80 mV (bottom) made using the conditions described in Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	353	 (B) Single-channel I-V relationships of human (open circles) and murine (filled circles) CFTR.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	354	 Data are means  plus or minus  SEM (n = 8 to 10) at each voltage.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	355	 (C) Relationship between chord conductance and voltage for the data shown in B.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	356	 (D) Effect of voltage on the Po of human (left ordinate) and murine (right ordinate) CFTR.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	357	 Columns and error bars indicate means  plus or minus  SEM (human, n = 6; murine, n = 10).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	358	 For human CFTR, voltage was -75 and +75 mV, whereas for murine voltage was -80 and +80 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	359	 The asterisks indicate values that are significantly different from the data at negative voltages (P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	360	  To quantify the voltage dependence of the murine CFTR Cl- channel, we measured i and Po of the full open state.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	361	 (We did not investigate the voltage dependence of the subconductance state because of its tiny single-channel current amplitude.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	362	 10 B compares the single-channel I-V relationship of murine CFTR with that of human CFTR.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	363	 For murine CFTR, at +100 mV i = 73  plus or minus  4% (n = 7) of that at -100 mV while for human CFTR at +100 mV i = 88  plus or minus  2% (n = 10) of that at -100 mV (P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	364	 Consistent with these data, the chord conductance of murine CFTR decreased by 25% over the voltage range -100 to +100 mV, whereas that of human CFTR decreased by only 12% (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	365	 Moreover, at each voltage tested, the chord conductance of murine CFTR was reduced compared with that of human CFTR (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	366	 10 D compares the Po of human and murine CFTR at negative and positive voltages.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	367	 These data demonstrate two important differences between human and murine CFTR: first, the Po of the full open state of murine CFTR is much reduced compared with that of human CFTR (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	368	 Second, the Po of murine CFTR is greatly decreased at positive voltages, whereas that of human CFTR is little changed (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	369	 For murine CFTR, the Po value at +80 mV decreased by 49  plus or minus  10% (n = 10) when compared with that at -80 mV (P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	370	 In contrast, for human CFTR, the Po value at +75 mV was decreased by only 5  plus or minus  1% (n = 6) when compared with that at -75 mV (P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	371	 Thus, these single-channel data suggest that inward rectification of murine CFTR is stronger than that of the human CFTR Cl- channel.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	372	   DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   The goal of this study was to investigate the inward rectification of macroscopic CFTR Cl- currents in excised inside-out membrane patches.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	373	 Using three independent methods, we demonstrated that CFTR exhibits inward rectification when bathed in symmetrical Cl--rich solutions.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	374	 The data indicate that this inward rectification is caused both by a voltage-dependent decrease in single-channel chord conductance and by changes in the kinetics of channel gating at large positive voltages.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	375	 They also suggest that inward rectification of the murine CFTR Cl- channel is stronger than that of human CFTR.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	376	In principal, inward rectification of the CFTR Cl- channel might either result from channel block by a soluble factor or be an intrinsic property of the CFTR channel protein.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	377	 Studies of other ion channels provide strong support for both hypotheses.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	378	 For example, the inward rectification of Kir channels, NMDA receptors, and cyclic nucleotide to gated channels is caused by voltage-dependent block of outward current flow by extrinsic cations.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	379	 In the case of Kir channels the blocking cations are intracellular Mg2+ and polyamines (Vandenberg, 1987; Lopatin et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	380	, 1994), whereas for NMDA receptors and cyclic nucleotide to gated channels the blocking cations are extracellular Ca2+ and Mg2+ (Nowak et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	381	, 1984; Zimmerman and Baylor, 1986).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	382	 In contrast, inward rectification of KAT1, an inward-rectifier K+ channel from the plant Arabidopsis thaliana, results from an intrinsic gating mechanism (Zei and Aldrich, 1998).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	383	 Like voltage-gated K+ channels (Hille, 2001), KAT1 possesses a voltage-sensor, the S4 segment that uses the energy of voltage to control channel gating (Zei and Aldrich, 1998).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	384	Several lines of evidence suggest that channel block is not likely to account for inward rectification of the CFTR Cl- channel in excised inside-out membrane patches.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	385	 First, changes in the composition of the intra- and extracellular solutions did not abolish inward rectification (for data and discussion, see the online supplemental material, available at http://www.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	386	 Second, inward rectification has been observed using cells expressing either native or recombinant wild-type human CFTR (e.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	387	, Quinton and Reddy, 2000; Lansdell et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	388	, 2000; Linsdell and Gong, 2002; this study), indicating that inward rectification is independent of the expression system used to investigate CFTR.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	389	 Third, inward rectification of CFTR Cl- channels reconstituted into planar lipid bilayers was unaffected by changes in the composition of the lipid bilayer (Zhao et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	390	, 1996), suggesting that the surface charge of the membrane lipid does not affect inward rectification.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	391	 Fourth, the effects of voltage on the function of the murine CFTR Cl- channel (present study) indicate that inward rectification is a common characteristic of human and murine CFTR.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	392	 Fifth, mutation of several residues within the MSDs alters the shape of the I-V relationship of CFTR.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	393	 Inward rectification of CFTR Cl- currents is accentuated by mutation of R334, T338, T339, and S341 (sixth transmembrane segment (M6); Gong and Linsdell, 2003; Linsdell et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	394	, 2002), S1118 (M11; Zhang et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	395	, 2000), and T1134 and N1138 (M12; Gupta et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	396	 In contrast, mutation of V317 (M5; Zhang et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	397	, 2002) causes outward rectification of CFTR Cl- currents.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	398	 Based on these data, we speculate that inward rectification is an intrinsic property of the CFTR Cl- channel.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	399	 Because ADP and PPi, two agents that interact with the NBDs, are without effect on inward rectification and because site-directed mutations in the MSDs enhance inward rectification, we propose that the CFTR pore determines this property of the CFTR Cl- channel.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	400	For the CFTR pore, itself, to be responsible for inward rectification, the architecture of the pore should facilitate the flow of Cl- from the intra- to the extracellular side of the membrane, but hinder Cl- flow in the opposite direction.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	401	 To transport ions at maximal translocation rates, ion channels have evolved charged lined vestibules that concentrate and funnel ions toward the selectivity filter (Green and Andersen, 1991; Dutzler et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	402	 Based on these considerations, inward rectification of current flow through the CFTR pore might be achieved by asymmetries in the geometry of the intra- and extracellular vestibules, differences in the distribution of Cl--binding sites between the two vestibules or a combination of these factors.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	403	Evidence for asymmetries in the topology of the intra- and extracellular vestibules is provided by studies of anion permeation and channel block.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	404	 Anion permeation studies indicate that the narrowest part of the CFTR pore is 0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	405	60 nm in diameter (Cheung and Akabas, 1996; Linsdell et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	406	, 1997), widening under certain circumstances to a diameter of 1.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	407	3 nm (Linsdell and Hanrahan, 1998b).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	408	 This constriction, which likely represents the selectivity filter, occurs in the region of F337 and T338 in M6 because mutation of these residues altered dramatically the anion permeability sequence of CFTR, whereas mutation of other residues in M6 had less marked effects on anion permeation (Linsdell et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	409	, 1998, 2000; McCarty and Zhang, 2001; Gong et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	410	, 2002; Gupta and Linsdell, 2003).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	411	 On the intra- and extracellular sides of this constriction, the pore enlarges.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	412	 The voltage dependence of channel block by large organic anions suggests that the CFTR pore contains a wide intracellular vestibule that funnels blocking anions deep into the pore where they bind, occlude the pore, and block Cl- permeation (Linsdell and Hanrahan, 1996; Sheppard and Robinson, 1997; Hwang and Sheppard, 1999; Zhou et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	413	 Less is known about the topology of the extracellular end of the CFTR pore.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	414	 Based on the ability of methanethiosulphonate reagents in the extracellular solution to react with M6 residues toward the cytosolic side of the membrane (Cheung and Akabas, 1996), there might also be a wide extracellular vestibule.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	415	 However, the inability of open-channel blockers to reach their binding sites when added to the extracellular solution and the short length of extracellular loops 3 and 6 led McCarty (2000) to propose that CFTR has a small extracellular vestibule.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	416	 Consistent with this idea, Linsdell and Hanrahan (1998a)(b) demonstrated that CFTR exhibits an asymmetric permeability to large organic anions (e.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	417	, galacturonate, glutathione, and lactobionate).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	418	 During the normal gating cycle, flow of large organic anions through the CFTR pore is only permitted in the intra- to extracellular direction (Linsdell and Hanrahan, 1998a,b).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	419	The sixth transmembrane segment plays a crucial role in determining the pore properties of CFTR (Sheppard and Welsh, 1999; McCarty, 2000; Gong et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	420	 Within M6, the residues R334 (Smith et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	421	, 2001; Gong and Linsdell, 2003), K335 (Anderson et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	422	, 2002), and possibly R352 (Guinamard and Akabas, 1999; Gong et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	423	, 2002) contribute to Cl--binding sites.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	424	 Assuming that the narrowest part of the CFTR pore occurs in the region of F337 and T338 (see above and Linsdell et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	425	, 1998, 2000; McCarty and Zhang, 2001; Gong et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	426	, 2002; Gupta and Linsdell, 2003), the data suggest that three Cl--binding sites (S341, I344, and R352) might be located in a spacious intracellular vestibule, whereas two Cl--binding sites (R334 and K335) might be located in a more confined extracellular vestibule.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	427	 This simple model suggests that current flow through the CFTR pore might inwardly rectify.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	428	 However, an important caveat of this model is that present knowledge of the mechanism of anion permeation by the CFTR Cl- channel is incomplete and it is quite likely that residues in other transmembrane segments contribute to Cl--binding sites.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	429	 Nevertheless, asymmetries in the size of the intra- and extracellular vestibules and/or the distribution of Cl--binding sites within the CFTR pore are plausible explanations for the inward rectification of CFTR Cl- currents.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	430	Besides the architecture of the CFTR pore, voltage-dependent gating might make some contribution to the observed inward rectification of current flow through the CFTR Cl- channel.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	431	 Work by other investigators and ourselves demonstrate that CFTR channel gating exhibits voltage dependence despite the lack of a marked effect of voltage on Po.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	432	 First, using cell-attached membrane patches from NIH 3T3 fibroblasts expressing wild-type human CFTR, Fischer and Machen (1994) demonstrated that slow (ATP dependent) gating is voltage independent, whereas fast (flickery intraburst) gating is voltage dependent, becoming the dominant gating mode at strong negative voltages.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	433	 Second, using excised membrane patches from Xenopus oocytes expressing wild-type human CFTR, Zhang et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	434	 (2002) demonstrated that burst duration increases at negative voltages, whereas interburst interval is unaffected by voltage.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	435	 Third, to investigate the flickery closures that interrupt bursts of channel openings, Zhou et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	436	 (2001) analyzed the gating kinetics of the CFTR variant K1250A whose prolonged openings facilitate the discrimination of fast and slow gating events.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	437	 (2001) found that the rate of transition from the short-lived closed state to the open state exhibits voltage dependence and is sensitive to permeant anions in the extracellular solution, suggesting that brief flickery closures represent the voltage-dependent occupancy of an anion-binding site within the CFTR pore by unknown intracellular anions.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	438	To elucidate the effects of voltage on CFTR channel gating, we adopted a different strategy to other investigators.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	439	 We employed kinetic modeling to analyze the gating behavior of single wild-type human CFTR Cl- channels in excised membrane patches bathed in symmetrical Cl--rich solutions at 37 degrees C and lightly filtered our data.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	440	 Using this approach, we determined the effect of voltage on both fast and slow gating events.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	441	 Our data indicate that voltage has significant effects on CFTR channel gating.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	442	 Membrane depolarization decreased both the duration of bursts and the interburst interval, but increased the duration of gaps within bursts.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	443	 However, because the voltage dependencies of the different rate constants were in opposite directions, Po was largely unaffected by voltage.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	444	 The voltage independence of Po and the lack of effect of ADP and PPi on the inward rectification of CFTR Cl- currents argue that changes in CFTR channel gating do not contribute to the rectification of macroscopic CFTR Cl- currents.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	445	 However, other data suggest the contrary.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	446	 First, the predicted CFTR Cl- current (N x i x Po) at +100 mV, which is accounted for by reductions in both i and Po, agrees closely with the measured CFTR Cl- current at this voltage.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	447	 Second, the Po of murine CFTR is decreased markedly at positive voltages.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	448	 Third, comparison of the data of Smith et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	449	 (2001) and Gong and Linsdell (2003) suggests that the strong inward rectification of the CFTR variant R334C is not accounted for by voltage-dependent changes in i.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	450	 Based on these data, we argue that voltage-dependent changes in CFTR channel gating contribute to the inward rectification of macroscopic CFTR Cl- currents.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	451	Our data indicate that the total equivalent gating charge for CFTR is only 0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	452	 The small size of the gating charge of CFTR is consistent with the lack of marked voltage dependence of CFTR channel gating.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	453	 The data suggest that residues with charged and uncharged polar side chains move only a very small distance within the transmembrane electric field.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	454	 These residues might be located either along the full-length of the CFTR pore or restricted to a specific region of the permeation pathway.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	455	 Alternatively, linear three-state kinetic schemes might be too simple to describe the voltage dependence of CFTR channel gating.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	456	 Because the total equivalent gating charge of CFTR is comparable to the amount of charge movement intrinsic to the voltage-dependent Cl- channel ClC-0 (Chen and Miller, 1996), we favor the former idea.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	457	 The amino acid sequence of ClC-0 lacks a motif equivalent to the S4 segment, the voltage sensor of voltage-gated cation channels (Hille, 2001).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	458	 Instead, permeant anions in the extracellular solution act as the source of the gating charge (Pusch et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	459	 The binding of Cl- ions to a Cl--binding site located at the extracellular end of the ClC-0 pore causes a conformational change that precedes channel opening and inward Cl- flow (Chen and Miller, 1996).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	460	 Because bound Cl- ions traverse the transmembrane electric field, gating is both voltage and Cl- concentration dependent (Pusch et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	461	 Excitingly, the structural basis of this gating mechanism has been elucidated following the determination of high-resolution crystal structures of bacterial CLC proteins (Dutzler et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	462	 In these bacterial CLC channels, the Cl--binding site closest to the extracellular end of the selectivity filter is gated by the carboxyl group of glutamate (E)148 that protrudes into the CLC channel pore: when the carboxyl group of E148 is bound to the Cl--binding site the pore is closed, but when a Cl- ion binds the pore opens to allow Cl- permeation (Dutzler et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	463	The regulation of CLC channel gating by localized motions of an amino acid side chain (Dutzler et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	464	, 2003) raises the question as to whether a similar mechanism might operate in the CFTR Cl- channel.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	465	 However, anion permeation through the CFTR pore is tightly linked to the function of the NBDs that power channel gating.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	466	 (2003) recently demonstrated that glutathione permeation through the CFTR pore is controlled by ATP binding rather than ATP binding and hydrolysis as in the case of Cl- permeation.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	467	 These data suggest that global conformation changes in the structure of the CFTR protein control Cl- permeation, not local changes in the orientation of amino acid side-chains.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	468	 If this idea were correct, it would suggest that CFTR channel gating shares similarities with activation gating in K+ channels that involves the reorientation of transmembrane -helices (Jiang et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	469	 Future studies should test this possibility.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	470	   FOOTNOTES   The online version of this paper contains supplemental material.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	471	Abbreviations used in this paper: CFTR, cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator; M, transmembrane segment; MSD, membrane-spanning domain; NBD, nucleotide-binding domain; PPi, pyrophosphate.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	472	1 Although very small, the membrane currents evoked by the voltage ramp protocol under basal conditions outwardly rectified.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	473	 For example, at -100 mV basal current was -0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	474	20 pA and at +100 mV basal current was 2.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	475	 When basal currents were subtracted from those recorded in the presence of ATP (1 mM) + PKA (75 nM), the outward rectification of basal current accounted for 6  plus or minus  2% (n = 10) of the inward rectification of CFTR Cl- current at +100 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	476	2 In contrast to analyses of rate constant values at  plus or minus 75 mV using Student's paired t test, some analyses of rate constant data over the range -75 to +75 mV using one-way ANOVAs failed to achieve statistical significance.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	477	 We attribute this difference to the fact that paired data were used for analyses using Student's paired t test, but pooled data were used for one-way ANOVAs.
