0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	0	Activation of F508 CFTR in an epithelial monolayer Zsuzsa Bebok1, Charles J.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Venglarik1,2, Zita Panczel3, Tamas Jilling4, Kevin L.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	2	1 Gregory Fleming James Cystic Fibrosis Research Center, Departments of 2 Physiology and Biophysics and 5 Medicine, University of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, Alabama 35294; 3 University Medical School of Pecs, Pecs H-7624, Hungary; and 4 Department of Pediatrics, Northwestern University Medical School, Evanston, Illinois 60201.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	3	    ABSTRACT Top Abstract Introduction Methods Results Discussion References.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	4	The F508 mutation leads to retention of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) in the endoplasmic reticulum and rapid degradation by the proteasome and other proteolytic systems.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	5	 In stably transfected LLC-PK1 (porcine kidney) epithelial cells, F508 CFTR conforms to this paradigm and is not present at the plasma membrane.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	6	 When LLC-PK1 cells or human nasal polyp cells derived from a F508 homozygous patient are grown on plastic dishes and treated with an epithelial differentiating agent (DMSO, 2% for 4 days) or when LLC-PK1 cells are grown as polarized monolayers on permeable supports, plasma membrane F508 CFTR is significantly increased.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Moreover, when confluent LLC-PK1 cells expressing F508 CFTR were treated with DMSO and mounted in an Ussing chamber, a further increase in cAMP-activated short-circuit current (i.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	8	00025 compared with untreated controls) was observed.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	9	 No plasma membrane CFTR was detected after DMSO treatment in nonepithelial cells (mouse L cells) expressing F508 CFTR.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	10	 The experiments describe a way to augment F508 CFTR maturation in epithelial cells that appears to act through a novel mechanism and allows insertion of functional F508 CFTR in the plasma membranes of transporting cell monolayers.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	11	 The results raise the possibility that increased epithelial differentiation might increase the delivery of F508 CFTR from the endoplasmic reticulum to the Golgi, where the F508 protein is shielded from degradative pathways such as the proteasome and allowed to mature.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	12	short-circuit current; dimethyl sulfoxide; cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator; cell differentiation.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	13	    INTRODUCTION Top Abstract Introduction Methods Results Discussion References.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	14	APPROXIMATELY 90% of cystic fibrosis (CF) patients possess at least one cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) allele that lacks a phenylalanine residue at CFTR position 508 (F508).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	15	 (4) indicated that the F508 mutation causes retention of CFTR in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and a failure to insert the protein in the plasma membrane.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Butyrate, an epithelial differentiating agent, has been shown to augment F508 maturation in nonpolarized cells grown on plastic (3).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Another report suggested the possibility that butyrate increases ion transport in CF nasal epithelia, although augmentation of F508 maturation was not directly shown (36).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Improvements in F508 CFTR due to butyrate have not been attributed to differentiating effects per se but to increased CFTR mRNA and protein levels.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The F508 folding defect is also temperature sensitive and influenced by high concentrations of glycerol (7, 37).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	20	 CFTR normally functions as a Cl channel in the context of polarized epithelial monolayers.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	21	 However, interventions that activate maturation and Cl secretion through F508 CFTR in physiologically important systems such as polarized epithelial cell monolayers have been difficult to establish.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	22	An effort in many laboratories has been directed toward development of channel openers for the F508 CFTR.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	23	 This strategy depends on at least some (e.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	24	, small amounts of) F508 protein in the plasma membrane (19).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Because studies of F508 processing have focused on undifferentiated cells, less information is available concerning CFTR maturation in polarized epithelia.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Previous observations in other laboratories suggest that measurable amounts of F508 protein might be present in highly differentiated F508 human nasal epithelial cells (9), CF sweat ducts in situ (35), or in the nasal airways of F508 CFTR mice (22).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	27	 In the present experiments, we adapted LLC-PK1 renal epithelial cells transfected with CFTR cDNAs for measurement of transepithelial Cl transport.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	28	 This cell line readily forms polarized cell monolayers (30, 34, 39) and may have advantages over primary CF airway epithelial cells (i.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	29	, since lung or nasal tissue from F508 patients is limited or less frequently available) for use in screening drugs for effects on CFTR.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Although the kidney-derived LLC-PK1 cell line does not endogenously express wild-type or F508 CFTR, the processing of wild-type and mutant CFTR in this cell type has been carefully studied and found to closely resemble the behavior of other epithelial cells that do endogenously express CFTR (28).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Moreover, kidney-derived epithelia have been a useful model system for characterizing effects due to epithelial differentiation.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	32	 For example, Madin-Darby canine kidney cells grown on filters have been used to study the distribution of membrane proteins in polarized cells (1) and the mechanisms underlying this distribution (12, 29).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	33	 LLC-PK1 cells have been used to explore specific markers of differentiation (27), ion conductance and membrane voltage (24), chemical induction of differentiation (26), and the differentiation-dependent expression of the Na+-glucose cotransporter (8).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	34	 We also studied the effect of DMSO on human nasal epithelial cells derived from F508 homozygous patients and on mouse L cells expressing F508 or wild-type CFTR (46).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	35	 In our studies, we found that growth of epithelial cells under conditions designed to induce a more differentiated phenotype (treatment with an epithelial differentiating agent, DMSO, or growth of the cells as monolayers on permeable supports) led to improvements in F508 CFTR processing.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Butyrate (5 mM for 24 h), glycerol (10% for 48 h), or growth at 27 degrees C (for 48 h) had no detectable effect on F508 maturation in these epithelial cell monolayers.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	37	    METHODS Top Abstract Introduction Methods Results Discussion References.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Parental LLC-PK1 cells were cultured in M199 media supplemented with 5% fetal bovine serum (FBS).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	39	 LLC-PK1 cells with stable expression of the wild-type or F508 CFTR (generous gift of S.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	40	 28) were cultured in DMEM medium supplemented with 10% FBS and 500  microg/ml G418 (Sigma).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	41	 DMSO (Sigma) was diluted in medium.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Cells were treated with DMSO (2% vol/vol) for 4 days after confluency.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Cd2+ was added to induce CFTR expression from the metallothionein promoter at 5  microM in experiments and controls.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Mouse fibroblast cells expressing F508 or wild-type CFTR (46) were cultured in DMEM medium supplemented with 10% FBS.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	45	Human nasal polyp cells were isolated and cultured according to an earlier described protocol (47).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	46	 LLC-PK1 cells grown on plastic were washed three times with PBS (pH 7.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	47	1 mM CaCl2) on ice and then lysed in a buffer containing 150 mM NaCl, 20 mM HEPES, 1 mM EDTA, 1% NP-40, 100  microg/ml aprotinin, 100  microg/ml leupeptin, and 2 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Lysate supernatant (300  microg protein) was immunoprecipitated at 4 degrees C for 2 h using an anti-CFTR COOH-terminal monoclonal antibody (Genzyme) and protein G agarose beads (Boehringer Mannheim).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Immunoprecipitated proteins were phosphorylated in vitro as described previously (4, 33) and separated on a 7% polyacrylamide gel.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Gels were placed on PhosphoScreen and analyzed with PhosphorImager (Molecular Dynamics).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Images were further characterized with IPLab spectrum (Signal Analytics).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	52	 RT-PCR was carried out using Promega PolyATtract series 9600 mRNA isolation and cDNA synthesis system, according to the manufacturer's protocol.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Briefly, mRNA was extracted from control and DMSO-treated samples (1  x  105 cells) and 50% of each mRNA sample was used to synthesize cDNA.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	54	 The remainder of the sample was identically treated, but without RT, as a control to exclude DNA contamination.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Samples were homogenized and diluted in 40  microl of prewarmed (70 degrees C) manufacturer's hybridization buffer, and mRNA was purified on oligo(dT) matrix.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	56	 After samples were washed, 10- microl samples were processed to cDNA by adding 5  microl of reverse transcriptase.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	57	 To ensure that PCR yield in these experiments was roughly dependent on the amount of mRNA starting material, pBluescript containing CFTR (gift of J.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Rommens) was transcribed in vitro with T7 polymerase and mRNA added to cell lysates from parental LLC-PK1 cells at known concentrations.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	59	 First-strand CFTR cDNA was then synthesized exactly as above and studied in parallel with cDNA from cells expressing wild-type or F508 CFTR.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	60	 In all studies, cDNA synthesis was stopped after 30 min by incubating the samples at 95 degrees C for 5 min.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Control experiments in which RT was omitted from the cDNA synthesis step led to no detectable PCR product under any conditions.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Quantitation was by densitometry using IPLab spectrum (Signal Analytics).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	63	CFTR detection by confocal immunofluorescence microscopy using anti-first nucleotide binding domain (NBD1) (rabbit) polyclonal antibody.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Coverslips were washed three times in PBS containing 1 mM Ca2+ and 0.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	65	5 mM Mg2+, fixed in 20 degrees C methanol for 20 min, and air dried at room temperature.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	66	 The cells were rehydrated in PBS for 5 min.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Nonspecific protein binding sites were blocked by incubating with 1% (wt /vol) porcine -globulin in PBS for 30 min at room temperature.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Primary antibody [a polyclonal (rabbit) antibody raised against the CFTR NBD1] (17, 33) was applied and incubated at room temperature for 40 min.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	69	 After subsequent washing (5  x  3-min washes in PBS), the cells were incubated with tetramethylrhodamine isothiocyanate (TRITC)-labeled anti-rabbit IgG antibody for 40 min and then washed, mounted, and visualized as described above.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Controls in which the first antibody was replaced by nonimmune rabbit serum were negative in all cases.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Cells were viewed with an Olympus IX70 inverted epifluorescence microscope at 623-nm light excitation using UPlanApo  x 100 or UApo/340  x 40 objectives.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Digital confocal images were captured using a Photometrics SenSys digital camera and IPLab spectrum software with Power Microtome (Signal Analytics).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	73	Detection of tight junction formation by confocal immunofluorescence microscopy using anti-zonula occludens-1 (rabbit) polyclonal antibody.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Coverslips were washed three times in PBS supplemented with 1 mM Ca2+ and 0.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	75	5 mM Mg2+ and fixed in 4% formaldehyde in PBS for 30 min at room temperature.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Nonspecific protein binding sites were blocked by incubating with 1% (wt /vol) porcine -globulin (Sigma) in PBS for 30 min at room temperature.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	77	 A rabbit polyclonal antibody, anti-zonula occludens-1 (ZO-1) IgG (Zymed Laboratories) (15), was applied and incubated at room temperature for 60 min.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	78	 After subsequent washing (5  x  3 min washes in PBS), the cells were incubated with TRITC-labeled anti-rabbit IgG antibody (DAKOPATTS) for 40 min at room temperature, washed in PBS, and mounted using Vectashield (Vector Labs) mounting medium.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Controls in which the first antibody was replaced by nonimmune rabbit serum were negative in all cases.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	80	 DMSO treatment (2%) was for 4 days.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	81	Identification of F508 CFTR single-channel activity in the plasma membranes of LLC-PK1 cells following DMSO treatment.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	82	 DMSO-treated cells grown on plastic were studied in the cell-attached configuration by the patch-clamp technique.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The bath and pipette solutions, electronics, pipette fabrication, and further details regarding the patch-clamp technique have been described previously (43).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The pipette solution contained an impermeant cation (i.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	85	, N-methyl-D-glutamine) so that inward current could only be due to Cl flow into the pipette.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	86	 CFTR channels were activated after excision by 250 U/ml protein kinase A (PKA) plus 200  microM ATP in the bath.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	87	Transepithelial transport through F508 CFTR.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	88	 LLC-PK1 cell monolayers were grown to confluency on permeable supports (Millipore, Anotec) for at least 5 days and then treated with 2% DMSO for 3-6 additional days.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Filters were mounted in an Ussing chamber, and short-circuit current (Isc) measurement was carried out as described in Ref.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Bumetanide was added at 100  microM to both the mucosal and serosal surfaces.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	91	 NaCl Ringer solution contained (in mM) 145 Na+, 5 K+, 124.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	92	8 mM of Cl was replaced by the impermeant anion gluconate.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	93	    RESULTS Top Abstract Introduction Methods Results Discussion References.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	94	DMSO treatment of LLC-PK1 cells expressing F508 CFTR.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	95	 DMSO, like butyrate, displays potent activity as an epithelial differentiating agent (14, 23, 31, 40).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Both drugs cause changes in the display of plasma membrane glycoproteins in epithelial cells, although the two compounds are believed to act by independent mechanisms (14, 23, 31, 40).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Dose and time dependencies of DMSO treatment (0, 2, 5, and 10% DMSO for 1, 6, or 12 h and 1, 3, 4, and 5 days) were evaluated systematically in LLC-PK1 cells that express recombinant F508 CFTR.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	98	 We found that treatment for 4 days with 2% DMSO led to maximal effects on F508 maturation and transepithelial Cl transport in these cells.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	99	 This 2% DMSO schedule had no visible effect on cell viability, and, in a quantitative assay of cell growth (CellTiter 96, Promega), the well-known differentiating effects of DMSO (which slow cell proliferation) decreased cell proliferation in the LLC-PK1 cells by only ~15%.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	100	 We therefore settled on this schedule for future studies.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	101	 We studied LLC-PK1 cells expressing wild-type or F508 CFTR and the parental (non-CFTR expressing) LLC-PK1 cell line (28).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	102	DMSO treatment leads to a mature, band C form of F508 CFTR.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Incomplete processing of CFTR can be identified by the absence of a mature, fully glycosylated (band C) form of the protein (4).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Lower-molecular-weight forms of CFTR (e.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	105	, band B) represent the high-mannose, endoglycosidase H-sensitive forms of the protein that are established cotranslationally in the ER.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	106	 The maturation of CFTR from core to complex glycosylation reflects the transition of the protein from the ER to the Golgi, where attachment of carbohydrates and trimming are accomplished as CFTR proceeds to the trans-Golgi network.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Immunoprecipitation of CFTR after a 4-day pretreatment with DMSO is shown in Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	108	 The result shows the appearance of mature, fully glycosylated CFTR after DMSO treatment in F508 cells.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	109	 This result supports the notion that F508 maturation is augmented by DMSO.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Figure 1 also indicates a small increase in total CFTR protein in LLC-PK1 cells after DMSO treatment.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	111	 To determine whether this increase was due to effects on steady-state levels of mRNA, we performed a semiquantitative RT-PCR from total cellular mRNA.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	112	 DMSO did not appear to cause increases in CFTR mRNA levels as judged by this RT-PCR assay (Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Unlike previous reports concerning butyrate treatment (3), the experiment suggests that increased F508 CFTR mRNA does not account for the modest increase in total F508 protein after DMSO treatment or the increase in band C.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	114	 These results also suggest that DMSO promotes F508 maturation through a mechanism that is different from that observed with butyrate.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	115	View larger version (32K):    Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	116	   A: immunoprecipitation and in vitro phosphorylation of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Location of 170-kDa band C, the fully processed form of CFTR, is shown.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	118	 A lower-molecular-weight form (band B) is also shown.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Band B represents the endoglycosidase H-sensitive, endoplasmic reticulum-localized form of the protein, whereas band C is the complex glycosylated form taken by CFTR at and beyond entry into the Golgi.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Total CFTR obtained from ~106 cells (~300  microg total cell lysate protein) is shown in each lane.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	121	 B: densitometric measurement of CFTR after in vitro phosphorylation.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Percentage of fully processed band C CFTR compared with total CFTR is shown.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Approximately 10% of total F508 CFTR became fully glycosylated after DMSO treatment.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Cells in these experiments were grown in plastic dishes.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Quantitation was by phosphor imaging.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	126	View larger version (25K):    Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	127	   CFTR mRNA levels after DMSO treatment.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	128	 A: poly(A) mRNA isolated from ~5  x  105 cells was used to synthesize first-strand cDNA and amplify a segment of the human CFTR first nucleotide binding domain (NBD1; Ref.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	129	 16; size ~500 bp, indicated by arrow).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	130	 PCR products of the predicted size were obtained in all cases.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Lane M displays a molecular size standard.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	132	 B: no evidence of increased CFTR mRNA was observed under the same DMSO treatment conditions shown in Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Known amounts of in vitro-transcribed CFTR mRNA in the reaction mixture (5, 2, 1, or 0 pg/ml) led to a roughly linear PCR yield under conditions shown.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Quantitation was by densitometry using IPLab spectrum (Signal Analytics).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	135	F508 CFTR localization in the plasma membrane.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	136	 We used digital confocal fluorescent microscopy for CFTR localization that was detected by a polyclonal (rabbit) antibody raised against CFTR NBD1.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	137	 The antibody used in these experiments has been validated previously by its ability to immunoprecipitate either truncated CFTR or full-length CFTR, immunolocalize CFTR to cells overexpressing the protein, and correctly identify the presence or absence of CFTR in vivo from salivary gland sections of CFTR wild-type or knockout mice of the same strain (5, 16, 17, 33).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	138	 In LLC-PK1 cells expressing the wild-type CFTR, the protein localized mainly to the perinuclear ER compartment and to the region of the plasma membrane (Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	139	 DMSO treatment only slightly increased the membrane staining of wild-type CFTR.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	140	 In contrast, F508 CFTR was detected in the perinuclear (ER) compartment in LLC-PK1 cells with no significant membrane staining.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	141	 After DMSO treatment, staining in the region of the cell membrane (similar to that observed in wild-type CFTR-expressing cells) could be detected.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	142	 F508 CFTR localizes to the perinuclear ER region of F508 homozygous human nasal epithelial cells (Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Treatment of these cells with DMSO (2% for 4 days) resulted in a more diffuse cytoplasmic staining that included staining of cells in the plasma membranes.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	144	 In contrast, DMSO treatment had no significant effect on F508 CFTR staining in mouse fibroblast cells (mouse L cells, Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	145	 These studies suggest that the specificity of effects of DMSO on F508 CFTR processing occurs in epithelial cells but not in fibroblast cells.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	146	View larger version (57K):    Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	147	   A: immunofluorescent detection of wild-type or F508 CFTR in recombinant LLC-PK1 cells.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	148	 B: CFTR staining in F508 homozygous human nasal epithelial cells in primary culture.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	149	 C: CFTR immunostaining in mouse L cells.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	150	 A polyclonal (rabbit) antibody directed against NBD1 was used to detect CFTR.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	151	 In A-C, confocal images are shown of cells under each condition.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	152	 DMSO treatment (2%) was for 4 days.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Controls in which 1) first antibody was replaced by nonimmune rabbit serum and 2) parental (non-CFTR expressing) LLC-PK1 or L cells were studied were negative in all cases.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	154	Identification of F508 channels in the plasma membranes of LLC-PK1 cells.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	155	 We also examined F508 CFTR activity in the plasma membranes of LLC-PK1 cells following DMSO treatment (Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	156	 4) using patch-clamp techniques.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Cells grown on plastic were studied in the cell-attached and excised inside-out configurations.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	158	 The pipette solution contained an impermeant cation (i.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	159	, N-methyl-D-glucamine) so that inward current could only be due to Cl flow.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	160	 The holding potential was approximately 60 mV.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	161	 A current-voltage relationship and typical tracing are shown in Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	162	 4, both consistent with the channel activity previously described for F508 CFTR (6, 21, 32).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	163	 The conductance of the channel is ~8-10 pS, and the channel is activated after excision by 250 U/ml PKA plus 200  microM ATP in the bath, as expected for a functional CFTR protein.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	164	 We observed CFTR channels in 2 of 27 seals in F508 LLC-PK1 cells and in 12 of 48 seals in the same cells treated with DMSO.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	165	 The wild-type CFTR was observed in 8 of 25 seals.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	166	 The open probability of the F508 channels was studied after stimulation by PKA and ATP.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	167	 In the representative tracing shown in Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	168	 4, open probability before activation was 2% (98% closed); open probability after activation was 97% (3% closed).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	169	 The wild-type CFTR also exhibited strong activation when cells attached (open probability up to 98% following PKA stimulation).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	170	View larger version (18K):    Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	171	   Single F508 CFTR channels in the plasma membrane of LLC-PK1 cells after DMSO treatment.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Cells were studied in the cell-attached and excised inside-out (I/O) configuration.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Single channels with properties similar to those described previously for F508 CFTR were observed (see text).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	174	 B: current-voltage relationship.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	175	Transepithelial Cl transport mediated by F508 CFTR following DMSO treatment.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	176	 To extend our findings concerning F508 CFTR in LLC-PK1 cells grown in plastic dishes, we also grew cells on permeable supports to form epithelial monolayers.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	177	 LLC-PK1 cells exhibit a more differentiated phenotype under these conditions, as indicated by tight junction formation, epithelial resistance measurements, and the capability to perform vectoral ion transport (11, 30, 38, 39).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Under these conditions, F508 LLC-PK1 cells had low, but detectable, Cl transport that was absent in parental (non-CFTR expressing) cells (P  <  0.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Resistance in the cell monolayers was ~100    cm2.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	180	 A 3-day DMSO treatment of F508 CFTR-expressing cells led to forskolin-activated currents in the direction of Cl secretion that were greatly increased compared with untreated F508 LLC-PK1 cells (P  <  0.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Transport was absent in parental LLC-PK1 cells with or without DMSO treatment, indicating specificity for F508 CFTR expression.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	182	 When Cl was omitted from solutions bathing the monolayers, Isc was not detectable either in wild-type or F508 CFTR-expressing cells under any treatment conditions, indicating that the Isc observed in the presence of Cl was due to vectoral Cl transport.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Studies of wild-type CFTR-expressing cells are shown for comparison.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Modest increases in monolayer resistance (e.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	185	, by 15-20%) were noted in most paired experiments as a result of DMSO treatment, a finding that suggests enhancement of tight junction formation in cells grown on permeable supports in the presence of DMSO.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	186	 A summary of these studies is shown in Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	187	View larger version (45K):    Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	188	   Short-circuit current (Isc) measurements in LLC-PK1 cells.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Representative tracings are shown with and without DMSO treatment.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	190	 F508 LLC-PK1 cell monolayers bathed in NaCl Ringer solution exhibited a rapid, forskolin-activated Isc in the direction of Cl secretion specifically following DMSO treatment (F508 + DMSO).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Isc disappeared when either Cl (F508 + DMSO, 6 mM Cl Ringer bath bilaterally) or F508 CFTR (parental + DMSO) was omitted.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	192	 For comparison, cells expressing the wild-type (wt) CFTR are shown.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Effects of bumetanide, a blocker that inhibits transepithelial Cl transport by inhibiting the basolateral Na+-K+-2Cl cotransporter, are also shown.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Resistance was ~100    cm2 in each experiment.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Mock-treated cells (F508, top right) represent vehicle treatment without DMSO.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Aperture area in these studies was 0.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	197	View larger version (14K):    Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	198	   Summary of Isc activation through F508 CFTR.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Maximal Isc stimulation by forskolin in F508 CFTR and parental LLC-PK1 cells under conditions of symmetrical (NaCl) Ringer solution is shown.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Statistics were by Student's t-test (compared with parental LLC-PK1 without DMSO, third bar from left); n = 12 paired experiments for each condition.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	201	Isc studies of alternative activators of F508 CFTR maturation in LLC-PK1 cells.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	202	 We performed the same sorts of experiments shown above on F508 LLC-PK1 cells following incubation with 10% glycerol (for 48 h), 5 mM butyrate (for 24 h; longer incubations led to substantial toxicity), or growth at 27 degrees C (for 48 h).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Each of these interventions has been shown to augment F508 processing in certain cell types grown on plastic (3, 7, 37).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	204	 We saw no evidence with any of these approaches of either Isc activation or band C CFTR.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	205	 These results are significant because they suggest that DMSO acts to potentiate F508 CFTR maturation through a mechanism that 1) is different from that observed with glycerol or butyrate, 2) is more potent than can be obtained with glycerol or butyrate, at least in the LLC-PK1 model, and 3) allows insertion of the F508 CFTR in the plasma membrane of a transporting cellular monolayer in vitro.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	206	DMSO treatment leads to a more differentiated phenotype in recombinant LLC-PK1 cells.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	207	 To determine whether DMSO altered the phenotype of LLC-PK1 cells, we probed cells grown on plastic with an antibody to ZO-1, a constituent of epithelial tight junctions (15, 41).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Organization and assembly of tight junctions is an additional, useful measurement of polarity and differentiation in epithelial cell monolayers.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Well-organized tight junctions occurring in an ordered distribution indicate a higher level of polarity and differentiation, whereas tight junction antigens that are absent, poorly developed, or distributed throughout the cytoplasm or plasma membrane may be indicative of a less differentiated phenotype.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	210	 7, a 4-day treatment with 2% DMSO led to qualitative increases in tight junction organization in LLC-PK1 cells, as detected by ZO-1 staining in the regions of cell-to-cell contact.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	211	View larger version (48K):    Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	212	   Tight junction formation in LLC-PK1 cells after DMSO treatment.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Confocal immunofluorescence microscopy of cells without and with DMSO treatment.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Increases in the organization of tight junction antigen zonula occludens-1 (ZO-1) were observed as a result of DMSO treatment.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	215	    DISCUSSION Top Abstract Introduction Methods Results Discussion References.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	216	In LLC-PK1 cells grown on plastic, F508 CFTR is absent from the plasma membrane (Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	217	 3) but can be detected at the cell surface when cells are grown as a monolayer on a permeable support (Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	218	 The maturation of F508 CFTR can be augmented further by treatment with nontoxic concentrations of a differentiation agent known to increase epithelial cell polarity, DMSO (14, 23, 31, 40).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	219	 The in vitro model described here for cell monolayers (as opposed to previous studies of nonpolarized cells grown on plastic) might be useful in the development of procedures to augment F508 CFTR maturation or to study openers of F508 CFTR Cl channels present in the plasma membrane.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	220	We tested the possibility that DMSO, like butyrate, increases F508 CFTR mRNA levels (Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	221	 We saw no evidence of increased CFTR mRNA in either wild-type or F508 LLC-PK1 cells under the same DMSO treatment conditions that partially corrected F508 protein processing.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Moreover, butyrate treatment of F508 cells at 5 mM caused no improvement in Cl transport in an Ussing chamber protocol.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	223	 These results suggest that DMSO augments the maturation of F508 CFTR by a mechanism that is different from the known effects of butyrate.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	224	 DMSO has also recently been suggested to act as a "chemical chaperone" and to correct the folding and biogenesis of the pathogenic prion protein in vitro (W.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Welch, personal communication).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Although it is possible that DMSO has effects on CFTR folding, there is no direct evidence in our experiments that DMSO can reach cytoplasmic levels that alter the kinetics, efficiency, or other aspects of CFTR folding in living cells to augment F508 CFTR processing.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Therefore, although an effect on CFTR folding remains an important consideration in our experiments, further studies will be necessary to test a direct role for DMSO as a chemical chaperone for CFTR.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	228	In our experiments, interventions that increase epithelial cell polarity and differentiation also conferred increases in F508 CFTR maturation.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Growth of epithelial cells on permeable supports is a well-established method of augmenting epithelial cell differentiation and has been described previously as leading to dome formation and a more differentiated phenotype in many cell types (13, 18, 25).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	230	 LLC-PK1 cells have previously been reported to switch from an undifferentiated to a more differentiated phenotype when grown on filters (48).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	231	 This method was therefore selected as one way to increase cell polarity in our experiments.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	232	 We showed that growth on permeable supports also led to functionally detectable F508 CFTR in the plasma membrane by Isc measurements (Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	233	 DMSO treatment is another well-described method for augmenting cell differentiation in epithelial cells derived from different tissues (14, 23, 31, 40).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Accordingly, we tested the influence of DMSO on F508 CFTR maturational processing.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	235	 DMSO treatment caused increased resistance in LLC-PK1 monolayers (presumably on the basis of greater organization of tight junctions), and the same treatment led to further increases in F508 CFTR activity at the cell surface (Figs.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Moreover, we observed that organization of tight junctions in LLC-PK1 cells increased under the same conditions that led to F508 maturation (Figs.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Finally, vectoral chloride transport (Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	238	 5) should only be detectable in a polarized epithelial monolayer and was observed in our studies of anion transport.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Together, these experiments indicate that a more differentiated phenotype also confers an increase in F508 CFTR maturation.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	240	 The effect of DMSO on F508 CFTR processing was also observed in primary human nasal polyp cells but not in nonepithelial cells (mouse fibroblast, L cells; Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	241	 Experiments in these other cell types suggest the usefulness of the approach for activating F508 processing in human epithelial cells.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	242	Transmembrane proteins are often distributed throughout the plasma membrane when cells are undifferentiated.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	243	 With the onset of differentiation and the development of adherens junctions, tight junctions, and cell matrix interactions, structural polarity is established.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	244	 The process by which proteins target to the apical membrane appears to occur by a default mechanism (10).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	245	 Our results may indicate that cellular polarity helps establish part of this default pathway.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	246	 The possibility that F508 CFTR enters the apical targeting pathway specifically after an increase in cellular differentiation is suggested by results in Figs.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	247	 Other contributors to F508 maturation, including stabilization of the folded structure of F508 protein, a change in F508 CFTR interactions with cellular chaperones, or a decrease in the rate of degradation of F508 CFTR in the ER (so as to allow more time to reach the Golgi), are among the alternative explanations for the findings shown here.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	248	In summary, the ER in epithelial cells is a hostile environment, insofar as the CFTR is concerned.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	249	 Wild-type and F508 molecules, even when folded into functional Cl channels, are polyubiquitinated and degraded in short order (half time of ~30 min) by the proteasome and possibly other proteolytic pathways (20, 44).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	250	 CFTR that escapes the ER and enters the Golgi may reach a "safe haven," where half time increases to  > 12 h for the post-ER form.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Our data suggest, after DMSO treatment in LLC-PK1 cells, an increased amount of the post-ER complex-glycosylated and membrane-localized F508 CFTR is observed.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Because neither block of ubiquitination nor proteasome inhibition has been reported to enhance F508 maturation, it is less likely that the effects observed here are caused by blockade of the proteasome or of ubiquitination.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Our results raise the possibility that induction of polarity in LLC-PK1 cells might increase a transition of F508 CFTR from the ER to the trans-Golgi network (Figs.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	254	 If the F508 CFTR quality control mechanism becomes "leaky" in differentiated cells compared with the undifferentiated state, the findings could have important implications concerning the in vivo processing of F508 CFTR, which occurs in well-organized cells within tissues characterized by tight junctions and polarity.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Further experiments are needed to test this possibility, as well as to test the effects of DMSO treatment in F508 CF mice.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Gadi, Jan Tidwell, Kynda Roberts and Bonnie Parrott for help with preparation of this manuscript, Eddie Walthall for technical assistance, and Drs.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	257	 Vytas Bankaitis and Douglas Cyr for useful discussions.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	258	This work was supported by the National Institutes of Health and the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	259	Address for reprint requests: E.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Sorscher, Gregory Fleming James Cystic Fibrosis Research Center, Univ.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	261	 of Alabama at Birmingham, 1918 Univ.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Boulevard (BHSB 798), Birmingham, AL 35294-0005.
