0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	383	 269: 17853-17857, 1994[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	384	 Autocrine signaling through ATP release represents a novel mechanism for cell volume regulation.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	385	 USA 93: 12020-12025, 1996[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	386	AJP Cell Physiol 274(3):C799-C809 0363-6143/98 $5.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	387	00 Copyright   1998 the American Physiological Society.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	0	  The Rockefeller University Press, 0021-9525/2003/1/157 $5.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	1	00 The Journal of Cell Biology, Volume 160, Number 2, 157-163 Report.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	2	Traffic-independent function of the Sar1p/COPII machinery in proteasomal sorting of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator Lianwu Fu and Elizabeth Sztul.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	3	Department of Cell Biology, University of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, AL 35294.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	4	 of Cell Biology, MCLM Room 668, 1530 3rd Ave.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	5	   Abstract Top Abstract Introduction Results and discussion Materials and methods References   Newly synthesized proteins that do not fold correctly in the ER are targeted for ER-associated protein degradation (ERAD) through distinct sorting mechanisms; soluble ERAD substrates require ER-Golgi transport and retrieval for degradation, whereas transmembrane ERAD substrates are retained in the ER.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Retained transmembrane proteins are often sequestered into specialized ER subdomains, but the relevance of such sequestration to proteasomal degradation has not been explored.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	7	 We used the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae and a model ERAD substrate, the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR), to explore whether CFTR is sequestered before degradation, to identify the molecular machinery regulating sequestration, and to analyze the relationship between sequestration and degradation.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	8	 We report that CFTR is sequestered into ER subdomains containing the chaperone Kar2p, and that sequestration and CFTR degradation are disrupted in sec12ts strain (mutant in guanine-nucleotide exchange factor for Sar1p), sec13ts strain (mutant in the Sec13p component of COPII), and sec23ts strain (mutant in the Sec23p component of COPII) grown at restrictive temperature.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	9	 The function of the Sar1p/COPII machinery in CFTR sequestration and degradation is independent of its role in ER-Golgi traffic.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	10	 We propose that Sar1p/COPII-mediated sorting of CFTR into ER subdomains is essential for its entry into the proteasomal degradation pathway.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	11	 These findings reveal a new aspect of the degradative mechanism, and suggest functional crosstalk between the secretory and the degradative pathways.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	12	Key Words: ER sorting; proteasomal degradation; CFTR; ERAD; yeast.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	13	   Introduction Top Abstract Introduction Results and discussion Materials and methods References   Quality control of newly synthesized membrane proteins occurs in the ER (Ellgaard and Helenius, 2001).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Incorrectly folded proteins are targeted for ER-associated protein degradation (ERAD)* and are eliminated by the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway (Brodsky and McCracken, 1999).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Because proteasomal degradation occurs in the cytoplasm, ERAD substrates must be retrotranslocated from the ER to the cytoplasm before digestion.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The cellular machinery involved in the sorting and translocation of ERAD substrates is under active investigation.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	17	 One of the key requirements is a fully competent early secretory pathway because mutations in proteins involved in ER-Golgi traffic cause disorganization of ER structure and inhibit ERAD (Taxis et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The Sec61p/Sec63p translocon (Plemper et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	19	, 1997) and auxiliary proteins Der1p (Knop et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	20	, 1996), Der3p/Hrd1p (Bordallo and Wolf, 1999), and Hrd3 (Hampton et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	21	, 1996) have been shown to be required for retrotranslocation of ERAD substrates.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	22	 In addition, a subset of molecular chaperones such as calnexin (McCracken and Brodsky, 1996), BiP (Plemper et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	23	, 2001), and p97 (Rabinovich et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	24	, 2002) participate in selecting ERAD substrates.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Evidence indicates that two distinct mechanisms participate in directing different substrates for ERAD (Vashist et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Soluble ERAD substrates such as carboxy peptidase Y (CPY), PrA, and KHN require functional transport between the ER and the Golgi (Caldwell et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	27	, 2001), and the degradation of these proteins is delayed when ER-Golgi traffic is inhibited in sec18 to 1 and sec12 to 4 strains.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Additional components encoded by PER17 (Vashist et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	29	, 2001), ERV14, and ERV29 (Caldwell et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	30	, 2001) appear essential in degradation of soluble ERAD substrates, and appear to function by regulating ER-Golgi transport of specific soluble proteins.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	31	 In contrast, the degradation of membrane ERAD substrates such as mutant forms of Ste6p, Yor1p, Sec61p, Vph1p, and cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) seem unaffected by sec18 to 1, sec12 to 4, sec21 to 1, per17 to 1, erv14, or erv29 mutations (Loayza et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	32	 These findings suggest that transmembrane ERAD substrates do not enter post-ER compartments of the secretory pathway before degradation.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	33	 In agreement, soluble ERAD substrates can be detected in post-ER transport vesicles, whereas transmembrane ERAD substrates are excluded (Vashist et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	34	The exact pathway for degradation of transmembrane ERAD substrates from the ER is unclear, but there is evidence to suggest that at least some retained proteins are sorted into specialized ER subdomains before degradation (Kamhi-Nesher et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	35	 It is unknown what molecular mechanisms regulate sequestration of ERAD substrates, and whether such sequestration is required for ER retrotranslocation and proteasomal degradation.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	36	 To explore these questions, we used the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae and mutant strains defective in the Sar1p/COPII sorting machinery and a known ERAD substrate, CFTR, as our model system.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	37	Sar1p/COPII-mediated selection of ER proteins for secretory traffic is one of the best understood mechanisms for selective recruitment of proteins in the ER (Antonny and Schekman, 2001).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	38	 COPII sorting is initiated by Sar1p, a small GTPase (Veldhuisen et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	39	, 1997) that is activated by Sec12p-mediated guanine-nucleotide exchange.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Sar1p in its GTP-bound state associates with the ER membrane and recruits the Sec23p/Sec24p to COPII complex and subsequently the Sec13p/Sec31p to COPII complex to the membrane (for review see Barlowe, 2000).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	41	 The assembly of the COPII coat on ER budding structures is coupled to the selection of transmembrane proteins into the nascent budding structures that will eventually bud from the ER as transport vesicles.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	42	 COPII function has been examined to date exclusively in the context of secretory traffic.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	43	CFTR is a chloride channel present on the apical surface of epithelial cells lining the respiratory, intestinal, and exocrine tissues (Kirk, 2000).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	44	 In mammalian cells, only 20% of newly synthesized wild-type CFTR folds correctly and is transported from the ER to the plasma membrane through the secretory pathway, whereas the remaining 80% of CFTR is degraded from the ER through the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway (Jensen et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	45	 In mammalian cells, CFTR is not sequestered into ER subdomains before degradation because inhibition of proteasomal activity by chemical inhibitors or overtaxing the proteolytic capacity by overexpressing CFTR leads to retrotranslocation of CFTR from the ER and its accumulation in cytosolic aggresomes (Johnston et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	46	 In yeast, the majority (if not all) of newly synthesized CFTR is also degraded through the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway, but in contrast to mammalian cells, CFTR in yeast is not delivered to aggresomes, but appears sequestered in ER subdomains before degradation (Kiser et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	47	Here, we report that the Sar1p/COPII machinery functions in sorting CFTR into ER subdomains before proteasomal degradation, and that such sorting is required for CFTR entry into the degradative pathway.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	48	 This function of Sar1p/COPII does not involve ER-Golgi traffic.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Our results support a model in which the Sar1p/COPII machinery participates in sorting proteins to both the anterograde secretory pathway and the degradative pathway.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	50	 These findings raise the possibility that all newly synthesized proteins are subjected to a Sar1p/COPII sorting mechanism, irrespective of their ultimate secretory or degradative fate.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	51	   Results and discussion Top Abstract Introduction Results and discussion Materials and methods References   GFP-tagged CFTR is a bona-fide ERAD substrate in yeast To provide a substrate for our studies, we generated a construct containing EGFP fused in frame to the NH2 terminus of human CFTR in a yeast expression vector under a copper-inducible promoter.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	52	 1 A, EGFP-CFTR is detected after immunoprecipitation with anti-CFTR antibody and anti-GFP antibody after copper induction of wild-type yeast carrying the EGFP-CFTR plasmid (Fig.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	53	 1 A, lanes 1 and 4), but not from yeast carrying an empty vector (Fig.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	54	 EGFP-CFTR is not seen in a sample precipitated with anti-F1ss antibody.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The mobility of EGFP-CFTR (175 kD) is appropriate for a chimera of EGFP (27 kD) and full-length human CFTR (145 kD).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	56	View larger version (26K):    Figure 1.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	57	 EGFP-CFTR represents yeast ERAD substrate.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	58	 (A) Yeast transformed with pCU426CUP1 (EGFP-CFTR, - lane) or pCU426CUP1/EGFP-CFTR (EGFP-CFTR, + lanes) were induced, labeled with [35S]methionine for 20 min, and lysed.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Lysates were immunoprecipitated with anti-CFTR, anti-F1ss, or anti-GFP pAbs.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	60	 A band of 175 kD, appropriate for a chimera of EGFP and CFTR, can be immunoprecipitated with anti-CFTR and anti-GFP antibodies from cells expressing EGFP-CFTR.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	61	 (B) Wild-type, pre1 to 1, and ubc6 yeast were transformed with pCU426CUP1/EGFP-CFTR, induced, and pulse-labeled with [35S]methionine for 20 min.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	62	 An equal amount of culture was taken at each chase time, lysed, and the lysates were immunoprecipitated with anti-CFTR antibody.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Relative intensities of EGFP-CFTR bands were quantitated.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	64	 EGFP-CFTR is stabilized in pre1 to 1 and ubc6 strains.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	65	  To ensure that EGFP-CFTR behaves as an ERAD substrate, we examined its degradation rate in mutant strains lacking either a functional proteasome subunit (pre1 to 1) or an ubiquitin-conjugation enzyme (ubc6).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Both proteins have been previously shown to be required for degradation of CFTR tagged at the COOH terminus with GFP (Kiser et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	67	 1 B, EGFP-CFTR in wild-type yeast is digested rapidly, with a half-life of 10 to 15 min (Fig.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	68	 1 B), slightly more rapidly than previously published (20 min, Kiser et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	69	 All CFTR appears to be degraded in yeast (Kiser et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	70	, 2001), as opposed to mammalian cells where 20% is transported to the plasma membrane.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	71	 It is possible that yeast does not have sufficient machinery to efficiently fold overexpressed CFTR, or that even correctly folded CFTR is "read" by yeast as defective.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	72	 In contrast to rapid degradation in wild-type yeast, EGFP-CFTR remains stable in pre1 to 1 mutant yeast even after 90 min of chase, and the half-life of EGFP-CFTR in the ubc6 strain is extended to 40 min.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Because our EGFP-CFTR construct is degraded through the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway in yeast, we use it as an ERAD substrate to test Sar1p/COPII involvement in proteasomal targeting.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	74	EGFP-CFTR is sorted to subcompartments of ER before degradation Previous studies have shown that CFTR tagged at the COOH terminus with GFP (Kiser et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	75	, 2001) is degraded as an integral membrane protein and colocalizes with the ER chaperone Kar2p in punctate ER structures before degradation.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	76	 To analyze our EGFP-CFTR construct, we first tested its association with membranes.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	77	 2 A, EGFP-CFTR is detected exclusively in the membrane pellet fraction after medium speed centrifugation, indicating that it is degraded as a membrane-associated form.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	78	View larger version (47K):    Figure 2.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	79	 EGFP-CFTR localization depends on functional Sar1p/COPII machinery.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	80	 (A) Yeast expressing EGFP-CFTR was subjected to membrane fractionation.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	81	 A sample of each fraction was processed by SDS-PAGE, transferred to nitrocellulose membrane, and immunoblotted with anti-CFTR antibody.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	82	 S; supernatant after high speed centrifugation.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	83	 P1, P2, P3; pellets after low speed, medium speed, and high speed centrifugation, respectively.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	84	 EGFP-CFTR is recovered exclusively in the membrane fraction.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	85	 (B) Wild-type yeast expressing EGFP-CFTR was grown to log phase and processed for immunofluorescence using anti-Kar2p or anti-Kex2p antibodies, or was incubated with the fluorescent dye FM 4 to 64 for 45 min at 0 degrees C, followed by 1 h at 24 degrees C to stain the vacuole.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	86	 EGFP-CFTR colocalizes only with the ER marker Kar2p.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	87	 (C) Wild-type yeast transformed with pCU426CUP1 (- EGFP-CFTR) or with pCU426CUP1/EGFP-CFTR (+ EGFP-CFTR) was grown to log phase, induced, and processed for immunofluorescence with anti-Kar2p antibodies (insets) and for electron microscopy.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Kar2p shows typical ER localization in - EGFP-CFTR cells, but distributes to punctate structures in + EGFP-CFTR cells.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Cells without EGFP-CFTR contain normal ER (arrows), but cells expressing EGFP-CFTR show accumulation of membranous elements (arrowheads).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	90	 (D) Wild-type, ubc6, sec18 to 1ts, and sec23 to 1ts yeast transformed with pCU426CUP1/EGFP-CFTR was grown to log phase and induced at permissive (24 degrees C) or restrictive (39 degrees C) temperature.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Live yeast were then imaged by fluorescence microscopy.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	92	 EGFP-CFTR localizes to ER subdomains in wild-type, ubc6, and sec18 to 1ts yeast grown at permissive or restrictive temperatures.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	93	 EGFP-CFTR localizes to ER subdomains in sec23 to 1ts yeast grown at permissive temperature, but is diffusely distributed throughout the ER in sec23 to 1ts yeast grown under restrictive temperature.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	94	  We performed immunofluorescence with known organellar markers to localize EGFP-CFTR.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	95	 2 B, EGFP-CFTR is not detected in small punctate structures containing the late Golgi marker Kex2p (Preuss et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	96	 This result agrees with findings that CFTR expressed in yeast undergoes ER-type N-glycosylation, but does not undergo Golgi-type oligosaccharide modifications (Kiser et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	97	 EGFP-CFTR is not detected on the plasma membrane, and does not colocalize with the fluorescent dye FM 4 to 64 (Fig.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	98	 2 B) shown to be transported to endosomal (unpublished data) or vacuolar compartments of yeast as a function of incubation time and temperature (Vida and Emr, 1995; the minimal colocalization in the vacuole is due to bleed-through from the strong EGFP-CFTR signal and is not visible in cells without EGFP-CFTR).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	99	 The lack of vacuolar localization is consistent with lack of degradation of CFTR via the Pep4p/Prb1p vacuolar proteases (Kiser et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	100	EGFP-CFTR is detected in relatively large punctate structures that contain Kar2p (Fig.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	101	 The punctate Kar2p distribution in EGFP-CFTR to expressing yeast is distinct from its normal cage-like perinuclear localization in control yeast (Paddon et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	102	 The effects of EGFP-CFTR expression on intracellular morphology were analyzed by electron microscopy of yeast transformed with either empty or EGFP-CFTR to containing plasmids.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	103	 2 C, normal nuclear membrane and sub to plasma membrane ER structures are evident in the control cell (arrows), in agreement with published images (Zhang et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	104	 In contrast, EGFP-CFTR cell shows clusters of membranous structures in proximity to the perinuclear ER (arrowheads).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Higher magnification shows them to be accumulations of tubular and vesicular elements, morphologically analogous to ER extensions observed in yeast expressing CFTR (Zhang et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	106	 The relative size of such clusters (average diameter 0.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	107	5 to 1  microm) corresponds to the approximate size of the fluorescent Kar2p/EGFP-CFTR puncta.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Significantly, membrane amplification induced by CFTR (Zhang et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	109	, 2001) or EGFP-CFTR (this work) is distinct from multi-layered ER "karmellae" induced by expression of HMG-CoA reductase (Koning et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Together, the data suggest that EGFP-CFTR localizes to subdomains of the ER network that represent penultimate stations before degradation.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	111	 The results also imply that sequestration into the ER domains is more efficient than subsequent removal by degradation.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	112	Functional Sar1p/COPII machinery is required for sorting EGFP-CFTR to ER subdomains To determine if the Sar1p/COPII machinery participates in sorting EGFP-CFTR, we examined its localization when COPII function is disrupted.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	113	 First, we tested the localization of EGFP-CFTR in wild-type, ubc6, and sec18 to 1 yeast strains when grown at 24 degrees C (permissive temperature for strains defective in COPII components) and when grown at 39 degrees C (restrictive temperature for strains defective in COPII components).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	114	 2 D, EGFP-CFTR in the wild-type strain remains as punctate spots at both temperatures.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Similarly, the pattern of EGFP-CFTR in the ubc6 strain defective for proteasomal degradation is analogous to that in the wild-type strain.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	116	 This strongly suggests that EGFP-CFTR is sorted into the punctate structure and maintained there before it is targeted for ubiquitination and degradation.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Our data, together with the finding that CFTR remains sequestered in Kar2p-containing subdomains in yeast strain (pre1 to 1pre2 to 2) defective for proteasomal degradation (Zhang et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	118	, 2001), suggest that the catalytic activity of ubiquitin-conjugating enzyme Ubc6p is not sufficient to remove EGFP-CFTR from ER subdomains, and that ubiquitination and proteasomal degradation are tightly coupled.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	119	 The same punctate EGFP-CFTR pattern is observed in sec18 to 1 strain grown at either temperature, indicating that block in vesicular fusion during ER-Golgi protein transport does not significantly affect EGFP-CFTR sequestration.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	120	Analysis of EGFP-CFTR localization in the sec23 to 1ts strain (Kuehn et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	121	, 1998) showed significant temperature-dependent changes (Fig.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	122	 At the permissive temperature, EGFP-CFTR is sequestered into ER subdomains, but at the restrictive temperature, EGFP-CFTR is diffusely distributed throughout the ER in a pattern characteristic of ER proteins (compare enlargement with Kar2p staining in inset; Fig.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Similar results were obtained when yeast strains mutant in other components of the Sar1p/COPII machinery (described below) were analyzed (unpublished data).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	124	Functional Sar1p/COPII machinery is required for EGFP-CFTR degradation To uncover whether the Sar1p/COPII machinery is also involved in CFTR degradation, we compared the degradation rate of EGFP-CFTR at permissive (24 degrees C) and restrictive (39 degrees C) temperature in yeast mutant in Sar1p/COPII components.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	125	 In wild-type strain, EGFP-CFTR is degraded rapidly at both temperatures, with a half-life of 10 to 15 min (Fig.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	126	 The temperature-sensitive strain, sec12 to 4ts, is defective in catalyzing GDP/GTP exchange on Sar1p at the restrictive temperature due to a P73L mutation (Barlowe and Schekman, 1993).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	127	 EGFP-CFTR is degraded rapidly in the sec12 to 4ts strain at permissive temperature; with a half-life (10 min) analogous to that in wild-type strain (Fig.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	128	 In contrast, the degradation rate is delayed significantly when the yeast is shifted to the restrictive temperature, with the half-life extending to 40 to 45 min, a threefold increase compared with the permissive temperature.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	129	 The temperature-sensitive strains sec23 to 1ts and sec13 to 1ts (Salama et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	130	, 1997) are defective at the restrictive temperature due to an S382L mutation (Yoshihisa et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	131	, 1993), and a mutation that has not yet been identified, respectively.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	132	 In both cases, COPII function is compromised.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	133	 EGFP-CFTR is degraded rapidly in both sec23 to 1ts and sec13 to 1ts strains at the permissive temperature, with half-lives of  < 15 min (Fig.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	134	 In contrast, the degradation rates are significantly delayed in both strains at the restrictive temperatures, with a half-life of 50 min.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	135	 The significant inhibition of EGFP-CFTR degradation suggests that functional COPII machinery is required for proteasomal degradation of EGFP-CFTR.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	136	View larger version (50K):    Figure 3.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	137	 EGFP-CFTR degradation depends on functional Sar1p/COPII machinery.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Wild-type (A), sec12 to 4ts (B), sec23 to 1ts (C), sec13 to 1ts (D), and sec18 to 1ts (E) yeast were transformed with pCU426CUP1/EGFP-CFTR.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Yeast were grown to log phase and induced at permissive temperature.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	140	 An equal amount of culture was then pulse-labeled with [35S]methionine for 20 min at either 24 degrees C or 39 degrees C.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	141	 An equal amount of culture was taken after indicated chase times and used to prepare cell lysates.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Lysates were immunoprecipitated with anti-CFTR or anti-CPY (for sec18 to 1ts) antibody.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Relative intensities of EGFP-CFTR bands were quantitated.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	144	 EGFP-CFTR degradation is significantly inhibited by inactivation of Sec12p, Sec23p, and Sec13p.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	145	  It must be stressed that EGFP-CFTR, like other transmembrane ERAD substrates, does not enter the ER-Golgi recycling degradative pathway.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Like the previously characterized CFTR (Kiser et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	147	, 2001), EGFP-CFTR is degraded with normal kinetics at permissive and restrictive temperatures in a sec18 to 1 strain (Fig.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	148	 The strain is defective in Sec18p function, as shown by a block in maturation of the vacuolar CPY at the restrictive temperature (Fig.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Together, the results indicate that ER-Golgi transport and recycling are not required for EGFP-CFTR degradation.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Our findings suggest a novel role for the Sar1p/COPII sorting machinery.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	151	 In addition to selecting correctly folded substrates into the forward secretory pathway (Schekman and Orci, 1996; Bannykh et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	152	, 2000) and selecting misfolded soluble ERAD substrates for the ER-Golgi recycling degradative pathway (Vashist et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	153	, 2001), Sar1p/COPII also sorts misfolded substrates into subdomains of the ER from which they are subsequently degraded.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	154	 How does the same machinery sort proteins into three distinct pathways? A common sorting mechanism for both correctly folded and misfolded membrane proteins presents a spatial problem because these classes must occupy distinct regions of the ER.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	155	 It is likely that additional targeting mechanisms coordinate with Sar1p/COPII to direct the proteins to ER exit or retention.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	156	 It appears that a primary distinction is made at the level of packaging into COPII vesicles; although correctly folded soluble and transmembrane proteins for secretory traffic and misfolded soluble ERAD substrates for ER-Golgi recycling degradative traffic are sorted into COPII vesicles, misfolded transmembrane ERAD substrates are excluded (Vashist et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	157	 There is evidence that transmembrane ERAD substrates are prevented from entry into COPII vesicles and are retained in the ER through the action of luminal ER proteins.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	158	 For example, mutants of the transmembrane ATPase Pma1p appear to be retained and degraded in the ER through the action of a protein disulfide isomerase to related protein, Eps1p (Wang and Chang, 1999).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Similarly, the retention of a transmembrane H2a precursor in the ER is determined by a pentapeptide sequence present on the luminal side of the ER (Shenkman et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	160	 In addition, ERAD substrates can be retained by binding to calnexin.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	161	 It has been shown that calnexin binds to wild-type and folding compromised F508CFTR in the ER, but the association with F508CFTR is prolonged and might facilitate ER retention (Pind et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	162	 ERAD substrates can be also retained by association with the translocon (Loayza et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Cytoplasmic chaperones may also participate in ER retention (Brodsky et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	164	 The finding that strains inactivated in the cytosolic Hsp70 Ssa1p do not sort CFTR into ER subdomains supports the view that ER sequestration requires the coordinate action of Sar1p/COPII and accessory factors.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	165	That Sar1p/COPII is likely to participate in the secretory and the degradative pathways is supported by data obtained from whole genome microarray analysis where many genes involved in secretory traffic were found to be UPR targets (Travers et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Initially, the up-regulation was viewed as means to increase traffic in the ER-Golgi recycling degradative pathway for soluble ERAD substrates (Caldwell et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	167	 However, our work suggests that the up-regulation is also a means to increase components required for ER sequestration of transmembrane ERAD substrates.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Specifically relevant to our analysis is the up-regulation of SEC12, SEC13, and SEC24.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Thus, it may be that the UPR-mediated up-regulation of these genes may not be a cellular strategy to remove protein from the ER by exporting them, but additionally might promote sorting of retained proteins toward degradation.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	170	   Materials and methods Top Abstract Introduction Results and discussion Materials and methods References   Antibodies and plasmids Anti-CFTR NBD1 pAb was described previously (Bebok et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	171	 David Bedwell (University of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, AL).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Anti-Kar2p pAb was a gift from Dr.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Jeffrey Brodsky (University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Anti-Kex2p mAb was a gift from Dr.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Vytas Bankaitis (University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Chapel Hill, NC).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Anti to COOH-terminal CFTR mAb was purchased from USBiological.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Anti-CPY antibody was purchased from Molecular Probes, Inc.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Goat anti to rat and anti to mouse antibodies conjugated with fluorescein isothiocyanate or rhodamine were purchased from Jackson ImmunoResearch Laboratories.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	179	To generate an inducible construct expressing GFP-tagged CFTR in yeast, pEGFP-CFTR plasmid (Moyer et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	180	, 1998) was first digested with SacII, and then treated with Klenow fragment followed by digestion with NheI.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	181	 The pRSETB/EGFP plasmid (provided by Dr.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	182	 David Bedwell) was first digested with HindIII and then treated with Klenow fragment followed by digestion with NheI.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	183	 The EGFP-containing fragment from pRSETB/EGFP and CFTR-containing fragment from pEGFP-CFTR were gel-purified, ligated, and transformed into Eschericia coli.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	184	 The resulting plasmid was then digested with NheI and EcoRV, and treated with Klenow fragment.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	185	 The EGFP-CFTR to containing fragment was gel-purified and cloned into the SmaI site of pCU426CUP1 (Labbe and Thiele, 1999).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	186	 The final construct was sequenced to ensure the correct open reading frame.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	187	Yeast strains CTY182 (MATa, ura3 to 52, his3 to 200, lys2 to 80), CTY252 (MATa, ura3 to 52, sec12 to 4ts), CTY253 (MATa, ura3 to 52, sec13 to 1ts), and CTY260 (MAT, ura3 to 52, leu2 to 3, 112, sec23 to 1ts) were a gift from Dr.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	188	 YHI29/W (MATa, ura3, leu2 to 3, 112, his3 to 11, 15, cans, GAL1), YHI29/1 (MATa, pre1 to 1, ura3, leu2 to 3, 112, his3 to 11, 15, cans, GAL1), and YWO0346 (MAT, ura3 to 1, leu2 to 3, 112, his3 to 11, 15, ade2 to 1 ocre, trp1 to 1, can1 to 100, ubc6::LEU2) were a gift from Dr.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Dieter Wolf (Universitat Stuttgart, Stuttgart, Germany).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	190	 SEY6210 (MAT ura3 to 52 leu2 to 3, 112 his3-200 trp1-901 lys2 to 801 suc2-9) and SEY5186 (MAT sec18 to 1 ura3 to 52 leu2 to 3, 112 GAL+) were a gift from Dr.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	191	Yeast media were prepared as described previously (Rose et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Unless specified, in all experiments, cultures were grown for a minimum of 5 to 6 generations to an A600 of no more than 1.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	193	Fractionation, immunofluorescence, and electron microscopy Yeast expressing EGFP-CFTR was fractionated as described previously (Paddon et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	194	 In brief, cells grown to exponential phase were converted to spheroplasts using yeast lytic enzyme (ICN Biomedicals) in the presence of 20 mM potassium phosphate buffer, pH 7.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	195	 The spheroplasts were washed and disrupted using a Dounce homogenizer in 25 mM Hepes-NaOH buffer, pH 7.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	196	4, plus protease inhibitors (Sigma-Aldrich).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Cell lysates were centrifuged at 4 degrees C at 500 g for 10 min, and the resulting supernatant was spun at 25,000 g for 15 min.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	198	 The resulting supernatant was centrifuged at 150,000 g for 1 h.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Pellet from each spin was washed with Hepes buffer and saved as P1, P2, and P3, respectively.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Protein concentration was measured using a Detergent Compatible Protein Assay kit (Bio-Rad Laboratories).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	201	For immunofluorescent studies, yeast were grown in synthetic complete medium lacking uracil to an OD600 of no more than 1.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Yeast were fixed by adding formaldehyde to 3% and incubating at either 24 degrees C or 39 degrees C for 30 min.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Cells were harvested and washed twice with 0.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	204	5, and once with potassium phosphate buffer containing 1.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	205	 The cell walls were digested by adding ss-mercaptoethanol to 0.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	206	 After incubating at 30 degrees C for 1 h, cells were washed twice with sorbitol buffer, applied to polylysine-coated coverslips, and were allowed to settle at RT for 20 min.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	207	 The cells were refixed with 3% formaldehyde for 5 min followed by quenching with 50 mM of NH4Cl for 5 min.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Cells were permeabilized with 0.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	209	1% Triton X-100 for 10 min and washed twice for 5 min each with blocking buffer (PBS containing 0.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Cells were incubated overnight with primary antibody diluted 1:5,000 for anti-Kar2p antibody and 1:2,000 for anti-Kex2p antibody.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Coverslips were washed three times with blocking buffer.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Cells were incubated with secondary antibody for 1 h and washed as above.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Coverslips were mounted on slides in 9:1 glycerol/PBS with 0.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Images were acquired with an inverted microscope (Axiovert 30; Carl Zeiss MicroImaging Inc.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	215	 IpLab Spectrum software (Signal Analytics Corp.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	216	) was used to control image acquisition.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	217	Yeast containing either an empty plasmid or EGFP-CFTR to containing plasmid were grown to an A600 of 0.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	218	5, induced with copper for 2 h, and processed for electron microscopy as described previously (Kaiser and Schekman, 1990).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Grids were examined on an electron microscope (model 100CX; JEOL USA, Inc.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	220	Pulse-chase labeling and immunoprecipitation Yeast were grown overnight to log phase at 24 degrees C in synthetic complete medium supplemented with appropriate amino acids.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	221	 EGFP-CFTR expression was induced with 100  microM of CuSO4 for 2 h (Labbe and Thiele, 1999).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	222	 A total of 32 OD600 U of cells was harvested (3 OD600 U for each time point) and resuspended in 4 ml synthetic complete medium plus 100  microM CuSO4.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Each culture was separated into two parts and was incubated with shaking at 24 degrees C or 39 degrees C for 10 min.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Cells were then labeled with 200  microCi of [35S]methionine (Trans35S label from ICN Biomedicals) for 20 min.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	225	 The label was chased with 40  microl of chasing mixture (1 mg/ml methionine, 1 mg/ml cysteine, and 15% yeast extract).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	226	4-ml samples were collected at 0, 15, 30, 60, and 90 min and added to 25  microl of 100% TCA (5% final TCA concentration).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Samples were mixed, placed on ice for 20 min, and washed twice with ice-cold acetone.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Cells were resuspended in lysis buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	229	5% SDS, and protease inhibitors) and broken down by vortexing with glass beads.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	230	 EGFP-CFTR was immunoprecipitated from total cell lysate using a polyclonal anti-NBD1 CFTR antibody (1:250 dilutions).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Immunoprecipitates were separated on 6% SDS-PAGE and analyzed by PhosphorImager (Molecular Dynamics, Inc.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	232	 EGFP-CFTR signal was quantified using ImageQuant Software (Molecular Dynamics, Inc.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	233	), and relative amounts were calculated and plotted using Excel software (Microsoft).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	234	 For CPY analysis, pulse-chase was done as above, and lysates were immunoprecipitated with anti-CPY antibodies.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Immunoprecipitates were resolved on 10% SDS-PAGE and analyzed as above.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	236	SDS-PAGE and immunoblotting Samples were resolved on 6% SDS-PAGE as described previously (Bebok et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Some gels were electrotransferred to nitrocellulose membrane and immunoblotted with anti to COOH-terminal CFTR mAb as described previously (Bebok et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	238	   Footnotes   * Abbreviations used in this paper: CFTR, cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator; CPY, carboxy peptidase Y; ERAD, ER-associated protein degradation.
