0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	0	Cysteine String Protein Interacts with and Modulates the Maturation of the Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator* Hui Zhang, Kathryn W.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Peters, Fei Sun, Christopher R.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	2	 Marino, Jochen Lang , Robert D.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	3	From the Department of Cell Biology and Physiology, University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15261, the  Department of Medicine, University of Tennessee, Memphis, Tennessee 38163, the   Institut Europeen de Chimie et Biologie, Pessac F-33607, France, and the   Physiological Laboratory, University of Liverpool, Liverpool L69 3BX, United Kingdom.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	4	Received for publication, December 7, 2001, and in revised form, May 1, 2002.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	5	    ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	6	The cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) is a cAMP-regulated chloride channel whose phosphorylation regulates both channel gating and its trafficking at the plasma membrane.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Cysteine string proteins (Csps) are J-domain-containing, membrane-associated proteins that have been functionally implicated in regulated exocytosis.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Therefore, we evaluated the possibility that Csp is involved in regulated CFTR trafficking.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	9	 We found Csp expressed in mammalian epithelial cell lines, several of which express CFTR.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	10	 In Calu-3 airway cells, immunofluorescence colocalized Csp with calnexin in the endoplasmic reticulum and with CFTR at the apical membrane domain.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	11	 CFTR coprecipitated with Csp from Calu-3 cell lysates.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Csp associated with both core-glycosylated immature and fully glycosylated mature CFTRs (bands B and C); however, in relation to the endogenous levels of the B and C bands expressed in Calu-3 cells, the Csp interaction with band B predominated.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	13	 In vitro protein binding assays detected physical interactions of both mammalian Csp isoforms with the CFTR R-domain and the N terminus, having submicromolar affinities.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	14	 In Xenopus oocytes expressing CFTR, Csp overexpression decreased the chloride current and membrane capacitance increases evoked by cAMP stimulation and decreased the levels of CFTR protein detected by immunoblot.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	15	 In mammalian cells, the steady-state expression of CFTR band C was eliminated, and pulse-chase studies showed that Csp coexpression blocked the conversion of immature to mature CFTR and stabilized band B.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	16	 These results demonstrate a primary role for Csp in CFTR protein maturation.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	17	 The physical interaction of this Hsc70-binding protein with immature CFTR, its localization in the endoplasmic reticulum, and the decrease in production of mature CFTR observed during Csp overexpression reflect a role for Csp in CFTR biogenesis.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The documented role of Csp in regulated exocytosis, its interaction with mature CFTR, and its coexpression with CFTR at the apical membrane domain of epithelial cells may reflect also a role for Csp in regulated CFTR trafficking at the plasma membrane.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	19	     INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	20	The cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR)1 is responsible for the cAMP-activated chloride conductance of epithelial cell apical membranes (1).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Mutations in the CFTR gene cause cystic fibrosis, whereas hyperactivity of this transport pathway produces secretory diarrhea.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	22	 The folding of CFTR is energetically complex; misfolding and degradation of the protein are features of the most common CFTR mutation (F508) (2, 3).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	23	 In addition, F508 CFTR is unable to undergo ATP-dependent conformational changes in the ER that are required for its proper folding.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	24	 When CFTR folding is retarded in the ER, the protein becomes a target for proteolysis by ER-associated degradation mechanisms that police the protein secretory pathway for misfolded or incompletely complexed proteins (4).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	25	 This degradation involves ubiquitination of the aberrant protein and its delivery to the proteasome (5, 6).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Nearly all of the F508 CFTR produced by the cell is destroyed in this manner; and because of its complex folding pattern, much of the wild-type protein is also degraded.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	27	 The mechanisms that govern CFTR folding/degradation processes are facilitated by chaperone and co-chaperone protein interactions (discussed further below).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	28	The primary step in CFTR activation involves cAMP/protein kinase A-mediated phosphorylation of its central regulatory (R) domain, which not only permits the channel to gate, but also alters pathways for CFTR trafficking at the plasma membrane (7).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	29	 In recent years, protein interactions at several CFTR domains have been implicated in channel function and trafficking.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	30	 The N-terminal cytosolic tail of CFTR is a site of syntaxin 1A binding (8), and syntaxin 1A overexpression is thought to inhibit CFTR currents by reducing channel gating (9) and by interfering with regulated CFTR trafficking to the plasma membrane (10).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	31	 A motif promoting CFTR endocytosis has been identified at the C terminus, and this region interacts physically with the plasma membrane endocytic adapter (AP-2) complex (11, 12).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	32	 The C terminus of CFTR corresponds to a PDZ (PSD-95/Disc-large/ZO-1) binding motif, which interacts with ezrin radixin moesin-binding phosphoprotein 50 or E3KARP to bring ezrin into proximity with CFTR (13, 14).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Ezrin can anchor protein kinase A at a position physiologically appropriate for CFTR phosphorylation (15, 16), and ezrin interactions with the cytoskeleton permit retention of CFTR at the apical membrane as a mechanism to establish its polarity in epithelial cells (17).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Here, we report the interaction of CFTR with another multidomain protein, the cysteine string protein (Csp).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	35	The Csps were first discovered in Drosophila and Torpedo (18, 19), and their expression has now been documented in a variety of tissues from several mammalian species (20, 21).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Csp null mutants in Drosophila produce a temperature-sensitive block of synaptic transmission followed by paralysis and premature death.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	37	 These findings demonstrate a crucial role for Csp in neurosecretion (22).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	38	 In neurons, Csp is associated predominantly with synaptic vesicles (19), and in secretory cells it is found in large dense core or secretory granules (23, 24).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Studies of membrane dye labeling (25) and neurotransmitter release (26, 27) indicated that Csp knockouts exhibit defective neurotransmitter exocytosis; presynaptic endocytosis and vesicle recycling appear to be intact.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Studies in neuroendocrine (28) and endocrine cells (24) have confirmed that altered Csp expression elicits an impaired secretory phenotype.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	41	Csps contain an N-terminal "J-domain," a central cysteine-rich "string" region, and a phylogenetically more variable C-terminal domain.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	42	 The J-domains of Csps are structurally conserved among different species, and this region provides a fingerprint of Csp as a member of the DnaJ/Hsp40 (heat shock protein) chaperone family.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	43	 As observed for other chaperone proteins (29), the HPD motif of the Csp J-domain mediates its binding to and activation of the Hsc70 chaperone ATPases, which influence protein conformation/binding.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Structural predictions indicate that the C terminus of Csp1 may form a coiled-coil region, and this structure may be important in view of the emerging evidence that Csp can interact with proteins involved in exocytosis, such as vesicle-associated membrane protein and syntaxins 1A and 4 (21, 30, 31).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Thus, prior results suggest that Csp could link functions of the SNARE complex with those of Hsc70.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The concept that assembly of the core fusion complex requires chaperone activity has been raised previously (21); however, the explicit roles of Csp and Hsc70 in the assembly or disassembly of SNARE components are not yet known.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	47	 The C terminus of Csp contains the only primary structural difference that exists between the mammalian isoforms: full-length Csp1, and its C-terminal truncated variant, Csp2 (32, 33).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	48	Csp expression in epithelial cells has not been characterized previously.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	49	 We found that various mammalian epithelial cell lines express two Csp isoforms and that the expression of Csp1 predominated over that of Csp2.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	50	 In Calu-3 airway epithelial cells, Csp partially colocalized with CFTR in the ER and apical plasma membrane domains.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Csp coprecipitated with CFTR from Calu-3 cell lysates and bound selectively to the N terminus and R-domain of CFTR with high affinity.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Coexpression of Csp isoforms with CFTR inhibited the functional responses associated with its cAMP stimulation, and exogenous Csp expression decreased the production of mature CFTR.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	53	 These findings suggest that Csp is a CFTR-binding partner that can influence the biogenesis and trafficking of CFTR.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	54	     EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	55	Materials and Reagents-- Protein A/G-agarose beads and Taq polymerase were purchased from Invitrogen.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Glutathione-Sepharose 4B was purchased from Amersham Biosciences.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	57	 DNA restriction endonucleases were from New England BioLabs.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	58	 DNA purification kits were obtained from Qiagen.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Csp1 and Csp2 cDNAs were subcloned into pcDNA3 with an N-terminal Myc tag (34).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Mouse hippocampus neuronal cell (SY5S) lysate, employed as a Csp protein positive control, was kindly provided by Dr.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Chaohua Yan (Children's Hospital, Pittsburgh).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Protein kinase A and other reagent grade chemicals were purchased from Sigma.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	63	Antibodies-- Anti-Csp serum was raised in rabbits against recombinant bovine Csp1 (32).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Monoclonal anti-GST and anti-Golgi 58K antibodies were purchased from Sigma.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Anti-CFTR polyclonal antibodies (R3195) were generated and affinity purified as described (35).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Anti-CFTR (mAb3484 and mAb3482) and anti-Csp monoclonal antibodies were obtained from Chemicon.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Horseradish peroxidase-conjugated anti-rabbit IgG and anti-mouse IgG were obtained from Sigma.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Monoclonal anti-calnexin antibodies were obtained from Affinity Bioreagents.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	69	Cell Culture-- Calu-3 and T84 cells were cultured as described by Sun et al.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	70	 CFPAC-1 cells were grown in Iscove's essential medium (Biofluids) containing 5% fetal bovine serum, 4 mM L-glutamine, and penicillin-streptomycin (Invitrogen).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Madin-Darby canine kidney and HEK293 cells were cultured in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (Sigma) with 10% fetal bovine serum, 4 mM L-glutamine, and penicillin-streptomycin.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Xenopus kidney-derived A6 epithelial cells were cultured as described previously (36).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	73	Reverse Transcription-PCR-- Total RNAs were prepared from the indicated cell lines by use of Trizol buffer (Invitrogen), and cDNAs were synthesized using reverse transcriptase and a dT15 primer.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	74	 PCRs were performed as described (24).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	75	 The following primers were used: 5'-ATTAGGATCCatggcagaccagagacagc (sense for human Csp; BamHI restriction site underlined), 5'-ACGAATTCTTAGTTGAACCCGTCAGTGTG (antisense for human Csp; EcoRI restriction site underlined), 5'-ATTAGGATCCATGGCAGATCAGCGGCAGC (sense for Xenopus Csp), and 5'-ACGAATTCTCAGTTGAATCCATCGGTGTG (antisense for Xenopus Csp).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	76	 PCR products from Calu-3 and A6 cells were cloned into the pCRII vector using the TOPO cloning reaction and transformation kit (Invitrogen) for sequencing.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	77	Western Blotting-- Crude membranes from various epithelial cell lines or oocytes were prepared as described by Lang et al.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	78	 To prepare crude membrane extracts, epithelial cells were detached by incubation for 5 min at 37  degrees C with 1 x  trypsin, and after two washes in ice-cold phosphate-buffered saline, cells were resuspended in ice-cold homogenization buffer (5 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	79	4, 250 mM sucrose, 1 mM EGTA, 10  microg/ml leupeptin, 2  microg/ml aprotinin), sonicated, and centrifuged at 100,000  x  g for 60 min.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Crude membranes were recovered and incubated with 0.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	81	5% Triton X-100 at 4  degrees C for 1 h and then centrifuged at 16,000  x  g for 1 h.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	82	 The supernatant was collected and stored for analysis.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	83	 50  microg of membrane extract was separated on 12% SDS-PAGE minigels and transferred to polyvinylidene difluoride membranes.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Blots were probed with a 1:2,000 dilution of Csp or CFTR antiserum.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	85	 For vesicular stomatitis virus glycoprotein (VSV-G) detection, blots were probed with a polyclonal antibody at 1:5000 dilution.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	86	Immunofluorescence-- Calu-3 cell labeling was performed as described previously (14).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Cells were seeded on filters (Costar Transwell) 2-3 weeks before use.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	88	 After washing away apical secretions, cells were fixed (4% paraformaldehyde) and permeabilized (0.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Filters were mounted on glass coverslips, and images were obtained using a Leica TCS-NT confocal microscope as described (14).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	90	Plasmid Constructs and GST Fusion Protein Expression-- Wild-type Csp1 and Csp2 were subcloned into pGEX-6p-1.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	91	 cDNAs encoding GST-CFTR R-domain (GST-R), GST-CFTR N terminus (GST-N) and GST-CFTR C terminus (GST-C) were described previously (15).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	92	 GST-CFTR-N random was constructed as GST-N, except for a one-nucleotide shift in the reading frame, which yields a different amino acid composition; its net charge and size are comparable with CFTR-N.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Purification and dialysis of GST fusion proteins were performed as described by Sun et al.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	94	Pull-down Assays and Coimmunoprecipitation-- 10  microg of GST fusion protein was incubated with 20  microl of preequilibrated glutathione-Sepharose 4B beads in 200  microl of DIGNAM-D buffer containing 0.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	95	1% bovine serum albumin at 4  degrees C for 1 h (38).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Calu-3 membrane fractions were added, and the incubation continued for an additional 2 h at 4  degrees C.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	97	 After five washes with DIGNAM-D buffer, samples were resuspended in 30  microl of 2 x  SDS sample buffer, boiled for 2 min, resolved on 12% SDS-PAGE, and probed with anti-Csp antibodies (1:2,000).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Coimmunoprecipitation was performed as described by Sun et al.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	99	 10% of the protein extract employed in the immunoprecipitation was loaded for subsequent immunoblot.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	100	In Vitro Binding and Competition Assays-- In vitro binding assays were performed as described by Sun et al.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	101	 (15), and in vitro competition assays were performed as described by Sun et al.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Briefly, 10  microg of GST-CFTR-R or GST-CFTR-N fusion protein was immobilized on glutathione beads and incubated with 106 cpm of 35S-labeled Csp1 or Csp2 in the presence of the indicated concentrations of unlabeled Csp1 or Csp2.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	103	 After five washes, samples were resuspended in SDS sample buffer and signals visualized by autoradiography.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	104	Transient Transfections-- HEK293 cells grown in 60-mm dishes were transiently transfected using LipofectAMINE (Invitrogen) with the indicated pcDNA3 or pcDNA3.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	105	1 expression plasmids, 4  microg of cDNA/dish.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	106	 After 24 h, the cells were rinsed with phosphate-buffered saline and either prepared for pulse-chase assays or lysed in RIPA buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	107	4, 150 mM NaCl, 1% Triton X-100, 1% sodium deoxycholate, 0.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	108	1% SDS) or Nonidet P-40 lysis buffer (0.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	109	09% Nonidet 40, 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	110	4, 150 mM NaCl and 10 mM NaMoO4).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Samples were incubated for 2 h in the appropriate lysis buffer and centrifuged at 16,000  x  g for 30 min at 4  degrees C.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Cell extracts were utilized for immunoblot analysis (see figure legends).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	113	Pulse-Chase Assays-- Metabolic labeling and immunoprecipitation of CFTR were performed using methods described previously (39, 40), with modifications.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Transfected HEK293 cells were starved in methionine- and cysteine-free Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium for 30 min, and then metabolically labeled with Redivue Pro-mix L-35S (140  microCi/ml; Amersham Biosciences) for 30 min at 37  degrees C.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Cells were washed twice with phosphate-buffered saline and lysed immediately or incubated in complete Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium for the indicated chase periods.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Cell lysates were precleared with protein A-agarose, and immunoprecipitation was performed as described (40) using M3A7 anti-CFTR, kindly supplied by Dr.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Immunoprecipitates were analyzed using 7% SDS-PAGE and autoradiography.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	118	Electrophysiology-- CFTR, Csp1, and Csp2 cRNAs were synthesized using the mMessage mMachine kit (Ambion) from linearized plasmids.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	119	 The quality of synthesized cRNA was determined by spectrophotometry and agarose gel electrophoresis.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Oocyte preparation and cRNA injections were carried out as described by Takahashi et al.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Expression proceeded for 2-6 days before current and capacitance recordings, which were performed as described (10, 41).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	122	 All data are provided as the mean  plus or minus  S.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	123	     RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	124	Csp Is Expressed in Epithelial Cells-- Immunoblotting was performed to determine whether Csp is expressed in several epithelial cell lines.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Crude membrane extracts from the mammalian cells HEK293, Madin-Darby canine kidney (type 2), CFPAC-1, Calu-3, and T84, and from the Xenopus A6 cell line were resolved on 12% SDS-PAGE and probed with an anti-Csp antiserum that does not distinguish between Csp isoforms (32).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	126	 As a positive control, membranes from the SY5Y human neuronal (hippocampal) cell line were applied to the gel.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	127	 1A, all of the mammalian epithelial cells examined expressed two Csp isoforms.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	128	 1A are appropriate in size for Csp1 (33-35 kDa), whereas the lower bands in mammalian cells correspond to the size expected for Csp2 (26-28 kDa); this isoform was uniformly less abundant.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	129	 In contrast, A6 cells expressed only one Csp isoform.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	130	 It is more closely related to Csp1 than Csp2 (33), although its molecular size is slightly smaller than the Csp1 in mammalian cells.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	131	 The Csp antiserum also recognized in vitro synthesized Csp1 and Csp2 (data not shown).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	132	View larger version (46K):    Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	133	   Csps are expressed in various epithelial cell lines.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Panel A, homogenates (15  microg of protein) from the indicated cell lines were probed with Csp antiserum.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Panel B, reverse transcription-PCR was performed as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	136	" No cDNA was added in the PCR designated Control.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	137	To confirm the expression of Csp isoforms in these cells, reverse transcription-PCR was employed, and the results are shown in Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	138	 The sizes of the PCR products were as expected for the cDNAs encoding Csp1 and Csp2.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	139	 These products are not derived from contaminating DNA because the primers employed span Csp exons.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Csp2 protein is truncated relative to Csp1 because of the insertion of a stop codon-containing RNA splice fragment (32); this accounts for the smaller size of the Csp2 protein but its larger cDNA and PCR product (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Although the PCR results are not quantitative, the Csp amplicon ratios from different cell lines generally agreed with the pattern of isoform expression observed by immunoblot.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	142	 As with the protein analysis, Csp isoforms were expressed at lower levels in T84 cells.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Only one isoform of Csp was detected in A6 cells, in accord with the protein data (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	144	 1A) and information in the data base.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Sequencing of these PCR products confirmed the expression of Csp1 and 2 in Calu-3 cells, and of the single isoform (33) reported in Xenopus A6 epithelia (data not shown).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	146	Csps Are Partially Colocalized with CFTR at the ER and Apical Membranes-- In non-epithelial cells, Csps are membrane-associated and are localized predominantly on large dense core vesicles or synaptic-like microvesicles (22-24, 42, 43).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	147	 A small fraction of Csp is located on the plasma membranes of neurons, neuroendocrine or endocrine cells.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Large dense core vesicles are present in epithelial cells having defined secretory products (e.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	149	 pancreatic acinar cells), but Csp distribution in epithelial cells has not been defined previously.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	150	To examine the subcellular distribution of Csps in airway epithelial cells, immunofluorescent staining was performed in polarized Calu-3 cells and visualized using confocal microscopy.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Sections taken at various cell depths (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	152	 2, A-D) showed a predominantly punctate and vesicular distribution pattern for Csp (green fluorescence).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Csp and CFTR (red fluorescence) colocalized in the most apical sections, as indicated by the yellow staining pattern of Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	154	 2E), a fraction of Csp colocalized with CFTR at the apical region of some cells, but the apex of other cells showed little apparent colocalization.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Although Csp colocalized with CFTR in apical membrane compartments, significant fractions of both proteins showed no apparent overlap by immunofluorescence in their steady-state cellular distributions (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	156	 This is partly because of the presence of Csp in what appear to be large secretory granules that lack CFTR (44).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	157	 These granules are likely to contain the secretory products characteristic of airway submucosal gland serous cells, which Calu-3 cells express (e.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	158	 mucins, microbial defense substances and protease inhibitors) (45).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	159	 CFTR was not detected in their membranes (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	160	 2), in contrast to the localization of CFTR found in the mucin granules of canine gallbladder cells (46).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	161	 This observation suggests that Csp may play a CFTR-independent role in secretory granule exocytosis from Calu-3 cells, and this possibility will require further study.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	162	View larger version (70K):    Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	163	   Colocalization of Csp with CFTR or with calnexin in Calu-3 cells.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Calu-3 cells were labeled with polyclonal Csp antiserum and monoclonal CFTR R-domain or calnexin antibodies.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Labeling was detected by Alexa488 (green indicating Csp) or Alexa568 (red indicating CFTR in panels A-E or calnexin in panel F).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Serial images in the xy plane were collected every 0.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	167	5  microm through the specimen depth; xy images (panels A-D), taken from cell apex to base, are separated by 2.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Panel E shows the xz scan of the region indicated in panel A.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Images were collected by confocal microscopy and analyzed using Metamorph (Universal Imaging) software.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	170	 2F, taken at the nuclear level, shows that Csp (green) was partially colocalized with calnexin (red), an ER marker.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Preliminary analysis of Calu-3 cells by sucrose density gradient centrifugation was consistent also with the colocalization of these proteins because Csp was found in fractions containing the ER marker calnexin.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	172	2 The results suggest that a fraction of Csp is colocalized with CFTR at both the ER and the apical membrane domain of Calu-3 epithelia.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	173	Interaction of CFTR with Csp-- To determine whether a physical interaction between Csp and CFTR could be detected in vivo, we performed coimmunoprecipitation experiments (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	174	 In these studies, the initial precipitation was performed with either Csp antiserum or with antibodies against the first nucleotide binding domain (NBD1) of CFTR.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	175	 3A (lane 3), Csp antibody coimmunoprecipitated the mature, glycosylated CFTR (band C, upper) as well as the immature, core-glycosylated CFTR (band B, lower) from Calu-3 cell extracts.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	176	 As a negative control, no CFTR was precipitated by a nonimmune IgG (lane 2).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	177	 As a control for the coimmunoprecipitation, we performed direct CFTR immunoblotting on the same Calu-3 membrane preparations (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Both CFTR bands were present, but the ratio of the B and C bands found in the Csp immunoprecipitation differs from that constitutively expressed.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Together with the results from the cellular localization experiments, the immunoprecipitation results suggest that in the steady state, Csp interacts with both the immature, core-glycosylated form of CFTR in the ER and with mature, fully glycosylated CFTR at the apical membrane domain.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	180	 3B, a CFTR NBD1 antibody coprecipitated Csp from Calu-3 membranes (see positive control, Calu-3 cell lysate, lane 1).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	181	 An N-terminal CFTR antibody did not precipitate significant Csp (data not shown).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	182	 The lower band denoted Csp in panel B likely represents deacylated Csp, produced by the coimmunoprecipitation conditions, which include overnight incubation with detergent, as noted by others (47).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	183	 This lower band is not observed under the conditions used for immunoblotting (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	184	 As a negative control, Csp did not coprecipitate with a GST antibody (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	185	 The absence of Csp coprecipitation by anti-CFTR-N could represent a problem of antibody affinity, or it may reflect impaired antibody access to its epitope at the N terminus of CFTR.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	186	View larger version (28K):    Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	187	   Coimmunoprecipitation of Csp and CFTR.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Calu-3 membrane extract was mixed with Csp or CFTR antibody and precipitated as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	189	" Immunoblots were probed with anti-CFTR (1:2,000, panel A) or anti-Csp antibodies (1:2,000, panel B).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Calu-3 cell membrane extract was loaded as a positive control (panels A and B, lanes 1).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Antibodies used for immunoprecipitation were nonimmune IgG and anti-Csp (panel A, lanes 2 and 3) and anti-GST and anti-CFTR-NBD1 (panel B, lanes 2 and 3).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	192	 The lower band denoted Csp in panel B likely represents deacylated Csp, produced by the coimmunoprecipitation conditions, which include overnight incubation with detergent.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	193	 This outcome was noted by others (43, 47).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Hc indicates antibody heavy chain.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	195	Csp Interacts with the R-domain and N Terminus of CFTR-- The results from coimmunoprecipitation experiments indicate that CFTR and Csp interact in vivo.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	196	 To evaluate CFTR domain interactions with Csp, we performed pull-down experiments in which GST or GST-CFTR fusion proteins were bound to glutathione-Sepharose beads and incubated with Calu-3 or CFTR-expressing HEK293 membrane extracts.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Protein complexes were washed, resolved on SDS-PAGE, and immunoblotting was performed using Csp antibodies.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	198	 To verify that comparable amounts of GST or GST fusion proteins were applied in these assays, the Western blots were subsequently stained with Coomassie Blue.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	199	 The similar amounts of fusion proteins present are illustrated in Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	200	 4B, both the CFTR R-domain and the N terminus showed significant interactions with Csp.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	201	 A weak interaction between CFTR-C and Csp was detected here, but this was not observed consistently.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	202	 No binding was detected between Csp and GST, GST-CFTR-N random, or GST-syntaxin 1A in these pull-down assays.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	203	 The interaction of Csp with CFTR-N is consistent with the finding from the above coimmunoprecipitation studies and suggests that the interaction with CFTR-N could be masked by Csp binding.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	204	View larger version (18K):    Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	205	   Csp interacts with the R-domain and N terminus of CFTR.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Bead-immobilized GST-CFTR fusion proteins were incubated with Calu-3 membrane extracts.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	207	 After washing, samples were resolved on 12% SDS-PAGE.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Coomassie Blue staining was used to determine protein loading (panel A); membranes were blotted with Csp antiserum (panel B).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	209	 GST-CFTR fusion proteins: lane 1, GST; lane 2, GST-R; lane 3, GST-C; lane 4, GST-N; lane 5, GST-N random; lane 6, GST-syntaxin 1A.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	210	As indicated above, two Csp isoforms have been identified in various mammalian species (21); Csp2 is truncated by 31 amino acids at the C terminus relative to Csp1.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	211	 The Csp isoform(s) that interact with CFTR or CFTR domains in Calu-3 cells (Figs.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	212	 3 and 4) cannot be determined because of the lack of isoform specific Csp antibodies.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Csp1 may be the more physiologically significant isoform because of its predominant expression and the presence of only Csp1 in some species (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	214	 In further characterizing CFTR-Csp interactions, we evaluated the influence of both Csp1 and Csp2; however, in the discussion following we refer to CFTR interactions with Csp, without attempting to discriminate whether they are mediated by a specific Csp isoform.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	215	Relative Affinities of Csp for CFTR Domains-- To determine the relative binding properties of Csp1 and 2 for CFTR, we performed binding assays with in vitro synthesized 35S-labeled Csp1 and Csp2.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Csp interactions were documented using autoradiography (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	217	 5A) and liquid scintillation counting (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	218	 As indicated by the data from both assays, the interaction of Csp1 with the CFTR R-domain (lane 2) was stronger than that with CFTR-N (lane 4), consistent with the Calu-3 cell pull-down experiments of Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	219	 In the present experiments, a weak interaction between CFTR-NBD1 and Csp1 (lane 5) was also detected relative to the GST negative control (lane 1).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	220	 The data for CFTR-C (lane 3) were not different from the GST control.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Unlike Csp1, Csp2 showed similar levels of binding to CFTR-R and CFTR-N.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Like Csp1, Csp2 showed significant but low level binding to CFTR-NBD1 relative to the GST control.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	223	 The lower panel provides pooled data from three independent experiments.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	224	View larger version (37K):    Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	225	   Quantitative Csp interactions with the CFTR R-domain and N terminus.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Immobilized GST-CFTR fusion proteins were incubated with 35S-Csp1 or 35S-Csp2, washed, and samples were resolved by 15% SDS-PAGE.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Csp binding was detected by autoradiography (panel A) and liquid scintillation counting (panel B).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Mean data from three independent experiments are shown.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Asterisks indicate a significant difference from the GST control.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Lane 1, GST; lane 2, GST-R; lane 3, GST-C; lane 4, GST-N; lane 5, GST-NBD1; S1 or S2, 1  microl of 35S-Csp1 or 35S-Csp2 loaded as a positive control.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	231	 The higher molecular mass bands are thought to represent Csp dimers and have been observed previously (47).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	232	To determine the relative binding affinities of Csps with the CFTR R-domain and N terminus, we performed in vitro competitive binding assays as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	233	" In these pull-down experiments, 35S-labeled Csp1 or 2 was mixed with various amounts of unlabeled Csp before mixing with immobilized CFTR domains.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	234	 6A, unlabeled Csp1 competed with labeled Csp1 for binding to CFTR-R, such that 1  microM unlabeled Csp1 eliminated 51% of 35S-Csp1 binding.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	235	 The results imply that the affinity for Csp1 binding to CFTR-R is ~1  microM.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Qualitatively similar results were obtained for Csp1 binding to the CFTR N terminus, but in this case the apparent binding affinity was ~10 nM.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	237	 6A, the association of labeled Csp2 with either the CFTR N terminus or R-domain was essentially eliminated in the presence of 1  microM cold Csp2 (data not shown).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	238	 These results indicate that both Csp1 and Csp2 show saturable binding to the R-domain and N terminus of CFTR and that the affinities of these interactions are in the submicromolar range.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Whether the differences in apparent binding affinity detected in these experiments (e.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Csp1 interactions with R and N) have physiological significance will require detailed knowledge of their functional consequences.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	241	View larger version (24K):    Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	242	   Affinity of Csp binding to CFTR-R and CFTR-N.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	243	 Panels A and B, immobilized GST-CFTR fusion proteins were incubated with 35S-Csp1 in the presence and absence of five concentrations of unlabeled Csp1 and binding detected by autoradiography (upper panels) or densitometric quantification after autoradiography (lower panels).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	244	 Lane B, 35S-Csp1 omitted as a negative control; lane C, equivalent amount of 35S-Csp1 added as a positive control.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	245	Csp Coexpression Inhibits CFTR Chloride Currents-- The multiple domain interactions observed for Csp binding to CFTR, as well as the colocalization of these proteins in the ER and apical membrane domain, suggest that the functional interactions between these proteins could be extensive.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	246	 To initiate such studies, we coexpressed CFTR with either Csp1 or Csp2 in Xenopus oocytes and determined the CFTR-dependent current and capacitance changes evoked during cAMP stimulation.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	247	 Prior studies of CFTR-expressing oocytes indicate that the cAMP-induced membrane current (Im) is caused by the chloride flow through the CFTR and that the corresponding increase in membrane capacitance (Cm) monitors changes in cell surface area which are associated with regulated insertion of CFTR into the plasma membrane (10, 41).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	248	 In relation to the initial rationale for these studies, we monitored Cm because Csp is known to function in regulated exocytosis in other systems (21).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	249	 Control oocytes not injected with CFTR cRNA showed no changes in Im or Cm in response to cAMP stimulation, as observed previously (41).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Expression of Csp without CFTR also yielded no Im or Cm responses to cAMP (data not shown).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	251	 The steady-state data from eight experiments in CFTR expressing oocytes are provided in Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Coexpression of Csp1 or Csp2 with CFTR decreased the Im and Cm responses that result from CFTR stimulation.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Although either Csp isoform reduced the functional expression of CFTR, Csp2 was the more potent inhibitor of Im and Cm (~90% inhibition) relative to Csp1 (~50% inhibition).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	254	 7 documents the expression of Myc-tagged Csp isoforms at the time of recording.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	255	 The band in lane 1, observed in oocytes expressing CFTR alone, corresponds to the single known endogenous Xenopus Csp, consistent with the A6 cell line data shown in Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	256	 The exogenous expression of Myc-tagged Csp1 and 2 are shown in lanes 2 and 3 of the upper panel.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	257	 We do not know whether the endogenous Xenopus Csp, which most closely resembles mammalian Csp1 (42), contributes to differences in the extent of inhibition by these isoforms or whether the different potencies relate to their structural features.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	258	View larger version (27K):    Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	259	   Csp coexpression inhibits CFTR Im and Cm.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Lower panel, Im (solid bars) and basal and stimulated Cm values (horizontal and vertical lined bars, respectively) in oocytes expressing CFTR or CFTR plus the indicated Csp isoform.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	261	 Stimulation was elicited by bath addition of 10  microM forskolin and 1 mM isobutylmethylxanthine.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Steady-state data are from three independent experiments are shown.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Numbers of observations: CFTR, 36; CFTR + Csp1, 14; CFTR + Csp2, 28.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	264	 Im and Cm inhibition with Csp coexpression was significant (p  <  0.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	265	 Upper panel, oocyte expression of endogenous Xenopus Csp (all lanes), Myc-Csp1 (lane 2), and Myc-Csp2 (lane 3) in parallel experiments.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	266	 cRNA injected/oocyte: CFTR, 1 ng; Csp isoforms, 5 ng.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	267	Csp Inhibits Functional CFTR Responses by Decreasing Steady-state CFTR Expression-- To determine whether the observed inhibition of CFTR current and capacitance changes was the result of a Csp-induced change in CFTR expression levels, we immunoprecipitated CFTR from oocytes expressing CFTR alone or CFTR plus Csp1, Csp2 or the Csp2 double mutant, H43Q/E93V.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	268	 CFTR was precipitated from oocyte membrane extracts, resolved on SDS-PAGE, and immunoblotted (see "Experimental Procedures").
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	269	 CFTR currents recorded from these populations of oocytes at the time of harvest are also provided.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	270	 8 (upper panel), the coexpression of Csp1 or Csp2 produced significant decreases in the level of CFTR expression (to 52 and 36% of the control level by densitometry, lanes 3 and 4, respectively).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	271	 As a negative control, CFTR was not detected in noninjected oocytes (lane 1).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	272	 As a positive control, we blotted CFTR expressed transiently in HEK293 cells (lane 6).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	273	 The apparent molecular masses of CFTR B and C bands expressed in oocytes was similar to those observed in HEK cells (a longer exposure demonstrated migration of HEK cell band B at the same location as observed in oocytes).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	274	 An increase in CFTR expression was observed with the Csp2 double mutant, but this did not result in currents greater than those of the CFTR control.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	275	 This degree of CFTR expression increase was not observed in all experiments, and it was not present in mammalian cells (see below).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	276	 The basis of this stimulatory effect of Csp2 double mutant has not been pursued.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	277	 As to the double mutant mutation sites, His-43 is a conserved site in the J-domain of Csp which is essential for Hsc70 binding and ATP hydrolysis (48), and Glu-93 is located in the Csp linker region and has been shown previously to abrogate the inhibitory effect of Csp overexpression on insulin release from pancreatic cells (24).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	278	 These results indicate that the effects of exogenously expressed Csp on CFTR activity are specific for known Csp functional domains, and they suggest that the inhibition of CFTR functional response is due primarily to a Csp-induced reduction in CFTR protein expression.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	279	View larger version (48K):    Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	280	   Csp coexpression reduces oocyte CFTR protein levels.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	281	 cRNAs encoding CFTR (1 ng) and Csp isoforms (5 ng) were injected into Xenopus oocytes as indicated.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Upper panel, results from CFTR immunoprecipitation.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	283	 Immunoprecipitation was performed with anti-CFTR monoclonal M3A7, and the immunoblot was probed with anti-CFTR polyclonal R3195 antibodies.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	284	 Lane 1, uninjected control; lane 2, CFTR alone; lane 3, CFTR plus Csp1; lane 4, CFTR plus Csp2; lane 5, CFTR plus Csp2 double mutant; lane 6, HEK293 cells transiently expressing CFTR used as a positive control.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Lower panel, cAMP-stimulated chloride currents recorded from the oocyte populations used for the immunoprecipitations.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Data are from five pooled oocytes for immunoprecipitation (50  microg of protein/lane) and four or five oocytes for ICl under each condition.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	287	 Recordings/immunoprecipitations were performed 4 days after injection.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	288	Csp Coexpression Inhibits CFTR Biogenesis-- The influence of Csp coexpression on the steady-state levels of CFTR expressed in mammalian cells was determined by cotransfecting HEK293 cells with plasmids encoding Csp and CFTR.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	289	 CFTR levels were determined by immunoblot after 24 h.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	290	 The Csp cDNAs used for transfection included an N-terminal Myc-tag, permitting exogenous Csp expression to be detected using an anti-Myc antibody (lower panel, Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	291	 As shown in the top panel of Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	292	 9A, the coexpression of either Csp1 or Csp2 with CFTR (lanes 3 and 4) eliminated the expression of mature, glycosylated CFTR (band C) and produced an accumulation of immature CFTR (band B).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	293	 This finding suggests that Csp overexpression interferes with the processing of CFTR to its mature form and that it stabilizes the immature form of CFTR.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	294	 The effect of exogenous Csp on CFTR biogenesis is specific because the Csp2 double mutant (H43V/E93Q) eliminated its inhibitory effect on CFTR maturation (lane 5).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	295	 In other experiments, a similar result was obtained with the Csp2 single mutant, H43Q, implying that a functional J-domain is critical for the inhibitory effect of Csp overexpression.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	296	 The enhancement of CFTR protein level by the Csp2 double mutant found in oocytes was not observed in mammalian cells.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	297	View larger version (34K):    Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	298	   Effect of Csp on CFTR biogenesis.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	299	 Panel A, HEK293 cells were transfected with CFTR (lane 2), CFTR plus Myc-Csp1 (lane 3), CFTR plus Myc-Csp2 (lane 4), and CFTR plus Myc-Csp2 double mutant (lane 5).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	300	 Lane 1, nontransfected control.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	301	 After 24 h, 50  microg of cell extract was resolved by 7% or by 15% mini-SDS-PAGE, and blots were probed with polyclonal anti-CFTR (R3195, 1:2,000), monoclonal anti-Hsc70 (1:2,000), or monoclonal anti-c-Myc (9E10, 1:2,000, Sigma) antibodies.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	302	 B and C indicate the positions of immature and mature CFTR, respectively.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	303	 Panel B, HEK293 cells were transfected with VSV-G (lane 1) or VSV-G plus Csp1 (lane 2); blots were probed with anti-VSV-G polyclonal (1:5,000).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	304	 Experiments were otherwise performed as in panel A.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	305	Because Csp is an Hsc70-binding protein, we examined the levels of Hsc70 by immunoblot under these conditions.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	306	 As shown in the middle panel of Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	307	 9A, the effect of Csp1 or 2 on CFTR expression was not associated with a change in Hsc70 expression levels when this Hsc70-binding protein was expressed.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	308	 Thus, the failure of cells to express mature CFTR is not caused by a change in the expression of this important CFTR chaperone.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	309	 In addition, the specificity of the Csp effect for CFTR biogenesis was determined by coexpressing Csp with the VSV-G.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	310	 Csp coexpression did not affect the production of the mature VSV-G, in experiments performed in a manner similar to those with CFTR (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	311	 This result suggests that the effect of expressed Csp is specific for maturation of CFTR.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	312	The effect of Csp on the steady-state expression of mature CFTR was supported by the results of pulse-chase assays.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	313	 10, Csp1 coexpression in HEK293 cells blocked the conversion of immature CFTR to mature CFTR.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	314	 As in prior studies (5), ~30% of wild-type CFTR matures to the fully glycosylated band C protein (lower panels); however, no band C was detected in Csp-coexpressing cells.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	315	 In addition, the half-life of immature CFTR was prolonged, consistent with the accumulation of band B observed in the steady-state data (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	316	 Similar effects on the biogenesis of mature CFTR resulted from the coexpression of Csp2 (data not shown).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	317	 With Csp coexpression, the rise in band B production at chase periods of 30 and 60 min is probably attributed to the lack of cold methionine and cysteine in the chase media; nevertheless, the experiments with CFTR alone were performed identically.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	318	 The results indicate that Csp interferes with CFTR biogenesis when Csp is overexpressed.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	319	 The implications of these findings for a physiological role of Csp in the production of CFTR will be discussed below.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	320	View larger version (51K):    Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	321	   Pulse-chase analysis of CFTR biogenesis in HEK293 cells, performed as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	322	" TTF indicates the transient transfection conditions.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	323	 35S-Labeled CFTR was immunoprecipitated using 3  microg of monoclonal CFTR antibody M3A7.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	324	 Samples were resolved on SDS-PAGE, and CFTR was revealed by autoradiography.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	325	 The intensities of CFTR C and B forms at the indicated times were quantified by densitometry and are expressed as a percentage of CFTR B form at chase time = 0 (taken as 100%).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	326	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	327	The results of this study show that Csp is expressed in a variety of epithelial cell lines, several of which are models for CFTR-mediated chloride secretion.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	328	 These cells expressed predominantly Csp1, as observed previously in neurons and secretory cells (21) (e.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	329	 Immunofluorescent labeling showed a membrane-limited distribution of Csp in ER and apical membrane compartments.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	330	 Significant amounts of CFTR coprecipitated with Csp from Calu-3 cell lysates; in protein binding assays, Csp associated with both the CFTR R-domain and the N terminus.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	331	 The overexpression of Csp decreased CFTR biogenesis, and it correspondingly reduced the functional response of CFTR to cAMP stimulation.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	332	 These results indicate that Csp interacts physically and functionally with CFTR in epithelial cells.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	333	 This is the first report of an action of Csp on protein maturation, as discussed below.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	334	Role of Csp in Regulated Exocytosis-- Csp is expected to influence CFTR directly by virtue of its localization at the cytosolic surfaces of intracellular membranes that contain CFTR.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	335	 A defining feature of the Csps is their central cysteine-rich (string) domain, where palmitoylation at multiple sites permits Csp to associate with membrane lipid (49).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	336	 Immunofluorescence demonstrated that Csp is distributed in membrane-limited compartments, including the apical membrane domain, in Calu-3 cells (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	337	 The Csps were discovered in Drosophila, and from their cellular distribution and knockout studies, a role for these proteins in neurotransmitter secretion became apparent (18).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	338	 Studies in neuroendocrine (28) and endocrine cells (24) have confirmed the role of Csp in regulated exocytosis.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	339	 Several studies have implicated a regulated exocytic event in the control of plasma membrane CFTR channel density (50).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	340	 In Xenopus oocytes expressing CFTR, cAMP stimulation enhances the chloride current and elicits increases in membrane capacitance and cell surface CFTR labeling, consistent with cAMP-regulated insertion of CFTR into the plasma membrane (10, 41, 51).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	341	 In adenovirus-transduced Madin-Darby canine kidney cells, CFTR was distributed in both intracellular and plasma membrane compartments under basal conditions and was recruited to the plasma membrane during cAMP stimulation (52).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	342	 The partial colocalization of Csp with CFTR at the apical membrane domain of Calu-3 cells (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	343	 2E) and its interaction with mature (band C) CFTR (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	344	 3A) is consistent with the concept that this protein may participate in post-Golgi CFTR trafficking events.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	345	 It will be interesting to determine whether Csp interacts with CFTR in a regulated trafficking compartment because this location would be consonant with the documented role of Csp in regulated exocytosis.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	346	 To perform such studies, however, it will be necessary to obviate the influence of Csp on CFTR maturation.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	347	A Role for Csp in CFTR Biogenesis-- We found Csp to be localized in airway epithelial cells in a compartment marked by the ER resident protein, calnexin.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	348	 Coimmunoprecipitation experiments showed that more of the core glycosylated, immature CFTR was associated with Csp than was the mature, fully glycosylated protein, particularly in proportion to the steady-state expression levels of the mature and immature forms of CFTR.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	349	 In addition, Csp coexpression reduced the production of mature CFTR, and this effect of Csp appears to require a functional J-domain.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	350	 These results imply that Csp and CFTR interact during CFTR biogenesis in the ER.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	351	 As a member of the DnaJ family of proteins, Csp could play a role in CFTR processing via its association with Hsc70.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	352	 The DnaJ proteins can serve as co-chaperones that recruit Hsc70 ATPases to specific substrates, where they activate the ATPase activity of the chaperone to modulate protein conformation (folding) or protein-protein interactions (4, 29).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	353	 Hsc70 has long been recognized as a CFTR chaperone, which coprecipitates with CFTR in the presence of ATP (39).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	354	 Hsc70 has been shown to assist in preventing the aggregation of NBD1, the domain in which the common CFTR folding mutant, F508, is located (4, 53, 54).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	355	 Normally, wild-type CFTR will be released from chaperones as it achieves its native conformation, but Hsc70 is thought to remain attached to misfolded CFTR where it can recruit the ubiquitin ligase, CHIP, to facilitate proteosome-mediated CFTR degradation (40, 55).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	356	Csp is a J-domain protein that interacts with Hsc70 and enhances its ATPase activity (56).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	357	 The interaction of Csp with Hsc70 and CFTR is likely to affect CFTR processing in one of two ways.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	358	 First, Csp may be a CFTR co-chaperone that stabilizes intermediate forms of CFTR to promote their folding and maturation.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	359	 This model suggests that Csp contributes positively to CFTR maturation, similar to the Hsc70 co-chaperone, Hdj-2 (53).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	360	 Second, Csp interactions with nonfolded CFTR intermediates may contribute to the degradation of nascent CFTR.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	361	 This model suggests that Csp may contribute to CFTR degradation, similar to the Hsc70-interacting protein, CHIP (see below).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	362	 Either model could explain how Csp overexpression reduces the steady-state expression levels of mature CFTR in mammalian cells or oocytes and therefore, the cAMP-stimulated CFTR currents (Figs.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	363	 In the first model, Csp overexpression causes a prolonged association of Hsc70 with CFTR, which can target CFTR for degradation (55).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	364	 Hsc70 has been shown to promote the ubiquitination and degradation of several cellular proteins (57).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	365	 For example, overexpression of Hsc70 leads to ubiquitination and degradation of apolipoprotein B (58).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	366	 Thus, a prolonged Csp-mediated association of CFTR with Hsc70, because of Csp overexpression, could lead to CFTR degradation, despite the possibility that the physiological role of Csp is to facilitate CFTR biogenesis.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	367	The second model is trivial, in that augmenting the level of a protein involved in CFTR degradation would reduce CFTR expression.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	368	 Illustrative of this model is the Hsc70-binding protein CHIP, a ubiquitin ligase whose overexpression promotes proteasome-mediated CFTR degradation (40).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	369	 CHIP appears to recognize slowly folding or misfolded forms of CFTR and promotes their destruction by binding to CFTR-associated Hsc70.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	370	 CHIP then targets CFTR to ubiquitin-conjugating enzymes.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	371	 The finding that proteosome inhibitors fail to promote trafficking of class II CFTR mutants suggests that mechanisms exist for irreversible targeting of protein to intracellular degradation processes before their cellular destruction.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	372	 CHIP appears to be a component of this pathway; in principle, Csp could function in this manner as well.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	373	Several findings favor the co-chaperone model.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	374	 First, the predominant interaction of Csp with CFTR band B in Calu-3 cells (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	375	 3) suggests a physiological role for Csp in the maturation of CFTR because the majority of the CFTR expressed in these cells is the fully glycosylated mature form.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	376	 Second, the direct interaction of Csp with CFTR subdomains in the absence of Hsc70 (Figs.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	377	 4 and 5) suggests that Csp may localize Hsc70 at specific sites to facilitate CFTR folding.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	378	 In contrast to CHIP (40), Csp does not require Hsc70 for its interaction with CFTR.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	379	 Third, Csp overexpression stabilized CFTR band B, which is contrary to the result expected for a protein that promotes degradation.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	380	 Finally, previous data indicate a positive role for Csp in protein folding processes, also favoring the first model of Csp interaction.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	381	 As is true of other DnaJ proteins, Csp can bind to unfolded proteins and prevent their aggregation (49).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	382	 This activity is synergistic with the similar action of Hsc70.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	383	 Together, these findings suggest that Csp may serve as a co-chaperone during CFTR biogenesis.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	384	Csp Interactions with the N terminus and R-domain-- With regard to protein interactions that could regulate CFTR biogenesis, it is interesting that Csp has the capacity to bind to both the R-domain and the CFTR N terminus.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	385	 Previous studies implicate the N terminus as a site important for the normal processing of CFTR and suggest that interactions of the R-domain with other CFTR subdomains may facilitate its biogenesis (3).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	386	 N-terminal truncations of CFTR are poorly processed, and little of the truncated protein is able to traffic to the plasma membrane.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	387	 In addition, several N-terminal disease mutations are processing mutants.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	388	 Several studies indicate that a pivotal point in CFTR synthesis is the generation of the R-domain.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	389	 Before synthesis of the R-domain, CFTR is unstable and is associated with chaperones to prevent NBD aggregation (53, 54).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	390	 Once the R-domain is formed, chaperone protein associations with CFTR decrease, and the nascent protein becomes more stable.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	391	 Other studies indicate that mutations near the N terminus of CFTR which lead ultimately to protein degradation are not recognized by the ER-associated degradation machinery until the R-domain is synthesized (3).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	392	 This implies that degradation processes recognize structural interfaces between CFTR subdomains.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	393	 These interdomain effects may be mediated by specific co-chaperones that can interact with several CFTR subdomains to facilitate access of Hsc70 to intermediates in the folding pathway; Csp is a candidate for such interactions.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	394	Finally, the discussion has focused primarily on CFTR biogenesis in the ER; however, it is possible also that the physiological action of Csp involves the trafficking of immature CFTR to post-ER compartments.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	395	 For example, Csp and CFTR could interact in the transition of CFTR to the ER-Golgi intermediate compartment or to proximal Golgi regions prior to CFTR glycosylation.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	396	 The mechanistic involvement of Csp in such trafficking processes may parallel its action in regulated exocytic events (see discussion above), presumably exploiting its interaction with Hsc70 to facilitate trafficking protein interactions.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	397	 In addition, a nonconventional pathway for CFTR trafficking has been proposed recently (59, 60) involving direct transit from the ER to the trans-Golgi network, perhaps via an endosomal compartment.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	398	 Csp could be involved in these trafficking steps; however, the significance of their role in CFTR maturation was cell type-dependent, and the presence of this pathway in epithelial cells has not yet been demonstrated.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	399	 Further studies will be necessary to evaluate these possibilities.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	400	Formerly, Csp has been implicated as an important component of the regulated exocytic machinery at the plasma membrane, and this was our rationale for examining Csp actions in relation to regulated CFTR trafficking.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	401	 However, the principal findings of the present study demonstrate a primary role for Csp in CFTR protein maturation.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	402	 Although Csp did not interact with the process of VSV-G maturation, it will be interesting to determine whether there are additional proteins whose biogenesis involves interactions with Csp.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	403	 Wrigley for excellent technical assistance; John R.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	404	 Riordan for antibody; Mark Silvis, Neil A.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	405	 Bradbury, and Meir Aridor for help with the pulse-chase studies; Simon C.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	406	 Watkins for assistance with image analysis; and Jeffrey L.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	407	 Brodsky and Meir Aridor for comments on the manuscript.
