0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	470	 276, 24891-24900[Abstract/Free Full Text] 59.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	471	 (2000) Traffic 1, 852-870[CrossRef][Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] 60.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	472	 277, 11401-11409[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	473	Copyright   2002 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	0	Tissue-specific in vivo transcription start sites of the human and murine cystic fibrosis genes.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	1	Nuffield Department of Clinical Biochemistry and Imperial Cancer Research Fund Laboratories, Institute of Molecular Medicine, University of Oxford, John Radcliffe Hospital, Oxford OX3 9DS, UK.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received June 20, 1997; Revised and Accepted December 15, 1997.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	3	The in vivo transcription start sites of the human cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene (CFTR) and its murine homologue (Cftr) have been mapped in a range of tissues using the technique of 5[prime] rapid amplification of cDNA ends (5[prime] RACE).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	4	 These are the first in vivo transcription start sites for CFTR or Cftr to be reported.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Distinct, tissue-specific patterns of CFTR start site usage were identified in both mouse and human.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	6	 In particular, striking variation in the position of the murine Cftr transcription start site was seen along the length of the intestinal tract; different start sites being utilized in ileum and in duodenum.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	7	 In humans, distinct transcription start sites are utilized in adult and foetal lungs.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	8	 In addition, a novel 5[prime]-untranslated exon of murine Cftr, denoted exon -1, was identified and shown to be expressed exclusively in mouse testis.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Expression of exon -1-containing Cftr transcripts was shown by mRNA in situ hybridization to be confined to the germ cells and to be regulated during spermatogenesis.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	10	Cystic fibrosis is a common, autosomal recessive disease characterized by intestinal blockages, exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, male infertility and progressive, degenerative lung disease (1).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	11	 These diverse symptoms result from mutation of a single gene, the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator or CFTR (2,3), the product of which functions as a cAMP-regulated, low conductance chloride channel (4).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	12	CFTR exhibits complex patterns of tissue-specific expression being expressed at low levels in specialized epithelial cells of the intestinal crypts, airway submucosal glands, pancreatic ducts, sweat gland ducts and the male reproductive tract (5-8).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	13	 In addition, the observed patterns of expression indicate that CFTR expression is regulated by hormones (9) and during development and differentiation (8,10,11).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Although the patterns of regulated CFTR gene expression are well known, surprisingly little is known of the genetic elements and transcription factors that regulate the tissue-specific expression of CFTR.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Both the mouse and human CFTR genes have promoters which resemble those of `housekeeping' genes (12-14), an observation that is inconsistent with the tissue and cell type specificity of CFTR expression.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	16	Knowledge of the position of the CFTR transcription start site utilized in CFTR-expressing cells in vivo is a prerequisite to understanding the regulation of the CFTR promoter.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	17	 CFTR transcription start sites previously have only been mapped in a number of immortalized cell lines (12,13,15), and it cannot be concluded that identical sites are used in vivo.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	18	 In the present study, we used a 5[prime] rapid amplification of cDNA ends (5[prime] RACE) approach to map accurately transcription start sites of human CFTR, and its murine homologue Cftr, in a range of primary tissues.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Distinct tissue-specific patterns of transcription start site usage were observed.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	20	 The implications of these findings with regard to the regulation of CFTR expression are discussed.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	21	 RESULTS Identification of murine Cftr transcription start sites by 5[prime] RACE.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	22	In order to identify the major in vivo Cftr transcription start sites utilized in mouse primary tissues, we performed 5[prime] RACE on total RNA isolated from adult mouse lungs, ileum, duodenum, testis, uterus, kidney, and also 16-day-old foetal mouse lungs.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	23	 First strand cDNA synthesis was performed using a Cftr-specific primer (MC6R; Table 1).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	24	 cDNAs were then homopolymer tailed and subjected to two successive rounds of hemi-nested PCR amplification with anchor primer complementary to the homopolymer tail and Cftr-specific nested primers (MC5R and MC2.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Discrete 5[prime] RACE products were amplified from each mouse tissue (Fig.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	26	 1 shows representative experiments).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	27	 These 5[prime] RACE products were excised and either sequenced directly or cloned into the vector pT7 blue (Novagen) and then sequenced.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	28	 The positions of the observed transcription initiation sites, numbered relative to the A of the initiating methionine codon of the Cftr open reading frame (ORF) at position +1, are shown schematically in Figure 2 and summarized in Table 2.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Single, major transcription start sites were observed for mouse adult lung (-82), kidney (-75), uterus (-72) and 16-day-old mouse foetal lung (-72).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Variation in Cftr transcription start site usage was seen along the length of the mouse intestinal tract; two start sites were observed in mouse duodenum (-60 and -19), whereas two different major start sites were mapped in mouse ileum (-72 and -75) corresponding to the most abundant 5[prime] RACE products amplified from this tissue (Fig.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	31	 In addition to the major start sites, a number of minor transcription start sites were observed in the ileum, kidney and uterus.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	32	 The minor 5[prime] RACE products from the ileum were isolated and found to correspond to transcription start sites at positions +27, -216 and -255.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Representative 5[prime] RACE PCR experiments performed on mouse tissue cDNA samples.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	34	 For each tissue, dC-tailed cDNA samples (TdT) and paired negative control cDNA samples that had not been homopolymer tailed (-) were subjected to identical PCR amplification.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	35	 (a) T-testis; (b) L, adult lung; FL, foetal lung; I, ileum; D, duodenum; U, uterus; K, kidney.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Lane M contains a 100 bp ladder (Promega), the most intense band corresponding to 500 bp.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	37	 The 700 bp of murine Cftr 5[prime]-flanking genomic sequence, spanning exons 1 and -1 and the intervening intron.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	38	 The nucleotide sequence is numbered relative to the first base of the initiation codon of the Cftr ORF.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Exons are shown in the upper case, with the first 17 amino acids of Cftr and the predicted amino acid sequence of a short upstream ORF shown in single letter code.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Bent arrows indicate the relative positions of the Cftr transcription start sites utilized in mouse tissues.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	41	 L, adult lung; FL, foetal lung; T, testis; I, ileum; D, duodenum; U, uterus; K, kidney.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Oligonucleotide primers used in reverse transcription and PCR Primer Exon Sequence HC6R 6 5[prime]-CCAGCTCTCTGATCTCTGTACTTCATCATC HC5R 5 5[prime]-TTATCTAGAACACGGCTTGACAGC HC2R 2 5[prime]-TTTGGTATATGTCTGACAATTCCAGGCGCT HC3R 3 5[prime]-ACATCGCCGAAGGGCATTAATGAGTTTAGG MC6R 6 5[prime]-GCAGCTCTTTGATCTCTGTACTTCACCATG MC5R 5 5[prime]-GTTCAGGTTGTTGGAAAGAAGACTAACAA MC2.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	43	1R 2 5[prime]-ACAAGTGGTCAGCTGAATCAGCAGAAGGGG.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	44	As the Cftr transcription start sites were mapped by a PCR-based technique, where more than one start site was observed, no absolute values can be assigned to the percentage of transcript initiating at each of the sites.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	45	 However, we can conclude that the most abundant products correspond to the major transcription start sites for Cftr and that, collectively, the minor 5[prime] RACE products constitute at most 10% of Cftr transcripts in any tissue.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Importantly, the two major start sites mapped in the ileum (-72 and -75) are used with approximately equal frequency while the two start sites mapped in the duodenum (-60 and -19) are used in an ~4:1 ratio, respectively.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Finally, the relative intensities of 5[prime] RACE products from foetal and adult lung correspond well with the known down-regulation of Cftr expression in adult mouse lung tissue (unpublished data).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Positions of the major murine Cftr transcription start sites utilized in mouse tissues, numbered relative to A of the initiation codon of the Cftr open reading frame at +1 Tissue Major start site(s) Minor start site(s) Testis -549   Lung -82   Foetal lung -72   Duodenum -19, -60   Ileum -75, -72 +27, -216, -255 Kidney -75   Uterus -72  .
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Positions of human CFTR transcription start sites, numbered relative to A of the CFTR translation initiation codon at +1 Tissue Position of start site Adult lung -69 Foetal lung -132 Intestine -69 Intestine -114 Pancreas -68 Identification of human CFTR transcription start sites by 5[prime] RACE.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	50	A significant amount of tissue-specific variation in the pattern of Cftr transcription start site usage was observed in the mouse.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	51	 In order to investigate whether similar variation in CFTR transcription start site usage also occurs in human tissues, we performed 5[prime] RACE on RNA isolated from human whole small intestine, whole pancreas, whole adult lung and whole foetal lung (pooled from 29 specimens in the age range 18-28 weeks): these tissues represent the major sites of CFTR expression relevant to CF disease pathology.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	52	 First strand cDNA synthesis was performed using a CFTR-specific primer (HC6R; Table 1).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	53	 cDNAs were then homopolymer tailed and subjected to two successive rounds of hemi-nested PCR amplification with an anchor primer complementary to the homopolymer tail and CFTR-specific nested primers (HC5R and either HC2R or HC3R; Table 1).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Discrete 5[prime] RACE PCR products were amplified from each human tissue (Fig.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	55	 3 shows representative experiments).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	56	 These 5[prime] RACE products were excised from a gel, purified and sequenced directly.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	57	 The positions of the transcription initiation sites, numbered relative to the A of the initiating methionine codon of the CFTR ORF at position +1, are shown schematically in Figure 4 and summarized in Table 3.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Mapping of transcription start sites for the CFTR gene in samples of human tissue total RNA.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	59	 For each tissue analysed, paired samples of dC-tailed cDNA (TdT) and negative control `No TdT' cDNA (-) were subjected to identical hemi-nested PCR amplification.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	60	 A first round of PCR amplification was performed with an anchor primer and the CFTR-specific primer HC5R, and a second round of PCR amplification was performed with anchor primer and HC2R (except * which was performed with anchor primer and HC3R).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	61	 L, lung; I, whole small intestine; P, pancreas; FL, foetal lung; M, 100 bp DNA ladder.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Sequence of the 5[prime]-flanking region of the human CFTR gene.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The nucleotide sequence is numbered relative to A of the translation codon at +1, and the initiation codon is double underlined.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Bent arrows indicate the positions of CFTR transcription start sites; the position of each site and the tissue in which it was mapped is shown.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	65	 FL, foetal lungs; L, adult lungs; I, whole small intestine; P, pancreas.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	66	The 5[prime] RACE products amplified from adult lung, foetal lung and pancreas corresponded to single transcription initiation sites at positions -69, -132 and -68 respectively, whilst the two 5[prime] RACE products amplified from small intestine corresponded to start sites at positions -69 and -114.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Because of limited availability of human tissues, it has not been possible to determine whether these two alternative start sites represent variation in start site usage along the length of the human intestinal tract, as is the case with murine Cftr, or whether these alternative start sites are used in different CFTR-expressing cell types all along the length of the intestine [e.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	68	 the epithelial cells lining the intestinal crypt versus the poorly characterized CFTR-expressing cells of the intestinal villus (16,17)].
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	69	 The results of this in vivo transcription mapping study are broadly consistent with previously published data from immortalized cell lines in that the single transcription start sites utilized in adult lung (-69) and pancreas (-68) and one of the start sites identified in intestine (-69) are close to the major CFTR start site(s) mapped in the colonic epithelial adenocarcinoma cell lines T84, HT-29 and Caco-2 (12,13,15).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	70	 However, none of the multiple minor start sites observed in T84, HT-29 and Caco-2 cells appear to be used in CFTR-expressing cells in vivo.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	71	The observation that distinct CFTR transcription start sites are utilized in adult (-69) and foetal lungs (-132) is intriguing given the previously reported developmental regulation of CFTR expression in the lung (10,11,18).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	72	 CFTR mRNA levels are substantially higher in foetal lungs than in adult lungs, with CFTR expression declining dramatically after birth, although the precise age at which this down-regulation occurs is not known.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	73	 It is possible that a switch in transcription initiation from the -132 site to the -69 site correlates with a particular stage in lung development.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	74	 A correlation between the pattern of CFTR transcription start site usage and the level of CFTR mRNA expression previously has been reported in CFTR-expressing cell lines, suggesting that a mechanism of CFTR regulation operates at the level of start site selection (15).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	75	 These data suggest that a similar mechanism might operate during human lung development.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Identification of a novel exon of murine Cftr.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	77	Figure 1 shows that a major 5[prime] RACE product of 420 bp was amplified from mouse testis.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	78	 DNA sequencing revealed that this PCR product extended from Cftr exon 2 up to the splice junction with exon 1 and contained 161 bp of Cftr exon 1 and 154 bp of unknown sequence, which was named exon -1.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Comparison of the sequence of the major 5[prime] RACE product from testis with the upstream genomic sequence of murine Cftr (19) confirmed the existence of exon -1 as a distinct, untranslated exon and indicated that the major transcription start site for Cftr in mouse testis is at position -549 relative to the initiating methionine codon of the Cftr ORF (Fig.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	80	 An intron of 285 bp separates exon -1 and exon 1, with the sequences for both splice donor and splice acceptor sites obeying the invariant GT-AG rule (20) at the exon -1/exon 1 splice junction.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	81	 The position of the exon -1/exon 1 boundary in polyadenylated RNA from mouse testis was confirmed by performing an independent RT-PCR amplification on mouse testis first-strand cDNA primed with oligo(dT) (not shown).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Exon -1 expression is testis specific.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	83	The tissue specificity of exon -1 expression was investigated using a dual probe RNase protection assay which simultaneously detected Cftr exon -1 and an internal Cftr sequence (Cftr exons 10-12; base pairs 1580-1865) in samples of mouse tissue total RNA.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Cftr exon 10-12 expression was detected in all tissues examined with the exception of pancreas (Fig.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	85	 5), in agreement with previous observations that Cftr is expressed at extremely low levels in rodent pancreas (5,21).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Significant levels of exon -1 expression were observed only in the testis (Fig.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	87	 The amounts of each protected fragment were quantitated using a Molecular Dynamics phosphoimaging cassette and Imagequant software, by comparison with the relevant standard curve of known amounts of RNA sense strands (not shown).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Approximately 95% of the Cftr transcripts expressed in murine testis contain exon -1, whilst in the other mouse tissues examined  < 5% of Cftr transcripts contained exon -1.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Simultaneous detection of CFTR exons 10-12 and CFTR exon -1 in single samples of mouse tissue total RNA by dual probe RNase protection analysis.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Lane 1, ileum; lane 2, duodenum; lane 3, ovary/oviduct; lane 4, uterus; lane 5, testis; lane 6, pancreas; lane 7, adult lung; lane 8, 16 day foetal lung; lane 9, salivary gland.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Lane 10 represents the yeast RNA negative control.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	92	 The expected positions of the two protected fragments are indicated.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	93	Germ cell-specific expression of Cftr exon -1.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	94	Cftr exhibits a cell type-specific pattern of expression in murine testis, with levels of expression varying during the different stages of spermatogenesis (22).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Cftr is expressed first in pachytene spermatocytes, with expression being maintained as these cells undergo meiotic division, to produce round spermatids, and then declining as the round spermatids elongate (22).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	96	 In order to determine whether Cftr exon -1 shows the same cell type-specific pattern of expression, we examined the in vivo expression of Cftr exon -1 in mouse testis by mRNA in situ hybridization.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	97	 A series of consecutive sections of adult mouse testis were hybridized with probes specific for exon -1 (Fig.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	98	 6) and for an internal region of Cftr (data not shown).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Identical patterns of cell type-specific expression were observed with both probes, demonstrating that expression of the exon -1-containing Cftr transcript is regulated during stages of spermatogenesis, in agreement with our previous observations of Cftr expression in mouse testis (22).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Cell type-specific expression of Cftr mRNA in adult mouse testis examined by in situ hydridization.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	101	 A series of consecutive sections of adult mouse testis were hybridized with 35S-labelled CFTR -1 antisense and sense probes.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	102	 (A) Brightfield view of haemotoxylin and eosin-stained section of mouse testis hybridized with a 35S-labelled CFTR -1 antisense probe.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	103	 (B) Darkfield view of the same section.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	104	 (C) Hybridized with a 35S-labelled CFTR -1 sense probe.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	105	CFTR expression in human testis has been reported to be extremely low and not associated with any particular cell type or with any particular stage of spermatogenesis-strikingly different from the rodent expression pattern (23).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Nevertheless, the existence of a human equivalent of the testis-specific murine Cftr exon -1 was investigated by performing 5[prime] RACE PCR in order to identify the CFTR transcription start site utilized in adult human testis.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	107	 The 5[prime] RACE procedure was repeated a total of three times, but no CFTR-specific product bands could be amplified.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	108	 As a positive control, CFTR expression in human testis was confirmed by RT-PCR using an internal CFTR primer set (not shown).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	109	 It was concluded, therefore, that the level of CFTR expression in human testis is extremely low but detectable by RT-PCR, but that this low level expression is below the limit of detection by 5[prime] RACE due to the latter method's inherently lower sensitivity.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Thus, the position of the CFTR start site utilized in adult human testis remains unknown, and no conclusions can be drawn regarding the expression of a human equivalent of murine Cftr exon -1 in human testis.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	111	In this study, we have mapped the in vivo transcription start sites for human CFTR and its murine homologue Cftr.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Using a sensitive 5[prime] RACE technique, we were able to map CFTR start sites in a number of different mouse and human tissues.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	113	 These are the first in vivo CFTR transcription start sites to be mapped for any species.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	114	In the case of murine Cftr, the use of distinct, tissue-specific transcription start sites leads to the production of Cftr transcripts which differ in the length of their 5[prime]-untranslated regions (5[prime] UTRs).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	115	 The observation that distinct transcription start sites are used in different tissues suggests that the tissue-specific regulation of Cftr expression may, in part, operate at the level of transcription start site selection.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Analysis of the primary sequence of the 5[prime]-flanking region of murine Cftr provides some clues as to how tissue-specific start site selection might be achieved.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	117	 No sequence likely to correspond to a TATA box element could be found upstream of any of the in vivo transcription start sites identified for murine Cftr (Fig.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	118	 However, Table 4 illustrates that sequences surrounding three of the Cftr transcription start sites, the -82 site utilized in lung and the -60 and -19 sites utilized in duodenum, are similar to the consensus sequence for the mammalian initiator (Inr) element, PyPyA(+1)N(T/A)PyPy, that has been suggested to maintain the fidelity of transcription initiation in promoters devoid of TATA boxes (24).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	119	 It is likely, therefore, that an Inr-dependent mechanism is responsible for directing the formation of a transcription pre-initiation complex in these tissues.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Sequence context of murine Cftr transcription start sites.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	121	 In each case, the transcription start site (+1) is underlined Position of start site Sequence context Inr consensus PyPyA(+1)N(T/A)PyPy -549 AGAAGGA -82 GCATTGA -75 CCTGGTC -72 GGTCCTG -60 CCAGATG -19 TCATTGC.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	122	Tissue-specific variation in the position of the CFTR start site was also observed in human tissues.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Most notably, distinct start sites appear to be used in adult and in foetal lungs.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	124	 However, the exact position of the CFTR transcription start site relative to the translation initiation codon does not appear to be conserved between equivalent tissues of mice and humans, suggesting that the precise mechanisms responsible for correct start site selection are not conserved cross-species.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	125	 This is perhaps not surprising given the apparent lack of primary nucleic acid sequence homology between the mouse and human proximal promoter regions (19,25).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	126	The identification of a testis-specific, untranslated exon of murine Cftr (exon -1) implies that Cftr expression in this tissue is under the control of a testis-specific alternative promoter.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Murine Cftr falls into a group of genes demonstrating cell type-specific expression in the testis, with expression being regulated during spermatogenesis (22).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Other genes in this group include many whose protein products are thought to play a particular role in the complex process of spermatogenesis (reviewed in 26), and a potential role for the Cftr chloride channel during spermatogenesis has been suggested (22).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Genes such as Cftr that are expressed both post-meiotically in the testis and in other tissues often produce testis-specific transcripts, generated by the use of testis-specific promoters, altered polyadenylation and/or tissue-specific alternative exon splicing (26).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	130	 We have shown that the testis-specific Cftr transcript is generated through the use of an alternative promoter and alternative splicing in the 5[prime] UTR, to include exon -1 at the extreme 5[prime] end of the transcript.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	131	 The vast majority (95%) of Cftr transcripts in mouse testis contain this additional untranslated exon, implying an important role for exon -1 with regard to either the function of Cftr in testis or the regulation of Cftr expression in this tissue.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	132	 The latter alternative would appear to be more plausible as a number of genes expressed post-meiotically in rodent testis exhibit negative translational regulation mediated by the binding of regulatory proteins to specific 5[prime] UTR sequences (reviewed in 27).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	133	 One of the families of germ cell-specific proteins proposed to mediate translational regulation in the testis are the Y-box proteins (28).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Y-box proteins may function both as DNA-binding transcription factors, which bind to specific, cis-acting Y-box promoter elements, and as RNA-binding proteins, which mediate translational regulation via mRNA masking in vertebrate gametes (29).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	135	 In this context, it is interesting to note that a Y-box consensus sequence, previously suggested to act as a positive regulator of transcription in the murine Cftr promoter (14), is contained within exon -1 and thus will be present exclusively in the 5[prime] UTR of testis-specific Cftr transcripts.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	136	Another feature of the murine Cftr 5[prime]-flanking region suggests that translational regulation may be a more general mechanism controlling Cftr expression.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	137	 An additional AUG codon is present at position -58, upstream of the Cftr ORF (Fig.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	138	 This upstream AUG precedes a short upstream ORF (uORF) that, if recognized by the translation machinery, would produce a small peptide of five amino acids in length.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	139	 This uORF will be present in the 5[prime] UTR of Cftr transcripts initiating upstream of position -58, including the major Cftr transcripts expressed in lung, foetal lung, ileum, kidney, uterus and testis.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	140	 The upstream AUG occurs in a weak Kozak context, with neither the critical purine at position -3 nor the G at position +4 being present (30), whereas the AUG of the Cftr ORF occurs in a much stronger Kozak context (31).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	141	 The scanning model predicts that translation will usually initiate at the first AUG in a favourable Kozak context (30).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Nevertheless, interaction between the translation machinery and the upstream AUG may have the effect of reducing the translation efficiency of the Cftr ORF.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	143	 The presence of the short uORF would therefore be predicted to reduce the translation efficiency of the major Cftr transcripts expressed in lungs, ileum and testis but not those expressed in duodenum, as the uORF is absent from the 5[prime] UTR of the duodenum transcript initiating at position -19 and is too close to the m7G cap site to exert an effect in the transcript initiating at position -60 (31).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Thus, by the use of distinct transcription start sites, the expression of Cftr might also be modulated at the translational level.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	145	The identification of the major Cftr transcription start sites utilized in vivo is an essential prerequisite to understanding the function of the Cftr promoter.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	146	 It will now be possible to define the promoter elements, transcription factors and mechanisms directing the complex patterns of in vivo Cftr expression.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	147	 MATERIALS AND METHODS Sources of mouse tissues for total RNA preparation.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	148	All human RNA samples were purchased from Clontech.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Mouse tissues were pooled from six male and six female adult mice, all of strain MF1.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Foetal lung tissue was pooled from three 16-day-old foetuses removed from a single timed pregnant female.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Total RNA was isolated using a guanidinium thiocyanate/acid phenol-chloroform extraction method (32).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	152	5[prime] RACE was performed using an adaptation of the method of Frohman (33).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	153	 First-strand cDNA synthesis was performed on 2  microg of total RNA using 10 pmol of primer MC6R (Table 1) and 200 U of superscript II reverse transcriptase (BRL).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	154	 RNA template strands were digested with 2 U of RNase H (BRL), and first-strand cDNAs were purified using QIAquik PCR purification columns (QIAGEN) and homopolymer tailed using 0.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	155	2 mM dCTP and 20 U of terminal transferase (Promega).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	156	 cDNAs were again purified using QIAquik columns and then subjected to two rounds of hemi-nested PCR amplifications using primers MC5R and MC2.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	157	1R and a 5[prime] RACE anchor primer specific for the homopolymer tail (purchased from BRL), with 10 pmol of each primer and 2.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	158	5 U of AmpliTaq Gold polymerase (Perkin Elmer) per PCR reaction.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	159	 5[prime] RACE products were either sequenced directly or ligated into the vector pT7 blue and the recombinant plasmids sequenced.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Sequencing reactions were performed using an AmpliTaq Dye Terminator Cycle Sequencing Kit (Applied Biosystems) and analysed on an ABI prism 377 automated sequencer.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	161	Dual probe RNase protection assays were performed using the RPA II system from Ambion.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Two probes were used to detect different regions of a single Cftr mRNA: the first, CFTR 10-12, corresponded to an internal region of Cftr spanning exons 10-12 [base pairs 1580-1865 of the Cftr cDNA (19)] in the vector Bluescript KS (Stratagene); the second, CFTR -1, contained 150 bp of mouse Cftr exon -1 and 50 bp of RACE anchor primer sequence, amplified from the mouse testis major 5[prime] RACE product by PCR using anchor primer (Gibco-BRL) and the primer MC -1R (5[prime]-ACCGTGGCCAATCTGCGGGACTTAGAACCC), and cloned into Bluescript SK (Stratagene).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	163	 The Bluescript vectors contain opposing T3 and T7 promoters to allow the synthesis of both 32P-labelled antisense RNA probes and control unlabelled sense strand RNAs by in vitro transcription.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Samples (20  microg) of mouse tissue total RNA were hybridized overnight with equal, excess amounts (0.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	165	) of 32P-labelled, antisense CFTR -1 and CFTR 10-12 probes.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Following RNase digestion and precipitation, protected products were resolved on 6% denaturing polyacrylamide gels and visualized by exposure to Kodak X-omat AR film.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	167	In situ hybridization was performed essentially as described previously (17).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Probes specific for two regions of mouse Cftr were used for in situ localization of Cftr mRNA: the first, CFTR 10-13, corresponded to a fragment of Cftr exons 10-13 [bases 1580-2108 of the Cftr cDNA (19)] in the vector Bluescript KS; the second, CFTR -1 was the same as that used for RNase protection (above).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Both probes were cloned in Bluescript vectors containing opposing T3 and T7 promoters for the generation of [35S]UTP-labelled sense and antisense strand RNA probes by in vitro transcription.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Cryostat tissue sections (10  microm) were hybridized overnight with 35S-labelled single-stranded RNA probes in 50% formamide at 55-60 degrees C.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Sections were then digested with RNase A to remove excess probe and other single-stranded RNA, and washed at a stringency of 0.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Slides were dipped in Kodak NTB-2 emulsion, exposed for 2 weeks at 4 degrees C, developed and counterstained with haematoxylin and eosin.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Sections were photographed under brightfield and darkfield illumination using a Nikon Optiphot-2 microscope equipped with a Nikon UFX-DX automatic camera.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Multiple tissue sections were hybridized with either sense or antisense probes for each of the two regions of Cftr and, in all cases, results were seen to be consistent for each probe.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	175	Searches of the GenBank database to look for sequence homology were performed using FastA from the GCG program.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	176	 was supported by a Wellcome Trust Prize Studentship and A.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	177	 by a Beit Memorial Research Fellowship.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Additional support for this work came from the Cystic Fibrosis Research Trust, ICRF, EU, Henry Smith Foundation and the University of Oxford.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	179	 is a Howard Hughes International Research Scholar.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	180	 (eds), The Metabolic Basis of Inherited Disease.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	181	 (1989) Identification of the cystic fibrosis gene: chromosome walking and jumping.

0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	187	 (1992) The multidrug resistance and cystic fibrosis genes have complementary patterns of epithelial expression.

0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	200	 (1982) A catalogue of splice junction sequences.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	201	 (1992) Expression and chromosomal localisation of the murine cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	202	 (1993) CFTR expression is regulated during both the cycle of the seminiferous epithelium and the oestrus cycle of rodents.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	203	 (1994) Differential cellular expression of cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator in human reproductive tissues.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	204	 (1994) DNA sequence requirements for transcriptional initiator activity in mammalian cells.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	205	 (1997) Phylogenetic analysis of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene in mammalian species argues for the development of a rabbit model for cystic fibrosis.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	206	 (1990) Post-meiotic gene expression.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	207	 (1995) Translational control in spermatogenesis.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	208	 (1994) Structural and functional properties of the evolutionarily ancient Y-box family of nucleic acid binding proteins.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	209	 (1993) A mouse Y-box protein, MSY1, is associated with paternal mRNA in spermatocytes.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	210	 (1991) An analysis of vertebrate mRNA sequences: intimations of translational control.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	211	 (1991) Structural features in eukaryotic mRNAs that modulate the initiation of translation.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	212	 (1987) Single-step method of RNA isolation by guanidinium thiocyanate-phenol-chloroform extraction.

0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	0	Temporal regulation of CFTR expression during ovine lung development: implications for CF gene therapy Fiona C.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Broackes-Carter, Nathalie Mouchel, Deborah Gill1, Stephen Hyde1, John Bassett2 and Ann Harris+.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	2	Paediatric Molecular Genetics, Institute of Molecular Medicine, Oxford University, John Radcliffe Hospital, Oxford OX3 9DS, UK, 1Nuffield Department of Clinical Laboratory Sciences, Oxford University, John Radcliffe Hospital, Oxford OX3 9DU, UK and 2Growth and Development Unit, Field Laboratory, Oxford University, Oxford OX2 8QJ, UK.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	3	Received September 10, 2001; Revised and Accepted November 13, 2001.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	4	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   The cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein is a small conductance chloride ion channel that may interact directly with other channels including the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	5	 CFTR is known to be more abundant in the airway epithelium during the second trimester of human development than after birth.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	6	 This could be a consequence of the change in function of the respiratory epithelium from chloride secretion to sodium absorption near term.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Alternatively it might reflect an additional role for CFTR in the developing airway epithelium.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Though the lung epithelia of CF fetuses and infants rarely show gross histological abnormalities, there is often evidence of inflammation.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Our aim was to establish whether CFTR expression levels correlated with specific developmental stages or differentiated functions in the ovine fetal lung.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	10	 We evaluated CFTR expression using a quantitative assay of mRNA at 14 time points through gestation and showed highest levels at the start of the second trimester followed by a gradual decline through to term.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	11	 In contrast, ENaC expression increased from the start of the third trimester.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	12	 These results support a role for CFTR in differentiation of the respiratory epithelium and suggest that its expression levels are not merely reflecting major changes in the sodium/chloride bulk flow close to term.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	13	 These observations may have significant implications for the likely success of CF gene therapy in the postnatal lung.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	14	   INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   The cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene encodes a small conductance cAMP-activated chloride ion channel (1).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	15	 CFTR protein is located primarily in the apical membranes of epithelial cells within the respiratory and digestive systems.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	16	 About 1000 disease-associated mutations have been defined in the CFTR gene (www.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	17	ca) and the majority are associated with characteristic airway disease, pancreatic insufficiency, male infertility and elevated levels of sodium chloride in sweat.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	18	 It is difficult to explain how mutations in a single small-conductance epithelial chloride channel cause the pleiotropic manifestations of this disease, though a complex picture is now emerging in which CFTR interacts directly or indirectly with additional proteins.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	19	 CFTR is known to regulate other ion channels including the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) (2) and the volume-activated chloride channel (3).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	20	 CFTR may also be involved in other cellular processes, for example, membrane recycling (4,5) and apoptosis (6,7).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	21	Relatively little attention has been given to progression of CF disease in utero though this affects postnatal pathology and may be of relevance to the likely success of gene therapy.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	22	 The initial pathology of CF is exhibited in the pancreas in the early second trimester of gestation, when proteinaceous material starts to obstruct the ductal tree (8,9).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	23	 This is perhaps not surprising since CFTR is expressed in epithelia from before the start of the second trimester of human development and CFTR expression levels are high in the mid-trimester pancreas (10 to 12).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	24	 In most tissues the CFTR expression levels show little fluctuation between the second trimester of gestation and postnatal life.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	25	 However, CFTR appears to be developmentally regulated in both human and sheep lung epithelium (11 to 13) where high expression levels during fetal life are in contrast to much lower abundance of CFTR mRNA by birth, and into adulthood.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	26	 The significance of this down-regulation of CFTR expression is the major focus of this work.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	27	Since it is not feasible to investigate human lung development in utero, we have used the sheep to provide a useful model of human lung development (14).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	28	 The sheep lung is anatomically more similar to human than that of the mouse, having submucosal glands throughout the cartilagenous airway.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	29	 The expression pattern of CFTR in sheep is similar to humans, both temporally and spatially and we have shown that the ovine CFTR gene sequence shows close homology to the human gene (14,15).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Expression of CFTR during human and sheep lung development has so far been assessed primarily by means of in situ hybridization (11,12), northern blotting (10,13) and reverse transcriptase to polymerase chain reaction (RT to PCR) (10,13).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	31	 CFTR expression levels are high in the lung during the second trimester of gestation and low postnatally.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	32	 To date, developmental expression of CFTR has only been examined at a limited number of time points and data have not been accurately quantitative.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Our aim was to evaluate CFTR expression at specific time points throughout gestation using a real-time quantitative RT to PCR assay provided by TaqMan technology.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	34	 We have generated a developmental profile of CFTR mRNA in sheep with particular attention to the down-regulation of CFTR in the respiratory system.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	35	 This profile has identified key gestational ages where CFTR expression is maximal and hence when targeting of potential in utero therapies might be of most benefit.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	36	   RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   Semi-quantitative RT to PCR of CFTR In preliminary experiments CFTR expression during ovine gestation was evaluated by semi-quantitative RT to PCR.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Primers C2R and C2L (16) that span exon 13 of the CFTR cDNA were used to reverse transcribe and amplify CFTR from RNA samples extracted from ovine tissues at 52, 66, 83, 94, 108, 129 and 143 days gestation, 147 (term) days and 2 days post-term.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Subunit c of the ovine ATP synthase (17) was used as a reference standard for these RT to PCR reactions.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	39	 The developmental profile of CFTR mRNA in lung tissue (Fig.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	40	 1) shows a decline between 83 days of gestation (mid-trimester) and term.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Since semi-quantitative RT to PCR has limited power in providing accurate data on relative expression levels of a gene, we then used real-time (TaqMan) RT to PCR to quantify the precise developmental expression of ovine CFTR in the lung.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	42	View larger version (41K):    Figure 1.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Developmental expression of CFTR in ovine airway.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Ovine lung samples from 52, 66, 83, 94, 108, 129 and 143 days gestation (G), 147 days (term) (T) and 2 days post-term (PT).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Semi-quantitative RT to PCR using CFTR primers C2R and C2L yielding a 792 bp fragment and ovine ATP synthase primers F1 and R1 producing a 530 bp fragment.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Fragments were separated on a 1.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	47	5% agarose gel and stained with ethidium bromide.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	48	  Validation of the real-time CFTR RT to PCR assay target The region of the ovine CFTR gene chosen for generating the TaqMan amplifying primers and probe covered the boundary between exons 6a and 6b.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Since the CFTR gene is known to exhibit a range of alternatively spliced forms in a number of species (18) it was necessary to confirm that no aberrant transcripts lacking parts of exons 6a and 6b were produced from the ovine gene.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Conventional RT to PCR was carried out using primers spanning exons 4 to 7 and no alternative transcripts lacking exons 6a or 6b were detected in RNA from lung at mid-gestation or birth, pancreas, small intestine, salivary gland and colon at 2 days after birth (data not shown).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	51	 These results suggested that the real-time TaqMan RT to PCR assay targeted to the exon 6a/6b boundary, would accurately reflect total CFTR mRNA transcription.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	52	Real-time RT to PCR for CFTR mRNA in ovine fetal tissues The real-time RT to PCR assay for ovine CFTR mRNA was optimized and its reproducibility established.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Values obtained from reactions in which template was omitted, consistently fell below the range of the standard curve and were  < 0.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Standard curves were highly reproducible for the ovine CFTR and ribosomal RNA assays (R2 = 0.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	55	99) and genomic contribution to the RT to PCR reactions was  < 0.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	56	Two series of experiments were performed: the first evaluated CFTR expression in ovine lung tissues throughout the developmental time course; the second evaluated CFTR expression in eight ovine tissues at 83 and 108 days of gestation and at 2 days post-term.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	57	Developmental expression of ovine CFTR in the lung The developmental profile of CFTR expression in the lung showed a gradual fall in mRNA levels though the 147 days of gestation (Fig.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Values at 52 days of gestation, the end of the first trimester, were 75-fold higher than those at birth.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	59	 By 66 days, CFTR mRNA levels were reduced 4.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	60	5-fold before increasing between 74 and 80 days.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	61	 After levels peaked at 80 days of gestation, there was a gradual decline toward birth with negligible levels of expression by 4 days before term (143 days) and at birth.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Two days after parturition, levels of CFTR mRNA increased slightly and this expression level was maintained at 2 weeks of age and in adult sheep tissue.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Experiments were performed three times with samples analysed in triplicate.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	64	 To evaluate the variation in CFTR expression levels in individuals at specific time points, samples were analysed from a sib pair at 74 days gestation and a half-sib pair at 2 days after birth.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	65	 In both cases, CFTR expression levels were not significantly different from each other (74 days, P = 0.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	66	86; two-tailed Student s t-test).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	67	View larger version (15K):    Figure 2.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Developmental expression of CFTR in ovine airway.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Quantitative RT to PCR using an ABI Prism 7700 sequence detection system.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Ovine lung samples were from 52, 66, 74, 80, 83, 90, 94, 108, 129 and 143 days gestation (G), 147 days (term) (T) and 2 and 14 days post-term (PT) and adult (A).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Mean values of triplicate assays are expressed as a percentage of CFTR mRNA in lung at 83 days.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Data are derived from CT values (threshold cycle at which a statistically significant increase in emission is first detected) produced by the ABI Prism 7700 sequence detection system for a CFTR assay normalized to 18S ribosomal RNA.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Error bars represent SD values.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	74	  Developmental expression of ovine CFTR in other organs The developmental expression of ovine CFTR in pancreas, small intestine, colon, trachea, salivary gland, kidney and muscle was evaluated at three different time points (83 and 108 days of gestation and 2 days post-term) (Fig.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Muscle provided a negative control and as expected had negligible amounts of CFTR mRNA expression for all three time points in these experiments.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Experiments were performed three times with samples analysed in triplicate.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	77	View larger version (25K):    Figure 3.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Developmental expression of CFTR in ovine tissues.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Quantitative RT to PCR using an ABI Prism 7700 sequence detection system.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Ovine tissue samples, pancreas, small intestine, colon, lung, trachea, salivary gland, kidney and muscle were from 83 and 108 days gestation (G) and 2 days post-term (PT).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Mean values of triplicate assays are expressed as a percentage of CFTR mRNA in lung at 83 days.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Data are derived from CT values produced by the ABI Prism 7700 sequence detection system for a CFTR assay normalized to 18S ribosomal RNA.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Error bars represent SD values.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	84	  These are the first quantitative data that enable comparison of CFTR expression levels between tissues of the one species.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	85	 They confirm the observation that the levels of CFTR mRNA in the pancreas and digestive system are significantly higher (at least 5-fold) than in the lung epithelium even at the time of maximal expression in the respiratory system.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	86	 The observation of greater levels of CFTR mRNA in the colon than in the small intestine is probably a unique feature of the sheep and its digestive system as there are data to show the opposite distribution in the human intestine (11).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Glandular organs such as pancreas, lung and salivary gland had a similar pattern of expression characterized by higher expression early in gestation followed by a decline towards birth with levels maintained 2 days post-term.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	88	 CFTR mRNA levels were higher in both pancreas and salivary gland than in lung.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	89	 In trachea CFTR mRNA levels were comparable to values in lung during gestation but rose at 2 days post-term.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Small intestine expressed lower levels of CFTR mRNA before birth in comparison to 2 days after birth.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Colon initially expressed very high amounts of CFTR mRNA, which then decreased slightly at mid-gestation before rising again to a high level after birth.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	92	 CFTR mRNA expression in the ovine kidney is very low and declines between 83 and 2 days post-term.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	93	Developmental expression of ovine ENaC in the lung The CFTR and ENaC ion channels are thought to interact directly (2), hence it was pertinent to evaluate also the developmental expression of ENaC in the ovine lung.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	94	 These assays were performed using conventional RT to PCR rather than real-time TaqMan RT to PCR due to lack of full sequence information for ovine ENaC and reported alternative splicing of this gene (19).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	95	 In marked contrast to CFTR, expression of the subunit of ENaC is very low in the ovine lung at 52 days of gestation, but gradually rises through 108, 129, 143 and 147 (term) days of gestation to much higher levels in 2 days post-term and adult lung (Fig.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Again, subunit c of the ATP synthase was used as a reference standard (17) for these semi-quantitative RT to PCR reactions.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	97	View larger version (36K):    Figure 4.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Developmental expression of ENaC in ovine airway.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Ovine lung samples from 52, 66, 83, 94, 108, 129 and 143 days gestation (G), 147 days (term) (T), 2 and 14 days post-term (PT) and adult.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Semi-quantitative RT to PCR using ENaC primers ENaF and ENaR yielding a 373 bp fragment and ovine ATP synthase primers F1 and R1 producing a 530 bp fragment.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Fragments were separated on a 1.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	102	5% agarose gel and stained with ethidium bromide.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	103	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   We have shown using semi-quantitative and quantitative RT to PCR that the high levels of CFTR expression seen in the second trimester ovine fetal lung decrease gradually through to term rather than declining suddenly near parturition.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	104	 The detection of significant CFTR expression during lung development with low levels after birth confirms previous observations in humans and sheep (11 to 13).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	105	 (13) showed, by RT to PCR and northern blots, that CFTR mRNA expression in ovine fetal lung was far higher than after birth and into adulthood, and that the high levels seen at 70 days of ovine gestation were comparable to CFTR mRNA in mid-trimester human fetuses.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	106	However, the previous data did not evaluate CFTR expression throughout gestation.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	107	 The gradual decline in CFTR that we observed during ovine fetal lung development could be accounted for by at least two explanations.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Either, the percentage of cells that express CFTR within the lung epithelium decrease with time or the levels of expression within the same cell type gradually decreases.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	109	 On the basis of previous data we would expect the former explanation to be correct.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	110	 In postnatal human lung epithelium significant CFTR expression is limited to specific cells within the serous portion of submucosal glands and individual cells in the airway surface epithelium (20,21).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	111	 This is in contrast to the apparent expression of CFTR mRNA in the majority of cells in the fetal lung epithelium (11).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Furthermore, in human trachea, CFTR expression was seen to be intermediate and diffuse during the first trimester by in situ hybridization (11).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	113	 In the second trimester, CFTR mRNA expression was reduced and limited to a subset of cells in the epithelia of the trachea and by the third trimester, only individual cells expressed CFTR but at very high levels (12).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	114	High levels of CFTR mRNA expression have been observed by in situ hybridization in pancreas, small intestine and colon from an early gestational age in humans (11).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	115	 These expression levels remain constant throughout gestation in contrast to lung expression patterns.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	116	 The temporal and spatial expression of CFTR mRNA in ovine small intestine, pancreas, colon, salivary gland and kidney and muscle seen in our experiments, closely parallel the human gene (13).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	117	 However, the quantitative assays show that in contrast to the human CFTR gene, which is expressed at a higher level in the crypts of the small intestine than in the colon, ovine CFTR mRNA is most abundant in the colonic epithelium.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	118	 This may reflect functional differences in the ruminant digestive system.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	119	 It is of interest that the decline of CFTR expression observed in ovine fetal lung between 83 days gestation and 2 days after birth is also seen in pancreas and salivary gland.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	120	 CFTR may have a significant role in the development and differentiation of other glandular tissues.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	121	The physiological implications of the gradual decline in lung CFTR expression levels during gestation warrant further discussion.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	122	 The fetal lung is filled with a high chloride, low pH fluid that is distinct from amniotic fluid.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Chloride is actively secreted from the lung epithelium into the lung lumen during development and as a chloride ion channel, CFTR protein could contribute to this process.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	124	 However, chloride conductances other than CFTR are likely to be more important in fetal lung fluid secretion since CF is not associated with hypoplastic lungs at birth.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Furthermore, the profile of CFTR expression during gestation does not correspond to changes in lung liquid secretion (22,23).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	126	Postnatally, the major ion flows across the airway epithelium are uptake of sodium.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Lung liquid begins to be reabsorbed by ovine lung epithelium at 140 days of gestation.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Sodium reabsorption is achieved primarily by sodium channels located on the apical surface of the lung epithelium, the main one being the ENaC (24).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Recent data have shown that ENaC is inhibited by CFTR, which probably interacts directly with it (2,25,26).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	130	 The gradual decline in CFTR mRNA levels and protein would be compatible with enabling ENaC activity.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Furthermore, we have shown that the abundance of ENaC transcripts is inversely proportional to the levels of CFTR mRNA in the developing ovine lung after the second trimester, hence the expression of the genes encoding these two ion channels may be also coordinately regulated.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	132	An additional possibility is that CFTR expression in the fetal lung epithelium has an important, as yet undefined functional role in normal lung development.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Though at birth lung pathology is not usually evident in CF, absence of functional CFTR protein in the developing lung has been reported to produce a pro-inflammatory state (27).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Increased levels of interleukin-8 were observed in the airway surface fluid of human CF fetal tracheal grafts implanted into severe combined immunodeficient (SCID) mice.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Though this apparent pro-inflammatory state of the epithelia did not result directly in histological abnormalities, challenge with Pseudomonas aeruginosa provoked an exaggerated immune response resulting in sloughing of epithelial cells and increased leukocyte activity, thereby increasing likelihood of further bacterial colonization (27).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	136	The high levels of CFTR expression early in gestation may correspond to an important function of CFTR protein unique to this developmental stage.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	137	 The periods of high and low CFTR expression that we have defined, correspond to distinct developmental phases in the sheep lung.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Relatively high levels of CFTR mRNA expression are observed during the pseudoglandular phase (between 40 and 80 days of sheep gestation) when the bronchial tree and acini form.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	139	 During the developmental progression to the canalicular phase (80 to 120 days of gestation) when differentiation into type I and II epithelial cells occurs, CFTR mRNA levels begin to decline, and remain low until birth.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	140	 (28) have shown that overexpression of CFTR in the lungs of wild-type mice, at 15 to 16 days (corresponding to the late pseudoglandular and early canalicular developmental stages), advanced epithelial cell proliferation and differentiation.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Furthermore, the same investigators suggested that transient expression of CFTR in CF mice following intramniotic injection of adeno-CFTR cDNA at 15 to 16 days of mouse gestation, corrected the lethal intestinal disease (29).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	142	 The expression profile of CFTR in the developing sheep lung is consistent with data from the mouse that suggest a crucial role for CFTR in lung epithelial maturation.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	143	 These observations may have important implications for current attempts to treat CF airway disease by postnatal gene therapy.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	144	   MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   Ovine tissue collection An accurately timed sheep-breeding programme was established.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Sheep breeds used were a cross between (ram) Poll Dorset and (ewes) Suffolk and Mule cross.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Ewes were killed by anaesthetic overdose.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Tissue was collected from fetuses and lambs at time points 52, 66, 74, 80, 83, 90, 94, 108, 129, 143 days of gestation, at term (147 days) and at 2 days and 2 weeks after birth.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	148	 For most time points only one ewe was killed, however, at 74 days the ewe was carrying more than one fetus which were evaluated separately and at 2 days post-term two ewes were sacrificed.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Tissues were snap-frozen in liquid nitrogen in cryotubes (Nunc) and stored in liquid nitrogen.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	150	Extraction of RNA from ovine tissues Tissue was homogenized in glass homogenizers and RNA was prepared by guanidinium thiocyanate extraction (30).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Following ethanol precipitation samples were stored at  to 20 degrees C.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	152	 The RNA pellet was resuspended in nuclease-free water and OD260 determined.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Volumes were adjusted to a concentration of 100 to 250 ng/ microl before aliquoting and storage at  to 20 degrees C.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	154	RT to PCR for ovine CFTR and ENac RT to PCRs were carried out as previously described by Chalkley and Harris (16) across the region encompassing exons 4 (4S3R, 5'-GGAATGCAGATGAGAATAGC-3') to 7 (A1L, 5'-GCTCCAAGAGAGTCATACCA-3') to ascertain whether alternative splicing of exons 6a and or 6b occurred.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	155	 For semi-quantitative RT to PCR, CFTR cDNA synthesis was primed with 3' primer (C2L) 5'-TCTTCACTTATTTCCAAGCC-3'.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	156	 cDNA was generated using Superscript (Life Technologies) at 42 degrees C for 1 h, PCR was then performed with the 5' primer C2R (16) 5'-AGCAGTATACAAAGATGCTG-3' and C2L (94 degrees C for 5 min, then 30 cycles of 94 degrees C for 1 min, 60 degrees C for 1 min, 72 degrees C for 1 min followed by a final cycle of extension at 72 degrees C for 5 min).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Primer concentrations were 10 ng/ microl.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Subunit c of sheep mitochondrial ATP synthase was coamplified as a control for total RNA using primers F1 and R1 at concentrations of 0.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	159	 For semi-quantitative RT to PCR of ovine ENaC reactions were carried out as described for CFTR but using primers for the subunit of ENaC subunit.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	160	 The 5' primer, 5'-CTGCTACACTTTCAACGACA-3', and the 3' primer, 5'-CTCCTTGATCATGCTCTCCT-3', were both used at 5 ng/ microl, and primers for ovine ATP synthase were used at 0.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	161	5 ng/ microl (annealing temperature of the PCR was 65 degrees C and extension time was 5 min).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	162	Real-time quantitative RT to PCR (TaqMan) using the ABI Prism 7700 sequence detection system (Applied Biosystems) Primer and probe sequences were designed using the ovine CFTR cDNA sequence (GenBank accession no.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	163	 U20418) and ABI PrimerExpress 1.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	164	 The ovine CFTR 5' primer was located in exon 6a, 5'-AAGCCGGGTTAGGGAAAATG-3'.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	165	 The 3' primer was located in exon 6b, 5'-TGCCTTAACTGATTGGATATTTTCAA-3'; the ovine CFTR TaqMan probe was 5'-CATTGATCTTTCCAGCTCTCTGATCTCTGTACTTCAT-3' and contained reporter dye FAM at the 5' end and quencher dye TAMRA at the 3' end.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	166	 18S rRNA primer and probes (5' primer, 5'-CGGCTACCACATCCAAGGAA-3'; 3' primer, 5'-GCTGGAATTACCGCGGCT-3'; and 5' VIC, 3' TAMRA modified probe 5'-TGCTGGCACCAGACTTGCCCTC-3') were supplied by Applied Biosystems.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	167	A one-step RT to PCR approach was adopted for quantitative analysis.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Independent assays were performed on each experimental sample to determine levels of both CFTR mRNA and 18S rRNA.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Variations in RNA loading between samples were controlled by normalizing levels of CFTR mRNA to levels of 18S rRNA.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	170	 CFTR RT to PCR assays (25  microl final volume) were performed using the TaqMan Gold RT to PCR Kit (Applied Biosystems) and contained 1x Buffer A, 7.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	171	3 mM each of dATP, dCTP, dGTP and 0.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	172	2 U/ microl RNase Inhibitor, 300 nM each of 5' and 3' primers and 100 nM probe, and included 5  microl of experimental total RNA template.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	173	 18S rRNA assays were identical in composition, except that reactions contained 5.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Experimental total RNA samples were diluted to 10 ng/ microl for the CFTR assays and to 0.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	175	01 ng/ microl for the 18S rRNA assays.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Reactions were carried out in MicroAmp Optical 96-well plates covered with MicroAmp Optical caps (Applied Biosystems).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	177	 The TaqMan RT conditions were 48 degrees C for 30 min followed by AmpliTaq Gold activation at 95 degrees C for 10 min and 40 PCR cycles of 95 degrees C for 15 s and 60 degrees C for 1 min.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	178	Data were analysed using ABI Sequence Detector software version 1.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Relative standard curves for CFTR and 18S rRNA levels were generated from seven, sequential, 5-fold dilutions of a common arbitrary sample of lung RNA at 83 days gestation.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	180	 The determined arbitrary values for CFTR were divided by the appropriate 18S rRNA value to give an expression ratio.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	181	 This ratio was then expressed as a percentage of one chosen sample (the  calibrator ).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	182	 For all experiments, total RNA at 83 days of gestation was used as the calibrator sample.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Standards and experimental samples were assayed three times with each sample analysed in triplicate in each experiment.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Reaction controls were performed which omitted RT and/or template RNA.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Standard curves were fitted by linear regression and goodness of fit was reported as the coefficient of determination (R2).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	186	   ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS   We thank Cliff Hanson and Frances Knight, David Smith, Sytse Henstra, Debbie Harrison, Andrew Rose and Ian Pringle for assistance.
