0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	0	Stress-associated Endoplasmic Reticulum Protein 1 (SERP1)/Ribosome-associated Membrane Protein 4 (RAMP4) Stabilizes Membrane Proteins during Stress and Facilitates Subsequent Glycosylation Atsushi Yamaguchia,c, Osamu Horib,c, David M.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Sternd, Enno Hartmanne, Satoshi Ogawab,c, and Masaya Tohyamaa,c a Department of Anatomy and Neuroscience, Graduate School of Medicine, Osaka University, Suita City, Osaka 565-0871, Japan b Department of Anatomy III, Kanazawa University, School of Medicine, Kanazawa City, Ishikawa 290-8640, Japan c Core Research for Evolutional Science and Technology, Japan Science and Technology, Tokyo 105, Japan d Department of Surgery, Department of Physiology and Cellular Biophysics, College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, New York, New York 10032 e Abteilung Biochemie II, Zentrum Biochemie und Moleculare Zellbiologie, Georg-August-Universitat, 37073 Gottingen, Germany.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	2	Correspondence to: Osamu Hori, Department of Anatomy III, Kanazawa University, Medical School, 13-1 Takara-Machi, Kanazawa City, Ishikawa 290-8640, Japan.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Tel:81-76-265-2162 Fax:81-76-234-4222 E-mail:osamuh{at}nanat.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	4	  Abstract Top Abstract Introduction Materials and Methods Results Discussion Acknowledgements References.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	5	Application of differential display to cultured rat astrocytes subjected to hypoxia allowed cloning of a novel cDNA, termed stress-associated endoplasmic reticulum protein 1 (SERP1).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Expression of SERP1 was enhanced in vitro by hypoxia and/or reoxygenation or other forms of stress, causing accumulation of unfolded proteins in endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress, and in vivo by middle cerebral artery occlusion in rats.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	7	 The SERP1 cDNA encodes a 66 to amino acid polypeptide which was found to be identical to ribosome-associated membrane protein 4 (RAMP4) and bearing 29% identity to yeast suppressor of SecY 6 protein (YSY6p), suggesting participation in pathways controlling membrane protein biogenesis at ER.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	8	 In cultured 293 cells subjected to ER stress, overexpression of SERP1/RAMP4 suppressed aggregation and/or degradation of newly synthesized integral membrane proteins, and subsequently, facilitated their glycosylation when the stress was removed.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	9	 SERP1/RAMP4 interacted with Sec61 and Sec61ss, which are subunits of translocon, and a molecular chaperon calnexin.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Furthermore, Sec61 and Sec61ss, but not SERP1/RAMP4, were found to associate with newly synthesized integral membrane proteins under stress.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	11	 These results suggest that stabilization of membrane proteins in response to stress involves the concerted action of a rescue unit in the ER membrane comprised of SERP1/RAMP4, other components of translocon, and molecular chaperons in ER.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	12	Key Words: hypoxia, endoplasmic reticulum stress, translocon, aggregation/degradation, refolding.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	13	  Introduction Top Abstract Introduction Materials and Methods Results Discussion Acknowledgements References.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	14	ISCHEMIC stress, due to hypoxemia alone or hypoxemia followed by reperfusion, is one of the most relevant environmental challenges, as it accompanies a spectrum of disorders associated with vascular dysfunction and aging.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The central nervous system typifies complexities of the cellular response to ischemia.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	16	 During ischemia itself, neuronal function is compromised, often resulting in loss of cell viability, due at least in part to the extracellular accumulation of excitatory amino acids and disordered calcium homeostasis (Choi 1995 ; Rothman and Olney 1995 ).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Subsequent reperfusion exacerbates injury through the formation of reactive oxygen species, which attack membranous and proteinaceous cellular constituents, further compromising their functions (McCord 1987 ; Solenski et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The cellular response to such ischemia occurs on many levels, including modulation of gene expression.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	19	 In this context, >80 different mRNAs have been identified in ischemic brain (for review see Koistinaho and Hokfelt 1997 ), and these encode proximal and distal regulators of the cellular stress response, immediate-early gene products, apoptosis-associated proteins, stress proteins, cytokines, and growth factors.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Although some of these undoubtedly contribute to pathways underlying neuronal death, others most probably represent adaptive responses promoting cellular survival in response to stress.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	21	In contrast to the extraordinary vulnerability of neurons to ischemic stress, astrocytes have a unique ability to tolerate and even proliferate under such conditions, assigning them a central role in the immediate cellular response and later events associated with tissue remodelling (Hertz 1982 ).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	22	 The potential of astrocytes to orchestrate events in the central nervous system triggered by ischemic stress has led us to analyze their response to hypoxia (H)1 and hypoxia followed by reoxygenation (R), using brain-derived rat astrocytes in order to simulate ischemia and ischemia/reperfusion, respectively (Hori et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	23	 We have found that astrocytes subjected to these environmental perturbations display upregulation of stress proteins (glucose-regulated protein [GRP] 78, GRP94, heat shock protein [HSP] 72, and heme oxygenase, type 1), and release the neurotrophic cytokine IL-6 (Maeda et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Further dissection of differential gene expression in astrocytes exposed to H/R allowed cloning of three novel cDNAs encoding: (a) a novel stress protein, oxygen-regulated protein (ORP) 150; (b) the rat homologue of the Drosophila splicing factor Tra2 (RA301); and (c) a novel vesicle transporter (RA410) (Matsuo et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	25	To further probe mechanisms through which astrocytes participate in the response to ischemic stress, we have cloned a novel stress-associated ER protein, termed SERP1, by differential display applied to primary cultures of astrocytes exposed to H.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Compared with homeostatic conditions, SERP1 expression is upregulated both in vivo and in vitro in response to H and R (including induction of brain ischemia), as well as under conditions associated with accumulation of unfolded proteins in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER stress).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	27	 SERP1 was found to be identical to ribosome-associated membrane protein 4 (RAMP4) and bearing ~30% homology to yeast suppressor of SecY 6 protein (YSY6p), suggesting participation in pathways controlling biogenesis of secretory and membrane proteins at the ER.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	28	 In cultured 293 cells subjected to ER stress, overexpression of SERP1/RAMP4 suppressed aggregation and/or degradation of integral membrane proteins under stress and facilitates glycosylation after the stress.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	29	 SERP1/RAMP4 interacted directly with Sec61 and Sec61ss, which are subunits of the translocon (Sec61 complex; Gorlich et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	30	 1992 ; Gorlich and Rapoport 1993 ), and calnexin, a membrane protein and a molecular chaperon in ER that associates with folding intermediates of glycoprotein (Ou et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Immunoprecipitation did demonstrate a binding of newly synthesized integral membrane proteins to Sec61 and Sec61ss but not to SERP1/RAMP4.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	32	 These results suggest that the stabilization of membrane proteins in response to stress involves the concerted action of a rescue unit in the ER membrane that appears to be comprised of SERP1/RAMP4, as well as other components of translocon, and molecular chaperons in ER.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	33	  Materials and Methods Top Abstract Introduction Materials and Methods Results Discussion Acknowledgements References.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	34	Cell Culture and Conditions for H/R and Other Stresses Astrocytes were isolated from the cerebral cortex of E18 rat embryos using a minor modification of previously described methods (McCarthy and de Vellis 1980 ).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	35	 In brief, cerebral hemispheres were obtained from E18 brains and the meninges were carefully removed.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Brain tissue was digested with papain (Worthington Biochemical Corp.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	37	) at 37 degrees C for 15 min and plated in 175-cm2 culture flasks (two brains/flask).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Cells were grown in MEM with 10% FCS for 10 d and agitated strongly on a shaking platform to separate astrocytes from microglia and oligodendroglia.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Cells were then replated into 150-mm diam dishes and grown for an additional 7 d.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Cultures used for experiments were comprised of >95% astrocytes, based on the morphological (fibroblast-like appearance with the formation of a cobblestone cell layer) and immunohistochemical (detection of glial fibrillary acidic protein [GFAP] with anti-GFAP antibody; Sigma Chemical Co.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	41	 When cells achieved confluence, the medium was replaced with serum-free MEM and cultures were subjected to H for the indicated times (up to 22 h) using an incubator equipped with an H chamber (Coy Laboratory Products) as described (Ogawa et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Using this chamber, the ambient oxygen tension in culture medium bathing the cells was ~8 to 10 Torr (Ogawa et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	43	 In some experiments, cells were returned to the ambient atmosphere after H and incubated for 4 h (R).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	44	 In other experiments, cells were maintained in normoxia and exposed to either calcium ionophore A23187 (1  microM for 8 h) (Sigma Chemical Co.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	45	), tunicamycin (1  microg/ml for 8 h) (Sigma Chemical Co.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	46	), or hydrogen peroxide (80  microM for 4 h) (Wako Chemicals).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Alternatively, cultures were subjected to heat shock at 42 degrees C for 2 h and then returned to 37 degrees C and incubated for an additional 2 h.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	48	293 cells and BHK cells were cultured in DMEM and transfected with the indicated expression vectors as described below.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	49	Differential Display Total RNA was extracted from cultured astrocytes subjected to normoxia or H for 20 h using Qiagen RNeasy kit, and differential display was performed as described (Liang and Pardee 1992 ).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	50	 In brief, RT-PCR with avian myeloblastosis virus reverse transcriptase (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) and ~300 random primers (12 to 21 oligonucleotides) were used to prepare cDNAs.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	51	 PCR products were separated by acrylamide gel (6%) electrophoresis, and cDNA bands of interests were cut out from the gel.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	52	 After cloning the cDNAs into pGEM-T vector (Promega), DNA sequencing was performed using a DNA sequencer (model 377; Applied Biosystems).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Differential expression of candidate genes in H versus normoxia was confirmed by Northern blotting using 32P-radiolabeled cDNAs as probes.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	54	Cloning of Rat and Human SERP1/RAMP4 cDNAs One of the cDNA fragments obtained by differential display, termed T41, was used to screen an adult cDNA library (lambda ZapII cDNA library; Stratagene).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	55	3 kb was obtained spanning the entire open reading frame (ORF) and polyadenylation signal, and both strands were sequenced.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Sequence searches and comparisons were carried out using several databases, including the National Center for Biotechnology Information, FASTA and BLAST molecular analysis systems, and EMBL/ GenBank/DDBJ.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	57	 The human SERP1/RAMP4 cDNA, which included the complete ORF of rat SERP1/RAMP4, was obtained from a human expression sequence tag (EST) clone through the IMAGE consortium.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	58	 DNA sequencing was performed on both strands for each clone.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	59	Northern Blot Analysis Total RNA (10 to 15  microg), isolated from cultured astrocytes or rat tissues, was separated on agarose/formaldehyde (1%) gels and transferred onto Immobilon N membranes (Millipore).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	60	 A cDNA fragment of SERP1/RAMP4 was labeled with 32P by the random hexamer procedure (specific activity 0.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	61	5 to 3 x 109 cpm/ microg DNA) and was used to probe membranes with immobilized RNA.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	62	5x SDS for 1 h, membranes were subjected to autoradiography.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Northern blots were also performed with rat Sec61, human Sec61ss (see below), rat GRP78 (cloned by PCR with specific primers), rat HSP72 (Imuta et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	64	 1998 ), human ORP150 (Kuwabara et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	65	 1996 ), and human oligosaccaryltransferase (OST; cloned by PCR with specific primers) cDNA fragments as probes.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	66	Expression of SERP1/RAMP4 in Ischemic Brain Unilateral middle cerebral artery (MCA) occlusion was performed in male Sprague-Dawley rats (250 g) as described (Garcia et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	67	 After 12 h of ischemia, rats were killed and brains were frozen at -80 degrees C.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Serial coronal sections were cut and SERP1/RAMP4 mRNA was detected by in situ hybridization using previously described techniques (Matsuo et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	69	 In brief, sense and antisense riboprobes for SERP1/RAMP4 were in vitro transcribed from the rat SERP1/RAMP4 cDNA inserted into the pGEM T vector.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	70	 After linearizing the vector with NcoI (for the sense probe) or SpeI (for the antisense probe), reaction mixtures were incubated with [35S]UTP (NEG-039H; Dupont-NEN) and SP6 or T7 RNA polymerase (Promega).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Brain sections were then hybridized with either sense or antisense probes and washed, dried, and subjected to autoradiography.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	72	 2 d later, films were developed and brain images were examined.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	73	 For some sections, slides were covered with photographic emulsion (Eastman Kodak Co.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	74	) for 2 wk, and were then developed and analyzed by dark-field microscopy.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	75	 SERP1/RAMP4 antigen was also detected by immunoprecipitation followed by the Western blotting with anti to SERP1/RAMP4 antibody as described below.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	76	Plasmid Construction and Generation of Antibodies SERP1/RAMP4 cDNA encoding the complete ORF was amplified by PCR using primers tagged with FLAG epitope at the NH2 terminus and cloned into pcDNA3 (Invitrogen).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	77	 The rat Sec61 and human Sec61ss cDNAs were cloned as described (Gorlich et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	78	 1994 ) and hemagglutinin (HA)-tagged, amplified by PCR, and ligated into pcDNA3.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	79	 All constructs were sequenced before transfection studies (see below).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Anti to human Sec61ss antibody was generously provided by Dr.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Rapoport (Harvard University, Boston, MA).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Reagents to detect receptor for advanced glycation endproducts (RAGE) at the protein level were prepared as described (Neeper et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Antibodies and cDNA for CD8 were kindly provided by Dr.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Kazunori Imaizumi (Osaka University Medical School, Osaka, Japan).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	85	Production of Anti-SERP1/RAMP4 Antibodies and Detection of SERP1/RAMP4 Protein To obtain antibody reactive with SERP1/RAMP4, a peptide with the sequence CTQRGNVAKTSRNAPEEK (containing an extra cysteine residue at the NH2 terminus), was synthesized and conjugated to keyhole limpet hemocyanin.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Rabbits were immunized by conventional methods.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Once high titer antibody was obtained, the antiserum was affinity-purified using a column with immobilized synthetic peptide (Proton Kit 1; Multiple Peptide Systems).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	88	 For detecting SERP1/RAMP4 protein, cultured astrocytes or 293 cells transfected with pcDNA3/FLAG-tagged SERP1/RAMP4 were lysed in 1% NP-40/10 mM Tris, pH 7.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	89	6, 150 mM NaCl, 1 mM EDTA, 1 mM PMSF, and 10  microg/ml aprotinin, and immunoprecipitation or Western blotting was performed using rabbit anti to SERP1/RAMP4 antibody or mouse anti-FLAG antibody.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Sites of primary antibody binding were determined by enhanced chemiluminescence method (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech), or using alkaline phosphatase to conjugated secondary antibodies.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Immunoblotting for other molecules used specific antibodies for each epitope, and the same general procedure as that for SERP1/RAMP4 was used.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	92	Immunocytochemical Analysis of BHK Cells To assess the subcellular localization of SERP1/RAMP4, BHK cells transiently transfected to overexpress FLAG-tagged SERP1/RAMP4 or YSY6p, were subjected to double-immunostaining with mouse anti-FLAG (Sigma Chemical Co.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	93	) and rabbit anti to protein disulfide isomerase (PDI) antibodies (the latter kindly provided from Dr.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Ryuichi Masaki, Kansai Medical University, Osaka, Japan) (Akagi et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Sites of primary antibody binding were visualized using TRITC-conjugated anti to mouse antibody (Sigma Chemical Co.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	96	) and FITC-conjugated anti to rabbit antibody (Sigma Chemical Co.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	97	 In other studies, RAGE was detected using rabbit anti-RAGE IgG followed by FITC-conjugated anti to rabbit antibody.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	98	Effect of SERP1/RAMP4 on Stabilization and Glycosylation of Membrane Proteins after Induction of Cell Stress 293 or BHK cells were transiently transfected with expression constructs for RAGE or CD8 (2  microg DNA/ml) alone or with pcDNA/SERP1/RAMP4 (2  microg DNA/ml) using lipofectamine (Life Technologies, Inc.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Where indicated, ER stress was induced by addition of the calcium ionophore A23187 (1  microg/ml) or tunicamycin (1  microM).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	100	 After overnight incubation, stabilization of membrane proteins (RAGE or CD8) was analyzed by immunoblotting or by immunoprecipitation, the latter after pulse to chase labeling.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Metabolic labeling was accomplished by addition of [35S]methionine (American Radiolabeled Chemicals) to the culture medium (0.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	102	25 mCi/ml), followed by incubation for 30 min in methionine-free DMEM, and a 1-h chase period in complete medium (i.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	103	 As a control experiment, stabilization of IB under stress conditions was also studied using anti-IB antibody (Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Inc.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Antiubiquitin antibody (StressGen Biotechnologies Corp.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	105	) was used to characterize the smear RAGE antigen under stress condition.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	106	 In some experiments, cells were released from the stress after overnight incubation with tunicamycin (1  microM) (i.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	107	, the medium was replaced with tunicamycin-free medium) and glycosylation of RAGE was analyzed by metabolic labeling with [35S]methionine (0.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	108	25 mCi/ml) for 3 h followed by immunoprecipitation with anti-RAGE antibody.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	109	Interaction of SERP1/RAMP4 with Sec61 Complex, Molecular Chaperons, and the Membrane Protein RAGE 293 cells (5 x 106 cells) were transfected with expression constructs for FLAG-tagged SERP1/RAMP4, or the membrane protein RAGE (see above).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	110	 After overnight incubation, cultures were lysed in 1% NP-40 or 2% deoxycholate (the latter followed by DNase I treatment)/10 mM Tris, pH 7.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	111	6, 150 mM NaCl, 1 mM EDTA, 1 mM PMSF, and 10  microg/ml aprotinin, and immunoprecipitation was performed with various antibodies, such as anti-FLAG (Sigma Chemical Co.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	112	), anti-Sec61, anti-Sec61ss, anti-RAGE (Neeper et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	113	 1995 ), anti-GRP78 (StressGen Biotechnologies Corp.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	114	), anti-ORP150, or anticalnexin (StressGen Biotechnologies Corp.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Immunoprecipitates were then subjected to SDS-PAGE and immunoblotted with indicated antibodies.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Cross-linking with disuccinimidyl suberate (DSS) (Pierce) was performed on membrane fractions isolated from 293 cells cotransfected with expression constructs for SERP1/RAMP4 and HA-tagged Sec61ss as described (Schmidt et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	117	 In brief, 107 cells were homogenized with a Dounce homogenizer in 0.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	118	25 M sucrose, 10 mM acetic acid, 10 mM triethanolamine, 1 mM EDTA, pH 7.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	119	4, and 1 mM PMSF, and then centrifuged at 1,000 g for 10 min.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Supernatant was spun again at 10,000 g for 30 min and supernatant from the second spinning was subjected to final centrifugation at 100,000 g for 60 min to clarify a cytosolic fraction.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Cross-linking was carried out by incubating membrane fractions with 1 mM DSS in PBS for 1 h.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Coimmunoprecipitation (co-IP) was then performed as described above.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	123	Laser Densitometric Analysis Laser densitometric analysis was performed to standardize the results of Western and Northern blotting with Quality One software (Pdi, Inc.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	124	) as described previously (Tsukamoto et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	125	  Results Top Abstract Introduction Materials and Methods Results Discussion Acknowledgements References.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	126	Identification of SERP1/RAMP4 Cultured rat astrocytes were exposed to H, and after RT-PCR, a differentially expressed amplicon of 400 bp termed T41 was identified.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Northern analysis using this cDNA as a probe and total RNA harvested from hypoxic astrocytes confirmed selective upregulation compared with normoxia (see below), and led us to clone the full-length cDNA.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	128	 A rat brain cDNA library was screened, and a 2.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	129	3-kb cDNA clone was obtained that contained only a single ORF and polyadenylation signal.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	130	 The cDNA encoded a protein of 66 amino acids, termed SERP1, including a putative transmembrane-spanning domain at the COOH terminus (Figure 1).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Based on sequence homology database searches, SERP1 displayed 29% identity at the amino acid level with the yeast protein YSY6p, which was identified as a high-copy suppressor of SecY/Sec61 mutant (Sakaguchi et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Human and Caenorhabditis elegans homologues of SERP1 were encoded in EST clones, and showed 100 and 53% identities, respectively.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	133	 We further found that SERP1 is identical to a ribosome-associated membrane protein termed RAMP4 which was copurified with Sec61 complex (Gorlich and Rapoport 1993 ).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	134	 elegans SERP1 cDNA sequences can be obtained from EMBL/GenBank/DDBJ under accession nos.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	135	 AB018546, AB022427, and Z81095, respectively.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	136	View larger version (6K):    Figure 1.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Amino acid sequence of rat and human SERP1.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	138	 The putative transmembrane domain is underlined and the sequence used for raising antibodies is indicated by the box.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	139	Expression of SERP1/RAMP4 under Homeostatic Conditions and in Response to Cell Stress Northern blotting of total RNA harvested from rat tissues demonstrated similar levels of SERP1/RAMP4 transcripts in a range of normal organs, whereas heart, lung, and muscle displayed lower levels of mRNA (Figure 2 a).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Cultured astrocytes exposed to H showed a time-dependent increase in SERP1/RAMP4 transcripts, although this occurred after relatively long-term oxygen deprivation (Figure 2 b, top, H12 and H22).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	141	 When cultures were returned to the ambient environment after hypoxia (R), an increase in SERP1/RAMP4 mRNA was kept for at least 4 h (Figure 2 b, top, H/R).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Levels of SERP1/RAMP4 mRNA under H and H/R were then compared with those of Sec61 complex (Sec61 and Sec61ss) and the molecular chaperons in ER (GRP78, ORP150), the latter known to be induced in H or other types of ER stress (Figure 2 b, top).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Transcripts of Sec61 and Sec61ss increased in a manner paralleling SERP1/RAMP4, whereas GRP78 and ORP150 displayed enhanced expression at earlier times and began to decline soon after replacement into normoxia.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Quantification of Northern analysis demonstrated that SERP1/RAMP4 and GRP78 mRNAs increased by ~5.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	145	0-fold in H, compared with normoxia, respectively (Figure 2 b, bottom).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	146	View larger version (108K):    Figure 2.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Expression of SERP1/RAMP4 in vivo and in vitro.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	148	 (a) Distribution of SERP1 mRNA in normal rat organs.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Total RNA (12  microg/lane) from the indicated organ of an adult male rat was applied to each lane.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	150	 B, brain; H, heart; Lu, lung; L, liver; K, kidney; S, spleen; M, muscle; and T, testes.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	151	 The lower panel shows ethidium bromide staining of the gel.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	152	 (b) Expression of SERP1/RAMP4 mRNA under H/R and comparison with those of translocon (Sec61 and Sec61ss) and molecular chaperons (ORP150 and GRP78).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Cultured rat astrocytes were subjected to H for 12 h (H12), 22 h (H22), H for 22 h followed by R for 4 h (H/R), and the same amount of total RNA (15  microg/lane) was used for Northern analysis.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	154	 The sixth panel shows ethidium bromide staining of the gel.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	155	 (c) Expression of SERP1/RAMP4, GRP78, or HSP72 mRNA in astrocytes subjected to other forms of stress.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Total RNA (10  microg/lane) from cultured rat astrocytes treated with A23187 (1  microM; A), tunicamycin (1  microg/ml; Tu), hydrogen peroxide (80  microM; H2O2), and heat shock (42 degrees C; HS) or without any treatment (C) were used for Northern blotting to detect SERP1/RAMP4 transcripts.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	157	 The middle panel shows ethidium bromide staining of the gel.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	158	 (d) Expression of SERP1/RAMP4 protein in cultured rat astrocytes exposed to H, H/R, and ER stress.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Protein extracts from cultured rat astrocytes (107 cells/condition) exposed to H (H22), H followed by R (H/R) (left panel), or treated with A23187 (1  microM; A) or tunicamycin (1  microg/ml; Tu) were immunoprecipitated with anti-SERP1/RAMP4 antibody and subjected to Western blotting with the same antibody.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	160	 The binding of primary antibody was detected by enhanced chemiluminescence method.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Migration of simultaneously run molecular mass standards is indicated on the far left in kD.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Quantification of SERP1/RAMP4 mRNA, GRP78 mRNA, and SERP1/RAMP4 antigen was performed by laser densitometry and is expressed as fold increase in intensity under each condition compared with normoxic control (results of quantification are shown in the graphs at the bottom of b, c, and d).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Mean  plus or minus  SD of three experiments is shown.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	164	Treatment of normoxic cultures with tunicamycin or A23187, both of which result in accumulation of unfolded polypeptides within the ER (Bush et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	165	8-fold increase in SERP1/RAMP4 transcripts, respectively, whereas hydrogen peroxide and HSP were without effect (Figure 2 c).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Accompanying H/R- and ER stress to induced elevation of SERP1/RAMP4 mRNA, there was a five- to sixfold increase in SERP1/RAMP4 antigen (~10 kD) as shown using immunoprecipitation followed by immunoblotting with anti-SERP1 antibody (Figure 2 d).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	167	Immunostaining of BHK cells transiently transfected with FLAG-tagged SERP1/RAMP4 displayed an overlapping distribution of SERP1/RAMP4 antigen and the ER marker PDI (Figure 3, a to c).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Although SERP1/RAMP4 has a putative N-glycosylation site at its NH2 terminus, treatment of SERP1/RAMP4-transfected cells with tunicamycin or incubation of SERP1/RAMP4 protein itself with endoglycosidase H revealed no change in SERP1/RAMP4 (with respect to either its subcellular distribution or migration on SDS-PAGE), suggesting that glycosylation had not occurred (data not shown).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	169	View larger version (42K):    Figure 3.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Immunostaining of BHK cells transfected with the FLAG-tagged pcDNA/SERP1/RAMP4 using anti-FLAG antibody (a), anti-PDI antibody (b), and both (c).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	171	 SERP1/RAMP4-transfected BHK cells were fixed in 0.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	172	1% NP-40/4% paraformaldehyde solution and subjected to the immunostaining protocol (see text).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Sites of primary antibody binding were visualized with TRITC-conjugated anti to mouse antibody for FLAG epitope (a), FITC conjugated anti to rabbit antibody for PDI (b), or using both detection systems (c).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Upper panels show lower magnification and lower panels higher magnification.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Note that the two epitopes colocalize throughout the interior, and even in peripheral regions of the cells.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	176	To extend our studies of SERP1/RAMP4 expression in response to oxygen deprivation in vivo, distribution of SERP1/RAMP4 transcripts and the expression of SERP1/RAMP4 antigen were assessed in rat brain after MCA occlusion.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	177	 In situ hybridization showed increased SERP1/RAMP4 transcripts, especially in the periischemic penumbral region, compared with lower levels of expression in nonischemic areas (Figure 4 a).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Microautoradiography suggested that induction of SERP1/RAMP4 transcripts occurred in both neurons and astrocytes in the ischemic hemisphere (Figure 4 b).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Immunoprecipitation followed by Western blotting with anti-SERP1/RAMP4 antibody confirmed ~5.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	180	7-fold induction of SERP1/RAMP4 antigen in rat ischemic brain (Figure 4 c).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	181	View larger version (26K):    Figure 4.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Expression of SERP1/RAMP4 in ischemic rat brain.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Brain ischemia was induced in rats by unilateral (left) MCA occlusion.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	184	 After 12 h of ischemia, rats were killed and brain slices were studied by in situ hybridization (a and b) with riboprobes derived from SERP1 cDNA to detect SERP1/RAMP4 transcripts.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	185	 SERP1/RAMP4 antigen was also studied with the homogenates of the same brain samples using immunoprecipitation followed by Western blotting with anti to SERP1/RAMP4 antibody (c).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	186	 b shows a microautoradiogram of boxed area in a, displaying enhanced SERP1/RAMP4 mRNA in the periischemic penumbral region.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	187	 c shows the induction of SERP1/RAMP4 at the protein level in ischemic brain.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	188	 C, control hemisphere; I, ischemic hemisphere.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Migration of simultaneously run molecular mass standards is indicated on the left side in kD.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Quantification of SERP1/RAMP4 antigen in ischemic brain (c, right) was showed as fold increase (mean  plus or minus  SD of three experiments).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	191	Effect of SERP1/RAMP4 on the Stabilization of Membrane Proteins in Response to ER Stress The effect of SERP1/RAMP4 on processing of two integral membrane glycoproteins, RAGE (Neeper et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	192	 1992 ) and CD8, was studied by cotransfecting 293 cells with expression vectors for each along with pcDNA/SERP1/RAMP4.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Transient transfection of cultures with pcDNA3/RAGE followed by treatment of cells with tunicamycin (Figure 5 a) or A23187 (data not shown) resulted in trapping of RAGE in the ER followed by degradation.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Similar results were observed when CD8 was overexpressed and cultures were treated with these drugs.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Intracellular levels of RAGE were analyzed by immunoblotting (Figure 5 b) and metabolic labeling with [35S]methionine followed by immunoprecipitation (Figure 5 c).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	196	 293 cells overexpressing RAGE and exposed to tunicamycin or A23187 showed a decrease in the amount of RAGE antigen (~58 and 36%, respectively, compared with quiescent cultures; Mr ~55 kD in glycosylated form and 52 kD in unglycosylated form), as well as a poorly defined smear of RAGE immunoreactivity in the upper portion of the membrane, the latter likely due to aggregation of RAGE (Figure 5 b, lanes 2 and 3), and/or several more rapidly migrating immunoreactive bands, consistent with the occurrence of degradation (Figure 5 b, lane 3).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Immunoprecipitation of cell lysates with anti-RAGE antibody followed by Western blotting with antiubiquitin antibody showed that the smear of RAGE immunoreactivity includes polyubiquitinated RAGE (data not shown).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Although cotransfection of quiescent 293 cells with pcDNA3/RAGE and pcDNA3/SERP1/RAMP4 had no apparent effect on RAGE antigen (Figure 5 b, lane 4), overexpression of SERP1/RAMP4 in tunicamycin- or A23187-treated cultures increased the intensity of the major RAGE band to ~80 and 86% of the intensity in untreated controls, respectively.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Furthermore, both higher and lower molecular weight immunoreactive RAGE bands disappeared in cotransfectants overexpressing RAGE and SERP1/RAMP4 (Figure 5 b, lanes 5 and 6).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	200	 In contrast, overexpression of Sec61ss instead of SERP1/RAMP4 did not have a similar effect on RAGE and overexpression of SERP1/RAMP4 did not stabilize cytosolic proteins, such as IB, which also undergoes degradation in response to stress conditions under study (data not shown).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	201	View larger version (60K):    Figure 5.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Effect of SERP1/RAMP4 on the stabilization and refolding of membrane proteins during and after ER stress.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	203	 (a) Subcellular localization of RAGE in control and in tunicamycin-treated cells.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	204	 RAGE-transfected BHK cells were fixed in 0.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	205	1% NP-40/4% paraformaldehyde and subjected to the immunostaining with rabbit anti-RAGE antibody (primary antibody) and FITC-conjugated anti to rabbit IgG (secondary antibody).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Addition of tunicamycin caused RAGE to be distributed mainly in the perinuclear region.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	207	 (b) Western blotting with anti-RAGE IgG using cell extracts from RAGE-transfected 293 cells with or without cotransfection with pcDNA/SERP1/RAMP4 and/ or treatment with tunicamycin and A23187 (top), and quantification of the intensity of RAGE-immunoreactive bands as a percentage of the intensity of the bands in control RAGE-transfected cultures (bottom).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Mean  plus or minus  SD of three experiments is shown.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Lane 1, RAGE transfection alone; lane 2, RAGE transfection plus tunicamycin; lane 3, RAGE transfection plus A23187; lane 4, RAGE plus SERP1/RAMP4 cotransfection; lane 5, RAGE plus SERP1/RAMP4 cotransfection plus tunicamycin; and lane 6, RAGE plus SERP1/RAMP4 cotransfection plus A23187.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	210	 (c) Immunoprecipitation with either anti-RAGE or anti-CD8 IgG after metabolic labeling for 30 min alone or with additional chasing for 60 min (top), and quantification of the intensity of the corresponding RAGE-CD8 immunoreactive bands as a percentage of the same band in control RAGE-CD8 to transfected cultures (bottom).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Mean  plus or minus  SD of three experiments is shown.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Lane 1, transfection with pcDNA3/RAGE or pcDNA3/CD8 alone; lane 2, transfection as in lane 1 followed by treatment with tunicamycin; lane 3, transfection as in lane 1 followed by treatment with A23187; lane 4, transfection as in lane 1 followed by cotransfection with pcDNA/SERP1/RAMP4 and treatment with tunicamycin; and lane 5, transfection as in lane 1 followed by cotransfection with pcDNA/SERP1/RAMP4 and treatment with A23187.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	213	 (d) Metabolic labeling of RAGE-transfected 293 cells after quenching tunicamycin treatment.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Control cells (lane 4) were not treated with tunicamycin or cotransfected with pcDNA3/SERP1/RAMP4.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Cultures were transfected or cotransfected with constructs encoding RAGE and/or SERP1.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Glycosylated and unglycosylated forms of RAGE are indicated by CHO+ and CHO-.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	217	293 cells transfected with pcDNA3/RAGE were labeled with [35S]methionine for 30 min after treatment of cell cultures with tunicamycin or A23187.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Immunoprecipitation of RAGE resulted in the appearance of the expected immunoreactive species (Figure 5 c, top).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	219	 However, RAGE present after 60 min into the chase period was substantially reduced in tunicamycin or A23187-treated cells (32 and 5% of untreated control, respectively), presumably due to degradation (Figure 5 c, lanes 2 and 3).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Cotransfection with pcDNA/SERP1/RAMP4, along with pcDNA3/RAGE, maintained, at least in part, levels of RAGE in cells exposed to tunicamycin (Figure 5 c, lane 4) (~73% of untreated control) or A23187 (Figure 5 c, lane 5; ~60% of untreated control).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Similar results were obtained when pcDNA3/CD8 was transfected instead of pcDNA3/RAGE (Figure 5 c).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	222	Effect of SERP1/RAMP4 on the Glycosylation of Membrane Proteins after the ER Stress In view of the enhanced expression of SERP1/RAMP4 in both H and R, and its homology with the yeast protein YSY6p (Sakaguchi et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	223	 1991 ), further studies were performed to assess the contribution of SERP1/RAMP4 to protein refolding (glycosylation) after stress.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	224	 SERP1/RAMP4 overexpression had no detectable effect on the glycosylation of RAGE in the presence of tunicamycin (Figure 5b and Figure c).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	225	 However, metabolic labeling with [35S]methionine for 3 h using pcDNA3/RAGE-transfected 293 cells after quenching tunicamycin treatment demonstrated that SERP1/RAMP4 overexpression not only stabilized unglycosylated RAGE but also facilitated, at least in part, the glycosylation of RAGE (Figure 5 d, lanes 2 and 3; ~24% of total RAGE was glycosylated).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	226	 These effects of SERP1/RAMP4 overexpression during and after the stress were not due to induction of the OST complex, the enzymes that are required for (N-linked) glycosylation (data not shown).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	227	Interactions of SERP1/RAMP4, RAGE, Sec61 Complex, and Molecular Chaperons To analyze the mechanism underlying the chaperon-like functions of SERP1/RAMP4 (by stabilizing and facilitating glycosylation of membrane proteins) under and after ER stress, we first studied the interaction of SERP1/RAMP4 with integral membrane protein RAGE.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	228	 However, co-IP of 293 cells transfected with pcDNA3/RAGE and pcDNA3/SERP1/RAMP4 did not show a complex comprised of both molecules under either normal and stress conditions.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Next, the binding of SERP1/RAMP4 to Sec61 complex was examined, since RAMP4 was originally copurified with Sec61 complex (Gorlich and Rapoport 1993 ).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Co-IP study using whole cell lysates in NP-40 to containing buffer (Figure 6 a) or co-IP after cross-linking of membrane fractions (Figure 6 b) revealed that SERP1/RAMP4 formed a stable complex with Sec61ss both in transfected cells and under endogenous conditions.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	231	 In Figure 6 b, lane 4, the two major bands at ~42 and 27 kD may represent the heterotrimer and heterodimer of Sec61ss and SERP1/RAMP4 complex based on the molecular masses of both molecules.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	232	 It should be noted that transfection of cells with pcDNA3/SERP1/RAMP4 resulted in at least 10 times higher expression of proteins, based on immunoprecipitation and Western blotting (data not shown).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	233	 To rule out the possibility that Sec61ss formed a complex with SERP1/RAMP4 after its dissociation from Sec61 complex in NP-40 to containing buffer, similar co-IP studies were performed with cell lysates made in the presence of deoxycholate (Figure 6 c).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Under these conditions, not only Sec61ss but also Sec61 was coimmunoprecipitated with SERP1/RAMP4.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	235	View larger version (34K):    Figure 6.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Interaction of SERP1/RAMP4, RAGE, Sec61 complex and molecular chaperon calnexin.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	237	 (a and c to f) 293 cells were transfected or cotransfected with constructs encoding FLAG-SERP1/RAMP4 and/or RAGE, and co-IP was performed with the indicated antibodies after lysis of cultures in buffer containing NP-40 (a, d, and e) or deoxycholate (c and f).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	238	 (b) Co-IP study after cross-linking membrane fractions from 293 cells cotransfected with pcDNA3/FLAG-SERP1/ RAMP4 and pcDNA3/HA-Sec61ss.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Cross-linking was performed with DSS as described in the text, and co-IP was carried out using anti-FLAG and anti-HA antibodies.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Migration of simultaneously run molecular mass standards is indicated on the left in kD.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	241	Formation of a complex between RAGE and Sec61 complex was also studied by co-IP; Sec61ss to RAGE complex was detected in response to stress in both NP-40 to  and deoxycholate-containing buffer, although Sec61 to RAGE binding was detected only in the presence of deoxycholate (Figure 6d and Figure e).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	242	 SERP1/RAMP4 also became associated with calnexin, which is a membrane protein and a molecular chaperon in ER (Figure 6 f).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	243	 Such an interaction occurred under control (endogenous) conditions and after overexpression of SERP1/RAMP4.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	244	 In these co-IP studies, ~10 and 15% of Sec61ss was coimmunoprecipitated with SERP1 and unglycosylated RAGE, respectively (data not shown).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	245	  Discussion Top Abstract Introduction Materials and Methods Results Discussion Acknowledgements References.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	246	A key facet of the cellular response to the environmental stress imposed by oxygen deprivation appears to be induction of molecular chaperons.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	247	 In this context, previous studies from our and other laboratories have demonstrated induction of molecular chaperons in ER, GRP78, GRP94, and a novel 150-kD polypeptide termed ORP150 (Lowenstein et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	248	 1996 ) in hypoxic and ischemic conditions.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	249	 Suppression of ORP150 transcripts in oxygen-deprived cultures of human embryonic kidney cells increased their vulnerability to H-induced apoptosis (Ozawa et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	250	 1999 ), suggesting that a stress response in ER might have a important role in adaptation to ischemic challenge.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	251	 The current studies describe another polypeptide, SERP1, whose expression is increased by H/R although the induction is preceded by those of molecular chaperons in ER, and which participates in the ER stress response due to the accumulation of unfolded proteins in the ER.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	252	SERP1 encodes a polypeptide localized to the ER and comprised of only 66 amino acids, which was identical to RAMP4.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	253	 RAMP4 was originally copurified with the core component of the protein-translocation machinery of the ER, the Sec61 complex, and it was recently reported that RAMP4 controls the glycosylation of major histocompatbility complex class II to associated invariant chain (Schroder et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Sec61 is a complex composed of , ss, and subunits, which assemble into a channel through which nascent proteins enter the ER (Gorlich et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	255	 A putative transmembrane-spanning domain at the COOH terminus probably anchors SERP1/RAMP4 in the ER membrane.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	256	 The orientation of SERP1/RAMP4 in the ER is likely to present the NH2 terminus to the cytosol, as predicted by previous studies of other similar proteins (Hartmann et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	257	 1993 ), and consistent with the apparent lack of glycosylation of the putative N-glycosylation site at the SERP1/RAMP4 NH2 terminus.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	258	 SERP1/RAMP4 displays homology with yeast YSY6p, identified based on its capacity to suppress the defect in protein export of a SecY (Sec61 homologue in bacteria) mutant (Sakaguchi et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	259	 The identity between SERP1 and RAMP4, and the homology between SERP1 and YSY6, as well as induction of SERP1 in response to ER stress at mRNA and protein levels, suggested the hypothesis that SERP1 might participate in the biosynthesis or degradation of secretory and membrane proteins.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	260	To evaluate the effect of SERP1/RAMP4 on protein processing, experiments were performed to address whether SERP1/RAMP4 has any effect on stabilization and refolding of membrane proteins during stress conditions (i.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	261	 Induction of ER stress with tunicamycin or A23187 in 293 cells promoted aggregation and degradation of two integral membrane proteins, RAGE and CD8, members of the Ig superfamily of cell surface molecules with a single transmembrane-spanning domain.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Cotransfection of 293 cells to overexpress SERP1/RAMP4 prevented accelerated aggregation and degradation of RAGE and CD8 in the setting of ER stress (Figure 5b and Figure c).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Although it is not yet clear whether these effects of SERP1/RAMP4 occurred by directly preventing the degradation of membrane proteins or by promoting their refolding in the ER, our results support the latter concept, because SERP1/RAMP4 did facilitate, at least in part, glycosylation of integral membrane proteins in the ER after ER stress was relieved (Figure 5 d) without induction of the OST.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	264	Co-IP and cross-linking studies revealed that SERP1/RAMP4 interacts with the Sec61 and Sec61ss subunits, which bind to RAGE (and by analogy, other membrane proteins) in response to cellular perturbation (Figure 6, a to e).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	265	 It is important to note that SERP1/RAMP4 is likely to interact with other ER proteins in addition to Sec61 and Sec61ss, as indicated by the presence of several bands after immunoblotting of SERP1/RAMP4 after cross-linking (Figure 6 b).
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	266	 However, in a previous cross-linking study, RAMP4 was not detected in a complex with Sec61ss (Kalies et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	267	 We speculate that the reason for this difference with our results is likely to derive from the use of different cross-linking agents.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	268	 1998 used bis-maleimidohexane, which depends on optimal juxtaposition of cysteines, whereas our study used DSS, which does not interact with sulfhydryl groups.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	269	 SERP1/RAMP4 is coprecipitated with calnexin (Figure 6 f), a membrane protein and a molecular chaperon in ER known to associate with folding intermediates of glycoproteins (monomeric glycoproteins) and believed to play a major role for the quality control apparatus in ER (Ou et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Together these results suggest that the stabilization of membrane proteins during and after ER stress involves the concerted action of a rescue unit in the ER membrane comprised of SERP1/RAMP4, components of the translocon such as Sec61 and Sec61ss, and ER chaperons, such as calnexin.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	271	Increased expression of components of the Sec61 complex begins relatively late during H (>12 h) and is sustained during R.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	272	 This suggests that induction of the Sec61 complex probably has an integral role for increased biosynthesis of luminal and membrane proteins in replacement of those damaged during stress.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	273	 It is noteworthy that expression of SERP1/RAMP4 parallels that of components of the Sec61 complex and not that of luminal ER chaperons, which declines during R.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	274	 This may indicate that the functions of the Sec61 complex and SERP1/RAMP4 during de novo protein synthesis are tightly coupled.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	275	 These considerations underline the importance of further studies to determine the detailed function of SERP1/RAMP4 in the context of cell stress, and the contribution of SERP1/RAMP4 to cellular processing of native polypeptides or disease-related proteins, such as the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) (Bebok et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	276	 1995 ) or amyloid-beta precursor protein (APP) (Coor et al.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Hori contributed equally to this work.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	278	 1 Abbreviations used in this paper: co-IP, coimmunoprecipitation; DSS, disuccinimidyl suberate; GRP, glucose-regulated protein; H, hypoxia; HA, hemagglutinin; HSP, heat shock protein; MCA, middle cerebral artery; ORF, open reading frame; ORP, oxygen-regulated protein; OST, oligosaccaryltransferase; PDI, protein disulfide isomerase; R, reoxygenation; RAGE, receptor for advanced glycation endproducts; RAMP, ribosome-associated membrane protein; SERP, stress-associated endoplasmic reticulum protein; YSY6p, yeast suppressor of SecY 6 protein.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	279	  Acknowledgements Top Abstract Introduction Materials and Methods Results Discussion Acknowledgements References.

0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Masao Sakaguchi (Kyusyu University, Fukuoka, Japan) and Koreaki Ito (Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan) for providing the information for yeast YSY6p and Dr.
0.4653881.10601334.html.plaintext.txt	283	 Naoya Sato (Osaka University) for giving valuable suggestions.
