0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	0	  The Rockefeller University Press, 0021-9525 $8.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	1	00 JCB, Volume 167, Number 1, 65-74 This Article Abstract PDF (Full Text) Supplemental Material Index Correction (v167,p567) Alert me when this article is cited Citation Map Services Alert me to new content in the JCB Download to citation manager Cited by other online articles Google Scholar Articles by Wang, X.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	2	 Articles citing this Article PubMed PubMed Citation Articles by Wang, X.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Related Collections Related Article Article.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	4	COPII-dependent export of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator from the ER uses a di-acidic exit code Xiaodong Wang1, Jeanne Matteson1, Yu An1,2, Bryan Moyer1, Jin-San Yoo1, Sergei Bannykh1, Ian A.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	5	1 Department of Cell Biology, The Scripps Research Institute, La Jolla, CA 92037 2 Department of Molecular Biology, The Scripps Research Institute, La Jolla, CA 92037 3 The Institute for Childhood and Neglected Diseases, The Scripps Research Institute, La Jolla, CA 92037 4 Mayo Foundation and S.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Johnson Medical Research Center, Mayo Clinic, Scottsdale, AZ 85259.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	7	   Abstract Top Abstract Introduction Results Discussion Materials and methods References   Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a childhood hereditary disease in which the most common mutant form of the CF transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) F508 fails to exit the endoplasmic reticulum (ER).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Export of wild-type CFTR from the ER requires the coat complex II (COPII) machinery, as it is sensitive to Sar1 mutants that disrupt normal coat assembly and disassembly.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	9	 In contrast, COPII is not used to deliver CFTR to ER-associated degradation.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	10	 We find that exit of wild-type CFTR from the ER is blocked by mutation of a consensus di-acidic ER exit motif present in the first nucleotide binding domain.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Mutation of the code disrupts interaction with the COPII coat selection complex Sec23/Sec24.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	12	 We propose that the di-acidic exit code plays a key role in linking CFTR to the COPII coat machinery and is the primary defect responsible for CF in F508-expressing patients.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Matteson contributed equally to this paper.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	14	Abbreviations used in this paper: BFA, brefeldin A; BHK, baby hamster kidney; CF, cystic fibrosis; CFTR, CF transmembrane conductance regulator; COPII, coat complex II; endo H, endoglycosidase H; ERAD, ER-associated degradation; GAP, guanine nucleotide activating protein; NBD1, nucleotide binding domain 1; VSV-G, vesicular stomatitis virus glycoprotein.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	15	   Introduction Top Abstract Introduction Results Discussion Materials and methods References   The cystic fibrosis (CF) transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) is a cAMP-regulated chloride channel found in the apical membrane of polarized epithelia lining many tissues including the intestine, pancreas, and lung (for reviews see Kopito, 1999; Riordan, 1999; Bertrand and Frizzell, 2003).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Although more than 1,000 mutations have been identified in the CFTR gene, F508 accounts for nearly 70% of CF alleles.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	17	 In homozygous individuals, the F508-CFTR mutation leads to severe forms of CF.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	18	 CFTR contains 12 transmembrane domains and three cytosolic oriented domains (nucleotide binding domain 1 [NBD1], R, and NBD2) involved in channel gating.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Current evidence suggests that deletion of Phe508 in NBD1 prevents proper folding and trafficking of CFTR from the ER to the plasma membrane (Kopito, 1999; Riordan, 1999; Bertrand and Frizzell, 2003).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	20	 F508-CFTR is a temperature-sensitive mutant, as transfer to the permissive temperature (27 to 30 degrees C) results in partial export from the ER (Denning et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Misfolded F508-CFTR that fails to exit the ER is eliminated by the ER-associated degradation (ERAD) pathway (Xiong et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	22	Export from the ER now appears to involve specific exit codes that couple cargo to a common cytosolic budding machinery (Barlowe, 2003).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	23	 A conserved di-acidic exit code found in the cytosolic tail of many type I transmembrane proteins was first identified in mammalian cells (Nishimura and Balch, 1997; Nishimura et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	24	, 2000) and subsequently in yeast (Votsmeier and Gallwitz, 2001; Malkus et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	25	 The di-acidic code directs selective (Balch et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	26	, 1994) and efficient (Nishimura and Balch, 1997; Nishimura et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	27	, 1999) ER export by promoting interaction of cargo with the coat complex II (COPII) budding machinery.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	28	 COPII (for review see Antonny and Schekman, 2001) consists of the Sar1 GTPase, the cargo selection protein complex Sec23/24 that is a Sar1-specific guanine nucleotide activating protein (GAP; Aridor et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	29	, 2002), and a coat polymer assembly factor, Sec13/31 (Pryer et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	30	 The Sar1 GTPase is recruited and activated by the ER-localized transmembrane protein Sec12, a guanine nucleotide exchange factor specific for Sar1 (Barlowe and Schekman, 1993; Weissman et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Sar1 activation is essential for recruitment of the Sec23/24 complex to the ER membrane to select cargo and to initiate COPII coat assembly.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	32	Assembly and disassembly of the COPII coat can be rigorously controlled in vivo and in vitro by use of biochemically characterized Sar1 mutants.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Sar1[T39N] (referred to as Sar1-GDP) is restricted to the GDP-bound state and biochemically functions as a competitive inhibitor of wild-type Sar1 recruitment, thereby preventing Sec23/24 attachment to the ER membrane and coat assembly (Kuge et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Sar1[H79G] (referred to as Sar1-GTP) has a reduced rate of GAP-stimulated hydrolysis, remaining in the GTP-bound state after activation.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Although efficiently recruited to the ER membrane where it promotes cargo recruitment and the assembly of coat polymers, its inability to undergo hydrolysis interferes with subsequent COPII coat disassembly, resulting in inhibition of ER to Golgi transport (Kuge et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	36	 In addition, we have demonstrated that the protein kinase inhibitor H89 blocks recruitment of COPII coat components and prevents vesicle formation from the ER (Aridor and Balch, 2000).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	37	 These probes provide powerful approaches to dissect the role of COPII function in transport of cargo through the secretory pathway.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	38	To develop a therapeutic means to stimulate F508-CFTR trafficking from the ER to the cell surface, it is necessary to understand the mechanisms and pathways that regulate its export from the ER.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	39	 We have previously shown that CFTR exits the ER in a COPII-dependent fashion (Yoo et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	40	 A recent paper (Fu and Sztul, 2003) proposed that COPII also regulates the delivery of wild-type CFTR to the ERAD pathway in the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae (Xiong et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	41	 We have now examined in detail the contribution of COPII to the export of CFTR to the Golgi and its potential contribution to the ERAD pathway in mammalian cells.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Our results demonstrate that although COPII is essential for export of wild-type CFTR from the ER, we found no evidence that COPII contributes to the targeting of either wild-type CFTR or the F508-CFTR mutant to ERAD pathway.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Intriguingly, we report that export of CFTR is highly sensitive to mutation of a highly conserved, consensus di-acidic exit code (Nishimura and Balch, 1997) found in the NBD1 domain of CFTR.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	44	 We find that coupling to the Sec23/24 cargo selection complex through the di-acidic code is critical for diverting CFTR from the ERAD pathway.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	45	 We propose that the di-acidic exit code plays a key role in linking CFTR to the COPII coat machinery and is the primary defect leading to disease in F508-expressing patients.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	46	   Results Top Abstract Introduction Results Discussion Materials and methods References   Degradation of wild-type CFTR is COPII independent To follow export of CFTR from the ER, baby hamster kidney (BHK) cells were transfected with CFTR using a vaccinia-transient expression system, pulse-labeled with [35S]methionine, and CFTR transport to the Golgi detected by processing of the band B N-linked core-oligosaccharide form to the band C complex form by Golgi-associated glycosyltransferases that has reduced migration on SDS-PAGE (Yoo et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	47	 In most tissue culture cell lines engineered to express CFTR, wild-type CFTR is inefficiently exported, resulting in processing of only 20 to 30% of the ER-associated band B to the Golgi-and post-Golgi mature band C form (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	48	 1 A, inset and bottom left panel; Riordan, 1999).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	49	 CFTR failing to exit the ER is degraded by ERAD indicated by the loss of band B (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	50	 1 A, inset and top panel; Xiong et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	51	View larger version (43K):    Figure 1.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Export of CFTR from the ER is COPII dependent.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	53	 BHK cells were transfected with pcDNA3.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	54	1 plasmids containing either wild-type CFTR or F508-CFTR or cotransfected with pcDNA3.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	55	1 containing the indicated Sar1 mutants as described previously (Yoo et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	56	 After a 30-min pulse with [35S]Met, CFTR was immunoprecipitated at the indicated chase time and quantitated using a Molecular Dynamics PhosphoImager as described previously (Yoo et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Expression levels of Sar1 mutants (5 to 10-fold endogenous) were monitored by immunoblotting with specific antibody as described previously (Yoo et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	58	 (A and B, top panels) Quantitation of CFTR in band B (ER form) reported as a percentage of total B plus C at the 0 time point.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	59	 (A and B, bottom panels) Quantitation of the CFTR band C glycosylated form reported as a percentage of total B plus C at the 0 time point.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Insets in A and B show representative autoradiographs containing band B and C (arrows).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	61	 In A (top right panel), a significant increase in amount of band B remaining in six independent experiments for cells transfected with Sar1-GTP compared with Sar1-GDP at 3 h is shown (P  <  0.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	62	 The dashed horizontal line indicates the level of band B remaining in the wild-type (mock) control.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	63	 In A (bottom right panel), the C/B ratios are shown for the 3-h time point.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Results in A and B are typical of at least three independent experiments.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	65	  We have previously reported (Yoo et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	66	, 2002) that Golgi processing of band B to band C is inhibited by cotransfection with the Sar1-GTP mutant when overexpressed 5 to 10-fold, demonstrating that CFTR exits the ER by a COPII-dependent pathway (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Inhibition is clearly evident in the ratio of band C to band B (C/B ratio).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	68	 When compared with the mock control C/B value of 1.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	69	8 at the 3-h time point, the C/B ratio in the presence of Sar1-GTP was  < 0.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	70	 To pursue the possibility that COPII is required for ER export but not ERAD, we examined the effect of the Sar1-GDP mutant that is restricted to the GDP-bound form on CFTR glycosylation or proteolysis.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	71	 As Sar1-GDP is a competitive inhibitor of recruitment of wild-type Sar1 to the Sec12 guanine nucleotide exchange factor (Weissman et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	72	, 2001) and Sar1 activation is essential for the recruitment of the cargo selection Sec23/24 complex to the ER membrane (Kuge et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	73	, 2001), Sar1-GDP competes with wild-type Sar1 to competitively reduce the efficiency of both COPII recruitment and coat assembly.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Although cotransfection of wild-type CFTR with Sar1-GDP (5 to 10-fold overexpression; Kuge et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	75	, 2002) strongly inhibited export as measured by processing of band B to band C (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	76	 1 A, inset and bottom panels, C/B ratio is  < 0.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	77	7), wild-type CFTR continued to be degraded efficiently in the presence of the mutant (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Identical results were observed at both early and late time points of transfection (unpublished data), indicating that the potential accumulation of other cargo in the ER in the presence of Sar1-GDP is unlikely to influence the effect of the Sar1-GDP on CFTR trafficking and degradation.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	79	 In contrast to Sar1-GDP, Sar1-GTP is a dominant-negative mutant that promotes cargo collection into stable COPII-coated intermediates.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	80	 As a consequence, targeting and fusion of these intermediates to the Golgi is blocked (Kuge et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Interestingly, cotransfection of wild-type CFTR with Sar1-GTP significantly (P  <  0.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	82	05) protected immature (band B) wild-type CFTR from degradation by the ERAD pathway when compared with degradation rate observed in the presence of the Sar1-GDP mutant (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	83	 This result raises the possibility that recruitment of CFTR to the assembling COPII polymer at ER exit sites prevents access to ERAD.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	84	We also examined the effects of both Sar1-GDP to  and Sar1-GTP to restricted mutants on F508-CFTR stability given that this protein is not exported from the ER and therefore completely degraded by ERAD (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Cotransfection of F508-CFTR with the Sar1-GTP to restricted mutant did not promote processing of band B to C (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	86	 1 B, inset and bottom panel), nor did it affect the kinetics of degradation by ERAD (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	87	 An identical result was observed with the Sar1-GDP to restricted mutants (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	88	 These results are consistent with the idea that failure to export from the ER reflects the inability of F508 to link to COPII.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	89	To provide additional evidence for the role of Sar1 in selection of wild-type CFTR for export, we took advantage of the protein kinase inhibitor H89 that we have previously shown to inhibit Sar1 recruitment and COPII coat assembly (Aridor and Balch, 2000).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Addition of H89 to cells stably expressing CFTR strongly reduced export (90%; Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	91	 ERAD continues efficiently, suggesting that COPII recruitment is not required for targeting for degradation as H89, like Sar1-GDP, uncouples cargo from the COPII coat machinery (Aridor and Balch, 2000).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	92	View larger version (21K):    Figure 2.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Export of CFTR from the ER but not degradation is inhibited by the kinase inhibitor H89.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	94	 BHK cells stably expressing either wild-type CFTR or F508-CFTR were labeled with [35S]Met for 30 min as described previously (Yoo et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	95	 After labeling, cells were chased for the indicated time in the absence or presence of 50  microM H89, and processing of CFTR from the band B ER form to mature band C was quantitated as described previously (Yoo et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Results are typical of two independent experiments.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	97	  We conclude that conditions that enhance COPII assembly on the ER membrane stabilize wild-type CFTR from ERAD.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	98	 In contrast, conditions that interfere with COPII recruitment prevent the export of wild-type CFTR, but have little effect on delivery of either wild-type CFTR or F508-CFTR to the ERAD pathway.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Thus, the ERAD pathway functions largely independently of the COPII machinery.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	100	Export, but not ERAD, is reversibly sensitive to a novel Sar1 temperature-sensitive (Sar1ts) mutant To ensure that the aforementioned results with the Sar1 mutants were not a consequence of targeting of either wild-type or mutant CFTR to a nonphysiological pathway, or reflect indirect effects of other cargo in the ER on CFTR export or stability, we developed a temperature-sensitive variant of Sar1.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	101	 This mutant is dominant-negative at the permissive temperature (32 degrees C), where it is folded properly.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	102	 It loses this dominant-negative activity when transferred to the restrictive temperature (40 degrees C), where it misfolds.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	103	 When cotransfected with the type 1 transmembrane protein vesicular stomatitis virus glycoprotein (VSV-G) at 32 degrees C, Sar1ts shows strong inhibition of processing of VSV-G from the endoglycosidase H (endo H) to sensitive ER form to the endo H to resistant Golgi form (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	104	 3 A), indicative of an ER to Golgi transport block.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	105	 In contrast, at 40 degrees C, a condition that promotes destabilization of the mutant protein, inhibition of export is lost (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Thus, Sar1ts shows a thermoreversible temperature-sensitive ER export block.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	107	View larger version (24K):    Figure 3.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	108	 ER export is reversibly sensitive to a novel Sar1 temperature-sensitive (Sar1ts) mutant.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	109	 (A) BHK cells were cotransfected with pcDNA3.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	110	1 containing either VSV-G or VSV-G and the indicated Sar1 mutant.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	111	 The effect of Sar1-GTP (control) or Sar1ts on processing of VSV-G from the endoglycosidase H to sensitive (endo Hs) ER form to the endo H to resistant (endo Hr) Golgi form after a 5-min pulse with [35S]Met at 32 degrees C followed by a 30 min chase at the indicated temperature was determined as described previously (Yoo et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	112	 (B) BHK cells were cotransfected with pcDNA3.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	113	1 containing wild-type CFTR either with vector only (mock) or, where indicated, cotransfected with pcDNA3.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	114	 The transport and processing of CFTR from band B to C was followed at the indicated temperature as described in Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	115	 The C/B ratios for the Sar1ts mutant at 32 and 40 degrees C are shown for the 3-h time point.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	116	 The asterisk in the top panel of B indicates that CFTR is exported very inefficiently from the ER as band C is only weakly processed to early Golgi oligosaccharide forms.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	117	 White lines indicate that intervening lanes have been spliced out.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Results are typical of three independent experiments.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	119	  Transient coexpression of Sar1ts and wild-type CFTR at 32 degrees C significantly inhibited the export of wild-type CFTR when compared with the mock control as measured by processing from the band B to the band C forms (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	120	 3 B, bottom right panel, C/B ratio is 0.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Sar1ts had no apparent effect on stabilizing wild-type CFTR from degradation at 32 degrees C (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	122	 3 B, top panel), which is consistent with the interpretation that Sar1ts interferes with COPII coat assembly but does not affect ERAD pathways.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Moreover, cotransfection of F508-CFTR with Sar1ts had no effect on either F508-CFTR export or degradation when compared with the controls expressing F508 alone at either 32 or 40 degrees C temperatures (unpublished data).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Importantly, we used a two-stage incubation protocol to examine the ability of CFTR to be exported from the ER after accumulation in the presence of the Sar1ts mutant at 32 degrees C.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Cells transfected for 14 h at 32 degrees C to prevent CFTR export were labeled for 30 min at 32 degrees C (stage 1).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Subsequently, cells were transferred to 40 degrees C (stage 2) to inactivate Sar1ts.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	127	 In contrast to incubation at 32 degrees C (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	128	 3 B, bottom right panel, C/B ratio is 0.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	129	5 at 3 h), upon transfer to 40 degrees C we observed normal processing of wild-type CFTR from band B to C (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	130	 3 B, bottom right panel, C/B ratio is >4 at 3 h).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Thus, reversible inhibition of processing of wild-type CFTR to band C imposed by incubation at 32 degrees C in the presence of Sar1ts interferes with the normal physiological pathway required for COPII-dependent export but not degradation.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	132	CFTR uses a di-acidic exit code for export from the ER To understand the requirement for COPII in the export of CFTR from the ER, we examined the CFTR sequence for the presence of the evolutionarily conserved tyrosine-based di-acidic code required for export of VSV-G (Nishimura and Balch, 1997; Nishimura et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	133	, 2000) and other transmembrane proteins from the ER in mammalian cells (Bannykh and Balch, 1998; Bannykh et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	134	, 1998) and yeast (Votsmeier and Gallwitz, 2001; Malkus et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Notably, CFTR contained a YKDAD motif (residues 563 to 567) in the first nucleotide binding motif (NBD1) that is evolutionarily conserved and similar to that found in VSV-G (YxDxE; Nishimura and Balch, 1997; Sevier et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	136	 The structure of the NBD1 domain of CFTR (1ROZ.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	137	pdb) reveals that the YKDAD motif is located in a surface-exposed loop linking the NH2-terminal helical domain containing Phe508 to the COOH-terminal sheet domain (Lewis et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Strikingly, transient expression of CFTR mutants in which either one (DAA-CFTR; Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	139	 4 B, inset and bottom panel) or both (AAA-CFTR; unpublished data) conserved Asp residues were mutated to Ala resulted in complete inhibition of export from the ER as measured by the inability of band B to be processed to band C and a morphological distribution consistent with localization to the ER (Bannykh et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Like F508-CFTR, cotransfection with Sar1-GTP failed to promote export or stabilize DAA-CFTR from ERAD, suggesting that mutation of the di-acidic motif uncoupled CFTR from COPII (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	141	 We also examined whether or not, like F508-CFTR, the DAA-CFTR phenotype is temperature-sensitive by examining its rate of export at the lowered temperature (30 degrees C).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Whereas transfer of F508-CFTR to 30 degrees C resulted in significant enhancement of transport to the cell surface reflecting its effect on conformational stability of NBD1 as observed previously (Denning et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	143	, 1996), we did not observe a similar increase in DAA-CFTR export at 30 degrees C (unpublished data).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	144	 These results suggest that the DAA mutation does not affect the fold of NBD1 in a similar fashion to the F508 mutation that can be stabilized by incubation at reduced temperature.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	145	View larger version (51K):    Figure 4.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	146	 CFTR uses a di-acidic code for export from the ER.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	147	 (A) Location of Phe508 and the di-acidic code in the NBD1 domain of CFTR (Lewis et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Shown in blue is Phe508; shown in red (carbon backbone) and yellow (side-chains) is the orientation of residues Asp565 and Asp567 (di-acidic code).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	149	 (B) Cells were either transfected or cotransfected with the indicated wild-type or mutant CFTR and the Sar1-GTP mutant as indicated.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Processing from band B to band C was quantitated as described in Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	151	 (C) Effect of BFA on stability of wild-type CFTR, F508-CFTR, or the DAA-CFTR mutant in the ER.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	152	 White lines indicate that intervening lanes have been spliced out.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Cells were pulse-labeled for 30 min with [35S]Met at 37 degrees C.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	154	 10  microg/ml BFA was added and incubation continued for 3 h at 37 degrees C.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	155	 (lanes a, d, and g) Total CFTR found in band B after pulse (expressed as a value of 100%).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	156	 (lanes b, e, and h) Fraction of CFTR found in band B after 3-h incubation in the absence of BFA.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	157	 (lanes c, f, and i) Fraction of CFTR found in band B after 3-h incubation in the presence of BFA.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	158	 The dashed bar in lane b indicates the total B + C at the 3-h time point in the absence of BFA.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Results are typical of at least two independent experiments for each condition shown.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	160	  To further characterize the biochemical properties of the DAA-CFTR mutant, we took advantage of the previous observation that treatment of CFTR-expressing cells with brefeldin A (BFA) reduces degradation of wild-type CFTR, but not F508-CFTR (Ostedgaard et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	161	 BFA triggers the collapse of the Golgi to the ER by preventing the recruitment of coat complex I to Golgi membranes (for review see Chardin and McCormick, 1999).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	162	 In contrast to its potent effect on coat complex I function in the Golgi, BFA has no effect on COPII function during ER export.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	163	 As a consequence, in BFA-treated cells ER-associated cargo is collected in export intermediates that accumulate in the absence of functional Golgi compartments (Lippincott-Schwartz et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	164	 As expected, addition of BFA prevented processing of wild-type CFTR from band B to C and partially stabilized wild-type CFTR from ERAD, likely reflecting recruitment to COPII intermediates (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	165	 In contrast, BFA did not prevent degradation of either the F508- or the DAA-CFTR mutant (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	166	 These results are consistent with the interpretation that both mutants fail to couple to the COPII machinery (Nishimura and Balch, 1997; Nishimura et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	167	, 1999), resulting in their delivery to the ERAD pathway.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	168	The biochemical interaction of CFTR with COPII is disrupted by the F508 and DAA mutations Although the results described in the previous section raise the possibility that CFTR may exit the ER through the di-acidic code, it remained to be shown that wild-type CFTR can engage the COPII machinery and whether interaction with COPII can be disrupted by the F508- or DAA-CFTR mutations.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	169	 For this purpose, we first examined the ability of CFTR to bind the Sec23/Sec24 cargo selection complex in immunoprecipitates recovered from detergent lysates of HEK293 cell lines stably expressing either wild-type CFTR or F508-CFTR.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	170	 5 A, in cells expressing wild-type CFTR, the protein is largely in the band C mature form with  < 5% in the band B ER form, an expected result given that wild-type CFTR accumulates in post-Golgi compartments.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	171	 In contrast, in F508-CFTR to expressing HEK293 cells, the only form is band B reflecting its ER localization, its level of expression reflecting continuous degradation by ERAD (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Despite the large difference in the steady-state level of CFTR in wild-type and F508-expressing cells, when we quantitated the recovery of Sec24 with respect to the total amount of wild-type CFTR or F508-CFTR in band B using immunoblotting, we observed that F508-CFTR bound  < 25% of that observed for wild-type CFTR (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Sec24 was not recovered from HEK293 cells that do not express CFTR (unpublished data).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Because immunoprecipitations were performed on ice, it is likely that the temperature-sensitive phenotype of F508-CFTR resulted in partial folding after transfer to ice, accounting for the observed level of recovery of Sec24.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Although the band B ER form would be expected to be the only form of CFTR that would bind the ER-specific COPII coat machinery, we examined whether or not immunoprecipitation of Sec24 would recover band C, the cell surface form.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Despite the large excess of band C in the cell (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	177	 5 A), immunoprecipitation of Sec24 followed by immunoblotting for CFTR only recovered the band B forms of either wild type or F508 (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	178	View larger version (30K):    Figure 5.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Wild-type CFTR but not DAA-CFTR binds COPII.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	180	 (A) HEK293 stably expressing wild type or F508 were lysed in the presence of 1% Triton X-100, and Sec23/Sec24 complex recovered by immunoprecipitation with a CFTR-specific mAb was quantitated as described in Materials and methods.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	181	 CFTR (bands B and C) and Sec24 were detected by immunoblotting with specific antibody as described in Materials and methods.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	182	 (B) As in A except the amount CFTR recovered by immunoprecipitation with a Sec24-specific polyclonal antibody was quantitated as described in Materials and methods using immunoblotting.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	183	 HEK293 cells not expressing CFTR were used as a control.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	184	 CFTR (bands B and C) were detected by immunoblotting with specific antibody.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	185	 (C) HEK293 cells were transfected with pcDNA3.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	186	1 plasmids containing either wild-type CFTR or DAA-CFTR as described previously (Yoo et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Cells were lysed in the presence of 1% Triton X-100, and the amount of Sec23/Sec24 complex recovered bound to band B of CFTR (expressed as a Sec24/band B ratio) was quantitated as described in Materials and methods.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	188	 CFTR (bands B and C) and Sec24 were detected by immunoblotting with specific antibodies.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	189	 (D) HEK293 stably expressing wild type or F508 incubated at 37 degrees C (wild type) or for the indicated time at 30 degrees C (F508) were lysed in the presence of 1% Triton X-100, and the amount of Sec23/Sec24 complex recovered bound to CFTR by immunoprecipitation with a CFTR-specific antibody was quantitated as described in Materials and methods.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Error bars indicates the SD for samples generated for each time point in triplicate.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	191	  To test the ability of the DAA-CFTR mutant to bind the Sec23/Sec24, we transfected HEK293 cells with wild-type CFTR or DAA-CFTR using the vaccinia expression system.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Strikingly, we observed that band B of the DAA-CFTR mutant bound  < 5% of that recovered in immunoprecipitates with wild-type CFTR (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	193	 These results support the conclusion that the marked inefficiency of DAA-CFTR to exit the ER is a consequence of its inability to couple to the cargo selection complex Sec23/Sec24.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	194	To correlate the effects of the di-acidic code DAA-CFTR mutant on COPII binding with the effects of Phe508 on the ability of the F508-CFTR to exit the ER after transfer to 30 degrees C, we performed a temperature-shift experiment.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	195	 5 D, with increasing incubation time at 30 degrees C, F508 showed a strong increase in its interaction with Sec24, approaching the value observed for wild-type CFTR at 37 degrees C at steady-state.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	196	 These results suggest that reduced temperature promotes maturation of CFTR and presentation of the exit code for interaction with the COPII coat machinery for export from the ER.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	197	   Discussion Top Abstract Introduction Results Discussion Materials and methods References   COPII-dependent export of CFTR Using Sar1 mutants with well-characterized biochemical properties, we found that export of wild-type CFTR is dependent on COPII coat assembly in mammalian cells.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	198	 This would be the expected result if wild-type CFTR, but not F508-CFTR, acquires the normal protein fold necessary for cargo selection by COPII.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Several lines of evidence support this conclusion.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	200	 First, the Sar1-GTP mutant that stabilizes coat assembly markedly reduces the rate of ERAD through capture into COPII transport intermediates that accumulate in the presence of activated Sar1 (Aridor et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Second, the Sar1-GDP mutant (that prevents COPII coat recruitment) inhibited export of wild-type CFTR, but did not stabilize the ER band B form.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	202	 It is unlikely that the effects of the GDP mutant on CFTR export were influenced by build-up of other cargo in the ER during the transient expression protocol as we observed inhibition of transport at the earliest time points of transfection when the inhibitory properties of the Sar1-GDP mutant begin to take effect.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	203	 This conclusion is supported by the ability of H89 to rapidly and efficiently uncouple CFTR from export in cells stably expressing wild-type CFTR.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Furthermore, in the two-stage assay using the Sar1ts mutant, we found that accumulation of CFTR in the ER at 32 degrees C had no effect on export after inactivation of Sar1ts at 40 degrees C.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Because we did not detect significant effects of Sar1-GDP (which uncouples CFTR from COPII) on degradation of CFTR, we suggest that the export and ERAD pathways operate independently.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	206	COPII does not participate in ERAD A recent paper (Fu and Sztul, 2003) suggested that targeting of CFTR to the ERAD pathway in S.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	207	 cerevisiae requires COPII because in the absence of COPII function CFTR accumulates in an ER-like subcompartment rather than being degraded (Kiser et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	208	, 2001; Fu and Sztul, 2003; Sullivan et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	209	 In contrast, we found that COPII does not participate in ERAD of either wild-type CFTR or F508-CFTR in mammalian cells.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	210	 The reasons for this discrepancy are now apparent.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	211	 First, CFTR will not exit the ER in yeast under any condition, limiting interpretation of the results (Kiser et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	212	, 2001; Fu and Sztul, 2003; Sullivan et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Second, all experiments used overexpression of a GFP-tagged variant of CFTR (GFP-CFTR).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	214	 A similar GFP-CFTR construct, when expressed in mammalian cells, has a markedly reduced rate of export and accumulates in ER tubular elements at 30 degrees C (comparable to experiments in yeast where cells are incubated at 24 degrees C) that significantly overlaps with calnexin (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	215	 This overlap is consistent with the fact that folding of nascent CFTR in the ER is likely to involve calnexin (Pind et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	216	 However, upon transfer to 37 degrees C, GFP-CFTR is efficiently exported to the cell surface of mammalian cells (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Thus, in mammalian cells, GFP-CFTR can accumulate transiently in a bona fide ER-like tubular network at reduced temperature that is unlikely to be a specialized COPII-regulated degradative subcompartment as suggested for yeast where export is blocked at all temperatures (Fu and Sztul, 2003; Sullivan et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	218	A third concern is that all experiments relied on temperature-sensitive COPII mutants to prevent degradation, leading to the interpretation that COPII is required for ERAD.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	219	 These experiments required prolonged incubation of yeast at the restrictive temperature (40 degrees C) to assess the effect of the mutant COPII component on ERAD.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	220	 It is well-established that elevated temperature (40 degrees ) in mammalian cells markedly stabilizes (approximately twofold) both wild-type CFTR and F508-CFTR from ERAD in response to induction of heat shock folding chaperones (Strickland et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	221	, 1999; Choo-Kang and Zeitlin, 2001; Farinha et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Thus, the twofold effect of the temperature-sensitive Sec12 variant on preventing CFTR degradation in yeast can be largely explained by the twofold difference in stability observed upon shift from the permissive to the restrictive temperature in control incubations in the absence of the Sec12ts (Fu and Sztul, 2003).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	223	Fourth, unlike the Sar1-GDP and -GTP mutants, the biochemical properties of the Sec13 and Sec23 temperature-sensitive mutants have not been characterized.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	224	 For example, both Sec13 and Sec23 temperature-sensitive variants may not be inactivated by shifting to the restrictive temperature as suggested (Fu and Sztul, 2003).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Rather they may promote stable coat assembly leading to partial segregation of CFTR from ERAD as we have observed during COPII coat polymer assembly promoted by the Sar1-GTP mutant.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	226	 We conclude that role of COPII is to direct CFTR selection into COPII vesicles, removing the protein from the ERAD COPII-independent targeted pool.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	227	A di-acidic code mediates CFTR export An important finding that provides new insight into the role of COPII in export of CFTR from the ER was that processing of band B to C was sensitive to mutation of the conserved di-acidic code exit motif originally detected in the cytoplasmic tail of VSV-G (Nishimura and Balch, 1997; Nishimura et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Consistent with this finding, a natural variant in the cystic fibrosis mutation database (http://www.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	229	ca/cftr/) has a substitution of G for D at position 565 (565DAD to 565GAD) that results in a severe deficiency phenotype, although this allele is complex (Tzetis et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	230	 The requirement for a di-acidic code in CFTR export is consistent with a similar requirement for a di-acidic motif for export of the multi-membrane-spanning K+ channel (Ma et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	231	, 2001; Ma and Jan, 2002) and yeast GAP permease (Malkus et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Given that transfer of the di-acidic code to an ER-retained protein is sufficient to promote efficient export (Nishimura and Balch, 1997; Nishimura et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	233	, 1999) and the fact that the di-acidic code recognizes the Sec24 subunit of the Sec23/24 complex (Miller et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	234	, 2002), it is now evident that the di-acidic motif may be used by CFTR to engage the Sec24.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Our CFTR coimmunoprecipitation results provide direct evidence that the DAD motif in NBD1 of CFTR serves as a functional ER exit code as loss of the code results in impaired binding to Sec23/24.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	236	 In the case of the GAP permease, it has been suggested that the di-acidic code, although necessary for export, is not sufficient ((Miller et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	237	 A similar constraint may apply to CFTR as the protein has a complicated cytosolic folding pathway involving numerous chaperones and cochaperones (Pind et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	238	, 1998; Brodsky, 2001; Zhang et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	239	, 2002) that may facilitate recognition of the Sec23/Sec24 complex (unpublished data).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	240	NBD1 domains of a large variety of ABC transporters have a similar structural organization (Schmitt and Tampe, 2002).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	241	 Structural alignment of the NBD1 domain of CFTR (Lewis et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	242	, 2004) with the NBD1 domain of the ABC transporter BtuCD reveals that the di-acidic code is found in a solvent-exposed loop connecting the NH2-terminal helical domain containing Phe508 with the more COOH-terminal sheet domain (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	243	 Given that the structure of Sar1 and the Sec23/24 complex containing a bound di-acidic peptide are available (Huang et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	244	, 2003), we built a homology model with the NBD1 of CFTR replacing the similar structural fold of NBD1 of BtuCD (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	245	 This new structure (BtuCD-NBD1CFTR) was then combined with the structure of the Sec23/24 -Sar1 complex to illustrate the ability of the di-acidic code loop in NBD1CFTR to insert directly into the Sec23/24 di-acidic code binding pocket (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	246	 S2 for a three-dimensional view, available at http://www.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	247	 Docking reveals little steric interference between residues within the binding pocket, or between residues defining the tertiary structure of BtuCD-NBD1CFTR and the Sar1/Sec24/23 complex.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Moreover, the orientation of the NH2 terminus of Sar1 (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	249	 6, red ss-strand; residues 25 to 34), which is linked to the flexible NH2-terminal tail involved in anchoring Sar1 to the membrane (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	250	 6, black dashed line; not observed in the crystal structure; Huang et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	251	, 2002), is oriented correctly to facilitate recruitment of Sec23/24 by activated Sar1.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	252	 It is apparent that Sar1 and BtuCD-NBD1CFTR interact with Sec23/Sec24 independently as shown for the holo cargo-selection complex.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Thus, the general structural features of the CFTR-NBD1 domain presented within the structure of BtuCD are consistent with the role of the di-acidic code in directing interaction with COPII for exit from the ER.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	254	View larger version (61K):    Figure 6.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	255	 CFTR-COPII cargo selection complex.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	256	 (bottom) The structure of CFTR-NBD1 (1ROX.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	257	pdb) is oriented to show its structural homology with the NBD1 structural domain of the bacterial ABC transporter BtuCD (1L7V.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	258	 In CFTR-NBD1, Phe508 is shown in blue and residues Asp565 and Asp567 (di-acidic code) are shown in yellow.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	259	 In BtuCD, the cytosolic domains are shown in green and putative transmembrane spanning domains are shown in red.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	260	 The short loop shown in red in BtuCD corresponds structurally to the di-acidic code-containing loop in CFTR-NBD1.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	261	 (middle) Homology structure containing CFTR-NBD1 and BtuCD (Btu-NBD1CFTR) docked to the Sar1/Sec23/24 complex (Bi et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	262	, 2003; see Materials and methods).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Gray rectangle illustrates the putative location of the membrane bilayer.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	264	 (top) The interaction of the CFTR-NBD1 di-acidic code with the binding pocket of Sec23/24 (Bi et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	265	 Shown in blue are Arg230, 235, 559, and 561 basic residues defining the di-acidic code pocket of Sec24 (Bi et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	266	 Only a minor steric interference is observed between Asp565 (CFTR-NBD1) and Leu616 (Sec24) in the homology model.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	267	 S2 for a three-dimensional rendering of the interface between CFTR-NBD1 and the Sec23/24 cargo complex.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	268	  Given the likely importance of the aromatic side-chain of Phe508 in stabilizing the conserved structural fold of the NH2-terminal helical domain of NBD1 (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	269	 6, blue residue), deletion of Phe508 in the F508-CFTR mutant may alter the orientation of the di-acidic motif-containing loop, thereby compromising its interaction with Sec24.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	270	 This notion was directly tested by the CFTR coimmunoprecipitation experiments where we found that binding of band B of F508 to Sec24 was much lower than that of wild-type CFTR.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	271	 Consistent with this interpretation, F508-CFTR-Sec24 interaction and transport to cell surface can be rescued by promoting folding at 30 degrees C.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	272	 Moreover, export of F508-CFTR from the ER can also be rescued in cis by additional point mutations in NBD1 that stabilize the structural fold (DeCarvalho et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	273	 Given that over 1,000 mutants have been reported to affect CFTR export and function leading to varying degrees of disease, it is not surprising that residues flanking the di-acidic code have also been reported in the mutation database.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	274	 Structural considerations strongly suggest that many of these flanking mutations, unlike the di-acidic code that is found in the solvent-exposed loop, are likely to affect the fold of the -helical and ss-strands that contribute to the structural organization of NBD1 and indirectly compromise presentation of the code (unpublished data).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	275	 We propose that the inability of the F508-CFTR mutant to engage the COPII machinery through Sec24 is the primary basis for the most common form of CF.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	276	   Materials and methods Top Abstract Introduction Results Discussion Materials and methods References   Materials Reagents for vaccinia transient expression were prepared as described previously (Yoo et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	277	 HEK293 stably expressing wild-type CFTR and F508-CFTR were obtained from N.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	278	 Bradbury (University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine, Pittsburgh, PA).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	279	 The M3A7 antibody was provided by J.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	280	 Riordan (Mayo Clinic, Scottsdale, AZ).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	281	Vaccinia transient expression Vaccinia transient expression and quantification was performed exactly as described previously (Yoo et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	282	 SEM were determined using the software program Prism.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	283	Immunoprecipitation of the CFTR-Sec24 complex HEK293 cells stably expressing wild-type CFTR or F508-CFTR, or vaccinia-transfected HEK293 cells transiently expressing wild-type CFTR and DAA-CFTR were lysed on ice in Triton X-100 lysis buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	284	4, 150 mM NaCl, and 1% Triton X-100) supplemented with complete protease inhibitor cocktail tablets (Roche Diagnostics GmbH).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Soluble fraction of the lysates were incubated with protein G beads coupled with anti-CFTR antibody M3A7 or anti-Sec24 polyclonal antibodies.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	286	 The immunocomplexes were washed and eluted with 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 6.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	287	 The protein components of the complexes were separated by SDS-PAGE.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	288	 CFTR and Sec24 were detected by immunoblot.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	289	 CFTR and Sec24 were quantitated by densitometry using a Molecular Dynamics Imaging System.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	290	 In brief, for CFTR detected by immunoblotting, immunoblots exposed in the linear range were quantitated by measuring the densities of band B or C.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	291	 A similar area immediately adjacent to bands B or C in each lane (background) were subtracted from the B or C value to obtain the indicated values shown in the Results.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	292	Structural alignment of CFTR-NBD1, BtuCD, and the Sec23/24 complex Fitting of CFTR-NBD1 to BtuCD and Sec23/24 was performed as follows.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	293	 The Sec24/NBD1 complex model was built from the Sec24/DXE peptide complex (1PD1.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	294	pdb) coordinates by superimposing DXE peptide onto the corresponding part of NBD1.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	295	 The Sec24/NBD1/Sec23 complex model was built from the Sec24/NBD1 model and Sec24/Sec23 complex (1M2V.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	296	pdb) by superimposing Sec24 in both coordinates.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	297	 The Sec24/NBD1/Sec23/Sar1 complex model was built from Sec24/NBD1/Sec23 model and Sec23/Sar1 complex (1M2O.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	298	pdb) by superimposing Sec23 in both coordinates.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	299	 The Sec24/NBD1/Sec23/Sar1/BtuCD complex model was built from the Sec24/NBD1/Sec23/Sar1 model and BtuCD (1L7V.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	300	pdb) by superimposing CFTR-NBD1 and BtuD in both coordinates.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	301	 Fitting was performed using the McLachlan algorithm (McLachlan, 1982) as implemented in the program ProFit (http://www.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	302	Online supplemental material Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	303	 S1 shows GFP-CFTR accumulates in the ER at 28 degrees C.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	304	 S2 is a three-dimensional rendering of CFTR-NBD1 di-acidic code docked to the Sar1/Sec23/24 cargo selection complex.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	305	 Online supplemental material is available at http://www.
