0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	362	 CFTR gene mutations to including three novel nucleotide substitutions to and haplotype background in patients with asthma, disseminated bronchiectasis and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	363	 An acidic sequence of a putative yeast Golgi membrane protein binds COPII and facilitates ER export.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	364	 Intracellular turnover of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	365	 Inefficient processing and rapid degradation of wild-type and mutant proteins.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	366	 The mammalian guanine nucleotide exchange factor mSec12 is essential for activation of the Sar1 GTPase directing endoplasmic reticulum export.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	367	 Evidence that endoplasmic reticulum (ER)-associated degradation of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator is linked to retrograde translocation from the ER membrane.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	368	 Non-conventional trafficking of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator through the early secretory pathway.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	369	 Cysteine string protein interacts with and modulates the maturation of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	370	Export in cystic fibrosis Nicole LeBrasseur J.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	0	A Principal Role for the Proteasome in Endoplasmic Reticulum-associated Degradation of Misfolded Intracellular Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator* Marina S.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Department of Biological Sciences, Stanford University, Stanford, California 94305-5020.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received for publication, December 14, 2001, and in revised form, January 16, 2002.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	3	    ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	4	Endoplasmic reticulum-associated degradation of misfolded cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein is known to involve the ubiquitin-proteasome system.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	5	 In addition, an ATP-independent proteolytic system has been suggested to operate in parallel with this pathway and become up-regulated when proteasomes are inhibited (Jensen, T.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	6	 In this study, we use two independent techniques, pulse-chase labeling and a noninvasive fluorescence cell-based assay, to investigate the proteolytic pathways underlying the degradation of misfolded CFTR.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Here we report that only inhibitors of the proteasome have a significant effect on preventing the degradation of CFTR, whereas cell-permeable inhibitors of lysosomal degradation, autophagy, and several classes of protease had no measurable effect on CFTR degradation, when used either alone or in combination with the specific proteasome inhibitor carbobenzoxy-L-leucyl-leucyl-L-leucinal (MG132).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Our results suggest that ubiquitin-proteasome-mediated degradation is the dominant pathway for disposal of misfolded CFTR in mammalian cells and provide new mechanistic insight into endoplasmic reticulum-associated degradation.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	9	     INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	10	The endoplasmic reticulum (ER)1 is the site of synthesis of membrane and secretory proteins and the site of their conformational maturation and assembly into correctly folded functional molecules.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	11	 "Quality control" refers to the system that monitors the folding and assembly of proteins in the ER, ensuring that only correctly folded proteins can mature to later compartments of the secretory pathway (1, 2).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Nascent proteins that fail to fold or assemble in the ER are degraded by a process known as ER-associated degradation (ERAD) (3).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Studies in mammalian cells and in yeast have led to the formulation of a general model for ERAD in which substrates are degraded by cytoplasmic proteasomes following retrotranslocation (i.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	14	 "dislocation") across the ER membrane by a process that requires the Sec61 translocon and functional ubiquitylation machinery at the cytosolic face of the ER membrane (4-6).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Dislocation of ERAD substrates across the ER membrane is kinetically coupled to their degradation by proteasomes, and in many cases, cytosolic intermediates of degradation are hard to detect (7, 8).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Although a central role for proteasomes in ERAD is widely accepted, a number of studies have suggested that other, nonproteasomal, proteolytic systems may also contribute to the elimination of misfolded proteins from the ER (9-12).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	17	The polytopic membrane protein cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) is a chloride channel expressed at the apical surface of polarized epithelial cells and one of the first integral membrane proteins demonstrated to be a substrate of the ubiquitin-proteasome system (9, 13).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Mutations in the CFTR gene cause the recessively inherited fatal disease cystic fibrosis.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Although nearly 1000 mutations have been linked to cystic fibrosis, the majority of Caucasian cystic fibrosis patients have at least one copy of the F508 mutation, a temperature-sensitive allele that is unable to fold correctly at physiological temperature.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	20	 As a consequence, F508 CFTR (F508) is not deployed to the plasma membrane and is instead rapidly degraded without being processed in the Golgi apparatus (14, 15).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	21	Several lines of evidence support a role for the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway in F508 turnover.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	22	 First, CFTR undergoes both co-translational and posttranslational ubiquitylation when expressed in a cell-free system (16, 17).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Second, inhibition of proteasome function with chemical inhibitors or with a dominant negative form of ubiquitin leads to accumulation of multiubiquitylated, undegraded forms of CFTR and F508 (13).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Third, degradation of F508 in a cell-free system is sensitive to inhibitors of both the 19 S and 20 S subunits of the proteasome (17, 18).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Curiously, despite this compelling evidence in support of a role for proteasomes in the degradation of misfolded CFTR, the effect of proteasome inhibition on the disappearance of F508 from pulse-chase studies is minimal (9, 13).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	26	 This observation has led some investigators to conclude that other proteolytic systems are primarily responsible for the ERAD of misfolded CFTR molecules (9).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	27	 However, no other proteases or proteolytic systems have been convincingly demonstrated to contribute to the degradation of CFTR or other ERAD substrates.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Therefore, the intracellular fate of F508 and the identity of the proteases that participate in its degradation remain unresolved.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	29	In this study, we used a reporter (GFP-F508) consisting of a fusion of GFP with F508 (19) to assess the participation of proteasomes and other proteolytic systems in F508 degradation.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Our data establish that proteolytic activities of the proteasome are responsible for vast majority of intracellular degradation of misfolded CFTR molecules.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	31	     EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	32	Reagents-- Most chemicals (with the exception of some proteasome inhibitors) were obtained from Sigma Chemical Co.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Epoxomicin and carbobenzoxy-L-leucyl-leucyl-L-leucinal (MG132) were obtained from Calbiochem.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	34	 YU102 was generously provided by Dr.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Graig Crews (Yale University, New Haven, CT).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Polyclonal anti-GFP antibody was a kind gift from Dr.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Michael Rexach (Stanford University).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	38	Constructs and Cell Lines-- pGFP-CFTR in a pEGFP-C1 vector (CLONTECH) was obtained from Dr.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Stanton (Dartmouth Medical School, Hanover, NH) and subsequently subcloned into pcDNA3.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	40	1 vector (Invitrogen) using NheI and EcoRV.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	41	 F508 mutation was introduced by replacing the [Pml1-Blp1] cassette within the CFTR sequence.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	42	 For selection of stable CHO cell lines, GFP-F508/pcDNA3 plasmid was linearized and transfected into CHO cells by calcium phosphate precipitation.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	43	 The cells were subjected to selection in G418-containing medium.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Stable transfectants were expanded in culture and enriched for GFP-F508-expressing cells by fluorescence-activated cell sorting of highly fluorescent cells after overnight incubation of these cells with the proteasome inhibitor N-acetyl-L-leucinyl-L-leucinyl-L-norleucinal.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Cells were then cloned into 96-well dishes at a density of 1 cell/well.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Clonal cell lines were expanded and analyzed for full-length GFP-F508 expression by immunoblotting, and a single clone (clone 2) was selected for this study.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Generation of human embryonic kidney HEK293 cells stably expressing GFPu was described elsewhere (20).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	48	35S Labeling and Immunoprecipitation-- CHO clone 2 cells were plated on 10  x  10-cm dishes and treated with 5 mM butyrate overnight to increase GFP-F508 expression.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	49	 The next day, cells were starved in cysteine/methionine-free media for 30 min and then labeled with [35S]cysteine/methionine (specific activity, 1 mCi/ml) for 30 min in the presence of 5 mM butyrate.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Two 10-cm dishes were harvested immediately after the pulse (t = 0 h), whereas the remaining dishes were chased in the presence of the protein synthesis inhibitor emetine (75  microM) or emetine and MG132 (25  microM) together.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	51	 At specified time intervals, cells were solubilized in buffer A (10 mM Tris, pH 7.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	52	5, 5 mM EDTA, 150 mM NaCl, 1% NP-40, 0.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	53	05% deoxycholate) containing a CompleteTM protease inhibitor mixture (Roche Diagnostics GmbH) for 30 min.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Cell lysates were precleared with protein A-Sepharose beads and incubated with anti-GFP antibody and protein A-Sepharose.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The immunoprecipitates were washed extensively with buffer A and fractionated by 4-15% gradient SDS-PAGE (Bio-Rad).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Quantitation of radioactive bands was done using PhosphorImager SI and ImageQuant software (Molecular Dynamics).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	57	Fluorescence-activated Cell-sorting Assay-- Analysis of GFP-F508 CFTR fluorescence by flow cytometry was performed using Coulter  Epics  XL-MCL Flow Cytometer and EXPO v.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Cells were typically incubated with 5 mM butyrate overnight to increase GFP-F508 CFTR expression or with 10  microg/ml N-acetyl-L-leucinyl-L-leucinyl-L-norleucinal for 3 h to increase GFPu steady-state level.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	59	 After the addition of emetine with or without protease inhibitors, cultures were incubated for different time intervals before analysis.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Data from 10,000 cells were collected, and the mean fluorescence of the cell population was used as a measure of GFP-F508 levels after each treatment.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	61	2 cells expressing GFP-F508 and HEK293 cells expressing GFPu were ATP-depleted by incubating the cells in glucose-free medium (Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium; Invitrogen) containing the metabolic inhibitors cyanide (5 mM) and 2-deoxy-D-glucose (5 mM) as described previously (21).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	62	 This procedure reduces ATP content below 10% of the baseline value within 10 min and sustains this low level of ATP content (22).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Based on this determination, the initial fluorescence measurement in ATP-depleted cells (t = 0 h) was taken at 10 min after exposure of cells to metabolic inhibitors.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	64	     RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	65	Effect of Proteasome Inhibitors on GFP-F508 Degradation in Metabolic Pulse-chase Analysis-- To validate the use of GFP-F508 as a model of F508 degradation, we performed pulse-chase analysis in a clonal CHO cell line (cl.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	66	2) stably expressing this fusion protein.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	67	2 cells were selected for low basal expression levels to avoid accumulation of GFP-F508 in detergent-insoluble aggresomes, which are highly refractory to degradation (23).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Before use, the cells were treated with the transcriptional activator sodium butyrate to increase GFP-F508 expression.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Under these conditions, aggregation of GFP-F508 was undetectable by either immunoblot or fluorescence microscopy (data not shown).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Immunoprecipitation of metabolically labeled cell lysates with anti-GFP antibody revealed a major Mr ~170,000 band corresponding to core-glycosylated GFP-F508 and high molecular weight (HMW) species migrating near the top of the gel (Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	71	 During the chase, the Mr 170,000 band disappeared with first-order kinetics (t1/2 = 50 min), consistent with previous determinations of F508 (9, 24, 25) and GFP-F508 half-life (23).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	72	 In the presence of MG132, a specific proteasome inhibitor (26), the half-life of this species was only modestly extended (t1/2 = 1.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	73	 A minor band migrating at Mr ~50,000 probably corresponds to an amino-terminal fragment of the GFP-508 fusion protein comprising Mr ~20,000 of CFTR in addition to the GFP moiety because it reacted with antibody to GFP, but not with an antibody raised against the carboxyl terminus of CFTR (data not shown).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Disappearance of the Mr 50,000 fragment paralleled that of the Mr 170,000 band (t1/2 = 1.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	75	1 h) and was also only modestly inhibited by MG132 (t1/2 = 1.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	76	 HMW forms of GFP-F508 were detected immediately after the pulse (top band in Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	77	 These complexes disappeared rapidly when the chase was conducted in the absence of proteasome inhibitor (t1/2 = 0.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	78	9 h), but in contrast to the core-glycosylated protein and the Mr 50,000 fragment, they were strongly stabilized by the presence of MG132 (t1/2 = 6.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	79	View larger version (59K):    Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	80	   Pulse-chase analysis of GFP-F508 CFTR degradation.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	81	 A, butyrate-treated CHO cells were labeled with [35S]cysteine/methionine and chased for the indicated time intervals in the presence or absence of MG132 (25  microM).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Cells were then solubilized, and lysates were immunoprecipitated with anti-GFP antibody as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	83	" B, quantitation of individual bands and total radioactivity in each lane was performed using ImageQuant software.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Filled symbols represent cells that were chased without MG132, and open symbols represent cells chased in the presence of 25  microM MG132.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	85	 The insets show semilog plots of these data.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	86	 In the insets, solid and broken lines represent cells chased without or with MG132, respectively.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	87	The HMW complexes could represent either polyubiquitylated forms of monomeric GFP-F508 (16, 17) or detergent-insoluble aggregates of CFTR (23).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	88	 To distinguish between these possibilities, we sought to determine whether the HMW material that accumulated during the chase in the presence of MG132 could be degraded after washout of the inhibitor.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Our results (data not shown) indicate that the HMW material was soluble in nonionic detergent and competent for degradation, strongly suggesting that the increase in molecular weight was due to covalent modification with Ub, as observed previously for CFTR in cell-free extracts (17).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	90	Quantification of the pulse-chase data indicates that MG132 was only marginally effective at stabilizing the Mr 170,000 F508 band.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Even when the total amount of GFP-immunoreactive material is considered (the sum of all electrophoretic species, Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	92	 1B, bottom right panel), only 40% of the initial amount of GFP-F508 was stable at the end of a 4-h chase, despite proteasome inhibition.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	93	 This observation suggests several plausible explanations.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	94	 First, as suggested by Jensen et al.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	95	 (9), in addition to proteasomes, other proteolytic systems could also contribute to F508 ERAD.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Alternatively, it is possible that some proteolytic activities within the proteasome remain uninhibited in the presence of MG132 and continue to degrade the substrate.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Finally, immunoprecipitation of radiolabeled material from detergent extracts of pulse-labeled cells may underestimate the amount of stable F508 if some of the protein becomes insoluble, if the epitope used for immunoprecipitation becomes inaccessible, or if the increased molecular weight (due to polyubiquitylation and/or aggregation) of the protein prevents it from being well resolved by SDS-PAGE.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	98	 We reasoned that a noninvasive method of monitoring the fluorescence of GFP-F508 in intact cells using fluorescence-activated cell-sorting analysis may be a more accurate way to measure protein stability because it does not rely upon efficient recovery of radiolabeled protein from cells or upon the detection of a resolvable electrophoretic species.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	99	 This would in turn allow us to better evaluate the effect of protease inhibitors on prevention of CFTR degradation.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	100	Fluorescence-based Determination of GFP-F508 Degradation-- To circumvent the limitations of the pulse-chase approach, we developed a fluorescence-based assay to measure degradation of GFP-F508.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Inhibition of GFP-F508 synthesis in butyrate-treated cells with emetine, an inhibitor of translational elongation, caused a rapid decrease in mean fluorescence, as measured by flow cytometry (Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Similar results were obtained with other translation inhibitors including cycloheximide and puromycin (data not shown).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Emetine does not affect the degradation kinetics of CFTR or F508 (13).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	104	 The decrease in GFP-F508 fluorescence fitted a first-order exponential with a t1/2 = 60 min, in good agreement with the GFP-F508 half-life measured in pulse-chase experiments (Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	105	 In a control experiment, CHO cells expressing GFP alone were incubated with emetine for up to 10 h without any loss of total fluorescence (data not shown), consistent with GFP being a stable protein (20) and indicating that emetine treatment does not cause detectable cell lysis during the course of the experiment.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Together, these results suggest that the decline in the fluorescence of cl.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	107	2 cells upon exposure to protein synthesis inhibitor faithfully reflects the degradation of F508 and constitutes a valid and convenient method for characterization of this degradation process.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	108	View larger version (17K):    Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	109	   Fluorescence-based measurement of F508 CFTR degradation rate.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Butyrate-treated cells were incubated with 75  microM emetine for the indicated time intervals, and cellular fluorescence was measured by flow cytometry.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	111	 The mean fluorescence of 10,000 cells was determined at each time point and represented as a percentage of initial fluorescence.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	112	 The inset shows a semilog plot of fluorescence decline versus time in emetine, from which the half-time of fluorescence decline was calculated.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	113	Inhibition of GFP-F508 Degradation by Proteasome Inhibitors-- To assess the effect of inhibition of different proteolytic systems on the degradation of mutant CFTR using the fluorescence assay, we evaluated the effect of a panel of protease inhibitors on the decline in GFP-F508 fluorescence in butyrate-treated cl.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	114	2 cells in the presence of emetine (Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Among the inhibitors tested, only those that are known to inhibit the proteasome (N-acetyl-L-leucinyl-L-leucinyl-L-norleucinal, clasto-lactacystin -lactone, and MG132) significantly slowed the degradation of GFP-F508.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	116	 In contrast, inhibitors of serine and cysteine proteases (TPCK, N-tosyl-Lys-chloromethyl ketone, and phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride), calpains (EDTA), lysosomal cathepsins ((2S,3S)-trans-epoxysuccinyl-L-leucylamido-3-methylbutane ethyl ester, chloroquine, and NH4Cl), and autophagy (3-methyladenine and wortmannin) had no measurable effect on the degradation process, either alone (Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	117	 3A) or in combination with MG132 (25  microM) (data not shown).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	118	 These data confirm a central role for proteasomes in the degradation of F508 and suggest that other major proteolytic systems do not contribute significantly to this process.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	119	View larger version (28K):    Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	120	   Effect of protease inhibitors on GFP-F508 fluorescence.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	121	2 cells were treated with 5 mM butyrate overnight and incubated for 4 h with emetine alone (75  microM) or with emetine and one of the following protease inhibitors: N-acetyl-L-leucinyl-L-leucinyl-L-norleucinal (ALLN; 10  microg/ml), (2S,3S)-trans-epoxysuccinyl-L-leucylamido-3-methylbutane ethyl ester (EST; 10  microM), -lactone (25  microM); EDTA (2 mM), chloroquine (150  microM), NH4Cl (10 mM), MG132 (25  microM), N-tosyl-Lys-chloromethyl ketone (TLCK; 2  microg/ml), 3-methyladenine (3-MA; 10 mM), TPCK (2  microg/ml), and wortmannin (100 nM).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Fluorescence at the end of 4 h was expressed as a percentage of initial fluorescence at t = 0, after subtraction of background fluorescence (CHO cell autofluorescence).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	123	 B, CHO clone 2 cells expressing GFP-F508 (solid line) or HEK293 cells expressing GFPu (broken line) were incubated with 75  microM emetine ( or , respectively) or with 75  microM emetine and 25  microM MG132 ( or , respectively) for the indicated time intervals.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Mean cellular fluorescence was expressed as a percentage of initial fluorescence at t = 0 h, after subtraction of background fluorescence.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	125	In the presence of MG132 (25  microM), the fluorescence of GFP-F508 first increased, reaching almost 120% of the initial fluorescence after 1 h of emetine chase (Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	126	 This increase probably reflects slow fluorogenesis of the GFP moiety (t1/2 = 30-90 min; 27, 28) in the absence of CFTR degradation.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Indeed, this transient increase in fluorescence is also observed with GFPu, a GFP molecule that is targeted to the ubiquitin-proteasome system for degradation via a short carboxyl-terminal degron (20) (Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	128	 However, in contrast to GFPu, which was completely stabilized by 25  microM MG132, the fluorescence of GFP-F508 started to decline after the first hour and dropped to about 70% of initial fluorescence after 4 h of emetine chase.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	129	 The half-time of the decline of GFP-F508 fluorescence in the presence of MG132 (25  microM) was 6.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	130	8 h, indicating that proteasome inhibition results in substantial stabilization of GFP-F508.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	131	To determine whether the continued decline in GFP-F508 fluorescence in the presence of MG132 was due to degradation by the proteasome, we examined the effect of increased inhibitor concentration on the fluorescence remaining at the 4 h chase point (Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	132	 These data suggest that GFP-F508 degradation is inhibited by MG132 biphasically with a high-affinity component (IC50  10  microM) and a low-affinity component that we were not able to saturate, even at concentrations as high as 300  microM.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	133	View larger version (17K):    Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	134	   Dose dependence of proteasome inhibitors in the fluorescence assay.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	135	 A, fluorescence of butyrate-treated CHO cl.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	136	2 cells was measured at 4 h after the addition of emetine and the indicated concentrations of MG132 and expressed as a percentage of the initial fluorescence at t = 0 h.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Values represent the average of three experiments.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	138	2 cells were incubated with emetine alone () or emetine plus the following concentrations of epoxomicin: 1  microM (), 5  microM (), 10  microM (), 20  microM (), and 50  microM ().
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Inset, rate constants of GFP-F508 degradation were calculated and plotted as a function of epoxomicin concentration.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	140	2 cells were incubated with increasing concentrations of epoxomicin in the absence () or presence () of 500  microM YU102.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Values represent the average of three separate experiments + S.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	142	To further investigate the role of proteasomes in GFP-F508 degradation, we performed a titration of epoxomicin, a highly specific and potent proteasome inhibitor (29).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Like MG132, epoxomicin inhibited GFP-F508 fluorescence decay biphasically with a high-affinity component (IC50  <  1  microM) and a low-affinity component (Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Although epoxomicin can inhibit all three of the characterized activities of the proteasomes, it is 66- and 500- fold more effective at inhibiting the chymotrypsin-like (CT-L) activity than the trypsin-like or peptidyl-glutamyl hydrolyzing activities, respectively (30).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	145	 To investigate whether the low-affinity component of the MG132 and epoxomicin titrations was due to non-CT-L activities, we performed a titration of epoxomicin in the presence of 500  microM YU102, an ','-epoxyketone inhibitor that is selective for the peptidyl-glutamyl hydrolyzing activity of the proteasome (30).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	146	 This treatment resulted in a small (10-15%) but significant increase in the degree of inhibition of GFP-F508 fluorescence decay at all epoxomicin concentrations (Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	147	 These results suggest that the CT-L and peptidyl-glutamyl hydrolyzing activities of the proteasome may contribute independently to the degradation of GFP-F508.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	148	A hallmark of proteolysis by the Ub-proteasome system is its dependence on ATP hydrolysis.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	149	 ATP is required for at least two steps in Ub-dependent degradation: activation of Ub, and substrate unfolding (31, 32).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	150	 However, previous studies suggested that the fraction of CFTR degradation that is insensitive to proteasome inhibitors is independent of ATP (9).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	151	 To assess the dependence of GFP-F508 degradation on ATP, we assayed GFP-F508 fluorescence in ATP-depleted cl.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	152	 These data demonstrate that GFP-F508 degradation is absolutely dependent on the presence of cellular ATP.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	153	 The degradation of GFPu was similarly dependent upon ATP (Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	154	View larger version (16K):    Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	155	   Effect of ATP depletion on GFP-F508 and GFPu degradation.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	156	2 cells expressing GFP-F508 (A) or HEK293 cells expressing GFPu (B) were subjected to emetine chase for up to 4 h in either high-glucose medium () or glucose-free medium containing 5 mM cyanide and 5 mM 2-deoxy-D-glucose ().
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Each data point represents an average of three separate experiments + S.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	158	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	159	ER-associated degradation is a central element of the quality control pathways that ensure that only correctly folded and assembled proteins are deployed in the secretory pathway of eukaryotic cells.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Although many studies have confirmed a primary role of the Ub-proteasome system in ERAD, the apparently minimal effect of highly potent proteasome inhibitors on the degradation of CFTR has remained an enigma and has suggested that other ATP-independent proteolytic systems also contribute to ERAD.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	161	 In this study, we have used a fluorescent substrate to re-evaluate the role of the UPS in ERAD.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Our data establish the primacy of the UPS in the degradation of ER-associated misfolded CFTR and suggest that the different proteolytic functionalities of the proteasome, associated with the three active -subunits, may operate independently in the degradation of an ERAD substrate (GFP-F508), but apparently not in the degradation of a cytoplasmic substrate (GFPu).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Three lines of evidence support our conclusion that the UPS is the principal pathway for degradation of misfolded CFTR.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	164	 First, proteasome inhibitors, but not inhibitors of serine or cysteine proteases or inhibitors of lysosomal or autophagic pathways, strongly stabilize GFP-F508 fluorescence.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Second, GFP-F508 degradation was inhibited by MG132 and epoxomicin in a dose-dependent fashion, with biphasic apparent IC50 values in the expected range for CT-L and non-CT-L activities (30).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Third, GFP-F508 degradation was strictly dependent on ATP, a hallmark of UPS-mediated proteolysis (31, 32).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	167	 The possibility that other proteases initiate the clipping of the CFTR molecule while it is situated in the ER membrane, followed by proteasome-mediated proteolysis, is also unlikely because simultaneous addition of protease and proteasome inhibitors did not protect CFTR from degradation.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Although our results do not rule out participation in CFTR degradation of protease classes for which cell-permeable inhibitors are not available (i.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	169	 aspartic proteases, aminopeptidases, and so forth) or of substrate-specific proteases (e.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	170	 colligin is a specific inhibitor of procollagen degradation (33)), these data establish that inhibition of proteolytic activities of the proteasome alone is sufficient to prevent the degradation of the majority of F508 molecules in living cells.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	171	In previous studies using metabolic pulse-chase labeling and immunoprecipitation, proteasome inhibitors including MG132 and lactacystin had a very modest effect at inhibiting the decay of the electrophoretic species corresponding to core-glycosylated F508 degradation (9, 13).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	172	 In the present work, we show that at least part of radiolabel lost from core-glycosylated GFP-F508 could be recovered as high molecular weight material.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Because this HMW material remains competent for degradation, our data suggest that in the absence of proteasome function, a significant fraction of radiolabeled GFP-F508 molecules are converted to multiubiquitylated forms.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Accumulation of HMW forms in the presence of proteasome inhibition is not observed for most other ERAD substrates such as the -subunit of the T-cell receptor (7, 34) and soluble proteins such as IgG light chains (8), which tend to accumulate as core-glycosylated detergent-soluble monomers in the ER after proteasome inhibition.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	175	 It is likely that this difference is a consequence of the topology of CFTR, in which most of the mass of the protein is accessible to the cytoplasmic face of the ER and hence to components of the ubiquitin conjugation system.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	176	 A recent study reported that inhibition of proteasome function leads to accumulation of a substantial fraction of CFTR in reconstituted cell-free extracts as high molecular weight multiubiquitylated protein (17).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	177	In our studies, no proteasome inhibitor or combination thereof was able to completely suppress the decay of GFP-F508 fluorescence.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	178	 It is unlikely that this apparent degradation (a ~20-30% decrease of fluorescence after a 4-h chase in the presence of proteasome inhibitors) is the result of cell death due to toxic effects of simultaneous exposure to emetine and proteasome inhibitor because  > 98% of cells were able to exclude propidium iodide staining at the end of a 4-h chase.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Alternatively, the decrease in GFP-F508 fluorescence could, in principle, be due to self-quenching of GFP fluorescence in closely packed aggregates of GFP-F508, which are known to form upon chronic exposure to proteasome inhibitors (23).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Such self-quenching is a form of fluorescence resonance energy transfer (fluorescence resonance energy transfer homotransfer).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Because we do not observe heterotransfer between the compatible fluorescence resonance energy transfer heterotransfer pair CFP-F508 and YFP-F508, even under conditions designed to maximize aggregation,2 it is unlikely that homotransfer between adjacent GFP-F508 molecules could account for the observed decrease in fluorescence.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	182	 It is also formally possible that the small decrease in GFP-F508 fluorescence could be due to partial unfolding of the GFP moiety by the ATPase activity of the 19 S proteasome cap, without actual degradation of CFTR itself.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	183	 However, the simplest explanation may be that none of the proteasome inhibitors used, alone or in combination, are able to fully inhibit all of the three proteasomal -subunits.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	184	 This explanation is consistent with conversion of a similar fraction (~30%) of labeled GFP-F508 as high molecular weight multiubiquitin conjugates in the presence of MG132 in both our pulse-labeling experiments (Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	185	 1) and in the cell-free experiments of Oberdorf et al.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	186	 It is likely, therefore, that the proteolytic activities of the proteasome associated with individual -subunits do not act in a strictly cooperative fashion in ERAD.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Our findings with GFP-F508 in vivo are consistent with those of Oberdorf et al.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	188	 (18), who found that complete inhibition of the 5-subunit (associated with CT-L activity) led to only a 40% reduction in cell-free CFTR degradation, and with those of Myung et al.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	189	 (30), who reported recently that selective peptidyl-glutamyl hydrolyzing inhibition is insufficient to inhibit protein degradation in vivo.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	190	 These data all strongly indicate that the catalytic sites of the proteasome function independently.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	191	 It is not clear why, in our studies, the degradation of GFPu, a small soluble substrate of the UPS, is completely inhibited by MG132, whereas degradation of GFP-F508 is not.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Perhaps this discrepancy is a reflection of functional differences in the mechanisms by which proteasomes engage substrates delivered from the cytosol and those that are dislocated across the ER membrane.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	193	We thank Neil Bence for providing HEK293 cells expressing GFPu and Karim Helmy for help with epoxomicin and ATP depletion experiments.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Craig Crews for a kind gift of YU102.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	195	 We also thank members of the Kopito laboratory for helpful comments.

0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	241	Copyright   2002 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	0	The role of regulated CFTR trafficking in epithelial secretion Carol A.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	1	Department of Cell Biology and Physiology, University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15261.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	2	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT CFTR LOCALIZATION IN CELLS REGULATED CFTR TRAFFIC MECHANISMS OF REGULATED CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	3	 CONSEQUENCES OF REGULATED CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	4	 SUMMARY APPENDIX REFERENCES   The focus of this review is the regulated trafficking of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) in distal compartments of the protein secretory pathway and the question of how changes in CFTR cellular distribution may impact on the functions of polarized epithelial cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	5	 We summarize data concerning the cellular localization and activity of CFTR and attempt to synthesize often conflicting results from functional studies of regulated endocytosis and exocytosis in CFTR-expressing cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	6	 In some instances, findings that are inconsistent with regulated CFTR trafficking may result from the use of overexpression systems or nonphysiological experimental conditions.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Nevertheless, judging from data on other transporters, an appropriate cellular context is necessary to support regulated CFTR trafficking, even in epithelial cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	8	 The discovery that disease mutations can influence CFTR trafficking in distal secretory and recycling compartments provides support for the concept that regulated CFTR recycling contributes to normal epithelial function, including the control of apical CFTR channel density and epithelial protein secretion.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Finally, we propose molecular mechanisms for regulated CFTR endocytosis and exocytosis that are based on CFTR interactions with other proteins, particularly those whose primary function is membrane trafficking.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	10	 These models provide testable hypotheses that may lead to elucidation of CFTR trafficking mechanisms and permit their experimental manipulation in polarized epithelial cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	11	cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator; membrane traffic; chloride channel; protein secretion.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	12	THE CYSTIC FIBROSIS TRANSMEMBRANE CONDUCTANCE REGULATOR (CFTR) is responsible for the cAMP-activated anion conductance of epithelial cell apical membranes.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	13	 As a principal apical conductance pathway, the CFTR anion channel is involved in cAMP-dependent Cl and bicarbonate secretion in airway and intestinal epithelia and exocrine glands.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	14	 It also influences the activity of other conductive pathways, through either linked regulatory interactions or electrochemical coupling that influences the driving forces for ion transport (49, 93).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Subsequent to the cloning of the CFTR gene, methods for in situ hybridization and the development of antibodies to CFTR permitted the characterization of its distribution in a variety of tissues (52, 104, 107).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The results generally correlated with the presence of cAMP/PKA-stimulated anion secretory processes in various epithelial tissues, identified in earlier studies using physiological methods.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Mutations in the gene encoding CFTR produce cystic fibrosis (CF), whereas hyperactivity of this transport pathway underlies secretory diarrheas.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	18	 CF disease arises from a reduced density and/or activity of CFTR in the apical membranes of secretory epithelial cells, such as those in the airways, exocrine pancreas, salivary glands, reproductive tissues, and intestines.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	19	 A regulated CFTR conductance pathway is also important for the normal functions of several absorptive cells, including epithelia lining the airway surface and sweat gland ducts (for a general review, see Ref.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	20	The subject of this review is CFTR trafficking in the distal portion of the protein secretory pathway, which lies between the trans-Golgi network and the plasma membrane.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Historically, studies of this pathway were motivated by the question of whether it would be possible to explain all of the manifestations of CF disease on the basis of a missing anion conductance at the apical membranes of epithelial cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Accordingly, functional roles for CFTR other than its primary role as an apical membrane anion conductance pathway have been proposed to contribute to CF pathology.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	23	 These include disease-associated changes in regulated protein secretion (65), the chemistry of macromolecular secretions (22, 33, 90), and the properties of the airway microenvironment that lead to bacterial colonization of CF airways (89).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	24	Although the attention of numerous investigators has focused on CFTR trafficking through the distal protein secretory pathway as a possible contributor to the complexity of CF disease, a consensus regarding the importance of intracellular CFTR function and the process of regulated CFTR trafficking within this subcellular domain has yet to emerge.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	25	 As an integral membrane protein, CFTR will reside at least transiently in all compartments of the protein secretory pathway as it migrates toward the cell surface.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Thus one can expect to find CFTR in membranes of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), Golgi, and endosomal and lysosomal compartments of epithelial cells (Fig.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Although there is no question that CFTR channels function as a regulated conductance pathway when they are resident in the apical membrane, numerous studies (see CFTR LOCALIZATION IN CELLS) have also indicated that a significant quantity of mature (i.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	28	, post-Golgi) CFTR is contained within intracellular compartments, that CFTR within these compartments is functional (9, 78), and that cAMP stimulation can modulate the distribution of CFTR between these compartments and the plasma membrane (see REGULATED CFTR TRAFFIC).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Therefore, the issue is not whether apical Cl conductance is due to regulation of the gating of membrane-resident CFTR channels or whether it results from the insertion of CFTR channels into the membrane, because both processes occur.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	30	 We want to know to what extent these forms of CFTR regulation are linked mechanistically and how trafficking of CFTR contributes to the overall conductance response.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	31	View larger version (36K):    Fig.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Intracellular locations of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) during maturation, plasma membrane insertion, and degradation.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Properly folded, nascent CFTR leaves the rough endoplasmic reticulum and travels through the Golgi, where it undergoes glycosylation to mature (band C) protein.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Mature CFTR leaves the Golgi in vesicles that can travel directly to the apical plasma membrane or to the recycling endosome.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	35	 CFTR-containing vesicles continually traffic between recycling endosomes and plasma membrane, with rates of trafficking and protein distribution determined by cell type, differentiation, and phosphorylation conditions.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	36	 CFTR eventually follows the late endosome-to-lysosome pathway for degradation.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Misfolded CFTR mutants and significant wild-type nascent CFTRs are degraded by the proteosome.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	38	This area of CFTR cell biology has been among the most contentious and unresolved subjects in CF research, and it continues to be so.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	39	 In a relatively recent review of this subject, Bradbury (10) argued that disparate conclusions regarding the regulation of the distribution of CFTR between plasma membrane and intracellular compartments might be reconciled if regulated CFTR trafficking was a property specific to epithelial cells, i.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	40	, studies showing a lack of CFTR trafficking were generally performed in fibroblasts.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Nevertheless, four years after the Bradbury review, the literature has not been clarified.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Accordingly, the task of bringing some synthesis to this conflicting data set is not an easy one.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Yet, we feel that it is possible to do so and that the attempt should add to our understanding of the control of plasma membrane CFTR density, a critical issue in CF disease.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	44	   CFTR LOCALIZATION IN CELLS TOP ABSTRACT CFTR LOCALIZATION IN CELLS REGULATED CFTR TRAFFIC MECHANISMS OF REGULATED CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	45	 CONSEQUENCES OF REGULATED CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	46	 SUMMARY APPENDIX REFERENCES   This review is primarily concerned with the steadystate distribution of CFTR between plasma membrane and intracellular compartments and with the effect of cAMP/PKA-mediated stimulation on its distribution.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	47	 The methods used to determine cellular CFTR localization have relied primarily on its detection by antibodies in cultured cells or tissue sections.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Other studies have employed functional assays subsequent to cell fractionation, and others have relied on the expression of epitope-tagged or green fluorescent protein (GFP)-CFTR fusion proteins as a method of locating exogenously expressed CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Cellular targets for these studies have included both polarized and non-polar cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Detection of a reliable CFTR signal has often required overexpression of this normally low-abundance protein in heterologous systems.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	51	Location of mature CFTR (band C).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	52	 From a biochemical standpoint, the prevailing view is that core-glycosylated, immature (band B) CFTR is localized in the ER, whereas complex glycosylated, mature (band C) CFTR is present primarily in compartments distal to the Golgi, including the apical membrane.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	53	 In contrast with many heterologous expression systems, relatively little band B is observed by immunoblot in most epithelial cells expressing CFTR endogenously at steady state.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	54	 For example, the ratio of band C to B in Calu-3 airway cells is 10 (100).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	55	 This indicates that most of the CFTR expressed endogenously in epithelial cells is located in distal compartments of the protein secretory pathway.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The first reported studies of CFTR localization, performed in COS-7 cells transiently expressing CFTR, showed a weak, diffuse plasma membrane staining pattern.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Most of the signal was intracellular, probably due to protein overexpression (23).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	58	 In polarized epithelial cells that express CFTR endogenously (T84, HT29, Caco-2, and airway epithelia), this signal was located unambiguously at the apical membrane domain (27, 28).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	59	 No staining was detected in the basolateral membrane, and little perinuclear staining of CFTR was observed in epithelial monolayers, implying that little CFTR is present in the ER at steady state (consistent with the low levels of band B).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	60	 (27) highlighted the importance of localizing CFTR within epithelial cells that express the protein endogenously.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	61	 In the same study, a mostly intracellular location of exogenously expressed CFTR was found in non-polar HeLa and 3T3 cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	62	 The central question concerning the issue of regulated CFTR trafficking is whether the protein that contributes to the plasma membrane anion conductance is present strictly in the apical plasma membranes of epithelial cells or whether it is present also in a subapical, post-Golgi compartment from which it is mobilized to the cell surface during stimulation.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	63	 A related issue is whether CFTR is stable in the plasma membrane or undergoes recycling to intracellular compartments.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	64	 In this regard, a rapid rate of CFTR endocytosis from the cell surface has been observed in both epithelial and nonepithelial systems (13, 61, 85).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	65	 These studies used biotinylation procedures to monitor the rate of CFTR internalization from the cell surface.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	66	 In T84 cells, it was estimated that 50% of cell surface CFTR is retrieved within a few minutes (85); in Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells the internalization rate was 5% per minute (61).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	67	 These rates of endocytosis are not different from those of constitutively recycling receptors, such as those for transferrin or LDL.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	68	 These findings, together with the estimated 24- to 48-h half-life of mature, plasma membrane CFTR (7, 41), indicate that virtually all of the CFTR that is internalized by endocytosis must be returned to the plasma membrane by a recycling/exocytic pathway.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	69	 The presence of this rapid CFTR recycling pathway is a minimal requirement for a regulated insertion-retrieval model that controls cellular CFTR distribution.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Thus the question should not be whether CFTR undergoes trafficking at the plasma membrane but whether this process contributes to a change in the distribution of CFTR between plasma membrane and intracellular compartments in response to cAMP/PKA regulation.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	71	In addition to these kinetic considerations, the presence of CFTR in endosomes under steady-state conditions has been established with the use of a combination of biochemical techniques and functional assays that rely on CFTR's anion channel activity.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	72	 (12) resolved CFTR in the early stages of endosomal retrieval within clathrin-coated vesicles from epithelial cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	73	 CFTR was demonstrated to be present in this compartment by immunoblot.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	74	 After removal of the clathrin lattice by uncoatase and fusion of the resulting membranes with planar lipid bilayers, currents with biophysical and regulatory properties characteristic of CFTR were observed.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Because clathrin removal was a necessary prerequisite for reconstitution, CFTR was definitely a component of this endocytic compartment.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Additional studies have demonstrated that the rapid endocytosis of CFTR from the cell surface depends on clathrin-mediated pathways and that CFTR is not significantly internalized into caveolae (11, 85).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Several transport and/or channel proteins have been found to internalize via clathrin-dependent endocytosis, including aquaporin-2 (AQP-2) (101), Na/H exchanger 3 (NHE3) (24), renal outer medulla K channels (ROMK) (114), and epithelial Na channels (ENaC) (96).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Recent studies of the mechanism of CFTR endocytosis (see Functional studies of endocytosis) indicate a direct physical interaction of CFTR with the plasma membrane adapter complex, making CFTR a specific target of this endocytic machinery.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	79	Other methods for demonstrating the presence of CFTR in endosomes have relied on the ability of CFTR to provide a pathway for anion transport that parallels the vacuolar H-ATPase.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	80	 (60) allowed CHO cells expressing CFTR to take up the pH-sensitive dye FITC-dextran into endosomes, where the rate of dissipation of a pH gradient across endosomal membranes was stimulated by addition of a proton ionophore.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	81	 In these intact cells, pH gradient dissipation was limited by the counterion.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Activation of cAMP production elicited a twofold increase in the rate of pH change in cells expressing CFTR but not in parental or mock-transfected cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The results were duplicated in microsomes isolated from these cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Biwersi and Verkman (9) used a similar method for monitoring endosomal pH in CFTR-transfected 3T3 cells and in T84 cells endogenously expressing CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Treatment of the cells with forskolin before microsome isolation produced an approximately twofold increase in the rate of subsequently measured pH gradient dissipation but had no effect on microsomes isolated from nontransfected or F508 CFTR-expressing 3T3 cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	86	 These data are also consistent with the presence of functional CFTR in endosomes that, in principle, could contribute to CFTR recycling.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Using immunofluorescence and confocal microscopy for detection of cellular CFTR, investigators have generated data that arrive at somewhat divergent conclusions with respect to the importance of regulated CFTR trafficking.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	88	 On one side of this issue is the study of Lehrich et al.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	89	 (55) in shark rectal gland, a tissue that expresses CFTR at high levels endogenously.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	90	 These investigators used quantitative confocal microscopy to show that CFTR immunofluorescence extended from the apical membrane into subapical, supernuclear regions of the cell and that during stimulation with secretagogues, the overall depth of this CFTR signal decreased by 50%.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Similar conclusions were reached when the histogram of CFTR fluorescence intensity as a function of distance from the apical membrane was quantitated.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	92	 These cAMP agonist effects on CFTR distribution, imposed in perfused, intact rectal glands before fixation, were reversible.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Whether this shift in fluorescence signal represents insertion of vesicles containing CFTR into the apical membrane remains unknown; however, the findings are consistent with the acute hormonal regulation of CFTR trafficking in an intact epithelial tissue.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	94	 (1, 2) used immunofluorescence microscopy to quantify the cellular location of CFTR in rat small intestine and the influence of cAMP-dependent agonists on its distribution.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) elicited a bicarbonate-rich fluid secretory response in isolated perfused intestinal loops and elicited, within the same time frame, a redistribution of CFTR to the apical membrane domain.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	96	 CFTR association with the apical membrane was quantified by colocalization of F-actin as a brush border marker.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	97	 In duodenal villus cells, VIP elicited a reversible, threefold increase in brush border associated CFTR, and it redistributed CFTR within the cell apex to the brush border within 30 min.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	98	 These studies were confirmed by immunoelectron microscopic methods (see Immunoelectron microscopy).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	99	 The results provide support for a physiological role for cAMP-induced CFTR-containing membrane traffic in the regulation of the apical anion conductance in a native, endogenously expressing epithelium.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	100	Other investigators have reached different conclusions with respect to regulated CFTR trafficking.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	101	 (70) expressed a GFP-CFTR fusion protein in MDCK type I epithelial cells and used quantitative confocal fluorescence microscopy and cell surface biotinylation to determine the effect of cAMP stimulation on apical membrane CFTR localization.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Their findings showed that cAMP did not stimulate detectable GFP-CFTR translocation from intracellular compartments to the apical membrane, along an apical-to-basal GFP fluorescence gradient that extended throughout the cell.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	103	 In these cells, cAMP did not regulate GFP-CFTR endocytosis, determined by apical biotinylation and subsequent immunoprecipitation.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Likewise, disruption of microtubules with colchicine did not affect cAMP-stimulation of Cl secretion or the expression of GFP-CFTR in the apical membrane.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Thus the authors concluded that cAMP stimulates CFTR-mediated Cl secretion in MDCK type I cells by activating only the channels that are resident in the apical membrane.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	106	 A regulated CFTR trafficking event may be lacking in this cell type; however, it is also reasonable to ask whether the exogenous expression of CFTR driven by the CMV promoter leads to saturation of regulated trafficking pathways (see Functional studies of exocytosis).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	107	A related study (58) involving measurements of cellular CFTR immunolocalization in endogenously expressing Calu-3 epithelia by fluorescence confocal microscopy detected no change in apical CFTR staining upon cAMP stimulation.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Surface biotinylation experiments reported in the same study (58) also showed no stimulation-dependent increase in apical membrane CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Two biotinylated proteins were detected by CFTR antibody precipitation following biotinylation; they were of equal intensity and 200 to 220 kDa in molecular size.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Yet, others have demonstrated by immunoblot that CFTR in Calu-3 cells shows the typical pattern of a predominant band C of 150 to 180 kDa and relatively little band B; the latter is presumably intracellular (c.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Thus it is not clear that the biotin-labeled proteins identified in these experiments were CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	112	It is possible that differences in the conclusions drawn from fluorescence measurements in native and cultured epithelial cells stem from variations in the distribution of CFTR in subapical compartments under nonstimulated conditions.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	113	 In the studies of native secretory tissues (shark rectal gland and rat intestine), the apical fluorescence signal extended into the cell sufficiently to detect a clear change in its distribution with stimulation.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	114	 In MDCK cells expressing GFP-CFTR (70), there was an even deeper distribution of expressed protein, but this may reflect its deposition in nonphysiological compartments, as described earlier in this article.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Given quantitative limitations of GFP visualization, 7 molecules/pixel (79), it may be necessary to express CFTR at nonphysiological levels to obtain a CFTR signal.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	116	 In Calu-3 cells (58), the CFTR signal was much more densely localized at the apical membrane domain.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Nevertheless, it is reasonable to ask whether a band of apical fluorescence detected in epithelial cross sections can resolve apical membrane CFTR from that present in a nearby subapical recycling pool.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Consideration of the point-spread function of fluorescence intensity variation with distance suggests that structures separated by  > 0.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	119	2  microm will not be resolved using light microscopy.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Thus immunofluorescence, even coupled with confocal microscopy, may lack the ability to resolve fluorescence signals from membrane vesicles having a diameter of 0.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	121	1  microm or less, which are components of the CFTR recycling pathway.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	122	 This vesicle size expectation is based on neurosecretory and other regulated trafficking vesicles (see APPENDIX).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	123	 For example, intracellular GLUT-4 staining by thin-section immunoelectron microscopy was localized to vesiculotubular structures 50 to 70 nm in diameter (62).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Thus it is possible that different conclusions at the light microscopic level may emerge from different cellular distributions of intracellular CFTR trafficking compartments and their constituents (see CONSEQUENCES OF REGULATED CFTR TRAFFICKING).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	125	 The results of several studies using immunoelectron microscopic methods are consistent with a subapical population of post-Golgi CFTR (c.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	126	 (86) used immunogold labeling to localize CFTR in vesicles present beneath the plasma membrane of human airway epithelial cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	127	 They also observed vesicles in the process of fusion or retrieval from the plasma membrane.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Immunogold labeling of CFTR-expressing L cells and Sf9 cells also demonstrated the presence of CFTR beneath the plasma membrane as well as in the rough ER (26).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Studies of the striated duct of rat submandibular gland cells by Webster et al.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	130	 (107) showed immunogold labeling of CFTR along the apical membrane as well as in numerous subapical membrane vesicles.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Their estimates of labeling density suggested that more CFTR is present in subapical intracellular compartments than in the plasma membrane under "resting" conditions.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Some of the CFTR-labeled vesicles also stained with antibodies against the transferrin receptor and rab4, two endosomal markers, indicating that these vesicles are likely part of an endosomal/recycling pathway for CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	133	The fluorescence measurements of Ameen et al.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	134	 (1), performed in rat small intestine, were confirmed by immunoelectron microscopy.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	135	 CFTR was identified in subapical vesicles in several intestinal cell types, including cells from the crypt, Brunner glands, and a subpopulation of villar cells where CFTR expression predominated (so-called CFTR high expressors, or CHE cells).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	136	 cAMP stimulation elicited a two- to threefold increase in CFTR labeling of the apical microvilli of CHE cells in response to cholera toxin, providing evidence for regulated insertion of CFTR into the apical membranes of a native epithelium.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	137	 (42) examined apical membrane domain CFTR localization as a function of CFTR expression level.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	138	 In an earlier study (43), these investigators showed that CFTR located in the plasma membrane could be discriminated from intracellular CFTR by using nonpermeabilized MDCK cells expressing an extracellular epitope-tagged CFTR (where the flag, M2 epitope, was added to the 4th extracellular loop of CFTR, after amino acid 901).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	139	 They found that cAMP stimulation increased the cell surface signal of CFTR two-to threefold in the steady state.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	140	 In the more recent studies, they induced CFTR expression by using a recombinant adenovirus that encoded M2-901/CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Virally expressed, FLAG-tagged CFTR was functional and could be detected on the apical surface of forskolin-stimulated, polarized MDCK (type II) cells by immunofluorescence performed on nonpermeabilized epithelial monolayers.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	142	 At a low multiplicity of infection (MOI) (i.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	143	, lower CFTR expression level), forskolin stimulated the insertion of M2-901/CFTR into the apical membrane, but at higher MOI and M2-901/CFTR expression levels, no agonist-dependent increase in surface expression could be detected.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Immunoelectron microscopy confirmed the redistribution of CFTR to the apical membrane upon forskolin stimulation at the lower CFTR expression levels and demonstrated that the apically inserted CFTR originated from a population of subapical vesicles.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Results similar to these have been obtained with the use of immunoelectron microscopy in Calu-3 cells endogenously expressing CFTR, where a two- to threefold increase in apical CFTR was observed in response to acute forskolin stimulation (Hug MJ and Frizzell RA, unpublished observation).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	146	The observations of Howard et al.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	147	 (42) may reconcile at least some of the prior conflicting reports regarding the effect of cAMP stimulation on CFTR trafficking.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	148	 They show that a high level of CFTR expression, obtained by using strong promoters, for example (70), can saturate pathways for regulated CFTR trafficking, even in epithelial systems.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Also in oocytes, the CFTR trafficking signal (cAMP-induced increase in membrane capacitance) saturated as the CFTR expression level was elevated by injection of more RNA (102).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Inappropriate trafficking of AQP-2, in relation to the actions of dominant-negative AQP-2 mutants, has also been observed at high protein expression levels (51).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Later in this article, we discuss candidate protein interactions that may mediate regulated CFTR trafficking at the apical membrane.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	152	 If cells express different levels of the relevant traffic regulatory proteins, then it is likely that the contribution of regulated CFTR trafficking to the total anion conductance (as opposed to regulated gating of membrane resident CFTR) will vary in different epithelial or nonepithelial systems.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	153	   REGULATED CFTR TRAFFIC TOP ABSTRACT CFTR LOCALIZATION IN CELLS REGULATED CFTR TRAFFIC MECHANISMS OF REGULATED CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	154	 CONSEQUENCES OF REGULATED CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	155	 SUMMARY APPENDIX REFERENCES   Functional studies of endocytosis.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	156	 The concept that the CF gene product may play a role in regulated membrane trafficking is not new.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	157	 The implication, from defective mucin and glycoprotein secretion found in CF airways and other organs (64, 67), was that the CF gene product, once identified, would be involved somehow in the control of protein secretory processes.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Because the secretion of mucin in several CFTR-expressing tissues is stimulated by cAMP (65), and because cAMP/PKA regulatory pathways also control CFTR gating, it was reasonable to anticipate that protein secretion by exocytosis may lead also to an increase in the numbers of CFTR channels in the plasma membrane (Fig.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	159	The first studies that implicated CFTR function in regulated endocytosis were performed in colonic and pancreatic epithelial cell lines, with the latter transduced to express CFTR using retrovirus vectors.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	160	 (13, 14) measured detergent-sensitive horseradish peroxidase and FITC-dextran uptake to monitor fluid phase endocytosis in T84 and CFPAC-1 cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	161	 They found that cAMP significantly inhibited fluid-phase endocytosis, and in pancreatic cells, this depended on the expression of wild-type (wt) CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	162	 No cAMP inhibition of endocytic activity was observed in parental CFPAC-1 cells or those transduced by empty vector.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	163	 A similar 60% inhibition of endocytosis was observed during cAMP stimulation of endogenous CFTR-expressing T84 (13) and 9HTEo-cells (94).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	164	 In T84 cells, PKC stimulation did not affect either basal endocytosis or the inhibitory effect elicited by cAMP stimulation.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	165	Methods employing biotinylation of the cell surface have also demonstrated that CFTR internalization is inhibited by cAMP/PKA.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	166	 (85) biotinylated carbohydrate residues on the extracellular surface of T84 cells using NHS-biotin.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Subsequent immunoprecipitation and radioisotope labeling of CFTR with the use of [32P]ATP and PKA was performed to distinguish between CFTR at the cell surface and in intracellular compartments.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	168	 These workers found that apical membrane CFTR was rapidly internalized by T84 cells (half-time of 3 min), and they showed that cAMP decreased this internalization rate to an extent similar to that found in prior studies of fluid-phase endocytosis (60% inhibition).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	169	 They also showed that the internalization rate of G551D CFTR was similar to that of the wild-type protein but that, interestingly, its endocytosis was not affected by cAMP.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	170	 This finding suggested that either the channel activity of CFTR is related to its ability to be retrieved from the cell surface or the altered structure of the G551D mutant precludes regulation of both gating and trafficking.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	171	 It was difficult to detect a change in the total amount of CFTR at the cell surface using the method of Prince et al.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Even at short times (1 min), only a 12% increase in apical membrane CFTR was detected.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	173	 However, the use of in vitro phosphorylation to detect CFTR after its biotinylation and immunoprecipitation may be influenced by the existing phosphorylation status of the protein, thus compromising surface CFTR detection.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	174	 That is, if CFTR is already phosphorylated by agonist, the subsequent CFTR signal would be reduced because phosphorylation sites are already occupied.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	175	 A method that avoids this complication employs a second CFTR antibody to detect biotinylated CFTR, which avoids the potential for back-phosphorylation to reduce the signal.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	176	 This approach also demonstrates a forskolin-induced inhibition of CFTR endocytosis, a depletion of the protein from intracellular compartments, and a consequent increase in plasma membrane CFTR (61).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	177	Studies documenting the presence of functional CFTR in endosomes have been extended to show a role for CFTR in postendocytic membrane trafficking.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	178	 (8) implicated a role for CFTR in cAMP-stimulated endosome-endosome fusion.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	179	 They labeled endosomes of CFTR-expressing and control 3T3 cells with fluorophores such that a fluorescence signal would be detected if endosomes from separately labeled cell populations fused with one another.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	180	 These investigators asked whether the presence of CFTR in these endosomes, and its stimulation by cAMP, influenced the fusion process.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Endosomes from nonstimulated CFTR-expressing cells fused with each other at a rate that did not differ from that observed in control cells not expressing CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	182	 The endosomes isolated from CFTR-expressing cells that were stimulated by forskolin, however, showed a 2.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	183	 This was abolished by endosomal Cl depletion, suggesting that a CFTR-mediated Cl flux, or the conformational changes in CFTR associated with Cl conduction, somehow contribute to this process.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	184	 These data are consistent with the concept that CFTR stimulation can alter membrane traffic in endosomal recycling pathways.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	185	Recent findings have been able to establish certain structural features of CFTR that govern its rapid removal from the cell surface.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	186	 (84) and Weixel and Bradbury (109) have demonstrated that the internalization of CFTR via clathrin-dependent mechanisms depends on the presence of a YXX motif (where is a bulky hydrophobic residue) at the CFTR COOH terminus.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Similar tyrosine-based endocytic motifs are present on other proteins that are rapidly retrieved from the cell surface (see Ref.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	188	 In vivo cross-linking and in vitro pull-down assays showed that CFTR binds to the plasma membrane endocytic adaptor complex AP-2.
