0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	189	 The CFTR COOH terminus was able to bind AP-2 but did not bind the Golgi-specific adaptor complex AP-1.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Mutation of the tyrosine residue at position 1424 of CFTR significantly reduced the ability of an isolated CFTR COOH terminus to bind AP-2.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	191	 The YDSI sequence of CFTR interacts specifically with the  micro2 subunit of AP-2 (108), a site implicated in adapter binding to similar endocytic motifs (74).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Protein binding studies showed that the COOH terminus binds selectively to this adapter subunit.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Cells expressing either a dominant negative  micro2 or a CFTR lacking the tyrosine-based internalization motif at the COOH terminus (Y1424A) fail to endocytose CFTR efficiently.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	194	 These studies indicate that the interaction of CFTR's COOH terminus with AP-2 guides it into the clathrin-mediated endocytic pathway, as observed for many cell surface receptors.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Although these studies provide compelling evidence for specific protein interactions that mediate CFTR retrieval at the cell surface, they do not yet provide an indication of how this process may be regulated by cAMP/PKA.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	196	 We have speculated on possible mechanisms for regulated CFTR endocytosis (see MECHANISMS OF REGULATED CFTR TRAFFICKING: PERPETRATOR OR BYSTANDER? and Fig.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	197	View larger version (30K):    Fig.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Model for molecular interactions regulating endocytosis of CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	199	 A: the COOH terminus of phosphorylated (asterisks) CFTR is not free to bind the adapter protein complex AP-2, limiting its internalization.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	200	 B: phosphorylated AP-2 adapter (see text) associates with the plasma membrane and with the COOH terminus of dephosphorylated CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Small blue "bubbles" indicate the CFTR site of AP-2 binding.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Binding of AP-2 to the plasma membrane initiates assembly of the clathrin lattice (structure simplified for this 2-dimensional representation).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	203	 C: AP-2-bound CFTR is sequestered in the forming clathrin-coated pit.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	204	 D: after the clathrin-coated vesicle has been internalized, coat and adaptor proteins are shed.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	205	Functional studies of exocytosis.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	206	 (13) on CFTR-dependent endocytosis also examined CFTR-dependent exocytic recycling to the cell surface.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	207	 To monitor exocytosis, the plasma membranes were pulse-labeled with a biotinylated lectin (WGA), and after its removal from the bath, the cells were allowed to take up lectin into intracellular compartments.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Remaining cell surface WGA was blocked with unlabeled avidin, and at various times the recycling of internalized WGA to the cell surface was assayed using Texas Red-labeled avidin.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	209	 In cells expressing wt CFTR, recycling and exocytosis of internalized marker was increased approximately threefold by forskolin, whereas cAMP stimulation had no effect on WGA recycling in either the parental CFPAC-1 cell line or in empty vector controls.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Importantly, these studies showed that cAMP-responsive recycling/exocytosis required CFTR expression.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	211	Similar findings were obtained in human airway cell lines (94) where recycling/exocytosis was monitored as the release of previously internalized FITC-dextran (a fluid-phase marker of endocytosis) from human airway cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Treatment of cells expressing wt CFTR with a cAMP analog elicited increased release of FITC-dextran, and this was accompanied by increases in membrane capacitance monitored during whole cell patch-clamp measurements.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Again, trafficking was CFTR dependent; cAMP had no effect on membrane capacitance or recycling/exocytosis in airway cells derived from a CF patient.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	214	 The investigators concluded that cAMP stimulates exocytosis and the CFTR Cl conductance of normal but not CF cells and that it does so by stimulating the delivery of CFTR channels from an intracellular pool to the plasma membrane.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	215	Much of the effort to determine whether cAMP stimulates CFTR-dependent membrane trafficking has employed measurements of membrane capacitance in cells that express CFTR endogenously or cells in which CFTR expression was induced.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	216	 These studies are summarized in Table 1, which tabulates the methods, conditions, and experimental results of these studies.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	217	 As discussed below, the diversity of methods and conditions used may contribute to their variable outcome.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Measurement of stimulated capacitance in CFTR-expressing tissue.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	219	Previous work in nonepithelial cell lines (e.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	220	, CHO cells) failed to show CFTR- and cAMP-dependent membrane trafficking (29, 47), again suggesting that the machinery for regulated CFTR recycling may be expressed only in epithelial cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	221	 However, studies of Xenopus oocytes generally have shown a good correlation between cAMP stimulation of CFTR currents and increases in membrane capacitance (81, 102, 105).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	222	 In the studies of Takahashi et al.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	223	 (102), the apparent changes in cell surface area with stimulation, determined from membrane capacitance measurements, were confirmed by using blinded measurements of membrane morphometry in stimulated and nonstimulated cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	224	 In addition, recruitment of CFTR to the cell surface was demonstrated by using epitope-tagged M2-901/CFTR labeling of nonpermeabilized cells (81).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Together, these findings are consistent with the exocytic insertion of CFTR into the oocyte plasma membrane during cAMP stimulation.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	226	 The cell surface immunofluorescence studies of Peters et al.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	227	 (81) suggested a low level of CFTR expression in the plasma membrane of nonstimulated oocytes (i.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	228	, fluorescence levels were near background in the absence of stimulation).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	229	 These data suggested that recruitment of CFTR to the cell surface is a significant component of CFTR current stimulation in this system.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	230	 However, this conclusion assumes that the flag-CFTR labeling approach can detect low levels of cell surface CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Although technically difficult, it would be optimal to determine a dose-response relation between cAMP-dependent cell surface CFTR labeling and some independent parameter such as the corresponding change in membrane capacitance.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	232	 It is possible, for example, that some threshold level of CFTR residing in the plasma membrane cannot be detected by this method, underestimating levels of CFTR at the cell surface under basal conditions.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	233	 However, this concern does not compromise the data, obtained from three different methods, consistent with stimulation-dependent recruitment of CFTR to the surface of these cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	234	The electrophysiological aspects of these studies were confirmed by the work of Weber et al.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	235	 (105), who used impedance analysis to assess membrane conductance and capacitance and correlated the changes in these parameters induced by cAMP.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	236	 In agreement with prior reports (81, 102), cAMP stimulation of CFTR-expressing oocytes evoked significant increases in both current and capacitance that were not observed in noninjected or F508-expressing cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Injection of Rp-cAMP (a specific cAMP antagonist) abolished the effects of the cAMP stimulation on both current and capacitance.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	238	 Interestingly, the less specific PKA inhibitors, KT5720 and H8, after prolonged (overnight) exposure, primarily blocked the capacitance increases evoked by cAMP while having less effect on the corresponding current activation.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	239	 However, these reagents have been shown to alter cytoskeletal properties.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	240	 For example, KT5720 induces microtubule rearrangement by inhibition of mitogen-activated protein kinase (76), and H8 has been shown to alter cytoskeletal protein phosphorylation through inhibition of PKC (63).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	241	 It would be interesting to explore these actions further, because both of these less selective kinase inhibitors produce cytoskeletal disruption, which may account for their inhibitory effects on membrane trafficking.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	242	 (106) showed that microtubule disruption markedly inhibits current and capacitance increases evoked by cAMP in CFTR-expressing oocytes, and similar conclusions have been reached in CFTR-expressing epithelial cells (103).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	243	Although two groups have independently demonstrated cAMP-dependent changes in membrane capacitance and other parameters indicative of regulated CFTR trafficking in Xenopus oocytes, using different analytic methods Liu et al.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	244	 (57) arrived at a different conclusion.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	245	 They employed a CFTR construct containing a cysteine substitution in the postulated CFTR conduction pathway to arrive at the conclusion that essentially all conductance activation by cAMP in oocytes was due to CFTR channels that are already present in the plasma membrane.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	246	 This approach relied on changes in conductance induced by treatment of this CFTR mutant with cysteine-reactive methanethiosulfonate (MTS) reagents, whose effects have been attributed to altered charge shielding properties in the CFTR conduction pathway.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	247	 When oocytes were treated briefly with 2-(trimethylammonium)ethyl methanethiosulfonate (MTSET; a positively charged modifier) for as little as 20 s before cAMP activation, the activated channels behaved as if their properties were already modified.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Because MTSET has been demonstrated in other systems to be cell impermeant, the data suggest that the modified channels must have already been present at the cell surface.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	249	 These findings are consistent with a lack of regulated CFTR redistribution in oocytes, but they need not negate the results of prior studies for two reasons.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	250	 First, this study used CFTR expression levels (based on conductance) that are 5 to 10 times higher than the prior work in which capacitance measurements were made.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	251	 As discussed earlier in this article, overexpression of CFTR can saturate pathways available for regulated trafficking.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Consistent with this idea, Takahashi et al.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	253	 (102) observed that increasing CFTR expression levels increased CFTR currents, but the corresponding capacitance changes plateaued, as if regulated trafficking pathways had saturated.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Constitutive delivery of CFTR to the plasma membrane at high expression levels would limit one's ability to detect a population of trafficking channels.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	255	 (57) did not measure membrane capacitance, cell surface CFTR, or any other measure of CFTR trafficking.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Nevertheless, there is not a facile explanation for differences between these carefully performed studies and those cited above.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	257	 It should be determined, using MTS CFTR modification together with capacitance measurements or surface CFTR labeling, whether high CFTR expression levels would account for these results.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	258	Two recent studies, performed in mammalian epithelial cells that endogenously express CFTR, have reported negative findings with respect to changes in membrane capacitance during cAMP stimulation.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	259	 As an independent assay, both studies also employed FM 1-43 dye labeling in an attempt to monitor membrane addition to the plasma membrane that would result from exocytosis stimulated by cAMP.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	260	 (21), membrane capacitance was measured in Calu-3 airway cells by imposing alternating sinusoidal and square voltage waveforms and monitoring the resulting currents to assess membrane capacitance and conductance.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	261	 The calculated capacitance changes induced by cAMP were insignificant.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	262	 In addition, they found no increase in steady-state plasma membrane labeling by FM 1-43 when the cells were stimulated by cAMP during fluorescence measurements.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Enhanced dye labeling (fluorescence intensity) would be expected if additional membrane were exposed at the cell surface as a result of exocytosis.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	264	 Thus the authors concluded that cAMP does not stimulate CFTR currents by increasing CFTR trafficking to the plasma membrane but stimulates only membrane-resident CFTR channels in Calu-3 cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	265	In a similar study, Chang et al.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	266	 (20) used sinusoidal voltage-current phase-lag analysis to estimate cell capacitance and fluorescence measurements of FM 1-43 membrane dye labeling in colonic HT29-Cl.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	267	19A and airway 14HBEo-cells, both of which express CFTR endogenously.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	268	 The outcome in the airway cell line was similar to that in study by Chen et al.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	269	, no detectable cAMP-induced changes in membrane capacitance or FM dye labeling.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	270	 In HT29 cells, increases in membrane capacitance with cAMP stimulation occurred only when endocytosis was blocked with the use of a dynamin antibody.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	271	 As the authors indicated, the absence of a change without dynamin inhibition may result from parallel increases in both exocytosis and endocytosis during stimulation, i.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	272	, no net increase in membrane area.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	273	 (20), despite the sophisticated methodologies employed, have two significant shortcomings that preclude definitive conclusions regarding regulated CFTR trafficking in these systems.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	274	 First, both studies were performed at room temperature, a condition that is known to impair regulated membrane traffic in a variety of systems.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	275	 For example, the release of amylase from pancreatic exocrine cells is decreased 70% at 25 degrees C compared with normal temperature.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	276	 The release of insulin from rat pancreatic islets is markedly inhibited at 25 degrees C, with a 90% reduction in the membrane capacitance response to stimulation (the Q10 was 11.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	277	 In addition, cAMP-regulated AQP-2 recycling in renal cells is blocked at 20 degrees C (38).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	278	 Indeed, recent data collected in this laboratory (45) indicate that studies performed at 37 degrees C in Calu-3 cells using either sinusoidal waveform analysis or current transient analysis show a 1 pF increase in membrane capacitance (basal membrane capacitance averages 20 pF) in response to cAMP stimulation that parallels the increase in membrane conductance.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	279	 When identical recordings were made at room temperature with 5 or 10 mM EGTA in the pipette solution (conditions of the Chen and Chang studies), cAMP elicited no significant increase in membrane capacitance.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	280	 It is interesting that early recordings of capacitance changes in airway cells (94) showed cAMP-dependent increases at 23 degrees C (Table 1); however, these experiments employed low EGTA concentrations (Ca buffering at normal resting levels) in the recording pipette.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	281	 Thus the recording conditions have not been consistent.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	282	The assays of FM dye labeling (also performed at room temperature) were conducted by using a protocol that is insensitive to small increases in membrane area.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	283	 The cells were labeled to steady-state intensity with FM dye, and their fluorescence intensity was monitored during cAMP stimulation.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	284	 However, if the increase in plasma membrane area induced by cAMP is only 3% over the basal membrane area (suggested from capacitance measurements at 37 degrees C; Ref.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	285	 46), this signal would not be detected during steady-state dye labeling.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Rather, subsequent to stimulation, it is necessary to wash out dye and agonist from the membrane to minimize plasma membrane (background) staining.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	287	 This permits visualization of the dye retrieved by subsequent endocytosis of labeled plasma membrane, assuming that the cell recovers to its original area following reversal of stimulation.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	288	 As recent studies in this laboratory performed at 37 degrees C have demonstrated, measurements performed in this manner indicate that FM 1-43 labeling is increased by cAMP stimulation in Calu-3 (45).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	289	 The protocol used in the studies of Chen et al.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	290	 (20) is similar to methods employed to monitor secretory granule release in systems that incorporate large amounts of membrane into the cell surface during stimulation (e.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	291	, pancreatic acinar cells), generally in response to stimulation by a cellular calcium rise (36).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	292	 In these systems, the addition of membrane (and increase in FM dye signal) at steady state is easily demonstrated, as it is in HT29 to 16E cells during stimulation of mucin secretion by Ca-dependent agonists (Bertrand CA, Laboisse C, Hopfer U, Bridges RJ, and Frizzell RA, unpublished observations).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	293	 Estimates of the numbers of CFTR channels in intracellular vesicles obtained by using data derived from Calu-3 cell and oocyte measurements are provided in the APPENDIX.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	294	 Important assumptions in these calculations include the single-channel parameters and assumed vesicle radius (100 nm).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	295	 The calculations are based on reported values of membrane current and capacitance changes from patch-clamp studies of cAMP-stimulated cells (46, 102).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	296	 These calculations and assumptions yield estimates of 1 to 10 channels per vesicle in these systems; they are not likely to provide more than one order of magnitude estimate of channel density.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	297	 The mean oocyte current and capacitance changes reported by Weber et al.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	298	 (105) were both approximately fourfold smaller than those in the Takahashi study (102) so that the calculated outcome would be unaffected.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	299	 (110) estimated the number of Na-dependent glucose transporters per oocyte vesicle at 10 to 20, based on freeze-fracture scanning electron microscopy.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	300	 The size of the imaged oocyte vesicles was 100 to 120 nm.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	301	 The value of 1 to 10 CFTRs per vesicle is instructive when considering whether one should be able to visualize vesicular GFP-CFTR by light microscopic methods.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	302	 As discussed earlier in this article, the sensitivity of GFP detection (79), together with these considerations, suggests that CFTR density in a single transport vesicle is near the limit of detection.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	303	 It is worth emphasizing that the source of CFTR current generation, whether membrane-resident or inserted channels, need not be a black-and-white issue.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	304	 In most systems, plasma membrane CFTR currents are likely to arise from both stimulation of membrane-resident channels and acutely trafficked CFTR channels, and the proportions of these may differ among cell types or experimental conditions (see CONSEQUENCES OF REGULATED CFTR TRAFFICKING).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	305	 Data from studies of the regulated trafficking of GLUT-4 or AQP-2 indicate that they undergo recycling even under basal conditions (15, 17).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	306	 During stimulation, the rate coefficients of the steps involved in recycling these proteins are altered, changing their distribution to increase the number of transporters and/or channels in the plasma membrane.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	307	 Presumably, regulated CFTR recycling behaves similarly.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	308	 As appears to be true of CFTR, the cellular background that can support regulated GLUT-4 or AQP-2 trafficking is very important.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	309	 Thus the expression of GLUT-4 in nonmuscle or nonadipose derived cells eliminates the insulin-regulated redistribution of GLUT-4 (40, 44).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	310	 Similarly for AQP-2, its endogenous expression in vas deferens results in a constitutive apical membrane localization; the channel is not found in a cAMP/PKA-regulated internal compartment as it is in renal epithelia, and there is no effect of stimulation on apical channel density (99).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	311	 A requirement for the proper cellular context is likely to also characterize the regulated trafficking of CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	312	 The AQP-2 data suggest that such differences can exist not only between epithelial and nonepithelial cells but also between epithelial systems.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	313	 This conclusion underscores the need to determine which cellular components provide the proper context.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	314	   MECHANISMS OF REGULATED CFTR TRAFFICKING: PERPETRATOR OR BYSTANDER? TOP ABSTRACT CFTR LOCALIZATION IN CELLS REGULATED CFTR TRAFFIC MECHANISMS OF REGULATED CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	315	 CONSEQUENCES OF REGULATED CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	316	 SUMMARY APPENDIX REFERENCES   The studies discussed above do not provide a mechanistic basis for the CFTR-dependent proteins and regulatory events involved in the control of CFTR distribution at the apical membrane.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	317	 Positive reports of regulated CFTR trafficking (increased exocytosis, decreased endocytosis, and increased endosome fusion) have indicated that these events require both the expression of CFTR and its stimulation by cAMP/PKA.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	318	 In addition, with the exception of Xenopus oocytes, these processes appear to be epithelial cell specific.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	319	 In view of the relatively recent discovery of the extensive interactions of CFTR with other proteins, speculation regarding possible molecular mechanisms governing at least some of these trafficking reactions seems warranted.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	320	 Although firm conclusions cannot be drawn at this stage, the principal value of the models we propose is to suggest testable hypotheses that may lead to an understanding of mechanism.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	321	 Moreover, it is our contention that the importance of regulated CFTR trafficking for anion secretion will continue to generate controversy until its mechanistic basis is understood to the extent that it can be manipulated experimentally (e.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	322	, in the same manner that identification of adapter protein interactions with CFTR has provided a mechanistic basis for CFTR endocytosis).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	323	 The physical interaction between the CFTR COOH terminus and the  micro2 subunit of the AP-2 adapter complex, indicated by the results of recent studies (108), suggests a model like that shown in Fig.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	324	 2 for PKA-mediated regulation of endocytosis.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	325	 This scheme is based on observations concerning the inherently rapid rate of CFTR-dependent endocytosis and the inhibitory effect of cAMP on this process (13, 14, 61, 85).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	326	 It assumes that CFTR is normally endocytosed at a rapid rate because of its interaction with the AP-2 adapter complex at the YDSI motif of the COOH terminus.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	327	 Recent data indicate that this interaction requires also phosphorylation of the  micro2 subunit, which facilitates AP-2 interactions with membrane lipids (25).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	328	 2 implies that the PKA-mediated inhibition of CFTR endocytosis may result from occlusion or obstruction of the adapter protein binding site at the COOH terminus by a CFTR phosphorylation event.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	329	 For example, this could result from an as yet unidentified physical interaction of the phosphorylated R domain with the COOH-terminal tail where adapters bind, or it could be mediated by another interacting protein whose association with the COOH terminus is proportional to CFTR phosphorylation.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	330	 The key feature of this model relies on phosphorylation-dependent accessibility of the COOH terminus site for adapter protein binding.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	331	A second possibility is that the YXX motif itself is altered by phosphorylation.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	332	 In species where CFTR's sequence has been described, the YDSI motif is highly conserved (108).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	333	 Although it does not conform to a canonical PKA consensus sequence, it is possible that the Y+2 serine is phosphorylated by PKA or another kinase, which acts to disrupt the adapter binding motif.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	334	 The possibility that AMP kinase, implicated in binding to this region of CFTR (39), is involved in phosphorylation of the YDSI internalization motif requires evaluation.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	335	 However, the function of this kinase is presumably to downregulate CFTR during metabolic stress, which would be expected to promote, not inhibit, CFTR retrieval.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	336	 Nevertheless, a phosphorylation event at or near this site could reduce the endocytic rate of CFTR in parallel with the activation of channel gating.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	337	 It remains to be determined whether such a mechanism can account for the finding, made in both epithelial and nonepithelial systems (13, 14, 85, 94), that PKA phosphorylation inhibits CFTR endocytosis, leading to retention of the channel on the cell surface.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	338	 What determines the ability of CFTR to enter a regulated (as opposed to constitutive; Fig.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	339	 1) secretory pathway during its progression to the cell surface? In Xenopus oocytes, a redistribution of CFTR between intracellular and plasma membrane compartments is demonstrable by immunofluorescence measurements, as discussed above.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	340	 These data can be interpreted to suggest that CFTR is stabilized, kinetically, in an intracellular compartment under nonstimulated conditions.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	341	 Therefore, it is reasonable to ask what structural feature(s) of CFTR provides for its entry into a regulated secretory pathway under basal conditions.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	342	 CFTR carries its own regulatory domain, and the phosphorylation of this domain stimulates both channel gating and trafficking.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	343	 Therefore, it is logical to ask whether the R domain is responsible for the entry of CFTR into a regulated pathway.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	344	 For this purpose, CFTR lacking the R domain has been expressed from two injected RNAs, each corresponding to a CFTR half molecule: N-TM1-NBD1 and TM2-NBD2-C (56).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	345	 Oocytes expressing these constructs showed spontaneous currents quantitatively similar to the stimulated currents of cells expressing wt CFTR, and they were not further augmented by cAMP stimulation.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	346	 In addition, there was no change in membrane capacitance during stimulation, indicating that regulated CFTR trafficking required the R domain.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	347	 The direct targeting of R-CFTR to the plasma membrane in these cells is consistent with the concept that the nonphosphorylated R domain may allow CFTR to access a regulated intracellular compartment and that CFTR within this compartment can be redistributed to the plasma membrane when the R domain is phosphorylated.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	348	 Therefore, it is reasonable to ask the following: What are the mediators of this process? Do protein interactions involving the R domain govern the movement of CFTR through this regulated trafficking pathway?.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	349	Although these questions cannot be answered with certainty at present, the relatively recent discovery by Kirk and colleagues (72, 73) that CFTR interacts physically and functionally with syntaxin 1A (S1A) suggests soluble N-ethylmaleimide-sensitive factor attachment protein receptor (SNARE) proteins as candidates for participation in this regulated trafficking process.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	350	 The interaction of S1A with the NH2 terminus of CFTR (73, 81) and the inhibition of CFTR currents during S1A overexpression (72) have been interpreted as the consequence of a direct interaction of S1A with CFTR that reduces its open probability (20).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	351	 However, in addition, Peters et al.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	352	 (81) showed that S1A overexpression decreased the density of CFTR channels in the plasma membrane.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	353	 They concluded that disruption of SNARE complex formation by overexpressed S1A interfered with CFTR trafficking (presumably with exocytosis).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	354	 As regards the functional involvement of syntaxin with CFTR, there is no reason to discount one mechanism in favor of the other; that is, syntaxin may regulate CFTR gating and also function as a component of the machinery that brings CFTR into the plasma membrane, or it may act as a regulator of that process.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	355	How might SNARE proteins be involved in regulated CFTR exocytosis? To pose an answer to this question, we should recount several observations.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	356	 First, the Kirk laboratory has shown that the NH2 terminus of CFTR, to which S1A binds, also interacts with a proximal portion of the R domain in protein binding studies (71).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	357	 A series of basic amino acid residues at the NH2 terminus is thought to mediate this association.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	358	 Mutation of these residues altered the magnitude and kinetics of CFTR current stimulation in oocytes and decreased the open probability of single CFTR channels (34), perhaps by interfering with NH2 terminus-R domain interactions that influence CFTR gating.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	359	 The NH2 terminus is also the site of S1A binding (73).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	360	 Thus it is possible that NH2 terminus-R domain interactions influence the association of CFTR with S1A or that it affects the ability of S1A to interact with other proteins necessary for CFTR trafficking.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	361	In relation to another possible scenario, we recently reported physical and functional interactions of another synaptic terminal protein, the cysteine string protein (Csp), with CFTR (115).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	362	 Csp is a resident of synaptic vesicles, and its knockout interferes with regulated neurotransmitter release (116), as does a S1A knockout (111).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	363	 In protein binding studies, Csp interacted with both the CFTR NH2 terminus and R domain.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	364	 It seems likely that the interactions of S1A and Csp with the NH2 terminus and the additional interactions of the NH2 terminus and Csp with the R domain may provide a means for linking proteins involved in regulated membrane trafficking to the regulatory (phosphorylation) status of the R domain (similar in general concept to the proposal above for regulated CFTR endocytosis).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	365	 According to the model shown in Fig.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	366	 3, phosphorylation of the R domain would alter these protein interactions in a manner that would lead to SNARE protein associations appropriate for fusion of CFTR-containing vesicles with the plasma membrane.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	367	 It is also of interest that Csp can bind to several SNARE proteins, including S1A, syntaxin 4, and vesicle-associated membrane protein 2 (VAMP-2) and that Csp has been proposed as a modulator of SNARE protein interactions (19).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	368	 According to this concept, NH2 terminus-R domain interactions within CFTR can alter single-channel properties, but they may also couple the phosphorylation-dependent activation of CFTR channel gating to proteins that regulate CFTR trafficking.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	369	 It is possible that a protein such as Csp, through its ability to interact with SNARE proteins on one hand and with both the NH2 terminus and R-domain of CFTR on the other, provides a transduction mechanism for coupling CFTR channel activation to channel trafficking mediated by the SNARE machinery.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	370	View larger version (28K):    Fig.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	371	 Model for molecular interactions regulating exocytosis and activation of CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	372	 A: under basal conditions, CFTR is distributed between the apical plasma membrane and subapical vesicles derived from the recycling endosome.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	373	 The NH2 terminus of CFTR binds to syntaxin 1A, which tethers vesicles close to the plasma membrane.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	374	 The cysteine string protein (Csp), localized to CFTR-containing vesicles at the apical membrane domain, binds to the R domain.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	375	 Blue bubbles indicate the CFTR site of syntaxin binding; interaction regions on other proteins are depicted by small boxes.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	376	 B: stimulation by cAMP activates PKA, phosphorylating (asterisks) the R domain and Csp.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	377	 R domain phosphorylation may disrupt binding between syntaxin and the NH2 terminus, which also interacts with the R domain (see text).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	378	 Csp-R domain interactions may also be altered by phosphorylation; Csp may then act as a chaperone for SNARE protein interactions involving syntaxin 1A, which is now free to bind vesicle-associated membrane protein (VAMP) and other members of the SNARE complex (not shown).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	379	 CFTR in the plasma membrane is active, and its gating is syntaxin sensitive.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	380	 C: the SNARE complex facilitates fusion of the CFTR vesicle to the plasma membrane, inserting active CFTR channels (D) and increasing CFTR channel density.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	381	   CONSEQUENCES OF REGULATED CFTR TRAFFICKING TOP ABSTRACT CFTR LOCALIZATION IN CELLS REGULATED CFTR TRAFFIC MECHANISMS OF REGULATED CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	382	 CONSEQUENCES OF REGULATED CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	383	 SUMMARY APPENDIX REFERENCES   CFTR channel density.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	384	 The most obvious consequence of regulated CFTR insertion/retrieval processes is that the distribution of CFTR between intracellular compartments and the apical plasma membrane will vary with agonist stimulation.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	385	 The analogy of this process to other examples of transporters whose overall plasma membrane activity is modulated by trafficking, such as the vasopressin-stimulated AQP-2 water channel or the insulin-dependent GLUT-4 transporter, have been cited throughout this article.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	386	 For CFTR, there is no doubt that the gating of this channel is regulated by phosphorylation when the channel is already present in the plasma membrane.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	387	 Why, then, should the trafficking of CFTR also be regulated? Control of insertion/retrieval is a common mechanism for regulation of transporters having slow activation kinetics.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	388	 Control of channel number would provide for amplification of the secretory response to agonist while preserving an option to sequester CFTR within a compartment where it cannot affect the plasma membrane Cl conductance.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	389	 High intracellular salt levels can be deleterious to cells, whose intracellular ionic composition and volume must be closely regulated (30).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	390	In addition, the contribution of trafficking events to anion secretion may vary with the differentiation status of the epithelium (6, 37).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	391	 It has been found, for example, that CFTR in some epithelial cells does not find its way to the plasma membrane until the tight junctions have formed and the cells polarize (68).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	392	 As the epithelium is developing, cells may utilize regulated trafficking as a means to fine tune the apical Cl conductance until the expression levels of other transporters, metabolic or regulatory components, on which overall secretory or absorptive ion movements depend are expressed at appropriate levels.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	393	 At that stage, the mature cell may find it reasonable to better anchor CFTR in the plasma membrane by virtue of PDZ domain (69, 97) and other interactions, to shift the balance of channel distribution in favor of the plasma membrane.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	394	 Yet, even in well-differentiated native epithelia, significant CFTR trafficking signals can be demonstrated (see REGULATED CFTR TRAFFIC).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	395	 Not until we know, from a mechanistic viewpoint, the protein interactions that mediate CFTR trafficking events will we be able to determine how such a balance is achieved or how it may be perturbed to counter the effects of disease.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	396	 Disease-related mutations that influence CFTR trafficking in distal compartments of the protein secretory pathway have been identified.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	397	 It is probably true that mutations in proteins that control general trafficking pathways would have a negative selective advantage and may be lethal; however, CFTR mutations that influence its trafficking have now been described.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	398	 Several reports have indicated that the half-life of F508 CFTR at the plasma membrane, and perhaps in other post-Golgi compartments, is markedly reduced relative to that of wt CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	399	 Using functional measurements of CFTR activity in CHO cells, Lukacs et al.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	400	 (59) found that the plasma membrane currents associated with F508 CFTR (recruited to the cell surface at low temperature) decayed with a half-time of  < 4 h, whereas the functional half-life of wt CFTR currents was  > 24 h.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	401	 (41) measured the half-life of F508 vs.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	402	 wt CFTR in the plasma membrane of LLC-PK1 cells using cell surface biotinylation, streptavidin-mediated isolation, and immunoblot analysis.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	403	 Mutant CFTR was brought to the cell surface with the use of a combination of low temperature and butyrate preincubation.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	404	 They found that the half-life of plasma membrane F508 CFTR was 4 h, whereas the corresponding half-life of wt CFTR exceeded 48 h in these cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	405	 The cAMP-dependent iodide efflux correlated with CFTR expression at the cell surface.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	406	 These authors concluded that F508 CFTR is more rapidly internalized and perhaps targeted to a degradation pathway.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	407	 The parallel study of Sharma et al.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	408	 (95) reached a similar conclusion.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	409	 Mutant CFTR was encouraged to escape the ER with the use of a combination of reduced temperature and chemical chaperone (glycerol) treatment.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	410	 They observed also a rapid degradation rate of F508 CFTR, which they attribute to decreased conformational stability: the protein was more susceptible to aggregation and protease digestion.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	411	 These authors favor the concept that folding defects of this CFTR mutant persist in the mature, post-Golgi protein (most studies agree that it lacks normal channel gating kinetics and open probability; c.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	412	 92) and that this leads to its more rapid degradation, perhaps by ubiquitin-proteasome pathways.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	413	 It is also possible, in view of the model for regulated CFTR endocytosis illustrated in Fig.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	414	 2, that the rapid degradation of F508 CFTR reflects its more rapid endocytic rate (41, 95), increasing its exposure to degradation mechanisms.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	415	 It is evident from these findings that the altered stability of mutant CFTR in distal trafficking pathways will require attention should rescue of F508 CFTR from ER degradation pathways be an achievable therapeutic target for CF disease.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	416	Another interesting disease mutation that influences distal pathway CFTR trafficking has been identified by Silvis et al.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	417	 These investigators searched the mutation database for disease mutations that may lead to increased CFTR endocytosis through creation of an endocytic motif.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	418	 The N287Y mutant resides in the second intracellular loop of CFTR and results in mild disease when expressed in combination with F508 CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	419	 This mutant did not exhibit a folding defect, because the N287Y and wt CFTRs showed similar maturation kinetics.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	420	 However, there was roughly 50% of the mutant at the plasma membrane at steady state relative to wt CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	421	 An increased colocalization of the mutant with the endocytic marker EEA1 suggested that this mutation alters the distribution of CFTR between plasma membrane and intracellular compartments.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	422	 Cl transport was reduced in proportion to altered cell surface CFTR, but the single-channel properties of N287Y were similar to those of wt CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	423	 Biotinylation experiments showed that N287Y CFTR was internalized approximately twice as fast as wt CFTR, which is expected to alter its distribution between plasma membrane and intracellular compartments.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	424	 These findings provide evidence of disease mutations where the primary defect lies in altered kinetics of CFTR recycling at the plasma membrane, resulting in subnormal apical membrane CFTR levels.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	425	Intracellular CFTR channel function.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	426	 A second consequence of regulated CFTR trafficking is that intracellular CFTR distribution may vary with the secretory status of the epithelium.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	427	 Despite indications that intracellular CFTR channels can be activated by cAMP/PKA (9, 77), the model of Barasch et al.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	428	 (5), suggesting that vesicular CFTR activity alters internal compartment pH, cellular glycoprotein processing, and bacterial colonization, has not been supported by subsequent studies (32, 35, 60, 83).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	429	 Nevertheless, there is a fundamental need for resolving the causes for increased bacterial adherence to CF cells and their glycoprotein secretory products and for the preferential binding of P.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	430	 aeruginosa to undersialylated CF mucins (16, 31, 48, 53, 91, 113).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	431	 These findings argue that the deletion of CFTR from the distal secretory pathway influences epithelial cell surface chemistry.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	432	 These properties of CF cells and their secretions could be affected by CFTR-dependent membrane trafficking events in intracellular compartments as well as at the plasma membrane domain.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	433	 (8) demonstrated that CFTR promotes endosome-endosome fusion, and, as with plasma membrane CFTR redistribution, this required both CFTR expression and cAMP stimulation.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	434	 If the presence of CFTR in internal membranes alters patterns of posttranslational glycoprotein modification by changing the compartmentation of enzymes or substrates involved in these processes (78), the surface chemistry of CF cells may be affected.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	435	 An issue related to the above discussion concerns the role of CFTR in epithelial tissue protein secretory activity, which is largely suggested by the data of McPherson and colleagues (65, 67), who examined mucin and amylase secretion by salivary glands of control and CF patients.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	436	 Metabolic incorporation of isotopic label into the carbohydrate residues of mucins was used to quantitate secretory rates.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	437	 The results showed that the -adrenergic stimulation of mucin and amylase secretion was reduced 60% in submandibular salivary glands derived from CF subjects.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	438	 An extensive series of studies showed that alterations in signal transduction mechanisms were not responsible for this difference and that the mucin content of control and CF glands was similar.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	439	 Recently, similar results have been obtained by using the salivary glands of CFTR knockout mice (67).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	440	 Again, the cAMP-dependent secretory component of secretion was impaired.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	441	 (66) have performed experiments of this type in several human airway cell lines.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	442	 They demonstrated independent regulation of 14C-labeled glycoconjugate secretion by PKA and PKC pathways (i.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	443	 The PKA agonist isoproterenol increased mucin release by 40% in control cells, but this effect was virtually eliminated (reduced to 3% stimulation) in cells derived from CF subjects.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	444	 A difference in PKC-mediated secretion between control and CF cell lines was not detected, similar to the observations of Bradbury et al.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	445	 (13) on cAMP-regulated membrane trafficking in T84 cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	446	 Moreover, the attenuated PKA response in CF airway cells could be restored by adenovirus-mediated CFTR expression.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	447	 The results suggest that CFTR can play an important role in cAMP-mediated glycoconjugate secretion.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	448	 Although not explicitly implicating CFTR in mucin release, the studies of Kuver et al.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	449	 (54) have demonstrated cAMP-dependent regulation of protein or mucin secretion in CFTR-expressing canine gallbladder epithelial cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	450	 CFTR was detected by immunostaining on mucin granule membranes.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	451	In studies that may have implications for epithelial protein secretion, Yilla et al.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	452	 (112) examined the influence of vacuolar H-ATPase inhibition on the constitutive protein secretory pathway in HepG2 cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	453	 Although treatment with concanamycin B did not influence ER-to-Golgi transit, the kinetics of protein traffic between the Golgi and plasma membrane were significantly impaired.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	454	 The secretion of albumin, 1-antitrypsin, and transferrin was delayed, and processing of N-linked glycans by sialyltransferases was inhibited, resulting in the secretion of less extensively modified glycoproteins.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	455	 This study implicates intracellular compartment acidification in the sialylation and N-linked glycan modification of secreted glycoproteins and with the rate of protein secretion.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	456	 In a related study, Jilling and Kirk (50) demonstrated that cAMP increased the secretion of several proteins, including 1-antitrypsin, into the apical but not the basolateral compartment of T84 cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	457	 This effect was Cl dependent and resulted also in an increase in protein sialylation.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	458	 An involvement of CFTR in regulated exocytosis could underlie the differences in protein secretion observed in studies of cells and/or tissues derived from normal and CF patients or CF knockout mice.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	459	 Once we understand the reasons for the ability of CFTR to alter membrane traffic, it may become apparent that the underlying mechanisms involved in the progression of CFTR between different compartments have certain features in common.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	460	 A critical question in this regard concerns the exit of CFTR protein from the ER.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	461	 Reasons for thinking along these lines include the common features controlling vesicle transit along compartments of the secretory pathway, e.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	462	, a combination of SNARE and coat protein associations, which often involve interactions with the cargo being conveyed (3).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	463	Our recent findings regarding Csp interactions with CFTR (115) also may provide an example of how common trafficking events may occur in the early and later components of the protein secretory pathway.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	464	 Csp regulates exocytosis in neurosecretory cells, and implications for a similar role in CFTR exocytosis were discussed above.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	465	 In addition, Csp plays a role in CFTR maturation in the ER.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	466	 Csp antibodies co-precipitate a large proportion of band B CFTR and localize Csp protein to the ER, in addition to its presence at the apical domain.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	467	 The major influence of Csp overexpression was a disruption of the biogenesis of mature CFTR (band C).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	468	 Because Csp is an Hsc70 binding protein, which also binds to CFTR, it is likely that Csp serves as a CFTR co-chaperone.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	469	 Csp overexpression may decrease CFTR biogenesis by prolonging its association with Hsc70, which can lead to CFTR degradation (88).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	470	 Much work needs to be done to determine the role of Csp in CFTR maturation, but it is interesting to speculate that the steps involved in the egress of nascent CFTR from the ER and from a regulated compartment of the distal secretory pathway to the plasma membrane may involve similar protein interactions.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	471	 Therefore, identifying the mechanisms underlying stage-specific CFTR trafficking events may also shed light on traffic occurring at other compartments of the cell.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	472	   SUMMARY TOP ABSTRACT CFTR LOCALIZATION IN CELLS REGULATED CFTR TRAFFIC MECHANISMS OF REGULATED CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	473	 CONSEQUENCES OF REGULATED CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	474	 SUMMARY APPENDIX REFERENCES   As with any active field of study, the above discussion leaves several issues unresolved.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	475	 On balance, there is good evidence that epithelial cells exhibit regulated CFTR trafficking as a mechanism to increase the density of CFTR channels at the cell surface.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	476	 This process may contribute to the cAMP-dependent secretion of proteins contained within this trafficking compartment.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	477	 Some results that show a lack of regulated CFTR trafficking may be attributable to the use of overexpression systems or nonphysiological experimental conditions.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	478	 Yet, there are other findings that cannot be similarly rationalized, and this may reflect the need for expression of the right set of interacting proteins, perhaps some of them as yet unidentified.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	479	 The finding that disease mutations influence CFTR trafficking events in the distal protein secretory pathway and thereby contribute to the CF phenotype further supports the concept that regulated CFTR recycling is important for normal epithelial function.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	480	 The era of CFTR interactions with other proteins, particularly with recognized traffic regulatory components, is beginning to shed light on the potential mechanism of regulated CFTR trafficking.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	481	 We suggest testable hypotheses (Figs.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	482	 2 and 3) regarding the manner in which CFTR phosphorylation may alter protein interactions and thereby affect the distribution of CFTR between apical membrane and intracellular compartments.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	483	 Yet, it is likely that controversy regarding the significance of this process will continue until we can identify the specific components of the CFTR-dependent trafficking machinery, permitting their expression or activity to be modulated experimentally in polarized epithelial cells and, ultimately, in the organism.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	484	   APPENDIX TOP ABSTRACT CFTR LOCALIZATION IN CELLS REGULATED CFTR TRAFFIC MECHANISMS OF REGULATED CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	485	 CONSEQUENCES OF REGULATED CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	486	 SUMMARY APPENDIX REFERENCES   The calculated CFTR channel density in transport vesicles from reported (46, 102) changes in whole cell current and capacitance during CFTR stimulation by cAMP is shown.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	487	 Common values for CFTR single-channel parameters are used to estimate channel number.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	488	Relationship among membrane current, capacitance increase, and the numbers of active CFTR channels and fused vesicles.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	489	 The pertinent equations for the number of active CFTR channels (NC) and fused vesicles (NV) are.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	490	where Im is the measured membrane current (Calu-3 cell, 500 pA; Xenopus oocyte, 4  microA), Po is the open probability of a CFTR channel (0.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	491	4), is the conductance of a CFTR channel (8 pS), and V = Vm  to  VR, or membrane potential minus reversal potential (20 mV);1 and.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	492	where Cm is the measured increase in membrane capacitance (Calu-3 cell, 0.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	493	9 pF; Xenopus oocyte, 80 nF), Cs is the specific capacitance of a biological membrane (1  microF/cm2), and rG is the radius of a spherical vesicle (100 nm).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	494	The channel density in a Calu-3 vesicle is 7,800/716, or 11 channels/vesicle.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	495	The channel density in an oocyte vesicle is 1 channel/vesicle.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	496	   ACKNOWLEDGMENTS   We thank Neil A.
