0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	830	 A cysteine-string protein is expressed in retina and brain of Drosophila.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	831	 J Neurogenet 7: 15 to 29, 1990.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	0	A2 adenosine receptors regulate CFTR through PKA and PLA2 B.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	1	Departments of 1 Human Genetics, 4 Medicine, and 5 Pediatrics, University of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham 35233; 2 Gregory Fleming James Cystic Fibrosis Research Center, University of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, Alabama 35294; and 3 Department of Pediatrics, University of Mississippi, Jackson, Mississippi 39216.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	2	    ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	3	We investigated adenosine (Ado) activation of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) in vitro and in vivo.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	4	 A2B Ado receptors were identified in Calu-3, IB-3-1, COS-7, and primary human airway cells.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Ado elevated cAMP in Calu-3, IB-3-1, and COS-7 cells and activated protein kinase A-dependent halide efflux in Calu-3 cells.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Ado promoted arachidonic acid release from Calu-3 cells, and phospholipase A2 (PLA2) inhibition blocked Ado-activated halide efflux in Calu-3 and COS-7 cells expressing CFTR.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Forskolin- and 2-adrenergic receptor-stimulated efflux were not affected by the same treatment.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Cytoplasmic PLA2 (cPLA2) was identified in Calu-3, IB-3-1, and COS-7 cells, but cPLA2 inhibition did not affect Ado-stimulated cAMP concentrations.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	9	 In cftr(+) and cftr(/) mice, Ado stimulated nasal Cl secretion that was CFTR dependent and sensitive to A2 receptor and PLA2 blockade.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	10	 In COS-7 cells transiently expressing F508 CFTR, Ado activated halide efflux.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Ado also activated G551D CFTR-dependent halide efflux when combined with arachidonic acid and phosphodiesterase inhibition.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	12	 In conclusion, PLA2 and protein kinase A both contribute to A2 receptor activation of CFTR, and components of this signaling pathway can augment wild-type and mutant CFTR activity.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	13	cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator; airway epithelia; Calu-3 cells; chloride secretion; nasal potential difference; protein kinase A; phospholipase A2.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	14	    INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	15	THE CYSTIC FIBROSIS TRANSMEMBRANE CONDUCTANCE REGULATOR (CFTR) is a cAMP-regulated Cl channel and is responsible for regulating ion transport in many tissues where it is expressed, including the airways and airway submucosal glands, sweat glands, gastrointestinal tract, pancreatic and bile ducts, and the reproductive tract (58, 74).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Defective CFTR function disrupts ion transport, which is believed to contribute to the clinical sequelae characteristic of cystic fibrosis (CF) (49, 58, 67, 74).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	17	 CFTR regulation in vivo is accomplished through ATP binding and hydrolysis at nucleotide binding domain-1 and -2 and regulation of the phosphorylation status of the regulatory domain (10, 11, 36).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	18	 This process is complex and depends on cAMP production through surface receptors that couple to adenylyl cyclase, cAMP degradation by phosphodiesterase (PDE) activity (40, 41), domain-domain interactions within the CFTR (55), protein-protein interactions between the CFTR and associated regulatory proteins (31, 32, 54, 64), and direct phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of the regulatory domain by protein kinase A (PKA) and phosphatases (6, 11), respectively.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Receptor-based pathways that signal through cAMP are therefore relatively accessible candidates for promoting activation of the CFTR in vivo.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	20	 This has been established for 2-adrenergic receptors, which are commonly stimulated in assays to detect CFTR-dependent Cl secretion as measured by changes in the nasal potential difference (PD) in mice and in humans (44).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	21	Adenosine (Ado) is a Cl secretagogue that signals through P1 purinergic receptors, and recent studies have demonstrated that A2B Ado receptors (ARs) can tightly couple to CFTR through PKA.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	22	 In Calu-3 cells, part of this coupling is due to compartmentalized signaling of CFTR with adenylyl cyclase and PKAII through A kinase anchoring protein interactions (34, 71).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	23	 T84 cells also express A2B-ARs, where they have been shown to mediate neutrophil-stimulated Cl secretion (48, 70).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Studies (2-4) have also suggested a role for phospholipase A2 (PLA2) in Ado-activated Cl secretion in T84 cells.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	25	 The nature of this role and whether similar signaling contributes to CFTR activation in other CFTR-expressing cells and tissues, however, are unknown.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	26	In this report, we describe CFTR regulation by A2-ARs in vitro and in vivo and evaluate the contribution of cytoplasmic PLA2 (cPLA2) to A2 receptor signaling in airway cells and the murine airway.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Our findings suggest that A2 receptors maximize CFTR activation by signaling through both adenylyl cyclase-PKA and cPLA2 and that components of these receptor signaling pathways can activate common disease-causing CFTR mutations.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	28	    METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	29	 All cell lines were purchased from the American Type Culture Collection (Manassas, VA).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	30	 COS-7 cells were grown in DMEM plus 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS) and 1% penicillin plus streptomycin.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	31	 IB-3-1 cells were grown in LHC medium plus 3% FBS and 1% penicillin plus streptomycin.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Calu-3 cells were grown in MEM plus 10% FBS and 1% penicillin plus streptomycin supplemented with nonessential amino acids.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	33	 To study polarized Calu-3 cells at an air-liquid interface, polyester Transwell-Clear Costar filters [0.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	34	4- microm pore diameter; 6-mm insert diameter for arachidonic acid (AA) release and Ussing chamber experiments and 24-mm insert diameter for immunocytochemistry experiments; Fisher Scientific, Pittsburgh, PA] were coated with human placental collagen matrix (Becton Dickinson, Franklin Lakes, NJ) at a concentration of 5  microg/cm2 overnight and then seeded at ~1  x  106 cells/cm2.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Once the filters were confluent (~1 wk), the medium was removed from the apical surface and the cells were fed only on the basolateral surface.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	36	 After 48 h, resistance was checked (~1,000-2,000    cm for the 6-mm filters and ~400-600    cm for the 24-mm filters), and at 72-96 h the cells were studied as described in Transepithelial short-circuit currents.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	37	 The primary human nasal cells were isolated and grown as explant cultures on Vectabond-treated glass coverslips as previously described (15) and were studied  < 1 wk after being seeded.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	38	 CFTR was transiently expressed in COS-7 cells with a vaccinia-based expression system as previously described (16, 17).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Cells grown on Vectabond-treated glass coverslips were infected with vaccinia containing the T7 polymerase (generous gift of Dr.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Moss, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD) at a multiplicity of infection of 10 for 30 min.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Wild-type (WT), F508, or G551D CFTR under control of the T7 promoter in the pTM-1 vector was then introduced into the cells in complex with N-[1-(2,3-dioleoyloxy)propyl]-N,N,N-trimethylammonium (DOTAP)-propane-1,2-dioleoyl-sn-glycero-3-phosphoethanolamine (DOPE; 20  microg DOTAP-DOPE and 5  microg pTM-1 CFTR/5  x  105 cells) for 4 h.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	42	 These CFTR plasmids in the pTM-1 vector were the generous gift of Dr.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Cheng (Genzyme, Cambridge, MA).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Cells were then washed in PBS, returned to DMEM plus 10% FBS, and studied 18-24 h postinfection (for WT CFTR and G551D CFTR) or after being grown at 29 degrees C for 48 h (F508 CFTR).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	45	Fluorescence-based halide efflux measurements.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	46	 To study CFTR activation, we measured halide efflux in COS-7 cells transiently expressing WT, F508, or G551D CFTR or in Calu-3 cells with the halide-quenched dye 6-methoxy-N-(3-sulfopropyl)quinolinium (SPQ; Molecular Probes, Eugene, OR) as previously described (16, 17).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Briefly, COS-7 cells were seeded on Vectabond-treated glass coverslips, and Calu-3 cells were seeded on Vectabond-treated coverslips coated with 5  microg/cm2 of human placental extracellular matrix.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Cells were grown until ~80% confluent.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Immediately before study, the cells were hypotonically loaded with 10 mM SPQ for 10 min and placed in a quenching NaI buffer.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	50	 The cells were then placed in a specially designed perfusion chamber and studied at 23 degrees C.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	51	 The fluorescence of individual cells was measured with a Zeiss inverted microscope (excitation 340 nm, emission  > 410 nm), a PTI imaging system, and a Hamamatsu camera.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Baseline fluorescence was measured in isotonic NaI buffer (16, 17), and cells were then perfused with isotonic dequench buffer (NaNO3 replaced NaI) at the indicated time point (generally 200 s).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	53	 The perfusate was then switched to dequench buffer plus agonist and requenched at the end of the experiment.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Fluorescence was normalized for each cell to its baseline value, and increases are shown as percent increase in fluorescence above basal (quenched) fluorescence.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Unless otherwise specified, the means  plus or minus  SE of all cells were included in the curves shown.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	56	 To detect the A2B-AR, cells were lysed with radioimmunoprecipitation assay buffer (150 mM NaCl, 1% Nonidet P-40, 0.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	57	1% SDS, 50 mM Tris-Cl, and 10 mg/ml of phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, pH 8.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	58	 For the COS-7 cells, lysates were immunoprecipitated with an isoform-specific polyclonal rabbit anti-A2B-AR-antibody (Alpha Diagnostics, San Antonio, TX) raised against a 16-amino acid sequence corresponding to the third extracellular domain of human brain A2B-AR cDNA as previously described (17).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Briefly, anti-A2B-AR antibody was linked to protein A agarose beads and incubated with cell lysates for 2 h.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Precleared cell lysates (beads without primary antibody) were used as the negative control.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	61	 The beads were then washed three times with PBS plus 0.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	62	1% Tween, and the immunoprecipitates were released with sample buffer incubated at 37 degrees C for 10 min.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	63	 For the Calu-3 and IB-3-1 cells, lysates were Western blotted without immunoprecipitation.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Proteins were separated by SDS-PAGE with precast 12% gels (Novex gels; Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA) and electrophoretically blotted onto polyvinylidene difluoride membranes.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	65	 The membranes were then blocked with 1% BSA in PBS for 30 min, washed three times with PBS plus 0.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	66	1% Tween, and probed with anti-A2B-AR antibody (1:1,000 dilution) for 2 h.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Negative control membranes were blotted with a fivefold excess (by weight) of A2B-AR-specific neutralizing peptide that was added with the primary antibody (Alpha Diagnostics).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The membranes were washed three times and incubated with secondary antibody (1:1,000 dilution of goat anti-rabbit antibody conjugated to alkaline phosphatase; Southern Biotechnology Associates, Birmingham, AL) for 2 h.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Membranes were washed three times and developed with 5-bromo-4-chloro-3-indolyl phosphate (BCIP) and 4-nitro blue tetrazolium chloride (NBT) in carbonate buffer (pH 9.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Similar techniques were used to identify cPLA2 in cell lysates using an affinity-purified mouse monoclonal IgG2b antibody raised against the amino-terminal domain of the human cPLA2 cDNA (Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Santa Cruz, CA).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	71	 This antibody was used to identify cPLA2 protein in cell lysate immunoprecipitates (Calu-3 and IB-3-1 cells; anti-cPLA2 linked to precleared protein G beads; Roche Diagnostics, Indianapolis, IN) or cell lysates alone (COS-7 cells).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Proteins were separated by SDS-PAGE with 8% precast gels, and after being blotted onto polyvinylidene difluoride membranes, the membranes were blocked and washed as above and probed with primary antibody (1:1,000).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	73	 The secondary antibody was a goat anti-mouse IgG alkaline phosphatase conjugate (1:1,000 dilution; Southern Biotechnology Associates), and blots were developed with NBT-BCIP as above.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Nasal explant cultures from human surgical specimens were grown on Vectabond-treated coverslips coated with 5  microg/cm2 of human placental extracellular matrix as previously described (15).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	75	 At 5 days of age, cells were fixed in 4% formaldehyde in PBS (20 min; pH 7.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	76	4), washed twice with PBS, and then permeabilized with 0.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	77	05% surfactant Triton X-100 (Pierce Endogen, Rockford, IL).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	78	 The slides were then pretreated with 1% BSA in PBS to block nonspecific protein-binding sites.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	79	 A2B-AR antigen was detected with the polyclonal rabbit anti-A2B-AR antibody (1:25 dilution) in 1% BSA for 1 h.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Cells were then washed three times with PBS over 15 min and incubated with secondary antibody (goat anti-rabbit FITC conjugate, 1:100 dilution in 1% BSA) for 1 h.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	81	 The cells were mounted with 4',6-diamidino-2-phenylindole Vectashield mounting fluid (Vector Laboratories).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	82	 For the studies of A2B-AR localization in polarized Calu-3 cells, the A2B-AR antigen was identified with the filter fold technique as previously described (7).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Briefly, high-resistance monolayers were fixed with 3% transmission electron microscopy-grade formaldehyde (Touismis, Rockville, MD) for 45 min at room temperature and stained without detergent permeabilization.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The fixed monolayers were washed three times with PBS over 15 min, blocked with nonimmune goat serum for 30 min (1:25 dilution; Vector Laboratories), and incubated with primary rabbit anti-A2B-AR antibody (1:100 dilution in nonimmune goat serum) for 1 h at room temperature.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Neutralizing peptide at five times (by weight) the concentration of primary antibody was used for negative control filters.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Goat anti-rabbit Alexa fluorochromes (1:80 dilution; Molecular Probes) were used to identify the primary antibody.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Nuclei were identified with Hoechst 33258 staining (20  microg/ml for 4 min).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	88	 The filters were folded with the apical side exposed and mounted in 0.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	89	1% p-phenylenediamine (Sigma, St.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Louis, MO) in PBS-glycerol (1:9 dilution).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Digital confocal images were captured and analyzed with an Olympus IX70 inverted reflective fluorescent light microscope at 623 nm excitation with UplanAPO  x 100 or U-APO/340  x 40 objectives, a Photometric Sensys digital camera, and IPLab Spectrum software supplemented with Power Microtome extension software (Signalytics, Fairfax, VA).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	92	Transepithelial short-circuit currents.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Calu-3 cells grown as monolayers at an air-liquid interface were mounted in modified Ussing chambers (Jim's Instruments, Iowa City, IA) and initially bathed on both sides with identical Ringer solutions containing (in mM) 115 NaCl, 25 NaHCO3, 2.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	94	2 MgCl2, and 10 D-glucose (pH 7.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Bath solutions were vigorously stirred and gassed with 5% CO2.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Solutions and chambers were maintained at 37 degrees C.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Short-circuit current (Isc) measurements were obtained with an epithelial voltage clamp (University of Iowa Bioengineering, Iowa City, IA).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	98	 A 3-mV pulse of 1 s duration was imposed every 100 s to monitor resistance, which was calculated with Ohm's law.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	99	 To measure stimulated Isc, the mucosal bathing solution was changed to a low Cl solution containing (in mM) 1.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	100	2 NaCl, 115 sodium gluconate, and all other components as above plus 100  microM amiloride.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Increasing concentrations of Ado were added to the mucosal or serosal bathing solutions (8 min of observation at each Ado concentration).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	102	 After cells were stimulated with 100  microM Ado, 200  microM glibenclamide was added to the mucosal bathing solution, effectively blocking the stimulated Isc ( > 90%).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Cftr(+) and cftr(/) mice (CFTRunc mice, C57BL6J genetic background) were studied by a conventional nasal PD protocol (29, 69).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	104	 The cftr(/) mice carried two copies of the human cftr cDNA, which contains a stop codon at position 489 (S489X).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Cftr(+) mice included cftr(+/+) and cftr(+/) mice, which have been shown to have similar nasal ion transport characteristics (42).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Genotypes were verified by PCR and dental enamel characteristics.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Both male and female mice ~16-40 wk of age were studied.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Mice were anesthetized with a cocktail consisting of ketamine (100 mg/ml, 82.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	109	5  microl), acepromazine (10 mg/ml, 30  microl), and xylazine (100 mg/ml, 15  microl) administered by intraperitoneal injection (0.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	110	 The mouse tail was gently abraded, placed in lactated Ringer solution, and connected through a calomel cell to a high-impedance voltage follower (VF-1; World Precision Instruments, Sarasota, FL).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	111	 An exploring bridge was established by connecting a Ag-AgCl electrode (wire) bridge to a syringe that pumped solutions at a rate of 180  microl/h.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	112	 After ~5 min, mice were appropriately somnolent to permit cannulation of the nostril with a PE-10 cannula pulled to a tip diameter of ~0.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	113	 The solutions perfused included Ringer lactate plus amiloride (100  microM; solution 1); a low Cl concentration ([Cl]) solution containing 2.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	114	4 mM KH2PO4, 115 mM sodium gluconate, 25 mM NaHCO3, 1.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	115	24 mM calcium gluconate2, and 100  microM amiloride (solution 2); and solution 3 (solution 2 plus agonist as described in text).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Each superperfused condition was studied for 6 min (total of ~18 min per protocol per mouse).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Calu-3 cells, grown to confluence on 35-mm culture dishes coated with 5  microg/ml of human placental collagen or as high-resistance monolayers at an air-liquid interface were washed in PBS and loaded with 1  microCi/ml of [3H]AA overnight (Moravek Biochemical, La Brea, CA).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	118	 The plates and filters were then washed five times with PBS and placed in MEM plus 10% FBS with and without 100  microM Ado (750- microl volume for the 35-mm plates; 150- microl apical volume and 300- microl basolateral volume for the cells on filters).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	119	 AA release was quantified for 20 min (cells on plates) and for 20 and 40 min (cells on filters).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	120	 The cells were lysed (1 N NaOH), and the effluxed AA from each plate was quantified by scintillation counting and normalized to the percent of total number of counts in a manner similar to that previously described (13).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Cellular cAMP was measured with an ELISA-based detection kit as previously described (17) (Cayman Chemical, Ann Arbor, MI).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Briefly, cells grown on 35-mm dishes (~7  x  106 cells/dish) were stimulated with agonist for 10 min, and the cellular cAMP was extracted with ice-cold ethanol.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	123	 The supernatants were vacuum dried and resuspended in phosphate buffer, and the cAMP levels were quantified per the manufacturer's directions.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	124	 For all experiments, papaverine (100  microM; nonspecific nonxanthine PDE inhibitor) was included to improve cAMP detection.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Xanthine-based inhibitors were avoided because these commonly interact with Ado receptors (39).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Ado hemisodium salt, chlorpromazine (CPZ), H-89 Cl, forskolin, zaprinast, and AA were purchased from Calbiochem (San Diego, CA); albuterol (Alb; salbutamol), theophylline, 8-cyclopentyl-1,3-dipropylxanthine (DPCPX), 8-phenyltheophylline, rolipram, and milrinone were purchased from Sigma; papaverine HCl was purchased from Research Biochemicals International (Natick, MA).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Descriptive statistics (means  plus or minus  SE) and tests of statistical significance were performed with SigmaStat software (Jandel, CA).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Paired and unpaired t-tests were used for samples with continuous data (cAMP levels, AA levels, stimulated PD measurements, and Isc), and 2 analysis was used to compare the number of F508 CFTR-expressing cells responding to different agonists (Ado, forskolin, DPCPX, and control).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	129	05 was considered statistically significant.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	130	    RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	131	Human airway cells express A2B-ARs.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	132	 With a polyclonal anti-A2B-AR antibody, Calu-3 and IB-3-1 cell lysates were probed for A2B receptor expression through Western blotting.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	133	 As a positive control, COS-7 cells, which our laboratory previously demonstrated to endogenously express A2B-ARs (17), were also evaluated.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Figure 1 shows that in all three cell types, a specific ~40-kDa band was identified.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Using the same anti-A2B-AR antibody, we investigated A2B receptor localization in primary human nasal airway cells (Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	136	 2A) and polarized Calu-3 cells (an airway cell line with a serous phenotype and high levels of CFTR expression; Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	137	 In both cell types, the antibody detected plasma membrane-localized A2B-AR.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Staining was predominantly along the apical surface in Calu-3 cells.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Functional studies in Ussing chambers demonstrated that Ado added to either the apical or basolateral surface briskly activated Isc (Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Ado was a more potent stimulus when added to the apical membrane than to the basolateral membrane, and Isc stimulated from either membrane was sensitive to apical glibenclamide blockade (~90% inhibition of stimulated Isc produced by 100  microM Ado; P  <  0.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Although the range of concentrations capable of activating Isc was most consistent with A2 receptor stimulation, these experiments do not exclude the possibility that additional AR subtypes may contribute to Ado-stimulated Isc.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Because HCO transport, in addition to Cl transport, may contribute to Isc in Calu-3 monolayers (22, 66), further functional studies of CFTR activity were performed with an SPQ-based halide efflux assay (15-17).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	143	View larger version (21K):    Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	144	   Identification of A2B adenosine (Ado) receptors (ARs).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Characteristic 40-kDa band was identified (+) in 3 cell types.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Negative controls () were precleared beads with cell lysates (COS-7 cell immunoprecipitates, no primary antibody conjugated to beads) or with addition of neutralizing peptide during Western blotting (Calu-3 and IB-3-1 cells, 5-fold excess of neutralizing peptide added during incubation with primary antibody).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	147	View larger version (39K):    Fig.

0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Top: Calu-3 cells were initially cultured in lactated Ringer solution followed by (from left to right) 1) mucosal low-Cl concentration ([Cl]) buffer + amiloride (100  microM), 2) addition of mucosal 1  microM Ado, 3) addition of basolateral 1  microM Ado, and 4) blockade with mucosal 200  microM glibenclamide.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Bottom: same experiment as above, except basolateral Ado (1  microM; 2) was added before mucosal Ado (1  microM; 3).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Right: Ado was a strong stimulus when added to either membrane.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	160	0  microM compared with 10  microM.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	161	0  microM compared with 10  microM; and P  <  0.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	162	001 for 10  microM compared with 100  microM.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Apical-stimulated Isc was greater than basolateral-stimulated Isc for 0.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Approximately 90% of the stimulated Isc (100  microM, either membrane) was blocked by glibenclamide (200  microM added to the mucosal compartment; data not shown).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	165	Ado stimulates PLA2, adenylyl cyclase, and CFTR activation.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	166	 In previous studies of CFTR regulation by A2B receptors in COS-7 cells, our laboratory (17) showed that A2B receptor signaling was a potent stimulus, accomplishing strong activation of CFTR despite only modest effects on cellular [cAMP] compared with forskolin.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	167	 These results were similar to those reported by Barrett and colleagues (3, 4) in T84 cells.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	168	 In subsequent studies by Barrett and Bigby (2), Ado-activated Isc in T84 monolayers was found to be associated with AA mobilization and sensitivity to PLA2 inhibition.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	169	 To determine whether PLA2 signaling might contribute to A2 receptor activation of CFTR in airway and COS-7 cells, we evaluated cells for cPLA2 expression and cPLA2 activity after Ado stimulation.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Figure 3 shows that in Calu-3, IB-3-1, and COS-7 cell lysates, a monoclonal anti-cPLA2 antibody detected an ~110-kDa protein consistent with cPLA2.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	171	View larger version (12K):    Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	172	   Identification of cytoplasmic phospholipase A2 (cPLA2) in 3 cell types.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Cell lysates were immunoprecipitated with anti-cPLA2 antibody (Calu-3 and IB-3-1 cells) and separated by SDS-PAGE.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	174	 cPLA2 antigen (~110 kDa) was detected with monoclonal anti-cPLA2 antibody (arrow).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Control conditions were precleared beads from cell lysates without primary antibody (Calu-3 and IB-3-1 cells).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	176	 COS-7 cell lysates were separated by SDS-PAGE and Western blotted with anti-cPLA2 antibody.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Controls received no primary antibody during blotting.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	178	Activated PLA2 releases AA from the sn-2 position of membrane phospholipids.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	179	 To determine whether Ado activated PLA2 and stimulated the release of AA in airway cells that express both A2B receptors and CFTR, Calu-3 cells were grown on plastic and on permeable supports at an air-liquid interface, loaded with [3H]AA, and exposed to Ado (100  microM; Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Ado stimulated AA release from Calu-3 cells grown in either condition.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	181	 AA release is expressed as percent of counts released (basolateral or apical) over total counts; P  0.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	182	 AA was released preferentially from the apical compartment, but a detectable amount (approximately [1/10] of apical release) was released from the basolateral surface (Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Studies of the effects of cPLA2 inhibition (with CPZ) or PKA inhibition (with H-89 Cl) on Ado-stimulated AA release were complicated by a mild (approximately twofold) increase in nonspecific AA release from Calu-3 cells after treatment with either inhibitor.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Cell viability after treatment with either compound was preserved, however, based on cytotoxicity assay studies (data not shown), SPQ retention and response (Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	185	View larger version (9K):    Fig.

0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	198	View larger version (35K):    Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	199	   Ado activation of halide efflux in cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR)-expressing COS-7 cells (A and B) and Calu-3 cells (C-E).

0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	201	 A: COS-7 cells expressing CFTR were stimulated with Ado (arrows), with activation seen at the higher concentration.

0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	204	 AA at 25 and 100  microM (arrows) failed to activate halide efflux.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	205	 B: COS-7 cells expressing CFTR were stimulated with forskolin (Forsk) alone (20  microM; arrow) or with addition of 25  microM AA (200 s) to forskolin stimulation of CFTR (20  microM).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Treatment with CPZ (50  microM) had no effect on forskolin activation.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	207	 T7 controls (no CFTR) stimulated with AA (25  microM at 200 s) and forskolin (20  microM, arrow) failed to activate halide efflux.

0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	214	 E: Calu-3 cells treated with CPZ (50  microM) from 200 s.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	215	 High-concentration Ado (100  microM) partially overcame CPZ blockade.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	216	View larger version (40K):    Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	217	   Ado stimulates cAMP production in COS-7, IB-3-1, and Calu-3 cells.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	218	 cAMP levels were measured by ELISA as described (see METHODS).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Cells were stimulated for 10 min before extraction, n = 4-12 cultures/condition.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Concentrations were 10  microM Ado, 50  microM CPZ, and 100  microM AA.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Papaverine (100  microM) was included in all conditions to enhance cAMP detection as previously described (17).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Values are means  plus or minus  SE for each condition.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	223	001 compared with control (100  microM papaverine).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	224	 D: Calu-3 cells cAMP dose-response curve.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	225	0, and 10  microM) stimulation of cAMP production was not inhibited by treatment with 100  microM CPZ.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	226	02 for Ado alone compared with papaverine control (100  microM).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	227	01 for Ado + CPZ compared with papaverine control.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	228	In addition to investigating CFTR activity with Isc measurements, studies were performed with SPQ, an established assay of CFTR activity and a specific assay of halide transport.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	229	 SPQ-based studies also allowed comparison of A2 receptor-stimulated halide transport in Calu-3 cells with that in COS-7 cells (which fail to polarize).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	230	 These cells represent a simple cell type used to study A2B receptor regulation of WT and mutant CFTRs because they express A2B receptors but not other purinergic receptors commonly found in airway cells and other complex epithelial cells (17).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	231	Ado-stimulated halide efflux in COS-7 cells expressing CFTR is shown in Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Ado alone activated halide efflux at 2  microM but not at 0.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	233	2  microM, consistent with signaling through lower-affinity A2 receptors rather than A1 receptors (Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Treatment of cells with the PLA2 inhibitor CPZ (50  microM) blocked Ado-activated efflux.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	235	 In contrast, addition of the PLA2 product AA (25  microM) augmented the Ado stimulus, shifting activation of halide efflux to 0.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	236	 AA alone (25 and 100  microM), however, failed to activate halide efflux in CFTR-expressing COS-7 cells.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	237	 These results suggest that cPLA2 signaling is part of the pathway by which A2 receptors activate CFTR in this model system.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	238	 The cPLA2 product AA when used alone, however, was insufficient and unable to substitute for Ado.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	239	 The results therefore suggest that for A2 receptors to activate CFTR, additional signaling pathways need to be stimulated.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	240	 5B), forskolin-activated halide efflux in COS-7 cells (+ CFTR) was not inhibited by CPZ.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	241	To test whether these observations applied to airway cells that express both CFTR and A2B receptors, halide efflux experiments were performed in Calu-3 cells.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Ado-activated halide efflux was blocked by CPZ (50  microM), whereas AA alone failed to activate efflux.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	243	 High concentrations of Ado (100  microM) were able to partially overcome the CPZ blockade (Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	244	 The Ado response was also blocked by the PKA inhibitor H-89 Cl (5  microM), indicating that Ado also utilizes adenylyl cyclase and cAMP to activate halide efflux.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	245	 In control experiments, 2-receptor activation of halide efflux with Alb was sensitive to H-89 Cl but not to cPLA2 inhibition with CPZ (Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	246	 These results are consistent with those in the COS-7 cells and indicate that distinct differences exist in the mechanisms by which A2 receptors and 2-receptors activate CFTR and halide transport in these in vitro systems.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	247	A2-ARs traditionally couple to adenylyl cyclase through Gs and elevate cellular cAMP, and previously, our laboratory (17) has shown that A2B receptor stimulation in COS-7 cells increases cAMP in a dose-dependent manner (17).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Whether A2 receptor stimulation of cAMP involves PLA2 signaling, however, is not known.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	249	 Figure 6 shows that in COS-7, IB-3-1, and Calu-3 cells, Ado (10  microM) increased cAMP.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Treatment of cells with the PLA2 inhibitor CPZ (50  microM) had no effect on Ado-stimulated cAMP production in all three cell lines, yet completely abolished Ado-activated halide efflux in both COS-7 and Calu-3 cells (Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Production of cAMP by lower doses of Ado (0.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	252	1 and 1  microM) was also not inhibited by CPZ treatment (Calu-3 cells; Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	253	 These results confirm that A2 receptors do couple to adenylyl cyclase and elevate cAMP but also show that the inhibitory effect that CPZ exerts on Ado stimulation of CFTR is independent of cAMP.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Rather, the results shown in Figs.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	255	 4-6 suggest that Ado stimulation leads to both cPLA2 and PKA activation, with each pathway required for the stimulation of CFTR.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	256	AA alone (100  microM) had variable effects on [cAMP], stimulating some cAMP production in airway cells (P  <  0.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	257	001 for the Calu-3 cells compared with control conditions) but not in COS-7 cells.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	258	 The cAMP produced by high-dose AA appeared to contribute little to CFTR activation.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	259	 AA alone was insufficient to acutely activate halide efflux in either Calu-3 cells or COS-7 cells expressing CFTR (Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	260	 5), and AA had no additive effect on [cAMP] when combined with Ado stimulation in any of the three cell types.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	261	 This was in contrast to the functional results, such as those shown in Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	262	 5A, in which the addition of AA to Ado stimulation appeared to augment CFTR-dependent halide efflux.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	263	Ado activation of CFTR-dependent Cl transport in vivo.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	264	 The results given in Ado stimulates PLA2, adenylyl cyclase, and CFTR activation provide a framework in which to investigate Ado-activated Cl transport in vivo.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	265	 For these studies, we investigated ion transport across the murine nasal mucosa using the nasal PD, a well-established bioelectric assay of CFTR activity in vivo.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	266	 Figure 7 shows examples of nasal PD tracings from a cftr(+) (Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	267	 In the cftr(+) mouse, Ado stimulated further hyperpolarization (Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	268	 7A, arrow #3), consistent with Cl conductance.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	269	 In the cftr(/) mouse, depolarization continued during perfusion with a low [Cl] solution and a low [Cl] solution plus Ado (500  microM).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Figure 8A summarizes a comparison of Ado (100  microM)-, Alb (100  microM)-, isoproterenol (Iso; 100  microM)-, and forskolin (10  microM)-stimulated Cl secretion in cftr(+) mice.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	271	 Ado was a potent Cl secretagogue, producing further polarization in 10 of 12 mice studied (P  <  0.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	272	005 compared with the no-agonist or Iso control mice).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	273	 Alb was also a strong agonist (similar to forskolin), producing further polarization in six of eight mice studied (P  <  0.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	274	05 for Alb and forskolin compared with Iso and control animals).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	275	 In contrast, Iso was less predictable, producing further hyperpolarization in only 5 of 14 mice.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	276	 Both AR stimulation with Ado (500  microM) and 2-receptor stimulation with the more specific 2-receptor agonist Alb (500  microM) failed to activate Cl conductance in cftr(/) mice (Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	277	 These studies confirm that both receptors stimulate CFTR-dependent Cl transport.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	278	 Ado-stimulated Cl conductance in cftr(+) mice was sensitive to A2 receptor blockade with 8-phenyltheophylline (P  <  0.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	279	02), indicating that Ado activates Cl conductance through A2 receptor signaling (Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	280	View larger version (19K):    Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	281	   Examples of nasal potential differences (PDs) in cftr(+) and cftr(/) mice.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Mice underwent a standard nasal PD protocol as described in METHODS.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	283	 Solution 1, lactated Ringer + 100  microM amiloride; solution 2, low [Cl] solution + 100  microM amiloride; solution 3, solution 2 + agonist.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	284	 Upward deflections are hyperpolarization (lumen negative), conventionally taken to represent Cl secretion.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	285	 A: cftr(+) mouse with 100  microM Ado included in solution 3.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	286	 B: cftr(/) mouse with 500  microM Ado included in solution 3.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	287	 A depolarizing phenotype throughout the entire protocol is seen.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	288	View larger version (11K):    Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	289	   Stimulated Cl transport in cftr(+) (A and C) and cftr(/) (B) mice.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	290	 Change in PD after the switch to solution 3 is shown.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	291	 A: cftr(+) mice stimulated with Ado (100  microM; n = 12), Alb (100  microM; n = 8), Forsk (10  microM; n = 10), isoproterenol (Iso; 100  microM; n = 14), and low [Cl] control (no agonist; n = 18) included in solution 3 are shown.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	292	005 for Ado compared with ISO or control.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	293	025 for FORSK compared with ISO or control; P  <  0.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	294	05 for Alb compared with ISO or control.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	295	 B: cftr(/) mice stimulated with Ado (500  microM; n = 10) or Alb (500  microM; n = 10).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	296	 A depolarizing phenotype is seen with both agonists that is similar to that of cftr(/) control mice (low-[Cl] alone in solution 3; n = 14).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	297	 C: cftr(+) mice stimulated with 50  microM Ado in solution 3 (n = 8) and 50  microM Ado (solution 3) + 100  microM 8-phenyltheophylline (8-PT) in solutions 2 and 3 (n = 10).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	298	02 for change in PD after stimulation with solution 3 (+ Ado) compared with solution 2 (no agonist).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	299	We next investigated the contribution of PLA2 to Cl secretion across the murine nasal mucosa.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	300	 Figure 9 shows the effect of the PLA2 inhibitor CPZ (100  microM) on Ado- and Alb-stimulated Cl conductance.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	301	 Ado (500  microM) strongly stimulated Cl secretion that was blocked by CPZ treatment (P  <  0.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	302	 In contrast, Alb (500  microM)-stimulated Cl secretion was not affected by CPZ.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	303	 Costimulation with Ado and Alb (500  microM each) failed to produce additive effects on Cl conductance, indicating that the two signaling pathways converge on CFTR-dependent and not other (CFTR-independent) Cl transport pathways (data not shown).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	304	 These results also confirm our in vitro observations, which demonstrated that A2 receptor activation of CFTR in vivo depends on PLA2 activity.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	305	View larger version (11K):    Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	306	   cPLA2 inhibition blocks Ado-stimulated Cl transport.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	307	 Nasal PDs were performed in cftr(+) mice as described in Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	308	 Mice were stimulated with Ado (500  microM) or Alb (500  microM) in solution 3 in the presence and absence of CPZ (100  microM, included in solutions 2 and 3).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	309	02 for Ado + CPZ compared with Ado alone, Alb alone, or Alb + CPZ.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	310	A2B-ARs activate F508 CFTR and G551D CFTR.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	311	 The results discussed in Ado activation of CFTR-dependent Cl transport in vivo show that Ado and A2 receptor signaling potently activate CFTR-dependent Cl transport in vitro and in vivo.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	312	 To determine whether A2B receptor signaling could be used to improve the activity of common disease-causing CFTR mutations, we transiently expressed F508 CFTR (class II mutation) and G551D CFTR (class III mutation) in COS-7 cells.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	313	 Figure 10 shows that after localization to the cell membrane (growth at 29 degrees C for 48 h), F508 CFTR was activated by A2B receptor stimulation (10  microM Ado) in a fashion similar to direct adenylyl cyclase activation with forskolin (20  microM).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	314	 Halide efflux was stronger than that produced by stimulation with DPCPX, an agent that can acutely stimulate F508 CFTR-dependent halide efflux in F508 CFTR-expressing cells [and is currently in clinical trials as an activator of F508 CFTR in CF patients (24, 30); P  <  0.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	315	001 comparing the proportion of responding cells stimulated by Ado with DPCPX].
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	316	 We did not test the ability of A2B receptor stimulation to activate F508 CFTR after prolonged treatment with DPCPX.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	317	 Activation of F508 CFTR was accomplished despite only modest effects of Ado on [cAMP] compared with forskolin (17).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	318	View larger version (31K):    Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	319	   A2B receptor activation of halide efflux in F508 CFTR-expressing cells.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	320	 COS-7 cells expressing F508 CFTR were studied after growth at 29 degrees C for 48 h.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	321	 Cells were perfused with NaI quenching buffer from 0 to 200 s, NO3 dequenching buffer from 200 to 500 s, and NO3 buffer + agonist from 500 s (arrow).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	322	 of screened cells per condition (as described in METHODS).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	323	 of responding cells in each condition was compared by the 2 test.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	324	 Values are means  plus or minus  SE of responding cells in each stimulated condition for Forsk (20  microM) and Ado (10  microM) or means  plus or minus  SE of nonresponding cells for the 8-cyclopentyl-1,3-dipropylxanthine (DPCPX; 30 nM)-stimulated cells and NO3 control cells.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	325	 Concentration of DPCPX used has previously been shown to maximally induce acute 36Cl release from F508 CFTR-expressing cells (24, 30).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	326	001 for Ado or Forsk compared with DPCPX or NO3 conditions.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	327	 11, COS-7 cells expressing G551D CFTR were stimulated with forskolin, Ado, or AA.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	328	 A series of PDE inhibitors was also evaluated because previous reports (62, 63, 77) suggested that surface-localized mutant CFTRs might be partially responsive to stimulation with certain PDE inhibitors.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	329	 Isotype-specific inhibitors (rolipram, PDE-4 specific; milrinone, PDE-3 specific; and zaprinast, PDE-5 and -6 specific) were used at concentrations ~20-fold above the inhibitor constant of their respective PDEs (72).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	330	 Two nonspecific PDE inhibitors (papaverine and theophylline) were studied at 200  microM.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	331	 PDE inhibitors such as milrinone have been evaluated in clinical trials for their ability to activate Cl conductance in normal subjects and in CF patients carrying the G551D CFTR mutation (68).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	332	 At the concentrations used, none of the PDE inhibitors alone consistently elevated cAMP in COS-7 cells (10-min exposure; data not shown), and none of the stimuli (including Ado) activated G551D CFTR-specific halide efflux (Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	333	 WT CFTR-expressing cells stimulated with forskolin are shown for comparison.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	334	 11B, G551D CFTR-expressing COS-7 cells were exposed to combinations of Ado (200  microM), AA (100  microM), and PDE inhibitors.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	335	 In contrast to the results in Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	336	 11A, A2B receptor stimulation, when combined with AA and PDE inhibition, strongly activated halide efflux in a fashion similar to that produced in WT CFTR-expressing cells.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	337	 Together, the results shown in Figs.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	338	 10 and 11 indicate that the activity of the two most common disease-associated CFTR mutations can be increased dramatically with A2B-AR signaling.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	339	View larger version (32K):    Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	340	   Activation of halide efflux in G551D CFTR-expressing cells.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	341	 A: G551D CFTR-expressing cells compared with wild-type (WT) CFTR-expressing cells.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	342	 COS-7 cells transiently expressing WT or G551D CFTR were studied with 6-methoxy-N-(3-sulfopropyl)quinolinium (SPQ) as described in METHODS; n 40 cells/condition.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	343	 G551D CFTR-expressing cells failed to activate halide efflux when stimulated with Ado (200  microM) + papaverine (PAP; 200  microM), Ado + rolipram (ROL; 20  microM) in combination, or Forsk (20  microM; arrow).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	344	 WT CFTR-expressing cells stimulated with Forsk (CFTR + Forsk; 20  microM) are shown for comparison.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	345	 B: G551D CFTR-expressing COS-7 cells stimulated with Ado (200  microM) and AA (100  microM) combined with a series of phosphodiesterase inhibitors (PDEis).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	346	 Cells were perfused with NO3 buffer + AA from 200 s and Ado + PDEi was added (arrows).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	347	 Isotype-specific PDEis were studied at concentrations ~20-fold over the inhibition constant of their respective PDEs.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	348	 Cells were also studied with Ado + AA alone (i.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	349	 Values are means  plus or minus  SE of all cells studied in each condition (n  >  40).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	350	 Concentrations of PDEis were (in  microM) 20 milrinone (MIL), 20 ROL, 200 PAP, 5 ZAP, and 200 theophylline (THEO).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	351	    DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	352	In this report, we investigated the cellular pathways utilized by Ado to activate CFTR-dependent ion transport.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	353	 Using a series of experimental systems, including single cells, polarized cell monolayers, and in vivo measurements in cftr(+) and cftr(/) mice, we demonstrated that Ado, through A2-ARs, activates CFTR-dependent halide transport.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	354	 These receptors are expressed in human airway cells and signal in part through cAMP and PKA.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	355	 We also demonstrated the dependence of this signaling pathway on PLA2 activity in vitro and in vivo.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	356	 Finally, we showed that the two most common disease-associated CFTR mutations can be activated by A2B receptors alone (F508 CFTR) or by using messenger pathways stimulated by A2B receptors (G551D CFTR).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	357	 These results help to establish the physiological role of Ado-stimulated Cl secretion in vivo and may identify new targets for improving the function of mutant CFTR molecules.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	358	Ado is a ubiquitous signaling molecule, serving protean functions ranging from regulation of neurotransmission to cardiovascular tone and inflammation in many organ systems.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	359	 Our results, together with those of other investigators, indicate an important role for Ado as a regulator of CFTR.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	360	 Ado and A2 receptors are potent activators of Cl secretion in primary human airway cell monolayers, in addition to canine and gerbil airway cells and T84 intestinal cells (28, 46, 59, 70).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	361	 In each of these systems, Cl secretion has been accomplished in the setting of low cAMP levels.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	362	 Part of this high efficiency is due to compartmentalization of A2B receptors, transduction proteins, and CFTR (34, 71).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	363	 Our results suggest that in addition to spatial compartmentalization, efficient transduction between A2 receptors and CFTR involves cPLA2 activation and AA signaling.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	364	 A2 receptors, including A2A and A2B subtypes, classically signal through stimulation of adenylyl cyclase, cAMP, and, ultimately, PKA (56).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	365	 Although A2A receptors appear to hold more strictly to this observation, A2B receptors have been shown to stimulate additional signaling pathways such as phospholipase C, direct regulation of calcium channels, and, in our experience, PLA2 (26).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	366	 These observations are of particular interest because recent studies (27) have demonstrated abnormal lipid profiles, including elevated AA levels, in murine CF tissues.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	367	 Our findings demonstrate that lipid signaling may be important to the regulation of CFTR activity by Ado in vitro and in vivo.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	368	 The present results therefore set the stage for future studies designed to test the relationship between membrane lipid composition, A2 receptors, and CFTR activity.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	369	There are two general classes of PLA2 enzymes: cPLA2 (three subtypes) and secretory PLA2 (seven subtypes) (33).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	370	 Both are expressed in many tissues including the lung and leukocytes.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	371	 cPLA2 translocates to cell membranes after activation and primarily releases AA from membrane lipids.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	372	 cPLA2 has been shown to play an important immunologic role in human airway epithelial cells, governing AA release from epithelia after immunostimulation (76).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	373	 Studies (50) have also observed dysregulation of PLA2 in the CF airway, with increased AA release seen after bradykinin exposure in F508 CFTR-expressing airway cells compared with normal control cells.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	374	 AA is the parent molecule of two important inflammatory signaling cascades including 1) the cyclooxygenase (COX) pathway, which leads to the production of prostanoids and thromboxanes and 2) the lipoxygenase pathway in which AA is metabolized to 5-hydroperoxyeicosatetraenoic acid, 5-hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid, and the leukotrienes A4-E4.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	375	 Clinical studies suggest that products of AA metabolism, including proinflammatory species, have direct relevance to CF-related inflammation.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	376	 The COX-1 inhibitor ibuprofen is routinely used in the pediatric CF population to reduce lung inflammation and slow the progression of CF lung disease (45).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	377	 Glucocorticoids, which suppress COX-2 expression, have also been studied in CF clinical trials, attenuating the decline in pulmonary function in pediatric CF patients (25).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	378	 The relevance of AA signaling pathways to CFTR activity and ion transport, however, has not been previously demonstrated.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	379	 Our results suggest that a buildup in AA may have beneficial effects on CFTR activity in the context of its activation by surface receptors.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	380	The mechanism by which A2 receptors activate CFTR-dependent Cl transport is complex.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	381	 CFTR activation by A2 receptors could be blocked by either PKA or cPLA2 inhibition (Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	382	 Production of cAMP was not reduced by PLA2 inhibition in any of the three cell lines (Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	383	 Although 10 min of high-dose (100  microM) AA exposure could stimulate some cAMP production in the two airway cell lines (primarily Calu-3 cells, likely through the actions of distal metabolites such as PGI, PGE2, PGF2 or PGD) (73), it failed to augment cAMP production by Ado or acutely activate CFTR when used alone (COS-7 or Calu-3 cells; Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	384	 These results suggest that the additional effects of AA on CFTR-dependent halide transport were not through influences on total cellular cAMP.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	385	 Rather, A2 receptors appear to activate both adenylyl cyclase and cPLA2 in parallel, with each signaling pathway contributing to the maximization of CFTR activity.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	386	 PLA2 signaling was not necessary to activate CFTR through receptors, however, because 2-adrenergic stimulation activated CFTR-dependent Cl transport in vitro and in vivo despite cPLA2 inhibition (Figs.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	387	Figure 12 is a summary model that provides three possible mechanisms by which cPLA2 and AA could contribute to A2 receptor activation of CFTR.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	388	 It is possible that Ado and/or AA exerts its effects in part by activating K+ channels and increasing the driving force for halide efflux.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	389	 AA has been shown to have both stimulatory and inhibitory effects on epithelial K+ channels, and modulation of basolateral K+ channel activity can strongly influence transepithelial Cl transport (20, 21).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	390	 In related experiments, Ado-activated halide efflux in CFTR-expressing COS-7 cells was not reduced by two K+ channel blockers, including barium and tetraethylammonium (10 mM each) (18, 19).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	391	 These results suggest that the stimulatory effects of Ado on CFTR seen in our studies were independent of K+ channel activation.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	392	 The observation that AA augmented the stimulation of CFTR by Ado and forskolin (Figs.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	393	 5 and 11), but failed to stimulate CFTR alone in vitro (Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	394	 5), suggests that AA may exert a permissive effect on CFTR activation.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	395	 Membrane-derived fatty acids, including AA and its metabolites, have been demonstrated to interact with ion channels and influence their activation by other signaling molecules, including nucleotide sensitivity of ATP-activated K+ channels (5, 65), light-sensitive transient receptor potential, and transient receptor potential-like channels (14), small Cl channels in rabbit parietal cells (61), the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor (9), and calcium channels as part of oscillating calcium currents (51).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	396	 AA does interact with CFTR and alter its Cl channel activity.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	397	 Cytoplasmic AA produces a flickery block of CFTR in inside-out membrane patches after heterologous expression (1, 35, 47).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	398	 Membrane lipids (including AA) can have differential effects on the function of other channels, stimulating channel activity on one surface and inhibiting channel activity on the other (52).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	399	 We speculate that AA or one of its metabolites may interact with an external portion of the channel or with an unidentified regulatory factor that secondarily influences CFTR Cl channel function.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	400	 Alternatively, products of AA metabolism could accelerate local cAMP production and, in this way, increase CFTR channel activity.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	401	 This process would be difficult to detect with total cellular assays to quantitate [cAMP].
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	402	 The effect would need to be quite dramatic, however, because G551D CFTR, which has previously been shown to be poorly responsive to powerful phosphorylating stimuli, appears to be activated by costimulation with AA (Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	403	 This occurs despite no detectable change in [cAMP] when combined with Ado (Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	404	 6A) but is most pronounced when combined with PDE inhibition.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	405	 Single-channel-based studies will be necessary to help clarify the mechanism by which cPLA2 and AA promote CFTR activity.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	406	 Finally, our results do not exclude the possibility that additional processes may be involved because CPZ has been shown to have effects on other cell signaling pathways in addition to PLA2 (8, 12, 23, 43, 57).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	407	View larger version (16K):    Fig.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	408	   Three potential mechanisms by which A2 receptors signal CFTR activation.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	409	 Ado stimulates A2 adenosine receptors (A2-AR), which activate cPLA2 and adenylyl cyclase.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	410	 AA or products of AA metabolism, when combined with cAMP, helped maximize CFTR transport of Cl.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	411	 The mechanism could involve effects on the electrochemical driving force for ion transport through CFTR (i.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	412	, activation of K+ channels) through direct effects of lipid species with CFTR or associated factors (direct effects) or possibly by increasing the rate of cAMP production in the vicinity of CFTR (accelerated cAMP production).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	413	 COX, cyclooxygenase; LO, lipoxygenase.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	414	 7-9 indicate that Ado is a potent Cl secretagogue in vivo, activating CFTR-dependent Cl transport across the murine nasal mucosa more predictably than Iso (when studied at 100  microM).
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	415	 This is of relevance to human nasal PD protocols, which typically use 2-receptor stimulation with Iso to aid in the detection of CFTR-dependent Cl transport.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	416	 Our results suggest that comparisons of these two receptor pathways in human subjects may improve the sensitivity of the nasal PD, which could have implications for clinical studies that use this assay to measure low-level CFTR function.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	417	 The importance of PLA2 signaling to Ado activation of Cl transport was also demonstrated in vivo because Ado- but not Alb-stimulated Cl conductance was sensitive to PLA2 inhibition.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	418	A2 receptor signaling may also be useful in improving the activity of disease-related CFTR mutations.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	419	 Using an in vitro system, we have demonstrated that CFTR mutations from three subclasses (classes II, III, and IV) can be activated by A2B receptors (17) (Figs.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	420	 Although the expression levels of the mutant CFTRs were far higher than those found in vivo, the results shown in Figs.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	421	 10 and 11 support the notion that mutant CFTRs, when localized to the cell membrane, can be activated by endogenous receptor-based signaling pathways.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	422	 Current approaches to increase mutant CFTR activity, including improvement of CFTR biosynthesis [e.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	423	, suppression of premature stop mutations with aminoglycoside antibiotics (7, 15, 75)], increase in trafficking of F508 CFTR to the cell membrane [e.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	424	, treatment with butyrate compounds (60)], or treatment of surface mutant CFTRs with activating compounds [e.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	425	, genistein or PDE inhibitors (38, 68)] may be complemented by the use of A2 receptor signaling pathways.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	426	 Our findings also suggest that common mutant CFTRs should be at least partially responsive to this signaling pathway when available at the cell membrane.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	427	In summary, our studies demonstrate that A2B-ARs are expressed in CF and normal airway cells, localizing predominantly to the apical membrane of polarized Calu-3 cells.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	428	 A2 receptors mediate activation of CFTR-dependent Cl transport in vitro and in vivo, utilizing cPLA2 and AA in addition to cAMP and PKA.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	429	 Ado and A2-ARs compare favorably with other agents as activators of CFTR-dependent Cl conductance, stimulating Cl secretion better than the 2-adrenergic receptor agonist Iso in mice and activating F508 CFTR similar to forskolin in vitro.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	430	 Our studies therefore provide a rationale for the investigation of the effects of Ado and A2 receptor signaling on measured Cl secretion in humans.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	431	We thank the University of Alabama at Birmingham (UAB) Adult and Pediatric Ear, Nose, and Throat Departments for providing remnant human tissue for immunocytochemical studies; Dr.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	432	 Zsuzsa Bebok (Department of Internal Medicine and UAB Cystic Fibrosis Research Center) and Albert Tousson (UAB Imaging Facilities Core) for providing guidance with the immunocytochemistry experiments; and Dr.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	433	 Kevin Kirk for helpful discussions regarding the manuscript.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	434	This work was supported by Cystic Fibrosis Foundation Grants CLANCY96LO and R464 and National Institutes of Health Grants R01-HL-67088-01, P50-DK-53090, and P30-DK-54781.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	435	 Clancy is a Cystic Fibrosis Foundation Leroy Matthews Award recipient.
