0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	669	00 Copyright   2002 the American Physiological Society.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	0	Rme-1 regulates the recycling of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator John A.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Picciano,1 Nadia Ameen,1,2 Barth D.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	2	1Cystic Fibrosis Research Centre, Department of Cell Biology and Physiology, 2Children's Hospital, University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15261; and 3Department of Molecular Biology and Biochemistry Rutgers, Piscataway, New Jersey 08854.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	3	Submitted 9 April 2003 ; accepted in final form 18 June 2003.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	4	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT METHODS AND MATERIALS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Endocytic motifs in the carboxyl terminus of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) direct internalization from the plasma membrane by clathrin-mediated endocytosis.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	5	 However, the fate of such internalized CFTR has remained unknown.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Internalized membrane proteins can be either targeted for degradation or recycled back to the plasma membrane.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Using cell surface biotinylation and antibody uptake studies, we show that CFTR undergoes constitutive endocytosis and recycling back to the plasma membrane.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Expression of dominant negative Rme-1 (a protein that regulates exit from the endosomal recycling compartment) in CFTR-expressing cells results in the expansion of recycling compartments.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Transferrin, a marker for the endosomal recycling compartment, and CFTR accumulate in these enlarged recycling endosomes.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Such accumulation leads to a loss of cell surface CFTR because it is prevented from being recycled back to the cell surface.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	11	 In contrast, traffic of the low-density lipoprotein (LDL) is unaffected by the expression of dominant negative Rme-1.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	12	 In addition, chimeras containing the extracellular domain of the transferrin receptor and the carboxyl terminal tail of CFTR also enter Rme-1-regulated recycling compartments and accumulate in these compartments containing dominant negative Rme-1, suggesting that in addition to endocytic signals, the carboxyl terminal tail of CFTR also contains intracellular traffic information.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	13	cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator; Rme-1; endocytosis; recycling; channel.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	14	CYSTIC FIBROSIS (CF), a common lethal genetic disease of Caucasians, results from mutations in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR), a member of the ABC superfamily of transport proteins (28).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	15	 CFTR is a cAMP-activated anion channel and channel regulator that functions at the apical membrane of polarized epithelia to regulate secretion in the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts (37).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Previous studies have shown that CFTR is not a stable component of the plasma membrane but is rather efficiently endocytosed from the cell surface (18, 27, 35) through clathrin-coated pits (4, 5).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Furthermore, such entry of CFTR into the clathrin-dependent endocytic pathway is mediated by binding of a tyrosine-based endocytic motif in the carboxyl terminus of CFTR (27, 35) to the medium subunit of the AP2 clathrin adaptor complex (36).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	18	 In addition to endocytic motifs, CFTR also interacts with PDZ-domain containing proteins (29, 32) and AMP kinase (10) at its carboxyl terminus and syntax-ins at its amino terminus (24, 25).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	19	 How all these interactions modulate cell surface expression of CFTR is not clear (2, 22), although morphological, biochemical, and functional data indicate that CFTR is present in cell surface and intracellular compartments in both heterologous expression systems and epithelial cells that natively express CFTR (1, 3, 33).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Although much is now known about the mechanisms of CFTR internalization, the fate of internalized CFTR is less well documented.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Previous studies have suggested that internalized CFTR is recycled (31), but the pathway and compartments through which CFTR traverses to undergo recycling are not known.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	22	Endocytosed material is directed initially to a sorting endosomal compartment from which it is directed to one of two destinations.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Some molecules such as the low-density lipoprotein (LDL) are retained in the sorting endosome, which matures into and/or fuses with late endosomes (6).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Molecules that are destined to be recycled back to the cell surface are initially targeted to the endosomal recycling compartment (ERC) (9, 23).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	25	 While the ERC has been extensively characterized on the basis of studies of transferrin receptor recycling (39) and insulin-regulated recycling of GLUT-4 (14), there are no data concerning the entry of ion channels, such as CFTR, into this compartment for recycling back to the cell surface.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Rme-1 is an epsin homology (EH) domain containing protein (8) recently identified as a key element in controlling exit from the ERC (15).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	27	 A dominant negative Rme-1 (Rme-1 G429R), when expressed in mammalian cells, has no effect on the endocytosis of integral membrane proteins such as the transferrin receptor but dramatically inhibits the recycling of the transferrin receptor back to the cell surface, trapping the receptor in the ERC (15).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Endocytosed proteins such as LDL, which are targeted to lysosomes and do not enter the ERC, are unaffected.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	29	 We examined the fate of endocytosed CFTR by using dominant negative Rme-1 as a tool for probing transport of CFTR through the ERC.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	30	   METHODS AND MATERIALS TOP ABSTRACT METHODS AND MATERIALS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Plasmids.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	31	 The transferrin receptor/CFTR chimera, in which the entire cytoplasmic domain of the transferrin receptor was replaced with amino acids 1,391-1,476 of CFTR, was a generous gift from Dr.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Jim Collawn (University of Alabama at Birmingham) (27).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	33	 TfR/CFTR was subcloned into the mammalian expression vector pCMV4 (Stratagene) using Cla1, and orientation was confirmed by sequence analysis.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Isogenic 293 cells stably expressing wild-type CFTR were generated as previously described (30) and maintained in DMEM supplemented with 10% FBS and hygromycin (150  microg/ml).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Two-hundred ninety-three cells expressing CFTR were transfected transiently by LipofectAMINE (GIBCO BRL) at 60% confluence and analyzed after 48-72 h.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	36	 TRvb1, a Chinese hamster ovarian (CHO) cell line that fails to express transferrin receptors, was generously provided by Dr.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Tim McGraw (Cornell University, Ithaca, NY) (20).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	38	 TRvb1 cells were transiently transfected with a transferrin receptor/CFTR chimera using LipofectAMINE (GIBCO BRL) and 24 h later with G429R green fluorescent protein (GFP)-tagged Rme-1.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Experiments were performed 48 h later.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	40	 To monitor recycling of CFTR, we used a modified cell surface biotinylation assay (7, 31, 34).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Briefly, plasma membranes were biotinylated at 4 degrees C using a cleavable reagent (Sulpho-NHS-SS-biotin; Pierce, Rockford, IL) and then warmed up to 37 degrees C to load endocytic vesicles with biotinylated proteins (including CFTR).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Remaining cell surface biotin was removed using MESNA as previously described (34).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Subsequently, the cells were either lysed or rewarmed to 37 degrees C to allow internalized biotinylated CFTR to recycle to the cell surface.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The cells were again cooled to 4 degrees C, the disulphide bonds on recycled cell surface proteins were reduced with MESNA, and the cells were lysed.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Biotinylated proteins were isolated by streptavidin-agarose beads, eluted into SDS sample buffer, and resolved on a 7.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Biotinylated CFTR was detected by Western blot analysis as described above.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	47	Fluorescent labeling and indirect immunofluorescence.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	48	 CFTR-expressing 293 cells were grown on polylysine-coated glass coverslips.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Two to three days posttransfection with or without GFP-tagged dominant negative Rme-1, cells were rinsed in ice-cold PBS supplemented with 2 mM CaCl2 and 1 mM MgCl2 (PBS-CM).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Cells were fixed in 2% paraformalde-hyde/0.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	51	1% Triton X-100 and exposed to antibodies against CFTR (M3A7 and L12B4; Upstate Waltham).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Antibody binding was visualized by using Cy3-conjugated goat anti-mouse secondary antibodies (Molecular Probes, Eugene, OR).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Antibodies against Rme were a generous gift from Dr.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Robinson (University of Cambridge, Cambridge, UK).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	55	 To label cells with transferrin, cells were incubated with 10  microg/ml Cy3-transferrin.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	56	 DiLDL (LDL labeled with 3,3'-dioctadecyclindocarbocyanine) was from Molecular Probes.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Confocal images were obtained on a Zeiss 510 META confocal scanning microscope.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Staining for CFTR was performed essentially as described (1).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Briefly, 293 cells were fixed in 2% paraformaldehyde in PBS for 2 h at room temperature, pelleted, and then embedded in 3% liquid gelatin and placed on ice for 10 min.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	60	1 M PBS overnight at 4 degrees C.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	61	 The pellet was frozen onto ultracryotome stubs under liquid nitrogen and stored in liquid nitrogen until use.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Ultra thin sections (70-100 nm) were cut by using a Reichert Ultracut U ultramicrotome with a FC4S cryoattachment.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Sections were picked up onto a drop of 2.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	64	3 M sucrose and mounted on Formvar-coated copper grids.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Briefly, sections were washed with PBS and then with nonspecific binding blocked with PBS containing 0.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	66	5% bovine serum albumin (BSA) and 0.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	67	15% glycine (in PBS containing 0.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	68	5% BSA), followed by a 30-min incubation with 5% normal goat serum.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Sections were incubated in primary antibodies (1:50) for 1 h and labeled with colloidal gold (1:25) at room temperature for 1 h (Amersham, Piscataway, NJ).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Sections were washed in PBS containing 0.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	71	5% BSA and PBS and fixed with 2.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Sections were post-stained in 4% uranyl acetate and embedded in 1.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Labeling was observed on a JEOL JEM 1210 electron microscope (Peabody) at 80 kV.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Cells were washed with ice-cold PBS and lysed in TGH buffer (1% vol/vol Triton X-100, 10% vol/vol glycerol, 25 mM HEPES-Na [pH 7.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	75	4]) containing protease inhibitors (Complete EDTA-free protease inhibitors; Roche) for 20 min on ice.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Nuclei and unbroken cells were removed by centrifugation (at 15,000 g for 5 min at 4 degrees C).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Soluble proteins were resolved on a 7.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	78	5% SDS-PAGE gel and transferred to a nitrocellulose membrane.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	79	 After block, membranes were probed with antibodies (CFTR; M3A7 Upstate, transferrin receptor; BD Pharmingen) and visualized by enhanced chemiluminescence (Pico West) as described (36).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	80	Immunomagnetic isolation of CFTR containing vesicles.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	81	 CFTR-expressing 293 cells transfected with G429R Rme-1 were washed in PBS and homogenized by passing the cells 20 times through a 25-gauge needle in buffer (250 mM sucrose containing 50 mM Na-HEPES [pH 7.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Postnuclear supernatants were obtained by centrifugation and incubated overnight at 4 degrees C with 1  microg/ml each of M3A7 and LB12B4 anti-CFTR antibodies.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Washed paramagnetic beads (25  microl) coated with sheep anti-mouse antibodies (Dynal Biotech) were added for a further 90-min incubation at 4 degrees C.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Vesicles were washed and isolated using standard magnetic separation protocols and subjected to immunoblot analysis by using antibodies described in the text.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	85	   RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT METHODS AND MATERIALS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   CFTR undergoes constitutive recycling.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	86	 To investigate endocytic recycling of CFTR, we initially confirmed that CFTR undergoes constitutive internalization.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	87	 1A, we observed a linear increase in the endocytic internalization of CFTR between 0 and 8 min.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	88	 After 6-8 min, the amount of apparent CFTR internalization did not increase because CFTR is rapidly recycled back to the cell surface (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	89	 We observed a linear increase in endocytic recycling of CFTR back to the cell surface between 0 and 5 min.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Thereafter, the amount of apparent CFTR recycling back to the cell surface failed to increase, presumably due to the rapid reinternalization of CFTR from the plasma membrane (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	91	View larger version (13K):    Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) undergoes constitutive endocytosis and recycling.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Endocytosis (A) and recycling (B) of CFTR were monitored as described in MATERIALS AND METHODS.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Results are expressed as means  plus or minus  SE of at least 3 separate experiments.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	95	Rme-1 identifies a recycling compartment in 293 cells.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	96	 To characterize further the endocytic recycling of CFTR, we investigated whether internalized CFTR entered compartments whose turnover was regulated by Rme-1.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Anti-Rme-1 antibodies labeled three structures within CFTR expressing 293 cells (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	98	 2a)-a compartment within the perinuclear region, intracellular vesicles, and the plasma membrane (see Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	99	 2a, inset), consistent with the localization of Rme-1 in CHO cells (15).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	100	 There was no colocalization of Rme-1 with endoplasmic reticulum markers (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	101	 2, a-c), lysosomal markers (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	102	 2, g-i), early endosome markers (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	103	 A minor component of apparent overlap was observed with Golgi compartments (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	104	 However, the signals were largely separable, and minor overlap probably represents a lack of special resolution of the optical slice.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	105	View larger version (84K):    Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Distribution of endogenous Rme-1 in 293 cells.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Cells were fixed and stained with polyclonal antibodies against Rme-1 (followed by secondary antibodies conjugated to Alexa 488) and monoclonal antibodies against endoplasmic reticulum (ER) markers (Bip) (a-c), Golgi markers (Golgin 97) (d-f), lysosomal markers (Lamp-1) (g-i), and early endosome markers (EEA1) (j-l) (followed by secondary antibodies conjugated to Cy3).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Mitochondria were initially labeled in live cells using Mito-tracker (Molecular Probes), followed by fixation and staining for Rme-1 (m-o).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	109	Expression of G429R Rme-1 slows transferrin recycling.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	110	 To confirm that G429R Rme-1 inhibited exit from endosomal recycling compartments in 293 cells, we transiently expressed GFP-tagged G429R Rme-1 in cells stably expressing wild-type CFTR.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Endosomal recycling compartments were identified by incubating cells for 60 min at 37 degrees C in the continued presence of Cy3-labeled transferrin.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	112	 3a), transferrin-positive compartments were seen as discrete perinuclear vesicles throughout the cytoplasm of the cell.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	113	 When experiments were performed using cells transiently transfected with G429R Rme-1, transferrin was observed in large perinuclear compartments (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Such compartments colocalized with GFP-tagged G429R Rme-1 (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	115	 3, c and d), consistent with the effects of G429R Rme-1 on affecting exit but not entry into the ERC.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Nontransfected cells incubated under similar conditions with DiLDL showed uptake of labeled LDL into large cytoplasmic vesicles (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	117	 3e), presumably late endosomes/lysosomes.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Transient expression of G429R Rme-1 (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	119	 3, g and h) did not affect the localization of DiLDL (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	120	 3, f and h), which showed little or no colocalization with GFP-tagged G429R Rme-1 (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	121	 These results are consistent with the premise that G429R Rme-1 has no effect on endocytic uptake nor on traffic to late endosomes/lysosomes but only affects exit from recycling compartments.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	122	View larger version (39K):    Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Expression of G429R Rme-1 affects the subcellular localization of transferrin but not low-density lipoprotein (LDL).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Cells stably expressing wild-type Rme-1 were incubated for 1 h in the continued presence of Cy3-labeled transferrin (a) or LDL labeled with 3,3'-dioctadecyclindocarbocyanine (DiLDL) (e).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Expression of G429R Rme-1 caused a redistribution of transferrin to large cytosolic vesicles (b) that colocalized with GFP-tagged G429R Rme-1 (c).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	126	 The merge of the transferrin and G429R signal shows almost complete overlap (d).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Expression of G429R Rme-1 did not affect the delivery of DiLDL to late endosomes and lysosomes (f), and no colocalization between GFP-tagged Rme-1 (g) and DiLDL was seen [as shown by lack of colocalization in the merge (h)].
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	128	CFTR is targeted to Rme-1-positive compartments.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Having shown that internalized CFTR recycles efficiently back to the plasma membrane, we determined whether such recycling involved trafficking of CFTR through the ERC in a similar fashion to such molecules as transferrin.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	130	 In untransfected cells, CFTR was seen associated with the plasma membrane (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	131	 4a), consistent with previously published data.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	132	 However, upon expression of G429R Rme-1, plasma membrane-associated staining for CFTR was markedly decreased, with a concomitant increase in intracellular CFTR localization (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Moreover, such intracellular CFTR was found to colocalize mostly with the recycling compartment as determined by colocalization with Rme-1 (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Neighboring cells that failed to take up plasmid for G429R Rme-1 retained cell surface staining for CFTR.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	135	View larger version (20K):    Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Expression of G429R Rme-1 affects the cellular localization of CFTR.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	137	 CFTR/293 cells were transiently transfected with GFP-tagged G429R Rme-1.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Cells were subsequently fixed and stained for CFTR by using Cy3-conjugated secondary antibodies.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	139	 In untransfected cells (a), CFTR was clearly seen at the plasma membrane.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	140	 In transfected cells (b and d), CFTR moved to an intracellular compartment with completely overlapped with GFP-tagged G429R Rme-1 (c and d).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Inset in d shows a higher magnification of the colocalized signal.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	142	To confirm that CFTR was indeed trapped in the ERC in the presence of G429R Rme-1, we performed immunogold electron microscopy on cells expressing CFTR.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Such studies revealed the presence of both transferrin receptor [a marker for the ERC (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	144	 5)] and CFTR within the same vesicle.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	145	 CFTR also colocalized with gold-labeled anti-GFP antibodies (data not shown).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	146	View larger version (154K):    Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Immunogold localization of CFTR to the endosomal recycling compartment (ERC).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Cells expressing CFTR and G429R Rme-1 were fixed and processed for immunogold electron microscopy as described in MATERIALS AND METHODS.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	149	 CFTR (arrows) were identified with 5-nm gold particles and transferrin receptor (arrowhead) with 15-nm gold particles.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	150	To confirm the redistribution of CFTR from a cell surface location to an intracellular compartment, cell surface biotinylation experiments were performed.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	151	 The presence of band C CFTR (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	152	 6, A and B) was seen in untransfected cells, cells transfected with wild-type Rme-1, and cells transfected with G429R Rme-1, arguing against a role for Rme-1 in the biosynthetic pathway.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	153	 While there was a slight reduction in the amount of cell surface CFTR in the presence of wild-type Rme-1, the expression of G429R Rme-1 caused a marked reduction in the amount of cell surface CFTR (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	154	 6, A and B), consistent with a redirection of CFTR to intracellular compartments.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	155	 The reduction in cell surface CFTR in the presence of G429R Rme-1 was not due to a global reduction in CFTR expression because the amount of total CFTR in cells expressing G429R Rme-1 was not significantly lower than that in untransfected cells (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	156	View larger version (28K):    Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Expression of Rme-1 (G429R) but not wild-type Rme-1 causes loss of cell surface CFTR.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Untransfected CFTR/293 cells, cells transfected with wild-type Rme-1, or G429R Rme-1 were subjected to cell surface biotinylation as described in MATERIALS AND METH-ODS.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	159	 After Streptavidin precipitation, subsequent immunoblot analysis revealed the presence of band C CFTR (A) in untransfected cells and in cells transfected with wild-type Rme-1 but markedly reduced in cells transfected with G429R Rme-1.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Shown in B are results of densitometric scans of data shown in A.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Analysis of total cell lysate CFTR in the presence or absence of G429R Rme-1 (C and D) revealed little difference in total CFTR.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Results are means  plus or minus  SE of 3 separate experiments.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	163	Immunomagnetic isolation of CFTR containing vesicles.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Immunofluorescence microscopy revealed the presence of CFTR trapped in the ERC in the presence of G429R Rme-1.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	165	 As an alternative strategy to show that G429R Rme-1 causes "trapping" of CFTR in the ERC, vesicles from CFTR/293 cells transfected with G429R Rme-1 were subject to immunomagnetic isolation by using anti-CFTR antibodies (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Because CFTR in ERC should be oriented such that the cytosolic domains of CFTR are facing the outside of the vesicle, we immunoprecipitated CFTR-containing vesicles from cells by using antibodies directed against the amino and carboxyl termini of CFTR.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Immunoblot analysis of such isolated vesicles revealed the presence of band C CFTR.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Rme-1 and transferrin receptor were also identified within CFTR-containing vesicles.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	169	 In contrast, markers for early endosomes (EEA1) and lysosomes (Lamp1) showed very little signal.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	170	View larger version (35K):    Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	171	 G429R Rme-1 localizes CFTR to ERC but not early endosomes or lysosomes.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	172	 CFTR-containing vesicles were subjected to immunomagnetic isolation.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	173	 For subsequent immunoblot analysis, the following antibodies were employed.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Robinson), transferrin receptor (TfR 85 kDa; Transduction Labs/BD Pharmingen), CFTR (180 kDa; Upstate Biotech), EEA1(180 kDa), and Lamp-1 (Transduction Labs/BD Pharmingen).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	175	The carboxyl terminal domain of CFTR contains ERC-targeting information.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	176	 To show that CFTR enters the ERC from the clathrin-coated endocytic pathway, we monitored the traffic of internalized CFTR.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Because the steady-state level of cell surface CFTR in the presence of G429R Rme-1 is extremely low and there are no high-affinity extracellular antibodies or ligands for CFTR, we decided to utilize a CFTR/transferrin receptor chimera transiently coexpressed with G429R Rme-1.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	178	 TRVb1 cells lacking endogenous transferrin receptors were transiently transfected with a CFTR transferrin receptor (TfR) chimera in which the cytoplasmic domain of the transferrin receptor was replaced with the carboxyl terminal domain of CFTR.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Twenty-four hours after such transfection, some cells were also transfected with G429R Rme-1.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Traffic of the CFTR/TfR chimera was monitored by using Cy3-conjugated transferrin.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Cells containing CFTR/TfR (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	182	 8, a and b) or CFTR/TfR and G429R Rme-1 (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	183	 8, c-f) were incubated for 1 h in the continued presence of Cy3 transferrin (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Cy3 transferrin was efficiently taken up in both sets of cells.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	185	 After the hour pulse with labeled transferrin, cells were subject to an hour chase in the absence of labeled transferrin and 100-fold excess of unlabeled transferrin.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Cells expressing CFTR/TfR alone (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	187	 8b) showed loss of cell associated signal because the transferrin was efficiently recycled back to the cell surface and released into the medium.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	188	 In contrast, cells expressing CFTR/TfR and G429R Rme-1 (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	189	 8d) failed to recycle internalized transferrin back to the cell surface.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	190	 The structures within which the transferrin remained colocalized with GFP-tagged G429R Rme-1 (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	191	View larger version (58K):    Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	192	 The carboxyl terminus of CFTR can target to ERC.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	193	 TRVb1 cells expressing CFTR/TfR chimeras in the presence of wild-type Rme-1 were labeled for 1 h in the presence of Cy3 transferrin (a), followed by a 1-h chase in the presence of 100-fold excess unlabeled transferrin (b).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Similar experiments were performed in cells expressing GFP-tagged G429R Rme-1 for cells incubated for 1 h in the presence of Cy3 transferrin (c), followed by a 1-h chase in the presence of 100-fold excess unlabeled transferrin (d).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	195	 For cells expressing GFP-tagged G429R Rme-1, the corresponding GFP signal is shown in green (e and f).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	196	   DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT METHODS AND MATERIALS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   It is now clearly established that signals in the carboxyl terminal domain of CFTR direct its entrance into the clathrin-mediated endocytic pathway (4, 12, 18, 27, 35, 36).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Of interest are the observations that the endocytic internalization kinetics for CFTR are rapid (12, 18, 27, 34) and that internalized CFTR appears to be fully functional (5, 17).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	198	 These observations suggest the possibility that internalized CFTR may be constitutively recycled back to the cell surface.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Indeed, given the rapid internalization kinetics of CFTR, biosynthetic kinetics would have to be equally rapid to maintain steady-state cell surface CFTR.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	200	 However, treatment of CFTR-expressing CHO cells with either cycloheximide or brefeldin A did not cause any diminution of forskolin-stimulated CFTR function up to 24 h (16), arguing that internalized CFTR may be recycled rather than degraded.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Studies by Swiatecka-Urban et al.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	202	 (31) have further argued that recycling of CFTR may be important in establishing its apical polarity in epithelial cells.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	203	Although the exit of material from the ERC and its reinsertion into the plasma membrane have been thought to be a constitutive pathway, such traffic nonetheless requires cellular machinery.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	204	 The role of Rme-1 in regulating aspects of the endocytic/recycling pathway has been established by using dominant negative mutants in CHO cells and C.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	205	 While Rme-1 has no effect on initial clathrin-mediated endocytic events, Rme-1 function is necessary for proteins to exit the ERC and travel back to the plasma membrane.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	206	 In contrast, Rme-1 plays no role in the traffic of proteins, such as LDL, to the late endosome/lysosome pathway.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Although there is only one Rme family member in C.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	208	 elegans, there are four related genes in humans (8, 21, 26).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	209	 As yet, the tissue distribution and expression overlap of CFTR with the different Rme-1 genes are not known.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	210	We show that internalized CFTR enters the endocytic recycling compartment on its traffic back to the cell surface in an identical fashion to the well-described marker for endosomal recycling, the transferrin receptor.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Expression of dominant negative Rme-1 has no effect on endocytosis, as shown by uptake of LDL, transferrin, and CFTR/transferrin chimeras, consistent with previously published data (8, 15).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	212	 In contrast to traffic of LDL to late endosomes/lysosomes, which is unaffected by dominant negative Rme-1 and shows no colocalization with GFP-tagged G429R Rme-1, transferrin (a marker for the recycling compartment) shows almost complete overlap with GFP-tagged G429R Rme-1.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	213	 CFTR localization in dominant negative Rme-1-expressing cells shows overlap with both transferrin and GFP, arguing that internalized CFTR enters the same recycling compartment that transferrin has access to.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	214	 The observation that expression of dominant negative Rme-1 caused a marked redistribution of CFTR away from the plasma membrane to being trapped in the ERC argues for a rapid endocytic rate for CFTR.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Indeed, several groups have shown that CFTR is efficiently endocytosed from the cell surface (12, 18, 27, 34).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Moreover, the redistribution of CFTR in the presence of G429R Rme-1 argues that maintenance of steady-state cell surface levels of CFTR is primarily due to recycling of internalized CFTR rather than insertion of newly synthesized CFTR.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	217	 The lack of high-affinity antibodies to extracellular domains of CFTR, and the low level of expression of cell surface CFTR in the presence of G429R Rme-1, precluded monitoring of CFTR from the cell surface to the ERC.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	218	 To confirm that entry of CFTR into the ERC was from the endocytic pathway, we monitored access of transferrin receptor/CFTR chimeras to the ERC.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Transferrin receptor constructs that lack a cytoplasmic tail are internalized inefficiently (13, 27).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Addition of the carboxyl tail of CFTR to tail-less transferrin receptors restores efficient internalization of the receptor and labeled transferrin reporters (27).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Transfection of cells with transferrin receptor/CFTR chimeras and dominant negative Rme-1 shows that labeled transferrin is trapped within the ERC, arguing that entry into the ERC is from the endocytic rather than the biosynthetic pathway.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Moreover, it argues that the carboxyl tail of CFTR does not contain any signals that direct traffic of CFTR away from recycling pathways to lysosomal degradative compartments.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	223	 While many endocytosed membrane proteins are thought to recycle to the cell surface via a juxtanuclear recycling compartment (23), this is not true for all proteins.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	224	 For example, Kir channels, a potassium channel family involved in regulating membrane excitability (38), do not recycle to the cell surface through Rme-1-regulated compartments (19).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Thus it is clear that different ion channels can traffic and recycle through diverse compartments.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	226	Many laboratories, both commercial and academic, are currently attempting to acquire pharmacological compounds to increase the efficiency with which mutant CFTR molecules fold, exit the endoplasmic reticulum, and get inserted into the plasma membrane.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	227	 The observation that even wild-type CFTR is rapidly removed from the cell surface argues for the necessity to understand recycling processes with the potential to increase the rate at which CFTR exits the recycling compartment and gets reinserted back into the plasma membrane.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	228	 This is particularly true for F508 CFTR, the most common mutation in CFTR, which even when "corrected" by growth of cells at reduced temperatures has a significantly shorter half-life in the plasma membrane the wild-type CFTR (11).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Thus a clear understanding of the molecular events governing the recycling of CFTR will provide inside into ways to augment the overall residence time of pharmacologically corrected mutant CFTR molecules at the cell surface.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	230	   DISCLOSURES   This work was supported by the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation and National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases Grants DK-57583 and P50-DK-56490 (component 2) (to N.

0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	0	Syntaxin 8 impairs trafficking of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) and inhibits its channel activity Frederic Bilan1,*, Vincent Thoreau1,*, Magali Nacfer1, Renaud Derand2, Caroline Norez2, Anne Cantereau2, Martine Garcia3, Frederic Becq2 and Alain Kitzis1,.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	1	1 Laboratoire de Genetique Cellulaire et Moleculaire, UPRES EA 2622, CHU de Poitiers, BP 577, 86021 Poitiers CEDEX, France 2 Laboratoire de Biomembranes et Signalisation Cellulaire, CNRS UMR 6558, Universite de Poitiers, France 3 Laboratoire d'Immunologie et Interactions Moleculaires, UPRES EA 2224, Universite de Poitiers, France.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	2	Author for correspondence (e-mail: a.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	3	   Summary Top Summary Introduction Materials and Methods Results Discussion References   The cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) is a cyclic AMP-dependent chloride channel that mediates electrolyte transport across the luminal surface of epithelial cells.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	4	 In this paper, we describe the CFTR regulation by syntaxin 8, a t-SNARE protein (target soluble N-ethylmaleimide-sensitive factor attachment protein receptor) involved in the SNARE endosomal complex.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Syntaxin family members are key molecules implicated in diverse vesicle docking and membrane fusion events.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	6	 We found that syntaxin 8 physically interacts with CFTR: recombinant syntaxin 8 binds CFTR in vitro and both proteins co-immunoprecipitate in HT29 cells.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Syntaxin 8 regulates CFTR-mediated currents in chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells stably expressing CFTR and syntaxin 8.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Iodide efflux and whole-cell patch-clamp experiments on these cells indicate a strong inhibition of CFTR chloride current by syntaxin 8 overexpression.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	9	 At the cellular level, we observed that syntaxin 8 overexpression disturbs CFTR trafficking.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Confocal microscopy shows a dramatic decrease in green fluorescent protein-tagged CFTR plasma membrane staining, when syntaxin 8 is coexpressed in COS-7 cells.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Using antibodies against Lamp-1, TfR or Rab11 we determined by immunofluorescence assays that both proteins are mainly accumulated in recycling endosomes.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Our results evidence that syntaxin 8 contributes to the regulation of CFTR trafficking and chloride channel activity by the SNARE machinery.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	13	Key words: CFTR, Syntaxin 8, SNARE, Recycling endosome, Trafficking.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	14	   Introduction Top Summary Introduction Materials and Methods Results Discussion References   Cystic fibrosis is the broadest autosomal recessive disorder among Caucasian populations.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	15	 It is characterized by mutations in the CFTR (cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator) gene that encodes a cAMP-activated chloride channel expressed at the apical membrane of epithelial cells (Rommens et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The CFTR protein is an ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporter with a specific cytoplasmic regulator domain (R) whose phosphorylation by protein kinase A (PKA) activates the CFTR chloride conductance (reviewed by Ostedgaard et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	17	In cystic fibrosis patients, dysfunction in the chloride channel activity of CFTR alone seems insufficient to elicit the deep disorders in the ionic equilibrium observed at the surface of epithelial tissues.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Indeed, CFTR expression has been linked to the regulation of numerous ionic channels and it is now assumed that CFTR is a key member of a complex network of ionic channels (Gabriel et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	19	, 2000) and cytoplasmic proteins in epithelia.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	20	 For example, CFTR interacts with several proteins containing PDZ (PSD-95/Dlg/ZO-1) domains.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Most of these proteins are localized in a subplasma membrane region (Short et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	22	, 2001), and one was found in the Golgi apparatus (Cheng et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Interactions were also detected between CFTR and proteins involved in the intracellular vesicle trafficking.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Notably, the C-terminus of CFTR binds to the endocytic clathrin adaptator complex AP-2 (Weixel and Bradbury, 2000), presumably during the internalization of CFTR from the plasma membrane.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Several studies are now focusing on the relationships between CFTR and proteins of the SNARE (soluble N-ethylmaleimide-sensitive factor attachment protein receptor) family.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	26	 These proteins are involved in the membrane fusion events happening during the different steps of vesicle trafficking in eukaryotic cells (reviewed by Chen and Scheller, 2001).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	27	Syntaxins belong to a subfamily of the t-SNAREs, whose C-terminal half contains the t-SNARE homology domain (Weimbs et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	28	, 1997) followed by a short hydrophobic tail that anchors the protein in its resident membrane.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	29	 The region of syntaxins upstream of this transmembrane domain protrudes at the cytoplasmic side of vesicle or plasma membrane.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Remarkably, a direct interaction between the SNARE homology domain of syntaxin 1A and the N-terminal cytoplasmic tail of CFTR is thought to be responsible for inhibiting CFTR chloride channel activity (Naren et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	31	We have previously described the cloning of human syntaxin 8 cDNA (STX8 gene), using the R domain of CFTR as a bait in the two-hybrid screening of a human fetal lung library (Thoreau et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Subsequently, syntaxin 8 has been localized in different endosomal compartments: it has been involved in trafficking from early endosome (EE) to late endosome (LE), or in homotypic fusion events in LE (Prekeris et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	33	 In the present study, we establish that syntaxin 8 overexpression inhibits CFTR channel activity and trafficking to the plasma membrane.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	34	 A direct regulation can also be suggested as we show evidence for the existence of a physical interaction between CFTR and syntaxin 8, either directly or within a protein complex.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Thus, we propose that syntaxin 8 is a member of the CFTR interaction network.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Our results strengthen the idea that the SNARE machinery directly regulates CFTR trafficking and activity.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	37	   Materials and Methods Top Summary Introduction Materials and Methods Results Discussion References   Constructs and antibodies cDNAs encoding human syntaxin 8, syntaxin 1A and syntaxin 3 were obtained by RT-PCR on total RNA isolated from the human colonic epithelial cell line HT29-CL19A.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Full-length STX8 cDNA was cloned into EcoRI and BamHI sites of the mammalian expression vector pcDNA3.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Full-length STX1A or STX3 cDNAs were cloned into NotI and XhoI sites of pcDNA3.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Using directed mutagenesis (QuikChangeTM Site-Directed Mutagenesis Kit, Stratagene), we have constructed a cytosoluble syntaxin 8 with a stop codon at position 211, noted Syn8TM, a protein that lacks its hydrophobic transmembrane anchor.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Three different recombinant syntaxin 8 in GST (glutathione-S-transferase)-fusion were generated inserting PCR fragments into BamHI and SalI sites of the bacterial expression vector pGEX-5X-3 (Pharmacia): Syn8TM (i.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Syn8 [aa 1-209]), Syn8 [aa 1-99] and Syn8 [aa 99-209].
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	43	 GST-Syn1ATM bacterial expression vector was a gift from A.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Naren (University of Alabama, Birmingham, AL).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	45	 GST-VAMP8TM (aa 1-74) and GST-Syn7TM (aa 1-236) bacterial expression vectors were obtained from W.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Antonin (Max-Planck-Institute for Biophysical Chemistry, Gottingen, Germany).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	47	 GST-vti1bTM vector (aa 1-207) was a gift from G.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	48	 von Mollard (Georg-August-Universitat, Gottingen, Germany).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Expression of CFTR tagged with GFP (green fluorescent protein) was analyzed using pS65T/EGFP-C1/WT-CFTR construct, a gift from K.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Karlson (Dartmouth College, Hanover, NH).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	51	The following antibodies were used in this study: rabbit polyclonal antibody against syntaxin 3, a gift from A.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	52	, 1997), monoclonal antibody against syntaxin 1A clone 78.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	53	3 (Synaptic Systems, Germany), monoclonal antibody against syntaxin 8 clone 48 (Transduction Laboratories); antibodies against CFTR, monoclonal antibody clone M3A7 with epitope at amino acid 1370-1380 (Chemicon International), used for immunoblotting, and monoclonal antibody clone 24-1 with epitope at amino acid 1377-1480 (R and D Systems), used for immunoprecipitation; antibody against GFP, monoclonal antibody clone GEP-20 (Sigma-Aldrich).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	54	 For immunofluorescence experiments, anti-syntaxin 8 antibody was prepared by immunization of a rabbit with bacterially expressed GST-Syn8TM.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Polyclonal antibody was then affinity purified from rabbit antiserum using CNBr-activated sepharose beads (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Monoclonal anti-TfR antibody was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (clone DF1513), monoclonal anti-Lamp 1 was obtained from Pharmingen, rabbit polyclonal anti-Rab11 antibody was a gift from B.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	57	, 2000) and rabbit polyclonal anti-NCX2 was provided by the intermediary of C.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Cognard (LBSC, Poitiers, France).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	59	 All fluorescent secondary antibodies were obtained from Jackson Immunoresearch Laboratories.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Secondary antibody for western blot was obtained from Amersham Pharmacia Biotech: horseradish peroxidase-conjugated goat anti-mouse IgG.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	61	Cell culture All cell lines were cultured at 37 degrees C in 5% CO2 in a medium containing 100 IU/ml penicillin (Panpharma SA, France) and 100  microg/ml streptomycin (Solvay Pharma, France).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	62	 CHO cells transfected with CFTR cDNA (CHO-CFTR), established by J.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	63	, 1991), were grown in MEM medium with Glutamax-I (Life Technologies) containing 100  microM methotrexate (Sigma-Aldrich) and supplemented with 7% fetal calf serum (Life Technologies).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	64	 COS-7 and HT29-CL19A cells were cultured in DMEM with Glutamax-I supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	65	Transfection CHO-CFTR cells were transfected with 1  microg of pcDNA3.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	66	1/Zeo( to ) plasmids encoding syntaxins, using 3  microl of FuGene6TM transfection reagent (Roche Diagnostics Corp.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	67	), according to the manufacturer's protocol.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	68	 After 24 to 48 hours incubation 40  microg/ml zeocin (Invitrogen) was added to the culture medium.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Resistant cells were cultured with 20  microg/ml zeocin and were tested by western blot and immunofluorescence.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	70	 To isolate clones overexpressing Syn8 or Syn8TM, cells were diluted and cultured in 24-well plates.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	71	For the electroporation of COS-7 cells, 2x106 cells at 90% confluence were trypsinized and resuspended in 800  microl of PBS with 10  microg of each plasmid.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	72	 After 5 minutes incubation on ice, cells were transferred into an electroporation cuvette (4 mm electrode gap, EquiBio Ltd) and electroporated with one shock at 300 V, 450  microF, using an EasyjecT Plus multipurpose electroporation system (EquiBio Ltd).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	73	 The cells were then incubated on ice for 10 minutes in 10 ml of culture medium, plated on glass coverslips, grown for 48 hours and treated subsequently for immunofluorescence analysis.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	74	Iodide efflux experiments CFTR chloride channel activity was assayed by measuring the rate of iodide (125I) efflux from transfected CHO cells as previously described (Derand et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	75	 All experiments were performed at 37 degrees C.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	76	 The loss of intracellular 125I was determined by removing the medium with efflux buffer every 1 minute for up to 10 minutes.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	77	 The fraction of initial intracellular 125I lost during each interval time was determined and time-dependent rates of 125I efflux were calculated from ln(125It1 / 125It2)/(t1  to  t2) where 125It is the intracellular 125I at time t, and t1 and t2 are successive time-points (Venglarik et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	78	Patch-clamp experiments Whole-cell chloride currents were recorded from CHO cells at room temperature with a List EPC-7 patch-clamp amplifier.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	79	 I-V relationships were built by clamping the membrane potential to  to 40 mV and by pulses from  to 100 mV to +100 mV by 20 mV increments.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Mediums generating a chloride gradient of 151 mM external concentration and 28 mM internal concentration were used.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	81	 The pipette solution contained: 113 mM L-aspartic acid, 113 mM CsOH, 27 mM CsCl, 1 mM NaCl, 1 mM MgCl2, 1 mM EGTA, 10 mM TES, 285 mOsm (pH 7.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	82	 MgATP (3 mM) was added just before patch-clamp experiments were started.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The external solution consisted of 145 mM NaCl, 4 mM CsCl, 1 mM CaCl2, 5 mM glucose, 10 mM TES, 340 mOsm (pH 7.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Results were analyzed with the pCLAMP6 package software (pCLAMP, Axon Instruments).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Cells were stimulated with forskolin (Sigma-Aldrich) or by the CFTR activator MPB-91 (5-butyl-6-hydroxy-10-chlorobenzo[c]quinolizinium) synthesized as previously described (Derand et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	86	Statistics Results are expressed as means  plus or minus  s.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	87	 To compare sets of data, we used either an analysis of variance (ANOVA) or Student's t test.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Differences were considered statistically significant when P < 0.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	89	 All statistical tests were performed using GraphPad Prism version 3.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	90	0 for Windows (Graphpad Software).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	91	Immunofluorescence Cells grown on glass coverslips were washed with PBS++ (PBS buffer supplemented with 1 mM CaCl2 and 1 mM MgCl2) and fixed for 10 minutes in 3% paraformaldehyde in PBS and permeabilized for 10 minutes in saponin buffer (0.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Cells were incubated in PBS++ containing 0.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	93	5% BSA for 45 minutes at room temperature to block unspecific antigen sites.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Then, coverslips were labeled for 1 hour with primary antibody (1:100 in blocking buffer).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	95	 The cells were washed three times in PBS++ containing 0.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	96	5% BSA and labeled with conjugated antibody (1:100) for 1 hour.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Coverslips were mounted with VectaShield fluorescence medium H1000 (Vector Lab).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	98	Confocal imaging The labeled samples were examined by confocal laser scanning microscopy using a BioRad MRC 1024.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	99	 The confocal unit was attached to an inverted microscope (Olympus IX70).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Maximal resolution was obtained with Olympus plan apo x60 water, 1.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	101	3 numerical aperture objective lens.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Fluorescence signal collection, image construction and scaling were performed through the control software (Lasersharp 3.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	103	 For colocalization study of CFTR, syntaxin 8 and endosomal markers, bleed-through was avoided during acquisition with red, green and far red fluorescence: images were collected sequentially and then merged as an RGB colored image.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	104	2 software permitted analysis of the degree of colocalization in the same focal plane.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	105	 For each pair of color combinations, a two-dimensional fluorogram displayed the intensity and distribution of different colored pixels within a merged image as a scattergram.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	106	 It was possible to select a subset of pixels from the scattergram that have significant intensity in both colors (as shown by colored rectangle) to visualize on the cell image the localization of the selected pixels.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	107	SDS-PAGE and immunoblot Cells were homogenized by several passes through a 23-gauge syringe needle in RIPA buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	108	5), 1 mM EDTA, 100 mM NaCl, 1% Triton X-100) containing protease inhibitors (20  microM leupeptin, 0.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	109	8  microM aprotinin, 10  microM pepstatin and 1.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	110	25 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Cell lysates were incubated on ice for 30 minutes and clarified by centrifugation at 15,000 g for 5 minutes at 4 degrees C.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Total proteins were quantified using the BCA protein assay reagent (Pierce), and 10-50  microg of proteins were loaded onto an SDS-PAGE apparatus.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	113	 SDS-PAGE was performed according to Laemmli and Favre (Laemmli and Favre, 1973).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Extracts were separated on 15% polyacrylamide gels to study syntaxin 8, and 7% for CFTR.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	115	 For western blots, proteins were transferred from gels to a 0.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	116	20  microm pore nitrocellulose membrane (Sartorius, Germany) using a Miniprotean III electroblotter (BioRad Laboratories).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Immunoblots were washed in PBS containing 0.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	118	1% Tween-20 (PBS-Tween) and then probed overnight at 4 degrees C with primary antibody in PBS-Tween.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Membranes were washed and incubated for 1 hour at 4 degrees C with the secondary antibody.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Bound antibodies were detected using enhanced luminol and oxidizing reagents as specified by the manufacturer (ECL, Amersham Pharmacia Biotech).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	121	Immunoprecipitation Cell lysates were prepared as described above with 1 ml of lysis buffer per 100 mm culture dish.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	122	 In these experiments, 3 ml of cell lysate supplemented with 9 ml of NET buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	123	05% Nonidet P-40) were incubated overnight at 4 degrees C with 2  microg of CFTR or Syn8 antibodies.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	124	 To precipitate immune complexes, an incubation with 3  microg of protein G-sepharose (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) was conducted for 1 hour at 4 degrees C.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Bead-bound complexes were washed three times with cold NET buffer and denatured in Laemmli buffer for 15 minutes at room temperature.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Samples were separated on SDS-PAGE and analyzed by western blot.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	127	Pull-down assays GST-fusion proteins were produced in E.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Cells transformed with pGEX (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) constructs were grown and lysed according to the manufacturer's protocol.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Recombinant proteins contained in lysates were purified by incubation for 30 minutes at 4 degrees C with 500  microl of glutathione-sepharose beads (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) followed by three washes with PBS, 1% Triton X-100.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	130	 GST-fusion protein yield was controlled by SDS-PAGE followed by Coomassie blue gel staining.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Then, 8x106 COS-7 cells stably transfected with GFP-CFTR were lysed as described above.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Lysates were mixed with 200  microg of recombinant proteins bound to glutathione-sepharose beads.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Incubation was conducted overnight at 4 degrees C.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Bead-bound complexes were washed three times in lysis buffer, denatured in Laemmli buffer for 15 minutes at room temperature, loaded on a 7% SDS-PAGE and analyzed by western blot using GFP antibody.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	135	   Results Top Summary Introduction Materials and Methods Results Discussion References   Inhibition of CFTR channel activity by syntaxin 8 overexpression in CHO cells In the first part of our study, we addressed the functional interactions of syntaxin 8 with CFTR.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	136	 CHO-CFTR cells were transfected with the plasmid pcDNA3.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	137	 After transfection, about 50% of the cells were found to overexpress syntaxin 8, as determined by immunofluorescence analysis (data not shown).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	138	 At this step, we observed by iodide efflux experiments a significant inhibition (40%) of CFTR channel activity in CHO-CFTR+Syn8 cells as compared with control CHO-CFTR cells (data not shown).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	139	 For further experiments we selected one clone, named CHO-2T (doubly transfected), highly overexpressing syntaxin 8 (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	140	View larger version (46K):    Fig.

0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Specific labeling was visualized using a TRITC-conjugated secondary antibody.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	144	 (B) Equal amounts of protein (10  microg) were subjected to SDS-PAGE followed by immunoblotting.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Syntaxin 8 overexpression was confirmed in the CHO-2T clone.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	146	 (C) Cell lysates containing an equal amount of protein were subjected to immunoprecipitation with CFTR antibody.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	147	 The presence of CFTR in CHO-CFTR and in CHO-2T cells was revealed by immunoblotting.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	148	The immunostaining of endogenous syntaxin 8 in CHO-CFTR cells presented a vesicle-like pattern.

0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	152	To verify that CFTR expression in CHO-2T clone was not affected compared with CHO-CFTR cells, we controlled the CFTR mRNA level by quantitative RT-PCR and found no significant difference between the two cell lines (data not shown).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Moreover, we performed immunoprecipitation to assess the presence of CFTR protein in each cell line (Fig.

0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Anti-CFTR immunoblotting revealed the characteristic mature (band C) and immature (band B) of CFTR in each CHO cell lines.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	156	The consequences of syntaxin 8 overexpression on CFTR channel activity were studied using iodide efflux and whole-cell patch-clamp experiments in CHO-CFTR and CHO-2T cells.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Control experiments were performed on CHO-CFTR cells transfected with a pcDNA3.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Resulting data exhibited no significant difference in CFTR channel activity between mock transfected and control CHO-CFTR cells (data not shown).

0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	176	To determine whether the cytosolic domain (90% of the entire protein) of syntaxin 8 could modulate CFTR channel activity, we used a soluble form of this protein (deleted of its transmembrane domain, noted Syn8TM).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	177	 CHO-CFTR cells were transfected with the appropriate vector as described above.

0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	188	View larger version (43K):    Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Analysis of CFTR channel activity in the presence of different syntaxins.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	190	 (A) Expression profile analysis of different syntaxins before (NT) or after plasmid transfection in CHO-CFTR cells (Syn8TM, Syn1A and Syn3).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	191	 (B) Summary of data collected from four independent iodide efflux experiments using CHO-CFTR cells (empty columns) or CHO+CFTR+Syn8TM clone (filled columns).

0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Data are expressed as a percentage of CFTR maximal activity.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	194	At this stage, we agreed that CFTR inhibition was not due to overexpression of any SNARE proteins.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Syntaxin 3, unlike syntaxin 1A, is known not to physically interact with CFTR (Naren et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	196	 So, we have assayed CFTR channel modulation under overexpression of each of these syntaxins in the CHO-CFTR model.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Stably transfected cells were characterized by fluorescent immunostaining (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	198	 We noticed that syntaxin 1A as well as syntaxin 3 antibodies were unable to detect endogenous proteins (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	199	 As expected, cells overexpressing syntaxin 1A or syntaxin 3 presented plasma membrane localization (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	200	 3Ad,f) of these proteins with a predominant perinuclear staining observed in the case of syntaxin 1A (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	201	 In each case, more than 40% of cells exhibited high level expression (data not shown).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	202	 We measured CFTR response by iodide efflux experiments under 5  microM forskolin stimulation and we found no significant difference between control and Syn3-transfected CHO-CFTR cells, whereas syntaxin 1A overexpression induced a 40% inhibition of CFTR channel activity (100 plus or minus 3.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	203	63 (n=12), respectively, expressed as a percentage of CFTR maximal activity) (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	204	To confirm our iodide efflux results, we performed whole-cell patch-clamp recordings and compared the properties of CFTR chloride currents in the presence or absence of syntaxin 8.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	205	 In control CHO-CFTR cells, the activity of CFTR Cl- current was stimulated by 5  microM forskolin and the current measured at +60 mV was 25.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	206	 The expression of syntaxin 8 in CHO-2T cells resulted in a dramatic reduction in the CFTR chloride current, with a current density, measured at +60 mV, of only 4.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	207	77 pA/pF (n=7 for each concentration, Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	208	 4B-D) with 5  microM and 10  microM forskolin, respectively.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	209	 These observations confirmed the flux study and showed that the chloride channel activity of CFTR is strongly affected by syntaxin 8.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	210	View larger version (22K):    Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Analysis by patch-clamp assay of the CFTR chloride channel activity in the presence of syntaxin 8.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Typical whole-cell currents recorded from a CHO-CFTR cell (A) and from a Syn8 and CFTR transfected CHO-2T cell (B) in the absence or presence of 5  microM forskolin in the bath.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Cells capacitances are 30 pS and 27 pS in A and B, respectively.
