0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	217	GFP-tagged CFTR trafficking is impaired by syntaxin 8 overexpression in COS-7 cells To understand how syntaxin 8 overexpression induces an inhibition of the CFTR chloride current, we investigated the impact of syntaxin 8 or cytosoluble syntaxin 8 expression on the cellular distribution of a GFP-tagged CFTR in COS-7 cells.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	218	 GFP-CFTR is known to be functional and the GFP tag does not affect its trafficking and localization (Moyer et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Moreover, we have observed, in COS-7 cells, that two cystic fibrosis widespread mutants, GFP-(F508del)CFTR and GFP-(G551D)CFTR, exhibited a pharmacological response and a trafficking consistent with the physiological data (data not shown).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Immunofluorescence study showed that in both cases (endogenous or overexpressed), syntaxin 8 was concentrated in a structure close to nuclear envelope, and a cytoplasm punctuated staining indicated the presence of syntaxin 8 in vesicle-like structures.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	221	For the following experiments, we have chosen a photomultiplier sensitivity allowing us to visualize overexpressed syntaxin 8 without fluorescence saturation.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	222	 At this sensitivity, endogenous syntaxin 8 was not detected.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Most of the cells overexpressing GFP-CFTR exhibited a strong plasma membrane staining with weaker intracellular staining (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	224	 When COS-7 cells were cotransfected with syntaxin 8 and GFP-CFTR, we observed a strong decrease or a disappearance of GFP-CFTR plasma membrane staining (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	225	 GFP-CFTR appeared in cytosolic or punctuated pattern as shown in Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	226	 5B with observation at different Z positions.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Moreover, cotransfection with the empty pcDNA3.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	228	1/Zeo( to ) vector did not affect GFP-CFTR localization at the plasma membrane (data not shown).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	229	View larger version (144K):    Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	230	 The impact of syntaxin 8 overexpression on GFP-CFTR cellular localization in COS-7 cells.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	231	 (A-C) Thick optical sections acquired with 2, 0.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	232	8  microm steps (from top to bottom).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	233	 (D-F) Projections of entire Z series.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Cells were transfected with GFP-CFTR alone (A,D), cotransfected with GFP-CFTR and Syn8 (B,E) and cotransfected with GFP-CFTR and the cytosoluble form of syntaxin 8: Syn8TM (C,F).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Green fluorescence resulting from GFP-CFTR expression shows strong and continuous localization of GFP-CFTR concentrated in plasma membrane of control cells (A,D).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	236	 In doubly transfected cells, overexpression of Syn8 (as revealed by red fluorescence) is associated with a strong reduction of GFP-CFTR plasma membrane localization, while a partial colocalization is visualized in a juxtanuclear region as revealed by yellow fluorescence.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	237	 By contrast, experiments using Syn8TM exhibit a large cytosolic staining of syntaxin 8 soluble form and a plasma membrane staining for GFP-CFTR (C,F).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	238	 (G) Control experiments studying NCX2 localization in wild-type or Syn8-transfected COS-7 cells.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Arrowheads indicate plasma membrane localization of NCX2 in both cases.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Each image is representative of six independent experiments.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	241	Control experiments using Syn8TM exhibited a large cytosolic staining that clearly differed from the wild-type syntaxin 8 immunostaining pattern.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Cells overexpressing Syn8TM presented a plasma membrane staining of GFP-CFTR in focal planes (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	243	 5C) and in the projection of all XY sections (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	244	 5F), with an intensity level comparable to GFP-CFTR overexpressing cells.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	245	 This result evidenced that double transfection did not affect the expression level of exogenous proteins such Syn8TM or GFP-CFTR as compared with cells transfected with only one of these cDNAs.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Thus, we could discount the possibility that the syntaxin 8 inhibitory effect on CFTR trafficking was simply due to an excess of protein biosynthesis in the cell.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	247	Cells overexpressing wild-type syntaxin 8 exhibited a colocalization with GFP-CFTR only in the juxtanuclear region (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	248	 However, accumulation of GFP-CFTR or syntaxin 8 in this region did not seem to be linked to the coexpression of both proteins, as GFP-CFTR or syntaxin 8 alone also had a strong staining of this organelle near the nucleus.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	249	 In the cytoplasm, syntaxin 8 often appeared as dot-like structures corresponding presumably to endosome/lysosome structures, whereas GFP-CFTR appeared more homogenous in the entire cytosol.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	250	 So, apart from juxtanuclear organelles, wild-type syntaxin 8 and GFP-CFTR did not seem to be colocalized in the distal part of cytosol.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	251	 By contrast, the Syn8TM immunostaining pattern colocalized with GFP-CFTR not only in the juxtanuclear area but also in a large part of the cytosol.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	252	 A colocalization between the two proteins was also observed at the plasma membrane in several focal planes (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	253	View larger version (71K):    Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Syntaxin 8 must be anchored in the membrane to inhibit GFP-CFTR plasma membrane localization.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	255	 We compared the intracellular localization of both proteins in COS-7 cells cotransfected with GFP-CFTR and Syn8 (A) or by GFP-CFTR and Syn8TM (B).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Overexpressed (Aa) syntaxin 8 shows a predominantly perinuclear staining and also appears in a cytoplasm punctuated pattern.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	257	 GFP-CFTR presents no plasma membrane localization (Ab), but is accumulated and colocalizes with syntaxin 8 only in the perinuclear region (arrows).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	258	 (B) Soluble syntaxin 8 (Syn8TM) displays a continuous staining within the cell, but is predominantly accumulated in compartments where GFP-CFTR is present, notably at the plasma membrane.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	259	These results showed that overexpressing wild-type syntaxin 8, which is anchored on the vesicle membrane, disturbed CFTR trafficking, whereas cytosoluble syntaxin 8 had no or little effect on CFTR plasma membrane localization.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	260	 As a control, we analyzed the distribution of a plasma membrane Na+/Ca2+ exchanger isoform (NCX2) (Li et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	261	, 1994), which is not known to interact with SNARE proteins.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	262	 As expected, the surface localization of NCX2 in COS-7 cells was not affected by syntaxin 8 overexpression (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	263	GFP-CFTR and syntaxin 8 colocalize and are accumulated in recycling endosomes (RE) in COS-7 transfected cells To identify the subcellular compartments in which GFP-CFTR and syntaxin 8 colocalize, we performed immunofluorescence studies with three well characterized markers of the endosomal and lysosomal compartments on wild-type and doubly transfected COS-7 cells.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	264	 As expected, cells overexpressing GFP-CFTR and syntaxin 8 exhibited a strong staining for both proteins in a juxtanuclear area, a compartment where the two proteins highly colocalize (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	265	 Each fluorogram showed that most syntaxin 8 and CFTR fluorescent plots were placed on the bisector line (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	266	 This indicated a high degree of colocalization of both proteins.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	267	 In each immunostaining experiment, the highest intensity of merged fluorescence corresponded to the juxtanuclear region (data not shown).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	268	 Syntaxin 8 immunostaining, whether using the rabbit polyclonal antibody (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	269	 7Aa,Ba) or the mouse monoclonal antibody (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	270	 7Ca), gave a classical tubular/vesicular-like pattern.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	271	 GFP-CFTR, as described above, was not localized on plasma membrane but on punctuated and tubular-like structures in the cytosol, and a strong signal was seen on the juxtanuclear area (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	272	 Lamp-1 (an LE/lysosomal marker) staining was observed as a strong vesicular and perinuclear pattern (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	273	 7Ac), but its distribution did not colocalize with Syn8 and GFP-CFTR cellular staining (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	274	 These data were confirmed by fluorograms showing that Lamp-1 fluorescence distribution was clearly separated from CFTR and Syn8 fluorescences (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	275	 By contrast, TfR immunostaining (endocytosis-recycling pathway) revealed a dot-like vesicular pattern more extensive in the cytosol than Lamp-1 staining (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	276	 Intracellular distribution between TfR and CFTR on the one hand (noted TfR/CFTR) and between TfR and Syn8 on the other hand (noted TfR/Syn8) was mostly in distinct compartments within the cell (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	277	 These results were supported by data from fluorograms, which showed two distinct fluorescences in each case.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	278	 Several plots with high intensity of overlapping fluorescence suggested a colocalization between TfR and CFTR on the one hand, and between TfR and Syn8 on the other, in vesicular structures near the nucleus (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	279	 When we compared the TfR/CFTR and TfR/Syn8 vesicular pattern in this region (insert), we observed many similarities suggesting that TfR, CFTR and Syn8 were present in the same vesicles.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	280	 As the juxtanuclear colocalization between CFTR and Syn8 partially matched to TfR localization, we could identify these vesicles as recycling or post-Golgi endosomes.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	281	 To test our hypothesis, we have used a rabbit polyclonal antibody against Rab11, a protein that has been found associated with trans-Golgi network (TGN) membranes, post-Golgi vesicles and recycling endosomes (Urbe et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	282	 In COS-7 cells, endogenous Rab11 displayed a punctuated vesicular pattern scattered throughout the cytoplasm and seemed to accumulate in a tubulo-vesicular structure near the nucleus (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	283	 In wild-type cells, a partial colocalization was found between Rab11 and TfR stainings (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	284	 7Db), but no overlap was detected between Rab11 and Lamp-1 stainings (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Finally, in COS-7 cells transfected with GFP-CFTR and Syn8, the Rab11 immunostaining profile matched exactly with CFTR and Syn8 stainings (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	286	 These results were sustained by fluorogram data showing Rab11/Syn8 and Rab11/CFTR fluorescent plots only on bisector line (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	287	 This clearly showed that these proteins had the same localization.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	288	 In conclusion, when syntaxin 8 inhibits CFTR trafficking in COS-7 transfected cells, CFTR appears to be restricted to a compartment including at least the recycling endosomes and possibly other post-Golgi vesicles.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	289	View larger version (63K):    Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	290	 GFP-CFTR and syntaxin 8 colocalize at least in the recycling endosome complexes in doubly transfected COS-7 cells.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	291	 In each experiment (except D), COS-7 cells were cotransfected with GFP-CFTR and Syn8, then costained with anti-syntaxin 8 antibody and anti-Lamp-1 (A), anti-TfR (B) or anti-Rab11 (C) antibodies.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	292	 All cell images present the projection of the entire Z series sections acquired by fluorescent confocal microscopy.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	293	 Fluorograms were obtained as described in Materials and Methods.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	294	 In each experiment, protein colocalizations were analyzed with three fluorograms.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	295	 Syntaxin 8 (a in A-C) and GFP-CFTR (b in A-C) exhibit perinuclear staining as expected.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	296	 These two proteins colocalize in the perinuclear region as shown in the merged images (d in A-C) and fluorograms (e in A-C).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	297	 Lamp-1 immunostaining pattern (Ac) exhibits no colocalization with GFP-CFTR and syntaxin 8 both on merged image (Ad) and fluorograms (Af,g), whereas the immunostaining profile obtained with TfR (Bc) presents a partial colocalization on merged picture (Bd) and fluorograms (Bf,g).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	298	 To further analyze colocalization compartments, we selected plots with high fluorescence intensity and placed them on the fluorogram bisector line (square in Bf,g) to generate images showing the colocalization patterns between CFTR and TfR (Bf') or Syn8 and TfR (Bg').
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	299	 The vesicular pattern obtained in each case is very similar and shows a colocalization between the three proteins within these vesicles.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	300	 By contrast, Rab11 immunostaining (Cc) closely matches in the perinuclear region with CFTR and syntaxin 8 stainings (Cd).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	301	 This high degree of colocalization is sustained by fluorogram data (Cf,g) displaying Rab11/CFTR or Rab11/Syn8 fluorescent plots placed on the bisector line.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	302	 As a control, we have studied endogenous localization between Rab11 and Lamp-1 or between Rab11 and TfR in wild type COS-7 cells.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	303	 As expected, no overlap was found between Lamp-1 and Rab11 stainings (Da), whereas a partial colocalization was observed in the perinuclear region between Rab11 and TfR (Db).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	304	 Each analysis is representative of three independent experiments.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	305	Syntaxin 8 physically interacts with CFTR To test the physical interaction between syntaxin 8 and CFTR, we performed immunoprecipitation experiments in CHO-2T and HT29-CL19A cell lines expressing both syntaxin 8 and CFTR.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	306	 Using lysates from both cell lines, we purified syntaxin 8 or CFTR complexes using monoclonal syntaxin 8 or CFTR antibodies, respectively.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	307	 As expected, syntaxin 8 and CFTR immunoprecipitated with high efficiency (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	308	 In these syntaxin 8 complexes, anti-CFTR western blot revealed the presence of the mature (band C) and immature (band B) forms of CFTR in each cell line (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	309	 Reversibly, in CFTR complexes, anti-syntaxin 8 western blot revealed a significant amount of the protein (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	310	 Notably, the existence of such an interaction in untransfected HT29-CL19A cells suggests the physiological relevance of this result.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	311	View larger version (39K):    Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	312	 CFTR and syntaxin 8 belong to the same protein complex.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	313	 (A) Co-immunoprecipitation of CFTR with Syn8 in CHO-2T and HT29-CL19A cell lysates.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	314	 Immunoprecipitated proteins were revealed after western blot with antibodies against CFTR.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	315	 Bands B and C represent immature and mature forms of CFTR, respectively.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	316	 CFTR antibody and nonimmune mouse IgG were used as positive and negative immunoprecipitation controls, respectively.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	317	 (B) Co-immunoprecipitation of Syn8 with CFTR in CHO-2T and HT29-CL19A cell lysates.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	318	 Immunoprecipitated proteins were revealed after western blot with antibodies against Syn8.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	319	 CHO-2T and HT29 cells lysates were used as a positive control for western blot.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	320	 Syn 8 antibody and nonimmune mouse IgG were used as positive and negative immunoprecipitation controls, respectively.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	321	We also investigated the interaction between CFTR and syntaxin 8 by an in vitro affinity binding assay using four recombinant GST-fusion proteins: as a positive control, the cytosolic domain of syntaxin 1A (Syn1ATM), the cytosolic domain of syntaxin 8 (Syn8TM), and two truncated domains of syntaxin 8 (Syn8[1-99] and Syn8[99-209]).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	322	 Recombinant GST protein was used as a negative control.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	323	 Bead-bound recombinant proteins were incubated with COS-7+GFP-CFTR cell lysate, and retained proteins were analyzed by western blot using an anti-GFP antibody (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	324	 A COS-7+GFP-CFTR cell lysate was used as a GFP-CFTR control.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	325	 The N-terminal tagging of CFTR by GFP did not affect the in vitro binding of syntaxin 1A, which has been shown to interact with the N-terminus of CFTR (Naren et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	326	 GFP-CFTR was pulled down with syntaxin 8 either with the full-length cytosolic domain of syntaxin 8 or with each of its truncated domain but predominantly with its N-terminal half upstream of its t-SNARE domain.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	327	 However, this interaction was far weaker compared with GFP-CFTR binding to syntaxin 1A.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	328	 Nevertheless, these results were significant as CFTR was not retained by GST alone.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	329	 Because pull-down experiments revealed a weak physical interaction between syntaxin 8 and CFTR, we hypothesized that intermediary proteins could be involved in CFTR/syntaxin 8 complexes.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	330	 The best candidates were the other components of the endosomal SNARE complex: VAMP8, vti1b and syntaxin 7.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	331	 Similarly, we produced these recombinant SNARE proteins to test their interaction with CFTR.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	332	 GFP-CFTR was pulled down either with VAMP8 or vti1b but not with syntaxin 7 (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	333	 These data suggested that endosomal SNARE proteins VAMP8 or vti1b bound CFTR in vitro with a comparable efficiency to syntaxin 1A (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	334	View larger version (48K):    Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	335	 In vitro interactions between CFTR and endosomal SNARE proteins.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	336	 (A) In vitro binding of GFP-CFTR with different recombinant cytosolic domains of syntaxin 8: GST-Syn8TM, GST-Syn8[1-99] and GST-Syn8[99-209].
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	337	 (B) In vitro binding of GFP-CFTR with different recombinant endosomal SNARE proteins: GST-Syn7TM, GST-VAMP8TM and GST-vti1bTM.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	338	 (A,B) Glutathione-sepharose-immobilized GST or GST-fusion proteins were incubated with COS-7+GFP-CFTR cell extracts.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	339	 Bound proteins were studied by anti-GFP immunoblot.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	340	 COS-7+GFP-CFTR lysate was used as a GFP-CFTR control; GST-Syn1ATM and GST alone were used, respectively, as positive and negative pull-down controls.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	341	   Discussion Top Summary Introduction Materials and Methods Results Discussion References   We have previously described the molecular cloning of human syntaxin 8 cDNA by the two-hybrid system using the R domain of CFTR as a bait to screen a human fetal lung cDNA library (Thoreau et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	342	 In the present report, we establish the functional relevance of an interaction between these two proteins.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	343	Regulation of CFTR channel activity by syntaxin 8 We have observed that syntaxin 8 overexpression is responsible for a strong inhibition of CFTR channel, activated either by the cAMP pathway (forskolin stimulation) or by a cAMP-independent pathway through the CFTR activator MPB-91 (Derand et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	344	 Such regulation of ionic channels by SNARE proteins has already been described.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	345	 For example, physical interactions have been assessed between syntaxin 1A and P/Q-type calcium channels, N-type calcium channels (Bezprozvanny et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	346	, 2000) and amiloride-sensitive epithelial sodium channels (Saxena et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	347	 Interestingly, syntaxin 1A inhibits CFTR chloride current by direct protein-protein interaction between the t-SNARE homology domain of syntaxin 1A and the N-terminal cytoplasmic tail of CFTR (Naren et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	348	 In another study (Peters et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	349	, 1999), cAMP-induced delivery to plasma membrane of CFTR present in peripheral vesicles was inhibited by syntaxin 1A in Xenopus oocytes.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	350	 As in the case of syntaxin 1A, our electrophysiological data indeed showed an inhibition of the CFTR activity due to syntaxin 8 overexpression.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	351	 This regulation is protein specific, as when we performed the same experiment with syntaxin 3, a SNARE protein that does not bind CFTR, we obtained a normal CFTR activation.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	352	 Moreover, CFTR modulation required syntaxin 8 to be anchored in membrane, as we showed that its soluble form has no effect on CFTR activity.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	353	 Thus, CFTR may directly be regulated by a protein-protein interaction, or alternatively, syntaxin 8 overexpression may disturb the vesicular transport machinery.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	354	 This could affect CFTR recycling or cellular targeting towards the plasma membrane and consequently inhibit the chloride channel activity measured at the cell level.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	355	Physical interactions between syntaxin 8 and CFTR We have shown a direct protein-protein interaction, given that CFTR was pulled down using immobilized GST-syntaxin 8 recombinant proteins.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	356	 Moreover, CFTR and syntaxin 8 could be co-immunoprecipitated with each other from CHO-2T or HT29-CL19A cell extracts.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	357	 These data suggest that syntaxin 8 interacts with CFTR either directly, or as a component of a CFTR-containing complex.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	358	 However, this interaction is different from the one observed between syntaxin 1A and CFTR.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	359	 Recombinant GST-syntaxin 1A binds CFTR with a high affinity (Naren et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	360	, 1997), whereas the interaction between syntaxin 8 and CFTR appears to be weaker.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	361	 Moreover, unlike syntaxin 1A in which only the t-SNARE domain interacts with CFTR, each moiety of syntaxin 8 binds CFTR.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	362	 Despite the fact that it will be necessary to test the in vitro binding between the different domains of CFTR and syntaxin 8 to ascertain a direct physical interaction, the immunoprecipitation results confirm that syntaxin 8 and CFTR are part of the same complex.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	363	 As we have precipitated both proteins with the same efficiency in CHO transfected cells and in HT29-CL19A cells (endogenously expressing both CFTR and syntaxin 8), we conclude that this interaction was not induced solely by overexpression.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	364	 As the affinity between syntaxin 8 and CFTR is weak, syntaxin 8 may not be the major partner of CFTR.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	365	 Tierce proteins may be necessary to establish a protein complex containing syntaxin 8 and CFTR.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	366	 This hypothesis is consistent with the pull-down and immunoprecipitation experiments, and could explain the small amount of CFTR retained by GST-syntaxin 8.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	367	 Possible candidates partner are the different components of the heterotetrameric endosomal SNARE core complex: vti1b, syntaxin 7 and VAMP8 (Antonin et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	368	 Our pull-down experiments suggest that VAMP8 and vti1b, which strongly and directly interact with CFTR, could be partner proteins involved in a CFTR/syntaxin 8 multimeric protein complex.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	369	 This result strengthens the idea that an entire SNARE complex could regulate ion channel delivery/insertion, retrieval or recycling to the plasma membrane.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	370	Syntaxin 8 is involved in CFTR trafficking Syntaxin 8 physical binding and functional regulation of CFTR prompted us to investigate, at the cellular level, the effect of syntaxin 8 overexpression on CFTR localization.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	371	 GFP fluorescence analysis on COS-7+GFP-CFTR cells showed a strong plasma membrane staining characteristic of mature CFTR cellular localization.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	372	 However, when syntaxin 8 was cotransfected with GFP-CFTR, a dramatic decrease or a disappearance of CFTR plasma membrane staining was observed and both proteins colocalized in a perinuclear region.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	373	 Syntaxin 8 impact on CFTR trafficking does not apply to any channel as, when we overexpressed syntaxin 8, the plasma membrane localization of endogenous Na+/Ca2+ exchanger was not affected.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	374	Moreover, coexpression of GFP-CFTR and Syn8TM, a cytosoluble form of syntaxin 8 (depleted of its transmembrane domain), led to a normal trafficking of GFP-CFTR to the plasma membrane.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	375	 Furthermore, a plasma membrane colocalization between Syn8TM and GFP-CFTR was observed and, interestingly, Syn8TM was seen in the plasma membrane only if CFTR was present too.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	376	 More generally, Syn8TM is located mainly in cellular structures where GFP-CFTR is abundant.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	377	 So, when syntaxin 8 is soluble, it may physically bind CFTR and follow its trafficking, but when syntaxin 8 is anchored in vesicle membrane, it binds CFTR too, but only in the cellular compartment where syntaxin 8 assumes its function (i.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	378	 As Syn8TM had no or little effect on CFTR trafficking, inhibition of CFTR trafficking by syntaxin 8 overexpression could not be related to an excess of protein synthesis in endoplasmic reticulum.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	379	 Moreover, syntaxin 8 must be anchored in vesicle membranes to impair CFTR trafficking, which means that the t-SNARE function of syntaxin 8 can be engaged.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	380	 These results reinforce the physiological relevance of a putative regulator role of syntaxin 8 on CFTR channel activity.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	381	Syntaxin 8 is involved in CFTR recycling pathway The precise identification of the colocalization region of CFTR and syntaxin 8 was determined using fluorescent confocal microscopy and three well characterized antibodies against Lamp-1, an LE/lysosomal marker protein, TfR (transferrin receptor), an EE/RE marker protein, and Rab11, which stains RE and TGN membranes.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	382	 Our results exhibited no colocalization between Lamp-1 staining and the juxtanuclear compartment where CFTR and syntaxin 8 were accumulated.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	383	 TfR vesicular pattern partially matched with this region, and CFTR, syntaxin 8 and TfR seemed to be located together in thin perinuclear vesicles.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	384	 By contrast, Rab11 staining was highly similar to syntaxin 8 and CFTR juxtanuclear staining and we observed a high degree of colocalization both on fluorograms and on the merged image.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	385	 These results indicate that when syntaxin 8 is overexpressed with GFP-CFTR, both proteins are mainly localized in the same compartment, which could be identified as recycling endosomes and/or TGN membranes.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	386	 Because we have colocalized CFTR and syntaxin 8 with TfR and Rab11 proteins, we favour the recycling endosome hypothesis.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	387	Syntaxin 8 is a t-SNARE protein that belongs at least to the endosomal SNARE complex (Antonin et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	388	, 2000), and is consequently involved in the endosomal pathway like syntaxins 7, 11 and 12/13 (Prekeris et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	389	 Its cellular localization was determined mainly in the early endosome, but syntaxin 8 was also detected in the late endosome and lysosome organelles.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	390	 The early endosome is a dynamic compartment displaying a highly complex and pleiomorphic organization that contains clearly two functionally distinct subcompartments without real physical boundaries: plasma membrane proteins are recycled via the recycling endosomes or degraded via the endosomal carrier vesicles/multivesicular bodies of the degradation pathway (reviewed by Gruenberg, 2001).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	391	 In some cases, syntaxin 8 was also observed at the plasma membrane (Subramaniam et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	392	, 2000; Kasai and Akagawa, 2001), suggesting a vesicular cycling of syntaxin 8.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	393	The mechanism of CFTR recycling is still poorly understood, but CFTR has previously been detected in recycling endosomes using fluorescence microscopy in human bronchial epithelial cells (Poschet et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	394	 Thus, physical binding between CFTR and syntaxin 8 may occur in recycling endosomes, a cellular compartment which is required for CFTR recycling pathway and where syntaxin 8, probably assembled with other SNARE proteins (i.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	395	 endosomal SNARE complex), is implicated in its vesicular trafficking function.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	396	 Syntaxin 8 overexpression is likely to disrupt the vesicular transport step in which it is involved, as it has been previously observed for several SNARE proteins (Dascher and Balch, 1996; Low et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	397	 This could explain CFTR accumulation in recycling endosomes in our experiments.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	398	 So our results show that syntaxin 8 appears as an important regulatory protein directly implicated in CFTR recycling pathway.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	399	In conclusion, SNARE proteins, and particularly syntaxin 8, participate actively in CFTR trafficking, recycling and/or in direct regulation of CFTR activity.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	400	 Here, we describe a relationship between CFTR and syntaxin 8 in the recycling endosome.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	401	 A recent paper showed that in cystic fibrosis cells a dysfunction in the recycling endosome pathway may have many repercussions on endocytic and plasma membrane processes (Poschet et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	402	 So elucidating the recycling pathway of CFTR could be important in understanding the physiopathology of cystic fibrosis.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	403	   Acknowledgments   We thank the following people for their gift or reagents: J.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	404	 Stanton (GFP-CFTR construct); A.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	405	 Naren (GST-Syn1ATM construct); W.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	406	 von Mollard (endosomal SNARE constructs); Y.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	407	 Salamero (Rab11 antibody and helpful discussions).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	408	 This work was supported by Vaincre la Mucoviscidose and Region Poitou-Charentes.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	409	   Footnotes   * These authors contributed equally to this work.

0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	0	SPECIAL TOPIC CFTR trafficking and signaling in respiratory epithelium Bruce R.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	1	Department of Environmental and Occupational Health, Graduate School of Public Health, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15238.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	2	    INTRODUCTION TOP INTRODUCTION MOLECULAR CHAPERONES AND.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	3	RESEARCH IN CYSTIC FIBROSIS (CF) remains at the leading edge of investigations employing human genetics and molecular and cellular biology.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	4	 In the 12 years since the discovery of the gene encoding the CF transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) Cl channel (14), translation of such efforts clinically has been remarkable and includes 1) identification of almost 1,000 different mutations (http://www.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	5	ca/cftr), including 70% with a phenylalanine deletion (F508) that has led to successful clinical detection of individuals with a family history (even before the completion of the human genome project) and 2) ~20 trials of human CF gene therapy involving dosing to the nose or airways (2, 22).
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Such rapid progress, however, belies the complexity of the CFTR gene and the pathophysiology of CF.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	7	CFTR is a unique member of the ATP-binding cassette transporter gene family in that it 1) conducts Cl, 2) transports substrates across membranes in a nonconductive fashion (e.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	8	, facilitates ATP release), 3) regulates other ion channel proteins (e.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	9	, positive regulation of outwardly rectifying Cl channels or negative regulation of Na+ channels), and 4) regulates intracellular compartment acidification and protein processing (18).
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Such complexity has led these authors to categorize defects in CF respiratory epithelium as primary (dehydration associated with dysfunctional Cl transport), secondary (hyperabsorption of Na+), or tertiary (enhanced binding of Pseudomonas aeruginosa; proinflammatory environment).
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Fundamental to such diversity is the awareness that very minor mutations (e.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	12	, F508, a single-amino acid deletion within a 1,480-amino acid protein) result in the profound pathological phenotype of CF (23).
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	13	 In the case of F508, the missense mutation results in a mutant CFTR that is believed to fold improperly, and such defects in its biosynthesis and trafficking result in little or no surface CFTR.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Other mutations in CFTR lead to genotypic or phenotypic changes that span the range from no CFTR in the membrane to CFTR that reaches the membrane but does not respond to appropriate stimuli or conduct Cl (6).
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Adding to this complexity is a recent report describing tissue-specific changes in the impairment of F508 processing (10).
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Some mutations overlap with PDZ-interacting domains on the COOH terminus of CFTR that are required for polarization of CFTR to the apical membrane of respiratory epithelium (13) and may underscore CFTR regulation of other ion channels by affecting the relationship between accessory proteins, linker proteins, and regulatory cofactors.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	17	Accordingly, research into the biosynthesis and trafficking of wild-type and mutated CFTR is at the forefront of CF investigations.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Although the defect in Cl conductance is critical to the pathology of CF respiratory epithelia, contributions of alterations in vesicle trafficking, protein processing, and immune function clearly contribute to the pathogenesis and maintenance of CF (18).
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	19	 These efforts underlie the disparities between genotype and phenotype in CF and suggest that in addition to nucleotide repair (gene therapy, aminoglycoside-dependent restoration of readthrough of full-length CFTR), pharmacotherapy targeted toward improved biosynthesis of mutated CFTR may be a useful adjunct approach to the treatment of CF (24).
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	20	    MOLECULAR CHAPERONES AND BIOSYNTHESIS OF CFTR TOP INTRODUCTION MOLECULAR CHAPERONES AND.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	21	The importance of providing mechanistic support for pharmacologically affecting the maturation of CF is placed in the context of our current molecular physiological understanding of the roles of various chaperones for CFTR by Brodsky (4) in this issue of the American Journal of Physiology-Lung Cellular and Molecular Physiology.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	22	 The steps in proper folding of CFTR, quality control mechanism of endoplasmic reticulum trafficking, and requisite association with various chaperones are outlined by Brodsky and reference is made to three original articles in the Special Topic.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	23	 The mechanisms by which sodium 4-phenylbutyrate may be a modulator of such chaperones are presented by Rubenstein and Lyons (17) and Choo-Kang and Zeitlin (5), and the in vivo efficacy of a chemical chaperone, trimethylamine oxide, in the restoration of defective Cl conductance in the critical target tissue (intestinal epithelium) of CFTR null mutant mice is presented by Fischer et al.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	24	 This collective work strongly supports the concept that small molecules are useful alternative or adjunct therapies for disorders of protein folding (23, 24).
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	25	    PROINFLAMMATORY PROFILE OF CF EPITHELIA TOP INTRODUCTION MOLECULAR CHAPERONES AND.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	26	A critical aspect of CF is chronic airway inflammation, and several groups have provided support that dysregulation of the inflammatory response is an intrinsic component of such a phenotype.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	27	 An editorial by Blackwell et al.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	28	 (1) accompanies the manuscript by Weber et al.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	29	 (21) and highlights the central role of unregulated nuclear factor (NF)-B in the proinflammatory cytokine profile of cells expressing mutated CFTR.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	30	 In this regard, blocking the production of NF-B may be an alternative rational therapeutic approach in CF therapy.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	31	 In addition to enhanced cytokine (interleukin-8, tumor necrosis factor-) production, oxidative stress appears to be a component of CF epithelia.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Previous in vitro work (9, 11) showed that CFTR is associated with the transport of glutathione (GSH).
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	33	 In the current Special Topic, Gao et al.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	34	 (8) show that the Cl channel-forming peptide N-K4-M2GlyR increased Cl secretion and GSH efflux in a human CF airway epithelial cell line, suggesting that apical Cl conductance (but not necessarily CFTR function per se) is coupled to GSH efflux.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	35	 (20) report in this issue that GSH was decreased in the epithelial lining fluid of CFTR-deficient mice and that an imbalance in antioxidant defense in CFTR-deficient mice was evident.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	36	 These data extend previous observations that GSH was decreased in the airway fluid of humans with CFTR (16) and that aerosol delivery of GSH may be a useful therapy for CF (15).
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	37	 GSH and other cellular defense mechanisms may indeed represent a rational therapeutic strategy in CF.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	38	    SERINE PROTEASE-SENSITIVE SODIUM HYPERABSORPTION IN HUMAN AIRWAY EPITHELIUM TOP INTRODUCTION MOLECULAR CHAPERONES AND.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	39	As noted above, Na+ hyperabsorption is a critical secondary-like phenomenon in CF epithelia.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Although the mechanism coupling such hyperabsorption to CFTR mutations remains unknown, an extracellular serine protease-mediated signaling pathway has been identified (19) that activates an amiloride-sensitive Na+ channel.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	41	 In the Special Topic in this issue, Bridges et al.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	42	 (3) show that human bronchial epithelial cells are sensitive to aprotinin.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Using the Kunitz domain of aprotinin as a pharmacophore, they show that BAY 39-9437, a recombinant Kunitz-type serine protease inhibitor, decreased Na+ absorption in non-CF and CF human bronchial epithelia.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	44	    EDITOR'S NOTE TOP INTRODUCTION MOLECULAR CHAPERONES AND.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	45	This is the first of a series of special topics that will appear routinely in the American Journal of Physiology-Lung Cellular and Molecular Physiology.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The purpose of these special calls is to highlight areas of significant interest in respiratory biology by soliciting input from a broad research community, fast tracking the submitted manuscripts through the review process, and publishing them under their own separate heading.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	47	 In this case, a call for papers in "CFTR Trafficking and Signaling in Respiratory Epithelium" initially appeared in July 2000 (12).
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	48	 This led to the seven manuscripts and two accompanying editorials that appear in the current issue.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	49	 This remarkable and timely turnaround in peer review is a testimony to the importance of the topic and the enthusiasm of the authors and reviewers to bring this information to our readership.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	50	This special topic section is a collection of papers accepted under a special call for manuscripts by the Editor.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	51	 See Journal web site for information about the next call.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	52	Address for reprint requests and other correspondence: B.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	53	 of Environmental and Occupational Health, Graduate School Public Health, Univ.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	54	 of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA 15238 (E-mail: brucep+{at}pitt.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	55	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.

0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Am J Physiol Lung Cell Mol Physiol 281: L31-L38, 2001[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	114	   Weber, AJ, Soong G, Bryan R, Saba S, and Prince A.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Activation of NF-B in airway epithelial cells is dependent on CFTR trafficking and Cl channel function.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Am J Physiol Lung Cell Mol Physiol 281: L71-L78, 2001[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Gene transfer for cystic fibrosis.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	118	 J Clin Invest 104: 1165-1166, 1999[Free Full Text].
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	119	 J Clin Invest 105: 853-854, 2000[Free Full Text].
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Novel pharmacologic therapies for cystic fibrosis.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	121	 J Clin Invest 103: 447-452, 1999[Free Full Text].
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	122	Am J Physiol Lung Cell Mol Physiol 281(1):L13-L15 1040-0605/01 $5.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	123	00 Copyright   2001 the American Physiological Society This Article Full Text (PDF) Alert me when this article is cited Alert me if a correction is posted Citation Map Services Email this article to a friend Similar articles in this journal Similar articles in ISI Web of Science Similar articles in PubMed Alert me to new issues of the journal Download to citation manager Google Scholar Articles by Pitt, B.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Articles citing this Article PubMed PubMed Citation Articles by Pitt, B.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	125	HOME HELP FEEDBACK SUBSCRIPTIONS ARCHIVE SEARCH TABLE OF CONTENTS Visit Other APS Journals Online.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	0	MINIREVIEW Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator STRUCTURE AND FUNCTION OF AN EPITHELIAL CHLORIDE CHANNEL* Myles H.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Center for Molecular Recognition, Departments of Physiology  and  Cellular Biophysics and Medicine, Columbia University, New York, New York 10032.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	2	    INTRODUCTION TOP INTRODUCTION Structural Basis of Channel.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Synthesis and Degradation Conclusions REFERENCES.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	4	The cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR)1 forms a Cl channel that is an essential component of epithelial Cl transport systems in many organs, including the intestines, pancreas, lungs, sweat glands, and kidneys.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	5	 In the Cl secretory intestinal epithelium, Cl enters the cells through a Na+-K+-2Cl cotransporter in the basolateral membrane and exits through CFTR in the apical membrane; water follows osmotically (1).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Absorptive epithelia use similar transporters and channels, but their polarized distribution between the apical and basolateral membranes is usually reversed.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	7	 A major determinant of the transepithelial Cl transport rate is the level of activation of CFTR (2, 3), which depends on the extent to which it is phosphorylated.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	8	 This is determined by the relative activities of kinases and phosphatases, the activities of which are often hormonally regulated (1).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	9	Defects in the gene encoding CFTR that reduce either its Cl transport capacity or its level of cell surface expression cause cystic fibrosis (CF) (4-6) as well as a form of male sterility due to congenital bilateral absence of the vas deferens (7).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	10	 CF is the most common lethal genetic disease in Caucasians, with about 30,000 CF patients in the United States.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	11	 In contrast, in intestinal epithelial cells overstimulation of CFTR because of the activation of protein kinases by bacterial enterotoxins causes secretory diarrhea (1, 8).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Secretory diarrhea is the second largest cause of infant mortality in the developing world, causing 3 million deaths per year of children under the age of 5.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Thus, although CFTR was named because of its association with CF, as a cause of disease, its relationship to secretory diarrhea is a more widespread public health problem.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	14	The cloning of CFTR in 1989 (9) has facilitated studies of its structure, function, regulation, biogenesis, and degradation, which will be reviewed in this article.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Issues reviewed elsewhere and not discussed here include the mechanisms by which mutations in CFTR cause CF (5, 6) and the possible role of CFTR in regulating the pH within intracellular organelles (10).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	16	     Structural Basis of Channel Function TOP INTRODUCTION Structural Basis of Channel.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Synthesis and Degradation Conclusions REFERENCES.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	18	CFTR is a member of the ATP-binding cassette (ABC) membrane transporter gene superfamily that includes both eukaryotic and bacterial proteins, such as the multiple drug resistance protein (MDR), the sulfonylurea receptor, the transporter for antigen presentation, and the bacterial periplasmic permeases (9, 11).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Being an ion channel makes CFTR unique in this gene superfamily in which most other members are ATP-driven membrane transporters.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	20	CFTR contains 1480 amino acids and consists of two homologous halves (Fig.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Each half contains six membrane-spanning segments and a nucleotide-binding domain (NBD).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	22	 The two halves of CFTR are linked by a cytoplasmic regulatory domain (R-domain) that contains a number of consensus phosphorylation sites (9).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	23	 In the proposed transmembrane topology (Fig.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	24	 1), which is supported by experimental evidence (9, 12, 13), 77% of the protein is in the cytoplasm, 19% in membrane-spanning segments, and 4% in extracellular loops, which (except for the M1-M2 and M7-M8 loops) are very short.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	25	 The M7-M8 loop contains two N-linked glycosylation sites that are used in vivo (12, 13).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Covalent linkage of the two halves is not required for assembly and function.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	27	 When expressed as separate proteins in the same cells the halves assembled into functional channels and could be co-immunoprecipitated.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	28	 This assembly required interactions within the membrane-spanning domains (13, 14).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	29	View larger version (16K):    Fig.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	30	   Transmembrane topology of CFTR.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Gray balloons on the M7-M8 loop indicate N-linked glycosylation sites.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	32	CFTR was inferred to be a monomer because following solubilization, with either ionic or nonionic detergents, biochemically distinct forms of CFTR, expressed in the same cells, could not be co-immunoprecipitated (15).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	33	 In contrast, two studies concluded that CFTR is a homodimer in situ based on the size of CFTR particles in freeze-fracture electron micrographs (16) and on the functional effects of coexpressing mutants with distinct functional properties (17).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	34	 In the homologous MDR transporter, however, dimers were not seen in cryoelectron microscopic images (18).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	35	Channel-lining Residues-- The channel lining is formed, at least in part, by residues from among the 12 membrane-spanning segments.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	36	 The major determinants of the channel's functional properties are likely to be among the channel-lining residues.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Water-accessible residues inferred to line the channel were identified in the M1, M3, and M6 segments using the substituted cysteine accessibility method (19-21).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	38	 These segments' secondary structure was inferred to be largely -helical based on the patterns formed by the channel-lining residues (19-21).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Further support for an -helical secondary structure of the membrane-spanning segments was provided by studies of synthetic peptides, the sequences of which corresponded to those of the M1-M6 segments.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	40	 These peptides were largely -helical in liposomes and in detergent micelles (22, 23).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	41	The minimum channel diameter was inferred to be ~5.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	42	3 A based on the size of the largest permeant anion (24).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Further studies using patches with larger numbers of channels showed that anions as large as lactobionate (10-13 A in diameter) were slightly permeable.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Thus, at least transiently, the diameter of the channel must be 10-13 A (25).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	45	 In the presence of cytoplasmic ATP the large anions were only permeable from the cytoplasmic side (25).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The molecular basis for asymmetric permeation by large anions is unknown.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	47	 There is no asymmetry in the conduction of small anions; the channel has a linear current-voltage relationship in Cl solutions (13).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Although some studies suggested that ATP was permeable through CFTR (reviewed in Ref.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	49	 26), it has been convincingly demonstrated that there is no measurable electrogenic ATP flux through CFTR (27-29).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	50	Mechanism of Charge Selectivity-- The ability to discriminate between Cl and cations is essential for the role of CFTR in epithelial Cl transport.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	51	 The extent of anion selectivity, as measured by the Cl to Na+ permeability ratio (30), ranges between 10 and 300 (31, 32).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	52	 We showed that the charge selectivity filter that discriminates between anions and cations is located at the cytoplasmic end of the channel and that both anions and cations can enter the extracellular end of the channel (33).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Arg-352, at the cytoplasmic end of M6, is a major determinant of charge selectivity.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Removal of the positive charge at this position reduced the Cl to Na+ permeability ratio approximately 10-fold (34).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	55	 We hypothesized that the positive charge of Arg-352 creates an electrostatic barrier to cation permeation.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Near Arg-352 the channel must be narrow enough so that the electrostatic barrier extends across the channel lumen (34).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	57	Halide Selectivity and Multiple Ion Occupancy-- The channel displays modest selectivity between halides.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	58	 The halide permeability sequence is I (1.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	59	2), indicative of weak interactions between permeating anions and channel binding sites (30, 32).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Multiple anions can simultaneously occupy the channel, thereby resulting in anomalous mole fraction effects in the single channel conductance in mixtures of Cl and SCN.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	61	 These effects were eliminated in the M6 mutant R347D, and Arg-347, therefore, was hypothesized to be at or near an anion binding site (35).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Arg-347, however, has been shown to form a salt bridge with Asp-924 (36).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Therefore, it is possible that rather than Arg-347 being a binding site itself, structural perturbation caused by the loss of the salt bridge disrupted an anion binding site elsewhere (30).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	64	Channel Inhibitors-- CFTR has few inhibitors and none are of high affinity or specificity (13).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	65	 The affinity of the channel blocker diphenylamine 2-carboxylate was reduced by mutating two water-accessible residues in M6.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Mutations of the aligned M12 residues increased diphenylamine 2-carboxylate affinity suggesting that the channel is lined by residues from both halves of CFTR (37).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	67	In contrast to their actions on other Cl channels and transporters, disulfonic stilbenes such as DIDS inhibit only when applied to the cytoplasmic side (38).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Cytoplasmic application of other large anions also caused flickery block of CFTR.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	69	 This is further evidence that the channel is asymmetric and contains an anion binding site in the cytoplasmic vestibule (39).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	70	 The residues forming the cytoplasmic vestibule remain to be identified, but the cytoplasmic loops probably do not contribute to the vestibule because none of the CF-related loop mutations affected ion conduction (40).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	71	The picture that is emerging is of a channel with a large extracellular vestibule that extends into the plain of the membrane and is accessible to anions and cations from the extracellular side (Fig.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	72	 The channel narrows toward the cytoplasmic end where the charge selectivity filter is located.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Finally, there is a short cytoplasmic vestibule that contains an anion binding site.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	74	 The channel lining is formed, in part, by residues from the M1, M3, M6, and M12 segments.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Little is known about whether the other eight membrane-spanning segments contribute to the channel lining.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	76	 The location of the gate that blocks ion conduction through the channel in the closed state is unknown.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	77	 The gate, however, is controlled by conformational changes in the cytoplasmic domains.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	78	View larger version (41K):    Fig.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	79	   Schematic illustrating the structure of CFTR and the relationships of its domains and associated proteins to the channel.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Membrane-spanning domains, red; the water-filled transmembrane channel, blue; NBD-1, yellow; NBD-2, orange; bound ATP, white ovals; R-domain, green; the N- and C termini are indicated by black lines; the associated proteins syntaxin 1A (Syn 1A) and Na+/H+ exchanger regulatory factor/ezrin-binding protein 50 (NHERF/EBP-50), purple.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Note the position of Arg-352, a major determinant of charge selectivity, at the narrow point in the channel.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Cl ions probably do not interact with the NBDs and R-domain as they pass through the channel.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The cytoplasmic vestibule has a binding site for large anions (see "channel-lining Residues").
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The interactions with PP2C and other channels and transporters are not shown (see "Interactions with Other Proteins").
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	85	     Regulation of CFTR Channel Gating TOP INTRODUCTION Structural Basis of Channel.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Synthesis and Degradation Conclusions REFERENCES.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	87	Two separate processes control the gating of CFTR: 1) phosphorylation and 2) binding and hydrolysis of ATP.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Phosphorylation is necessary for activation, but it is not sufficient.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	89	 After phosphorylation, gating between the closed and open states is controlled by ATP hydrolysis (12, 13, 41).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	90	Phosphorylation Is a Prerequisite for Channel Activation-- The R-domain contains multiple consensus phosphorylation sites for cAMP-dependent protein kinase (PKA), protein kinase C (PKC), and Type II cGMP-dependent protein kinase (9, 12, 13, 41, 42).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	91	 The more extensive the phosphorylation, the greater the channel open probability (41, 43).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	92	 There appears to be extensive redundancy in the regulatory PKA phosphorylation sites.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Five sites are phosphorylated in vivo, but removal of these sites or all 10 dibasic PKA sites reduced but did not eliminate PKA activation (44).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	94	 CFTR is still phosphorylated after removal of the 10 dibasic sites indicating that phosphorylation at non-dibasic PKA sites is sufficient for channel activation; one such site has been identified (12, 13, 41).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	95	 PKC phosphorylation may be a prerequisite for activation by PKA (45).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Finally, although genistein, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, activates CFTR this occurs through a direct interaction with CFTR and does not involve a tyrosine kinase (reviewed in Ref.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	97	After phosphorylation, CFTR is deactivated by protein phosphatases (41).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Dephosphorylation is largely mediated by protein phosphatases PP2C and PP2A (46, 47).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	99	 PP2C is closely linked to CFTR in the membrane as it could be co-immunoprecipitated with CFTR as well as cross-linked to CFTR by bifunctional cross-linkers, whereas PP1, PP2A, and PP2B could not (48).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	100	Channel Gating Requires ATP Hydrolysis-- Following phosphorylation, opening and closing of the channel is controlled by ATP binding and hydrolysis (12, 13, 41).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Non-hydrolyzable ATP analogs do not support channel opening (49).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Purified, phosphorylated, reconstituted CFTR binds ATP with a Km of 0.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	103	3 mM and hydrolyzes ATP at a rate of about 1 molecule/s (50), similar to the rate of channel gating.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	104	 ATP hydrolysis occurs in the NBDs, which contain highly conserved Walker A and B motifs found in other ATPases (9, 13, 41, 49).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	105	A construct lacking the R-domain, CFTR-R, did not require phosphorylation to open and close in the presence of ATP (13).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Adding soluble, phosphorylated R-domain peptide to CFTR-R enhanced its ATP sensitivity resulting in an increased channel open probability (51, 52).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Thus, the R-domain interacts with the NBDs and regulates their ATP affinity.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	108	Structure of a Bacterial NBD-- In the homologous bacterial periplasmic permeases the NBDs and the transmembrane domains are usually separate gene products that assemble during biosynthesis (11, 53).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	109	 The histidine periplasmic permease contains two copies of its NBD protein, HisP; each copy has a single nucleotide binding site.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	110	 The x-ray crystal structure of HisP was determined (54).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	111	 The sequence conservation between the bacterial and eukaryotic NBDs implies that their structures are similar and that aligned residues perform similar functions in HisP and CFTR.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	112	HisP has a novel structure (54).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	113	 It contains only small regions of structural similarity with RecA and the  and  F1-ATPase subunits.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	114	 HisP is shaped like the letter L (Fig.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	115	 One arm (Arm I) of the L contains the ATP binding site, including the Walker A and B motifs.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Most interactions between the Walker A residues and ATP are via hydrogen bonds between the backbone amides and the ATP phosphates.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	117	 An aspartate at the C terminus of the Walker B motif, aligned with CFTR residues Asp-572 and Asp-1370, in NBD-1 and -2, respectively, was inferred to bind the Mg2+ ion required for hydrolysis.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	118	 CFTR residues Gln-493 and Ser-573 in NBD-1 and Gln-1291 and Glu-1371 in NBD-2 align with the catalytically important residues in HisP that hydrogen bond to a water molecule that in turn hydrogen bonds to the -phosphate.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	119	 This water molecule is thought to attack ATP because its hydrogen bond lies parallel to the P-O bond that is broken during ATP hydrolysis (54).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	120	 The adenine base forms a hydrophobic interaction with a single aromatic residue, perhaps explaining the lack of specificity among nucleotide triphosphates that can gate CFTR (49).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	121	The other arm in the HisP structure, Arm II, contains a LSGGQ motif that forms the foundation around which Arm II is built.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Arm II was inferred to interact with the membrane-spanning domains (54).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	123	 The residue aligned with Phe-508 in CFTR, the site of the most common CF-associated mutation, lies on an exposed surface of an -helix in Arm II.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	124	Channel Gating and the Sites of ATP Hydrolysis-- The current hypothesis that ATP hydrolysis at NBD-1 opens the channel and ATP hydrolysis at NBD-2 closes the channel to terminate a burst is consistent with the functional effects of mutations in the NBDs (13, 41).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Mutations in the NBD-2 Walker motifs that decrease its ATP hydrolysis rate slow channel closing (55-58).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Similar mutations in NBD-1 reduce channel opening.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	127	 The NBD-1 mutations also altered channel closing rates, suggesting there are functional interactions between the NBDs (55-57).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	128	 In both the crystal structure and in solution HisP forms a dimer, the interface of which is located along the edge of Arm I (54).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Thus, direct contacts between the NBDs may be the structural basis for the functional interaction.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Mixtures of ATP and non-hydrolyzable analogs lock channels in the open state.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Presumably ATP hydrolysis at NBD-1 opens the channels and binding of a non-hydrolyzable analog at NBD-2 prevents closing (13, 41).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	132	The gating behavior of CFTR has been described by several kinetic models.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Cyclic models with essentially irreversible steps corresponding to the ATP hydrolysis steps provide the best descriptions of channel gating (reviewed in Refs.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	134	     Interactions with Other Proteins TOP INTRODUCTION Structural Basis of Channel.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Synthesis and Degradation Conclusions REFERENCES.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	136	In addition to its function as a Cl channel, CFTR acts as a regulator of other channels and transporters (26).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	137	 CFTR mediates cAMP regulation of amiloride-sensitive Na+ channels (60), outward rectifying Cl channels (61, 62), Cl/HCO3 exchanger (63), and the ROMK K+ channel (26).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Whether these regulatory functions result from direct interactions between CFTR and the channels and transporters or through indirect interactions via other proteins remains to be determined.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	139	Direct interactions with CFTR have been shown for several proteins.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Syntaxin 1A interacts with the cytoplasmic N-terminal domain of CFTR and inhibits channel activity (64).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	141	 A family of PDZ-binding domain proteins, including the Na+/H+ exchanger regulatory factor (65) and ezrin-binding protein 50 (66), bind to the C terminus (D-(S/T)-X-L) (Fig.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	142	 These proteins presumably couple CFTR to the cytoskeleton and may be involved in apical membrane localization.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Finally, as mentioned above, CFTR is closely associated with protein phosphatase 2C (48).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	144	     Synthesis and Degradation TOP INTRODUCTION Structural Basis of Channel.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Synthesis and Degradation Conclusions REFERENCES.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	146	Attention has focused on the synthesis and degradation of CFTR because many mutations that cause CF, such as F508, lead to the misfolding of CFTR in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and subsequent degradation of CFTR (reviewed in Refs.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	147	 The synthesis of wild-type CFTR is inefficient.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Only about 30% of newly synthesized CFTR develops endoglycosidase H-resistant mature glycosylation suggestive of translocation from the ER to the Golgi complex (68, 69).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	149	 In contrast, 100% of the homologous MDR matures (70).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	150	 CFTR molecules that fail to mature are polyubiquitinated and degraded via a cytoplasmic, proteasome-dependent pathway (71, 72).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	151	 In the ER, CFTR transiently associates with several chaperones including the cytoplasmic Hsp70 and Hsp90 and the ER membrane chaperone calnexin (67, 73).
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	152	 The molecular basis for the inefficient processing of CFTR in the protein synthetic pathway remains to be elucidated.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	153	     Conclusions TOP INTRODUCTION Structural Basis of Channel.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Synthesis and Degradation Conclusions REFERENCES.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	155	CFTR has an important role in epithelial Cl transport both as a Cl channel and as a regulator of other channels and transporters.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Studies of the channel have begun to provide a picture of its structure and regulation.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Understanding how CFTR interacts with other channels and transporter will provide insights into the cellular regulation of epithelial transport and the pathophysiology that results from defects in CFTR or from its overstimulation by bacterial toxins.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	158	 One hopes that further studies will provide a basis for the design or identification of specific, high affinity CFTR inhibitors that would be useful for basic studies of the role of CFTR in epithelial Cl transport and potentially as a therapy for secretory diarrhea, a major cause of morbidity and infant mortality in the developing world.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Jonathan Javitch for comments on this manuscript.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	160	* This minireview will be reprinted in the 2000 Minireview Compendium, which will be available in December, 2000.

0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	225	 95, 8496-8501[Abstract/Free Full Text] 66.

0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	227	 79, S167-S173[Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] 68.
