0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	231	 (1995) Cell 83, 121-127[Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] 73.
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	232	 17, 6879-6887[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.4315326.10660517.html.plaintext.txt	233	Copyright   2000 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	0	Characterization of the oligosaccharide structures associated with the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator Catherine R.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Lachapelle, John Marshall, Elizabeth A.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	2	Genzyme Corporation, 31 New York Avenue, Framingham, MA 01701 to 9322, USA.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	3	Received on April 26, 2000; revised on June 26, 2000; accepted on June 26, 2000.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	4	   Abstract Top Abstract Introduction Results Discussion Material and methods Acknowledgments Abbreviations References   The cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) is a plasma membrane-associated glycoprotein.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	5	 The protein can exist in three different molecular weight forms of approximately 127, 131, and 160 kDa, representing either nonglycosylated, core glycosylated, or fully mature, complex glycosylated CFTR, respectively.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	6	 The most common mutation in cystic fibrosis (CF) results in the synthesis of a variant (F508-CFTR) that is incompletely glycosylated and defective in its trafficking to the cell surface.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	7	 In this study, we have analyzed the oligosaccharide structures associated with the different forms of recombinant CFTR, by expressing and purifying the channel protein from either mammalian Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) or insect Sf9 cells.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Using glycosidases and FACE analysis (fluorophore-assisted carbohydrate electrophoresis) we determined that purified CHO-CFTR contained polylactosaminoglycan (PL) sequences, while Sf9-CFTR had only oligomannosidic saccharides with fucosylation on the innermost GlcNAc.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	9	 The presence of PL sequences on the recombinant CHO-CFTR is consistent with a normal feature of mammalian processing, since endogenous CFTR isolated from T84 cells displayed a similar pattern of glycosylation.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	10	 The present study also reports on the use of FACE for the qualitative analysis of small amounts of glycoprotein oligosaccharides released enzymatically.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	11	Key words: CFTR/FACE analysis/ polylactosaminoglycans/oligomannosidic saccharides.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	12	   Introduction Top Abstract Introduction Results Discussion Material and methods Acknowledgments Abbreviations References   Cystic fibrosis (CF) is caused by mutations in the gene encoding the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR; Boat et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Patients with CF are marked by dysfunctional epithelia due to the absence of functional CFTR chloride (Cl to ) channels at the apical plasma membranes of the affected cells.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Studies have shown that CFTR is a membrane-associated glycoprotein whose Cl to  channel activity is regulated by protein kinase A-mediated phosphorylation (Cheng et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Electrophoretic analysis has indicated that CFTR can exist as three different molecular weight forms of approximately 127 kDa, 131 kDa, and 160 kDa, referred to as bands A, B, and C, respectively (Gregory et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Bands A, B, and C represent different glycoforms of CFTR with band A representing nonglycosylated CFTR, band B representing core glycosylated CFTR, and band C representing the mature CFTR with complex glycosylation (Cheng et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	17	 These posttranslational modifications of CFTR may represent an important marker of protein processing (Cheng et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The presence of core glycosylated band B CFTR, for example, indicates processing of the protein in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), while mature band C CFTR with complex glycosylation is representative of processing in the Golgi (Cheng et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	19	The significance of CFTR glycosylation is understood best, however, by studying the mutant F508-CFTR.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	20	 The deletion of the phenylalanine residue at position 508 (F508) in CFTR is the most common cause of cystic fibrosis (Boat et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	21	 At 37 degrees C, mutant F508-CFTR is synthesized predominantly as bands A and B, suggesting that the variant protein is unable to traffic normally to the Golgi apparatus (Cheng et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	22	 For this reason no CFTR chloride channels are detected.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	23	 However, the processing of recombinant F508-CFTR can revert towards that of wild-type CFTR when the incubation temperature for the cells is reduced to 26 degrees C (Denning et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	24	 At this lower temperature, some CFTR becomes fully processed and is presented at the plasma membrane, as evidenced by the appearance of very small amounts of mature band C CFTR and the detection of cAMP-regulated Cl to  channel activity at the cell surface (Denning et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	25	Studies on the relationship of glycosylation to the function of CFTR suggest that the addition of carbohydrate to CFTR is not a necessary prerequisite for the protein to target to the plasma membrane or to function as a cAMP-stimulated Cl to  channel (Gregory et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	26	, 1993); however, determining the oligosaccharide structures associated with CFTR should contribute to a better understanding of the structure of this complex transmembrane protein and the influence that F508-CFTR has on other cell membrane glycoproteins.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	27	 In this study we have analyzed the pattern of glycosylation of the different forms of CFTR (O'Riordan et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	28	, 1995) by expressing the channel protein in either mammalian or insect cells.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	29	 We show that the pattern of glycosylation of recombinant CFTR expressed in mammalian cell systems is representative of that which occurs on endogenous CFTR, while CFTR expressed in insect cells is not fully processed.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	30	   Results Top Abstract Introduction Results Discussion Material and methods Acknowledgments Abbreviations References   Different glycosylation forms of CFTR are expressed in mammalian and insect cells Two types of mammalian cells, CHO (Chinese hamster ovary) and C127 (mouse mammary adenocarcinoma), and an insect cell line (Sf9) were used for the overexpression of human CFTR (Marshall et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	31	 The different glycosylation forms of CFTR (bands A, B, and C) were expressed at varying levels depending on the cell type used.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	32	 CFTR prepared from lysates of recombinant C127 and CHO cells were predominantly of the fully mature band C form (160 kDa) with a minor component of band B (Figure 1A, lane 2, and Figure 1B, lane 3).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	33	 However, CFTR prepared from recombinant Sf9 insect cells appeared predominantly as an 131 kDa polypeptide (Figure 1B, lane 2), which is similar in size to the band B form observed in mammalian cells (Figure 1A, lane 2).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	34	 This is expected, since proteins expressed in Sf9 cells have been reported to harbor solely oligomannosidic glycosylation (Vialard et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Further studies on the oligosaccharide structures of wild type CFTR were performed using CFTR purified from both these sources.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	36	View larger version (26K):    Fig.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Expression of CFTR in different cell types.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Autoradiographs of immunoprecipitated CFTR from transfected (A) C127 cells and (B) CHO and Sf9 cells.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	39	 CFTR was labeled by phosphorylation with [-32P]-ATP and the catalytic subunit of cAMP-dependent PKA, and then electrophoresed on 6% SDS to polyacrylamide gels.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Bands B and C represent core-glycosylated and fully glycosylated CFTR respectively.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	41	 (A) Lane 1, mock-transfected C127 cells; lane 2, C127 cells transfected with wild type CFTR; lane 3, C127 cells transfected with F508-CFTR.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	42	 (B) Lane 1, uninfected Sf9 cells; lane 2, Sf9 cells infected with wild type CFTR baculovirus; lane 3, CHO cells transfected with wild type CFTR, lane 4, parental CHO cells.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	43	  Fractionation of the bands B and C forms of CFTR by lectin affinity chromatography Since the bands B and C forms of CFTR differed in carbohydrate content, they could be further fractionated and purified by lectin affinity chromatography.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The lectin wheat germ-agglutinin specifically recognizes N-acetylglucosamine residues (Nagata and Burger, 1974) that are present on complex carbohydrate glycoproteins and therefore could be used to separate the band C CFTR (which contains complex carbohydrate structures) from band B CFTR (which contains only oligomannose structures).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	45	 As shown in Figure 2, chromatography of T84 cell lysates on wheat-germ agglutinin Sepharose resulted in retention of the band C, but not the band B, form of CFTR.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The bound band C form of CFTR could be recovered from the resin in a highly purified form by elution with buffer containing 0.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	47	5 M N-acetylglucosamine (Figure 2 lanes 3 and 4).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Similarly, insect Sf9-derived CFTR which was synthesized predominantly as the band B species of CFTR failed to bind to wheat germ-agglutinin Sepharose (data not shown).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	49	 These results are consistent with band B CFTR containing only core glycosylation and band C CFTR containing carbohydrates of the complex type (Cheng et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	50	View larger version (52K):    Fig.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Affinity chromatography of CHO-CFTR using wheat germ agglutinin.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	52	 T84 cells expressing CFTR were lysed with 1% CHAPSO and applied onto wheat germ lectin Sepharose.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Bound proteins were eluted from the resin with 0.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Column fractions were immunoprecipitated with MAb 13 to 1 and phosphorylated in the presence of [-32P] ATP and the catalytic subunit of protein kinase A.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Lane 1 represents the load, lane 2, the flow through, and lanes 3 and 4 represent band C-CFTR specifically eluted with 0.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	56	  Characterization of CHO-CFTR using the glycosidases N-glycanase and endo to ss-galactosidase Digestion of the purified band C CFTR (160 kDa) from CHO cells with N-glycanase, which cleaves N-linked oligosaccharides between the oligosaccharide structure and an asparagine residue, resulted in a reduction of the size of the protein to that observed for band A CFTR (127 kDa), indicating that the mature band C CFTR was modified by N-linked glycosylation (Figure 3, lane 2).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	57	 As CFTR is a membrane glycoprotein, we also determined whether it harbored polylactosamine carbohydrate structures that are known to be associated with this class of glycoproteins (Gahmberg et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Indeed, digestion of purified band C CFTR with endo-ss-galactosidase (which hydrolyzes polylactosamine-containing structures) reduced its size to 131 kDa (Figure 3, lane 3), arguing for the presence of such structures on CFTR.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Additional digestion of the endo-ss-galactosidase treated band C with N-glycanase resulted in a further reduction in size to that of band A (Figure 3, lane 4).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	60	View larger version (36K):    Fig.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Endo-ss-galactosidase and N-glycanase digestion of CHO-CFTR.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Purified band C-CFTR from CHO cells (lane 1) was digested with N-glycanase (lane 2), endo-ss-galactosidase alone (lane 3), or endo-ss-galactosidase followed by N-glycanase (lane 4).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Samples were separated on 6% SDS to polyacrylamide gels followed by Coomassie blue staining.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	64	  Characterization of CHO-CFTR using lectin blots Further characterization of the structure of the N-linked oligosaccharides present on band C CFTR purified from CHO cells was performed using lectin blots.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Two lectins were used, DSA (Datura stramonium agglutinin) and MAA (Maackia amurensis agglutinin).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	66	 DSA is known to bind unbranched (Yamashita et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	67	, 1987) and branched polylactosamine sequences (Fukuda and Fukuda, 1984) and oligosaccharides containing an outer -mannose residue substituted with Gal ss (1,4) GlcNAc at both the C-2 and C-6 positions (Cummings et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	68	, 1982; Cummings and Kornfeld, 1984; Merkle and Cummings, 1987).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	69	 The lectin MAA recognizes sialic acid that is linked either (2 to 3) or (2 to 6) to galactose (Haseley et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Since CHO cells are unable to effect (2 to 6) sialylation (Carr et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	71	, 1989), it is predicted that CHO-CFTR, if sialylated, would be of the (2 to 3) type.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	72	 This was indeed confirmed when band C CFTR isolated from CHO cells failed to react with SNA (Sambucus nigra agglutinin), a lectin that recognizes specifically only (2 to 6) sialic acids (Haseley et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Figure 4 shows that band C CFTR reacted strongly with the lectin DSA but weakly with MAA.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	74	 However, following treatment with endo-ss-galactosidase, there was a marked decrease in reactivity of the digested CFTR with both of these lectins (Figure 4).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	75	 The observation that treatment of CFTR with endo-ss-galactosidase greatly reduced its ability to bind DSA, coupled with the demonstration above that band C CFTR was sensitive to endo-ss-galactosidase digestion, indicate that mature CHO-CFTR is comprised predominantly of polylactosamine structures.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	76	 That CFTR also reacted, albeit weakly, with MAA suggests the presence of sialic acid residues on the polylactosamine chains.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	77	View larger version (44K):    Fig.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Endo-ss-galactosidase treatment of CFTR followed by lectin blotting.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Immunoaffinity purified band C-CFTR from CHO cells was treated with endo-ss-galactosidase as described in Materials and methods, transferred to nitrocellulose and probed using either the lectin DSA (Datura stramonium agglutinin) or MAA (Mackia amurensis agglutinin).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	80	 The position of CFTR is indicated.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	81	 (+) refers to CFTR which had been treated with endo-ss-galactosidase and (-) to untreated samples.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	82	  FACE analysis of oligosaccharides released following digestion of band C CFTR with glycosidases The structure of the oligosaccharides released by N-glycanase or endo-ss-galactosidase digestion of band C CFTR isolated from CHO cells was assessed with a relatively simple and rapid method called FACE (fluorophore-assisted carbohydrate electrophoresis; Friedman and Higgins, 1994).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	83	 In FACE, 8-aminonaphthalene-1,3,6-trisulfonic acid (ANTS) is covalently linked with high efficiency by reductive amination to the reducing end of oligosaccharides (Jackson, 1990).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The resulting ANTS-oligosaccharide conjugates have fluorescence emission properties, such that conjugates that have been electrophoretically resolved on high-density polyacrylamide gels are detectable at very low (picomole) levels.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	85	 In the case of neutral oligosaccharides, ANTS labeling also confers charge on the labeled conjugate.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Figure 5 shows fluorescent band patterns of ANTS-labeled oligosaccharides released from band C-CFTR following digestion with either N-glycanase (Figure 5A) or endo-ss-galactosidase (Figure 5B).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	87	 The oligosaccharides released from CFTR after treatment with N-glycanase alone co-migrated between the trisialo triantennary and asialo tetraantennary oligosaccharide standards.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	88	 The N-glycanase to released oligosaccharides from neuraminidase-treated band C CFTR had slower mobility and migrated between the asialo biantennary and asialo tetraantennary oligosaccharide standards (data not shown).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	89	 This slower mobility was due to removal of sialic acid by neuraminidase, which affects the charge on the released oligosaccharides.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	90	 This data suggests that the oligosaccharide structures present on mature CFTR are no larger than that of the tetra antennary type.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	91	 To further analyze the nature of these oligosaccharide chains, FACE analysis was also performed on oligosaccharides released by endo-ss-galactosidase treatment of band C CFTR.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	92	 As predicted, the molecular size of the oligosaccharides released by endo-ss-galactosidase digestion were of very low molecular weight (Figure 5B), which is consistent with release of sialylated lactosamines (Figure 5B).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	93	View larger version (33K):    Fig.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	94	 FACE analysis of oligosaccharides released from band C CHO-CFTR.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Immunoaffinity-purified band C-CFTR from CHO cells was separated on a (4 to 20%) gradient polyacrylamide gel, transferred onto Immobilon and then stained using Amido black.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	96	 The CFTR protein bands were then excised from the Immobilon and treated with either N-glycanase (A) or endo-ss-galactosidase (B).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	97	 The oligosaccharides released were labeled using ANTS and analyzed on a high density polyacrylamide gel.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Lanes: 1, standards; 2, control (enzyme alone); and 3, oligosaccharides released after glycosidase digestion.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Structural representations of oligosaccharide standards   Glycosylation pattern of CFTR produced in insect Sf9 cells It has been shown that insect glycoproteins, like those in other cell systems, are first synthesized and attached to a high-mannose oligosaccharide, [Asn]-GlcNAc2-Man9-Glc3 (Hsieh and Robbins, 1984).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	100	 These oligosaccharide structures are sensitive to endoglycosidase-H, which removes sugars from the high-mannose glycoprotein, leaving one molecule of N-acetylglucosamine attached to asparagine.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Analyses of N-glycans isolated from endogenous or recombinant glycoproteins expressed in insect cells revealed that this innermost N-acetylglucosamine can be subject to fucosylation (Jarvis and Summers, 1989; Kuroda et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	102	 In the case of N-linked glycans, further processing can lead to the formation of proteins with a trimannosyl core ([Asn]-GlcNAc2-Man3).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	103	 There are conflicting reports as to whether insect cells have the necessary enzymes for the processing of high-mannose carbohydrates into complex type oligosaccharides.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	104	 In the case of CFTR, for example, expression in insect Sf9 cells results in the expression of the endoglycosidase-H sensitive band B only (data not shown).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	105	 To characterize this glycosylation further we analyzed the oligosaccharides released by both endoglycosidase-H and N-glycanase digestion of Sf9-CFTR using FACE.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Figure 6 (lane 2) shows the pattern of ANTS labeled oligosaccharides released upon digestion of Sf9-CFTR with endoglycosidase-H.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	107	 The oligosaccharides released co-migrated with the oligomannose standards (Figure 6, Table IB), confirming that Sf9-CFTR contained endoglycosidase-H sensitive oligomannose glycosylation.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Oligosaccharides released by Endo-H will migrate faster than the indicated standards, since Endo-H leaves the GlcNAc residue attached to the asparagine of the glycoprotein.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Interestingly, when insect CFTR was digested with N-glycanase, which releases both complex and high-mannose oligosaccharide structures, the main oligosaccharide released had an electrophoretic mobility slightly slower than Man3 consistent with the presence of fucosylated Man3 (Figure 6, lane 1).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	110	 This structure is most likely fucosylated in 1 to 6 linkage, since 1 to 3 fucosylation inhibits N-glycanase (Tretter et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Endo-H cannot release either 1 to 3 or 1 to 6 fucosylated structures (Trimble and Maley, 1984), which explains why several bands are visible in the Endo-H lane while one band predominates in the N-glycanase lane.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	112	 This pattern of glycosylation is very similar to what was reported by Kuroda et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	113	 (1990), for influenza virus hemagglutinin expressed in insect cells.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	114	 This result is also consistent with the fact that fucosylation of insect oligosaccharides occurs on the innermost N-acetylglucosamine, which is only released with N-glycanase treatment, but remains attached to the peptide with endoglycosidase-H digestion.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	115	View larger version (49K):    Fig.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	116	 FACE analysis of oligosaccharides released from Sf9-CFTR.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Oligosaccharides released by either endoglycosidase-H or N-glycanase digestion of Sf9-CFTR were ANTS labeled and analyzed by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Lane 1 contains ANTS-labeled oligosaccharides released by N-glycanase digestion of Sf9-CFTR; lane 2, ANTS labeled oligosaccharides released by endoglycosidase-H digestion of Sf9-CFTR; lane 3, glucose polymer standards.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Migration of oligosaccharide standards of Man3 to Man9 and Man3F is also indicated.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	120	  Comparison of recombinant and nonrecombinant forms of CFTR It would therefore appear that there are distinct differences in the pattern of glycosylation of CFTR, depending on the cell system used to express the protein.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Mature CFTR from CHO cells, for example, showed unusual polylactosamine structures, in contrast to the oligomannose glycosylation observed on Sf9-CFTR.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	122	 To examine whether the presence of polylactosamine glycosylation is a feature only of recombinant CFTR expressed in CHO cells, but does not truly represent the type of glycosylation that occurs on endogenous CFTR, non-recombinant CFTR expressed in T84 cells was characterized.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	123	 To address this issue, CFTR from T84, CHO and Sf9 cells was digested with N-glycanase (Figure 7).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Digestion of band C-CFTR isolated from T84 cells with N-glycanase generated a protein with an apparent molecular weight of 127 kDa (band A).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Thus, mature CFTR expressed in T84 cells and digested with N-glycanase comigrated with the product of N-glycanase digestion of mature CFTR from CHO cells (Figure 7).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	126	 The large reduction in molecular weight after N-glycanase digestion of T84-CFTR suggests that T84-CFTR also likely contained polylactosamine glycosylation.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Furthermore, T84-CFTR showed the same molecular weight shift as did CHO-CFTR upon digestion with endo-ss-galactosidase (Figure 8).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	128	 This suggests that the type of glycosylation observed on recombinant CHO-CFTR was probably representative of the type of glycosylation that occurs on nonrecombinant forms of CFTR.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	129	View larger version (70K):    Fig.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Comparison of CFTR expressed in Sf9, CHO, and T84 cells.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Cell lysates were prepared from CHO, T84 and Sf9 cells and then immunoprecipitated with MAb 24 to 1 (anti-CFTR carboxy terminus antibody).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Immunoprecipitates of CFTR were digested with the glycosidases N-glycanase or endo-ss-galactosidase and then phosphorylated using [-32P]-ATP and the catalytic subunit of protein kinase A.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	133	 The labeled, digested immunoprecipitates of CFTR were then subsequently analyzed on a 6% SDS to polyacrylamide gel.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	134	  View larger version (45K):    Fig.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Endo-ss-galactosidase digestion of CFTR from T84 and CHO cells.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Band C-CFTR from CHO or T84 cells were immunoprecipitated with MAb 24 to 1 (anti-CFTR carboxy terminus antibody), digested with endo-ss-galactosidase and phosphorylated using [-32P]-ATP and the catalytic subunit of protein kinase A.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	137	 The labeled, digested immunoprecipitates of CFTR were then resolved on a 6% SDS to polyacrylamide gel.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	138	     Discussion Top Abstract Introduction Results Discussion Material and methods Acknowledgments Abbreviations References   We have shown that the mature band C form of CFTR expressed in CHO cells has a unique pattern of glycosylation consisting of complex structures of N-acetyllactosamine repeating units.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	139	 This was evidenced by its sensitivity to digestion by N-glycanase and endo-ss-galactosidase, by its binding characteristics to DSA lectin, and its electrophorectic mobility using FACE.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	140	 The occurrence of such glycoforms is not necessarily a result of expression of CFTR in a recombinant cell per se, since endogenous CFTR from T84 cells was shown to have similar characteristics.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	141	 These polylactosaminoglycans (PL) are heterogeneous oligosaccharides and are distinct from the more common complex type asparagine-linked oligosaccharides by having side chains of Galss1 to 4GlcNAcss1 to 3 repeats which are susceptible to endo-ss-galactosidase (Scudder et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	142	The importance of these PL sequences on the mature, fully processed CFTR is as yet unclear.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	143	 The anion exchanger Band 3, a major glycoprotein of erythrocytes, reportedly also contains similar PL structures (Fukuda, 1985; Feizi, 1985).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	144	 It was speculated (Beppu, 1992) that IgG autoantibody against Band 3 of the human erythrocyte membrane (anti-Band 3) plays a role in removing senescent or damaged erythrocytes from circulation by recognizing the sialylated poly-N-lactosaminyl sugar chains.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Other suggested functions for poly-N-lactosaminyl structures on Band 3 include shielding potential antigenic sites on external loops and protection of the protein from proteolytic degradation (Casey, 1992).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Likewise, it could be that the presence of poly-N-lactosamine structures on CFTR may help reduce the antigenicity of the protein or maintain the channel in an active form in the membrane by improving its stability or preventing it from being degraded by proteases.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	147	The role of the oligosaccharide chain in the activity of transport proteins has not been extensively studied.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	148	 However, PL-associated structures have been reported to influence the processing, proper trafficking, and targeting of some plasma membrane proteins to their sites of action (Wang et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Interestingly, the effect of lowering the temperature on two important enzymes responsible for the synthesis of PL sequences, namely ss1 to 3-N-acetylglucosaminyltransferase and ss1 to 4-galactosyltransferase, has been documented.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	150	 It has been shown that LAMPS (lysosomal associated membrane glycoproteins) expressed in HL-60 cells at lower temperatures (21 degrees C) are processed further to acquire more poly-N-acetyllactosamines than LAMPS produced at 37 degrees C (Wang et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	151	 This was attributed to a longer association of LAMPS with Golgi compartments where the ss(1 to 3)-N-acetylglucosaminyltransferase and ss(1 to 4)-galactosyltransferase enzymes are normally resident.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Perhaps the observation that lowering the temperature of incubation of F508-CFTR expressing cells facilitates processing of the mutant protein to band C (Denning et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	153	, 1992) may be due, in part, to a longer association of the variant protein with the Golgi complex, thereby allowing it to acquire the extended PL structures.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	154	Baculovirus expression of CFTR in the Sf9 insect cell system resulted in the expression predominantly of a protein band that comigrated with that for band B CFTR.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	155	 The expression of a band B-like CFTR in the Sf9 cells is consistent with earlier reports indicating that only oligomannose structures are contained on recombinant proteins expressed in this insect cell line (Wojchowski et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	156	, 1987; Greenfield, 1988; Luckow and Summers, 1988) and that little further processing of the original high-mannose oligosaccharide core occurs in these cells.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Using FACE, we showed that Sf9-CFTR was further modified by fucosylation at the innermost N-acetylglucosamine residue.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	158	 This confirms the presence of a fucosyltransferase gene in insect cells as first reported by Davidson and Castellino (1991), who demonstrated the presence of fucose on recombinant human plasminogen (r-HPg) expressed in Sf21 insect cells.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	159	 These investigators were also the first to demonstrate that the addition of complex carbohydrate structures to proteins expressed in insect cells could occur, but was specifically dependent on the infective process employed.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	160	 In this present study CFTR expressed in the Sf9 insect cell system had only oligomannose structures; however, it may be possible to manipulate the nature of CFTR glycosylation in these cells by altering the infective process, thus generating fully processed CFTR that is more representative of endogenously expressed CFTR or CFTR expressed in recombinant mammalian cells.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	161	Presently, it is unclear whether these different glycoforms of CFTR exhibit different activities.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Some studies have suggested that the carbohydrate moiety is dispensable for CFTR Cl to  channel activity (Morris, 1993).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	163	 A mutant CFTR that was altered such that it was now unable to undergo N-glycosylation was shown to retain cAMP-stimulated Cl to  channel activity (Gregory et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Similarly, Sf9-CFTR that lacks complex oligosaccharide structures also exhibited functional CFTR channel activity (Bear et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	165	 However, other studies have suggested that the state of glycosylation of CFTR may affect its stability at the plasma membrane (Luckas et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Clearly, the effect of carbohydrate addition on the structure and function of CFTR requires further investigation.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	167	 This in turn may have implications for development of relevant therapies for treatment of CF patients harboring the most common form of the disease.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	168	   Material and methods Top Abstract Introduction Results Discussion Material and methods Acknowledgments Abbreviations References   Materials FACE reagents and equipment were supplied by Glyko (Novato, CA); N-glycanase, endo-ss-galactosidase, neuraminidase, and the Lectin-Link Kit were supplied by Genzyme (Cambridge, MA); DIG Glycan Differentiation Kit was supplied by Boehringer-Mannheim; Wheat germ agglutinin Sepharose was supplied by Sigma (St.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	169	Cell cultures The human colon carcinoma cell line T84 was obtained from the American Type Culture Collection (ATCC CCl 248).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Established C127 (mouse mammary epitheloid cells) and CHO (Chinese hamster ovary) cells stably transfected with the human CFTR cDNA were generated and maintained as described previously (Marshall et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	171	 The growth and infection of Sf9 cells with recombinant CFTR-expressing viruses have also been described previously (O'Riordan et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	172	Purification of recombinant CFTR from CHO cells for carbohydrate analysis CHO-CFTR was immunoaffinity purified using the monoclonal antibody MAb 13 to 1 cross-linked to a hydrazide resin, essentially as described by O'Riordan et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Briefly, CFTR was solubilized out of the membranes using 1.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	174	5% -lyso PC and the solubilized material then incubated with the resin overnight at 4 degrees C.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Following extensive washing with wash buffer (150 mM NaCl, 50 mM Tris to HCl, pH 8.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	176	0, 1 mM EDTA and 1% sodium cholate) to remove nonspecifically bound proteins, CFTR was eluted from the resin using 150 mM NaOH, 10% glycerol, 1 mM EDTA, pH 11.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	177	5% sodium cholate (neutralized with 0.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	178	Treatment with endo-ss-galactosidase and N-glycanase Approximately 100 g of immunoaffinity purified CFTR in neutralized elution buffer (150 mM NaOH, 10% glycerol, 1 mM EDTA, pH 11.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	179	5% sodium cholate buffer and neutralized with 0.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	180	01 units of endo-ss-galactosidase enzyme for 6 h at room temperature.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Reaction was stopped by the addition of SDS to PAGE sample buffer followed by electrophoresis on a 4 to 20% gradient gel.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Alternatively, for samples which were analyzed by FACE, the reaction was stopped by evaporating samples to dryness using a speed vacuum.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	183	 For N-glycanase digestion, CFTR was first denatured by adding sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS) to 0.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	184	1% and ss-mercaptoethanol to 50 mM and incubating at 37 degrees C for 5 min.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	185	8% and the reaction initiated by adding 40 units of N-glycanase (Genzyme) and incubating for 2 h at 37 degrees C.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	186	 All reactions were done in neutralized elution buffer as described above.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Reactions were stopped by evaporation to dryness using a speed vacuum.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	188	Fluorophore-assisted carbohydrate electrophoresis (FACE) FACE analysis was applied as previously described (Friedman and Higgins, 1994).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	189	 The carbohydrate moiety of CHO-CFTR was prepared for FACE analysis by first running 100 to 200  microg of immunoaffinity purified material on a 4 to 20% SDS-PAGE gel followed by transfer to a PVDF membrane in 10 mM CAPS, 10% methanol, pH 11.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	190	 The conditions for electrophoresis are described in O'Riordan et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	191	1% amido black in 20% ethanol and the background was destained in 20% ethanol.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	192	 After destaining, the membrane was kept in 50 mM NaHPO4, pH 7.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	193	 The CFTR band was excised and cut into small pieces being careful not to let the membrane dry out.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	194	 The pieces were placed in a microfuge tube and covered with approximately 100 to 200  microl of 50 mM NaHPO4, pH 7.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Carbohydrates were then removed from CFTR using N-glycanase as described above.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	196	 In some instances, CFTR was digested with neuraminidase prior to N-glycanase digestion.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Briefly, membranes were rinsed with 50 mM NaHPO4, pH 5.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	198	5 then covered with 200  microl of 50 mM NaHPO4, pH 5.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	199	1 units) of neuraminidase were added, and the reaction allowed to proceed overnight at room temperature.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Fluorescence labeling of the carbohydrate residues was carried out for 18 h using reagents and protocol supplied by Glyko (Novato, CA).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Electrophoresis reagents and equipment were also supplied by Glyko.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	202	Lectin blots and SDS to PAGE analysis Immunoaffinity purified CFTR was electrophoresed under standard conditions and then transferred to nitrocellulose paper as described before (O'Riordan et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Both the DIG Glycan Differentiation Kit (Boehringer-Mannheim) and the Lectin-Link Kit (Genzyme Corp.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Lectin blotting was performed according to the manufacturers  directions.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	205	Immunoprecipitation and protein phosphorylation using protein kinase A T84 cell lysates were prepared by treating the cells with lysis buffer (50 mM Tris to HCl, pH 7.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	206	5, 150 mM NaCl, 1% NP-40, 1 mM PMSF, and 5 mM aprotinin).
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	207	 After incubation on ice for 30 min, unlysed cells were removed by centrifugation at 14,000g.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	208	 CFTR was immunoprecipitated with the monoclonal antibody MAb 13 to 1 (Gregory et al.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	209	, 1991) and the immunoprecipitates then incubated with protein kinase A (20 ng) and [-32P]ATP (10 mCi) in a final volume of 50  microl in kinase buffer (50 mM Tris to HCl pH 7.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	210	5, 10 mM MgCl2 and 100 mg/ml bovine serum albumin) at 30 degrees C for 50 min.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Samples were heated for 5 min at 37 degrees C before electrophoresis.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Glycosidase digestion of immunoprecipitates was performed by overnight digestion in the presence of the enzyme in 10 mM sodium phosphate buffer, pH 6.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Digestion was performed prior to the phosphorylation assay.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	214	Wheat germ agglutinin chromatography Wheat germ agglutinin Sepharose was equilibrated with phosphate-buffered saline.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	215	 T84 cell lysates were prepared as described above and applied to the equilibrated wheat germ agglutinin Sepharose.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	216	 The flow-through fraction was collected and the column was washed with PBS before elution with 0.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Both the flow-through fraction and the N-acetylglucosamine eluate were assayed for CFTR by immunoprecipitation with the monoclonal antibody Mab 13 to 1.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	218	 The immunoprecipitates were incubated with protein kinase A and [-32P]ATP (10 mCi) as described above and labeled proteins were analyzed by SDS to PAGE.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	219	   Acknowledgments Top Abstract Introduction Results Discussion Material and methods Acknowledgments Abbreviations References   We thank Drs.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	220	Wadsworth and Helen Romanczuk for critical review of the manuscript.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	221	   Abbreviations Top Abstract Introduction Results Discussion Material and methods Acknowledgments Abbreviations References   ANTS, 8-aminonaphthalene-1,3,6-trisulfonic acid; CAPS, 3-(cyclohexylamino) propane sulfonic acid; CHAPSO, (3-[(3-cholamidopropyl)dimethylammonio]-2-hydroxy-1-propanesulfonate; CHO, Chinese hamster ovary; CFTR, cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator; CF, cystic fibrosis; FACE, fluorophore-assisted carbohydrate electrophoresis; PAGE, polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis; PC, phosphatidylcholine; PMSF, phenylmethylsulfonylfluoride; PL, polylactosaminoglycans; SA, sialic acid.

0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	223	   References Top Abstract Introduction Results Discussion Material and methods Acknowledgments Abbreviations References   Altmann,F.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	224	 (1993) Processing of asparagine-linked oligosaccharides N-acetylglucosaminyltransferase and II activities in cultured lepidopteran cells.

0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	228	 (1989) Protein and carbohydrate structural analysis of a recombinant soluble CD4 receptor by mass spectrometry.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	229	 (1992) Enzymatic deglycosylation of human Band 3, the anion transport protein of the erythrocyte membrane.

0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	231	 (1991) Carbohydrate variant of the recombinant beta-subunit of human choriogonadotrophin expressed in baculovirus expression system.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	232	 (1990) Defective intracellular transport and processing of CFTR is the molecular basis of most cystic fibrosis.
0.4183819.11087715.html.plaintext.txt	233	 (1984) The distribution of repeating [Gal ss 1,4 GlcNAc ss 1, 3] sequences in asparagine-linked oligosaccharides of the mouse lymphoma cell lines BW5147 and PHAR 2.
