0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	0	The  Subunit of the Sec61 Complex Facilitates Cotranslational Protein Transport and Interacts with the Signal Peptidase during Translocation.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	1	* Abteilung Biochemie II, Zentrum Biochemie und Molekulare Zellbiologie, Georg-August-Universitat, 37073 Gottingen, Germany; and  Harvard Medical School, Department of Cell Biology, Boston, Massachusetts 02115.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	2	    Abstract Top Abstract Introduction Materials  and  Methods Results Discussion References.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	3	The Sec61 complex is the central component of the protein translocation apparatus of the ER membrane.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	4	 We have addressed the role of the  subunit (Sec61) during cotranslational protein translocation.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	5	 With a reconstituted system, we show that a Sec61 complex lacking Sec61 is essentially inactive when elongation and membrane targeting of a nascent chain occur at the same time.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	6	 The translocation process is perturbed at a step where the nascent chain would be inserted into the translocation channel.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	7	 However, if sufficient time is given for the interaction of the nascent polypeptide with the mutant Sec61 complex, translocation is almost normal.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Thus Sec61 kinetically facilitates cotranslational translocation, but is not essential for it.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	9	Using chemical cross-linking we show that Sec61 not only interacts with subunits of the Sec61 complex but also with the 25-kD subunit of the signal peptidase complex (SPC25), thus demonstrating for the first time a tight interaction between the SPC and the Sec61 complex.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Interestingly, the cross-links between Sec61 and SPC25 and between Sec61 and Sec61 depend on the presence of membrane-bound ribosomes, suggesting that these interactions are induced when translocation is initiated.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	11	 We propose that the SPC is transiently recruited to the translocation site, thus enhancing its activity.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	12	    Introduction Top Abstract Introduction Materials  and  Methods Results Discussion References.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	13	IN higher eukaryotes, most proteins are transported across the ER membrane in a cotranslational manner.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	14	 The translating ribosome binds tightly to the ER membrane (Connolly et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	15	, 1994), and the growing nascent polypeptide chain is transferred directly from the channel in the ribosome into a channel in the membrane (Blobel and Dobberstein, 1975; Connolly et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	16	, 1989; Simon and Blobel, 1991; Gorlich et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	17	, 1992b; Gorlich and Rapoport, 1993).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	18	The cotranslational translocation pathway in mammals can be reproduced with reconstituted proteoliposomes containing only three membrane protein components: the SRP receptor complex, the translocating chain-associating membrane (TRAM)1 protein, and the Sec61 complex (Gorlich and Rapoport, 1993).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The signal recognition particle (SRP) receptor is required to target a ribosome- nascent chain complex to the ER membrane.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	20	 The function of the TRAM protein is still unclear; it is only required for the translocation of a subset of proteins (Gorlich et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	21	 The Sec61 complex represents the essential core of the translocation machinery in the ER membrane.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	22	 It consists of three subunits, an  subunit (Sec61) that spans the membrane 10 times, and  and  subunits (Sec61 and Sec61, respectively) that each span the membrane a single time.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	23	The Sec61 complex is evolutionarily highly conserved and is proposed to carry out at least three different functions.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	24	 First, it is the major constituent of the protein conducting membrane channel.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Cross-linking experiments have shown that its  subunit is in continuous proximity of nascent polypeptide chains passing through the membrane (Mothes et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Recent electron microscopic data demonstrate that the Sec61 complex can form cylindrical oligomers that presumably represent the channels (Hanein et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Second, the Sec61 complex is tightly associated with membrane-bound ribosomes and is likely to be the ribosome receptor (Gorlich et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	28	, 1994; Jungnickel and Rapoport, 1995).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Third, the Sec61 complex is involved in a signal sequence recognition event that takes place inside the membrane (Jungnickel and Rapoport, 1995).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	30	The role of the Sec61 complex subunits for its different functions is not yet clear.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Whereas the presence of a multi-spanning  subunit in a channel-forming protein complex may not be surprising, the role of the two small single-spanning polypeptide chains remains mysterious.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	32	 A particular enigma is the  subunit.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	33	 In Saccharomyces cerevisiae, the simultaneous deletion of the  subunits of the two homologous Sec61 complexes (Sec61p and the Ssh1p complex) is not lethal; the cells only show a growth defect at elevated temperatures (Finke et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Thus, despite the fact that the protein is evolutionarily highly conserved, it does not appear to be absolutely required in vivo.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Posttranslational protein transport across yeast ER membranes in vitro is reduced, but not completely prevented, when the  subunits are lacking.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	36	 At which point the transport process is inhibited, and whether the  subunits play any role in the cotranslational mode of protein transport has not yet been investigated.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	37	The function of the  subunit of the Sec61 complex may not necessarily be restricted to the actual translocation process.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	38	 The transport of proteins across the ER membrane must be intimately coupled to their modification and folding, and it seems possible that the  subunit could be involved in interactions between the translocation channel and modifying enzymes or chaperones.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	39	 A physical association of these proteins with the channel may enhance the efficiency of their function.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	40	 A good example is the signal peptidase, an abundant enzyme whose active site is in the lumen of the ER.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Although it can cleave the signal peptide of even completed polypeptide chains, its efficiency is probably much higher when it can act on polypeptide chains that are just emerging from the translocation channel into the lumen of the ER.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	42	 One may therefore predict its physical association with channel constituents.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	43	 The signal peptidase complex is composed of five membrane protein subunits (Evans et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	44	, 1986), two with an active site for enzymatic activity, one with a lumenal domain of unknown function, and two (12 and 25 kD) with cytosolic domains.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	45	 The function of the latter is particularly unclear because they cannot contribute to the enzymatic activity on the lumenal side of the membrane, and are not essential for the viability of yeast cells (Lively and Walsh, 1983; Fang et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	46	, 1996; Kalies and Hartmann, 1996; Mullins et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	47	 They would be especially good candidates to serve as linkers to the translocation channel.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	48	In the present paper, we have analyzed the role of the  subunit of the Sec61 complex in the cotranslational translocation pathway in mammals.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Using a reconstituted system, we demonstrate that the  subunit kinetically facilitates, but is not essential for, cotranslational translocation.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	50	 The protein does not play a role in the interaction of the ribosome with the Sec61 complex, but rather in the insertion of the nascent chain into the translocation site.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Using a bifunctional cross-linker, we also provide evidence that it interacts specifically with the 25-kD subunit of the signal peptidase complex (SPC25), thus demonstrating for the first time a tight interactions between the SPC and the Sec61 complex.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Cross-linking is only observed in the presence of membrane-bound ribosomes.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	53	 These data thus suggest that, upon ribosome binding to the Sec61 complex, an interaction between the cytosolic domains of the Sec61 and SPC25 serves to recruit the signal peptidase complex to the translocation site.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Together with the observation that cross-linking between the  and  subunits of the Sec61 complex is also dependent on translocation, these data provide first evidence for structural changes in the translocation apparatus upon initiation of cotranslational translocation.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	55	    Materials and Methods Top Abstract Introduction Materials  and  Methods Results Discussion References Preparation of Reconstituted Proteoliposomes.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	56	Microsomes treated with puromycin and high salt (PK-RM) (Gorlich and Rapoport, 1993) were solubilized at a concentration of 2 eq/ microl in SB (50 mM Hepes/KOH, pH 7.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	57	6, 15% glycerin, 400 mM potassium acetate, 10 mM magnesium acetate, and 10  microg/ml leupeptin, 2  microg/ml pepstatin, and 5  microg/ml chymostatin as protease inhibitors) containing 1.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	58	5% decylsucrose for 30 min on ice.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	59	 After centrifugation for 10 min at 14,000 rpm in a microfuge, 0.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	60	7% deoxyBigChap was added to the supernatant.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	61	 500  microl detergent extract was mixed with 100  microl of an immunoaffinity resin that contained 0.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	62	2 mg/ml affinity-purified antibodies directed against the NH2 terminus of Sec61, covalently coupled to protein A-Sepharose (Gorlich and Rapoport, 1993).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The column was previously equilibrated with SB containing 1.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	64	 The incubation was done for 18 h in an overhead shaker in a cold room.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Every 6 h the resin was replaced with a new one.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	66	 The non-bound material was collected and proteoliposomes were produced by incubation with SM2-biobeads at 4 degrees C (Bio Rad Laboratories, Hercules, CA) (Gorlich and Rapoport, 1993).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Proteoliposomes containing the purified Sec61 complex were prepared as described previously (Kalies et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	68	The signal peptidase complex (SPC) was purified as reported (Gorlich and Rapoport, 1993).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Proteoliposomes were produced by mixing 20  microl of the SPC preparation (200 eq) with 20  microl of a phospholipid mixture (phosphatidylcholine, phosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylserine, and phosphatidylinositol in a ratio of 100:25:3:12.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	70	5; total concentration 5 mg/ml).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	71	 40  microg SM2 biobeads equilibrated in SB were added and vesicles were prepared as described (Gorlich and Rapoport, 1993).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	72	Binding of Ribosomes to Proteoliposomes.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	73	The purification, radioactive labeling, and binding of ribosomes to reconstituted proteoliposomes were done as described (Kalies et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	74	 The ribosome binding was carried out at 26 degrees C.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	75	Cross-linking with Bis-maleimidohexane.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	76	A 25 mM stock solution of bis-maleimidohexane (BMH) in dimethylformamid was prepared.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Microsomes or proteoliposomes were incubated with increasing amounts of BMH for 30 min at 0 degrees C in a cross-link buffer containing 50 mM Hepes/KOH, pH 7.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	78	6, 100 mM KCl, 5 mM MgCl2, 250 mM sucrose, and protease inhibitors.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	79	 The reaction was quenched by addition of 100 mM -mercaptoethanol and the samples were analyzed by SDS-PAGE and immunoblotting, using various antibodies.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	80	Transcription, Translation, and Translocation.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	81	Transcripts coding for preprolactin were produced by in vitro transcription with T7 RNA polymerase of the plasmid pGEMBP1.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	82	 For full-length transcripts, the plasmid was cut with PstI and in the case of the transcripts coding for the 86-mer with PvuII.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	83	Translation of the full-length protein was carried out in the wheat germ system in the presence of 40 nM SRP, [35S]methionine, and membranes at 26 degrees C for 30 min.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	84	 After 15 min, 4  microM edeine was added to prevent further initiation.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	85	 In a parallel experiment translation was started in the absence of membranes for 15 min at 26 degrees C.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	86	 4  microM edeine and membranes were then added.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	87	 The samples were incubated on ice for 10 min followed by an incubation at 26 degrees C for additional 15 min.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Half of the sample was precipitated with 15% TCA.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	89	 The other half was treated with 0.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	90	5 mg/ml proteinase K for 30 min on ice, before precipitation with TCA.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	91	 The pellets were washed with acetone and dissolved in SDS sample buffer.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	92	 After SDS-PAGE, the gels were dried and analyzed in a quantitative manner with a PhosphorImager (Bas 1000; Fuji, Tokyo, Japan).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	93	Translation of the 86-mer of preprolactin was done in the reticulocyte lysate system in the presence of [35S]methionine at 24 degrees C for 20 min.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	94	 For the mock translation, the mRNA was omitted.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	95	 2 mM cycloheximide and 5 eq membranes were added to 300  microl translation mix and the incubation was continued at 0 degrees C for 10 min and at 25 degrees C for 5 min.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	96	 After centrifugation in a microfuge at 14,000 rpm for 5 min the samples were layered on top of a sucrose cushion (400  microl of 50 mM Hepes/KOH, pH 7.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	97	6, 100 mM KCl, 5 mM MgCl2, and 500 mM sucrose) and were centrifuged at 75,000 rpm for 20 min (rotor TLA 100.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Finally the pellets were resuspended in 65  microl cross-link buffer.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	99	Immunoblotting, Immunoprecipitation, and Antibodies.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	100	Immunoblotting was carried out as described (Gorlich et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Before immunoprecipitation, the samples were denatured in SDS sample buffer omitting reducing reagents.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	102	 The samples were then mixed with 10 vol of SB containing 1% Triton X-100, and incubated for 20 min on ice.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Affinity-purified antibodies against Sec61 coupled to protein A-Sepharose were added.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	104	 After shaking in a cold room for 3 h, the antibody resin was washed with 1% Triton X-100 in SB.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Finally, the material bound to the column was analyzed by SDS-PAGE and Western blotting.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	106	Polyclonal antibodies directed against the following synthetic peptides were used: against the NH2 terminus of Sec61 (Gorlich et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	107	, 1992b); against the COOH terminus of Sec61 (Gorlich and Rapoport, 1993); against the position 137 to 150 of the SRP-receptor  (docking protein ); against the COOH terminus of the TRAM protein (Gorlich et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	108	, 1992a); against the NH2 terminus of Sec61 (DQVMQFVEPSRQC); and against the COOH terminus of SPC25 (Kalies and Hartmann, 1996).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	109	    Results Top Abstract Introduction Materials  and  Methods Results Discussion References Sec61 Facilitates Cotranslational Protein Translocation.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	110	We used reconstituted proteoliposomes, immunodepleted of the  subunit of the Sec61 complex, to investigate the role of the protein in cotranslational protein translocation.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Mammalian PK-RM, were solubilized in a detergent mixture that leads to the dissociation of the Sec61 complex into its subunits.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	112	 The detergent extract was incubated either with antibodies directed against Sec61 that had been immobilized on protein A-Sepharose or, to generate a mock-depleted extract, with protein A-Sepharose alone.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	113	 The efficiency of immunodepletion was tested by Western blotting, using a radioactively labeled secondary antibody and a PhosphorImager.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	114	 In a typical experiment, the depleted proteoliposomes contained  < 0.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	115	5% of the original amount of Sec61, whereas all other proteins tested remained almost unaffected (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	116	 The only exception was Sec61, the concentration of which was reduced to 50- 70% in the worst case.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Apparently, under the conditions used, the  and the  subunits are not totally dissociated.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	118	View larger version (38K):    Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	119	   Sec61 facilitates cotranslational protein translocation.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	120	 (A) To produce proteoliposomes lacking Sec61 ribosome-free membranes (PK-RM) were solubilized under conditions where the Sec61 complex dissociates into its subunits.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	121	 The detergent extract was immunodepleted with an antibody column directed against Sec61 or was incubated with protein A-Sepharose to generate a mock-depleted extract.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	122	 After reconstitution the proteoliposomes and PK-RM were analyzed by SDS-PAGE and Western blotting using a radioactively labeled secondary antibody and a PhosphorImager system for quantitation.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	123	 (B) The membranes and proteoliposomes analyzed in A were tested for their competence to translocate polypeptides.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Preprolactin mRNA was translated in the wheat germ system in the presence of SRP and microsomes or proteoliposomes, respectively, at 26 degrees C (lanes 2-8).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	125	 In a parallel experiment translation was started in the absence of microsomes.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	126	 After addition of membranes or proteoliposomes, respectively, the targeting reaction was carried out at 0 degrees C followed by an elongation at 26 degrees C (lanes 10-16).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Half of the sample was treated with proteinase K to assay for material that is translocated into the vesicles and is therefore protected against the added protease.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	128	 DP,  subunit of the SRP receptor; pPL, preprolactin; PL, prolactin.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	129	We then tested the reconstituted proteoliposomes for their ability to translocate proteins synthesized in a wheat germ translation system.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Microsomes (PK-RM) served as a control.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Transcripts coding for full-length preprolactin were translated at 26 degrees C in the presence of microsomes or proteoliposomes, the concentration of which was normalized for their Sec61 content (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	132	 PK-RM and mock-depleted proteoliposomes had the same translocation activity (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	133	 1 B, lanes 6 and 7), whereas the depleted proteoliposomes were totally inactive (lane 8).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	134	 In the absence of Sec61, processed prolactin was produced (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	135	 1 B, lane 4) that, however, was accessible to the action of proteinase K; it therefore presumably represents material generated by signal peptidase that was incorporated into the reconstituted membrane in the inverse orientation.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	136	Since Sec61 is not essential in yeast, we wondered if the mammalian Sec61 complex lacking this component may show in vitro translocation activity under less stringent conditions than used before.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	137	 We therefore performed the translocation reaction such that more time would be allowed for the membrane binding of the ribosome- nascent chain complex.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Translation of the full-length transcript coding for preprolactin was initially carried out in the presence of SRP but absence of membranes.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	139	 This leads to a translational arrest when the polypeptide chain reaches a length of ~70 residues.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	140	 The membranes were then added at 0 degrees C, conditions that allow efficient membrane binding of the ribosome-nascent chain complexes but no chain elongation.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	141	 The samples were then warmed up to 26 degrees C to continue translation and concomitant translocation.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	142	 With this protocol, proteoliposomes lacking Sec61 were active in translocation, although their activity was lower by a factor of three compared with the wild-type complex (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Thus, the depleted proteoliposomes are capable to translocate polypeptides if given enough time in the membrane targeting reaction.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	144	 The results also indicate that the Sec61 complex lacking its  subunit has not been irreversibly denatured during the prolonged immunodepletion procedure.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	145	 These data suggest that the ribosome-nascent chain complex was targeted to the membrane and thus brought in contact with the signal peptidase, but that a subsequent translocation step was perturbed.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	146	 We also found that a fragment of preprolactin of 86 amino acids could be efficiently targeted to reconstituted proteoliposomes and reached a protease-protected state even if Sec61 was lacking (data not shown), supporting the conclusion that insertion of the nascent chain into the Sec61-depleted translocation site can occur if no chain elongation is going on.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	147	It should be noted that in the absence of membranes, almost no full-length preprolactin could be observed (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	148	 1 B, lanes 1 and 9), indicating that under the conditions used, SRP produced a tight translational arrest.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Both the microsomes and the two types of proteoliposomes were able to release the translational arrest (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	150	 1 B, lanes 2-4 and 10-12), indicating that this reaction is not dependent on the presence of Sec61.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	151	Sec61 Is Not Required for Ribosome Binding.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	152	Our data suggested that in the absence of Sec61, the binding of the ribosome-nascent chain complex to the ER membrane is less efficient.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	153	 This could be due to either a defect in the interaction of the mutated Sec61 complex with the ribosome, or to a perturbed insertion of the nascent chain into the translocation site.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	154	 We therefore analyzed whether the  subunit plays a role in ribosome binding.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Depleted and mock-depleted proteoliposomes were incubated at physiological salt concentrations with radioactively labeled ribosomes and increasing amounts of unlabeled ribosomes, both lacking nascent polypeptide chains.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Under these conditions, the ribosomes interact mainly with the Sec61 complex (Kalies et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	157	 To separate the unbound from the bound fraction, the membranes were floated in a sucrose gradient.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Scatchard plot analysis was used to estimate the number of binding sites and the apparent dissociation constants (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Both the depleted and mock-depleted proteoliposomes were found to bind ribosomes with approximately the same binding constant.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Also, the number of binding sites was about the same.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	161	 The measured parameters are in good agreement with published data for the binding of ribosomes to PK-RM and proteoliposomes (Kalies et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	162	, 1994), although the dissociation constants seem to be somewhat higher at 26 degrees  than at 0 degrees C.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Thus, steps other than the interaction between SRP and its membrane receptor or the binding of ribosomes to the Sec61 complex must be responsible for the less efficient insertion of the nascent polypeptide chains into proteoliposomes lacking Sec61.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	164	View larger version (20K):    Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	165	   Binding of ribosomes to reconstituted proteoliposomes.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Sec61- and mock-depleted proteoliposomes were incubated with radioactively labeled ribosomes and increasing amounts of unlabeled ribosomes at physiological salt concentrations and 26 degrees C.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	167	 To separate the bound from the unbound fraction the samples were submitted to flotation in a sucrose gradient.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	168	 The number of binding sites and the apparent dissociation constants were estimated by Scatchard plot analysis.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Kd, dissociation constant; eq, membrane equivalant (Walter and Blobel, 1983).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	170	Sec61 Interacts with the 25-kD Subunit of the Signal Peptidase Complex.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	171	To further analyze the function of Sec61, we investigated its molecular environment in the membrane by chemical cross-linking.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Rough microsomes (RM) were treated with increasing amounts of BMH, a bifunctional cross-linking reagent that reacts with sulfhydryl (SH) groups.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	173	 The proteins were subsequently separated by SDS-PAGE and analyzed by immunoblotting with antibodies against Sec61 (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Three cross-linked products were detected with the antibodies (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	175	 The apparent molecular weights of the cross-linked proteins were estimated to be 12, 23, and 38 kD, assuming an apparent molecular weight for Sec61 of 13 kD.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	176	View larger version (36K):    Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	177	   Analysis of the environment of Sec61 by chemical cross-linking.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	178	 RM were treated with increasing amounts of bis-maleimidohexane (BMH) and were subsequently analyzed by SDS-PAGE and immunoblotting using antibodies directed against the  subunit of the Sec61 complex (lanes 1-6).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	179	 To identify the cross-linked polypeptides, RM were treated with BMH as indicated.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	180	 The samples were subsequently immunoprecipitated under denaturing conditions with an anti-Sec61 column.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	181	 The precipitated material was analyzed by Western blotting using antibodies directed against Sec61 (lanes 7-10), Sec61 (lanes 11-14) or the 25-kD subunit of the signal peptidase complex (SPC25) (lanes 15-18), respectively.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Lanes 1, 7, 11, and 15 show the results for untreated RM.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	183	To identify the cross-linked proteins, microsomes were treated with two different concentrations of BMH and dissolved in SDS-containing buffer to dissociate noncovalent chemical bonds.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	184	 The extract was subjected to immunoprecipitation with Sec61 antibodies and the precipitated material was analyzed by Western blotting using different antibodies.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	185	 3 shows the immunoblots with antibodies directed against Sec61 (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	186	 3, lanes 11-14) and SPC25 (lanes 15-18).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	187	 The product containing the 38-kD protein could be immunoprecipitated with Sec61 antibodies (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	188	 3, lane 10) and was recognized by the Sec61 antibody (lane 14), indicating that it is generated by cross-linking between the  and  subunits of the Sec61 complex.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	189	 The product containing a protein of ~23 kD could be immunoprecipitated with Sec61 antibodies (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	190	 3, lane 9) and reacted with antibodies against SPC25 (lane 17) and is thus generated by cross-linking between these two proteins.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Neither Sec61 nor SPC25 were coprecipitated with Sec61 if BMH was omitted (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	192	 3, lanes 12 and 16), and both antibodies recognized single bands in untreated RM (lanes 11 and 15).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	193	The product containing the protein of ~12 kD did not react with any of the antibodies tested.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Considering its size, we suspected that it may represent a product generated by cross-linking of two  subunits of the Sec61 complex.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	195	 To test this assumption, purified Sec61 complex was reconstituted into proteoliposomes and subjected to cross-linking with BMH.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	196	 When analyzed by SDS-PAGE and immunoblotting with Sec61 antibodies, a cross-linked product containing a 12-kD protein was again observed (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	197	 4 A, lanes 10-12), indicating that the cross-linking partner is indeed a constituent of the Sec61 complex.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	198	 The smaller cross-linked product in Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	199	 4 A, lanes 11 and 12 (marked with an asterisk) is probably generated by cross-linking between Sec61 and Sec61, the smallest subunit of the Sec61 complex.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	200	 The appearance of this cross-linked product in native microsomes was variable among different experiments.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	201	View larger version (50K):    Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	202	   Sec61 is involved in ribosome-dependent structural changes of the translocation site.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Rough microsomes (RM), ribosome-free membranes (PK-RM), proteoliposomes produced from an unfractionated detergent extract of PK-RM (total), and proteoliposomes containing the purified Sec61 complex (Sec61p) or the purified signal peptidase complex (SPC), respectively, were treated with BMH as indicated.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	204	 After SDS-PAGE the samples were analyzed by immunoblotting with antibodies against Sec61 (A) or SPC25 (B).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	205	 The position of a probable cross-link between Sec61 and Sec61 is marked by an asterisk.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	206	Ribosome-dependent Structural Changes of the Translocation Site.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	207	We were concerned that the membrane-bound ribosomes may prevent full access of the bifunctional cross-linker to Sec61 so that only a subset of its interacting partners could be detected.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	208	 However, to our surprise, when PK-RM were used in cross-linking experiments, not only were no additional cross-links observed, but those between Sec61 and Sec61 and between Sec61 and SPC25 could no longer be seen (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Treatment of RM with high salt or puromycin alone did not change these cross-links (data not shown), suggesting that their disappearance requires the dissociation of the ribosomes into subunits.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	210	 In agreement with this assumption, proteoliposomes reconstituted from a crude detergent extract of microsomes or proteoliposomes containing only the purified Sec61 complex, which both lack membrane-bound ribosomes, also did not give these cross-links (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	211	A similar conclusion could be drawn when the cross-linking reaction was analyzed with SPC25 antibodies (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	212	 With RM two cross-linked products were seen, one of ~36 kD between SPC25 and Sec61, and another of ~46 kD (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	213	 With PK-RM or with proteoliposomes reconstituted from a crude detergent extract, the adduct of SPC25 and Sec61 was no longer observed (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	214	 4 B, lanes 4-6 and lanes 7-9, respectively), whereas the 46-kD cross-linked product remained unchanged.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	215	 The latter was also observed with proteoliposomes containing only the purified signal peptidase complex (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Two SPC subunits, the nonglycosylated SPC25 and the glycoprotein SPC22/23 carry SH groups and have an appropriate molecular weight to produce this 46-kD cross-link with SPC25.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	217	 As the molecular weight of the cross-linked product did not change after treatment with N-glycosidase F (data not shown), we conclude that it consists of two SPC25.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	218	To exclude that the high salt treatment during the preparation of PK-RM was responsible for the structural alterations identified, ribosomes were detached from the membrane by an independent method.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	219	 When the reaction with BMH was performed in the presence of 10 mM EDTA under low salt conditions, the cross-link between Sec61 and Sec61 and that between Sec61 and SPC25 could not be seen anymore (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	220	 However, the homotypic cross-link between two Sec61 remained unchanged, indicating that the EDTA did not interfere with the reactivity of the BMH.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	221	 It should be noted that the extent to which the cross-linking intensity was reduced varied in different experiments.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	222	View larger version (60K):    Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	223	   Structural changes of the translocation site in EDTA-treated microsomes.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	224	 RM were incubated with 10 mM EDTA before BMH was added as indicated.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	225	 The samples were analyzed by SDS-PAGE and immunoblotting with anti-Sec61 antibodies.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	226	If the ribosome-dependent alteration of the cross-link pattern has a real physiological significance it should be possible to reproduce the cross-link between Sec61 and Sec61 and that between Sec61 and SPC25 by a retargeting of ribosomes carrying nascent polypeptide chains at ribosome free membranes.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Ribosome-nascent chain complexes were produced by an in vitro translation of truncated mRNA coding for the first 86 amino acids of preprolactin (86-mer).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Ribosome-free membranes (PK-RM) were then added to the translation mix (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	229	 As controls PK-RM and RM were incubated with a translation mix that did not contain any preprolactin mRNA (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	230	 After isolation of the membranes aliquots of each sample were treated with different amounts of BMH.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	231	 The samples were analyzed by Western blotting with Sec61 antibodies using enhanced chemiluminescence as a detection system (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	232	 6 A) or by quantitative immunoblotting using radioactively labeled secondary antibodies and a PhosphorImager (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	233	 6 B) shows that the incubation of PK-RM with ribosome-nascent chain complexes led to a clear restimulation of the cross-link intensity between Sec61 and Sec61 and between Sec61 and SPC25.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Similar results were obtained if EDTA-treated membranes were analyzed (data not shown).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	235	View larger version (47K):    Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	236	   Structural changes of the translocation site are induced by the targeting of ribosomes carrying the preprolactin 86-mer (pPl 86mer).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	237	 (A) Translation was carried out in the reticulocyte lysate system in the presence (lanes 4-6) or absence (lanes 1-3 and 7-9) of mRNA coding for the pPl 86-mer.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	238	 After addition of PK-RM (lanes 1-6) or rough microsomes (lanes 7-9), respectively, the targeting reaction was carried out at 0 degrees C followed by an incubation at 26 degrees C.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	239	 The membranes were collected by a centrifugation through a sucrose cushion, separated into three aliquots and treated with bis-maleimidohexane (BMH) as indicated.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	240	 The samples were analyzed by immunoblotting with antibodies against Sec61 using as a detection system enhanced chemiluminescence (A) or radioactively labeled secondary antibodies (B), respectively.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	241	 The unknown cross-link marked with an asterisk was not observed in other experiments.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	242	 (B) A PhosphorImager system was used for quantitation of the cross-linking intensities.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	243	 The cross-linking intensities obtained for RM were defined as 100%.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	244	Taken together, these data provide evidence that the  subunit of the Sec61 complex is involved in ribosome- dependent conformational changes of the translocation channel and that it specifically interacts with the signal peptidase during cotranslational translocation.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	245	    Discussion Top Abstract Introduction Materials  and  Methods Results Discussion References.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	246	In this paper, we have studied the role of the  subunit of the Sec61 complex during cotranslational protein translocation into the mammalian ER.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	247	 We have found that the translocation competence of reconstituted proteoliposomes immunodepleted of Sec61 is greatly reduced when tested under conditions in which membrane targeting and translation occur at the same time.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	248	 However, if ribosomes carrying short nascent chains are first targeted to the membrane before translation is continued, i.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	249	, if enough time is given for their membrane insertion, the depleted proteoliposomes are only marginally reduced in their activity.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	250	 These results can be explained by the assumption that elongation of a nascent chain and its insertion into the translocation channel are kinetically competing processes: if the membrane insertion is too slow, elongation of the nascent chain would continue in the cytosol and its folding would prevent a later interaction of the signal sequence with the translocation apparatus.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	251	 We therefore infer that the  subunit is required for a rapid insertion of the ribosome-bound nascent chain into the translocation sites in the ER membrane.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	252	 The observation that the  subunit is not essential is in agreement with the fact that the deletion of the two  subunits in yeast cells is not lethal and leads to a growth phenotype only at elevated temperatures.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Since microsomes isolated from the mutant had a reduced activity for posttranslational protein transport, these and the present results indicate that the  subunit plays a role in both pathways, but is not absolutely required in either one.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	254	As the cotranslational translocation process is known in much detail, we have been able to analyze the effect of Sec61 depletion on the various steps.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	255	 One of the first steps is the interaction of the ribosome-nascent chain- SRP complex with the SRP receptor in the membrane that leads to the release of the translational arrest exerted by SRP.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	256	 This reaction was not perturbed by the depletion of Sec61, although previous data showed that, for optimal release, both the SRP receptor and the Sec61 complex are required (Gorlich and Rapoport, 1993).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	257	 We therefore conclude that the  subunit is not essential for this activity of the Sec61 complex.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	258	 The binding of ribosomes to the ER membrane was also not affected by the absence of Sec61.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Both the number of binding sites and the dissociation constant remained unchanged and were almost identical to the values determined for the reconstituted, purified wild-type Sec61 complex.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	260	 These results are consistent with the observation that proteolytic degradation of the cytosolic domain of Sec61 in microsomes does not prevent the binding of ribosomes (Kalies et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	261	 Taken together, our results indicate that even in the absence of Sec61, efficient release of the SRP arrest and binding of the ribosome-nascent chain complex to the Sec61 complex can occur.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	262	 This conclusion is further supported by the observation that the membrane targeted nascent chains undergo signal peptide cleavage by signal peptidase located in the wrong orientation in the reconstituted membrane.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	263	 It therefore appears that a step subsequent to membrane targeting, most likely the step in which the nascent chain is inserted into the Sec61 channel, is perturbed in the absence of the  subunit.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	264	 Structural changes in the Sec61 channel, which may be required for its opening (Crowley et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	265	, 1994; Jungnickel and Rapoport, 1995), may occur with a reduced rate.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	266	To further analyze the function of Sec61, we have probed its molecular environment in ER membranes by cross-linking.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	267	 A bifunctional cross-linker was used that reacts specifically with SH groups and therefore can be expected to give a relative simple cross-linking pattern.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	268	 As predicted, in rough microsomes Sec61 was found in close proximity to the  subunit of the Sec61 complex.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	269	 We also found a cross-linked product consisting of two Sec61 molecules, perhaps explained by the occurrence of oligomers of the trimeric Sec61 complex in microsomes (Hanein et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Most interestingly, however, a specific cross-linked product containing SPC25 was observed.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	271	 Conversely, when the cross-linking partners of SPC25 were analyzed, the only partner outside the signal peptidase complex was found to be Sec61.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	272	 Remarkably, 70% of SPC25 could be cross-linked to Sec61.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	273	 We therefore believe that the cross-link between the two proteins indicates their specific interaction.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	274	 These data provide the first evidence that the signal peptidase physically contacts the protein conducting channel in the membrane.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	275	 The cross-linking between Sec61 and SPC25 has likely occurred between their cytosolic domains since the only cysteine in Sec61 is in its NH2 terminus and two appropriately located cysteines exist in the NH2-terminal domain of SPC25 (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	276	 7), previously shown to be cytosolic (Kalies and Hartmann, 1996).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	277	 SPC25 has almost no amino acid residues in the lumen of the ER where the active site of the signal peptidase resides (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	278	 7) and its function was therefore obscure.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	279	 On the basis of our data, we propose that it is involved in an interaction with the Sec61 complex to bring the enzyme close to the translocating polypeptide substrate.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	280	 However, sequestration in the translocation site may not be absolutely essential for its function because the signal peptidase complex is very abundant and can probably reach its substrates by mere diffusion in the plane of the membrane, explaining why neither SPC25 nor Sec61 are essential for the viability of yeast cells.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	281	View larger version (20K):    Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	282	   Membrane topology of the signal peptidase complex and the Sec61 complex.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	283	 The topologies of all subunits are schematically illustrated.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	284	 The dark boxes indicate hydrophobic segments or membrane spanning segments, respectively.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	285	 SPC22/23 is drawn in the glycosylated form.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	286	 The position of SH-groups is marked by white circles.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	287	Further evidence for our conjecture that Sec61 may be involved in recruiting the signal peptidase complex to the translocation site comes from cross-linking experiments in which ribosome-stripped membranes were used.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	288	 These membranes gave many cross-link-reduced cross-links between Sec61 and SPC25.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	289	 After retargeting of ribosome-nascent chain complexes at almost ribosome-free membranes, the cross-linking between both proteins was increased, suggesting that their interaction is induced when translocation is initiated by ribosome binding.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	290	 The cross-linking between Sec61 and Sec61 was also dependent on the presence of membrane-bound ribosomes.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	291	 Both effects required the dissociation of the ribosome, and not merely the release of the nascent chain from the ribosome, since they occurred with puromycin at high but not at low salt concentrations.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	292	 The changes in cross-linking pattern upon ribosome removal or retargeting of ribosome-nascent chain complexes could be caused by conformational alterations in an assembled complex or by dissociation of an assembly into subcomplexes.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	293	 In any case, they provide first evidence for structural changes among known components of the translocation apparatus induced by the onset of cotranslational translocation.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	294	Received for publication 11 April 1997 and in revised form 10 February 1998.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	295	   The work was supported by a grant from the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	296	    Address all correspondence to Dr.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	297	 Hartmann, Abteilung Biochemie II, Zentrum Biochemie und Molekulare Zellbiologie, Georg-August-Universitat, Gossler Strasse 12 d, 37073 Gottingen, Germany.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	298	    Abbreviations used in this paper.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	299	BMH, bis-maleimidohexane; PK-RM, puromycin and high salt-treated rough microsomes; RM, rough microsomes; SPC, signal peptidase complex; SPC25, the 25-kD subunit of the signal peptidase complex; SRP, signal recognition particle; TRAM, translocating chain-associating membrane.

0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	326	 Signal sequence-dependent function of the TRAM protein during early phases of protein transport across the endoplasmic reticulum membrane.

0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	328	 Methods Enzymol 96: 84-93 Copyright   1998 by The Rockefeller University Press.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	0	Cystic fibrosis, gene therapy, and lung inflammation: for better or worse? Lisa M.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	1	Department of Physiology and Biophysics, University of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, Alabama 35294-0005.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	2	THE STUDY by van Heeckeren and colleagues, one of the current articles in focus (Ref.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	3	 L717 in this issue), addresses the question of whether adenoviral delivery of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) to the cystic fibrosis airways attenuates inflammation and mortality associated with a chronic bacterial infection.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	4	 This is an intriguing question because adenoviral vectors themselves can invoke a substantial immune response that prohibits their repeated administration to the lung (2).
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	5	 In their article, van Heeckeren and coworkers report that, within the infected cystic fibrosis lung, CFTR expression and/or adenoviral vector-induced inflammation yields a significant survival advantage.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	6	 This promising observation may have profound implications for the utility of adenoviral vectors in the gene therapy treatment of cystic fibrosis.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	7	CFTR mutations and cystic fibrosis lung pathophysiology.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Cystic fibrosis is the most common autosomal recessive disorder in the Caucasian population, with a frequency of 1 in 2,500 live births.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	9	 It is caused by defective function of the cftr gene product (14), which encodes a 170- to 180-kDa protein that functions as a cAMP-regulated chloride channel.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	10	 The CFTR protein is expressed normally in those tissues affected in cystic fibrosis, including airway submucosal glands and airway epithelial cells.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	11	 The cystic fibrosis respiratory disease phenotype includes thick mucus secretion and bacterial colonization of the lung with a select few bacterial pathogens, including Pseudomonas aeruginosa (13).
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	12	 aeruginosa infections compounded by an inability to clear this organism result in a profound neutrophil migration into the airways and secretion of a variety of inflammatory mediators, including neutrophil elastase, reactive oxygen species, and inflammatory cytokines, which cause irreversible damage to the airways and gas-exchange components.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	13	Cystic fibrosis and adenoviral vector-mediated gene therapy.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Correction of the defective cftr gene in vivo has long been the holy grail of the cystic fibrosis research community.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The use of adenoviral vectors in this pursuit has been problematic (reviewed in Ref.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	16	 In early clinical trials, the administration of adenoviral vectors encoding CFTR demonstrated great promise, with transient correction of chloride transport defects.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Subsequent studies, however, failed to repeat this initial finding and, moreover, revealed that adenoviral vector-mediated delivery of CFTR to the cystic fibrosis airways was limited by the local immune response associated with multiple vector administrations.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Similarly, van Heeckeren and colleagues (19) reported previously that P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	19	 aeruginosa-induced bronchopulmonary inflammation also limited the efficacy of adenoviral vector-mediated gene transfer.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Despite this limitation, several studies suggest that the extent of CFTR correction required for a normal lung phenotype may be quite low (2), thereby validating the use of adenoviral vectors in cystic fibrosis gene therapy.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	21	Until the current study by van Heeckeren et al.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	22	 (20), the impact of adenoviral vector-mediated gene therapy had not been examined in the context of a cystic fibrosis lung chronically infected with bacteria (19).
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	23	 In this ambitious study by van Heeckeren and coworkers (20), the authors determined whether CFTR delivery improved the outcome of a cystic fibrosis murine model infected with P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Specifically, the authors reported that gut-corrected cystic fibrosis mice treated with an adenoviral vector encoding CFTR and inoculated with P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	25	 aeruginosa-laden agarose beads exhibited a significantly greater cumulative 10-day survival compared with sucrose controls; survival of empty vector controls, however, was not significantly different.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Importantly, these authors observed that there were no differences between mice receiving the CFTR vector or controls with regard to the extent of lung inflammation.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	27	 From these data, the authors concluded that the observed survival advantage in mice receiving adenoviral delivery of CFTR to the cystic fibrosis lung may be due to CFTR expression and/or proinflammatory effects of the adenoviral vector.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	28	 adenoviral vector-induced inflammation.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Because cumulative 10-day survival was not significantly different between mice receiving CFTR-encoding vectors vs.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	30	 empty vector controls, it is likely that CFTR expression plays a small role in this response.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	31	 As the authors note (20), it is possible that the administration of an adenoviral vector may have induced a protective immune response that improved cumulative survival.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	32	 In support of this possibility, the authors observed a persistent lung lymphocytosis in response to adenoviral vector administration; this response was further enhanced upon challenge with P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	33	 aeruginosa-laden agarose beads.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Interestingly, the authors did not observe increased bacterial killing in mice treated with either the CFTR-encoding adenoviral vector or the empty vector control.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	35	Early studies by Markham and coworkers (8, 12) suggest that T cell-mediated immune responses are protective against P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	36	 For example, these authors have shown that adoptive transfer of T cells from mice immunized with P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	37	 aeruginosa to granulocytopenic mice resulted in nearly 100% survival upon challenge with P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Similar findings have been reported by others (3).
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Despite these reports, the exact nature of T cell-mediated immunity in P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	40	 aeruginosa infections remains unclear.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Hoiby and colleagues have reported that, in a rat model of P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	42	 aeruginosa pnuemonia (4) and in cystic fibrosis patients (11), chronic P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	43	 aeruginosa infection induces a T helper type 2 (Th2)-like response.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Th2 responses are characterized by the production of IL-4 and IL-5 and are important in the generation of humoral immunity.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	45	 These results are further supported by their observation that chronic P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	46	 aeruginosa lung infection is more severe in a Th2 responding mouse strain (BALB/c) (10).
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	47	 With regard to protective T cell immunity, Hoiby and coworkers (4, 5, 9) have demonstrated that induction of a Th1-dominated cytokine response improves the outcome of chronic P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Th1 responses are characterized by the production of IFN- and are instrumental in the generation of cell-mediated immunity.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Interestingly, previous studies have shown that adenoviral vector administration can trigger a Th1 response in the lungs of mice (18, 21) and humans (1).
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	50	 In light of these findings, it is tempting to conclude that the improved cumulative survival observed in the van Heeckeren study (20) is a function of an adenovirus-induced Th1 response; however, this conclusion may be too simplistic.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	51	Several recent studies call into question the beneficial nature of a Th1 response in P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Reports examining the role of the virulence factor alginate (17) and the quorum-sensing molecule N-(3-oxododecanoyl)homoserine lactone (16) in P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	53	 aeruginosa pathogenicity indicate that each of these factors induces a Th1-predominated immune response that may contribute to P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Moreover, Schultz and colleagues (15) have reported recently that, in a rat model of P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	55	 aeruginosa pneumonia, endogenous IFN- impairs bacterial clearance and host defense.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Clearly, differences in the strain of P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	57	 mucoid), type of infection (acute vs.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	58	 chronic), route of administration, and model system of analysis must be taken into account when considering the role of Th1/Th2 responses in P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	59	Despite the ongoing debate of T cell responses in P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	60	 aeruginosa infections, it should be noted that these studies were performed in non-cystic fibrosis model systems.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Because recent evidence indicates that T cell responses may be dysregulated in cystic fibrosis (6, 7), such studies need to be performed in the context of the cystic fibrosis lung.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	62	 This is underscored by the van Heeckeren study (20), which suggests that adenoviral vector-induced inflammation may promote survival of cystic fibrosis mice during a chronic P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	63	 As with all well-conceived studies, this study precipitates a number of unanswered questions.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	64	 For example, in the absence of P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	65	 aeruginosa infection, does the nature of the inflammatory response differ between mice receiving an adenoviral vector encoding CFTR vs.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	66	 empty vector controls? Does CFTR play a role in the T cell immune responses triggered by P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	67	 aeruginosa infection? How does the hyperimmune response of the cystic fibrosis lung contribute to adenoviral vector- or P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	68	 aeruginosa-mediated inflammation? Future studies examining immune responses triggered upon adenoviral vector administration of the P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	69	 aeruginosa-infected cystic fibrosis airways should provide new and important information regarding the utility of adenoviral vectors in cystic fibrosis-related gene therapy.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	70	This work was supported by a grant from the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation (to L.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	71	   FOOTNOTES   Address for reprint requests and other correspondence: L.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	72	 of Physiology and Biophysics, Univ.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	73	 of Alabama at Birmingham, MCLM 966, 1918 Univ.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	74	, Birmingham, AL 35294-0005 (E-mail: lschwieb{at}uab.
