0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	0	EDITORIAL FOCUS Activation of NF-B in airway epithelial cells is dependent on CFTR trafficking and Cl channel function Adam J.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Weber, Grace Soong, Ruth Bryan, Shahryar Saba, and Alice Prince.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	2	College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, New York, New York 10032.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	3	    ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	4	Polymorphonuclear leukocyte-dominated airway inflammation is a major component of cystic fibrosis (CF) lung disease and may be associated with CF transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) dysfunction as well as infection.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Mutant F508 CFTR is mistrafficked, accumulates in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), and may cause "cell stress" and activation of nuclear factor (NF)-B.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	6	 G551D mutants also lack Cl channel function, but CFTR is trafficked normally.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	7	 We compared the effects of CFTR mutations on the endogenous activation of an NF-B reporter construct.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	8	 In transfected Chinese hamster ovary cells, the mistrafficked F508 allele caused a sevenfold activation of NF-B compared with wild-type CFTR or the G551D mutant (P  <  0.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	9	 NF-B was also activated in 9/HTEo/pCep-R cells and in 16HBE/pcftr antisense cell lines, which lack CFTR Cl channel function but do not accumulate mutant protein in the ER.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	10	 This endogenous activation of NF-B was associated with elevated interleukin-8 expression.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Impaired CFTR Cl channel activity as well as cell stress due to accumulation of mistrafficked CFTR in the ER contributes to the endogenous activation of NF-B in cells with the CFTR mutation.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	12	nuclear factor-B; cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator; chloride channel; inflammatory response; intracellular calcium; mitogen-activated protein kinase.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	13	    INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	14	CYSTIC FIBROSIS (CF) transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) mutations have many effects on the physiology of respiratory epithelial cells in addition to the expected effects on Cl transport.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	15	 One of the major clinical manifestations of CFTR mutations is excessive airway inflammation (14-17), implying that CFTR affects the immune function of airway epithelial cells, particularly the expression of nuclear factor (NF)-B-dependent proinflammatory chemokines and cytokines.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Several lines of experimental evidence suggest that CFTR dysfunction influences the exogenous activation of epithelial immune function (8, 30).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Bacteria persist in the respiratory tract of CF patients due to decreased antimicrobial activity in CF airway surface fluid and impair bacterial clearance due to mucus plugging (25).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Cells with CFTR mutations have increased numbers of asialoglycolipid receptors for common bacterial pathogens (24).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Ligation of these receptors activates NF-B-dependent epithelial interleukin (IL)-8 production to recruit polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNs) from the circulation into the airways (8).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Epithelial expression of IL-8 after bacterial stimulation is increased in cells with CFTR dysfunction, a finding demonstrated in both matched CF and corrected cell lines (5, 9, 27, 30) and in cftr-deficient [cftr(/)] mice compared with normal control mice (29).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	21	 How CFTR dysfunction might affect the endogenous expression of NF-B-dependent genes is less well documented.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	22	NF-B is a transcription factor required for the expression of many genes important in inflammation.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	23	 It is complexed in the cell cytoplasm with IB- and -, which are selectively phosphorylated, ubiquitinated, and degraded in the proteasome in response to stimuli (2).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	24	 There is both signal-dependent and signal-independent IB- phosphorylation (20), a distinction that may be relevant to the endogenous activity of NF-B as opposed to the activation in response to a superficial stimulus such as bacterial attachment to surface receptors.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Ligation of superficial asialo-GM1 receptors on epithelial surfaces by bacterial adhesins stimulates Ca2+-dependent kinase activity through mitogen-activated protein kinase phosphorylation and NF-B activation (23a).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	26	 NF-B translocation may be regulated by other intracellular factors that lead to a different pattern of IB- phosphorylation than that elicited by extracellular stimuli (4).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	27	 It has been proposed that the abnormal trafficking of F508 CFTR and its accumulation in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) provides sufficient intracellular stress to cause NF-B activation (2).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	28	The most common CFTR mutation responsible for CF in ~70% of patients is the deletion of a phenylalanine residue (F508) in the nucleotide binding domain.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	29	 The F508 mutant CFTR not only fails to transport Cl in response to cAMP but accumulates in the ER due to abnormal maturation and folding (1, 7, 32).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	30	 From experimental data generated with adenovirus mutants targeted for retention in the ER, Pahl and colleagues (18, 19) proposed that homozygous F508 mutations in CFTR would similarly cause Ca2+ release, activation of NF-B, and resultant transcription of proinflammatory cytokines and chemokines.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Comparison of the endogenous activation of NF-B in IB3 cells (W1282X/F508), a trafficking mutant similar to the homozygous F508 mutation, with that in corrected C-38 cells, which express a functional but truncated form of CFTR, was consistent with this hypothesis.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	32	 The transcriptionally active p65 component of NF-B was found in the nuclei of unstimulated CF cells but not of the corrected cells by immunofluorescence labeling and was confirmed by gel shift assays (8).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Manipulations to increase CFTR trafficking to the apical surface of the cell, such as growth at low temperature or the addition of glycerol, decreased the amount of p65 found in the IB3 cell nuclei.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Although these observations were consistent with the hypothesis that abnormal CFTR proteins cause endogenous activation of NF-B, they did not differentiate between two possible mechanisms: that "cell stress" associated with CFTR mistrafficking leads to changes in intracellular Ca2+ concentration ([Ca2+]i) and stimulation of NF-B translocation or that CFTR Cl channel dysfunction by itself is associated with endogenous activation of NF-B.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	35	Other types of CFTR mutations cause "CF-like" physiology, i.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	36	, lack of Cl secretion in response to cAMP, without causing trafficking abnormalities or resulting in the accumulation of mutant proteins in the ER (7).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Analysis of the activation of NF-B in such cell lines would provide the opportunity to determine whether Cl channel dysfunction alone is associated with the regulation of NF-B.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	38	 The G551D CFTR mutant, in which a conserved glycine in the ATP binding cassette is mutated, lacks Cl channel function, but the protein is properly folded and trafficked (12).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Patients with the G551D mutation have a clinical disease that is indistinguishable from that caused by the more common F508 mutation (10).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The 9/HTEo human tracheal epithelial cell line transfected with a plasmid directing constitutive expression of the CFTR regulatory (R) domain also fails to transport Cl in response to cAMP while expressing low levels of wild-type CFTR message detected by RT-PCR (21).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	41	 These 9/HTEo/pCep-R cells are readily activated by Pseudomonas aeruginosa and express significantly more IL-8 than control cells containing the empty vector (5).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	42	 The impact of impaired CFTR Cl channel activity on the normal interaction of IBs and NF-B is not known.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Recently constructed 16HBE cell lines expressing plasmid-encoded cftr in the sense or antisense orientation also provide the opportunity to test the impact of CFTR Cl channel function on the activation of NF-B in airway cells without the confounding issues of mistrafficked CFTR protein (23).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	44	In the experiments detailed in this report, several matched cell lines with CFTR dysfunction due to lack of Cl channel function, CFTR misfolding, mistrafficking, or both were tested for endogenous activation of NF-B and basal IL-8 expression.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Although CFTR mistrafficking typical of the common F508 mutation and associated cell stress may be responsible for the increased expression of proinflammatory cytokines and chemokines associated with CF cells, we sought to establish whether CFTR Cl channel function as well as the effects of CFTR mistrafficking contributes to endogenous activation of NF-B and the excessive inflammation that characterizes CF airway pathology.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	46	    MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	47	9/HTEo cells, a human tracheal epithelial cell line (11), were grown in DMEM supplemented with 10% FCS and were stably transfected with either pCep, a vector control, or pCep-R, providing constitutive expression of the R-domain of CFTR resulting in typical CF-like physiology, i.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	48	, failure of Cl secretion in response to cAMP (21) and altered superficial sialylation (5).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	49	 IB3 cells (F508/W1282X), a human bronchial epithelial cell line, and C-38 cells, "corrected" cells with normal physiology that express an episomal truncated form of CFTR (33), were obtained from P.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Zeitlin (Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, MD) and grown in LHC-8 medium (Biofluids, Rockville, MD) plus 10% FCS.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	51	 The IB3 cells used in these studies contain the empty vector.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	52	 16HBE cells transfected with plasmids expressing the first 131 nucleotides of cftr in either the sense or antisense orientation were grown in MEM plus 10% FCS plus L-glutamine and have been previously described (23).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Cells expressing the antisense plasmid failed to respond to cAMP agonists with Cl secretion.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Stably transfected Chinese hamster ovary (CHO)-K1 cells that express F508 CFTR or G551D CFTR were obtained from J.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Riordan (Mayo Clinic Scottsdale, Scottsdale, AZ) and grown in MEM plus 200  microM methotrexate plus 8% FCS.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	56	 CHO-K1 cells were obtained from the American Type Culture Collection (ATCC) and lipofected with pCep plasmid constructs expressing either wild-type CFTR, G551D CFTR, F508 CFTR, or the vector alone, provided by M.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Drumm (Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland OH).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	58	 CHO cells were grown in MEM plus 10% FCS.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	59	 CFTR expression in the cells was verified by immunodetection with COOH terminus-specific mouse monoclonal anti-CFTR antibody (Genzyme, Minneapolis, MN).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Total RNA was isolated from confluent monolayers of IB3 and C-38 cells grown in 10-cm plates with RNeasy Mini Kit, and RT was performed with Omniscript RT (both from QIAGEN, Valencia, CA).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	61	 PCR primers for human IL-8 were 5'-TACTCCAAACCTTTCCAACCC-3' and 5'-AACTTCTCCACAACCCTCTG-3'.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	62	 The cells were stimulated by the addition of 0.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	63	 aeruginosa PAO1 (5  x  109 colony-stimulating units/ml) scraped from an agar plate and resuspended in cell culture medium.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	64	 IL-8 in epithelial cell culture supernatants was measured with ELISA (R and D Systems, Minneapolis, MN).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	65	 The cells were weaned from serum for 18 h, and the supernatants were harvested 18 h later for IL-8 ELISA.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Duplicate wells were treated with trypan blue to assess epithelial viability during the assay, which was  > 75%.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Each IL-8 data point was determined in quintuplicate, and means  plus or minus  SD were calculated.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Significance was evaluated with a one-way ANOVA with Dunnett's posttest (GraphPad Instat version 3.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	69	00, GraphPad Software, San Diego, CA) to test the null hypothesis that there was no difference in the amount of IL-8 produced by the epithelial cells with different CFTR function.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	70	Activation of NF-B Detected by Luciferase Reporter Constructs.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	71	Cells were grown in six-well plates to 80-90% confluence, washed once with PBS, and replated with serum- and antibiotic-free medium.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	72	 The cells were transiently transfected with LipofectAMINE 2000 reagent (Life Technologies, Gaithersburg, MD), 1  microg of each plasmid DNA, pNF-B-Luc (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA) and a constitutively active pRL-TK (Promega, Madison, WI), to control for transfection efficiency and incubated at 37 degrees C in 5% CO2 for 18 h.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Lipofection of the CHO cells was done with an additional 3  microg of pCep-CFTR vector DNA.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	74	 The cells were washed once, lysed, and harvested with passive lysis buffer (Promega).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Luciferase assays were performed with the reagents and protocol for the dual-luciferase reporter assay system (Promega) and analyzed with a luminometer.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	76	 After standardization for transfection efficiency, data were plotted as the means of quadruplicate samples and are representative of at least three independent experiments.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Statistical analysis was performed with an unpaired t-test for the experiments involving epithelial cells and a one-way ANOVA to analyze the results obtained with the CHO cells to accommodate a larger sample size.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	78	Relative levels of [Ca2+]i were estimated in fluo 3-loaded IB3 and C-38 cells by fluorescence imaging.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Monolayers of C-38 or IB3 cells were grown for 2 days on Lab-TekII chambered slides (Nalge Nunc International, Naperville, IL) in LHC-8 medium (Biofluids) supplemented with 10% FCS.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	80	 The monolayers were washed and dye loaded with fluo 3-AM (Bio-Rad, Hercules, CA) for 0.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	81	5 h at room temperature in the dark in modified Ringer solution (145 mM NaCl, 5 mM KCl, 1 mM Na2HPO4, 2 mM CaCl2, 10 mM glucose, 20 mM HEPES, and 1 mM MgSO4, pH 7.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	82	 The cells were rinsed in Ringer solution and incubated for 30 min to allow continued cleavage of the acetoxymethyl ester.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The monolayers were imaged on a Zeiss Axiovert microscope at  x 40 magnification with Inovision software.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Images were taken at 10-s intervals before and after the addition of stimuli, and each image is the average of eight scans.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Final measurements were taken after the addition of the ionophore 4-bromo-A-23187 (Bio-Rad) to allow for correction of differences in dye loading.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Images were analyzed with Scion image software (Scion, Frederick, MD).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Significance was determined with an unpaired t-test to compare the mean relative fluorescence of the two populations of epithelial cells.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	88	Airway epithelial cells were grown to near confluence on Lab-TekII eight-chambered glass slides (Nalge Nunc International).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	89	 They were washed with PBS, fixed with 4% paraformaldehyde in PBS for 20 min at room temperature, washed three times with PBS, and blocked in 10% goat serum in Ca2+/Mg2+ PBS for 1 h at room temperature.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	90	 After blocking, the cells were washed three times in PBS and incubated with a 1:100 dilution of rabbit polyclonal antibody p65 (Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Santa Cruz, CA) for 1 h at room temperature, washed, and then incubated with goat anti-rabbit IgG conjugated to tetramethylrhodamine B isothiocyanate (TRITC; 1:50; Zymed, South San Francisco, CA) in PBS plus 0.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	91	1% BSA plus an equal volume of bis-benzimide (50  microg/ml) for 1 h at room temperature.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	92	 The cells were imaged on a Zeiss Axiovert S100 microscope with a Hamamatsu Orca II digital camera and Inovision software.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	93	 560D15 and 400DF15 band-pass filters were used for TRITC and bis-benzimide imaging, respectively.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Emission data were collected with a triple-pass filter at wavelengths of 460 nm for bis-benzimide and 602 nm for TRITC.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	95	    RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	96	Activation of NF-B in Epithelial Cells With CFTR Dysfunction.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	97	To determine whether lack of CFTR-associated Cl channel function affects the basal activation of NF-B in airway epithelial cells, two cell lines with defective CFTR function but without mutations associated with mistrafficking were studied.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	98	 9/HTEo/pCep cells and 9/HTEo/pCep-R cells, which have constitutive overexpression of the CFTR R-domain and fail to transport Cl in response to cAMP, were transfected with an NF-B-luciferase reporter construct.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	99	5-fold greater activation of NF-B than 9/HTEo/pCep cells expressing the vector control (Fig.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Similarly, 16HBE cells expressing cftr antisense, previously shown to lack CFTR-dependent Cl channel activity, had fivefold greater activation of the NF-B reporter than the cells expressing cftr in the sense orientation (P  <  0.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	101	View larger version (15K):    Fig.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	102	   Nuclear factor (NF)-B activation in airway epithelial cells with defective cystic fibrosis (CF) transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) Cl channel function.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	103	 The relative activation of an NF-B-luciferase reporter construct in 16HBE cells expressing cftr sense or antisense construct, 9/HTEo/pCep, and 9/HTEo/pCep-R cells is shown (n = 12 experiments).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	104	Nuclear p65 (Rel A) in Cells With CFTR Dysfunction Detected by Immunofluorescence.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	105	The presence of the p65 (Rel A) component of NF-B in the cell nucleus is generally indicative of NF-B activation and gene transcription.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	106	 To verify that activation of NF-B as detected by the reporter constructs was indicative of nuclear localization of the p65 component, the cell lines were permeabilized, treated with antibody to p65 that was detected with a goat anti-human IgG conjugated to TRITC with bis-benzimide to stain the nuclei.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	107	 The control cells with normal CFTR function, either 9/HTEo/pCep or 16HBE/cftr sense, had predominantly cytosolic p65 fluorescence (Fig.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	108	 In contrast, within the fields of 9/HTEo/Cep-R and 16HBE/cftr antisense cells, there were significantly more cells with nuclear p65 TRITC fluorescence colocalizing with the blue bis-benzimide nuclear stain.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	109	View larger version (127K):    Fig.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	110	   Fluorescence imaging of airway epithelial cells to localize NF-B p65.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Digital images of permeabilized cells were analyzed with Inovision software to localize anti-p65 NF-B-tetramethylrhodamine isothiocyanate (TRITC) and -bis-benzimide nuclear fluorescence.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	112	Activation of NF-B in CHO Cells Expressing Wild-Type and Mutant CFTR.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	113	CHO cells that were transiently transfected with the pCep empty vector or pCep vector expressing wild-type CFTR had low levels of basal NF-B activation as did the cells transfected with the plasmid expressing the mutant G551D CFTR (Fig.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	114	 This was in contrast to the threefold increase in luciferase activity associated with CHO cells expressing mutant F508 CFTR (P  <  0.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	115	001 for F508 compared with the pCep vector control).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Experiments done with stably transfected CHO cells yielded similar results (Fig.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	117	 3C); expression of F508 CFTR was associated with a sevenfold increase in reporter activation compared with that in the CHO cells expressing the G551D mutation (P  <  0.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	118	001) or CHO cells transfected with the reporter construct alone (P  <  0.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	119	 The relative expression of CFTR in the CHO cells was roughly equivalent (Fig.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	120	 In the CHO cells, expression of the F508 CFTR mutation was sufficient to activate NF-B, whereas the presence of comparable amounts of the mutant G551D CFTR was not.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	121	View larger version (21K):    Fig.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	122	   NF-B activation in Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells transiently transfected with CFTR.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	123	 A: relative activation of an NF-B-luciferase reporter construct in CHO cells without CFTR () or transiently transfected with the pCep vector; wild-type (wt) CFTR, G551D CFTR, or F508 CFTR cloned in pCep (n = 12 experiments).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	124	 B: immunodetection of CFTR in the transiently transfected CHO cells: Lane A, control CHO cells; lane B, pCep-wild-type CFTR; lane C, pCep-G551D CFTR; lane D, pCep-F508 CFTR.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	125	 C: NF-B activation in stably transfected CHO cells (n = 12 experiments).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	126	 D: immunodetection of CFTR in stably transfected CHO cells.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Lane A, without CFTR (control); lane B, G551D CFTR; lane C, F508 CFTR.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	128	IL-8 Expression Is Increased in Cell Lines With CFTR Dysfunction.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	129	The nuclear localization of NF-B is associated with the transcription of several genes such as IL-8, a major PMN chemokine, that are important in inflammation.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Increased expression of IL-8 has been frequently reported to be characteristic of CF cells after bacterial stimulation as well as under basal conditions (8).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	131	 To determine whether the activation of NF-B seen in the epithelial cell lines with dysfunctional CFTR is associated with an IL-8 response, IL-8 expression was assessed with RT-PCR (Fig.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	132	 (These unstimulated cells did not produce sufficient amounts of IL-8 in serum-free medium to detect with a standard ELISA.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	133	) There was increased IL-8 mRNA expression detected in the IB3 cells compared with the endogenous levels in the C-38 cells, and both cell lines increased IL-8 mRNA expression in response to bacterial stimulation, included as a positive control.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	134	View larger version (32K):    Fig.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	135	   Interleukin (IL)-8 mRNA expression in IB3 and C-38 cells.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Expression of IL-8 mRNA was analyzed by PCR after reverse transcription and compared with a -actin control.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Lane A, IB3 cells; lane B, IB3 cells stimulated with Pseudomonas aeruginosa; lane C, C-38 cells; lane D, C-38 cells stimulated with P.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	138	IL-8 production could be reliably measured by ELISA in 9/HTEo and 16HBE cell culture supernatants accumulated over 18 h after being weaned from serum.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	139	 The 9/HTEo/pCep-R cells produced more IL-8 than those expressing the vector control (P  <  0.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	140	001), and lack of CFTR expression in the 16HBE cells expressing cftr antisense was also associated with increased IL-8 expression (P  <  0.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Thus cell lines with defective CFTR Cl channel activity, regardless of the nature of the CFTR defect, had increased IL-8 production compared with the corresponding cell line with normal CFTR activity.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	142	View larger version (15K):    Fig.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	143	   IL-8 expression in cells with CFTR Cl channel dysfunction.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	144	 The relative amounts of IL-8 in epithelial cell culture supernatants were detected by ELISA.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	145	 For the purposes of comparison, the amount expressed by each of the control cell lines (16HBE/cftr sense = 21  microg/ microg protein; 9/HTEo/pCep = 3.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	146	75 ng/ microg protein) was considered as 100% (n = 5 experiments).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	147	[Ca2+]i in Cells With ER Overload.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	148	Epithelial cells with mistrafficked CFTR and "ER overload" have been postulated to have increased release of Ca2+ from ER stores as a consequence, a response that could activate Ca2+-dependent kinase activity.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Relative [Ca2+]i was estimated in subconfluent IB3 and C-38 cells loaded with the fluorescent indicator fluo 3-AM (Fig.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	150	 When the populations of the different cell types were compared, there was a consistent trend of increased [Ca2+]i associated with the IB3 cells, with relative basal fluorescence ranging from 0.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	151	85 compared with that in the population of C-38 cells, which had basal [Ca2+]i in the range of 0.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Comparing the relative fluorescence of 10 individual cells at a single time point (30 s), the IB3 cells had a relative mean fluorescence of 0.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Both cell types responded to the addition of P.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	154	 aeruginosa with increased [Ca2+]i.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	155	View larger version (19K):    Fig.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	156	   Relative intracellular Ca2+ concentration ([Ca2+]i) in IB3 and C-38 cells.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Each tracing represents the relative level of [Ca2+]i in an individual cell normalized to the maximal level obtained after addition of the ionophore.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	158	 The relative response to the addition of 109 colony-forming units/ml of PAO1 is indicated.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	159	 The relative mean [Ca2+]i at 30 s in unstimulated IB3 cells (0.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	160	758) was significantly higher than that in C-38 cells (0.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	161	    DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	162	Airway inflammation is a major factor in the pathogenesis of CF pulmonary disease.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Clinical studies have clearly established a direct correlation between infection, IL-8 secretion, and the accumulation of PMNs and their toxic products in the CF lung (14-17).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Bacterial stimulation of cells with CFTR mutations activates significantly greater cytokine expression than matched cells with normal CFTR function (5, 8, 29, 30).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Several reports (8, 28) suggest that cells with CFTR dysfunction have endogenously upregulated expression of proinflammatory cytokines and chemokines.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Young infants with CF, even without detectable evidence of prior infection, have PMNs and increased amounts of IL-8 in their airways (14), and proinflammatory cytokine expression is increased in cells cultured directly from uninfected CF tissues (28).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	167	 These findings are consistent with the in vitro studies demonstrating endogenous activation of NF-B in CF but not in corrected cell lines.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	168	 As indicated by the data in this report, lack of CFTR Cl channel function and the physiological consequences of mistrafficked mutant CFTR both appear to contribute to the endogenous activation of NF-B in CF airway cells, which is manifested by the increased expression of IL-8 in these cells, even in the absence of bacterial stimulation.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	169	There is evidence of endogenous activation of NF-B in cells with CFTR dysfunction due to several different mechanisms.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	170	 In previous studies, IB3 cells, which express the W1282X/F508 mutation associated with mistrafficked CFTR that accumulates in the ER, were found to have significant amounts of the p65 component of NF-B in nuclei under basal conditions in which there was no nuclear NF-B in the corrected C-38 cells (8).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Because the translocation of NF-B can be associated with many types of stimuli, additional consequences of accumulated mutant CFTR in the ER were also demonstrated in the mutant cell line.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	172	 The IB3 cells were found to have higher basal [Ca2+]i, a predicted consequence of "ER stress" (2, 18).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	173	 The presence of nuclear NF-B in the IB3 cells could be correlated with increased IL-8 expression as estimated by RT-PCR compared with that in the control C-38 cell line.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	174	 The concentration of IL-8 in the tissue culture supernatant was minimal in these cells after an 18-h incubation in serum-free medium; however, the relative amount of IL-8 message was consistent with a previous report by DiMango et al.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Not all investigators have found increased endogenous levels of IL-8 associated with CFTR mutations (30).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Cell culture conditions, effects of FCS, and handling of the monolayers all can affect the translocation of NF-B and endogenous expression of IL-8.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Thus it seems relevant to demonstrate that the presence of nuclear p65 appears to be associated with the expected biological response, namely IL-8 expression.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	178	The activation of other NF-B-dependent pathways is not necessarily increased in IB3 compared with C-38 cells.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Stimulation of NF-B translocation is associated with an antiapoptotic effect in many cell lines including respiratory epithelial cells.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Rates of apoptosis can be increased by proteasome inhibitors that inhibit IB degradation and block NF-B translocation (31).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	181	 In a study published recently (23), the rates of IB3 and C-38 cell apoptosis were equivalent both under control conditions and after bacterial stimulation despite the observed differences in endogenous nuclear NF-B.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Thus the association between CFTR dysfunction, activation of NF-B, and transcription of NF-B-dependent genes is somewhat selective and is not a global response.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	183	The consequences of CFTR mistrafficking and the activation of NF-B were further demonstrated in CHO cells that do not normally express CFTR.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	184	 The presence of the mistrafficked mutant F508 CFTR was a significant stimulus for NF-B activation in CHO cells.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	185	 The G551D CFTR, which does not function appropriately as a Cl channel but is trafficked normally to the apical surface of the respiratory epithelial cell (10), did not stimulate NF-B.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Expression of normal CFTR from the same plasmid construct did not cause NF-B activation in CHO cells nor did transfection with the empty vector or the luciferase reporter construct.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Although both the G551D and F508 CFTR mutations are associated with clinical disease and lack of Cl secretion in response to cAMP (10), the major difference between these mutants is the mistrafficking and accumulation of F508 CFTR within the ER.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Thus it appears that the consequences of mistrafficking of F508 are sufficient to activate NF-B in CHO cells.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	189	In epithelial cells, unlike CHO cells, there appears to be a requirement for normal CFTR function in regulating NF-B-dependent gene transcription.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	190	 The homozygous F508 or the compound F508/W1282X mutation could activate NF-B by two independent mechanisms: cell stress associated with mistrafficking or effects directly due to lack of CFTR Cl channel activity.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Cell lines that lack CFTR Cl function due to either the overproduction of the CFTR R-domain or the expression of CFTR antisense had activated NF-B and significant amounts of endogenous IL-8 production compared with the corresponding control cell lines.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	192	 The amount of IL-8 endogenously expressed by these cell lines was greater than that of the IB3 or C38 cells and could be quantified by a standard ELISA assay.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	193	 The presence of the p65 component of NF-B in nuclei of undisturbed cells grown on coverslips as well as the relative activation of an NF-B reporter construct compared with appropriate controls indicates that their activated state is unlikely to be an artifact of either cell transformation or manipulations occurring during cell culture.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Because neither the 9/HTEo/pCep-R or the 16HBE/cftr antisense cells have excessive CFTR accumulation in the ER, the lack of CFTR Cl channel function in these epithelial cells appears to be responsible for the observed increase in NF-B activation and IL-8 expression.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	195	Exactly how CFTR dysfunction contributes to the activation and nuclear localization of NF-B is unclear.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	196	 There are multiple mechanisms for NF-B activation that can be divided into signal-dependent and signal-independent pathways (20).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	197	 In airway epithelial cells, bacterial attachment to asialo-GM1 activates a Ca2+-dependent signaling pathway that results in NF-B activation and IL-8 transcription through a cascade that includes phosphorylation of both the p38 and extracellular signal-regulated kinase families of mitogen-activated protein kinases (23a).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	198	 A signal-independent pathway, perhaps involving IB or NF-B regulation directly, may be affected by mistrafficked CFTR.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	199	 IB- has been shown to be increased in IB3 cells under basal conditions and is hypophosphorylated, enabling nuclear NF-B with bound IB- complexes to direct transcription (30).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Hypophosphorylated IB- may be involved in either signal-dependent or the persistent activation of NF-B (26).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Diminished levels of cytosolic IB- was associated with CF (F508/F508) bronchial gland cells in primary culture and correlated with the presence of nuclear NF-B Rel A (27).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	202	 It is possible that CFTR function, perhaps by affecting pH in specific intracellular compartments (3), affects relevant kinase or phosphatase activity.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Abnormalities in signal transducer and activator of transduction-1 phosphorylation in the same 9/HTEo/pCep-R cells have been described recently (13), indicating that CFTR may have a role in multiple signaling pathways.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	204	 These observations reflect the complexities of CFTR involvement in the normal physiology of the epithelial cell.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Strategies such as gene therapy to correct CFTR Cl channel function alone, which do not ameliorate the effects of mutant CFTR mistrafficking in the majority of airway epithelial cells, may not be sufficient to control the inflammatory component of CF lung disease.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	206	These consequences of CFTR dysfunction in activating translocation of NF-B and stimulating the expression of proinflammatory cytokines are important in not only understanding the many roles of CFTR in normal cell physiology but are also clinically relevant.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	207	 The majority of CF patients with the most common F508 CFTR alleles have multiple reasons for increased expression of inflammatory mediators in their airways.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	208	 The effects of CFTR mistrafficking and ER stress, lack of CFTR Cl channel function, and exogenous stimulation due to airway infection all act to increase epithelial NF-B translocation and the expression of proinflammatory genes.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	209	 This epithelial immune activation does provide multiple targets for therapy.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	210	 It may be possible to devise a therapy to modulate the endogenous upregulation of NF-B-dependent gene transcription without compromising the epithelial barrier function or the host inflammatory response to exogenous airway pathogens.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	211	Expert technical assistance was provided by Robert Adamo.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	212	This work was supported by National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute Grants HL-56194 (to A.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Prince) and P50-HL-60293 (to P.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Davis, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, OH).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Imaging studies were performed in the Optical Microscopy Facility of the Herbert Irving Cancer Center at Columbia University (New York, NY), supported by National Center for Research Resources Grant 1-S10-RR-10506.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	216	Original submission in response to a special call for papers on "CFTR Trafficking and Signaling in Respiratory Epithelium.
