0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	316	00 Copyright   2001 the American Physiological Society.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	0	RAPID COMMUNICATION Syntaxin 1A inhibits regulated CFTR trafficking in Xenopus oocytes Kathryn W.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	1	Department of Cell Biology and Physiology, University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15261.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	2	    ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	3	The cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) is an epithelial cell Cl channel, whose gating activity and membrane trafficking are controlled by cAMP/protein kinase A (PKA)-mediated phosphorylation.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	4	 CFTR Cl currents are regulated also by syntaxin 1A (A.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Nature 390: 302-305, 1997), a protein best known for its role in membrane trafficking and neurosecretion.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	6	 To examine the mechanism of syntaxin 1A inhibition, we expressed these proteins in Xenopus oocytes and monitored agonist-induced changes in plasma membrane capacitance and cell surface fluorescence of CFTR that contains an external epitope tag.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	7	 cAMP stimulation elicited large increases in membrane capacitance and in cell surface labeling of flag-tagged CFTR.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Coexpression of CFTR with syntaxin 1A, but not syntaxin 3, inhibited cAMP-induced increases in membrane capacitance and plasma membrane CFTR content.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Injection of botulinum toxin/C1 rapidly reversed syntaxin's effects on current and capacitance, indicating that they cannot be explained by an effect on CFTR synthesis.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Functional expression of other integral membrane proteins, including Na-coupled glucose transporter hSGLT1, inwardly rectified K channel hIK1, P2Y2 nucleotide receptor, and viral hemagglutinin protein, was not affected by syntaxin 1A coexpression.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	11	 These findings indicate that acute regulation of the number of CFTR Cl channels in plasma membrane is one mechanism by which cAMP/PKA regulates Cl currents.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Inhibition of plasma membrane CFTR content by syntaxin 1A is consistent with the concept that syntaxin and other components of the SNARE machinery are involved in regulated trafficking of CFTR.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	13	membrane traffic; SNARE proteins; immunofluorescence; capacitance; cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	14	    INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	15	CYSTIC FIBROSIS IS CAUSED by mutations in the gene encoding the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR), which accounts for the cAMP-stimulated Cl conductance at the apical membranes of many secretory and absorptive epithelial cells (22).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Biochemical and electrophysiological studies have demonstrated that CFTR Cl channel activity requires protein kinase A (PKA)-mediated phosphorylation of its R-domain (18, 31) and binding and hydrolysis of ATP at one or both nucleotide binding domains (1, 23, 26).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	17	 In addition to facilitating CFTR Cl channel gating, cAMP/PKA stimulation of CFTR-expressing cells evokes changes in membrane trafficking.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	18	 cAMP stimulates exocytosis and inhibits endocytosis, and these regulated trafficking events require the expression of wild-type CFTR (5).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The close correlation observed between CFTR-dependent increases in Cl current and membrane capacitance suggests that CFTR resides in the membrane vesicles whose trafficking is influenced by cAMP-dependent agonists (25, 30).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Accordingly, Cl current stimulation by cAMP/PKA may arise from increases in channel open probability (Po) and/or from increases in the number (N) of active CFTR Cl channels residing in the plasma membrane.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	21	Results of recent studies have implicated a role for membrane traffic regulatory proteins in the control of CFTR Cl currents.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	22	 (20) showed that syntaxin 1A is expressed in colonic secretory epithelial cells, and they detected an interaction between CFTR and syntaxin 1A using in vitro protein binding assays (21).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Coexpression of syntaxin 1A with CFTR in Xenopus oocytes inhibited cAMP-stimulated Cl currents, and this inhibition could be reversed by the syntaxin binding protein, munc-18.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	24	 They proposed that syntaxin 1A and munc-18 regulate CFTR, and thus Cl secretion, at the apical membranes of secretory epithelial cells.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	25	Using measurements of plasma membrane capacitance and cell surface expression of CFTR, we demonstrate here that syntaxin 1A expression interferes with cAMP/PKA-regulated CFTR trafficking.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	26	 We used epitope-tagged CFTR to show that cAMP stimulation elicits an increase in plasma membrane CFTR content, which is paralleled by a cAMP-induced increase in plasma membrane capacitance.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Syntaxin 1A coexpression selectively inhibited the cAMP-induced increase in membrane capacitance and reduced the amount of CFTR detected in the plasma membrane.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	28	 This syntaxin-induced reduction in N is consistent with the role of this protein as a component of the membrane fusion machinery.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	29	    MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Oocyte isolations and RNA injections were performed as described previously (8, 11).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Xenopus laevis was obtained from Xenopus 1 (Ann Arbor, MI).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Oocytes were isolated surgically and follicular cells removed during a 60- to 90-min collagenase incubation (2 mg/ml, type 2; Worthington).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Stage 5-6 oocytes were maintained in a modified Barth's solution overnight before injection (50 nl vol) with cRNA for CFTR, syntaxin 1A, or syntaxin 3.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Noninjected oocytes served as controls.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Expression was allowed to proceed at 18 degrees C for 1-3 days before current recordings or immunofluorescence measurements were performed.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	36	 The ND-96 solution utilized for the current measurements contained (in mM) 96 NaCl, l KCl, 1.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Recordings of CFTR-dependent Cl current (ICl) and membrane capacitance (Cm) changes were performed as described in Ref.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Briefly, cells were impaled with two 3 M KCl-filled electrodes connected to a GeneClamp 500 amplifier (Axon Instruments, Foster City, CA) via Ag-AgCl pellet electrodes and referenced to the bath by an Ag-AgCl pellet.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Membrane potentials were allowed to stabilize before current and capacitance recordings.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The voltage clamp was controlled by an AD/DA interface board (AXOLAB 1100) using a PC-running software generated in the laboratory.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Membrane capacitance was calculated from the time course of current decay during a 10-mV hyperpolarizing voltage pulse.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	42	 The decay time constant was derived from a single exponential fit of the pulse currents, and Cm was calculated on-line as described (30).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Steady-state membrane currents were recorded at 60 mV; these inward currents reflect Cl flow through CFTR during stimulation by cAMP, as shown in prior studies (8, 11).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Values of ICl and Cm were obtained at 2-s intervals; steady-state values are given in the figures.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	45	 We used immunofluorescence techniques to monitor the expression of CFTR in the oocyte plasma membrane.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Cells were injected with cRNA encoding an epitope-tagged CFTR, which contains the flag epitope (DYKDDDK) inserted into the predicted fourth extracellular loop of CFTR, after amino acid position 901, and designated M2-901/CFTR.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Prior studies have shown that this flag-tagged CFTR behaves identically to its wild-type counterpart during macroscopic current stimulation (13), and single channel measurements detect no difference in channel gating or PKA/ATP regulation relative to wild-type CFTR (24).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	48	M2-901/CFTR-expressing oocytes were subjected to a staining protocol to quantitate CFTR protein expression at the cell surface using the monoclonal M2 antibody (Kodak).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Oocytes were cooled rapidly to 0-4 degrees C and incubated with M2 antibody overnight at this temperature (1:1,250 dilution).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	50	 After they were washed with 5% FCS-ND-96, oocytes were incubated at 4 degrees C in fluorescein-conjugated goat anti-mouse IgG (1:100 dilution) and then washed five times as above.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	51	 This protocol avoids permeabilization or fixation conditions that might expose intracellular flag-CFTR to the M2 antibody.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Thus the staining conditions and epitope position were selected to permit detection of M2-901/CFTR only when it is localized in the plasma membrane and the epitope is exposed at the cell surface.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	53	 For some experiments, CFTR Cl currents were recorded from M2-901/CFTR-expressing oocytes before implementing the staining protocol.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	54	 This permitted CFTR Cl currents and cell surface expression to be determined in the same cells.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	55	 In other experiments, oocytes were fixed and permeabilized to assess total flag-CFTR labeling using ice-cold Caltag reagents (proprietary).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Cells were immersed in 200  microl medium A for 15 min, washed once in 5% BSA-C (Aurion)/ND-96, and placed in 200  microl medium B for 30 min.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	57	 After three washes in BSA-C/ND-96, they were subjected to the staining protocol described above.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	58	Individual oocytes were scanned on a Molecular Dynamics multiprobe 2001 laser confocal microscope at  x 10 magnification using 10- microm optical sections.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Sections were scanned at 512  x  512 pixels (488 nm laser, 510 nm primary beam splitter, 510 nm secondary beam splitter).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Control (uninjected) oocytes were scanned to set the fluorescence background; the laser intensity and voltage were set accordingly.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Image planes throughout the depth of the specimen were collected.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	62	 A quantitative measure of protein expression at the surface of the oocyte was derived from a maximal intensity rendered image.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The periphery of the image was delineated and the mean pixel intensity calculated.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	64	 cRNAs were transcribed in vitro using the Message Machine kit (Ambion) from linearized plasmids.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Rat syntaxin cDNAs were kindly provided by the laboratory of Dr.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Richard Scheller (Stanford University, Stanford, CA).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Their expression was confirmed by immunoprecipitation of 35-kDa proteins from oocytes expressing syntaxin 1A or syntaxin 3 (data not shown).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Plasmids encoding the control proteins (see Fig.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	69	 5) were gifts of the laboratories of Drs.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Ernst Wright (University of California, Los Angeles, CA), John Edelman (Vollum Institute), and David Julius (University of California, San Francisco, CA).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Botulinum toxin/C1 (BoT/C1) was obtained from Wako Chemical Industries (Japan) and injected in 25-nl PBS.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	72	 All results are expressed as means  plus or minus  SE.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	73	    RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	74	cAMP increases plasma membrane CFTR.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Figure 1 shows composite images of intact, nonpermeabilized oocytes expressing epitope-tagged M2-901/CFTR (Fig.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	76	 A representative image from a control, noninjected oocyte is displayed in Fig.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	77	 CFTR currents and cell surface fluorescence were determined 2-3 days after cRNA injection.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	78	 In noninjected oocytes, background fluorescence was low (Fig.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Oocytes expressing M2-901/CFTR under nonstimulated conditions showed low levels of surface staining that were slightly above background, suggesting a low level of CFTR expression in the plasma membrane in the absence of agonist stimulation (Fig.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	80	 M2-901/CFTR oocytes stimulated with forskolin/IBMX for 15 min showed a large and significant increase in surface fluorescence (Fig.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	81	 The low fluorescence intensity detected in the absence of agonist suggests that the staining protocol does not permit access of the M2 antibody to intracellular epitope.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	82	 In assays performed on permeabilized oocytes, the addition of forskolin/IBMX had no influence on fluorescence intensity using the same labeling conditions (CFTR basal, 25.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	83	 This result indicates that recognition of the flag epitope by the M2 antibody does not require CFTR stimulation.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	84	View larger version (82K):    Fig.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	85	   Effect of cAMP stimulation on cell surface cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Confocal images and fluorescence intensities of oocytes injected with M2-901/CFTR cRNA (1 ng) or water were obtained as described in MATERIALS AND METHODS.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	87	 A: noninjected control; scale bar, 200  microm.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	88	 B: nonstimulated oocyte expressing M2-901/CFTR.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	89	 C: M2-901/CFTR-expressing oocyte stimulated with 10  microM forskolin + 1 mM IBMX for 15 min.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	90	 D: mean fluorescence intensity and current (60 mV); results from 3 experiments with 8 oocytes treated as in B and C.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Intensity values are corrected for background fluorescence intensity (18  plus or minus  2) recorded from noninjected oocytes (n = 5).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	92	Average data from three experiments in nonpermeabilized oocytes are provided in Fig.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Also shown are the results from parallel measurements of steady-state current obtained before and after addition of forskolin/IBMX; these values are consistent with the magnitude of CFTR current stimulation observed in prior studies (8, 11).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	94	 The immunofluorescence data indicate that the increase in Cl current is paralleled by an increase in plasma membrane CFTR.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	95	 For oocytes in the stimulation group, the staining protocol was initiated 15 min after addition of forskolin/IBMX, the time when Cl currents rise to their plateau level.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Thus detection of the M2 epitope at the cell surface occurs within the time frame required for the cAMP-induced increases in Cl current and membrane capacitance (30).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	97	 These findings are consistent with the idea that cAMP/PKA stimulation induces the insertion of CFTR-containing vesicles into the plasma membrane.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	98	Syntaxin 1A inhibits cAMP/PKA-induced increases in plasma membrane capacitance and CFTR.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	99	 The effects on ICl and Cm of syntaxin coexpression with CFTR are illustrated in Fig.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	100	 When syntaxin 1A was coexpressed with CFTR, Cl current stimulation by cAMP was inhibited, as reported by Naren et al.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	101	 In parallel with the syntaxin-induced reduction in Cl current, cAMP stimulation of membrane capacitance is also markedly inhibited.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	102	 The inhibition of changes in both ICl (ICl) and Cm (Cm) is selective for syntaxin 1A.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Coexpression of syntaxin 3 with CFTR did not affect these parameters significantly, suggesting that these effects are syntaxin isoform specific.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	104	 This finding also eliminates translational competition between the CFTR and syntaxin cRNAs as an explanation of the inhibitory effect of syntaxin 1A on the agonist-induced ICl and Cm.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	105	View larger version (23K):    Fig.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	106	   Effect of syntaxin coexpression on current (ICl, 60 mV) and capacitance (Cm) responses to cAMP stimulation.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Oocytes were injected with cRNA for CFTR (1 ng) and/or syntaxin 1A or 3 (Syn1A and Syn3, respectively; 5 ng).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Steady-state values of ICl and Cm were obtained during stimulation by 10  microM forskolin and 1 mM IBMX (n = 5, each group).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Similar levels of inhibition of current and capacitance were obtained with syntaxin 1A doses ranging between 1 and 20 ng (with CFTR constant at 1 ng, data not shown).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	110	The effect of syntaxin 1A coexpression on CFTR detected at the oocyte surface during cAMP/PKA stimulation is illustrated in Fig.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	111	 1C, these images were collected from oocytes stimulated with maximally effective concentrations of forskolin and IBMX (see legend to Fig.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	112	 The noninjected control oocyte illustrates the background level of cell surface staining in the presence of agonists (Fig.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	113	 This low fluorescence intensity indicates that cAMP stimulation does not increase background fluorescence in the absence of CFTR expression (compare with Fig.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	114	 During cAMP stimulation, M2-901/CFTR was readily detected in the surface membrane (Fig.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	115	 3B), but coexpression with syntaxin 1A markedly reduced plasma membrane CFTR during cAMP stimulation (Fig.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	116	 This result is consistent with the syntaxin 1A-induced decrease in cAMP-dependent Cm, shown in Fig.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	117	 As with the membrane capacitance and current responses, syntaxin 3 coexpression had no effect on cell surface CFTR staining (data not shown).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Quantitation of the results from four experiments (Fig.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	119	 3D) shows that CFTR surface expression correlates with the magnitude of currents recorded from the same oocytes before antibody labeling.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	120	 With syntaxin 1A coexpression, cell surface CFTR fluorescence intensity fell nearly to the level of the water-injected controls.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Thus insertion of CFTR into the plasma membrane is required for activation of the CFTR Cl currents recorded from these cells during stimulation, and syntaxin 1A reduces CFTR Cl currents by decreasing the amount of CFTR in the plasma membrane during stimulation.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	122	View larger version (62K):    Fig.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	123	   Effect of syntaxin 1A on cell surface CFTR during cAMP stimulation.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Oocyte injections: no RNA (A); M2-901/CFTR cRNA (B; 1 ng); M2-901/CFTR + syntaxin 1A cRNA (C; 5 ng).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	125	 All oocytes were exposed to 10  microM forskolin + 1 mM IBMX for 15 min before labeling.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Small adherent air bubbles produced nonstained areas, as in B; such areas were  < 5% of oocyte image area.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	127	 D: Mean current (60 mV) and fluorescence intensity measured sequentially in same oocytes.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Results from 4 experiments with 16 oocytes treated as in B and C.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Values corrected for background intensity (23  plus or minus  2) of water-injected controls (n = 10).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	130	The effects of BoT/C1 on CFTR ICl and Cm with and without syntaxin 1A coexpression are shown in Fig.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	131	 We injected BoT/C1 60 min before recording the current and capacitance responses to forskolin/IBMX.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	132	 BoT/C1 acutely reversed the syntaxin 1A inhibition of ICl and Cm, presumably due to cleavage of syntaxin 1A.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	133	 The toxin did not interfere with the ICl or Cm responses in oocytes injected with CFTR alone.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	134	 This relatively rapid reversal of CFTR function argues against an effect of syntaxin on the level of CFTR protein expression as an explanation for the inhibitory effect on CFTR current or capacitance.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	135	 For comparison, the half time for inhibition of CFTR currents in oocytes by brefeldin A is ~6 h (data not shown).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	136	 This finding indicates that the steady-state rates of CFTR production and degradation in these cells are not sufficiently rapid for protein synthesis to account for the BoT/C1 reversal of syntaxin's effects on CFTR.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	137	View larger version (28K):    Fig.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	138	   Effect of botulinum toxin C1 (BoT/C1) on current (ICl) and capacitance (Cm) responses to cAMP stimulation.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Oocytes were injected with 1 ng BoT/C1 60 min before recording.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	140	 2; results are from 3 experiments with at least 8 oocytes/group.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	141	Finally, we examined the influence of syntaxin coexpression on the activities of several other plasma membrane transport or receptor proteins.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	142	 These control experiments were performed to examine the possibility that syntaxin 1A may block the functional expression of CFTR by generally interfering with the migration of proteins through the biosynthetic pathway leading to the plasma membrane.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	143	 cRNA amounts were selected based on prior reports using these constructs (see references below), and the currents obtained are similar in magnitude.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Coexpression of syntaxin 1A with the Na-dependent glucose transporter SGLT1 (12), the ATP-sensitive Ca-activated K channel IK1 (14), or the P2Y2 purinergic receptor (17) had no effect on the currents associated with activation of these proteins (Fig.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	145	 5, see legend for activation conditions).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	146	 In addition, syntaxin 1A did not inhibit plasma membrane expression of the viral hemagglutinin (HA) protein at the oocyte surface, which was detected by immunofluorescence using techniques similar to those used for detection of cell surface M2-901/CFTR [background-subtracted HA fluorescence intensities: HA alone, 24.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	147	1 (n = 6); HA + syntaxin 1A, 29.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	148	0 (n = 5); cRNAs: 5 ng HA, 10 ng syntaxin 1A].
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	149	 These data show that syntaxin 1A does not impair HA protein expression, even when the cRNA dose ratio is in favor of syntaxin 1A.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	150	 In addition, relative protein expression level for hIK1 can be judged from the current, which is comparable with that obtained from CFTR (compare Figs.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Because the single-channel current amplitude and Po of hIK1 are greater than those of CFTR (12), a similar macroscopic current requires the expression of less protein.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Despite this, hIK1 currents were not inhibited by syntaxin 1A, even at five times the dose required for maximal inhibition of CFTR (see legends to Figs.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Accordingly, syntaxin 1A is not simply disrupting the expression and targeting of integral plasma membrane proteins, rather its inhibitory effect was specific for CFTR.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	154	View larger version (22K):    Fig.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	155	   Effect of syntaxin coexpression on activity of other plasma membrane proteins.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Numbers in parentheses indicate cRNA amounts injected/oocyte.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	157	 A: Na-coupled glucose transporter hSGLT1 (50 ng); syntaxin 1A (5 ng).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Inward Na current at 100 mV evoked by addition of 5 mM -methyl-D-glycoside to the bath.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	159	 B: inward rectifier K channel (hIK1; 50 ng); syntaxins 1A or 3 (10 ng).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Inward K current at 100 mV evoked by bath addition of 1  microM ionomycin.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	161	 C: current-voltage relationship for endogenous Cl current elicited by P2Y2 nucleotide receptor (5 ng) activation by bath addition of 100  microM UTP; syntaxin 1A (5 ng).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	162	 See text for citations and other details.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	163	    DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	164	In a previous study (30), we showed that cAMP stimulation increased both Cl current and membrane capacitance in CFTR-expressing Xenopus oocytes.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	165	 These effects were reversible with agonist washout and required CFTR expression.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Changes in ICl and Cm were closely correlated with one another as the agonist dose or CFTR expression level were varied, or when CFTR mutants with different ICl responses were expressed.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	167	 The increase in cell surface area detected by Cm was confirmed by morphometry of the oocyte surface in the same cells used for electrical recordings (30).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	168	 This close correlation between ICl and Cm suggests that CFTR activation by cAMP/PKA elicits reversible stimulation of membrane vesicle insertion into the plasma membrane, a process that is implicated in a variety of CFTR-expressing cells (4).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	169	The results obtained from oocytes expressing an epitope-tagged CFTR verify this concept.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Incorporation of an extracellular flag epitope permits detection of CFTR protein at the surface of nonpermeabilized cells (13).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	171	 This approach obviates problems of resolving protein localization in the plasma membrane, since standard immunofluorescence techniques do not have sufficient resolution to distinguish protein in 100-nm submembrane vesicles from that in the plasma membrane.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	172	 CFTR bearing a flag tag in its fourth extracellular loop was not detected appreciably at the surface of oocytes under basal, nonstimulated conditions, when CFTR Cl currents are near zero (Fig.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	173	 cAMP stimulation increased plasma membrane CFTR sevenfold within the time frame associated with stimulation of ICl and Cm (~15 min, Figs.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Control experiments indicated that M2 antibody staining of noninjected oocytes was not affected by cAMP stimulation, i.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	175	, the surface labeling signal is CFTR and stimulation dependent.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	176	 The correlations between cAMP-stimulated CFTR current, capacitance, and cell surface labeling show that CFTR insertion by exocytosis is an important event in the stimulation of plasma membrane Cl conductance of these cells by cAMP.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	177	The oocyte has proven to be a useful model for studies of other transporter-related membrane-trafficking events.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Previous studies include relocation of -aminobutyric acid transporters to the plasma membrane in response to protein kinase C activation (7) and regulation of the cell surface expression of several Na-dependent cotransport processes by protein kinases A and C (12).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	179	 In addition, the influence of mutations in the amiloride-sensitive Na channel (ENaC), which produce hypertension by prolonging the plasma membrane residency time of ENaC, was characterized mechanistically using the oocyte expression system (28).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	180	The biochemical events that control membrane insertion and retrieval processes at the plasma membrane are thought to conform to principles first identified for vesicle transit among compartments of the protein biosynthetic pathway (2, 29).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Interactions among proteins that comprise the soluble N-ethylmaleimide-sensitive factor attachment protein target receptor (SNARE) protein complex control the targeting, docking, fusion, and retrieval of membrane vesicles that contain secretory products or integral membrane proteins, like CFTR, that will become constituents of the plasma membrane.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	182	 The physiological importance of SNARE proteins is exemplified in the highly regulated process of neurosecretion; our understanding of the actions of these proteins in membrane-trafficking events in epithelial cells is relatively meager.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	183	Our findings implicate a role for syntaxin in regulated CFTR trafficking.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Coexpression of CFTR with syntaxin 1A reduced the cAMP-dependent membrane insertion event that is detected as an increase in membrane capacitance (Fig.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Syntaxin also blocked the increase in plasma membrane CFTR that occurs during stimulation of its activity by cAMP/PKA (Fig.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	186	 CFTR was not detected at significant levels in the plasma membrane under basal conditions (Fig.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	187	 1), and it was not present appreciably at the cell surface during cAMP stimulation in cells coexpressing syntaxin 1A.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	188	 These effects were specific for CFTR, as opposed to other integral membrane proteins examined, they were selective for this syntaxin isoform, and they could not be explained by an effect of syntaxin on CFTR synthesis.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Taken together, these findings indicate that syntaxin 1A interferes with cAMP/PKA-stimulated trafficking of CFTR to the cell surface.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	190	What is the mechanism of this effect? The results of Naren et al.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	191	 (20, 21) suggest that CFTR Cl currents are inhibited due to a physical interaction between these proteins.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	192	 A protein-protein interaction has been observed also between N-type Ca channels and syntaxin 1A (27), which may contribute to syntaxin-associated downregulation of Ca currents (3, 32).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Assuming that a physical interaction occurs between syntaxin 1A and CFTR in vivo, expressed syntaxin 1A may prevent CFTR insertion into the plasma membrane by binding with CFTR contained in vesicles that would normally fuse with the plasma membrane.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Second, a CFTR-syntaxin 1A complex may be retrieved rapidly from the plasma membrane by endocytosis.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Our measurements detect net membrane area (Cm) or steady-state plasma membrane CFTR and do not distinguish whether the effect of syntaxin is on insertion or retrieval of CFTR.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	196	It is possible also that overexpressed syntaxin associates primarily not with CFTR but with other SNARE components to block the membrane fusion process.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	197	 According to this view, syntaxin 1A overexpression would disrupt the stoichiometric interactions among SNARE proteins that are required for the plasma membrane fusion of CFTR-containing vesicles.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	198	 This effect of expressed syntaxin has been observed previously.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	199	 For example, exogenous expression of the Golgi t-SNARE, syntaxin 5, inhibited protein traffic from endoplasmic reticulum to Golgi, the step in which this syntaxin isoform functions (9).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Likewise, expression of syntaxin 1A, but not 1B, blocked glucose-stimulated insulin secretion in pancreatic  cells (19).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	201	 In MDCK cells, syntaxin 3 is apically localized, and its exogenous expression selectively inhibited apical targeting and apical recycling of the immunoglobulin receptor (16).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	202	 These findings suggest that overexpression of a specific syntaxin isoform disrupts the pathway in which that isoform normally plays a role in membrane-trafficking events.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	203	 If this is true, then our results suggest that endogenous SNARE proteins, including a Xenopus syntaxin 1A ortholog, are responsible for cAMP-regulated plasma membrane CFTR insertion in oocytes.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Expression of the core components of the SNARE machinery has been observed in the cortical granules of sea urchin oocytes (6).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Accordingly, the SNARE fusion machinery would be employed to mediate the membrane insertion of CFTR, and an interaction of CFTR with SNARE proteins could explain how the expression of CFTR alone can confer cAMP-dependent membrane-trafficking events on cells where none was present before CFTR expression (5, 30).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	206	The requirement for specific SNARE components in this process could also account for the apparent failure of certain cell types to support regulated CFTR-trafficking events (10, 15).
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	207	 The demonstration that syntaxin 1A is expressed in colonic secretory cells (1) is consistent with the concept that this protein, together with other components of the SNARE machinery, mediates the cAMP/PKA-regulated insertion of CFTR into the apical membranes of these cells.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Although our findings suggest that the SNARE machinery plays an important role in the regulated trafficking of CFTR at the plasma membrane, they do not rule out a direct regulation of CFTR's gating (Po) that could result from a physical interaction with syntaxin.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Accordingly, syntaxin could directly regulate CFTR Cl currents, perhaps in relation to SNARE protein-mediated membrane-trafficking reactions that control the amount of CFTR present in the plasma membrane.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Qi contributed equally to this work.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	211	We thank Megan Weiss for technical assistance, Patricia Connelly for help with the manuscript, and the laboratory of Richard Scheller for syntaxin cDNAs.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	212	This research was supported by National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases Grant DK-50829 and by the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation Grants 97RO and 96PO.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	213	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	214	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	215	  1734 solely to indicate this fact.
