0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	278	Am J Physiol Cell Physiol 277(1):C174-C180 0002-9513/99 $5.
0.48486084.10409120.html.plaintext.txt	279	00 Copyright   1999 the American Physiological Society.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	0	Proliferation, not apoptosis, alters epithelial cell migration in small intestine of CFTR null mice Ann Marie Gallagher and Roberta A.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	1	Department of Molecular and Experimental Medicine, The Scripps Research Institute, La Jolla, California 92037.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	2	    ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	3	Expression of a mutated cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) has been shown to enhance proliferation within CF airways, and cells expressing a mutated CFTR have been shown to be less susceptible to apoptosis.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Because the CFTR is expressed in the epithelial cells lining the gastrointestinal tract and all CF mouse models are characterized by gastrointestinal obstruction, we hypothesized that CFTR null mice would have increased epithelial cell proliferation and reduced apoptosis within the small intestine.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	5	 The rate of intestinal epithelial cell migration from crypt to villus was increased in CFTR null mice relative to mice expressing the wild-type CFTR.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	6	 This difference in migration could be explained by an increase in epithelial cell proliferation but not by a difference in apoptosis within the crypts of Lieberkuhn.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	7	 In addition, using two independent sets of CF cell lines, we found that epithelial cell susceptibility to apoptosis was unrelated to the presence of a functional CFTR.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Thus increased proliferation but not alterations in apoptosis within epithelial cells might contribute to the pathophysiology of CF.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	9	cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator; animal model; pathophysiology.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	10	    INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	11	THE CYSTIC FIBROSIS TRANSMEMBRANE conductance regulator (CFTR) is a chloride channel that is mutated in CF.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Mutation of the CFTR results in a decrease in epithelial cell chloride permeability.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Although the defect affects all exocrine tissues, in humans it manifests itself primarily in the airways and intestine.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	14	 CF is characterized by reduced chloride and fluid secretion, which results in accumulation of mucus within the bronchioles and in meconium ileus in CF newborns and intestinal obstructions in older CF patients.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	15	 In all mouse models of CF in which the CFTR has been deleted by insertional or deletional mutagenesis, intestinal pathophysiology is characterized by mucus accumulation in the crypts of Lieberkuhn, goblet cell hyperplasia, and intestinal obstruction.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	16	 In addition, the CFTR is expressed in the epithelial cells lining the gastrointestinal tract with a reduction in expression along the crypt-to-villus axis (7, 26).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	17	Previously, Gottlieb and Dosanjh (9) showed that cultured C127 mouse mammary epithelial cells stably transfected with the F508-mutated CFTR remained viable and were less susceptible to apoptosis induced by cycloheximide or etoposide than cells expressing the wild-type CFTR.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Programmed cell death, or apoptosis, is a physiologically relevant process that occurs in regenerating tissues such as the lung and intestine.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Cell turnover is a balance between proliferation and elimination, and cell proliferation has been shown to be greater in airway epithelia and nasal polyps in CF patients than in tissue from non-CF patients (12, 15).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Although this phenomenon has traditionally been attributed to inflammation, the possibility that the proliferative differences might be due to differential expression of the CFTR has not been addressed.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	21	Because all mouse models of CF (CFTR /) develop intestinal obstructions (10) and the CFTR is expressed in epithelial cells lining the gastrointestinal tract, we hypothesized that the CFTR / mouse intestine would show evidence of altered apoptosis and/or enhanced proliferation relative to mice expressing the wild-type CFTR.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	22	 The hypothesis was tested in vivo using a knockout mouse model of CF.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Mice expressing a mutant CFTR were found to have a greater rate of migration of epithelial cells up the crypt-villus axis within the small intestine.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	24	 This increased rate could be attributed to an increase in the proliferative capacity of cells within the crypts of Lieberkuhn but not to differences in apoptosis.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Because these current results contradict the previous findings (9) of differences in apoptosis between cells transfected with the F508 CFTR and the wild-type CFTR, studies were extended to further examine apoptosis in two independent cell culture models of CF.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	26	    METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	27	A mouse model of CF generated by Dr.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Beverly Koller (University of North Carolina) was used for all studies (3).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	29	 In this model (cftrtm1Unc), the CFTR gene has been disrupted by gene targeting, and as with all mouse models of CF, the animals develop intestinal obstructions and typically die within weeks of birth.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	30	 However, by replacing the drinking water with Colyte (Schwarz Pharma, Milwaukee, WI), a commercially available electrolyte solution containing 6% polyethylene glycol, the mice remain alive past 18 mo of age (10).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Animals were maintained within the custom breeding colony at The Scripps Research Institute with all animals receiving Colyte in place of drinking water.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	32	 At the time of weaning, the genotypes of all mice were determined by isolation of tail DNA and PCR amplification of the CFTR alleles as described previously by Koller et al.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	33	 All animal studies adhered to approved institutional animal protocols and American Association for Accreditation of Laboratory Animal Care guidelines.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	34	Bromodeoxyuridine (BrdU; Sigma Chemical, St.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Louis, MO) was suspended in PBS at 20 mg/ml and administered via intraperitoneal injection at 150  microg/g body wt.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	36	 The mice were killed by halothane overdose 2-48 h after BrdU injection.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	37	 The small intestine was isolated and excised, rinsed in PBS, splayed open along its length, and rinsed twice to remove contents.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	38	 The splayed intestine was fixed in Z-Fix (10% buffered formalin containing zinc; Anatech, Battle Creek, MI), coiled from proximal to distal end to form a "Swiss roll," dehydrated, and embedded in paraffin for tissue sectioning.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Tissue sections of Swiss rolls allow for examination of the entire length of the intestine in a single section.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	40	 BrdU incorporation on Swiss rolls was analyzed by immunohistochemistry.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Briefly, 3- microm-thick tissue sections were cleared of paraffin and rehydrated through graded alcohols.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Endogenous peroxidase activity was blocked by 0.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	43	3% hydrogen peroxide in methanol for 15 min at room temperature.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	44	1 N HCl, 15 min at 37 degrees C), tissue was treated with 2 N HCl for 30 min at 37 degrees C and rinsed in 0.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Tissue sections were incubated with anti-BrdU (Sigma Chemical) at 1:500 in 20% normal goat serum (90 min at 37 degrees C).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Incubation with biotinylated goat anti-mouse IgG (1:2,000 in PBS containing 1 mg/ml IgG-free BSA; Caltag, Burlingame, CA) for 60 min at room temperature was followed by enzymatic labeling with horseradish peroxidase-conjugated streptavidin (1:1,000 in PBS/BSA, 30 min at room temperature; Caltag).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	47	01% H2O2 were used for color development.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Tissues were counterstained with Gill's hematoxylin (Fisher Scientific, Pittsburgh, PA), dehydrated through graded alcohols, and placed on a coverslip with Permount (Fisher Scientific).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	49	Epithelial cell migration was evaluated in CFTR +/ and CFTR / mice by measuring the distance between the base of the intestinal crypts at the most distal Paneth cell along the epithelial cells to each BrdU-positive nuclei within the crypt-villus structure.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	50	 The investigator was blinded to animal identification and time after BrdU injection.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Through the use of a  x 20 objective on a Nikon TE300 microscope and a Spot Diagnostics Instruments digital camera (Sterling Heights, MI), 5 to 24 crypt-villus structures were captured for each animal and analyzed using MetaMorph imaging software (Universal Imaging, West Chester, PA).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Three individual time courses for BrdU migration were performed for a total of 20 animals (3 animals/genotype at 2 and 24 h, 4 mice/genotype at 48 h).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	53	 ANOVA was used to assess whether there was a genotypic difference in migration rate, and a two-tailed t-test was utilized to determine if there was a difference in distance of migration at 48 h after BrdU injection.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	54	Spontaneous and Induced Epithelial Cell Apoptosis.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	55	In situ terminal deoxynucleotidyltransferase dUTP nick-end labeling (TUNEL) has been found to be unreliable as a method of detecting apoptosis in the gastrointestinal tract (21).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Therefore, a method previously described by Potten (21) in which apoptosis is quantified by calculating the percentage of cells with condensed and/or fragmented nuclei within the first 10 cells following the Paneth cells in the crypts of Lieberkuhn was used to quantify apoptosis in the small intestine of CFTR mice.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Crypts were scored by an investigator blinded to the identity of animals that met the following criteria: 1) Paneth cells could be viewed, 2) the crypt lumen could be seen, and 3) a minimum of 10 nonoverlapping epithelial cells in the crypt column could be distinguished.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Levels of spontaneous apoptosis were evaluated in control animals.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Whole body cesium gamma irradiation was used to induce apoptosis in the small intestine of CFTR mice in an attempt to uncover genotypic differences in susceptibility to apoptosis.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	60	 An initial dose-response curve using CFTR +/ mice revealed that significant epithelial cell apoptosis could be seen 3 h after whole body cesium gamma irradiation with 100 rads.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Higher doses of gamma irradiation did not result in detection of more apoptotic cells.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Therefore, subsequent experiments were performed with a dose of 100 rads, and the animals were killed 3 h after gamma irradiation.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Following fixation and sectioning as described above, intestinal tissue was deparaffinized, stained with hematoxylin, and placed on a coverslip with Permount.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	64	 The average number of apoptotic nuclei was determined in a minimum of 50 crypts/animal in 18 CFTR / mice (8 control, 10 irradiated) and 14 each of +/ and +/+ mice (5 control, 9 irradiated) and expressed as a percentage of the first 10 crypt cells.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	65	 ANOVA was used to test whether irradiation increased intestinal cell apoptosis, and two-tailed t-tests were used to determine the statistical significance of irradiation within each genotype.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	66	Intestinal Epithelial Cell Proliferation.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	67	Immunohistochemical detection of proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) was evaluated within the crypts of control (nonirradiated, no BrdU) CFTR mice by an investigator blinded to animal identity.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Tissues were acquired and processed as described above, and paraffin-embedded Swiss rolls were dewaxed and rehydrated through graded alcohols.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Tissues were incubated with Target retrieval solution (DAKO, Carpinteria, CA) at 95 degrees C for 20 min and at room temperature for an additional 20 min.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Endogenous peroxidase activity was blocked by 0.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	71	3% hydrogen peroxide in methanol before incubation with anti-PCNA (clone PC10, DAKO) for 90 min at 37 degrees C in 20% normal goat serum.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	72	 After rinsing with PBS, tissue was incubated with biotinylated goat anti-mouse IgG (Caltag) suspended 1:2,000 in PBS containing 1 mg/ml IgG-free BSA.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	73	 After 30 min incubation with horseradish peroxidase-conjugated streptavidin (Caltag), color was developed with SigmaFast diaminobenzidine (0.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	74	2 mg/ml urea-H2O2), counterstained with hematoxylin, dehydrated through alcohols, and placed on a coverslip with Permount.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Proliferation was evaluated by determining the average number of PCNA-positive cells present within the first 10 cells following the Paneth cells in a minimum of 25 crypts/animal.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Twelve animals (17) were used to determine if there was a genotypic difference in epithelial cell proliferation.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	77	 A two-tailed t-test was used to determine statistical significance.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	78	 C127 mouse mammary epithelial cells stably transfected with the wild-type CFTR or the CFTR with the deletion of phenylalanine at position 508 (C127 F508) were obtained from Dr.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Denning (Howard Hughes Medical Institute, University of Iowa College of Medicine) (4).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	80	 These cells were grown in DMEM (GIBCO BRL, Rockville, MD) supplemented with 10% FBS (HyClone, Logan, UT), penicillin, streptomycin, and Fungizone (Sigma Chemical) and passaged 1:5 two times per week.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	81	 The cell lines were grown in the presence of Geneticin (500  microg/ml; GIBCO BRL).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	82	 CFT1 cell lines, which were derived from tracheal epithelial cells isolated from a 24-year-old CF patient homozygous for the F508 mutation, were obtained from J.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Yankaskas (University of North Carolina).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The parental cell line (CFT1-C2) was used to establish the other three cell lines and has been immortalized with human papilloma virus.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	85	 CFT1-LCFSN cells overexpress the wild-type CFTR introduced by retroviral vector (20).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	86	 CFT1-F508 cells express an additional copy of the CFTR with the F508 mutation, and the CFT1-LC3 is a retroviral vector control cell line overexpressing the -galactosidase gene.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	87	 These cells were grown in Ham's F-12 (Fisher Scientific) supplemented with insulin (10  microg/ml), hydrocortisone (1  microM), endothelial cell growth supplement (ECGS; 3.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	88	75  microg/ml), epidermal growth factor (25 ng/ml), T3 (30 nM), transferrin (5  microg/ml), and cholera toxin (10 ng/ml) (all hormones were obtained from Sigma Chemical).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	89	 All cells, except the CFT1-C2 cells, were grown in the presence of Geneticin (500  microg/ml) and were passaged 1:3 two times per week.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	90	Membrane destabilization detected by YOPRO-1 uptake.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Cells were plated at 10,000 cells/well into 96-well tissue culture plates.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	92	 After 24 h, the medium was aspirated and replaced with 100  microl sterile PBS.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Cells were ultraviolet (UV) irradiated at 0-8,000 J/m2 using a Fisher Scientific UV crosslinker, the PBS was replaced with fresh medium, and the cells were incubated at 37 degrees C with 5% CO2.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	94	 After 16 h, 25  microM YOPRO-1 (10  microl) was added to each well and incubated at 37 degrees C for 10 min.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	95	 YOPRO-1 is taken up by cells with an unstable membrane and binds to double-strand DNA; therefore, apoptotic or necrotic cells will be labeled with YOPRO-1 (13).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	96	 With the use of a fluorescence plate reader (Bio-Tek Instruments, Winooski, VT), YOPRO-1 was found to be excited at 530 nm and emissions were detected at 480 nm.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Cells were lysed with 10  microl of lysis buffer (125 mM EDTA and 2.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	98	5% Nonidet P-40) and incubated at 37 degrees C with 5% CO2 for 30 min after which fluorescence was evaluated to determine the total number of cells per well.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	99	 The ratio of the first fluorescence (apoptotic and necrotic cells) to the second fluorescence (total cells) was taken to evaluate percent death and plotted against UV dose.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	100	Nuclear condensation and fragmentation.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Cells were plated at 30,000 cells/chamber into four-well chamber slides.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	102	 One cell type was plated per chamber slide with cells plated in the first and fourth chambers only.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	103	 After allowing the cells to adhere and reach ~80% confluence, the medium was aspirated and replaced with 500  microl sterile PBS.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	104	 One chamber (containing control cells) was covered with an opaque material to prevent irradiation while the chamber slide was irradiated at 2,000 J/m2.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	105	 The position of the control and irradiated cells was randomized to ensure that the analysis was done under blinded conditions.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	106	 The PBS was aspirated and replaced with fresh medium.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Cells were incubated at 37 degrees C with 5% CO2 for 6 h after which 37% formaldehyde was added to each chamber (final concentration: 3.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	108	 During fixation, the slides were centrifuged at 1,200 rpm for 15 min to ensure minimal loss of cells during the fixation procedure.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	109	 The cells were fixed for an additional 15 min, rinsed with PBS, and allowed to air dry.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	110	 At the time of analysis, 30  microM Hoechst no.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	111	 33342 in PBS were added to each chamber, slides were coverslipped, and a minimum of 300 cells/chamber were analyzed for nuclear condensation and fragmentation by fluorescence microscopy.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	112	 The percentage of fragmented and condensed nuclei from three separate experiments was obtained with the experimenter blinded to cell type and irradiation dose.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	113	To confirm that the mutated CFTR was responsible for the resistance to apoptosis, C127 F508 cells were infected with a CFTR adenovirus in an attempt to restore susceptibility to death in these cells.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	114	 C127 F508 cells were plated at 5,000 cells/well in a 96-well tissue culture plate and allowed to adhere overnight.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Preliminary studies with the -galactosidase adenovirus (Ad2/CMVgal-4, gift from Genzyme, Framingham, MA) showed that these cells were fairly resistant to infection by this adenovirus and required 20,000 infective units/cell for 95% infectivity.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Cells were infected with the 20,000 infective units of CFTR adenovirus (Ad2/CFTR-16, gift from Genzyme) suspended in DMEM containing 2% heat-inactivated FBS for 60 min at room temperature, followed by 48 h at 37 degrees C with 5% CO2.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	117	 After this infection, cells were UV irradiated and evaluated with YOPRO-1 as described above to determine susceptibility to death.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	118	 -Galactosidase adenovirus-infected and uninfected cells were used as negative controls.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	119	    RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	120	Mouse models of CF are consistent in their susceptibility to gastrointestinal obstruction; therefore, studies were designed to determine whether a nonfunctional CFTR alters the kinetics of epithelial cell migration within the gastrointestinal tract and ultimately might underlie the pathophysiology within the intestine.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	121	The rate of migration of BrdU-labeled cells up the crypt-villus axis is faster in CFTR / mice than in their CFTR +/ littermates (P = 0.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	122	 By 48 h, the distance that the epithelial cells from the CFTR / mice have migrated is significantly greater than the distance of migration in the CFTR +/ mouse intestine (P = 0.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Because epithelial cell migration from the crypts of Lieberkuhn up the intestinal villi is the net result of proliferation and apoptosis within the crypts, both components were evaluated separately to see if either or both are altered as a result of the expression of the mutant CFTR.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	124	 An increase in epithelial cell migration might occur if apoptosis is reduced and/or proliferation within the crypts of Lieberkuhn is increased.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	125	View larger version (12K):    Fig.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	126	   Intestinal epithelial cell migration in cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) / and CFTR +/ mice.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	127	 CFTR mice given an intraperitoneal injection of bromodeoxyuridine (BrdU) were killed 2-48 h after BrdU injection.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Cells that incorporated BrdU were localized immunohistochemically, and the distance from the base of the crypt of Lieberkuhn to each BrdU-positive cell was determined in 20 animals (3 animals/genotype were evaluated at 2 and 24 h and 4 animals/genotype were examined at 48 h).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	129	 BrdU-labeled epithelial cells from CFTR / mice migrate up the intestinal villi at a faster rate than do cells from CFTR +/ mice.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Each point represents the mean  plus or minus  SE of the most distal BrdU-positive cell for the animals in the group.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	131	 At 48 h after BrdU migration, the distance in migration is significantly different between the 2 genotypes (P = 0.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	132	Levels of spontaneous apoptosis are not different between CFTR genotypes, with CFTR / mice exhibiting 5.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	133	6% apoptosis within the crypts and CFTR +/ and CFTR +/+ mice presenting 6  plus or minus  2.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	134	1% apoptosis, respectively (Fig.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	135	 To determine whether the low levels of spontaneous apoptosis seen within the crypts masks a difference in susceptibility to apoptosis, intestinal apoptosis was induced with whole body cesium gamma irradiation.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Irradiation significantly increased apoptosis in all genotypes (P  <  0.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	137	001) but did not uncover any differences in susceptibility to apoptosis between genotypes (Fig.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Epithelial cells at the villus tips do not show nuclear fragmentation and condensation and, additionally, detection of apoptosis in the gastrointestinal tract by TUNEL is highly variable (19).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Therefore, apoptosis at the villus tips could not be examined in this study.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	140	View larger version (21K):    Fig.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	141	   Irradiation induced crypt cell apoptosis in CFTR mice.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	142	 CFTR mice were subjected to whole body cesium gamma irradiation and killed 3 h after irradiation.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Apoptosis was evaluated in the first 10 cells following the Paneth cells in 50 crypts of Lieberkuhn per animal.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	144	 of animals per group is noted above each bar.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Values are means  plus or minus  SD.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Gamma irradiation (100 rad) induced 10-fold increases in apoptosis within the epithelial cells in the crypts of Lieberkuhn in CFTR /, CFTR +/, and CFTR +/+ mice (P  <  0.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	147	 There were no genotypic differences in susceptibility to apoptosis.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	148	To determine whether the difference in epithelial cell migration is the result of differences in crypt cell proliferation, epithelial cells within the crypts of Lieberkuhn were evaluated for expression of PCNA.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	149	 A significantly greater percentage of epithelial cells from CFTR / mice (49.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	150	6%) express PCNA than those from animals expressing at least one copy of the functional gene (CFTR +/, 36.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	151	View larger version (11K):    Fig.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	152	   Intestinal epithelial cell proliferation in CFTR mice.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) was detected by immunohistochemistry in the first 10 cells following the Paneth cells in 25 crypts of Lieberkuhn in 7 CFTR / mice and 5 CFTR +/ mice.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	154	 The %PCNA-positive cells per crypt revealed significantly more proliferative capacity in the crypts of Lieberkuhn of CFTR / mice (49.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	155	 *Significant difference (P = 0.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	156	The results of the animal studies contradict the previous cell culture findings presented by Gottlieb and Dosanjh (9), in which cells expressing the mutated CFTR were more resistant to apoptosis than cells expressing the wild-type CFTR.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Therefore experiments were designed to determine whether the cell culture results were misleading.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	158	Mouse mammary epithelial cells expressing a mutated CFTR (C127 F508) are more resistant to death induced by 1,000 or 2,000 J/m2 UV irradiation than cells expressing the wild-type CFTR (Fig.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	159	 With UV irradiation doses at or above 4,000 J/m2, a similar percentage of cell death was seen in both cell types.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	160	 This is consistent with the previous findings (9) that C127 F508 cells are more resistant than C127 wild-type cells to induction of apoptosis by etoposide and cycloheximide.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	161	View larger version (20K):    Fig.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	162	   Dose-response curve for ultraviolet (UV)-induced cell death in C127 cells expressing the wild-type CFTR (C127 wt) and C127 F508 cells.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	163	 C127 cells UV irradiated at doses of 0-8,000 J/m2 were evaluated for cell death 16 h after irradiation by uptake of the DNA binding fluorochrome YOPRO-1.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Only cells with an unstable plasma membrane will take up YOPRO-1; therefore, the ratio of fluorescence emissions before and after cell lysis allows for the determination of %cell death.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	165	 C127 wt are more susceptible to UV irradiation-induced death than are cells expressing the F508-mutated CFTR.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	166	001) produces significant genotypic differences in death.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Irradiation with doses at or above 4,000 J/m2 results in similar %cell death in the two cell lines.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Values are means  plus or minus  SD of 2-6 experiments/dose with a minimum of triplicates for each dose in each experiment.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	169	To determine whether the difference in susceptibility to UV irradiation seen in the C127 cell lines is a result of differences in expression of a functional CFTR, C127 F508 cells were infected by an adenovirus expressing the wild-type CFTR before induction of apoptosis.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Although cells overexpressing the mutant CFTR may have a low level of CFTR activity (2), expression of the wild-type CFTR in the C127 F508 cells did not increase the susceptibility of these cells to death relative to cells infected with the -galactosidase adenovirus or uninfected cells (Fig.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	171	 These data suggest that expression of the functional CFTR does not make C127 cells more susceptible to apoptosis than cells expressing a mutated CFTR.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Instead, the data suggest that the observed difference in apoptosis is unrelated to the CFTR but instead may have been a property acquired during the clonal selection process.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	173	View larger version (32K):    Fig.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	174	   Dose effect of UV irradiation on cell death in adenovirus-infected C127 F508 cells.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	175	 C127 F508 cells were infected with an adenovirus construct containing the wild-type CFTR (wt CFTR) or the -galactosidase gene (b-gal) or were uninfected.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	176	 After 48 h of infection, apoptosis was induced by 2,000 J/m2 UV irradiation.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Sixteen hours after irradiation, cells were evaluated for cell death by uptake of YOPRO-1.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Expression of the wild-type CFTR did not alter susceptibility to death by UV irradiation relative to the uninfected control cells.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	179	 -galactosidase expression made the cells more sensitive to UV irradiation.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	180	 The data reflect 2 experiments performed in quadruplicate with the range of data reflected by the error bars.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	181	To further assess whether the original data were misleading, a second set of cell lines was tested to determine susceptibility to apoptosis based on expression of a functional or mutated CFTR.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	182	 In the CFT1 cell lines, at 16 h after UV irradiation, cell death increased in a dose-dependent manner to a similar extent across cell lines (Fig.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Similar data were obtained 6 h after UV irradiation using nuclear condensation and fragmentation as markers of apoptosis (Fig.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	184	 In addition, UV irradiation of CFT1 cell lines resulted in a similar time course of DNA degradation (data not shown) with DNA laddering present at 3 h after UV irradiation in all four cell lines.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Furthermore, cleavage of caspase 3 (PharMingen, La Jolla, CA) and caspase 9 (New England Biolabs, Beverly, MA) after UV irradiation was not different across cell lines (data not shown).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Thus the current data from the C127 and CFT1 cell lines suggest that the CFTR does not play a role in apoptosis.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	187	View larger version (36K):    Fig.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	188	   Dose-response curve for UV-induced cell death in CFT1 cell lines.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	189	 CFT1 cells were UV irradiated at doses of 0-8,000 J/m2 and evaluated for cell death as described in the Fig.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	190	 No differences were seen across cell lines.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Cells expressing the wild-type CFTR (LCFSN) were equally susceptible to death by UV irradiation as were cells from the parental cell line (C2), cells expressing additional copies of the F508 mutation (dF508), or cells expressing the -galactosidase vector control (LC3).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	192	 The data reflect 2 experiments performed in quadruplicate with error bars reflecting the range of the data.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	193	View larger version (30K):    Fig.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	194	   Effect of UV irradiation on nuclear condensation and fragmentation in CFT1 cells.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	195	 CFT1 cells were UV irradiated at 0 and 2,000 J/m2, fixed after 6 h, and evaluated for nuclear condensation and fragmentation by fluorescence microscopy after staining the nuclei with 30  microM Hoechst no.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	196	 A: examples of typical nuclear condensation and fragmentation for each cell line.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	197	 B: means  plus or minus  SD of %apoptosis seen in 3 separate experiments in which a minimum of 300 cells was counted per cell type per experiment.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	198	 The amount of apoptosis seen for each cell line was similar and independent of the expression of the wild-type or mutated CFTR.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	199	    DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	200	Many CF patients and all mouse models of CF have a common pathology in their susceptibility to gastrointestinal obstruction.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	201	 In the normal intestine, epithelial cells line the villi of the absorptive surfaces.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	202	 These cells are continuously regenerated by proliferation in the crypts of Lieberkuhn, differentiation, and migration up the villi.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	203	 At the tips of the villi, the cells undergo apoptosis and are shed into the lumen (11, 24).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	204	 (18) have shown that both proliferation and apoptosis occur in the stem cells within the crypts and that apoptosis within the crypts is likely to be an important part of the homeostatic process for tissue maintenance.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Under normal conditions, stem cell proliferation and epithelial sloughing are in equilibrium.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	206	 As we have shown in the current study, epithelial cells in CFTR / mice migrate up the crypt-villus axis at a greater rate than in animals expressing a functional CFTR.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	207	 The epithelial cells from CFTR / mice migrated 27% farther in 48 h than those from the CFTR +/ mice.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	208	 This difference in rate is due to differences in proliferation and not apoptosis within the crypts of Lieberkuhn with ~12% more cells with proliferative capacity in the CFTR / mice than the CFTR +/ mice.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Because villus length is not different between the genotypes (data not shown), the increased number of cells proliferating within the crypt and migrating up the villi would lead to an increase in the mass of cells that are sloughed into the gastrointestinal tract.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	210	The increased proliferative capacity within the CFTR-null mice may be attributed to a cellular defect within the cells as a result of a nonfunctional CFTR, although the mechanism by which this might happen is unknown.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Potentially, differences in intracellular pH might account for the enhanced proliferation in CFTR / cells.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Cytosolic pH is thought to be one of the factors that control the rate of proliferation (8) with cytoplasmic alkalinization constituting a signal for mitogenesis (1, 22, 27).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	213	 In addition, cells with higher intracellular pH are more likely to be in the S, G2, or M phases of the cell cycle, whereas cells with lower pH are more likely to be in G1 (19).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Cells expressing a mutated CFTR have been reported (5, 6) to have an elevated cytosolic pH, and overexpression of the wild-type CFTR but not a mutant CFTR results in growth arrest (23).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Thus a mutation in the CFTR may result in an elevated intracellular pH, which stimulates the cell to undergo proliferation more readily and thus increase the rate at which epithelial cells of the crypts of Lieberkuhn proliferate and migrate up the intestinal villi.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	216	All the mouse models of CF show evidence of inflammation and intestinal obstructions (10); thus the possibility that the stimulus to enhanced proliferation within the intestine of the CFTR / mice might be due to differences in inflammation cannot be ruled out.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Proliferation in nasal polyps (12, 16) and epithelium of bronchial airways (15) has been shown to be increased in CF patients and has been attributed to airway inflammation.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Chronic inflammation has been shown to be present in the CF intestine with increased luminal content of immune cell constituents, secretory immunoglobulins, and cytokines (25).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Therefore, inflammation within the gastrointestinal tract potentially can be a stimulus to enhanced proliferation.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	220	Initial studies by Gottlieb and Dosanjh (9) showed decreased susceptibility to apoptosis in cells expressing the mutated CFTR relative to cells expressing the wild-type CFTR.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	221	 In this initial study, cycloheximide and etoposide were used to induce apoptosis.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	222	 The CFTR is an anion channel that when mutated does not allow for chloride to be transported across the plasma membrane.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Because this is a transport problem, one concern with the use of any drug or chemical to induce apoptosis is a difference in the ability of the cells to transport the drug or chemical across the cell membrane.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	224	 To avoid this potential problem in the current studies, UV irradiation was utilized as the apoptotic stimulus.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Cells expressing the mutated CFTR were more resistant to apoptosis induced by UV irradiation than cells expressing the wild-type CFTR, which is in accordance with the findings of Gottlieb and Dosanjh (9).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	226	 However, one control that was lacking from the original set of experiments was the introduction of the wild-type CFTR into these resistant cell lines to restore susceptibility to apoptosis.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	227	 In the current study, infection of C127 F08 cells with an adenovirus expressing the wild-type CFTR failed to restore susceptibility to apoptosis.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	228	 -galactosidase adenovirus-infected cells were found to be more susceptible to death than both the uninfected and infected CFTR cells.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	229	 The reason behind this increased propensity toward death is not known.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	230	 The -galactosidase construct used in these experiments was the nuclear-targeted protein, which, because of its location of expression, may make the cells more susceptible to the DNA-damaging effect of UV irradiation.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	231	 To confirm the findings from the C127 cells, an independent set of cell lines was used to determine whether expression of a mutated or wild-type CFTR results in differences in susceptibility to apoptosis.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Cells with a mutated CFTR were found to be no different in their sensitivity to UV irradiation than cells expressing the wild-type CFTR when evaluated for membrane destabilization detected by the uptake of YOPRO-1, nuclear condensation and fragmentation, DNA degradation, or caspase cleavage.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Thus taken together the data suggest that the CFTR does not play a role in a cell's susceptibility to apoptosis.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	234	In the CFTR-null mice, epithelial cell kinetics within the gastrointestinal tract differ from mice expressing at least one copy of the functional CFTR.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	235	 The altered proliferation within the crypts of Lieberkuhn is not accompanied by changes in apoptosis but results in an increased rate of cell migration up the villus.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	236	 The increased number of cells reaching the intestinal lumen might contribute to the viscosity of the luminal contents and increase the likelihood of intestinal blockage, one of the pathophysiological hallmarks of CF.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	237	 If epithelial cell proliferation and turnover is increased in parallel in the CF lung and pancreas, this might contribute to the viscosity of the bronchial and pancreatic secretions and exacerbate the symptoms of CF.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	238	This research was supported by a postdoctoral fellowship from the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation (A.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Gallagher), a grant from the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation (R.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Gottlieb), and an award from the Pew Foundation Scholars Program in Biomedical Sciences (R.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	241	Address for reprint requests and other correspondence: R.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Gottlieb, The Scripps Research Institute, 10550 N.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	243	, MEM220, La Jolla, CA 92037 (E-mail: robbieg{at}scripps.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	244	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	245	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.

0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	317	 Nature 353: 434-437, 1991[ISI][Medline].
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	318	   Vicentini, LM, and Villereal ML.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	319	 Inositol phosphates turnover, cytosolic Ca2+ and pH: putative signals for the control of cell growth.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	320	 Life Sci 38: 2269-2276, 1986[ISI][Medline].
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	321	Am J Physiol Gastrointest Liver Physiol 281(3):G681-G687 0193-1857/01 $5.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	322	00 Copyright   2001 the American Physiological Society.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	0	THEMES Genetic Disorders of Membrane TransportII.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Regulation of CFTR by small molecules including HCO3* Beate Illek1,2, Horst Fischer1, and Terry E.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	2	1 Children's Hospital Oakland Research Institute, Oakland 94609; and 2 Department of Molecular and Cell Biology, University of California, Berkeley, California 94720.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	3	    ABSTRACT Top Abstract Introduction References.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	4	Cystic fibrosis (CF) affects a number of epithelial tissues, including those in the gastrointestinal tract.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	5	 The goal of this review is to summarize data related to regulation of the protein product of the CF gene, CF transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR), by a variety of small molecules.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	6	 There has been a surge of interest in discovering small molecules that could be exogenously added to cells and tissues to regulate CFTR and could potentially be used alone or in combination with genetic approaches for therapy in CF.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	7	 We will discuss the apparent mechanisms of action of genistein, milrinone, 8-cyclopentyl-1,3-dipropylxanthine, IBMX, and NS-004; several of which appear to interact directly with one or both nucleotide binding domains of CFTR.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	8	 We also discuss how HCO3 interacts with CFTR as both a permeating anion and a potential regulator of Cl permeation through the CFTR ion channel.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	9	 It is likely that there are complicated interactions between Cl and HCO3 in the secretion of both ions through the CFTR and the anion exchanger in intestinal cells, and these may yield a role of CFTR in regulation of intestinal HCO3 secretion as well as of intra- and extracellular pH.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	10	cystic fibrosis; cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator; pharmacology; epithelial transport; chloride secretion.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	11	    INTRODUCTION Top Abstract Introduction References.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	12	CYSTIC FIBROSIS (CF) is the most common fatal genetic disease of the Caucasian population, with an incidence of 1 in 2,500 live births and a carrier frequency of ~1 in 25.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	13	 The disease is caused by mutations in the CF transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) (30), which functions as a cAMP-activated Cl channel.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	14	 At the cellular level, CFTR dysfunction results in defective cAMP-regulated Cl conductance, primarily in cells of epithelial origin (27).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Although lung disease is the primary cause of mortality in CF patients, a significant proportion of the morbidity can be directly attributed to gastrointestinal complications.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The duodenum, jejunum, ileum, and colon express high levels of CFTR mRNA (30).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Immunocytochemical analysis also demonstrated high CFTR protein expression at the luminal surfaces along the intestine (7).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The small intestine of CF patients exhibits decreased Cl and fluid secretion that results in meconium ileus (lower water content and higher viscosity compared with non-CF patients) in ~10% of all CF newborns and accumulation of mucus and intestinal obstructions [primarily in ileocecum and large intestine in  > 20% of adult patients (see Ref.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Intestinal pathophysiology appears to be the hallmark of recently developed transgenic CF mouse models.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	20	 The ileocecum and large intestine appear to be the most common sites of intestinal blockade, whereas jejunal obstructions occur less frequently (13).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	21	Thus CFTR plays an important role in intestinal secretion.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	22	 This secretion is controlled by multiple hormones and nerve cell transmitters, which will couple to the activation of CFTR as well as the other ion channels and transporters that are required to generate transepithelial secretion.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Phosphorylation of CFTR by protein kinases (PK) and dephosphorylation by protein phosphatases (PP) is considered the major way by which CFTR Cl channel activity is physiologically regulated.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	24	 In addition, the normal gating cycle (both opening and closing) of CFTR requires ATP binding and hydrolysis at the two nucleotide binding domains (NBDs) of CFTR (see Ref.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	25	 ATP concentration is likely maintained constant in cells and is therefore not a significant physiological regulator.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	26	In addition to phosphorylation/dephosphorylation and ATP binding and hydrolysis, investigators have searched for exogenous compounds that are potential therapeutic activators of the mutant CFTR protein found in CF patients.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Figure 1 shows the chemical structures of several such small molecules that will be discussed in this review.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Some of these small molecules appear to bind directly to one or both of the NBDs of CFTR and, if CFTR has been prephosphorylated, increase the open probability of the channel.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	29	 In the first portion of this review, PHARMACOLOGICAL REGULATION OF CFTR BY SMALL MOLECULES, we will discuss work showing that genistein, 8-cyclopentyl-1,3-dipropylxanthine (DPCPX), IBMX and other xanthines, and NS-004 all seem to operate this way.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	30	 In addition, we will discuss the phosphodiesterase (PDE) inhibitor milrinone, which also stimulates CFTR but through a mechanism that is less well characterized.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	31	View larger version (14K):    Fig.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	32	   Chemical structures of compounds discussed in text.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	33	 DPCPX, 8-cyclopentyl-1,3-dipropylxanthine.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	34	In the second portion of this review, HCO3 PERMEATION AND POSSIBLE REGULATION OF CFTR-MEDIATED CL CURRENTS, we will discuss the question of HCO3 permeation and potential regulation of CFTR.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	35	 This has been a controversial area of research.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Most secretory epithelia secrete both Cl and HCO3, and CFTR seems to be involved in a critical way that is still poorly understood.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	37	 We will discuss data relevant to the question of whether the key role of CFTR is to conduct HCO3 itself or to play some sort of permissive role in HCO3 secretion through an adjacent anion exchanger that requires Cl at the cell's luminal aspect to exchange for cellular HCO3.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Alternatively, CFTR could also be required to keep cellular Cl concentration low enough that Cl enters the cell on the exchanger and exchanges for cellular HCO3.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	39	 We will also discuss the possibility that HCO3 may regulate the activity of CFTR by altering the permeation of Cl due to the multi-ion pore behavior of CFTR.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	40	    PHARMACOLOGICAL REGULATION OF CFTR BY SMALL MOLECULES.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Genistein is a member of the large class of naturally occurring flavonoids.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Some flavonoids are more potent than genistein in activating CFTR (19), but we will focus on genistein because it has been investigated the most thoroughly.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Genistein is a potent activator of CFTR (e.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	44	 20, 22), but the activating mechanism has been debated.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Genistein did not seem to operate through activation of protein kinase A (PKA), PKC, or PKG, because there were no increases in intracellular cAMP, Ca2+, or cGMP concentrations (21, 32).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Genistein is a well-known tyrosine kinase (PTK) inhibitor, and two other PTK inhibitors (tyrphostin 47 and tyrphostin B42) also stimulated CFTR, and genistein-stimulated channel activity was blocked by the tyrosine phosphatase inhibitor vanadate (21, 32).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	47	 However, several other PTK inhibitors (tyrphostin A23, tyrphostin A51, erbstatin analog, and herbimycin) failed to stimulate CFTR (20).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Genistein also stimulated CFTR equally well when GTP (a poor substrate for tyrosine kinases) was used as a replacement for ATP (10).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Some results suggested that genistein activated CFTR by blocking a PP: inactivation rates of CFTR currents on cAMP removal were markedly decreased by genistein (20), and CFTR was phosphorylated on the same amino acids by both genistein (which did not raise cAMP concentration) and forskolin (which did) (29).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	50	More recent data have indicated that the most likely explanation for the stimulatory effect of genistein was through direct binding to an NBD of phosphorylated CFTR.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Genistein did not directly open CFTR channels, because genistein did not stimulate CFTR in ATP- or cAMP-depleted monolayers (22).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Similarly, genistein activation of CFTR in excised patches required both ATP and prior phosphorylation by PKA (10).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	53	 In addition, genistein stimulated phosphatase-resistant, thiophosphorylated CFTR, even in the presence of PKI (to block PKA) or VO4 (to block PP) (10, 39).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Kinetic analysis indicated that a genistein concentration of  < 35  microM induced prolonged openings of CFTR (similar to the effect of a nonhydrolyzable ATP analog), whereas a genistein concentration of  > 35  microM caused prolonged closed times (38).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	55	An attractive model for stimulatory and inhibitory effects of genistein on CFTR is that of Gadsby et al.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	56	 This model (11) proposes that ATP binding and hydrolysis at NBD1 control channel opening and closing at low phosphorylation levels, and once ATP hydrolysis at NBD1 has opened a highly phosphorylated CFTR channel, ATP binding to NBD2 can stabilize the open state.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Hydrolysis of the nucleotide at NBD2 terminates the stabilization.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Agents that interfere with ATP hydrolysis at NBD2 [e.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	59	, 5'-adenylylimidodiphosphate (AMP-PNP) or pyrophosphate] induce prolonged burst opening.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Genistein is a competitive inhibitor with ATP for binding to PTK (inhibitor constant, 13.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	61	7  microM) and to other ATP-binding proteins, and crystal structure analysis of the Src family tyrosine kinase Hck revealed that the structurally related flavone and CFTR activator quercetin (19) localized to the binding site for the adenine ring of AMP-PNP or ATP (34).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	62	 When considering the sequence homology shared by Walker A-type-binding motifs of PTK and NBDs of CFTR, it therefore seems possible that genistein competes for ATP-binding sites on CFTR, possibly at NBD2 (10), thereby slowing down ATP hydrolysis and preventing CFTR channel closure.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	63	 It is unlikely that genistein activates CFTR by binding to a Src kinase, because this would require activation of a tyrosine kinase and genistein blocks tyrosine kinases.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	64	 It might also be proposed that higher concentrations of genistein inhibit CFTR by competing with ATP at NBD1 (which may have a lower affinity for genistein binding) and prevent CFTR from opening.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	65	 The substituted benzimidazolone NS-004 has effects that are quite similar to those exhibited by genistein.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	66	1 to 1  microM) and F508-CFTR (at  > 10  microM) without raising cAMP concentration and also in the presence of a PKA inhibitor (12), but it was necessary to pretreat cells with forskolin before patch excision to observe CFTR channel activation by NS-004.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	67	 In addition, the drug caused active CFTR channels to increase their activity, but it had no effect when added after channel rundown, indicating that NS-004 required phosphorylated CFTR.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	68	 NS-004 did not inhibit in vitro PP activity.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Thus, although NS-004 was thought to operate by directly opening CFTR (12), the drug may use a mechanism similar to that of genistein to increase open probabilities of phosphorylated, active channels without affecting either PK or PP.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	70	 The cardiotonic drug milrinone is an inhibitor of cGMP-inhibited PDE (a class III PDE) and was selected from several drugs inhibiting PDE isozymes (23).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Because PDE inhibitors raise cellular cAMP concentration and CFTR is activated by increases in cAMP concentration, it has been assumed that milrinone (and also IBMX, see below) stimulate CFTR by raising cAMP.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	72	 However, the exact mechanisms have not been determined.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Milrinone activated both normal and F508-CFTR in transformed nasal epithelial cells (24), and a combination of forskolin and milrinone (but not milrinone alone) increased the potential difference across nasal epithelium of F508-CFTR mice in vivo but not in transgenic mice lacking CFTR (24).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Milrinone activated CFTR even when cells had been maximally stimulated with forskolin or some other cAMP agonist, indicating that the drug likely had other effects than to stimulate production of cAMP.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	75	IBMX, DPCPX, and other xanthine derivatives.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	76	 IBMX is an inhibitor of PDE with broad specificity.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Despite its broad use as a PDE inhibitor, it seems unlikely that IBMX works solely via this mechanism.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	78	 IBMX activated CFTR even when cells had been maximally stimulated with forskolin or some other cAMP agonist (23).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Although other substituted xanthine derivatives activated CFTR, there was no correlation between effects on CFTR and cellular cAMP and ATP concentrations (4).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	80	 We have also found, through use of a fluorescence assay for PKA activity (as opposed to measurements of cAMP concentration using RIA), that forskolin caused fibroblasts to raise cAMP concentration to such a high level that PKA activity was saturated (by maximally binding cAMP), and IBMX (which indeed raised cAMP concentration) had no further effect to increase PKA activity (B.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Machen, unpublished observations).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	82	 It therefore seems likely that the stimulatory effects of IBMX on CFTR are due to combined effects to raise cAMP (when PKA has not been saturated) and also to block PP or directly bind to CFTR.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	83	The xanthine derivative DPCPX is an adenosine A1 antagonist that may have some selectivity for F508-CFTR compared with effects on wild-type CFTR.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	84	 DPCPX stimulates F508-CFTR channels in a variety of epithelial and fibroblast cells (8, 15).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	85	 In some cells, correction of the CF defect by transfection with the CFTR gene rendered the transfected cells insensitive to DPCPX.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	86	 In contrast, DPCPX stimulated recombinant CFTR channels from HEK cell microsomal membranes incorporated into planar lipid layers (2).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	87	 The effects of DPCPX seemed not to be due to an effect on A1 receptors, because Northern analysis showed that a DPCPX-sensitive cell line (CFPAC-1) had no A1 receptor mRNA, and another xanthine analog 1,3-diallyl-8-cyclohexylxanthine (DAX) was a potent CFTR activator but a poor A1 adenosine receptor antagonist.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Using a rapid membrane filtration assay, Cohen et al.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	89	 (6) reported that DPCPX bound to NBD1 of F508-CFTR [dissociation constant (Kd) = 1.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	90	0 nM] with an affinity 17 times higher than that to NBD1 of wild-type CFTR (Kd = 17.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	91	0 nM) with a rank order among different xanthines of DAX  >  DPCPX  >  caffeine  >  DA-DPCPX  >  adenosine  >  >  IBMX  >  2-thio-DPCPX.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	92	 These results were consistent with a unique binding site for DPCPX and related xanthines on NBD1 of CFTR in the vicinity of F508 (2).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	93	 DPCPX was ~25-fold more potent than IBMX in potentiating F508-CFTR by a mechanism other than elevation of intracellular cAMP concentration (15).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Stimulation of CFTR by DPCPX or DAX required prephosphorylated CFTR (2).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Thus DPCPX (and likely all the other xanthines, including IBMX), genistein, and NS-004 all seemed to activate prephosphorylated CFTR by binding directly to CFTR.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	96	 DPCPX appeared to bind to NBD1 rather than to NBD2, and it also seemed to be more selective for F508-CFTR than wild-type CFTR.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	97	Pharmacological stimulation of mutant CFTR and therapeutic potential.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	98	 The most common mutation in CF, F508-CFTR, leads to a trafficking-impaired protein that gets degraded in the cell (40).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Some mutations lead to trafficking-competent, but misfunctional, proteins (e.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	100	 It appears that mutants with different misfunctions will need selective treatments.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	101	 For example, genistein failed to activate F508-CFTR in CF bronchial epithelial cells (22), but addition of genistein and cAMP agonists to NIH/3T3 cells overexpressing F508-CFTR caused a strong, synergistic activation (18).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Alternatively, when CF nasal epithelial cells were treated with 4-phenylbutyrate or low temperature to increase expression of F508-CFTR in the membrane (31, 40), genistein was a potent stimulant (9).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	103	 In addition, the trafficking-competent G551D-CFTR mutant expressed in fibroblasts was stimulated by the combination of genistein and forskolin when forskolin alone was ineffective (9).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	104	 These data indicate that genistein targets CFTR mutants present in the plasma membrane.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Both NS-004 and, especially, DPCPX have also been shown to activate F508-CFTR.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	106	 IBMX produced a small, CFTR-related secretory response in jejunum, cecum, and rectum from G551D mice but had no effect in the nasal epithelium (36).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	107	 NS-004 restored near normal channel activity from P574H-CFTR (a mild, trafficking-impaired mutation in NBD1) (3).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	108	 These results suggest that, in addition to their direct effects on CFTR, these drugs may also have other effects that increase the number of channel proteins found in the membrane.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	109	 It is also important to remember that there may be tissue-specific effects of the drugs, because epithelial cells will require concomitant activity of basolateral K+ channels to secrete fluid efficiently.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	110	    HCO3 PERMEATION AND POSSIBLE REGULATION OF CFTR-MEDIATED CL CURRENTS.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	111	Background: Role of CFTR in HCO3 secretion across intestine.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	112	 HCO3 secretion is a key function that occurs in the stomach, pancreas, and small and large intestine.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	113	 HCO3 secretion is particularly important in the duodenum to protect the intestinal mucosa against damage from large amounts of acid from the stomach (1).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Transepithelial secretion of HCO3 likely involves the concerted activities of an apical anion channel, Cl/HCO3 exchange, HCO3 uptake across the basolateral membrane, and/or production of HCO3 by intracellular carbonic anhydrase activity.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	115	 The paracellular pathway may also contribute, since a transepithelial gradient for HCO3 favoring secretion occurs.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Electrogenic HCO3 secretion is activated by secretagogues that increase intracellular cAMP, cGMP, or Ca2+ concentrations (1), and this HCO3 secretion required the presence of CFTR in all segments of the small intestine in mice (16, 17, 33).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	117	 However, the specific mechanism(s) involved remains a mystery.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	118	 With the use of the pH stat method in combination with inhibitors of anion exchange and CFTR, recent work (5) with duodenum from normal and CFTR knockout mice shows that CFTR may have contributed to HCO3 secretion in two ways: directly by conducting HCO3 into the lumen and also indirectly by conducting Cl into the lumen, which could be recycled back into the cell via anion exchange for HCO3.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Because CFTR is expressed at highest levels in the crypts (7), electrogenic HCO3 secretion is predicted to occur primarily in this region.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	120	 In contrast, CFTR is expressed at lower levels and carbonic anhydrase activity is expressed at higher levels in the villus epithelium, so CFTR-coupled Cl/HCO3 exchange activity may be primarily localized to the villus.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	121	Does CFTR conduct HCO3? Patch-clamp studies showed that HCO3 was conducted through CFTR in NIH/3T3 cells recombinantly expressing wild-type CFTR (26), with a permeability ratio of Cl to HCO3 of 0.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Similar measurements have also been presented recently by Linsdell et al.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	123	 (25), who found a permeability ratio of Cl to HCO3 of 0.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	124	 We also measured CFTR-mediated permeation of HCO3 across the apical membrane of Calu-3 monolayers, and conductance ratios of cAMP-stimulated HCO3 and Cl currents of 0.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Thus HCO3-to-Cl permeability or conductance ratios of CFTR ranged from 0.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	126	 A role of CFTR's function as a HCO3 conductor has also been suggested in CF models using a variety of methods comparing wild-type CFTR-expressing cells with F508-CFTR-expressing CF cells (22, 35) or wild-type with CFTR knockout mice (CFTR /) (5, 13, 17, 33).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	127	 These reports suggested the possibility that a defect in HCO3 secretion through CFTR may contribute to the pathophysiology of CF pulmonary disease (22, 35).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	128	 In contrast to these experiments that showed that CFTR conducts HCO3, Quinton and Reddy (28) (P.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Quinton, personal communication) showed using microelectrode methods that in intact sweat ducts HCO3 was equally impermeant through CFTR as gluconate.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	130	 This contradiction remains unresolved.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	131	Does CFTR contribute to cytosolic and/or extracellular pH regulation? If CFTR is permeant to HCO3, it is expected that it should contribute to movements of HCO3 into and out of the cell and thereby alter pH of the cell or extracellular fluids.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	132	 In NIH/3T3 cells expressing exogenous CFTR, we showed forskolin-stimulated changes of pH that were absent in cells expressing F508-CFTR (26).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Data have also been presented for biliary epithelial cells showing that CFTR may regulate the activity of the anion exchanger and alter cytosolic pH regulatory ability in these cells (14) In contrast, we have recently compared cytosolic pH regulation in CF and CFTR-corrected nasal cells and found no apparent differences (L.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	134	 A possible explanation was that these cells expressed Na+/H+ and Cl/HCO3 exchange and Na+-HCO3 cotransport, and these mechanisms were much more prominent than CFTR in regulating cytosolic pH.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Thus, in cells that express prominent activity of transporters that regulate cytosolic pH, the conductive pathway for HCO3 across CFTR might be of minor importance for cytosolic pH regulation.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	136	 However, CFTR might still contribute importantly to the accumulation of HCO3 in the poorly buffered apical/luminal fluid.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	137	Do anions regulate Cl permeation through CFTR? It has been well described that thiocyanate (SCN) is highly permeant across CFTR, but when mixtures of Cl and SCN are used, the conductance of CFTR decreases (37).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	138	 This effect has been interpreted in terms of multi-ion pore behavior of CFTR, i.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	139	, interactions of anions within the pore can lead to anomalous effects.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Also, the halide anion I both permeated and blocked CFTR.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	141	 We have similarly shown that both F and HCO3 added to the apical surface reduced Cl conductance of CFTR in Calu-3 cells (Illek and Machen, unpublished observations).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	142	 In vivo both Cl and HCO3 are present in the cytosol at similar concentrations, and both are driven by the membrane potential into the pore of CFTR, suggesting that both ions may compete for common binding sites in the permeation path, and thus affect the permeation of each other.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	143	 This could be particularly important for tissues that secrete large amounts of HCO3.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	144	Summary: Role of CFTR in HCO3 secretion.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	145	 The exact role of CFTR in HCO3 permeation under physiological conditions likely depends on the relative expression of CFTR and other HCO3 channels, HCO3 transporters and paracellular permeability of HCO3.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	146	 In addition, the cell-to-lumen electrochemical driving forces for Cl and HCO3 will determine ion movements across the luminal cell membrane and tight junctions.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	147	 CFTR appears to be important both as a HCO3 conductance and also in some way as a direct or indirect regulator of adjacent anion exchange, e.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	148	, as a source of luminal Cl that may exchange for cellular HCO3 and/or as a means of keeping cellular Cl concentration low enough that the anion exchanger operates as an HCO3 secretion mechanism.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Many CFTR-expressing epithelia, including the intestine, pancreas, and liver, exhibit different gradients of Cl and HCO3 along the length of the organ, so these relationships will also be affected by the anatomic structures.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	150	We apologize to those whose work we were unable to quote due to space limitations.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	151	* Second in a series of invited articles on Genetic Disorders of Membrane Transport.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	152	Study in our laboratories has been supported by grants from the National Institutes of Health (R01-DK-51799), Cystic Fibrosis Research, Inc.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	153	, the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation (Grant ILLEK96F0), and the Commercial Endowment of Children's Hospital Oakland.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	154	Address for reprint requests: T.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	155	 of Molecular and Cell Biology, Univ.
